DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 1, 2010, or the 24th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1868: Mongkut, king of Siam, dies at the age of 64. In only 17 years he implemented sweeping political, economic and social changes with help from the West.
1916: Peking University Professor Hu Shih's proposal that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style wins quick acceptance.
1918: T.E. Lawrence, the British officer known as "Lawrence of Arabia, " and the Arab forces of Emir Faisal capture Damascus from the Turks.
1920: The Peking government cracks down on Russian settlements in China.
1921: The Chinese Communist Party sets up a branch in Hunan Province with Mao Tse-tung as its secretary.
1924: Jimmy Carter, an American peanut farmer who became the 39th president of the United States, is born. He was instrumental in getting Israel and Egypt to sign the Camp David agreement ending hostilities between the two countries.
1936: Gen. Francisco Franco Bahamonde, 44, is proclaimed "Chief of the Spanish State" by the nationalist military junta trying to seize power in Spain.
1946: The International War Crimes Tribunal in Nuremberg sentences 12 Nazi leaders to death.
1947: The Japanese Ministry of Education abrogates the name of Kyoto Imperial University.
1949: The Chinese communists set up a regime in Beijing with Mao Tse-tung as party chairman. The regime was recognized by the Soviet Union the next day.
1956: The ROC government implements regulations governing distribution of land to retired servicemen.
1958: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, a U.S. government agency that conducts and coordinates research on flight within and beyond the earth's atmosphere, is formally set up as an independent agency headquartered in Washington, D.C.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Nigeria.
1964: Japan's "bullet train" makes its first journey from Tokyo to Osaka.
1965: A coup attempt by Indonesian communists is crushed by Suharto, an army officer who becomes president of Indonesia two years later.
1969: The sound barrier is broken by the Concorde 001 during a test flight in France.
1972: Louis Leakey, British archaeologist and anthropologist, dies in London at the age of 69. He discovered the 1,750,000-year-old Zinjanthropus fossil at Olduvai Gorge and the contemporaneous "Homo habilis" at Lake Natron in Tanzania between 1959 and 1964.
1974: The annual three-day meeting of the Sino-U.S. Cooperation Science Program is held in Taipei.
1975: Muhammad Ali beats Joe Frazier in a rematch in Manila. Ali had recaptured the world heavyweight title after defeating the fearsome George Foreman in a sensational upset in 1974. Frazier had beaten Ali in 1971.
1976: Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung leaves for Lesotho to attend a ceremony marking the kingdom's independence.
1982: Helmut Kohl is sworn in as West Germany's sixth chancellor.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of society.
1997: Gul Mohammed, the world's shortest man at 56 centimeters tall, dies. 1999: Taiwan announces the termination of flights to and from the Philippines after negotiators from the two sides failed in last-ditch efforts to address a stormy dispute over passenger quotas.
2000: Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew says he is "less pessimistic" about cross-strait ties than he had been before his recent visit to Taiwan.
2001: A six-day conference of Asian Aborigines sponsored jointly by the Asian Indigenous People's Pact (AIPP) and Taiwan Aborigines concludes in Taitung, eastern Taiwan with a statement supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations Indigenous People's Workshop.
2001: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) approves the opening of electronic commerce insurance services for domestic insurance companies.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Every system of moral law must be based upon man's own consciousness. It must be verified by the common experience of men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Moderate quake rocks Yilan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 08:43:56 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 5.1 on the open-ended Richter scale struck Yilan in northeastern Taiwan Friday with no immediate damage reported, the Central Weather Bureau said.
The earthquake, which occured at 3: 56 a.m., was centered 11.4 kilometers north of the Yilan seismic station at a depth of 102.1 kilometers, seismologists said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan loses to South Korea in Asian U18 basketball semis

TEXT.P: Taiwan missed an opportunity to make history by losing to South Korea 79-68 Thursday in the semifinal of the FIBA Asia U18 Championship for Men in Sanaa, Yemen.

If the team had advanced to the championship game, it would have at least matched its best record -- silver medal finishes in 1972 and 1989 -- in the biennial tournament and could have made a challenge for its first gold in history.

Taiwan was dealt a knockout blow in the decisive third quarter, when the Koreans opened the second half with a 17-2 run, turning a close game into a rout. Taiwan was out-scored 23-10 in the period and trailed by as many as 18 points.

Unable to match Korea's inside play, Taiwan was out-rebounded 39-22. Korea, which was led by Lee Seounghyun's 17 points and 14 rebounds and Lee Jonghyun's 15 points and 10 rebounds, also made 10 more free throws than the Taiwanese.
Center Hu Lung-mao scored a team-high 25 points to go with eight rebounds and six steals for Taiwan, which was leading 35-34 at halftime. Chen Ying-chun and Huang Po-wei had 13 points each.

The team will meet Iran, which lost to China in the other semifinal match, in Friday's bronze medal game. It is still something worth playing for because the top three teams in the tournament will represent Asia in the 2011 FIBA U19 World Championship, which will be played in Latvia June 30-July 10, 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Securities transaction rules for foreign investors relaxed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 11:29:40 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said Thursday that it had relaxed securities transaction regulations for foreign investors and overseas Chinese investors by allowing them to buy stocks in the underwriting phase.

Previously, foreign investors and overseas Chinese investors were allowed only to buy stocks that had been already listed on the main board or the over-the- counter (OTC) market, no matter whether the stocks were sold in primary listings or in the form of Taiwan depository receipts.

"We are in a fast-changing market. The FSC, after taking market reality and public opinion into consideration, has decided to broaden the scope of investments for foreign investors, " said Wu Kuei-mao, chief secretary of the FSC's Securities and Futures Bureau.

Underwriting is the process by which investment bankers known as underwriters raise investment capital from investors on behalf of a company that is issuing securities before a listing on the main board or the OTC market.
Foreign investors and overseas Chinese investors are now permitted to participate in share subscriptions in the underwriting stage, the FSC said.

Lin Tung-liang, chief secretary of the FSC, said the FSC had been planning the rule relaxation for some time and was waiting for an appropriate time to boost the presence of foreign investors in the local capital market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Under-the-table dealings across the strait

TEXT.P: Chen Zhimin, China's vice minister of public security, visited Taiwan Sept. 13-18 for an official visit. The visit, however, was not made public until Sept. 27, and the government has so far not released any details.
Such secret dealings have become a model for interaction between the Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) . This sends a dangerous message to the Taiwanese people.

Under the leadership of President Ma Ying-jeou, cross-Taiwan Strait affairs have often bypassed the democratic monitoring mechanism. Most of the time, consensus or agreements are reached between the KMT and CPC without the people's knowledge. Examples include Taiwan's observer status at the World Health Assembly under the name Chinese Taipei and the signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement.

This clandestine model for cross-strait negotiations is exactly what has been sought after by China, because it enables the KMT and the CPC to determine Taiwan's future by themselves, skipping the Taiwanese people.
The people must see this situation clearly. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 1, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Business group welcomes resumption of U.S.-Taiwan trade talks
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 30 (CNA) 10/01/10 12:04:00 (By Jorge Liu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The U.S.-Taiwan Business Council expressed welcome Thursday to an announcement that Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Demetrios Marantis will lead a U.S. delegation to Taiwan for bilateral trade talks.

"After a three-year freeze over access to Taiwan's beef market, this signifies a welcome resumption in dialogue between America and its 10th-largest trading partner, " the non-profit business group said in a statement.

The statement was released after the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) announced earlier in the day that talks under the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) between the United States and Taiwan will soon be resumed.

It said Marantis will be the most senior official to have visited Taiwan representing the Barack Obama government. His visit "heralds an important first step in re-establishing a robust dialogue on areas of mutual interest," the statement said.

Council President Rupert Hammond-Chambers said the upcoming dialogue will focus on issues regarding pork and rice, and he expressed hope that it will not fall into another dispute like the one that saw a Taiwanese ban on U.S. beef imports.

The statement made clear that the council will support the negotiation and conclusion of agreements between the two sides to address issues on taxation, investment, e-commerce, the liberalization of Taiwan's energy market, and pharmaceuticals.

Since its signing in September 1994, the TIFA has provided an official channel for Taiwan-U.S. dialogue on trade and economic issues. Talks under the agreement were suspended by the U.S. in 2007, however, in retaliation for Taiwan's beef ban.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan donates funds to U.K.-based conservation groups
DOC.DATELINE: London, Sept. 30 (CNA) 10/01/10 12:55:43 (By Jennifer Huang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Forestry Bureau under the Council of Agriculture made a combined donation of US$15,600 to two U.K.-based organizations Thursday to support their international conservation projects.

On behalf of the forestry bureau, Katharine S.Y. Chang, Taiwan's representative to the United Kingdom, presented a donation of US$5,600 to Chris Wright, representative of the Born Free Foundation, to support an East African conservation project in West Kilimanjaro, Tanzania.
Chang praised the foundation's West Kilimanjaro project, which oversees the training of pastoralists to monitor human activity and protect wildlife in the area.
Wright expressed thanks for the donation and said he also hopes to enhance cooperation with Taiwan in promoting environmental protection and sustainable development around the world.

A day earlier, Taipei's Representative Office in the U.K., on behalf of the forestry bureau, also donated US$10,000 to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI) to support its 2010 Global Strategy for Plant Conservation plan.

Sara Oldfield, secretary-general of the BGCI, expressed gratitude for Taiwan's long-term support of global conservation and biological diversity, and said she also hopes to further enhance cooperation with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai to issue US$1 billion in bonds
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 13:05:19 (By Chang Liang-chih and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. Ltd., the world's largest contract electronics product maker, said Friday that it will issue US$1 billion-worth of overseas convertible bonds Oct. 12 to meet funding demand for overseas production material purchases.
Hon Hai said the capital to be raised from the bond sales will also be used to repay debt in an attempt to cut interest payments.

The convertible bonds will have a maturity of three years with a zero coupon rate, the company said, adding that it has set a conversion price of NT$152.75 (US$4.90) for each Hon Hai share for bond-holders who would like to exchange their bonds for company shares.

On July 19, Hon Hai scrapped an earlier bond sales plan as its stock price "failed to reflect the company's value" after the stock got hammered following a string of suicides by workers at its Shenzhen complex in China earlier this year.
Hon Hai said the cancellation of the bond issuance plan was also because the date of issuance approved by the Financial Supervisory Commission had expired.
However, the company resurrected the plan July 24 by revising the terms of the bond sale to the three-year maturity rather than the previous five-year offering.
"I suspect Hon Hai might expand its business through acquisitions or mergers in the near future, for which funds will be necessary, " Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said.
According to Grand Cathay Securities, Hon Hai's short term debt totaled NT$171.4 billion as of the second quarter of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Impact of latest interest rate hikes

TEXT.P: Major Taiwanese banks are expected to raise their interest rates in the coming few days after the Central Bank of the Republic of China (CBC) bumped up its key lending rates by another 0.125 percentage points from Friday.

The hike -- the second so far this year -- brought the CBC's discount rate on loans to commercial banks to 1.5 percent, the interest rate on collateralized loans to 1.875 percent and the rate on unsecured loans to 3.75 percent.

Responding to the CBC's move, local commercial banks are likely to inch up their deposit rates by 0.06 percentage points and lending rates by about 0.125 percentage points to reflect their higher capital costs, banking sources said.

Economists said the latest interest rate hikes indicate that the domestic monetary policy will become more neutral after the CBC had previously kept interest rates low since September 2008 amid the global financial crisis.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Economic Daily News:

The latest interest rate hikes come amid steady domestic economic recovery and rising consumer prices and also reflect the CBC's hopes of gradually bringing relatively low interest rates back to normal levels, CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan said after a quarterly CBC board meeting.

Perng further said the bank will continue to execute selected prudential measures to rein in skyrocketing housing prices and that it will continue jawboning with local mortgage lenders on risk management.
Market analysts said the central bank mainly was targeting real estate speculators when it adopted selected credit tightening measures in June for the first time.
This time around, the analysts said, land developers and construction companies will be the principal targets of selected credit control measures.
Banking sources said the CBC will conduct spot checks once every two weeks on commercial banks' total lending to land developers, particularly those who own many plots of unused or unoccupied land.
Perng said buying large parcels of land but failing to launch any construction projects on them should be defined as "piling up land for profiteering."
If bank loans to land developers continue to spike, banking sources said, the CBC is likely to unveil stricter regulations before the end of the year to better regulate such lending. (Oct. 1, 2010).
China Times:

Senior bankers present at Thursday's CBC board meeting said the central bank has directed commercial banks to require land developers or construction companies to produce construction licenses within six months of securing loans and to stipulate that they must launch construction projects within one year or face the requirement of repaying the mortgage loans.

Citing data released by H&B Realty, Perng said at the CBC board meeting that housing prices have declined 2.88 percent since June, when the CBC adopted credit tightening measures to cushion real estate speculation, including capping each home mortgage in the greater Taipei area at 70 percent of collateral. (Oct. 1, 2010).
Commercial Times:

Perng said the latest interest rate hikes are part of the central bank's efforts to keep deposit interest rates above the domestic inflation rate so that local people need not worry about that interest income on their bank deposits are offset by rises in consumer prices.

According to Perng, the local real interest rate will closely approach zero this year in terms of the 1.23 percent growth rate of the annual consumer price index forecast by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
Perng said the central bank will keep a close watch on the domestic economic situation and maintain a positive real interest rate. (Oct. 1, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier demands probe into irregularities in freeway project
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 13:51:28 (By Su Lung-chi and Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih instructed the relevant authorities Friday to investigate the illegal hiring of foreign workers for a freeway construction project in the central county of Nantou, after six foreigners were killed in an accident a day earlier.

Wu said he was concerned about the presence of foreign workers at the site because the construction contract expressly prohibits such hiring. He told the Council of Labor Affairs and the Department of Social Affairs of Nantou County to investigate the matter.
Wu said the problem of illegal foreign workers is a lingering issue, as the whereabouts of thousands of foreign workers remain unknown.

The accident occurred when a 50-meter high, 80-meter wide section of scaffolding collapsed Thursday at the construction site of the Beishan Interchange of the No. 6 Freeway, triggering a landslide in which seven people were killed, including the six foreign nationals.
While the authorities said the workers were probably working illegally, the contractor, Kuo Ten Construction, said their identities had not yet been established.

DOC.HEADLINE: Annual International Small Business Congress to kick off Oct. 5
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 14:08:14 (By Lin Hui-chun and Hanna Liu)

TEXT.P: The annual International Small Business Congress (ISBC) will be held in Taipei Oct. 5-7, the ISBC said in a statement released Friday.
The congress, now in its 36th year, groups policy makers and participants from around the world in the small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) sector.
This year's conference is expected to draw around 600 delegates from 30 countries, said Robert Sun-quae Lai, director-general of the SME Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

The conference focuses on topics that include SME opportunities in responding to changes in the external environment, new business opportunities in the greater China area and innovation in entrepreneurship, he said.

Francis Chen, founder of Franz Collection Inc., Sunil Kaushal, CEO of Taiwan Standard Chartered Bank Ltd., and Stanley Au, chairman of the Macau SME Administration, will deliver keynote speeches at the conference, the statement said.
Several booths will be set up on the sidelines of the conference to showcase Taiwan's high-quality goods and local specialties, according to the ISBC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close flat in quiet trading

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed little changed Friday in quiet trading, with investors remaining on the sidelines watching closely how companies will report their September sales next week, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 6.40 points, or 0.07 percent, to 8,244.18 after moving between 8,220.73 and 8,260.28 on turnover of NT$111.96 billion (US$3.59 billion).

The market opened up 0.26 percent as rotational buying resumed in select old economy stocks, but the gains were compromised by cautious sentiment ahead of the September sales announcements by electronics heavyweights, the dealers said.

The construction sector outperformed the broader market as the central bank did not come up with any widely expected dramatic measures to impact the industry Thursday, such as the imposition of housing loan limitations to cap local property prices, they said.
In its quarterly policy making meeting, the central bank announced a hike of the key discount rate by 0.125 percentage points to 1.50 percent.
"The central bank move was better than expected, despite the rate hike," Concord Securities analyst Allen Lin said.
"The market was kind of relieved that the central bank imposed no further tightening regulations directly on the property market, " Lin said.
Lin said he was expecting the market to continue to move in a trading range between 8,200 points and 8,400 points next week.
A total of 1,895 stocks closed up and 1,806 down with 357 remaining unchanged.

The construction sector posted the highest gains, up 0.89 percent. Paper and pulp stocks rose 0.8 percent, textiles gained 0.65 percent, plastics and chemical shares added 0.62 percent, and financials rose 0.29 percent.
The cement sector closed up 0.24 percent and the foodstuff sector was 0.08 percent higher, while the machinery and electronics sector fell 0.17 percent.
In the construction sector, Sakura Development rose 2.47 percent to NT$22.80 and Hung Poo Real Estate gained 1.72 percent to close at NT$44.25.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. university dedicates building to forensic scientist Lee

TEXT.P: The University of New Haven will dedicate a newly completed US$14 million building at its campus in Connecticut to forensic scientist Henry Lee, with university President Steven H. Kaplan officiating the inauguration ceremony on Oct. 15, a university press release said Thursday.

"Dr. Lee has been a pioneer in the field of forensic science for more than 40 years, " Kaplan said in the press release. "With the dedication of the new Henry C. Lee Institute of Forensic Science building, we will establish a benchmark by which technologically advanced forensics training facilities will be measured for decades to come."

Lee joined the university's Department of Forensic Science as an assistant professor and program director in 1975. Under his leadership, the forensic science program has expanded from just half a dozen students and limited laboratory space to a premier forensic sciences teaching center in the United States.
He arrived in the U.S. from Taiwan in 1972 to pursue his education in forensic science and biochemistry in New York after working for several years in the Taipei Police Department.

As a forensic scientist, he has worked on famous cases such as the O.J. Simpson and Laci Peterson cases, as well as the post-Sept. 11 forensic investigation. In 2008, he was invited to conduct investigations of the March 19 shooting incident of then-President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu in Tainan, southern Taiwan, on the eve of Taiwan's presidential election.

On March 1, 2007, the university dedicated the College of Forensic Sciences to the highly reputed Lee, and renamed it the Henry C. Lee College of Criminal Justice and Forensic Sciences. Meanwhile, the university started raising funds for the establishment of a state-of-the-art building to house a learning center.

The Forensic Learning Center will include high-tech laboratories, virtual crime scene training modules and classrooms to train police, lawyers, investigators and students in new concepts and practices in forensic scene investigation and examination of physical evidence, according to the press release.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: The courage of the central bank

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of the Republic of China announced a 0.125 percentage point hike in its discount rate Thursday. The measure appears to run counter to the bank's efforts to block the inflow of hot money to try to slow down the appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar.

The hike, which followed a similar one three months ago, has fueled expectations that Taiwan's key interest rate will be raised every quarter. Instead of repelling the hot money, this measure will actually attract more hot money into Taiwan.

Over the past two years, South Korea -- Taiwan's main competitor in the international market -- has seen a 70 percent drop in its currency, due mainly to the global financial crisis and the military standoff with North Korea. Failing to keep its currency at relatively low levels, Taiwan has lost its competitive advantage with South Korea as a result.

While the central bank's decision to further raise interest rates at such a sensitive time allows us to see its courage, we pray that the central bank also has a viable way to fight off an influx of hot money. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 1, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition urged to support implementation of absentee voting
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 15:48:40 (By Justin Huang, Wen Kuei-hsiang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Minister of the Interior urged the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Friday to support a government plan to implement an absentee voting system, which he said has won overwhelming public support.

The system, which allows voters away from the location of their household registration to cast their ballots, will benefit students, workers and military personnel who have the right to vote but do not live in their hometowns, said Jiang Yi-huah, citing ministry statistics showing that more than 80 percent of the people in the country have expressed support for the system.
Jiang made the call in a response to media inquires on the DPP's opposition to the government's plan to adopt the system in time for the 2012 presidential election.

The Ministry of the Interior decided the previous day that it will push for an amendment to the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Act to make absentee voting in the presidential election possible.

However, DPP spokesman Lin Yu-chang said society has not yet reached a consensus on whether or not absentee voting should be implemented and that there is a lack of coordinating measures or a mechanism to prevent flaws or irregularities.
The party also believes that such a system should start with a small election, instead of a major poll such as a presidential election, he said.
Lin accused the government of making the decision "in a manner that is not sufficiently prudent and careful" and said the plan has been drawn up for political reasons.

DOC.HEADLINE: Previous rate hike lowered housing prices: central bank chief
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 16:29:58 (By Chou Yun-chieh and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: An interest rate hike in June effectively curbed local property market prices, Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) Governor Perng Fai-nan said Friday, the day after the bank raised the benchmark interest rate for the second time this year.
Perng was responding to ruling Kuomintang legislator Lin Te-fu, who questioned the government's recent policies in handling rising housing prices at a parliamentary session.

The governor said that according to reports from several construction companies and property realtors, buyers of pre-sales housing and new homes had more room to negotiate in August, allowing home prices to fall by 2.8 percent from June.

The central bank's policy moves had proved effective, Perng said, adding that home mortgages in Taipei City accounted for about 52 percent of total new mortgage lending, down from 59 percent in June, Perng said.
Perng also said that the central bank had taken actions to "manage risks," not "dampen the housing market."
He said that as more than 38 percent of total bank lending was in home mortgages recently, the financial health of the banking industry could be affected.
"So the central bank decided to "take cautious, targeted measures," he said.
A day earlier, the central bank raised its benchmark discount rate by 0.125 percentage points to 1.5 percent, after a similar move on June 24 from a record- low 1.25 percent.
The central bank introduced mortgage restrictions in June, including a 70 percent cap on loans for second homes in the Taipei metropolitan area to cool real estate prices.
Meanwhile, Premier Wu Den-yih also said that the government was not dampening property markets.
High housing prices are an issue in Taipei metropolitan area, but in areas south of Taoyuan, the issue is purchasing power, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIG's Taiwan unit chooses new chief executive

TEXT.P: Insurance giant American International Group's (AIG) 's Taiwan unit chose Richard Bender, executive vice president and chief agency officer at AIA Hong Kong, as acting chief executive on Friday.

Nan Shan Life Insurance Co. announced in a statement that Bender replaced Frank Chan, who retired, and will serve as the company's acting president and CEO after a board meeting approved the appointment.
Nan Shan did not say whether Bender will keep his positions at the group's Hong Kong subsidiary.
Bender's appointment will become effective after approval from the regulator, the statement said.

A Hong Kong consortium comprising Primus Financial Holdings and China Strategic Holdings recently terminated a deal to acquire Nan Shan after the Taiwan government rejected its application in late August.
The sale was controversial as the government cast doubt over the consortium's long-term management capability and lack of a strong commitment to the rights of Nan Shan workers.
Neither AIG nor Nan Shan have made public statements as to whether the Taiwan unit will be put up for sale again.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes down on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the Taiwan dollar Friday, dropping NT$0.02 to close at NT$31.310.
Turnover totaled US$909 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.330 and moved to a low of NT$31.066 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government watchdog begins probe into freeway construction collapse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 17:23:38 (By Sophia Yeh, Chou Yung-chieh, Lin Heng-li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan, the branch of government that monitors the behavior of officials and civil servants, launched an investigation Friday into a fatal accident on a freeway construction site to find out whether any officials are involved in illegal or irregular practices with regard to the project.

Control Yuan Minister without Portfolio Lee Ping-nan, who is in charge of the probe, said earlier in the day that he and his colleague Cheng Jen-hung will make an Oct. 4 visit to the site of the accident that took seven lives a day earlier.
The probe will focus on safety measures at the construction site on the No. 6 Freeway in Nantou County, central Taiwan, and the alleged illegal employment of foreign workers there.

They will also check whether the relevant authorities, including the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, have been negligent in ensuring that the construction was being carried out properly and safely, Lee said.

The accident occurred when a 50-meter high, 80-meter wide section of scaffolding collapsed at the construction site of the Beishan Interchange on the freeway, triggering a landslide in which seven workers were killed, six of whom were foreigners.
The foreign laborers, all of whom were Indonesian, did not have work permits issued by the Taiwan Area National Expressway Engineering Bureau.
CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan told the media she has demanded heavy punishment for any contractors who have illegally hired foreign workers.

She also sought heavy punishment for anyone found to have failed to protect their employees, as an initial investigation suggested that the collapse might have been caused by weak supports resulting from bad grouting carried out by inexperienced workers.
The collapse also injured one local and one Vietnamese worker.

Construction of the interchange project, which began in January last year and is scheduled for completion Jan. 12, 2011, was suspended immediately following the collapse. It will not be resumed until safety checks have been completed, with the contractors obliged to cover any losses caused by the accident, according to the expressway engineering bureau.

The bureau also said the consultancy company responsible for overseeing the project, Sinotech Engineering Consultants, should be held accountable for allowing foreign workers to be illegally employed at the site. Sinotech officials declined to comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indonesian office awaiting identification of dead workers

TEXT.P: Indonesia's representative office in Taiwan has not begun to handle the deaths of six Indonesian migrant workers killed in a construction site accident Thursday as it has yet to be informed of their identity, an official with the office said Friday.

Seven workers, including six who were reportedly Indonesian, were killed and two others were injured after a sprawling network of scaffolding at a construction site for a No. 6 Freeway exit ramp collapsed early Thursday afternoon.
The No. 6 Freeway, which connects Caotun to Puli in central Taiwan, saves travel time to the popular tourist areas of Sun Moon Lake and Cingjing Farm.

"We've been in contact with labor affairs authorities since the accident happened, but we're still waiting for the final identification report from the police department to proceed with subsequent procedures, " said Amina Tjandra, a member of the Indonesian Economic and Trade Office to Taipei's Labor Department.
The six migrant workers were reportedly illegally hired by contractors.
Tjandra said she has no information about the six workers.
"If the media report is correct, they could be undocumented workers who legally entered Taiwan but left their previous job, " she said.

There were 151,723 Indonesian workers in Taiwan as of the end of August, according to figures from the Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training under the council. The number accounts for more than 40 percent of the 372,146 migrant workers in Taiwan at the time.

Just over 85 percent of Indonesian workers -- 129,046 out of 151,723 -- were working in Taiwan in August as caregivers, while less than 1 percent were employed in the construction industry, the figures showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: IC designer's primary listing approved by TWSE

TEXT.P: MStar Semiconductor, Inc., a Cayman Islands- registered integrated circuit designer, has obtained approval from the Taiwan Stock Exchange to launch a primary listing on the main board, the exchange said Friday.

MStar, capitalized at NT$4.56 billion (US$146 million) , is planning to issue 50.71 million new shares at NT$201 each to raise NT$10.19 billion from the listing as operating capital for future expansion, according to the company's prospectus.
MStar products are used largely in consumer electronics products, in particular LCD TVs and LCD displays for computers.
The company said it expects the fund raising will be completed by the end of the second quarter in 2011. Capital Securities has been appointed as the underwriter for the sale.
MStar, set up in Taiwan in June 2002, moved its headquarters to and registered in the Cayman Islands in 2007 to expand globally, according to the prospectus.
The company has kept its operations in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, while most of its products are sold outside Taiwan.

In 2009, Asia, excluding Taiwan, accounted for 83.45 percent of the company's total sales of NT$27.71 billion. Taiwan contributed 10.19 percent, Europe made up 6.30 percent and the Americas represented 0.06 percent.
Last year, MStar posted NT$3.63 billion in net profit, up 45.8 percent from a year earlier.

Integrated Memory Logic, a U.S.-based IC designer, is the only foreign company that has launched a primary listing on Taiwan's main board since May, while seven other companies have been approved by the stock exchange and are preparing for their listings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Long lines as vaccinations for seasonal flu kick off
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 18:10:50 (By Chen Ching-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Hundreds of people, particularly the elderly, lined up outside hospitals in Taipei Friday to receive free seasonal flu vaccinations, the first day of the government's flu-prevention campaign for this year.
Even before midday, nearly 1,000 people had received a number from the Taipei Veterans General Hospital to get their free vaccination in anticipation of the approaching peak flu season.
A long line also formed at Taipei City Hospital's Renai Branch.
An 85-year-old man surnamed Hsueh, accompanying his wheelchair-bound wife to the hospital for vaccination, said he and his wife had received flu inoculations every year for the last five years.
"We are healthier and have spent less on medicine and doctor visits since receiving the vaccinations," he said.
"The vaccine protects my child, " said a mother surnamed Chao who had brought her two-year-old to the hospital to receive a free shot.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control, said the center has purchased nearly 3 million doses of seasonal flu vaccine this year, some from Taiwan's Adimmune Corp. and the rest from overseas firms Novartis and Sanofi-Aventis.
"The vaccines have been distributed to 3,662 public health institutions nationwide," he said.
"Supplies will be smooth and adequate, unlike last year, when the inoculation process was brought to a halt due to shortages, " he added.

The vaccination program will run from Oct. 1-Nov. 30, for citizens aged over 65, children aged between six months and 10 years, medical personnel in charge of disease control and prevention, poultry breeders, and patients with rare or serious diseases, according to Shih.
If the number of doses exceeds requirements, he said, any surplus will be made available to the general public from Dec. 1.
People who are not on the priority list for free inoculation can still get vaccinated at a cost of between NT$500 (US$15.63) and NT$600, Shih pointed out.

The public health authorities began offering free vaccinations against seasonal flu as well as swine flu -- officially known as influenza A(H1N1) -- in 2009, amid global fears over A(H1N1), which can be fatal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Concerns over Taiwan's water supply eased by recent rains: agency
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 18:16:27 (By Lee Hsi-chang and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Heavy rainfall brought by several storms in September has helped ease worries that Taiwan will suffer water shortages during the fast approaching dry season, the Water Resources Agency (WRA) said Friday.
Water levels at Taiwan's major reservoirs are now generally above 80 percent of capacity, ensuring a stable water supply for most of the country through next spring, the WRA said.
More than half of Taiwan's reservoirs are filled to more than 90 percent of capacity, topped by Tsengwen Reservoir in southern Taiwan, which is nearly full, according to WRA figures.
Only four have water levels below 80 percent of their capacity: Taipei's Feitsui Reservoir, Keelung City's Hsinshan Reservoir, Tainan County's Wushantou Reservoir and Nantou County's Wushe Reservoir.

Even those reservoirs, however, were replenished by Typhoon Fanapi on Sept. 17 and other weather fronts in recent weeks, helping relieve water shortages and curtailing the need for water rationing around Taiwan, the WRA said.
Despite the improved water supply situation, the WRA urged people to conserve water whenever they could to help the country get through the dry season, which runs from November to April.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asian university basketball tournament to be held in Taoyuan

TEXT.P: Seven teams from as many countries will participate in the 2010 Asian University Men's Basketball Championship from Oct. 3-8 in the northern county of Taoyuan, the Chinese Taipei University Sports Federation (CTUSF) said Friday.

Myongji University of South Korea, Tianjin Polytechnic University of China, Universite Saint-Esprit De Kaslik of Lebanon and university All-Star teams from Hong Kong, Mongolia, Thailand and host Taiwan will participate in the biennial invitational tourney, according to the CTUSF.
The single round-robin tournament will be held in Kainan University, which is located in Luzhu Township, Taoyuan County.
The competition was launched in 2006, with Myongji University winning the inaugural title. An Iranian university All-Star team took home the championship in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Community hospitals need support to survive: Control Yuan member
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 19:18:43 (By Yeh Su-ping and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Control Yuan member Huang Huang-hsiung said Friday that the government should implement proper policy measures to help community hospitals survive, as the number of such hospitals decreased more than 30 percent over the past 15 years.
He said that under the current system and standard of payments, community hospitals -- which are considered to better meet social service needs -- find it difficult to survive.
"The government should consider how to provide sufficient support to community hospitals in terms of policy, budget and payment system," Huang said at a press conference.
Many community hospital managers said that a lot of people prefer waiting in medical center corridors to seeking help from community hospitals, he added.

Since Taiwan introduced the national health insurance system 15 years ago, the number of community hospitals dropped from 568 to 385, while the number of medical centers and regional hospitals rose sharply, Huang said.

He noted that in 1995, there were 13 medical centers and 48 regional hospitals in Taiwan. As of the end of 2009, the number of medial centers had increased 77 percent to 23, while the number of regional hospitals rose by 62 percent to 78.

Huang also said that in 2009, the volume of medical services provided by community hospitals accounted for only 18.7 percent of the country's total medical services, while medical centers and regional hospitals accounted for 41.2 percent and 37.7 percent respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Google expands Android Market to include Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 19:45:47 (By Jeffrey Wu and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Google Inc.'s Taiwan branch announced Friday that the search engine giant had expanded its online smartphone application store Android Market, allowing Taiwanese sellers to cash in on rising global demand for mobile applications.
"We(Taiwanese people) has always been a hardware maker, and it is difficult for us to sell software, " Google Taiwan General Manager Chien Lee-feng said at a news conference in Taipei.

Taiwanese companies and individuals can now develop various types of applications, or apps, and offer them on Android Market for paid users to download, Chien said. Every developer receives 70 percent of the revenue from each application sold.
Chien said that the number of countries in which developers can register on Android Market rose from nine to 29, including Taiwan.
The apps market will be open to Taiwanese buyers within two weeks, according to Google Taiwan.
In August, Google said that more than 200,000 devices for Android, an operating system developed by Google mainly for smartphones, were being registered daily.
A total of over 80,000 applications were available to download as of the end of September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Court holds hearing on extending ex-president's detention
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 19:58:18 (By Lai Yu-chia and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court held a hearing Friday on whether to further extend the detention of former President Chen Shui-bian, who has been held since Dec. 30, 2008 in connection with corruption and money laundering charges.

Presiding judge Teng Chen-chiu said that the court would hand down a ruling on whether Chen will remain detained for two more months before the current extension expires on Oct. 18. The former president's detainment was previously extended for three months in July.

Chen said at the court hearing that he has been detained for 674 days and that he has said "all he has to say." One should not assume that he has access to channels of fleeing the country because he has been president, he added.
Chen pointed out that Teng had said that if he remitted all the money his family held overseas back to Taiwan, he would have a good chance of being released.

The former president said that he had remitted all US$18.43 million back. The amount fell short of the US$21 million the prosecution alleged his family had laundered to Swiss banks because of losses including processing fees and charges for the early termination of investment contracts.
"If the judge still won't release me on bail now that I've returned the money, is he cheating me?" the former president asked.
After the hearing, Chen returned to the Taipei Detention Center.

He and his wife Wu Shu-jen were found guilty of corruption, forgery and money- laundering in September 2009 and given life sentences, but the Taiwan High Court reduced the sentences to 20 years on June 11.
Chen, his wife and the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office, which led the probe into the ex-president's cases, all appealed the verdict to the Supreme Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: The absurdity of an anti-corruption agency

TEXT.P: When President Ma Ying-jeou put forward a proposal in July to set up an anti- corruption agency under the Ministry of Justice, the low level of the proposed agency immediately raised doubts about its effectiveness.

Ma also said agency staff would be selected from existing members of the Bureau of Investigation and ethics departments of government offices. This is an even worse idea because it is tantamount to pouring old wine in a new bottle, which would not help change the existing culture in which bureaucrats stick up for one another.

An example is the recent corruption scandal that erupted over Taipei City's Xinsheng Overpass improvement project. Huang Hsi-hsun, a former chief of the city's New Construction Office who is under investigation in the case, has obtained an investigative report from the city government's ethics department.
This shows that ethics departments of government offices are either worthless or are an accomplice to irregularities. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 1, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC tech upgrade in China 'positive': Macquarie
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 20:25:30 (By Chang Liang-chih and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The approval obtained by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), the world's largest contract chip maker, to upgrade the production technology at its foundry in China is a "positive" for the company, a research note issued by Macquarie Securities said Friday.

Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs issued the green light to TSMC Wednesday, allowing the company to upgrade the technology at its 8-inch wafer plant in Shanghai to the 0.13 micron process from the current 0.18 micron process.

"We view this as a positive, as the upgrade will boost TSMC's competitiveness, " against companies such as China's Semiconductor International Corp., in product categories that include driver ICs and complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) sensors, the research note said.

Macquarie said it expects the technology upgrade will boost TSMC's capacity in China by 33.3 percent by the end of the first quarter of 2011, 55.6 percent by the end of second quarter and 100 percent by the end of next year.
The securities firm said the development will help TSMC gain a higher market share in China.
In late February, the government relaxed its restrictions on local foundry investment in China by allowing chip makers to upgrade to the 0.13 micron process from the 0.18 micro process.

The relaxation came after the local high-tech industry strongly urged the government to change its policy on fears Taiwanese companies in China would fall behind foreign rivals that had applied to adopt the 0.13 micron process or even more advanced technology in China.

Meanwhile, Macquarie said TSMC's shipments in the fourth quarter are expected to remain at about the same level as in the third quarter, a more optimistic assessment than the market consensus projecting a 5-10 percent decline.
The securities firm said orders placed by mobile customers, such as Qualcomm and Broadcom, are expected to serve as the main engine of TSMC's sales in the fourth quarter.
Macquarie said it maintained a "neutral" recommendation on TSMC shares with a 12-month target price of NT$60.00.
TSMC closed unchanged at NT$62.00 on Taiwan's stock exchange Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan trade delegation hosts product fair in Seoul
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 20:45:31 (By Chiang Yuan-chen and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: A commodity fair promoting Taiwan-made products opened in Seoul Friday, with Taiwanese manufacturers hoping to capitalize on trade opportunities created by Asia's growing economy.
A delegation led by the Importers and Exporters Association of Taipei (IEAT) hosted the event at a hotel in the Korean capital.
The group consisted of 35 Taiwanese brands, including household cleaner manufacturer Farcent Enterprise Co. and kitchenware producer Sinon Corporation.
The exhibition showcases patented household goods made by Taiwanese companies that cater to Korean consumers, from LED lights and furniture to stationery and toys.
South Korea was Taiwan's fifth biggest trade partner last year while Taiwan was its seventh biggest source of imports, said association Chairman Liu Kuo-chao.
Bilateral trade contracted in 2009 due to the global economic
downturn, but has grown 58.7 percent to US$14.55 billion in the first seven months of this year, Liu said.

Chang Yang Horng, director of the Taiwan Trade Center in Seoul, said Taipei's recent signing of a trade deal with Beijing that will allow some of Taiwan's products to be given tariff reductions or exemptions in China, could spur increased business with Korea.
He contended that Korean businesses can take advantage of the trade deal by cooperating with Taiwanese enterprises to expand their share of the emerging market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Treatment reduces swelling in Cambodian girl's 'elephant arm'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 20:46:11 (By Hau Hsue-chin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A tailor-made elastic bandage has helped reduce swelling in the arm of a two- year-old Cambodian girl who checked into Taichung Veterans General Hospital in central Taiwan for treatment on Aug. 28, her doctor said Friday.
The young patient from Cambodia, Reachny Mich, whose condition has been described as an "elephant arm, " was prescribed the elastic garment by pediatric hematologist Chang Teh-kao.
The sleeve reduced her right arm's circumference from 31 centimeters two weeks ago to 26 centimeters, Chang said at a news conference at the hospital.
"It proves that our conservative therapy to reduce the massive swelling in her arm has worked, " he said.
The two-year-old was brought to Taiwan by her mother about one month ago for examination and possible treatment of her arm, which weighed so much the girl was unable to walk.
Chang said Mich's right arm was four to five times larger than her left arm. He diagnosed the girl with a rare case of Klippel-Trenaunay Syndrome, a deformation of blood vessels and bones.
The girl was fortunate as she has not suffered from arteriovenous malformation, an abnormal connection between veins and arteries that would otherwise cause heart failure, Chang said.
"It is hoped that the circumference of the child's arm will decrease to about 20 centimeters in a month," Chang said.
He said that doctors decided not to perform surgery on the child because they felt she was too young and the surgery could cause complications.
"It will take six months to one year for us to complete the current treatment. We will make a new assessment if there is a problem with the sleeve," he said.

Reachny Mich is expected to be released from the hospital in one month so she and her mother can rent a home near the hospital and visit the doctor twice a week, according to Hsu Yu-pi, a volunteer at the hospital.
Hsu has been assisting the two with their finances as they seek medical attention in Taiwan. They have also received a donation of NT$100,000 (US$3,125) from Royal Philips Electronics.
Mich was discovered by a Taiwanese medical team when it visited Cambodia in April to provide free medical services.

DOC.HEADLINE: New scenic area administrator counting on foreign visitors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 21:00:20 (By Huang Po-kai and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The new director of the Southwest Coast National Scenic Area Administration believes the area's ecological and cultural features will prove appealing to overseas visitors, and he said he plans to tap into that market to boost tourism in the region.

Unveiling his plans to promote tourism in the scenic area that covers the southern Taiwan counties of Yunlin, Chiayi, and Tainan, Chang Cheng-yuan said he will invite international media to explore the region's natural beauty.

He said he is convinced that with its shoals, lagoons and estuary wetlands and unique religious customs, the scenic area has the potential to draw tourists from abroad for cultural and ecological excursions.
Chang took over the post earlier in the day from Acting Director Cheng Jung-feng at the administration's office in Tainan County.

Part of Chang's confidence in attracting visitors from abroad stems from his having served as the director of the Tourism Bureau's New York office for eight years until he was appointed to govern the scenic area.

He said at the swearing-in ceremony that in his eight years in New York, he successfully promoted sightseeing in Taiwan. Of all Americans who visited Taiwan in 2009, 25 percent came for pleasure, compared with 8 percent of American arrivals in 2006, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mercedes-Benz sales in Taiwan soar as economy rebounds
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 21:10:06 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Driven by Taiwan's growing economy, sales of Mercedes-Benz cars are expected to rise 40 percent year-on-year in 2010 to 7,000 units, the German luxury car's largest dealer in Taiwan said Friday.

The CMI Group, which is also a major shareholder of Mercedes-Benz Taiwan Ltd., said at an event to mark its 40th anniversary that it was upbeat about Taiwan's luxury car market because of the improving economic environment.
A.A. Khoo, president of CMI, estimated that 7,000 Mercedes-Benz cars, priced at an average of NT$2 million apiece, will be sold in Taiwan this year, compared to more than 5,000 sold in 2009.
"Although it takes about two to three months to deliver a car, most local buyers are willing to wait, an indication of rising consumer confidence, " Khoo said at the CMI anniversary event.

The CMI president said that he expected Mercedes-Benz car sales in Taiwan to maintain double-digit growth annually because the luxury car's sales here have been relatively stable compared to other parts of Asia.
The CMI Group also revealed Friday that it had plans to diversify its business into the local property market.

Khoo expressed optimism over the prospects for Taiwan's residential and commercial real estate markets, even though the country's central bank raised benchmark interest rates for the second time this year on Thursday.
CMI Property Ltd., a subsidiary of the CMI Group, plans to develop a 132,000 square-meter plot of land into a high-tech industrial park in northern Taiwan's Guandu in two to three years, Khoo said.
In addition, the company is also planning to take part in a joint development project to build a city hall MRT station in central Taiwan's Taichung City.

The auto group established the property company in 2005 to tap into the market for commercial buildings and luxury houses, but little had been known about its activities and future plans until Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA warns against visiting Ecuador

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) warned Taiwanese tourists Friday against traveling to Ecuador in the aftermath of a reported coup attempt in the South American country.
Ecuadorian troops rescued the country's president, Rafael Correa, after a shootout with the police in the capital city of Quito, the ministry said in a statement.
A state of emergency has been declared in Ecuador, but all Taiwanese nationals in Ecuador are safe, the MOFA statement added.
It also warned local residents against making unnecessary visits to the South American country in light of political instability.

On Thursday, the MOFA also issued a press release to alert Taiwanese nationals about visiting France, which has been warned about an imminent terrorist attack after the kidnapping of French nationals in Niger and bomb threats in Paris.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to impose anti-dumping on China-made chemical retroactively

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced Friday that Taiwan will impose anti- dumping duties retroactively on benzoyl peroxide made in China because it has been sold in Taiwan at lower than market prices.

The anti-dumping duties, which will range from 4.73 percent against three specific companies to 59.70 percent against other Chinese exporters of the chemical, will be levied over a five-year period beginning retroactively from May 20 this year, according to the MOF's Department of Customs Administration.
Benzoyl peroxide is a chemical compound often used as the active ingredient in products to treat acne, dye hair or whiten teeth because of its antiseptic and bleaching properties.
The move was not the first time Taiwan had imposed anti-dumping duties on products made in China.

Chinese-made footwear has been subject to an anti-dumping duty of 43.46 percent since March 16, 2007 while Chinese-made towels have been subject to an anti- dumping duty of 204.1 percent since June 1, 2006.
The two duties are scheduled to expire on March 15, 2012 and May 31, 2011 respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei to host Daniel Pearl memorial concert

TEXT.P: A free concert featuring a variety of outdoor musical performances by local and foreign musicians will take place in Taipei Saturday in memory of a slain Wall Street Journal reporter.

The annual Daniel Pearl World Music Days, marked for the ninth time in Taipei, will cover bluegrass, blues, country, as well as rock and roll, performed by 12 bands at Treasure Hill from 2 p.m. to 10 p. m.

The event has grown internationally to include more than 4,900 performances in 102 countries and Taipei was among the first cities to participate in this event, the event's co-organizer American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said in a statement.
It is held in honor of Daniel Pearl, an American journalist and musician whose brutal killing shocked the world in 2002.
While working on a story in Pakistan, Pearl was kidnapped and beheaded by terrorists. At that time, he was based in India as the South Asia bureau chief for the Wall Street Journal.
To celebrate his life, Daniel's musician friends launched the Daniel Pearl World Music Days in 2002, spreading a message of tolerance, hope and humanity.
U.S. President Barack Obama also joined this drive.

In a recent public message, he wrote, "I am pleased to send greetings to all those gathered for the 9th Annual Daniel Pearl World Music Days. Throughout history, music has shown a limitless capacity to open our hearts and spur our imaginations."

"These events honor the legacy of Daniel Pearl and help lift up countless lives. As you participate in this month-long celebration of music, let us recommit to promoting tolerance and fellowship throughout the world," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIG's Taiwan unit chooses new chief executive (update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 22:18:05 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The workers' union for indebted American International Group's (AIG) Taiwan unit called for dialogue with the company's new chief executive soon after he was appointed on Friday, in the wake of a failed attempt by AIG to sell the unit.
"We urge the new CEO to talk with us and to lead Nan Shan Life Insurance Co. to operate in accordance with laws, " Wedding Lan, a spokesman for the union, told the Central News Agency by telephone.

Hours earlier, Nan Shan announced the appointment of Richard Bender, executive vice president and chief agency officer at AIA (American International Assurance) Hong Kong, as acting president and CEO to replace Frank Chan, who retired.
The Taiwan government rejected the sale of the unit to a Hong Kong consortium on Aug. 31, voicing concern about the buyer's long-term capability and rights of Nan Shan's workers.
Lan blasted Nan Shan management for a lack of communication about the sale and asked the new chief executive not to repeat the mistake.
A dialogue will help the employees understand the management's difficulties in running the Taiwanese insurer and help the management know how it can better protect workers' rights, he added.
He said that the workers' union would not necessarily oppose a deal to sell Nan Shan, but doesn't want to see any possible negative impact on the company's 37,000 employees.
Meanwhile, AIG was mulling its options on whether it will sell its Taiwan unit again, a Taiwanese spokeswoman said.

"AIG is now conducting a cautious assessment on the possible results of managing Nan Shan on its own, putting it up for sale again or launching an initial public offering (IPO), " Nan Shan spokeswoman Amanda Chou told CNA by telephone.
She said the board meeting that chose Bender did not discuss the next step for the Taiwanese insurer.
Bender will keep his positions at AIG's Hong Kong subsidiary, but will be based in Taiwan after taking the new post, Chou added.
Bender's appointment will become effective after approval from Taiwan's regulator, a press statement from AIG said.
Such an approval should not be a problem as Bender serves as "acting" CEO of Nan Shan, an official with the Taiwan-based Financial Supervisory Commission's Insurance Bureau said.
Speaking on condition of anonymity, a Nan Shan executive told CNA that the appointment of an acting CEO rather than a formal CEO would likely pave the way for another attempt to sell the unit.
AIG has been working to repay the U.S. government for a bailout that saved the company two years ago.
A Hong Kong consortium comprising Primus Financial Holdings and China Strategic Holdings in September terminated a deal to acquire Nan Shan after the Taiwan government rejected its application.
Lan, an active spokesman for the union, was relieved of his senior executive position after the sale was rejected.
The union staged a sit-in Sept. 28 to protest the Nan Shan management's treatment of Lan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bayer works with government to provide after-school program

TEXT.P: A German pharmaceutical company and the Ministry of Education (MOE) are funding an after-school program for underprivileged elementary school students in Nantou County, a school principal said Friday.

Through the ministry's "Star Angel Project, " Bayer has since mid-September been providing 14 disadvantaged students from Dehua Elementary School -- including seven from the Tao aboriginal tribe -- with meals, tutoring programs and aboriginal language classes, principal Liang Yu-chang said.
The Tao tribe is the smallest recognized Taiwanese aboriginal tribe, with only about 700 members throughout the country.
One of the beneficiaries, a fourth grader who identified herself as "Chien- chien, " lives with her 70-year-old grandmother and a physically disabled father who struggles to provide for the family.
"There is no one at home to teach me how to do school exercises," the girl said at the press conference.
The grandmother said she felt a lot of pressure when Chien-chien approached her with questions from school because she was illiterate.
"Thanks to the program, I feel very relieved knowing that Chien-chien will come home with the answers, " the grandmother said, adding that the girl's grades have improved over the past two weeks.
Liu Chung-cheng, head of the Department of Education in Nantou County, said there was still a lot of work to do.
"There are approximately 5,200 students in Nantou who need help, but only 600 are taken care of. We welcome more assistance from the corporate world, " Liu said.

The MOE, in cooperation with private companies and local organizations, began the Star Angel Project in 2008 to provide children from disadvantaged families with a safe environment for studying and playing.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIS helps prevent traffic accidents during Fanapi

TEXT.P: A geographic information system (GIS) used to monitor the country's road system proved effective at keeping motorists away from potentially dangerous roads when Taiwan was struck by Typhoon Fanapi in mid-September, the Directorate General of Highways (DGH) said Friday.

The first-hand information provided by the system allowed the DGH to monitor many vulnerable road sections and bridges prior to and during the storm and reduce the risk of casualties, said Chen Shou-chiang, an engineer with the DGH's Central Emergency Command Center.

According to the DGH, the 18 road sections were completely blocked by landslides and other natural obstacles triggered by the typhoon, and the other 48 that suffered minor damage, were all tracked by the system.

Because of the GIS, the agency was able to close off some roads and bridges before the storm hit to prevent motorists from being caught in sudden road or bridge collapses and it could also monitor the roads in real-time to keep vehicles away soon after problems occurred.
The DGH added that all 66 of the affected road sections were opened to traffic by the end of September.

The installation in April of the NT$1.3 million (US$41.000) cloud computing system aimed at integrating information from relevant government branches to enhance the response to natural disasters, Chen said.

He said the system has encouraged cross-department collaboration, with agencies having access to the platform's database all able to share instant typhoon information and local contacts to improve response efficiency.

Participating agencies include the Central Weather Bureau, the National Science and Technology Center for Disaster Reduction, the Water Resources Agency, and the Soil and Water Conservation Bureau, according to the DGH.
Until now, however, the system has been only partially open to the public due to the Computer-Processed Personal Data Protection Law.
"Technically speaking, the system is ready to go online anytime," Chen said. "We hope a public edition without specific information will hit the road soon."

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to help puppet show company secure soft loans after fire
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 22:50:08 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The government will help a venerable Taiwanese puppet show company secure preferential loans to help it overcome the loss of invaluable puppets and other props and equipment to a fire, Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday.

More than 2,000 puppets that formed a crucial part of Taiwan's folk cultural heritage were destroyed Thursday when an early morning fire engulfed the studios of the famous company, Pili International Multimedia Inc., in Tuku Township in Yunlin County.
The blaze raged for more than two hours before it could be extinguished.

All of the company's puppets, manuscripts, stage props, film production equipment and a number of newly completed films were burned to ashes, an incalculable cultural loss, said Chris Huang, chairman of the puppet company that produces films and video games featuring the puppets.
The company estimated the monetary value of the losses sustained in the fire at around NT$100 million (US$3.17 million).
The Executive Yuan has contacted Mega Bank and other public banks to offer preferential loans to the company, Wu said during a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan.
He added that both he and President Ma Ying-jeou had called Huang after the fire to express their sympathy and made known their willingness to help.

Meanwhile, in response to a question from a legislator, Wu said the administration plans to establish a Taiwanese puppet show museum in Yunlin County dedicated to helping preserve the legacy of the folk art.

Huang comes from Taiwan's most prominent puppet family, whose members, including his late grandfather Huang Hai-tai and his father Huang Chun-hsiung, have maintained a tradition of finding new ways to advance the artistry of performing with wooden puppets.
Their creative performances and skillful management established the company as the living history of Taiwan's puppet show development.

Huang, along with his brother Vincent, later took over the company's operations with a younger generation's vision and passion, establishing Pili Multimedia and bringing the company into the modern era.
They adopted Hollywood production techniques, as well as computer animated special effects and digital sound effects, that took the traditional artform to a whole new level.

DOC.HEADLINE: Design of freeway construction site not flawed: government

TEXT.P: A preliminary review of a construction site where a section of a No. 6 Freeway interchange collapsed and killed seven workers found that there was no flaw in the roadway's design, the body supervising the construction said Friday.

Tseng Dar-jen, head of the National Expressway Engineering Bureau, dismissed speculation that an inappropriate design led to an overloading of an elevated girder during the grouting process, triggering the collapse of the scaffolding.

The elevated support girder can hold up to two times its designated weight, Tseng said, but the actual weight of the cement poured into the section had reached only one-third of the girder's capacity when the collapse occurred.

The official also rejected speculation that the accident happened because the contractor was rushing to meet the project's January 2011 due date. Tseng said 88 percent of the Beishan Interchange project had been completed when the accident happened.
"The construction project was definitely not rushed, " he said.
The collapse of the scaffolding surprised the 10 workers at the site at the time, one of whom was not a regular on the project. Seven were killed and the three others were injured in the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talks to discuss medical cooperation, investment protection: Chiang
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 23:40:22 (By Kou Mei-lan and Hanna Liu )

TEXT.P: Issues related to medical cooperation and investment protection will be discussed in the next round of formal talks between Taiwan and China, Taiwan's top negotiator with China said Friday.

Speaking at a board meeting of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said officials on the two sides are currently making preparations for the upcoming negotiations, slated to be held at the end of this year in Taiwan.

After the conclusion of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that Taiwan signed with China in June, the two sides agreed to continue negotiations on four topics -- merchandise trade, services, investment protection and trade dispute settlement, Chiang said.
"In the coming round of talks, the two sides will hold discussions on medical cooperation and investment protection, " he said.
Meanwhile, Chiang is scheduled to visit Europe from Oct. 3-9 and will deliver a speech focusing on cross-strait relations at the European Parliament, according to the SEF.
During his trip to Europe, the SEF chairman will also deliver a speech in his capacity as vice chairman of the Kuomintang at an annual meeting of the British Conservative Party.
Then, Chiang will visit Japan Oct. 13-19 to meet with local business associations and communities and deliver two speeches.

DOC.HEADLINE: Concerns over Taiwan's water supply eased by recent rains: agency
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 18:16:27 (By Lee Hsi-chang and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Heavy rainfall brought by several storms in September has helped ease worries that Taiwan will suffer water shortages during the fast approaching dry season, the Water Resources Agency (WRA) said Friday.
Water levels at Taiwan's major reservoirs are now generally above 80 percent of capacity, ensuring a stable water supply for most of the country through next spring, the WRA said.
More than half of Taiwan's reservoirs are filled to more than 90 percent of capacity, topped by Tsengwen Reservoir in southern Taiwan, which is nearly full, according to WRA figures.
Only four have water levels below 80 percent of their capacity: Taipei's Feitsui Reservoir, Keelung City's Hsinshan Reservoir, Tainan County's Wushantou Reservoir and Nantou County's Wushe Reservoir.

Even those reservoirs, however, were replenished by Typhoon Fanapi on Sept. 17 and other weather fronts in recent weeks, helping relieve water shortages and curtailing the need for water rationing around Taiwan, the WRA said.
Despite the improved water supply situation, the WRA urged people to conserve water whenever they could to help the country get through the dry season, which runs from November to April.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asian university basketball tournament to be held in Taoyuan

TEXT.P: Seven teams from as many countries will participate in the 2010 Asian University Men's Basketball Championship from Oct. 3-8 in the northern county of Taoyuan, the Chinese Taipei University Sports Federation (CTUSF) said Friday.

Myongji University of South Korea, Tianjin Polytechnic University of China, Universite Saint-Esprit De Kaslik of Lebanon and university All-Star teams from Hong Kong, Mongolia, Thailand and host Taiwan will participate in the biennial invitational tourney, according to the CTUSF.
The single round-robin tournament will be held in Kainan University, which is located in Luzhu Township, Taoyuan County.
The competition was launched in 2006, with Myongji University winning the inaugural title. An Iranian university All-Star team took home the championship in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Community hospitals need support to survive: Control Yuan member
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 19:18:43 (By Yeh Su-ping and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Control Yuan member Huang Huang-hsiung said Friday that the government should implement proper policy measures to help community hospitals survive, as the number of such hospitals decreased more than 30 percent over the past 15 years.
He said that under the current system and standard of payments, community hospitals -- which are considered to better meet social service needs -- find it difficult to survive.
"The government should consider how to provide sufficient support to community hospitals in terms of policy, budget and payment system," Huang said at a press conference.
Many community hospital managers said that a lot of people prefer waiting in medical center corridors to seeking help from community hospitals, he added.

Since Taiwan introduced the national health insurance system 15 years ago, the number of community hospitals dropped from 568 to 385, while the number of medical centers and regional hospitals rose sharply, Huang said.

He noted that in 1995, there were 13 medical centers and 48 regional hospitals in Taiwan. As of the end of 2009, the number of medial centers had increased 77 percent to 23, while the number of regional hospitals rose by 62 percent to 78.

Huang also said that in 2009, the volume of medical services provided by community hospitals accounted for only 18.7 percent of the country's total medical services, while medical centers and regional hospitals accounted for 41.2 percent and 37.7 percent respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Google expands Android Market to include Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 19:45:47 (By Jeffrey Wu and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Google Inc.'s Taiwan branch announced Friday that the search engine giant had expanded its online smartphone application store Android Market, allowing Taiwanese sellers to cash in on rising global demand for mobile applications.
"We(Taiwanese people) has always been a hardware maker, and it is difficult for us to sell software, " Google Taiwan General Manager Chien Lee-feng said at a news conference in Taipei.

Taiwanese companies and individuals can now develop various types of applications, or apps, and offer them on Android Market for paid users to download, Chien said. Every developer receives 70 percent of the revenue from each application sold.
Chien said that the number of countries in which developers can register on Android Market rose from nine to 29, including Taiwan.
The apps market will be open to Taiwanese buyers within two weeks, according to Google Taiwan.
In August, Google said that more than 200,000 devices for Android, an operating system developed by Google mainly for smartphones, were being registered daily.
A total of over 80,000 applications were available to download as of the end of September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Court holds hearing on extending ex-president's detention
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 19:58:18 (By Lai Yu-chia and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court held a hearing Friday on whether to further extend the detention of former President Chen Shui-bian, who has been held since Dec. 30, 2008 in connection with corruption and money laundering charges.

Presiding judge Teng Chen-chiu said that the court would hand down a ruling on whether Chen will remain detained for two more months before the current extension expires on Oct. 18. The former president's detainment was previously extended for three months in July.

Chen said at the court hearing that he has been detained for 674 days and that he has said "all he has to say." One should not assume that he has access to channels of fleeing the country because he has been president, he added.
Chen pointed out that Teng had said that if he remitted all the money his family held overseas back to Taiwan, he would have a good chance of being released.

The former president said that he had remitted all US$18.43 million back. The amount fell short of the US$21 million the prosecution alleged his family had laundered to Swiss banks because of losses including processing fees and charges for the early termination of investment contracts.
"If the judge still won't release me on bail now that I've returned the money, is he cheating me?" the former president asked.
After the hearing, Chen returned to the Taipei Detention Center.

He and his wife Wu Shu-jen were found guilty of corruption, forgery and money- laundering in September 2009 and given life sentences, but the Taiwan High Court reduced the sentences to 20 years on June 11.
