Chen, his wife and the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office, which led the probe into the ex-president's cases, all appealed the verdict to the Supreme Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: The absurdity of an anti-corruption agency

TEXT.P: When President Ma Ying-jeou put forward a proposal in July to set up an anti- corruption agency under the Ministry of Justice, the low level of the proposed agency immediately raised doubts about its effectiveness.

Ma also said agency staff would be selected from existing members of the Bureau of Investigation and ethics departments of government offices. This is an even worse idea because it is tantamount to pouring old wine in a new bottle, which would not help change the existing culture in which bureaucrats stick up for one another.

An example is the recent corruption scandal that erupted over Taipei City's Xinsheng Overpass improvement project. Huang Hsi-hsun, a former chief of the city's New Construction Office who is under investigation in the case, has obtained an investigative report from the city government's ethics department.
This shows that ethics departments of government offices are either worthless or are an accomplice to irregularities. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 1, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC tech upgrade in China 'positive': Macquarie
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 20:25:30 (By Chang Liang-chih and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The approval obtained by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), the world's largest contract chip maker, to upgrade the production technology at its foundry in China is a "positive" for the company, a research note issued by Macquarie Securities said Friday.

Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs issued the green light to TSMC Wednesday, allowing the company to upgrade the technology at its 8-inch wafer plant in Shanghai to the 0.13 micron process from the current 0.18 micron process.

"We view this as a positive, as the upgrade will boost TSMC's competitiveness, " against companies such as China's Semiconductor International Corp., in product categories that include driver ICs and complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) sensors, the research note said.

Macquarie said it expects the technology upgrade will boost TSMC's capacity in China by 33.3 percent by the end of the first quarter of 2011, 55.6 percent by the end of second quarter and 100 percent by the end of next year.
The securities firm said the development will help TSMC gain a higher market share in China.
In late February, the government relaxed its restrictions on local foundry investment in China by allowing chip makers to upgrade to the 0.13 micron process from the 0.18 micro process.

The relaxation came after the local high-tech industry strongly urged the government to change its policy on fears Taiwanese companies in China would fall behind foreign rivals that had applied to adopt the 0.13 micron process or even more advanced technology in China.

Meanwhile, Macquarie said TSMC's shipments in the fourth quarter are expected to remain at about the same level as in the third quarter, a more optimistic assessment than the market consensus projecting a 5-10 percent decline.
The securities firm said orders placed by mobile customers, such as Qualcomm and Broadcom, are expected to serve as the main engine of TSMC's sales in the fourth quarter.
Macquarie said it maintained a "neutral" recommendation on TSMC shares with a 12-month target price of NT$60.00.
TSMC closed unchanged at NT$62.00 on Taiwan's stock exchange Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan trade delegation hosts product fair in Seoul
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 20:45:31 (By Chiang Yuan-chen and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: A commodity fair promoting Taiwan-made products opened in Seoul Friday, with Taiwanese manufacturers hoping to capitalize on trade opportunities created by Asia's growing economy.
A delegation led by the Importers and Exporters Association of Taipei (IEAT) hosted the event at a hotel in the Korean capital.
The group consisted of 35 Taiwanese brands, including household cleaner manufacturer Farcent Enterprise Co. and kitchenware producer Sinon Corporation.
The exhibition showcases patented household goods made by Taiwanese companies that cater to Korean consumers, from LED lights and furniture to stationery and toys.
South Korea was Taiwan's fifth biggest trade partner last year while Taiwan was its seventh biggest source of imports, said association Chairman Liu Kuo-chao.
Bilateral trade contracted in 2009 due to the global economic
downturn, but has grown 58.7 percent to US$14.55 billion in the first seven months of this year, Liu said.

Chang Yang Horng, director of the Taiwan Trade Center in Seoul, said Taipei's recent signing of a trade deal with Beijing that will allow some of Taiwan's products to be given tariff reductions or exemptions in China, could spur increased business with Korea.
He contended that Korean businesses can take advantage of the trade deal by cooperating with Taiwanese enterprises to expand their share of the emerging market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Treatment reduces swelling in Cambodian girl's 'elephant arm'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 20:46:11 (By Hau Hsue-chin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A tailor-made elastic bandage has helped reduce swelling in the arm of a two- year-old Cambodian girl who checked into Taichung Veterans General Hospital in central Taiwan for treatment on Aug. 28, her doctor said Friday.
The young patient from Cambodia, Reachny Mich, whose condition has been described as an "elephant arm, " was prescribed the elastic garment by pediatric hematologist Chang Teh-kao.
The sleeve reduced her right arm's circumference from 31 centimeters two weeks ago to 26 centimeters, Chang said at a news conference at the hospital.
"It proves that our conservative therapy to reduce the massive swelling in her arm has worked, " he said.
The two-year-old was brought to Taiwan by her mother about one month ago for examination and possible treatment of her arm, which weighed so much the girl was unable to walk.
Chang said Mich's right arm was four to five times larger than her left arm. He diagnosed the girl with a rare case of Klippel-Trenaunay Syndrome, a deformation of blood vessels and bones.
The girl was fortunate as she has not suffered from arteriovenous malformation, an abnormal connection between veins and arteries that would otherwise cause heart failure, Chang said.
"It is hoped that the circumference of the child's arm will decrease to about 20 centimeters in a month," Chang said.
He said that doctors decided not to perform surgery on the child because they felt she was too young and the surgery could cause complications.
"It will take six months to one year for us to complete the current treatment. We will make a new assessment if there is a problem with the sleeve," he said.

Reachny Mich is expected to be released from the hospital in one month so she and her mother can rent a home near the hospital and visit the doctor twice a week, according to Hsu Yu-pi, a volunteer at the hospital.
Hsu has been assisting the two with their finances as they seek medical attention in Taiwan. They have also received a donation of NT$100,000 (US$3,125) from Royal Philips Electronics.
Mich was discovered by a Taiwanese medical team when it visited Cambodia in April to provide free medical services.

DOC.HEADLINE: New scenic area administrator counting on foreign visitors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 21:00:20 (By Huang Po-kai and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The new director of the Southwest Coast National Scenic Area Administration believes the area's ecological and cultural features will prove appealing to overseas visitors, and he said he plans to tap into that market to boost tourism in the region.

Unveiling his plans to promote tourism in the scenic area that covers the southern Taiwan counties of Yunlin, Chiayi, and Tainan, Chang Cheng-yuan said he will invite international media to explore the region's natural beauty.

He said he is convinced that with its shoals, lagoons and estuary wetlands and unique religious customs, the scenic area has the potential to draw tourists from abroad for cultural and ecological excursions.
Chang took over the post earlier in the day from Acting Director Cheng Jung-feng at the administration's office in Tainan County.

Part of Chang's confidence in attracting visitors from abroad stems from his having served as the director of the Tourism Bureau's New York office for eight years until he was appointed to govern the scenic area.

He said at the swearing-in ceremony that in his eight years in New York, he successfully promoted sightseeing in Taiwan. Of all Americans who visited Taiwan in 2009, 25 percent came for pleasure, compared with 8 percent of American arrivals in 2006, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mercedes-Benz sales in Taiwan soar as economy rebounds
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 21:10:06 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Driven by Taiwan's growing economy, sales of Mercedes-Benz cars are expected to rise 40 percent year-on-year in 2010 to 7,000 units, the German luxury car's largest dealer in Taiwan said Friday.

The CMI Group, which is also a major shareholder of Mercedes-Benz Taiwan Ltd., said at an event to mark its 40th anniversary that it was upbeat about Taiwan's luxury car market because of the improving economic environment.
A.A. Khoo, president of CMI, estimated that 7,000 Mercedes-Benz cars, priced at an average of NT$2 million apiece, will be sold in Taiwan this year, compared to more than 5,000 sold in 2009.
"Although it takes about two to three months to deliver a car, most local buyers are willing to wait, an indication of rising consumer confidence, " Khoo said at the CMI anniversary event.

The CMI president said that he expected Mercedes-Benz car sales in Taiwan to maintain double-digit growth annually because the luxury car's sales here have been relatively stable compared to other parts of Asia.
The CMI Group also revealed Friday that it had plans to diversify its business into the local property market.

Khoo expressed optimism over the prospects for Taiwan's residential and commercial real estate markets, even though the country's central bank raised benchmark interest rates for the second time this year on Thursday.
CMI Property Ltd., a subsidiary of the CMI Group, plans to develop a 132,000 square-meter plot of land into a high-tech industrial park in northern Taiwan's Guandu in two to three years, Khoo said.
In addition, the company is also planning to take part in a joint development project to build a city hall MRT station in central Taiwan's Taichung City.

The auto group established the property company in 2005 to tap into the market for commercial buildings and luxury houses, but little had been known about its activities and future plans until Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA warns against visiting Ecuador

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) warned Taiwanese tourists Friday against traveling to Ecuador in the aftermath of a reported coup attempt in the South American country.
Ecuadorian troops rescued the country's president, Rafael Correa, after a shootout with the police in the capital city of Quito, the ministry said in a statement.
A state of emergency has been declared in Ecuador, but all Taiwanese nationals in Ecuador are safe, the MOFA statement added.
It also warned local residents against making unnecessary visits to the South American country in light of political instability.

On Thursday, the MOFA also issued a press release to alert Taiwanese nationals about visiting France, which has been warned about an imminent terrorist attack after the kidnapping of French nationals in Niger and bomb threats in Paris.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to impose anti-dumping on China-made chemical retroactively

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced Friday that Taiwan will impose anti- dumping duties retroactively on benzoyl peroxide made in China because it has been sold in Taiwan at lower than market prices.

The anti-dumping duties, which will range from 4.73 percent against three specific companies to 59.70 percent against other Chinese exporters of the chemical, will be levied over a five-year period beginning retroactively from May 20 this year, according to the MOF's Department of Customs Administration.
Benzoyl peroxide is a chemical compound often used as the active ingredient in products to treat acne, dye hair or whiten teeth because of its antiseptic and bleaching properties.
The move was not the first time Taiwan had imposed anti-dumping duties on products made in China.

Chinese-made footwear has been subject to an anti-dumping duty of 43.46 percent since March 16, 2007 while Chinese-made towels have been subject to an anti- dumping duty of 204.1 percent since June 1, 2006.
The two duties are scheduled to expire on March 15, 2012 and May 31, 2011 respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei to host Daniel Pearl memorial concert

TEXT.P: A free concert featuring a variety of outdoor musical performances by local and foreign musicians will take place in Taipei Saturday in memory of a slain Wall Street Journal reporter.

The annual Daniel Pearl World Music Days, marked for the ninth time in Taipei, will cover bluegrass, blues, country, as well as rock and roll, performed by 12 bands at Treasure Hill from 2 p.m. to 10 p. m.

The event has grown internationally to include more than 4,900 performances in 102 countries and Taipei was among the first cities to participate in this event, the event's co-organizer American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said in a statement.
It is held in honor of Daniel Pearl, an American journalist and musician whose brutal killing shocked the world in 2002.
While working on a story in Pakistan, Pearl was kidnapped and beheaded by terrorists. At that time, he was based in India as the South Asia bureau chief for the Wall Street Journal.
To celebrate his life, Daniel's musician friends launched the Daniel Pearl World Music Days in 2002, spreading a message of tolerance, hope and humanity.
U.S. President Barack Obama also joined this drive.

In a recent public message, he wrote, "I am pleased to send greetings to all those gathered for the 9th Annual Daniel Pearl World Music Days. Throughout history, music has shown a limitless capacity to open our hearts and spur our imaginations."

"These events honor the legacy of Daniel Pearl and help lift up countless lives. As you participate in this month-long celebration of music, let us recommit to promoting tolerance and fellowship throughout the world," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIG's Taiwan unit chooses new chief executive (update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 22:18:05 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The workers' union for indebted American International Group's (AIG) Taiwan unit called for dialogue with the company's new chief executive soon after he was appointed on Friday, in the wake of a failed attempt by AIG to sell the unit.
"We urge the new CEO to talk with us and to lead Nan Shan Life Insurance Co. to operate in accordance with laws, " Wedding Lan, a spokesman for the union, told the Central News Agency by telephone.

Hours earlier, Nan Shan announced the appointment of Richard Bender, executive vice president and chief agency officer at AIA (American International Assurance) Hong Kong, as acting president and CEO to replace Frank Chan, who retired.
The Taiwan government rejected the sale of the unit to a Hong Kong consortium on Aug. 31, voicing concern about the buyer's long-term capability and rights of Nan Shan's workers.
Lan blasted Nan Shan management for a lack of communication about the sale and asked the new chief executive not to repeat the mistake.
A dialogue will help the employees understand the management's difficulties in running the Taiwanese insurer and help the management know how it can better protect workers' rights, he added.
He said that the workers' union would not necessarily oppose a deal to sell Nan Shan, but doesn't want to see any possible negative impact on the company's 37,000 employees.
Meanwhile, AIG was mulling its options on whether it will sell its Taiwan unit again, a Taiwanese spokeswoman said.

"AIG is now conducting a cautious assessment on the possible results of managing Nan Shan on its own, putting it up for sale again or launching an initial public offering (IPO), " Nan Shan spokeswoman Amanda Chou told CNA by telephone.
She said the board meeting that chose Bender did not discuss the next step for the Taiwanese insurer.
Bender will keep his positions at AIG's Hong Kong subsidiary, but will be based in Taiwan after taking the new post, Chou added.
Bender's appointment will become effective after approval from Taiwan's regulator, a press statement from AIG said.
Such an approval should not be a problem as Bender serves as "acting" CEO of Nan Shan, an official with the Taiwan-based Financial Supervisory Commission's Insurance Bureau said.
Speaking on condition of anonymity, a Nan Shan executive told CNA that the appointment of an acting CEO rather than a formal CEO would likely pave the way for another attempt to sell the unit.
AIG has been working to repay the U.S. government for a bailout that saved the company two years ago.
A Hong Kong consortium comprising Primus Financial Holdings and China Strategic Holdings in September terminated a deal to acquire Nan Shan after the Taiwan government rejected its application.
Lan, an active spokesman for the union, was relieved of his senior executive position after the sale was rejected.
The union staged a sit-in Sept. 28 to protest the Nan Shan management's treatment of Lan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bayer works with government to provide after-school program

TEXT.P: A German pharmaceutical company and the Ministry of Education (MOE) are funding an after-school program for underprivileged elementary school students in Nantou County, a school principal said Friday.

Through the ministry's "Star Angel Project, " Bayer has since mid-September been providing 14 disadvantaged students from Dehua Elementary School -- including seven from the Tao aboriginal tribe -- with meals, tutoring programs and aboriginal language classes, principal Liang Yu-chang said.
The Tao tribe is the smallest recognized Taiwanese aboriginal tribe, with only about 700 members throughout the country.
One of the beneficiaries, a fourth grader who identified herself as "Chien- chien, " lives with her 70-year-old grandmother and a physically disabled father who struggles to provide for the family.
"There is no one at home to teach me how to do school exercises," the girl said at the press conference.
The grandmother said she felt a lot of pressure when Chien-chien approached her with questions from school because she was illiterate.
"Thanks to the program, I feel very relieved knowing that Chien-chien will come home with the answers, " the grandmother said, adding that the girl's grades have improved over the past two weeks.
Liu Chung-cheng, head of the Department of Education in Nantou County, said there was still a lot of work to do.
"There are approximately 5,200 students in Nantou who need help, but only 600 are taken care of. We welcome more assistance from the corporate world, " Liu said.

The MOE, in cooperation with private companies and local organizations, began the Star Angel Project in 2008 to provide children from disadvantaged families with a safe environment for studying and playing.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIS helps prevent traffic accidents during Fanapi

TEXT.P: A geographic information system (GIS) used to monitor the country's road system proved effective at keeping motorists away from potentially dangerous roads when Taiwan was struck by Typhoon Fanapi in mid-September, the Directorate General of Highways (DGH) said Friday.

The first-hand information provided by the system allowed the DGH to monitor many vulnerable road sections and bridges prior to and during the storm and reduce the risk of casualties, said Chen Shou-chiang, an engineer with the DGH's Central Emergency Command Center.

According to the DGH, the 18 road sections were completely blocked by landslides and other natural obstacles triggered by the typhoon, and the other 48 that suffered minor damage, were all tracked by the system.

Because of the GIS, the agency was able to close off some roads and bridges before the storm hit to prevent motorists from being caught in sudden road or bridge collapses and it could also monitor the roads in real-time to keep vehicles away soon after problems occurred.
The DGH added that all 66 of the affected road sections were opened to traffic by the end of September.

The installation in April of the NT$1.3 million (US$41.000) cloud computing system aimed at integrating information from relevant government branches to enhance the response to natural disasters, Chen said.

He said the system has encouraged cross-department collaboration, with agencies having access to the platform's database all able to share instant typhoon information and local contacts to improve response efficiency.

Participating agencies include the Central Weather Bureau, the National Science and Technology Center for Disaster Reduction, the Water Resources Agency, and the Soil and Water Conservation Bureau, according to the DGH.
Until now, however, the system has been only partially open to the public due to the Computer-Processed Personal Data Protection Law.
"Technically speaking, the system is ready to go online anytime," Chen said. "We hope a public edition without specific information will hit the road soon."

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to help puppet show company secure soft loans after fire
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 22:50:08 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The government will help a venerable Taiwanese puppet show company secure preferential loans to help it overcome the loss of invaluable puppets and other props and equipment to a fire, Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday.

More than 2,000 puppets that formed a crucial part of Taiwan's folk cultural heritage were destroyed Thursday when an early morning fire engulfed the studios of the famous company, Pili International Multimedia Inc., in Tuku Township in Yunlin County.
The blaze raged for more than two hours before it could be extinguished.

All of the company's puppets, manuscripts, stage props, film production equipment and a number of newly completed films were burned to ashes, an incalculable cultural loss, said Chris Huang, chairman of the puppet company that produces films and video games featuring the puppets.
The company estimated the monetary value of the losses sustained in the fire at around NT$100 million (US$3.17 million).
The Executive Yuan has contacted Mega Bank and other public banks to offer preferential loans to the company, Wu said during a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan.
He added that both he and President Ma Ying-jeou had called Huang after the fire to express their sympathy and made known their willingness to help.

Meanwhile, in response to a question from a legislator, Wu said the administration plans to establish a Taiwanese puppet show museum in Yunlin County dedicated to helping preserve the legacy of the folk art.

Huang comes from Taiwan's most prominent puppet family, whose members, including his late grandfather Huang Hai-tai and his father Huang Chun-hsiung, have maintained a tradition of finding new ways to advance the artistry of performing with wooden puppets.
Their creative performances and skillful management established the company as the living history of Taiwan's puppet show development.

Huang, along with his brother Vincent, later took over the company's operations with a younger generation's vision and passion, establishing Pili Multimedia and bringing the company into the modern era.
They adopted Hollywood production techniques, as well as computer animated special effects and digital sound effects, that took the traditional artform to a whole new level.

DOC.HEADLINE: Design of freeway construction site not flawed: government

TEXT.P: A preliminary review of a construction site where a section of a No. 6 Freeway interchange collapsed and killed seven workers found that there was no flaw in the roadway's design, the body supervising the construction said Friday.

Tseng Dar-jen, head of the National Expressway Engineering Bureau, dismissed speculation that an inappropriate design led to an overloading of an elevated girder during the grouting process, triggering the collapse of the scaffolding.

The elevated support girder can hold up to two times its designated weight, Tseng said, but the actual weight of the cement poured into the section had reached only one-third of the girder's capacity when the collapse occurred.

The official also rejected speculation that the accident happened because the contractor was rushing to meet the project's January 2011 due date. Tseng said 88 percent of the Beishan Interchange project had been completed when the accident happened.
"The construction project was definitely not rushed, " he said.
The collapse of the scaffolding surprised the 10 workers at the site at the time, one of whom was not a regular on the project. Seven were killed and the three others were injured in the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talks to discuss medical cooperation, investment protection: Chiang
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/10 23:40:22 (By Kou Mei-lan and Hanna Liu )

TEXT.P: Issues related to medical cooperation and investment protection will be discussed in the next round of formal talks between Taiwan and China, Taiwan's top negotiator with China said Friday.

Speaking at a board meeting of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said officials on the two sides are currently making preparations for the upcoming negotiations, slated to be held at the end of this year in Taiwan.

After the conclusion of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that Taiwan signed with China in June, the two sides agreed to continue negotiations on four topics -- merchandise trade, services, investment protection and trade dispute settlement, Chiang said.
"In the coming round of talks, the two sides will hold discussions on medical cooperation and investment protection, " he said.
Meanwhile, Chiang is scheduled to visit Europe from Oct. 3-9 and will deliver a speech focusing on cross-strait relations at the European Parliament, according to the SEF.
During his trip to Europe, the SEF chairman will also deliver a speech in his capacity as vice chairman of the Kuomintang at an annual meeting of the British Conservative Party.
Then, Chiang will visit Japan Oct. 13-19 to meet with local business associations and communities and deliver two speeches.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 2, 2010, or the 25th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
322 B.C.: Aristotle, Greek Philosopher, dies of a stomach illness at the age of 62. A pupil of Plato, the tutor of Alexander the Great, and the author of works on logic, metaphysics, ethics, natural science, politics and poetics, he profoundly influenced western thought.
1803: Samuel Adams, American statesman, dies at the age of 81. He was one of the signatories of the Declaration of Independence.
1835: Texan-Americans strike the first blow for an independent Texas by staging an armed uprising against the central government of Antonio de Santa Anna in the town of Gonzales, located 108 km east of San Antonio.
1869: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, Indian leader, is born. He used non-violent civil disobedience in his campaign for Indian independence.
1870: Rome becomes the capital of Italy.
1871: Cordell Hull, American statesman, diplomat, and the secretary of state under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, is born. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1945.
1909: A 220-km railway from Peking to Changchiakow (Kalgan) in Inner Mongolia, the first railroad built and owned by China, is opened to traffic.
1918: The world's first public health college is established at John Hopkins University in Baltimore.
1920: U.S. marines, sent by President Woodrow Wilson to Haiti to restore order, clash with rebel forces and kill their leaders.
1924: The League of Nations in Geneva adopts a protocol for the peaceful settlement of international disputes.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is appointed commander-in-chief of the Northwestern Communist-Suppression Army, and Chang Hsueh-ling is appointed the deputy commander-in-chief, with their headquarters located in Sian.
1942: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt's special envoy, Wendel Willkie, arrives in Chungking to confer with Chinese leaders.
1945: George Smith Patten Jr., American general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany, is demoted by U.S. Army Chief-of-Staff Dwight D. Eisenhower.
1973: Siri Siriyodhin, Thai speaker of the House of Representatives and head of an 11-member parliamentary mission, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: A total of 319 model soldiers are cited to mark the ROC's 21st Armed Forces Day.
1985: The ROC government announces the liberalization of gold imports and transactions.
1985: Rock Hudson, Hollywood star, dies of AIDS at the age of 59.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the revision of tariffs, lowering the highest tariff rate to 58 percent.
1989: The ROC and Liberia re-establish diplomatic relations. Peking severs formal ties with Liberia in protest.
1990: A hijacked Chinese jet crashes into two parked planes at the Guangzhou airport, killing 127 people.
1996: A Peruvian plane crashes into the Pacific Ocean, killing all 20 people on board.
1998: Sanjaasuregiin Zorig, a popular government minister and the leading figure in Mongolia's peaceful democratic revolution, is murdered.
1999: Overseas Chinese communities around the world donate a total of NT$540 million (US$16.9 million) for victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake in Taiwan.
2001: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) is studying the feasibility of using undercover agents in its battle against organized crime.
2004: Iraqi insurgents shoot down a U.S. military helicopter near Baghdad, killing 36 soldiers and crewmen aboard.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "During the examination of every system of moral laws with the teaching of acknowledged great and wise men of the past, there must be no divergence. Applying the examination to the operations and porches of nature in the physical universe, there must be no contradiction."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan wins bronze in Asian U18 basketball tourney

TEXT.P: Taiwan won its first medal in the FIBA Asia U18 Championship for Men since 2000 and a berth to represent Asia in the 2011 FIBA U19 World Championship after edging Iran 65-60 in the bronze medal game in Sanaa, Yemen late Friday Taiwan time.

Hung Kang-chiao scored a team-high 18 points and Hu Lung-mao added 17 points as Taiwan used a 14-5 run in the third quarter to control the momentum before holding off Iran's furious rally in the final period.

Taiwan, which opened the biennial tournament with an overtime loss to the defending champion Iran, limited the Iranians to a miserable 30 percent field goal shooting percentage in the game for a sweet revenge.
"We have improved a lot, haven't we? " Taiwan head coach Huang Wan-lung quipped after the game, according to the post-game report on the FIBA Asia Web site.

Taiwan last won a medal -- also a bronze -- in the biennial tourney in Kuala Lumpur in 2000, when Huang served on the Taiwanese junior national team as an assistant coach under South Korean head coach Chung Kwang Suk.
Taiwan has never won the junior tournament. It won silver medals in 1972 and 1989 and took home bronze in 1974, 1987, 2000 and 2010. Two years ago, Taiwan finished an all-time worst ninth place.

With the win, Taiwan secured one of three Asian berths in the 2011 FIBA U19 World Championship, which will be held in Latvia from June 30 to July 10, 2011. Taiwan's previous appearance in the world's top-level junior competition came 23 years ago, when they played at Bormio, Italy in 1987.
China routed South Korea 103-80 in the title game to win its ninth gold in the history of the tournament. The gold and silver medalists will also play in Latvia.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Who will protect Wen Jiabao?

TEXT.P: At the United Nations General Assembly last week, Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao said China will "push forward political restructuring" while deepening its economic restructuring.
This was the first time that a Beijing leader has spoken of the necessity for political reform by China at the United Nations, and was the fifth such remark by Wen since Aug. 20.

The lack of freedom and democracy within the Chinese Communist Party is the most serious problem with China's totalitarian regime. So far, there have not been signs that Wen is at risk of being purged, which can be seen as progress. There are therefore calls in China for the protection of Wen.

For Taiwan, pushing for China's democratization is a more imperative issue than having Beijing remove the missiles targeting Taiwan, because this is the greatest debt the Chinese communists owe to China's modernization and its 1.3 billion people. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 2, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Young doctors have little dignity

TEXT.P: Two abnormal phenomena are prevalent in the medical sector. Fewer medical students are specializing in internal medicine, surgery, pediatrics, obstetrics and gynecology, and more are concentrating on plastic surgery. The number of practicing doctors switching to plastic surgery is also increasing, resulting in a decrease in the number of life-saving doctors.

The phenomena can be attributed to the heavy stress, difficult work and high risk of being sued that life-saving doctors face. In addition, the income of plastic surgeons is higher than hospital doctors because plastic surgery is not covered by the National Health Insurance (NHI) and patients are required to foot the bill by themselves.
For example, a surgeon receives only around NT$50,000 in NHI reimbursement for a unilateral mastectomy, while a plastic surgeon earns NT$100,000 for a thermacool facelift procedure.

Another problem is the low pay for new doctors. A National Taiwan University medical school graduate who has just obtained a medical license must work 15 hours a day and sleep in the hospital at night, but they make only NT$40,000 to NT$60,000 a month.
The low-pay policy for young doctors is driving them away, which will leave the nation critically short of specialist doctors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier hails Hsinchu Science Park
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/10 13:33:02 (C.C. Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih hailed Saturday the achievements of the Hsinchu Science Park, lauding its remarkable production value and protection of labor safety and the environment.

Addressing the inauguration of the Industrial Safety and Environmental Protection Month sponsored by the Hsinchu Science Park Administration, Wu praised the park as the bellwether of Taiwan's industrial development and a guidepost of public work safety.
Wu also cited UMC Chief Operating Officer Wen Yang Chen for the company's good performance in labor safety protection.
National Science Council Minister Lee Lou-chuang, Hsinchu Mayor Hsu Ming-tsai, Hsinchu County Magistrate Chiu Ching-chun and over 2,000 company representatives attended the ceremony.

The park's revenue for the first half of this year totaled NT$569.1 billion (US$18.18 billion), marking an annual increase of 58 percent, Hsinchu Science Park Administration statistics showed. It is expected to record NT$1.2 trillion in revenue for the whole of 2010.
The Hsinchu Science Park, which has 130,000 workers, was established in 1980 and is the best-known of Taiwan's high-tech facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA English news budget for Oct. 2

TEXT.P: Celebration 10. President backs liberalization on higher education 11. CLA steps up search of runaway foreign workers

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's information institute unveils new gadgets

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Institute for Information Industry has unveiled a number of inventions for better social networking, medical care and navigation at an invention fair that runs through Sunday.

The government-sponsored body designed a large white plastic capsule that automatically provides pills at different times of the day, with music and lights to prevent patients from forgetting to take their medication or taking the wrong pills.

"Users can set times on a small tablet device connected to the iCapsule by wireless, helping elderly people take medicine correctly at proper times, " the institute's media contact Chang Shu-yuan told the Central News Agency recently at the Taipei International Invention Show and Technomart.
The 18-by-7 centimeter device stands upright and drops pills into a dish from seven differently colored compartments.
"A patient can also take an individual compartment of pills with them if they need to go out for the entire day, which is quite convenient, "she said.
The invention will be one of the entries competing for the German International Forum Design Award later this year, according to the institute.
Another invention of the institute's is a small device called "pippo" that allows users to quickly swap personal information through radio-frequency identification with just one click of the device.
The device is 3 centimeters in width and length and can be integrated with social websites such as Facebook and Twitter.
In addition to creating new inventions, the institute has demonstrated at the fair how it can improve on existing technologies.

For example, the institute made public "i-WANT" technology for navigation devices or mobile phones. I-WANT can increase the navigational accuracy of these devices from the 5-20 meter range to a distance of 1-3 meters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Accident exposes foreign worker issues

TEXT.P: "Why there were illegal foreign laborers at a national expressway construction project? " Premier Wu Den-yih asked Friday after an accident at a construction site on the No. 6 Freeway in central Taiwan took seven lives a day earlier. Six of the victims were later found to be runaway Indonesian workers.

Wu instructed the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) to immediately investigate how the contractors for the project were allowed to employ runaway foreign workers without being brought to justice.
He also asked relevant authorities to look into what caused the fatal collapse of a 50-meter tall, 80-meter wide section of scaffolding used in the construction of a freeway interchange.
"Anyone found accountable should be brought to justice. Nobody should be let off, " Wu said in a determining tone.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

CLA statistics showed that the number of foreign workers who are unaccounted for has reached 33,000. "Where are they now? " Wu asked, suspecting the laborers, who entered Taiwan legally but failed to show up at their declared place of work, have been working in the country illegally.

National Immigration Agency Director-General Hsieh Li-kung said the agency has identified four of the six Indonesian victims -- three entered Taiwan as "fishing workers, " and the other as a factory worker.

Hsieh said he believed the increasing number of illegal foreign workers resulted from a constant shortage of workers at construction sites and local employers' practice of hiring illegal foreign workers to cut down the costs.
"These are the culprits" that lured foreign workers away from the obligations of their contracts, Hsieh said. (Oct. 2, 2011).
China Times:

Bad policies were the leading reasons that pushed foreign laborers to leave the workplace where they were legally employed. They included the fact foreign workers from countries like Indonesia and Vietnam are all required to apply for a loan -- no matter how unnecessary the money is to them -- from a bank in Taiwan before they are permitted to come to the island for work.
After they begin work, the laborers are also obliged to pay their broker NT$1,700 (US$55) every month in fees. Some unethical brokers impose even more charges.

The wage system is also a problem. While the standard wage for a factory worker who works eight hours a day is NT$17,280 a month, those hired as "family workers" can have monthly salaries of only NT$15,840. Some of them have to work around the clock if they attend sick, elderly people.
In addition, light punishments for employing runaway foreign workers have also been blamed for the growing number of illegal workers. (Oct. 2, 2011).
Liberty Times:
CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan stressed that all the contractors and subcontractors for the freeway interchange project would be investigated following the fatal collapse.
Those found hiring runaway foreign workers will be fined up to NT$750,000, with a prison sentence of up to three years for repeat offenders, Wang said.
Although Premier Wu demanded a crackdown on the employment of runaway foreign workers, officials had trouble finding efficient measures to carry out the order.

Chou Chun-teng, head of the CLA Central Region Inspection Office, said that in their unannounced checks at construction sites, they seldom find illegal workers. Their inspectors have to pass control personnel before being allowed to enter the construction site, and the procedure exposes their mission, he said. (Oct. 2, 2011).

DOC.HEADLINE: Fiji grants visa-free privileges to Taiwanese tourists
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/10 15:13:12 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of the Fiji Islands has granted visa-free privileges to Taiwanese passport holders, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday.
The ministry said in a statement that Taiwanese citizens with hotel reservations in Fiji and onward air tickets will be eligible for visa-free entry, entitling them to stay for up to four months.
The ministry said the decision by the Fijian government is expected to encourage more Taiwanese tourists to go to the South Pacific country.
The visa-free privileges are also expected to enhance business exchanges between Taiwan and Fiji, according to the ministry.
MOFA statistics show that around 2,000 Taiwanese tourists visit Fiji each year.

The ministry said that since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May 2008, one of the government's diplomatic priorities has been to push for visa-free privileges from countries that have no formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
So far, a total of 33 countries, including New Zealand, Ireland, Britain, Japan, South Korea and Singapore, have granted visa-free privileges to Taiwanese tourists, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: First cold front of the season to hit Taiwan Sunday

TEXT.P: The first cold front of the season will hit Taiwan Sunday, bringing lows of 21 degrees Celsius, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Saturday.
Daytime temperatures will range between 23 degrees and 31 degrees Celsius in northern Taiwan, which is expected to be the most affected area, the bureau said.
The CWB forecast also said there would be a chance of heavy rain in northern and northeastern Taiwan.
Temperatures will have returned to normal by Oct. 6, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign students make multinational banner for ROC Centennial

TEXT.P: A group of 80 foreign high school exchange students showed their affection for Taiwan by sewing a banner Saturday composed of their countries' flags as a warm- up event for next year's Republic of China centennial celebration.

The three-meter by 13-meter patchwork banner, which includes the national flags of 23 countries, will make its debut at this year's Double Ten national day parade, in which more than 100 students from six continents will dress in traditional costumes and carry the banner to symbolize the friendship between Taiwan and the respective countries.

The idea of making a multinational banner was pitched by the ROC Centenary Foundation and the Rotary International District 3520 in the hope that more of Taiwan's international friends can participate in honoring the country's centennial.

"One of the most important parts of the celebration is to increase Taiwan's international exposure by letting the world see Taiwan, and we hope more of Taiwan's foreign friends can join in the festivities," said the foundation's Chou Cheng-feng.
Proudly draping the Mexican flag on his back, Luis Rojom said he had always wanted to visit Taiwan after learning about the country in his history classes.
"I wanted to come here to learn Chinese and integrate with my host family to see this beautiful and complex culture, " said the 18-year-old, who is visiting Asia for the first time.
French exchange student Marine Mounier said her experience in Taiwan has been "truly wonderful."
"The Taiwanese people are very nice and friendly. Taipei is a big city and it is very different from my hometown. I really like Taiwan," she said.
The students are members of a one-year exchange program sponsored by Rotary International Taiwan, which sponsors approximately 200 foreign exchanges students each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visa-free privileges for EU expected soon: foreign minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/10 16:30:31 (By T.C. Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The process of securing visa-free privileges for Taiwanese tourists to the European Union is "going smoothly" and the measure might be implemented soon, Minister of Foreign Affairs Timothy C.T. Yang said Saturday.

"The visa-exemption treatment could be provided by the end of this year if approved by the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union," Yang told reporters during a sightseeing tour of eastern Taiwan's Taitung County with foreign ambassadors to Taiwan.
"I am cautiously optimistic about the matter, which has been proceeding smoothly," he said.

According to ministry spokesman James Chang, the European Commission, the EU's executive arm, submitted a proposal in July suggesting that the EU include Taiwan on its Schengen visa-free privilege list.

A working panel of the Council of the European Union and the Committee on Foreign Affairs of the European Parliament discussed the proposal in September and were both positive about granting Taiwanese visitors visa-free privileges, Chang said.
He added that the Council of European Commission and the European Parliament are slated to hold meetings in October or November to screen and vote on the matter.
The Schengen Area comprises the territories of 25 European countries, which include 22 EU member states and three-non EU states -- Norway, Iceland and Switzerland.
The visa-waiver program is also applicable to three non-Schengen EU member states -- Romania, Bulgaria and Cyprus.
The Schengen Area operates very much like a single state for international travel purposes, with border controls for travelers traveling in and out of the area, but with no internal border controls.
Taiwan has so far been given visa-exemption privileges by 33 countries, including New Zealand, Ireland, Britain, Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public works open to private contracts to top NT$200 B in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/10 16:40:44 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The commission said the government has selected 57 public works projects worth about NT$171.3 billion to be offered to private contractors next year, and is studying other potential infrastructure development programs for participation by the private sector.

Among the 57 projects are a Taichung metro system development plan, an economic and trade zone development plan for Kinmen, and four land development plans in Taipei's Xinyi district, the commission said.
The government is hoping to lower its financial burden and stimulate economic activity by encouraging the private sector to invest in infrastructure projects through a variety of business models.

Under the Act for Promotion of Private Participation in Infrastructure Projects, the government offers the private sector incentives such as relaxed rules on land acquisition and preferential tax status to encourage investment.
The commission said it has scheduled a conference for the end of October to unveil the public works projects for 2011 and seek private sector investment.
The commission added that it has set up an office to provide assistance such as financial planning and on-the-job training to private firms interested in participating.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA plans to raise reward for reporting illegal foreign workers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/10 16:49:20 (By Wang Shu-fen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), the top authority on labor affairs, has stepped up measures to crack down on illegal foreign workers in Taiwan, including a plan to raise rewards for people who report them.

A fatal accident at a construction site on a freeway in central Taiwan that killed seven people -- six of them illegal foreign workers -- further exposed the problem of the employment of runaway foreign workers, which Premier Wu Den- yih has ordered must be addressed.
The CLA said that every year, the council has a budget of NT$10 million (US$322,000) for rewarding people who inform on runaway workers.
Each report of an offense that is later proved true is rewarded with NT$5,000. However, the award budget has never been used up, the council said.
The CLA is considering increasing the amount, it said.

CLA statistics show that since Taiwan began to import workers from countries such as Thailand, Indonesia and Vietnam in 1990, the number of runaway foreign workers recorded so far has reached over 90,000.
While some 60,000 runaways have been caught and repatriated, there are more than 30,000 people still unaccounted for, official tallies show.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady hosts lunch party for underprivileged children
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/10 16:58:03 (By Garfie Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: First lady Chow Mei-ching hosted a party at the president's official residence Saturday, treating 50 underprivileged children to her home-made food.

The group of children from Chiayi, Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Hualien counties arrived at the house in downtown Taipei on the first leg of a two-day tour of the capital city under the arrangement of the World Vision Taiwan charity.
Chow, dressed in T-shirt and jeans, greeted the children at the gate with Hsiaojeou, the first family's dog.
In a space decorated with colorful ribbons and posters of animated cartoon characters, the children enjoyed a lunch of salad and jam sandwiches prepared by Chow.
President Ma Ying-jeou was absent during the meal because of his tight itinerary, but returned home before the departure of the children to see them off.

According to World Vision Taiwan, Ma and Chow have over the past 13 years sponsored seven Taiwanese children through the World Vision program, six of whom have visited the presidential residence with their siblings.

DOC.HEADLINE: New diagnostic tool recommended for young picky eaters

TEXT.P: The Child Health Promotion Society of Taiwan is launching a new easy-to-use diagnostic tool for pediatricians and parents concerned by their children's picky eating habits, the organization's president, Lee Hung-chang, announced at a press conference Saturday.

IMFeD, or identification and management of feeding difficulties, a tool based on six classifications of feeding difficulty, is already widely applied in some Southeast Asian countries but is not yet popular in Taiwan, a place where, according to a 2006 study, 60 percent of children aged 1 to 10 do not have a balanced diet, Lee said.
IMFeD consists of a tear-off questionnaire that parents can easily complete before going to a clinic, helping physicians to identify underlying reasons for feeding difficulty.
There are many reasons contributing to feeding difficulties, said Chao Hsun- chin, a doctor from Chang Gung Memorial Hospital who specializes in pediatric gastroenterology and hepatology.

Chao said that because the questionnaire narrows down the possible causes into six categories, doctors can use it as a reference in choice of treatment, whereas parents can see their children's physical condition more objectively and approach the problem methodically.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese delegation wins US$36 million in orders in Indonesia
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/10 17:12:07 (By Lin Hui-chun, Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: A trade and investment delegation led by Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen- shiang has won orders worth US$36 million in Indonesia during a three-day visit, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Saturday.
The delegation, which returned to Taipei earlier in the day, held several business seminars during the visit, attracting about 1,200 potential buyers, the MOEA said.

The delegation comprised more than 150 representatives from around 100 major Taiwanese companies, including Teco Group, Winbond Electronics Corp., CPC Corp. Taiwan, Tainan Enterprises Co. and Taiwan Sugar Corp.

The ministry said the delegation was the largest trade and investment group from Taiwan to visit the Southeast Asian country and shows that Taiwan's business sector pays great attention to the Indonesian market.
Shih met with Gita Wirjawan, head of Indonesia's Coordinating Investment Board, while the other delegates visited major industrial zones looking for business opportunities.
Packed with abundant natural resources and a huge population, Indonesia has become one of the most important markets in Southeast Asia, the ministry said.
The ministry said there is room for Taiwan and Indonesia to work together economically, especially after the signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) across the Taiwan Strait.

Indonesia and Taiwan can complement each other in industrial development, as Taiwan is strong in the information technology, machinery and auto component industries, while Indonesia has an edge in the oil, natural gas, timber, rubber and textile industries, it added.
Taiwan's accumulated investments in Indonesia total US$13.95 billion, according to the ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four of six dead Indonesian workers identified

TEXT.P: Four out of six Indonesian workers killed in a freeway construction collapse have been identified and officials have been working round the clock to identify the other two, an immigration official said Saturday.
Seven workers, including the six Indonesians, were killed and two others were injured after a sprawling network of scaffolding at a construction site for a No. 6 Freeway exit ramp collapsed Sept. 30.

As of Saturday, the four identified workers were 29-year-old Sutarji, 24-year- old Sunaryo, 31-year-old Suprapto and 20-year-old Sirmanto, according to Chang Chi, deputy director-general of the National Immigration Agency (NIA).
According to the NIA, the six workers were all undocumented migrant workers who had fled their previous employers and had overstayed their visas for up to three years.

The agency was working closely with the Indonesian Economic and Trade Office in Taipei -- Indonesia's representative office in Taiwan -- and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to help the families of the dead workers to get to Taiwan as soon as possible, Chang said.

The accident has brought up widespread social ramifications, with Premier Wu Den-yih pledging to enforce a crackdown on undocumented foreign workers and domestic employers and contractors who illegally hire migrant workers.
Wu has also instructed the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to uphold the human rights of the dead workers and to provide their families with as much assistance as possible.

There were 151,723 Indonesian workers in Taiwan as of the end of August, according to figures from the Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training under the CLA. The number accounted for more than 40 percent of the 372,146 migrant workers in Taiwan at that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. scholar backs liberalization in Taiwan's higher education
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/10 17:35:54 (By Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A U.S. scholar has expressed support for Taiwan's policy of opening its universities to Chinese students, saying the step is essential if Taiwanese universities are to stay competitive.

According to William C. Kirby, a distinguished service professor at Harvard University and a historian of modern China, internalization is a big challenge for universities both in Taiwan and the United States when their counterparts in China are growing fast in size and quality and are becoming increasingly internationalized.

"Taiwan and the United States have to move fast to recruit the very best from anywhere, " Kirby said in a dialogue with President Ma Ying-jeou that was featured in the latest edition of Ma's online video journal released Saturday.
Kirby pointed out that universities in China are getting stronger by recruiting students and faculty not only from all over China but also from Hong Kong, Taiwan and the United States.
The School of Economics and Management of Tsinghua University, for example, has a high percentage of foreign students and half of its courses are taught in English, he said.
Taiwan, however, enjoys great advantages that are not found in China, such as democracy, rule of law and a long-standing spirit of open inquiry, he said.

"If its (Taiwan's) education system can truly be as open as its economy has become and seek the best faculty and the best students from all sources, it will be the best in Asia, and it will be a natural magnet for talent in the coming decade," Kirby said.
Ma for his part said the recognition of Chinese diplomas and the admission of Chinese students to universities in Taiwan are the first steps in internationalizing Taiwan's universities.
"A democratic and free society cannot close its doors, nor can it be an ostrich" with its head in the sand, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC head reiterates principle of China policy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/10 17:58:01 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan reiterated Saturday that "putting Taiwan first for the benefit of the people" is the highest principle of Taiwan's China policy and that the people of Taiwan have the right to choose the future direction of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Speaking at a seminar in Taipei on continuity and changes in cross-strait relations from 2008 to 2010, Lai said the core rights of Taiwan's people are a key foundation for developing cross-strait relations and she noted that democracy, sovereignty and security are rights that should be protected.
"It also needs to be ensured that the people have the right to decide the future development of cross-strait relations, " Taiwan's top China policy planner said.
Lai said the people of Taiwan should have the right to meaningfully take part in international affairs, compete in a fair trade environment and not be discriminated against by other countries.
"Taiwan has the right to negotiate and sign economic agreements with its trade partners," she added.
Taiwan's underprivileged traditional industries, agriculture and labor should be protected by the government during the process of regional integration, she said.
Once those core rights and interests are understood and respected, cross- strait relations can be developed in a healthy way, Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan smart clothes rack wins gold at invention fair

TEXT.P: A rack designed by a Taiwanese inventor that automatically prevents drying clothes from getting rained on impressed judges at one of Asia's largest invention shows Saturday, taking a gold award.
When a drop of rain falls on a sensor on the clothes rack, the rack pulls the clothes under a cover to prevent the garments from getting wet.
When the rain stops, the clothes automatically come out of the cover, said the inventor, Yang Yen-tang, at the Taipei International Invention Show and Technomart set to end the following day.
When the sun goes down, the rack also pulls the clothes under the cover, Yang said.
"I originally designed this for my wife because she likes to dry clothes in the sun after laundering them, " the 66-year-old told reporters at the fair.
Yang, who has also won awards in South Korea for his invention, was one of 137 gold winners at Taiwan's largest invention show.
A total of 962 entries from 18 countries took part in the competition, with 832 entries from Taiwan and 130 entries from other countries featuring more than 2,000 new inventions and technologies
Taiwan was the top winner with 113 gold awards, 115 silvers and 153 bronzes.
It was followed by Malaysia with 15 medals, Russia with 14 medals and South Korea with seven medals.

The show, now in its sixth year, has been growing steadily, said Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Huang Chung-chiou at the award ceremony. He noted that the government has been providing consulting and financial assistance to help local inventors commercialize their ideas.
The number of entries this year rose 38 percent from last year, while the number of participating countries soared 50 percent, hitting a six-year high, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Candidates urged to promise to protect animals
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/10 19:16:16 (By Kelven Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Animal rights advocates established an animal protection policy monitoring league Saturday and urged the candidates running in the Nov. 27 municipality mayoral and council elections to promise to protect animal rights.
The activists, mostly web users who love animals, also called for voters to cast their ballots for candidates who promise to protect animals if they are elected.

Huang Tai-shan, one of the league's founders, said its main mission includes promoting amendments to the Animal Protection Act and pushing the municipal election candidates to endorse a pledge to treat animals in a decent manner.

Candidates will be asked to promise that if they are elected, they will set up animal protection departments in their respective municipal governments and deploy police to crack down on illegal breeders and animal abuse cases, he said.
The league will publish the names of candidates who agree to sign the endorsement ahead of the Nov. 27 elections for the reference of animal-loving voters, Huang said.

Another of the founders, Ho Chung-hsun, said that the Animal Protection Act does not protect animals at all and accused local governments of using it to kill nearly 100,000 stray cats and dogs a year.
Ho said he hopes those elected in the coming elections will set limits on killing strays and move to amend the regulations, as they are not useful in efforts to protect animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese boyband takes fans on trip to Hualien
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/10 19:17:48 (By Wang Shu-fen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese boyband Fahrenheit served as a "conductor for a day" on a tourist train to the eastern county of Hualien Saturday, attracting more than 1,000 fans from 15 countries.

Fans from Japan and South Korea, where the act is particularly popular, screamed and waved when they saw their idols appear at the Taipei Train Station. Other fans came from as far afield as New Zealand, Australia, Europe and the United States.

This is the second year the four-member group has been appointed by the Tourism Bureau as a Taiwan tourism ambassador. Prior to the start of the train journey, the boys also promoted the locally famous train lunch box.

After the train arrived in Hualien, the group accompanied the fans on a visit to Liyu Lake and introduced indigenous culture there. The four members of the group also promoted some new sightseeing spots in Hualien and Taitung.

The group, formed in 2006, conducted three press conferences in Japan and South Korea in March to promote tourism in Taiwan. It also led a group of 850 fans on a trip to the northeast coast of Taiwan in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan unveils microalgal biofuel technology
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/10 19:58:24 (By Wei Shu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: A research institute unveiled Saturday a Taiwan-developed technology for producing biofuel from microalgae, as part of efforts to target the growing environmentally friendly renewable energy industry.

The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) , which developed the technology, showed off the process of turning microalgae into biodiesel at the four-day Taipei International Invention Show and Technomart exhibition organized by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council and scheduled to end the following day.
Microalgae, which has extraordinary potential for cultivation as an energy crop, consumes large quantities of carbon dioxide and produces oxygen through photosynthesis.

During the process of consuming carbon dioxide, microalgae turns carbon dioxide into materials containing oil. The ITRI uses these materials to produce crude lipids that can then be converted into biodiesel. According to the ITRI, one gram of algae will produce 0.5 grams of lipids.
"Taiwan is encircled by the ocean, which makes it very convenient for obtaining microalgae to produce biodiesel, " said Lin Yun-hui, a manager of the ITRI's biofuel laboratory.
Lin said a liter of ocean water contains 1 gram of microalgae, which can be multiplied to about 5 grams after a week of cultivation.
"However, we have invented multi-layer filters that are able to boost the density of the microalgae in ocean water and extract about 120-150 grams from a single liter of ocean water," Lin said.
However, Lin noted that production costs of microalgae biodiesel are high and said it remains to be seen when such fuel will be commercially viable.

The ITRI's microalgal biofuel production technology development has been financially sponsored by the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs in a four-year project that started in 2009 and will cost a total of NT$240 million (US$7.67 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan weighs subsidized IVF to boost birth rate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/10 21:36:16 (By Chen Ching-fang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The government is weighing the feasibility of subsidizing in-vitro fertilization (IVF) treatment in an effort to slow the continuing decline in the birth rate, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Saturday.
If the subsidy program is adopted and offered to infertile couples, the official said, the number of newborns could increase by an estimated 1,000 to 2,000 a year.

Chao Kun-yu, deputy director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion (BHP), said the bureau has drafted two potential IVF subsidy programs for the reference of the Ministry of the Interior's (MOI's) Population Policy Committee.
One of the proposals requires the government to offer each infertile couple NT$50,000 (US$1,609) in IVF subsidies per year, while the other calls for an annual subsidy of NT$150,000, Chao said.
"The first option would cost the national coffers about NT$600 million per year, and the needed outlay would spike to NT$2.2 billion if the second option were to be adopted," Chao said.
According to DOH statistics, more than 6,000 local married couples receive IVF treatment each year, with some couples receiving multiple treatments in a single year, Chao said.

The BHP has assessed that the number of IVF treatments would increase by 50 percent if the government were to subsidize each couple by NT$50,000 a year and could double if the subsidy was raised to NT$150,000.
IVF, which costs between NT$150,000 and NT$250,000 per treatment, is not covered by the national health insurance program.

According to Chao, the MOI asked the BHP to assess the efficacy of subsidizing IVF treatment after Tseng Chi-jui, dean of Taipei Medical University's College of Medicine came up with the proposal recently.

Tseng, an expert in reproductive medicine, said the government's plan to offer child-rearing subsidies for third and subsequent children under two years of age would be less effective in encouraging people to have more children than offering IVF subsidies.

"The government should follow the lead of Japan, South Korea and Singapore and subsidize IVF, which would be far more effective in raising our country's birth rate, " Tseng wrote in an article carried in a local newspaper.

BHP Director-General Chiu Shu-ti echoed Tseng's view Saturday, saying that the MOI-proposed incentives to encourage married couples to have second or third children are ineffective because most couples only want one child.
Chiu said she looks forward to an early launch of the subsidy program to help promote child birth.

Taiwan's fertility rate -- the average number of children born to a woman over her lifetime -- has been on a steady decline since reaching 1.6 in 2001. It hit a low of 1.03 in 2009, the world's second lowest, higher only than that of Germany.

A biennial demographic assessment released by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) in August said the country's fertility rate could drop further to an estimated 0.94 this year because of the traditional superstition that the Year of the Tiger is not a good time for babies to be born.
Taiwan has also lagged behind other major Asian countries in terms of birth rate -- the average annual number of births during a year per 1,000 persons in the population.
According to the latest CEPD estimate, Taiwan's population will reach zero population growth in 2022, four years earlier than previously forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: President sends condolences over death of Mrs.Lee Kuan Yew
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/10 22:10:04 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng, Garfie Lee and Sofia wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou sent condolences to Singapore Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew over the death of his wife, who died earlier Saturday, a spokesman said.
The president and Vice President Vincent Siew had been briefed on the news and both sent their condolences, said Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang.
Messages of condolences were conveyed via Taiwan's representative to Singapore, Vanessa Shih, according to Lo.
Kwa Geok Choo, the wife of the Singapore's first prime minister and the mother of its current leader, died after suffering strokes in 2008. She was 89.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan smart clothes rack wins gold at invention fair

TEXT.P: A rack designed by a Taiwanese inventor that automatically prevents drying clothes from getting rained on impressed judges at one of Asia's largest invention shows Saturday, taking a gold award.
When a drop of rain falls on a sensor on the clothes rack, the rack pulls the clothes under a cover to prevent the garments from getting wet.
When the rain stops, the clothes automatically come out of the cover, said the inventor, Yang Yen-tang, at the Taipei International Invention Show and Technomart set to end the following day.
When the sun goes down, the rack also pulls the clothes under the cover, Yang said.
"I originally designed this for my wife because she likes to dry clothes in the sun after laundering them, " the 66-year-old told reporters at the fair.
Yang, who has also won awards in South Korea for his invention, was one of 137 gold winners at Taiwan's largest invention show.
A total of 962 entries from 18 countries took part in the competition, with 832 entries from Taiwan and 130 entries from other countries featuring more than 2,000 new inventions and technologies
Taiwan was the top winner with 113 gold awards, 115 silvers and 153 bronzes.
It was followed by Malaysia with 15 medals, Russia with 14 medals and South Korea with seven medals.

The show, now in its sixth year, has been growing steadily, said Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Huang Chung-chiou at the award ceremony. He noted that the government has been providing consulting and financial assistance to help local inventors commercialize their ideas.
The number of entries this year rose 38 percent from last year, while the number of participating countries soared 50 percent, hitting a six-year high, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Candidates urged to promise to protect animals
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/10 19:16:16 (By Kelven Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Animal rights advocates established an animal protection policy monitoring league Saturday and urged the candidates running in the Nov. 27 municipality mayoral and council elections to promise to protect animal rights.
The activists, mostly web users who love animals, also called for voters to cast their ballots for candidates who promise to protect animals if they are elected.

Huang Tai-shan, one of the league's founders, said its main mission includes promoting amendments to the Animal Protection Act and pushing the municipal election candidates to endorse a pledge to treat animals in a decent manner.

Candidates will be asked to promise that if they are elected, they will set up animal protection departments in their respective municipal governments and deploy police to crack down on illegal breeders and animal abuse cases, he said.
The league will publish the names of candidates who agree to sign the endorsement ahead of the Nov. 27 elections for the reference of animal-loving voters, Huang said.

Another of the founders, Ho Chung-hsun, said that the Animal Protection Act does not protect animals at all and accused local governments of using it to kill nearly 100,000 stray cats and dogs a year.
Ho said he hopes those elected in the coming elections will set limits on killing strays and move to amend the regulations, as they are not useful in efforts to protect animals.
