DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 3, or the 26th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1863: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln officially designates the last Thursday of November a national holiday, to be called Thanksgiving Day.
1867: Elias Howe, the U.S. inventor and manufacturer who designed early sewing machines, dies at the age of 48. He patented the sewing machine and made about US$2 million from the patent, subsequently winning patent-infringement suits against a number of manufacturers, including Isaac M. Singer.
1888: Carl von Ossietzky, the German journalist and pacifist who won the 1935 Nobel Peace Prize, is born. He was imprisoned for exposing Germany's military buildup.
1929: Yugoslavia becomes the official name of the Kingdom of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes.
1932: Iraq becomes independent after the British mandate ends.
1952: The first British atomic weapon is exploded off the Monte Bello Islands, west of Australia.
1963: President Ramon Villeda Morales of Honduras is overthrown in a military coup.
1966: Lesotho, which was formerly governed by Britain as the Protectorate of Basutoland, becomes independent.
1970: "Yu Chao," the first 100,000-ton oil tanker built in Taiwan, is launched. "Yu Chao" is the name of a legendary Chinese ruler who taught the people to build tree houses for protection against wild beasts.
1972: Armando Yoshida Vaca, new Bolivian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1972: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko sign a pact limiting the number of defensive missiles of their respective countries to 200.
1973: Gen. Robert E. Cushman, commandant of the U.S. Marine Corps, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The sixth World Chinese Pharmacists Amity Conference opens in Taipei.
1975: The 10th World Chinese Traders Conference opens in Taipei with more than 900 overseas Chinese from 57 countries and areas attending.
1976: ROC Finance Minister Walter H. Fei leaves for Manila for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
1976: Jack Davis, president of Rotary International from 1977 to 1978, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1977: Former Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is arrested on corruption charges.
1989: Troops loyal to Panamanian strongman Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega crush a coup attempt by junior officers.
1990: Singapore and mainland China establish diplomatic relations.
1990: East and West Germany formally unite to become the single nation of Germany, with Berlin as its capital and Helmut Kohl as provisional chancellor.
1995: Manuel Saturnino da Costa, prime minister of Guinea-Bissau, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1997: A powerful earthquake rocks central Italy, causing more damage to the frescoed interior of the 13th-century Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi.
1997: Japan's magnetically levitated train breaks the world speed record for a manned train when it is clocked at 451 kilometers per hour on an experimental track west of Tokyo.
1999: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs extends its appreciation for the efforts of the 25 countries that support membership in the United Nations for the ROC.
2000: Premier Tang Fei announces his resignation after a four-month period in office, the shortest premiership in ROC history.
2001: Dr. Chern Jeng-shing, an official with the Republic of China's Cabinet- level National Science Council (NSC), is elected a member of the prestigious International Academy of Astronautics (IAA).
2001: The Hong Kong branch of the Taiwan-based United World Chinese Commercial Bank (UWCCB) opens, becoming the eighth Hong Kong branch of Taiwan-funded banks.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Confronted with the spiritual powers of the universe, a man must be able to maintain moral law without any doubts. He must be prepared to wait a hundred generations without any misgivings for the coming of a man of perfect divine nature to confirm moral law."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China Times: The Jody Chiang phenomenon

TEXT.P: After over 30 years in the trade, Jody Chiang, one of the most successful singers of her generation in Taiwan, has been all the more remarkable in recent concerts -- to the thrill of audiences of all ages.
Tickets to Chiang's latest concerts have been sold at amazing speed, and she has been forced to add additional dates to satisfy her fans.

Chiang, who started her singing career at the age of 12 in Japanese-style pubs in Taipei and went on to become a pop queen, singing in Taiwanese, won the hearts of the audiences not only because her evergreen popularity backed up by her numerous classics, but also because of her amazing singing voice, which enthralls practically anyone who hears it.

She has not been absent from Taiwan's pop music arena for a single year and has remained popular on all stages -- from club performances in the years when Taiwan's economy was taking off, to TV shows some 20 years ago, to live concerts in the high-technology era in the most recent decade.

Her songs have, in a certain sense, become a window of Taiwanese people's collective sentiments and morale over the decades -- ranging from life's anxiety and uncertainties, to the loneliness of people who have left their homes to work in the cities.

Let's embrace the valuable phenomenon of Jody Chiang, who has been nicknamed by many as "the second sister." She is actually the sister of everybody in Taiwan. (Editorial abstract -- China Times, Oct. 3, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Give foreign laborers viable options
DOC.DATELINE: Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) 10/03/10 16:19:29 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Chairwoman Wang Ju-hsuan said Saturday that her council will convene a meeting at the end of this month to study whether to allow foreign laborers to switch employers freely to reduce the number of foreign laborers who abscond from their jobs.
Wang made the remarks after a fatal accident at a construction site on the No. 6 Freeway in central Taiwan earlier in the week. Six of the victims were later found to be runaway Indonesian workers.

Foreign workers on Taiwan's public construction projects reportedly have to spend at least half of their permitted time in Taiwan -- 18 months -- simply to pay back their labor brokerage fees. Some are even forced to return to their countries before they have repaid these fees, which encourages them to leave their jobs and seek illegal work.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Liberty Times:

Foreign labor rights groups believe that the main reason foreign workers abscond is because they cannot switch employers freely. For this reason, what the government should do is not step up a crackdown on foreign workers, but allow them to switch employers freely, the groups said.
In response, Wang said that the matter will be discussed in a meeting on foreign labor policy later this month.

To protect the rights of employers, if the policy is put into practice, there will also need to be complementary measures, such as giving the original employers notice of three months or longer to allow them time to find replacements.
At present, foreign laborers can switch jobs and are not subject to restrictions of region or sector. For example, a foreign caregiver in Pingtung can switch jobs to work in a factory in Taoyuan.

However, as a change of job requires the consent of both the original and prospective employers, if the employers do not agree to the switch, foreign laborers still find that the easiest option is to abscond and work illegally.
The human rights advocates have therefore asked for further easing of restrictions, allowing foreign laborers to more easily switch jobs. (Oct. 3, 2010)
China Times:
Ku Yu-ling, president of the Taiwan International Workers' Association, said that those foreign laborers who are able repay their brokerage fees are the lucky ones.

She noted that many factories in Taiwan closed during the financial crisis that began two years ago, and that many foreign workers lost their jobs after just a few months in Taiwan, leaving them heavily in debt.

Ku said foreign workers have to pay on average between NT$80,000 and NT$250,000 in brokerage fees, and added that according to the results of a survey, foreign workers have to spend at least 18 months "working for nothing."
In addition, a large number of foreign workers employed as caregivers reportedly have to work very long hours.
These caregivers are nominally employed only to take care of patients, but are often also expected to clean and cook, with no time off.

Foreign workers working in Taiwanese homes are divided into two groups -- housemaids and caregivers. However, the conditions for employing a housemaid are strict and only around 2,000 families in Taiwan can meet the requirements.

Employing a caregivers, however, is much easier, and about 180,000 families apply to employ them. Although the conditions for employing them are more lax, they should only be tasked with caring for designated patients and should not be asked to do other household work.
But Ku said that because caregivers work within families, the authorities are usually unable to monitor them, and employers often simply treat them as servants. (Oct. 3, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Facebook blocks Taiwan's weather bureau

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau (CWB) has said that its weather forecasting service on the world's largest social networking site, Facebook, has been blocked "for unknown reasons" for about a week.
The bureau said in a Sept. 29 statement that it had been barred from posting Facebook messages since Sept. 27.
In a recent notice to the bureau, Facebook cited a "violation of user rules" as a reason for the ban, according to the bureau's statement.
The bureau has received no response from the Facebook administrators, despite repeated requests for an explanation for the ban, the statement said.

Liu Guo-long, deputy head of the bureau's Meteorological Information Center, told Taiwan's Chinese-language daily Liberty Times Sept. 30 that the bureau had read all the Facebook rules and still was at a loss as to what rules it had violated.
The bureau therefore simply started a similar service on a new Facebook account, the statement reads.
The banned page had attracted 25,371 followers since it was set up June 10, while the new page had already attracted 1,006 followers.
On Sept. 4, Facebook imposed a ban on a CWB official who used the website in a private capacity to issue weather forecasts, because he posted copyright- protected photographs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese girl youngest medalist at invention show

TEXT.P: An 18-year-old Taiwanese girl who invented a pair of modified chopsticks has become the youngest medalist this year at one of Asia's largest invention shows that ended Sunday in Taipei.

Hsu Wei-ju won a bronze medal and two special awards in the categories of female inventor and young inventor at the Taipei International Invention Show and Technomart, the organizers announced Saturday.
"The award took her by surprise and it is her first invention, " said her mother, who received the awards on her daughter's behalf.
"It took her six months to produce the chopsticks," she added.

The prize-winning chopsticks are made of medical-grade stainless steel, while most other metal chopsticks are made of industrial stainless steel. In addition, her mother said, most telescopic chopsticks on the market are inconvenient to wash, but Hsu's design improves on this flaw, making them easier to clean.
A total of 962 entries from 18 countries took part in the competition, with 832 entries from Taiwan and 130 entries from other countries, featuring more than 2,000 new inventions and technologies.
Taiwan was the top winner with 113 gold awards, 115 silvers and 153 bronzes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four quakes jolt Yilan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 3 (CNA) 10/03/10 16:59:33 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A string of four earthquakes, including a magnitude 5 temblor, jolted Taiwan's northeastern Yilan area early Sunday morning, with no casualties reported, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
The magnitude 5 quake occurred at 3: 23 a.m., with its epicenter located 6.9 km southwest of the county's Nanao, according to the CWB's Seismology Center.
The temblor also had an intensity of 5.0 in Taroko Gorge and Hoping Rural Township in the neighboring county of Hualien, according to the center.
The quake had an intensity of 4.0 in the townships of Suao and Luodong in Yilan County and at Hehuanshan in central Nantou County, the center said.
Earthquake monitoring stations in other areas north of the southern county of Chiayi also recorded the jolt, center officials said.
The magnitude 5 temblor was followed by three aftershocks before 6: 35 a.m. that day -- of magnitudes of 3.5, 3.1 and 3.1, respectively.
Center officials said the four jolts were normal seismological activity that helped release accumulations of tectonic pressure that regularly builds up in the area.

Eastern Taiwan is located on a juncture between the Philippine Sea and the Eurasian tectonic plates, where underground activity is common and tectonic pressure regularly builds up, according to Kuo Kai-wen, director of the CWB's Seismology Center.

The center welcomed 10 mild earthquakes, including a magnitude 5.1 temblor, that shook Hualien County over 15 hours from Sept. 28 as constructive tectonic activity that helped release underground pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Damage from FPG plant fire hard to estimate: manager
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 3 (CNA) 10/03/10 17:04:29 (By Huang Kuo-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A fire that broke out early Sunday at a plant belonging to Nanya Plastics Corp., one of the pivotal companies of the Formosa Plastic Group (FPG) , has created another great challenge faced by the group since two fires at its petrochemical complex in Yunlin County in July.
"The damage caused by the fire is hard to estimate. It's gone, " said Chen Wen- yang, a deputy manager of the plant, after the fire, which broke out at around 8:30 a.m.

The Nanya Second Plant, located in Taibao City in the southern county of Chiayi, is Taiwan's only manufacturer of high-class, waterproof synthetic paper known as White Pearl, or PEPA, used mainly for labeling bottles.
According to the results of an initial investigation by firefighters, the fire was found to have probably been caused by a leakage of fuel oil in the plant's electrical control room.

The fire engulfed the plant, which had stocks of resin, methylbenzene and lubricant, sending billows of black smoke into the air for several hours. As of noon, the fire still had not been extinguished.
No injuries were reported, Chen said.
Plant authorities said that the chemicals are not classed as controlled substances, but warned that contact with the smoke from the fire could cause skin irritation.
Chiayi Magistrate Chang Hwa-kuan immediately went to the scene of the blaze, where she announced the fire to be a major industrial hazard.
She ordered the establishment of an emergency response center, blocked off access to areas surrounding the plant and set up a medical attention station.
Nearly 100 residents from nearby boroughs staged protests at the plant to vent their anger after the fire.
The protesters demanded compensation on a par with that offered by FPG to residents in Yunlin after the two fires that occurred there in July, according to Yeh Chuan-cheng, a borough chief.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Flora Expo to begin three-week trial run Oct. 9

However, some city councilors said the trial run might fail to reflect the real situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suspect arrested for selling online counterfeits
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 3 (CNA) 10/03/10 19:32:16 (By Yeh Tzu-kang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A suspect has been arrested for selling counterfeit products online, intellectual property rights police in Chiayi, southern Taiwan, said Sunday.

The police said they nailed the suspect, identified only by his surname of Kuo, in Tainan, southern Taiwan, and seized nearly 2,000 items of fake brand name products, which they estimated to be worth about NT$10 million (US$317,460).

Police said they were tipped off a month earlier about people importing fake items bearing brand names such as Louis Vuitton, Gucci, Swarovski, Tiffany and Cartier, including jewelry and crystal, and selling them online.
The results of an initial investigation found that the suspect had been operating for six months. He was turned over to the Chiayi Prosecutors Office for violations of the trademark law.

DOC.HEADLINE: Toxic disaster response team mobilized following FPG plant fire
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 3 (CNA) 10/03/10 19:53:54 (By Huang Kuo-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) dispatched a toxic disaster response team to a plant belonging to Nanya Plastics Corp. in the southern county of Chiayi Sunday after a fire engulfed the plant, causing massive air pollution.

Nanya Plastics Corp, one of the pivotal companies of the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG), was ordered by the Chiayi County government to immediately suspend operations in the wake of the fire that took eight hours to extinguish.

The county government also handed out a fine of NT$1 million (US$31,250) to Nanya for the severe air pollution caused by the fire. Although the levels of sulfides and nitrogen oxide in the black smoke that billowed from the plant were within allowable levels, the odor concentration of the smoke far exceeded allowable levels, said the Chiayi County Environmental Protection Department.

The fire, which broke out at around 8: 30 a.m. that day, engulfed the plant, which had stocks of resin, methylbenzene and lubricant, sending thick black smoke into the air for several hours. The fire was not extinguished until 4 p.m.
No injuries were reported.

The Nanya Second Plant, located in Taibao City in the southern county of Chiayi, is Taiwan's only manufacturer of high-class, waterproof synthetic paper known as White Pearl, or PEPA, used mainly for labeling bottles.
The fire dealt another heavy blow to FPG after two fires at the group's petrochemical complex in Yunlin County in July.

FPG Chairman Wang Wen-yuan was reported to be monitoring developments closely since the fire broke out and was said to have instructed Nanya Plastics Corp.'s President, Wu Chia-chao, to "handle the aftermath properly."
Wu estimated that the damage caused to the plant was as high as roughly NT$150 million and that about 30 percent of its production lines were destroyed.
"Part of the production will be now be taken over by Nanya's two other plants in Chiayi County and China," Wu said.
The Nanya Second Plant used to produce some 2,000 tons of PEPA a month, worth between NT$100 million and NT$150 million, according to Wu.
The results of an initial investigation by firefighters suggested that the fire was probably caused by a leakage of fuel oil in the plant's electrical control room.
Chiayi Magistrate Chang Hwa-kuan immediately went to the scene of the blaze, where she announced that the fire had been designated as a major industrial hazard.
She ordered the establishment of an emergency response center, blocked off access to areas surrounding the plant and set up a medical attention station.
Nearly 100 residents from nearby boroughs staged protests at the plant to vent their anger after the fire.
The protesters demanded compensation on a par with that offered by FPG to residents in Yunlin after the two fires that occurred there in July, according to Yeh Chuan-cheng, a borough chief.
The FPG agreed in August to pay up to NT$500 million in compensation for the agricultural and fishery losses caused by the two fires.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should focus on vocational training: vice president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 3 (CNA) 10/03/10 21:11:53 (By Chen Shuei-fang and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew said Sunday that Taiwan's public education program should put more stress on technical and vocational training to help the country cultivate skilled personnel and improve its competitiveness.

Speaking at an award ceremony for the 40th National Skills Competition held in Taichung City, central Taiwan, Siew said manpower cultivation is a major way of continuing Taiwan's economic miracle, since the country lacks natural resources.
"Once you have developed your own skills, you will be able to live a more self- sufficient life," he said.
Taking Germany as an example, Siew said the vocational schools within that country's education system have helped Germany emerge as an industrial power.
He added that an improved talent pool could also increase Taiwan's international competitiveness.
The education authorities should work together to promote vocational education at a deeper level, especially in the area of training teachers and improving international exchanges, he said.
The 46 winners of the skills awards will go forward to participate in the next WorldSkills competition in London, scheduled to take place Oct. 5-8, 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Facebook blocks Taiwan's weather bureau

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau (CWB) has said that its weather forecasting service on the world's largest social networking site, Facebook, has been blocked "for unknown reasons" for about a week.
The bureau said in a Sept. 29 statement that it had been barred from posting Facebook messages since Sept. 27.
In a recent notice to the bureau, Facebook cited a "violation of user rules" as a reason for the ban, according to the bureau's statement.
The bureau has received no response from the Facebook administrators, despite repeated requests for an explanation for the ban, the statement said.

Liu Guo-long, deputy head of the bureau's Meteorological Information Center, told Taiwan's Chinese-language daily Liberty Times Sept. 30 that the bureau had read all the Facebook rules and still was at a loss as to what rules it had violated.
The bureau therefore simply started a similar service on a new Facebook account, the statement reads.
The banned page had attracted 25,371 followers since it was set up June 10, while the new page had already attracted 1,006 followers.
On Sept. 4, Facebook imposed a ban on a CWB official who used the website in a private capacity to issue weather forecasts, because he posted copyright- protected photographs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese girl youngest medalist at invention show

TEXT.P: An 18-year-old Taiwanese girl who invented a pair of modified chopsticks has become the youngest medalist this year at one of Asia's largest invention shows that ended Sunday in Taipei.

Hsu Wei-ju won a bronze medal and two special awards in the categories of female inventor and young inventor at the Taipei International Invention Show and Technomart, the organizers announced Saturday.
"The award took her by surprise and it is her first invention, " said her mother, who received the awards on her daughter's behalf.
"It took her six months to produce the chopsticks," she added.

The prize-winning chopsticks are made of medical-grade stainless steel, while most other metal chopsticks are made of industrial stainless steel. In addition, her mother said, most telescopic chopsticks on the market are inconvenient to wash, but Hsu's design improves on this flaw, making them easier to clean.
A total of 962 entries from 18 countries took part in the competition, with 832 entries from Taiwan and 130 entries from other countries, featuring more than 2,000 new inventions and technologies.
Taiwan was the top winner with 113 gold awards, 115 silvers and 153 bronzes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four quakes jolt Yilan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 3 (CNA) 10/03/10 16:59:33 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A string of four earthquakes, including a magnitude 5 temblor, jolted Taiwan's northeastern Yilan area early Sunday morning, with no casualties reported, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
The magnitude 5 quake occurred at 3: 23 a.m., with its epicenter located 6.9 km southwest of the county's Nanao, according to the CWB's Seismology Center.
The temblor also had an intensity of 5.0 in Taroko Gorge and Hoping Rural Township in the neighboring county of Hualien, according to the center.
The quake had an intensity of 4.0 in the townships of Suao and Luodong in Yilan County and at Hehuanshan in central Nantou County, the center said.
Earthquake monitoring stations in other areas north of the southern county of Chiayi also recorded the jolt, center officials said.
The magnitude 5 temblor was followed by three aftershocks before 6: 35 a.m. that day -- of magnitudes of 3.5, 3.1 and 3.1, respectively.
Center officials said the four jolts were normal seismological activity that helped release accumulations of tectonic pressure that regularly builds up in the area.

Eastern Taiwan is located on a juncture between the Philippine Sea and the Eurasian tectonic plates, where underground activity is common and tectonic pressure regularly builds up, according to Kuo Kai-wen, director of the CWB's Seismology Center.

The center welcomed 10 mild earthquakes, including a magnitude 5.1 temblor, that shook Hualien County over 15 hours from Sept. 28 as constructive tectonic activity that helped release underground pressure.
