"Once you have developed your own skills, you will be able to live a more self- sufficient life," he said.
Taking Germany as an example, Siew said the vocational schools within that country's education system have helped Germany emerge as an industrial power.
He added that an improved talent pool could also increase Taiwan's international competitiveness.
The education authorities should work together to promote vocational education at a deeper level, especially in the area of training teachers and improving international exchanges, he said.
The 46 winners of the skills awards will go forward to participate in the next WorldSkills competition in London, scheduled to take place Oct. 5-8, 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 4, or the 27th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1669: Rembrandt van Rijn, Dutch painter whose works are unmatched in their portrayal of subtle human emotions, dies at the age of 63.
1777: U.S. forces led by George Washington attack the British at Germantown but are repulsed.
1822: Rutherford B. Hayes, the 19th president of the United State, is born. Winning the controversial election of 1876 by one electoral vote, he pacified the South by removing federal troops in 1877, supported the welfare of minority groups, and reformed the civil service.
1824: Mexico becomes a republic.
1830: Belgium becomes an independent state after being part of the Netherlands since 1815.
1878: China opens its first embassy in the United States when Chen Lan-pin presents his credentials to President Rutherford B. Hayes.
1904: Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, French sculptor and the creator of the Statue of Liberty, dies at the age of 70.
1905: Orville Wright, American aviator, is the first person to fly an aircraft for more than 33 minutes.
1910: Portugal is proclaimed a republic as King Manuel II flees to Britain.
1924: Charlton Heston, American actor, is born. He was best known for his appearances in such film epics as "El Cid" as well as "Ben Hur" for which he won an Oscar.
1947: The Russians successfully launch Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite.
1947: Max Planck, German physicist, dies in his home in Gottingen at the age of 89. He won a 1918 Nobel Prize for discoveries in connection with the quantum theory.
1949: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the USSR.
1949: The U.S. State Department reaffirms its recognition of the Nationalist government as the only legal government of China.
1952: The pacemaker, an external device developed by Dr. Paul Zoll of Harvard Medical School, is for the first time fitted to a human, David Schwarts, to control his heartbeat.
1969: Anthony Grey, a Reuters correspondent, is freed from house arrest after being held in Beijing by the Communist China for 20 months.
1974: The 75-member Peiping opera troupe leaves Taipei for the United States on a 72-day performance tour.
1977: The construction of the Shihkang Dam, capable of supplying 420,000 metric tons of water daily, is completed in central Taiwan.
1978: The ROC Ministry of National Defense announces the successful development of the "Hsiung Feng" missile.
1986: A 12-member political reform group of the Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang (KMT) decides to announce the lifting of the emergency decree at the appropriate time and passes legislative principles for the National Security Law during the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: An Israeli cargo plane crashes into a residential area in Amsterdam, killing more than 200 people.
1993: Russian troops loyal to President Boris Yeltsin capture the parliament building in Moscow after two days of fighting in which more than 300 die. Vice President Alexander Rutskoi and other parliamentary leaders are herded into Lefortovo prison.
1994: An undersea earthquake rocks Russia's Kuril Islands, killing more than 16 people.
1999: Taiwan's U-Land Airlines forges a cooperation relationship with Vietnam's Pacific Airlines to operate flights between Taipei and Ho Chi Minh City.
2000: Yu Kuo-hwa, former premier of the ROC, dies of respiratory failure at the age of 87 at Taipei Veterans' General Hospital.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian appoints Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to take the place of Tang Fei as premier.
2001: A local basketball team financed by Chinese-language Internet portal Sina.com announces that it is officially quitting the basketball scene in Taiwan and relocating to mainland China.
2001: New Palau Ambassador to the Republic of China Johnson Toribiong presents the credentials to President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.
2001: The Republic of China government spokesman expresses welcome for U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's remarks that the United States will not make deals against Taiwan's interests, describing it as "a very friendly statement" toward Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is true of the really great moral man that every act of his life becomes an example for generations, that everything he does becomes a statute for generations, and that every word he utters becomes a law for generations."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Monday from its previous close, moving up 16.98 points at 8,261.16 on a turnover of NT$3.277 billion (US$104.03 million).
The weighted price index rose 6.4 points, or 0.07 percent, to close at 8,244.18 Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$31.050 at 9:45 a.m. Monday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.26 from Friday's close. ENDITE

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Nanya plant fire

TEXT.P: Nanya Plastics Corp., Taiwan's top plastics manufacturer and a major subsidiary of Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) , saw one of its factories in Chiayi County go up in flames Sunday.
The fire tarnished the image of one of the country's largest private business conglomerates as the group has seen three fires and explosions at its plants in as many months.
Those incidents have inevitably caused serious environmental pollution in the vicinities of the plants in Chiayi and Yunlin counties, and have drawn strong protests from local residents.

The string of plant fires are signs of lax management at FPG factory complexes. It is sad and regrettable to see the group retrogress in its corporate administration and safety record less than two years after the death of its founder Wang Yung-ching.

Wang was known for his down-to-earth working style and strictness in corporate management. Following his death, there have often been reports of his family members sparring over allocation of his huge assets. It is deplorable that the scions of the family have failed to uphold their father's responsible work ethics and let the FPG plants threaten public safety.
We hope the Wang family will never forget their social responsibility in maintaining a safe and healthy living environment in business operation. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 4, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA chief's visa statement 'correct': EU parliament member
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Oct. 3 (CNA) 10/04/10 11:52:46 (By Tsao Yu-fan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign minister was "perfectly correct" to be optimistic about the European Union (EU) listing Taiwan in its visa-waiver program, the chairman of the European Parliament-Taiwan Friendship Group said Sunday.
Charles Tannock told reporters in Brussels that it was expected that Taiwan will see the result of its bid for the Schengen visa-free privilege in the next three months.

A day earlier in Taipei, Minister of Foreign Affairs Timothy C.T. Yang said that the process of securing visa-free privileges for Taiwanese tourists to EU countries was "going smoothly" and the measure could be implemented soon.
"The visa-exemption treatment could be provided by the end of this year" if approved, Yang told the local press.
According to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Council of the European Union and the European Parliament were slated to hold meetings in October or November to screen and vote on the matter.
The Schengen Area comprises the territories of 25 European countries, including 22 EU member states and three-non EU states -- Norway, Iceland and Switzerland.
The visa-waiver program is also applicable to three non-Schengen EU member states -- Romania, Bulgaria and Cyprus.
Taiwan currently receives visa-exemption privileges for 33 countries, including New Zealand, Ireland, Britain, Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: Investors optimistic ahead of HTC smartphone release
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 12:38:04 (By Tien Yu-pin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Investors were mostly upbeat ahead of the release of HTC Corporation's September sales report on Oct. 6 and its Taipei debut of the HTC Desire HD and HTC Desire Z Android-based smartphones on Oct. 7, local media reported Monday.
Cell phone parts manufacturers said HTC's Q4 shipments were expected to reach a record 10 million units, reports said.

They said HTC had received orders for more than 11 million units for Q4, but shipments will be affected by a shortage of certain cell phone parts and the company's nearly 100 percent capacity utilization rate.
Shipments in Q3 are estimated to be above 7 million units, higher than the company's forecast of 6.5 million units, institutional investors said.
The company is scheduled to release its September sales and profits for the third quarter on Oct. 6.

Its third quarter sales are expected to reach NT$75 billion, exceeding the company's target of NT$70 billion, and net profit is expected to rise above NT$12 per share in the quarter -- the highest among all listed companies in Taiwan, investors said.

With the injection of sales from the company's new smartphones and the Windows Phone 7 mobile operating system expected to be launched in mid-October, HTC's performance in Q4 will be even better than Q3, they said.

One local newspaper reported that HTC's combined earnings per share (EPS) in the first three quarters of this year is likely to stand above NT$30, surpassing integrated circuit designer Mediatek Inc. to become the most profitable stock.
HTC's EPS in Q1 and Q2 was NT$6.38 and NT$10.3 respectively.

HTC said that this week's phone release will be the largest event it has ever held in Taiwan, with more than 350 celebrities and representatives from Asian media organizations expected to attend the event.

HTC Chief Executive Officer Peter Chou has said that at least 30 telecommunication carriers around the world -- the highest number in the company's history -- decided to buy the new HTC Desire HD since it was first launched in Europe in September. Almost all mobile phone operators in Europe will introduce the new Android-based smartphone, he said.
HTC shares opened NT$7 higher at NT$714 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Plant fires and corporate responsibility

TEXT.P: Nanya Plastics Corp. saw one of its plants in Chiayi County's Taibao City go up in flames Sunday morning, burning until firefighters were able to put it out at around 1 a.m. Monday.

It was the third major safety glitch involving factory sites of FPG -- one of Taiwan's largest private conglomerates -- over the past three months. In July, the group's Mailiao petrochemical complex in Yunlin County was twice hit by fires and explosions.

Nanya, Taiwan's largest plastics maker, has been ordered to shut down its Chiayi plant, which produced about NT$150 million (US$4.76 million) worth of PEPA, a high-class synthetic paper used for packaging and printing purposes, a month. The county government also fined the company NT$1 million.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the incident:
United Daily News:

Heavy "black rains" fell in Chiayi City and Shueishang and Jhongpu townships Sunday afternoon, hours after a fire broke out at Nanya's Chiayi Second Plant in neighboring Taibao City earlier in the day.

Local environmental officials said that the "black rains" contained particulate pollution caused by the Nanya plant fire. Some local residents said the company should compensate them for car-washing fees. Farmers in the plant's vicinity were also concerned about possible damage to their crops.

Although Nanya executives said the materials used at the Taibao plant were common chemicals and non-toxic, environmental experts said the materials released a pungent odor and could cause skin irritation.
FPG Chairman Wang Wen-yuan is scheduled to visit the Chiayi County government Monday, a move said to be part of an effort to pre-empt protests from local residents.
Strong protests from Yunlin residents after the Mailiao plant fires in June forced the FPG to offer huge compensation for local residents. (Oct. 4, 2010).
China Times:
Chen Wen-yang, deputy manager of Nanya's Chiayi plant, apologized to local residents for the fire Sunday and promised to discuss remedy measures within one week.

The Nanya plant was Taiwan's only factory that produced high-quality synthetic paper, also known as pearl paper. Chen said the fire would not disrupt the pearl paper supply because the company has another production line. He also said it would take an estimated NT$100 million to build a new PEPA plant which takes at least one year to complete. (Oct. 4, 2010).
Liberty Times:
As fires at the Chiayi plant and the Mailiao petrochemical complex all took place on Sundays, people are concerned about FPG's holiday safety measures and management.
Petrochemical industry observers said a string of fires at FPG plant sites signal structural problems in the group following the death of founder Wang Yung-ching in October 2008.
They said the group should review its internal monitoring mechanism, training programs and production facilities to prevent similar accidents.
Nanya President Wu Chia-chao, who took a high-speed rail train to Chiayi Sunday to help with the rescue effort, said the company does not relax its safety supervision on holidays.
"We follow the same stringent standard operation procedures on holidays as we follow on workdays, " he stressed after Sunday's incident. (Oct. 4, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: NT dollar reaches two-year high, export-related shares fall
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 14:11:14 (By Kao Chao-fen, Chang Chien-chun and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Backed by the rise of other Asian currencies, the New Taiwan dollar staged a strong appreciation against the U.S. dollar and briefly reached its highest rate in more than two years during morning trade Monday.
The U.S. currency opened flat at NT$31.310 and fell to NT$30.976 -- the lowest level since August 2008, when it briefly hit NT$30.915. It later recovered slightly to close morning trade at NT$31.007.
Dealers said that foreign funds continued to flow into local markets after Taiwan's central bank raised the benchmark interest rate for the second time this year on Thursday last week.
Institutional investors are mostly upbeat that the NT dollar will keep moving up against the greenback.
Affected by the strong rise of NT dollar, stock market investors were reluctant to trade export-oriented electronics shares during Monday's session.
Traders said that the appreciation of local currency would increase electronic firms' foreign exchange losses and was also likely to squeeze their revenues and gross profit margins.

They said that if the NT dollar rose by 1 percent against the U.S. dollar, the gross profit margins of chip foundry United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) would decrease by 0.5 percentage points, and the margins of Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Inc. ( ASE Inc.) , a semiconductor packaging and test services provider, would drop by 0.2 percentage points.
The stronger NT dollar is considered positive to asset-backed shares, however, and most construction shares rose sharply.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan high-tech fair in Jakarta draws good response: TAITRA
DOC.DATELINE: Jakarta, Indonesia, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 15:51:25 (By Fu I-Chien and Hanna Liu )

TEXT.P: A three-day information and communication technology (ICT) product fair that showcased the best of Taiwan's upper-end products in Jakarta, Indonesia has drawn encouraging response from Indonesian consumers, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Monday.

The quasi-official council organized the Oct. 1-3 event as part of a marketing and branding project by the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, an official from the TAITRA's Indonesian office said.

Booths in the courtyard of the Mal Kelapa Gading, one of the largest shopping centers in Indonesia, highlighted products from 19 Taiwanese ICT companies, including Acer, Asus, D-link, Trend Micro, Genius, Mio, MIS and Transcend, the official said.

Acer's Indonesia branch and Genius sponsored booths to provide an opportunity for visitors to try out Taiwanese online games. The online game market in Indonesia is expected to boom, the official added.
The fair also featured a costume contest and dancing and singing performances to draw attention from consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close mixed, electronics suffer

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed mixed Monday, with the rise of the local currency against the U.S. dollar dampening interest in electronics stocks but boosting asset-backed shares, dealers said.
The weighted index edged up 1.92 points, or 0.02 percent, to 8,246.1 after moving between 8,240.67 and 8,300.04 on turnover of NT$138.29 billion (US$4.46 billion).

The market opened up 0.2 percent as the stronger Taiwan dollar -- which rose to its highest level against the greenback in more than two years in the morning -- boosted asset-backed shares and briefly pushed the index above the key 8,300 level.

Worried, however, that the appreciation of the local currency would affect sales of Taiwan's export-oriented electronics vendors, investors started unloading their holdings of electronics companies that are expected to release September sales figures this week.

Kevin Lin, senior vice president at Fuh Hong Financial Planning Co., said institutional investors simply wanted to take profits on electronics shares prior to Taiwan's special municipality elections on Nov. 27.
"They do not want to wait until the electronics firms release their next sales figures in early November, because that would be too close to the elections," Lin said.
A total of 1,755 stocks closed up and 2,301 finished down, with 225 remaining unchanged.
The paper and pulp sector posted the highest gains, up 3.96 percent. Textile shares rose 2.92 percent, the cement sector gained 1.44 percent, and financial shares advanced 1.27 percent.
Construction issues rose 1.25 percent, plastics and chemicals shares were 0.74 percent higher, and foodstuff shares added 0.21 percent.
The machinery and electronics sector fell 0.93 percent, the only one of the eight major stock categories losing ground on the day.
Integrated circuit designer Mediatek Inc., fell NT$21, or 4.85 percent, to NT$428.
Smartphone maker HTC dropped NT$9, or 1.27 percent, to NT$698, still maintaining its position as the most expensive stock in Taiwan.

It rose as high as NT$723 at one point during the session on expectations that the company will release better monthly revenue figures this week, and that sales remain strong with the debut of two new Android-based smartphones.

Dealers noted that Yulon Motor Co., a leading automobile manufacturer in Taiwan with a stockpile of assets, performed well Monday because the group is expected to benefit from growing demand in Taiwan and China.
Yulon shares closed limit-up at NT$60.9.

DOC.HEADLINE: Formosa Plastics chairman apologizes for plant fire
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 16:22:23 (By Yeh Tzu-kang, Huang Kuo-fang, Lin Huei-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) Chairman Wang Wen-yuan apologized Monday for a fire the day before at a plant run by group affiliate Nan Ya Plastics Corp. in the southern Taiwan county of Chiayi.
The head of Taiwan's largest private-sector enterprise addressed the apology to all Chiayi residents during a meeting with Chiayi County Magistrate Chang Hwa- kuan at the latter's office.
Nan Ya Plastics has launched overall safety checks and will take full responsibility, Wang said.
He told reporters that pending investigation, he had no idea what caused the fire.
The blaze broke out at around 8: 30 a.m. Sunday at Nan Ya's Chiayi Second Plant in Taibao City. The factory produced a high-quality waterproof synthetic paper known as white pearl, or PEPA.
It took firefighters nearly 17 hours to extinguish the blaze. No casualties were reported.
The fire dealt another heavy blow to the group after two fires at the group's petrochemical complex in Mailiao Township in the southern county of Yunlin in July.
On Monday, the Chiayi County government put together an expert panel to evaluate damage caused by the latest fire and handle resident complaints.

At a news conference before receiving Wang, Chang said the fire was a "serious industrial safety incident" that caused severe air pollution in the county, which is one of Taiwan's major agricultural areas.

Anyone who suffered from losses due to the pollution will have an opportunity to present evidence, and if there are losses proven, the panel will help people claim compensation from Nan Ya, Chang said.
Experts were also asked to determine whether the fire affected the quality of water, air or soil in the county, she added.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Monday it had drawn up a cooperation plan with other agencies, including the Environmental Protection Administration, to monitor the operations of Taiwan's petrochemical industry.
The plan will be implemented immediately if approved by the Executive Yuan, the officials said, noting that FPG petrochemical factories would likely be the first target because of public concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan reports first superbug case

TEXT.P: A TVBS cameraman who was injured in a shooting in New Delhi last month and received medical treatment there has contracted the drug-resistant superbug NDM-1, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Monday.
In a text message to the media, the CDC said the cameraman -- the first known patient with the bacterium in Taiwan -- was showing no symptoms from the superbug.
The Department of Health (DOH) and the CDC were to hold a press conference to give more details of the case.
CDC listed NDM-1, short for New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase-1, as a communicable disease in September.
The CDC required local hospitals to immediately report any suspected cases, especially those in which the patient has received medical treatment in India or Pakistan.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Missing the point on the wealth gap problem

TEXT.P: Both an Executive Yuan special panel headed by Vice Premier Sean Chen and a Presidential Office economic advisory task force have come up with proposals to address the problem of the widening wealth gap facing the country.

Neither of the teams, however, dared to touch the crux of the problem. Both dodged the responsibility of reviewing the government's tax policies and refrained from proposing adjustments to direct taxes, such as income tax, inheritance tax and corporate income tax.

It is not surprising that neither team wanted to make such a policy review because most of their members were vocal advocates of the sizeable reductions to the inheritance and gift taxes early last year.

They also would not like to weigh whether the decision to cut the corporate income tax to 17 percent from this year would exacerbate the rich-poor divide in the local society, because both the president and the premier have been touting the tax cut as a key momentum to drive the Taiwan economy to a new "golden decade."
The administration of President Ma Ying-jeou, however, cannot buck the principle of "levying higher taxes on rich persons" if it truly wants to tackle the thorny issue of the wealth gap.

This goal can only be reached by raising the income tax, capital gains tax or inheritance tax. Proposals put up by the two task forces, such as imposing a luxury tax, yacht tax or other indirect taxes, could by no means be effective in contributing to the goal. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 4, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes down on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the Taiwan dollar Monday, dropping NT$0.06 to close at NT$31.250.
The greenback dropped to its lowest level against the local currency in more than two years during the morning session, but recovered in late trading as Taiwan's central bank intervened.
Turnover totaled US$873 million, compared to US$909 million on last Friday.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.310 and moved to a low of NT$30.976 -- the lowest level since August 2008, when it briefly hit NT$30.915.
Dealers said that foreign funds continued to flow into local markets after Taiwan's central bank raised the benchmark interest rate for the second time this year on Thursday last week.
Institutional investors are upbeat that the Taiwan dollar will continue to rise against the greenback.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative panel holds screening for top judicial posts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 17:09:51 (By Lai You-chia and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan held a screening hearing Monday on President Ma Ying-jeou's nominations for the top two leadership positions in the Judicial Yuan.
The hearing, organized by caucuses of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), paved the way for the legislature to vote on the nominees Oct. 8.
On Aug. 24, Ma nominated Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Rai Hau-min to be president of the Judicial Yuan, with law professor Su Yeong-chin as his vice president.

The top two Judicial Yuan posts opened up after Lai In-jaw and Hsieh Tsay-chuan resigned as president and vice president in July to take responsibility for a scandal in which three senior judges were detained for alleged corruption.

According to the Constitution, the president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan are appointed by the country's president from among 15 justices of the Constitutional Court and confirmed by the legislature.
Seven legislators across partisan lines and seven scholars and legal pundits took part in the hearing and gave their opinions on the nominees.

Former New Party Legislator Hsieh Chi-ta, who was not on the 14-member panel, issued an open letter to Rai outside the Legislative Yuan, accusing him of intervening in judicial proceedings on a corruption scandal involving former Taiwan Provincial Assemblyman Chen Chin-teh.
KMT Legislator Chiu Yi, one of the screening lawmakers, said the scandal remains unclear although the case was closed and Chen was acquitted in 2007 after 13 years of judicial proceedings.
"It would be a real scandal if the new Judicial Yuan leadership does not look into the case again," Chiu said.

DPP Legislator Kuan Bi-ling accused Rai of neglecting duties in his capacity as CEC chairman by being absent from a commission vote on whether KMT Legislator Diane Lee should be stripped of her legislative seat after a dual citizenship row in January 2009. The CEC revoked Lee's elected status the following month.
"(Rai) is the worst nomination that President Ma has made, " Kuan said.
Meanwhile, Lin Feng-cheng, executive director of the non-profit Judicial Reform Foundation, welcomed Rai's nomination.

Lin said that although Rai has not worked on the country's judicial frontline, a speech he delivered recently rekindled hope in Taiwan's legal sector, particularly a phrase saying that "a country's judiciary should only exist for the people's interests."
Three other university academics spoke highly of the nominees. A fourth professor said that by working together, Rai and Su would produce a synergy and boost the country's judicial development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former president to oversee opening of seized files
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 17:43:28 (By Lin Chang-shun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian will oversee the opening of boxes of official documents that he removed from the Presidential Office at the end of his term, the Special Investigation Division (SID) under the Supreme Prosecutors Office said Monday.

SID Director Chen Hung-tah said that the former president, who has been held since Dec. 30, 2008 in connection with corruption and money laundering charges, will take part in the opening of 58 cartons of documents that prosecutors retrieved from his office and other places in September.

The opening is scheduled to take place at the Taipei Detention Center, where the former president is held, beginning on Oct. 6, Chen Hung-tah said. Staff from Chen's office and officials from the Presidential Office will also be present.
The opening process is expected to take 10 working days, Chen Hung-tah added.

Prosecutors seized 58 cartons of documents from Chen's office on Sept. 15 as part of an investigation into allegations that he took more than 20 boxes of classified files with him when he left the Presidential Office in May 2008.
The Presidential Office said Sept. 10 that it had instructed Chen's office to return the documents and files after being notified of their existence by Chen's office.
The former president's aides, however, said that they were not in a position to do so and that they would hold onto the documents until Chen was released from detention.
The Presidential Office then filed a lawsuit with the SID alleging Chen' s office had violated the Embezzlement of Public Property Act.

After questioning Chen Song-shan, director of the former president's office, the SID issued search warrants and conducted a search of the old and new locations of Chen's office, leading to the seizure of the 58 cartons.
The former president has been sentenced to 20 years in prison for embezzling state funds, laundering money, accepting bribes and committing forgery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Compensation should be same for foreign, Taiwanese workers: Ma
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 18:14:44 (By Lee Shu-hua and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Foreign laborers who are injured or killed while working should not receive any less compensation than Taiwan citizens, President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday, referring to the death of six Indonesians in a freeway construction accident last week.

Compensation in cases of occupational accidents involving foreign workers should be handled "with additional care, " Ma told a weekly meeting of executive members of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , according to party spokesman Su Jin- pin.
Ma doubles as KMT chairman.
Six foreign and one Taiwanese worker were killed when scaffolding collapsed at an interchange construction site on the No. 6 Freeway in central Taiwan last Thursday.
Ma said Monday that while efforts are made to address safety in the workplace, authorities should also take measures to protect foreign workers' rights and benefits, according to Su.
Ma also instructed relevant authorities to put in place mechanisms to prevent accidents in non-public places, such as residential buildings, factories and industrial parks, Su added.

He said the president voiced concern about two separate fires over the weekend: one that engulfed a Yunlin County film studio known for producing Taiwanese glove puppet TV shows, and another at a Nan Ya Plastics plant in Chiayi County.
No casualties were reported in either fire.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Focusing on core economic issues

TEXT.P: With the U.S. and European economies entering a protracted period of adjustment and the Chinese currency facing ever stronger pressure to appreciate, Taiwan must adjust its export-oriented and China-reliant economic growth strategy to stay viable and competitive in the rapidly changing global market.

First and foremost, the government should work to change the domestic economic structure that has for years relied heavily on the information technology and electronics industries as the key engines of growth. With demand in the U.S. and Europe declining steadily, such a strategy will no longer work.

Given Taiwan's increasingly closer economic interaction with China, the government should refer to Beijing's economic restructuring and industrial upgrading plans in plotting out a new course for our own new economic development.
The government should also take steps to encourage local companies to abandon the model of using China as home to their production lines.

In addition, it must prevent stock and property bubbles created by an influx of hot money into Asia and other emerging markets around the world, awash with hot money as a result of the easy money policies adopted by the U.S. Fed and European central bank.

The government cannot afford to sit on its hands and allow the local stock and property market to be distorted by hot money because such dealings could have a fatal impact on the domestic economy over the long run. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 4, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: No need to panic over Taiwan's first case of "superbug": CDC

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) on Monday urged the public not to panic over the country's first reported case of the NDM-1 "superbug, " saying the patient has been asymptomatic so far and is out of the hospital.

Speaking at a press conference in Taipei, CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi urged people to maintain a high level of personal hygiene by constantly washing their hands and adhere to the proper protocol when using antibiotics to guard against the bug.
Shih said Taiwan's patient zero was a male cameraman who was operated on in New Delhi last month after being shot by masked gunman.
The man may have contracted a bacteria made resistant to most antibiotics by the NDM-1 gene during the operation, he said.

"The man underwent surgery and was hospitalized in a high-risk country. This is the first time that the strain has been detected in Taiwan and we therefore have reason to believe that this was an imported case," he said.
According to Shih, during tests conducted on the man's anus, wound and urine, traces of the antibiotic-resistant superbug were found around his anus.

The man, who was shot in the abdomen, was accompanied by a team of medical workers on his return flight to Taiwan on September 27. Shih said all the waste material on the aircraft was properly disposed of.
The cameraman, who works for local cable TV news station TVBS, is reportedly in good health but must report back to the CDC on a weekly basis for follow-up visits.

Bacteria with the NDM-1 gene has infected people around the world, but its main infection epicenter is in India and Pakistan. They are resistant to most available antibiotics, including carbapenems that are used as a last resort when common antibiotics have failed.
In August, the World Health Organization (WHO) released a statement warning governments to take measures to combat anti-microbial resistance.

"WHO suggests that countries should be prepared to implement hospital infection control measures to limit the spread of multi-drug resistant strains and to reinforce national policy on prudent use of antibiotics, reducing the generation of antibiotic resistant bacteria," the WHO statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: German scholar reflects on impact of Germany's reunification

TEXT.P: Two decades after the reunification of East Germany and West Germany, many Germans of the formerly separated country continue to wrestle with problems that arose, even as many others recognize the benefits of reunification, said a visiting professor on the 20th anniversary of the historic event.

"While most of the people in Germany have a positive assessment of the reunification, frustration from a depressed job market and other unfulfilled demands also led to relative negative assessment by many, " Professor Dr. Stefan Wolle of the Free University (FU) of Berlin told an audience in Taiwan.

As this year marks two decades since the two sides reunified, the German Institute Taipei invited the historian and head of research at the DDR Museum in Berlin to give a series of lectures in Taiwan.
At academic institutes and universities where Wolle spoke, audiences were enthusiastic to learn from the historian the German experience of reunification.
Speaking of the uniqueness of German reunification, the scholar pointed out that "the drive for reunification came as a surprise to many observers."
"The desire for unity by no means came from above. It was articulated by the masses on the street," he said.

Immediately after the monetary union on July 1, 1990, people in the east found that while they finally gained long-desired freedom and the entitlement of consumers, they had to meet the challenges of severe competition in a market economy.

Wolle pointed out that the monetary union failed to prepare East Germans for the devastating consequences of a collapsing economy in the former East Germany, also known as the German Democratic Republic (GDR).

As West German retail outlets offered an abundance of goods which overwhelmed the market, demand for East German products almost completely collapsed and industrial production in former East Germany abruptly dropped by half within a year.

Between 1989 and 1992, the number of employed people in the east dropped from 9.7 million to 6.7 million; the sluggishness of the job market was comparable to the Great Depression years between 1929 and 1932, Wolle noted.

Over the years, the job market in the new federal states have hardly recovered from the post-reunification sluggishness, and the bitterness among those who were used to a system of guaranteed employment and social security was understandable, according to the professor.
He pointed out that most German people had a positive assessment of the transformation of Germany, but quite a few had complaints and worries about the free market economy.
The frustration of those forced into a disadvantaged position after the reunification had given rise to nostalgic sentiment of the " harmony" under the socialist system, Wolle said.
The so-called "Ost-talgia" for " the idyll behind the barbed wire", as Prof. Wolle suggested, reflected people's disappointment over unfulfilled promises.

From 1990 and 1991, Wolle worked as an expert on files of the Stasi (the Ministry of State Security of the GDR) and was a member of the committee for the dissolution of the secret police organization.

He said, in the long process of integration, the German people should think beyond the limitations of the current situation. Meanwhile, the authorities should note the spiritual aspects and psychological complications people still faced, while the progress of infrastructure reconstruction in the former GDR should be recognized, Wolle said.

The former member of the Academy of Sciences of the GDR in the 1970s and 1980s spoke as an academician while using survey reports to reflect assessments by German people, and also as a witness who had led a life under the socialist system of East Germany and as an active participant in the process of reconciliation.

He said that he was impressed to find the audience in Taiwan had great interest in the German experience, adding that from the questions raised, he found people in Taiwan were relatively well-informed about contemporary German history.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's trade promotion group visits Manila
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 19:33:23 (By Emerson Lim and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A 25-member Taiwan trade promotion mission, organized by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , arrived in Manila Monday for trade talks that are expected to draw the participation of executives from nearly 200 companies in the Philippines.

The TAITRA mission is comprised of executives of 17 Taiwanese companies involved in machinery, spare parts, telecommunications facilities and products, health care equipment and health foods, as well as auto parts.

In addition to one-on-one trade talks, mission members are expected to visit several major shopping malls and factories around the Philippines to gain further understanding of the business climate in the Southeast Asian country, said Huang Jung-chun, mission leader and a TAITRA official.
He estimated that the visit will generate business opportunities worth US$1 million.

Two-way trade between the two countries reached US$4.1 billion in the first six months of this year, with Taiwan's exports to the Philippines totaling some US$3 billion and its imports from that country amounting to US$1.1 billion, according to Donald C.T. Lee, Taiwan's representative in the Philippines, who was also present at a welcoming party that was held at Hotel Dusit Thani in Manila.
Taiwan is currently the seventh largest trade partner of the Philippines, Lee said. The Philippines is one of Taiwan's top 10 export markets.
Amadeo Perez Jr., chairman of the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO), extended a welcome to the mission at the party.
MECO is a quasi-official body authorized by the Philippine government to handle exchanges between the Philippines and Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.
Addressing the event, Perez lauded the Taiwanese manufacturers for their innovative capabilities in developing advanced and new products.
"Cooperation between Taiwanese and Philippines manufacturers will help sharpen the Philippine industries' global competitiveness, " he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Spot baldness likely to trigger other autoimmune diseases: study

TEXT.P: A recent study of more than 4,000 Taiwanese "spot baldness" patients has found a correlation between the affliction and other autoimmune diseases, Taipei Veterans General Hospital said Monday.

According to the study done by the hospital, patients suffering from spot baldness have a higher risk of contracting other autoimmune diseases such as atopic dermatitis, lupus, psoriasis and rheumatoid arthritis, said an attending physician.

With the help of the Bureau of National Health Insurance's database, the study's researchers analyzed the records of 4,334 spot baldness patients from 1996 to 2008 and cross-checked the incidence of autoimmune diseases with their ages, said Chen Chih-chiang, the doctor who led the study.

The results showed that children with spot baldness under 10 have 9.7 times more of a chance to get lupus, while patients in the 11-20 age group were prone to psoriasis and rheumatoid arthritis, Chen said.
Patients older than 60 have a higher risk of thyroid disease, he added.
Spot baldness, known formally as alopecia areata, describes the patchy loss of hair on the scalp or the body.

Though it has many causes that are hard to pinpoint, Chen said the study, to be published in Journal of the American Academy of Dermatology, could help doctors detect in a timely manner other autoimmune diseases in alopecia patients and reduce the waste of medical resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Solar shares fall sharply on German solar subsidy cut
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 20:07:13 (By Hsu Hsiang-hsin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Shares of Taiwanese solar power producers fell sharply Monday on news that Germany, the world's largest solar market, is likely to cut its subsidies for solar energy products and power early next year, dealers said.

Institutional investors said that although most solar firms are still expected to post strong sales and profits in September and for the third quarter as a whole, the negative news still hurt local solar energy vendors.
The news had been expected by most investors, but it still cast a cloud over the industry's outlook and triggered profit-taking pressure, they said.
Green Energy Technology shares closed limit-down at NT$88.7, and Sino-American Silicon Products shares also fell by the maximum 7 percent limit to NT$89.8.

Media reports quoted a German federal network agency as saying that new photovoltaic solar energy installations in the first eight months of the year had exceeded the number installed in all of 2009 as well as the target for 2010.
As a result, Germany might slash solar subsidies by 13 percent next January.
Meanwhile, a local photovoltaic solar association ran a half-page newspaper ad Monday to urge the government to fully implement the Renewable Energy Development Act.
The association asked the government to further simplify administrative procedures to assist the public in installing solar equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Construction firms less likely to be affected by new bank measures

TEXT.P: Construction companies in Taiwan will suffer a less-than-expected impact from the new tightening measures that government-controlled banks are expected to impose on financing, as the booming market equips them with solutions, analysts said Monday.

"When needing more funds, some of the local constructors can choose -- and some already have chosen -- to sell their less popular commercial properties as it is easy to do so when the property market is booming right now, " H&B Business Group spokeswoman Jessica Hsu told the Central News Agency in a telephone interview.
She did not expect the government will hit the property market hard as local banks rely heavily on land and construction financing.

Her remarks came days after local news media reported that Land Bank of Taiwan and Taiwan Cooperative Bank -- Taiwan's largest sources of land and construction financing -- were scheduled to be "more cautious" in reviewing loan applications from Monday.

These banks will also ask construction companies to start their construction projects within one year after receiving the loans, or they will raise interest rates on the loans or cancel the loans, the reports said.

Bright Lee, a spokesman for Evertrust Rehouse Co., told CNA by telephone that the impact of the new measures will affect small construction companies more than big ones as big companies have more ways to raise funds, such as by issuing new shares.

He added that many of local big contractors have set up companies in other fields -- many of which are quite successful -- and these big companies can get funds from their other companies if necessary.

At its quarterly board meeting on Sept. 30, Taiwan's central bank did not launch additional measures to cool the housing market in the capital city of Taipei and surrounding Taipei County as widely expected.
The central bank, however, said in a statement that it is necessary to continue to ask local banks to tighten control on land financing risks.

Since June, the central bank has launched a series of tightening moves on bank lending to curb the upward spiral of housing prices as the soaring prices have raised complaints and fears that many local residents would not be able to buy a home.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-Taiwan defense industry conference opens
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 20:47:01 (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: An annual U.S.-Taiwan defense industry conference opened Sunday at Cambridge, Maryland with more than 140 government officials, scholars, experts and representatives from defense companies taking part.

Rupert Hammond-Chambers, president of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, said the meeting has provided a platform for both sides and defense companies to discuss the issues of safety and national defense.
The themes of this year's meeting include an assessment of threat faced by Taiwan from China, and Taiwan's capacity to engage in asymmetric warfare.

Yang Nien-dzu, deputy defense minister of Taiwan, said the purpose of the meeting is to increase bilateral cooperation and friendship and to discuss with the United States how to strengthen cooperation in Taiwan's military transformation process.
He expressed the hope that the United States would sell Taiwan F-16C/D jet fighters which it has long sought to guard its air space and enhance its self- defense capability.

Prior to the conference, Hammond-Chambers was asked when he thought the U.S. would sell F-16C/D fighters to Taiwan so it can replace its aging fleet. He answered that he believes Washington will do so in the first term of U.S. President Barrack Obama.
The conference has been held annually since 2002.
U.S. officials participating in this year's Oct. 3-5 conference
included Beth M. McCormick, deputy assistant secretary for
defense, trade & regional security of the U.S. Department of
State, and Wallace Gregson, assistant secretary of Defense for
Asian & Pacific Security Affairs.
Hsiao Bi-khim, director of the Department of International Affairs of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party, will speak later Monday at the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan prepares for mega National Day celebration

TEXT.P: A 52-minute fireworks display will light up the skies over Taipei Sunday night in celebration of the 99th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China, the organizing committee announced on Monday.

The day's activities will kick off early Sunday outside the Presidential Office with three well-known vocalists leading the singing of the ROC's national anthem, followed by a string of performances by five schools and the military.

President Ma Ying-jeou will then give his annual Double Ten Day address, accompanied by the first lady. A parade of 23 floats from 10 counties and various government agencies will also add color to the celebration.

According to the committee, backpacks or handbags that exceed 30 centimeters in length and umbrellas or heavy colorful raincoats will not be allowed. In case of inclement weather, only light colored transparent raincoats will be permitted.
Other items barred include batons, sticks, knives, balloons, and blow horns.
Small folding chairs can be used, but cameras with long lenses must not be brought into the restricted zones, the committee said.
In the afternoon, another float parade that looks ahead to the country's centennial anniversary next year will run from the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to the square outside Taipei City Hall.
This year, the main evening celebration will be held on the offshore island of Penghu.

The entire show, featuring a full line of pop artists, aboriginal singers, and bands and a 30-minute fireworks display, will be broadcast live in Taiwan as well as in different parts of the world via the Overseas Compatriots Commission's Macroview Television Service.
Another fireworks show will be held around the same time in Taipei, the committee said.

A series of cultural activities and exhibitions, including a nationwide design competition, movie festival, and a traditional puppet display at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, will also be held until the end of the year in honor of the country's birthday.

A total of 263 foreign dignitaries, including the president of Sao Tome and Principe, the prime minister of the Solomon Islands, and parliamentary members of South Korea, Kuwait, and Mongolia will attend this year's National Day celebration, said Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng. who serves as the committee chairman.

The chairmen of Taiwan's six major political parties have been invited to attend the celebration, but the heads of the two major opposition parties -- the Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- have yet to reply to the invitation, Wang said.
This year's National Day celebration will cost NT$46 million, NT$3 million more than in 2008 because of the extra cost of transporting equipment to Penghu, Wang said.
Taiwan suspended the celebration in 2009 after a deadly typhoon wrecked havoc in southern Taiwan, leaving more than 700 people dead.

DOC.HEADLINE: Strong retail sales sign of consumption rebound: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 21:15:31 (By Lee Shu-hua and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that the wave of shopping seen at department stores during their anniversary sales the past two days indicates that consumption has recovered to the level it attained before the global financial storm hit in 2008.
"That shopping wave, especially from women, impressed us, " he said in a meeting with Lions Club International members at the Presidential Office. Spending each day reached a reported NT$300 million.
But Ma also acknowledged that while some had fully recovered from the financial crisis, it had also expanded Taiwan's rich-poor divide, leaving many disadvantaged people throughout society.
As part of the effort to deal with the problem, the Executive Yuan recently revised social relief regulations that authorize the government to offer subsidies to more low-income households, Ma said.
He also urged the Lions Club, which holds activities geared to the public interest, to help narrow the rich-poor gap.

DOC.HEADLINE: Specialists differ over potential threat of 'superbug'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 22:17:12 (by Chen Li-ting and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The first person in Taiwan to be infected by bacteria carrying the NDM-1 gene was asymptomatic and the bacteria nontoxic, but specialists worry the bug's mutating gene could jump to local bacteria, making them equally resistant to antibiotics.
Taiwan's Centers for Disease Control (CDC) confirmed Monday that a Taiwanese cameraman shot in India in September had contracted the superbug, which first emerged in South Asia.
The CDC believes it is not likely to become a communicable disease, and it has designated it as "non-contagious."

Wang Fu-de, the director of Taipei Veterans General Hospital's Infection Control Office said the superbug is mainly spread through invasive surgeries when a patient's immune system is weak, and he contended that the chance of the average person being infected is low.
Su Ih-jen, the deputy superintendent of National Cheng Kung University Hospital and a former head of the CDC, disagreed.

"This is a big deal and should not be handled this way," he said, mainly because of fears that the NDM-1 gene mutation in the carrier's bactera will transfer its drug resistant property to other local bacteria.
If the patient's stool contains NDM-1, Su said, then the drug resistant gene could transfer to regional bacteria like E. coli, which residents of Taiwan could later be infected with.

This was the greatest concern, he said, because it would be very difficult to treat. At present, bacteria with the NDM-1 gene resist even carbapenem antibiotics, which are generally used as a last resort to treat conditions resistant to regular antibiotics.

Huang Li-min, a physician in National Taiwan University Hospital's Department of Pediatrics and an infectious disease specialist, said discharging the NDM-1 carrier from the hospital was a practical response to a difficult problem.
"It's not that Taiwan is not willing to deal with the situation. It's simply that nothing can be done," he said.
If the patient were to be kept in the hospital, where there are so many people being operated on or with weak immune systems, it would only increase the chances of spreading disease, he said.

Huang acknowledged, however, that once a "healthy carrier" returned home, the household could be contaminated with the NDM-1-affected bacteria, and family members would have to emphasize their own personal hygiene.
Even then, Huang admitted, family members were still at risk of becoming "healthy carriers" of bacteria with the NDM-1 gene.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese pitcher ends season with new Dodgers ERA record
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 22:20:10 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese pitcher Kuo Hong-chih concluded the best MLB season of his career Sunday by securing the Los Angeles Dodgers record for lowest ERA based on a minimum of at least 50 innings pitched.

The 29-year-old pitched a scoreless inning in relief against the Arizona Diamondbacks, lowering his ERA to 1.200. That was slightly better than the previous record of 1.202 set by Cy Young award-winning reliever Eric Gagne in 2003.

"Gagne is still my idol, " Kuo said after the game. Gagne recorded 152 saves from 2002-2004 for the Dodgers before an arm injury derailed his career, though he attempted numerous comebacks before retiring in April 2010.
In the final game of the season, Kuo took over in the bottom of the ninth with the Dodgers leading 3-1, and yielded only a walk in securing his 12th save of the season.
The left-hander started the season injured but later emerged as the Dodgers' best reliever and the only one in Major League Baseball to record at least 10 saves and 20 holds during the 2010 season.
Kuo's 56 appearances earned him an additional US$25,000 in incentives.
It was his best season since first making the Dodgers roster in 2005. He struck out 73 while yielding only 29 hits and 18 walks in 60 innings pitched.
Aside from his record-setting ERA, his WHIP (walks and hits per inning pitched) was an astounding 0.78. Anything below 1 is considered outstanding.
Kuo started the 2010 season as a setup man but was installed as a closer in mid- August in place of the struggling Jonathan Braxton.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magnitude 6.8 earthquake hits off eastern Taiwan coast
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 22:28:33 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A magnitude 6.8 earthquake struck off the Taiwan's eastern coast at 9: 28 p.m. Monday, according to Central Weather Bureau (CWB) data.
The tremor was felt around Taiwan, but there were no reports of casualties or damage from the quake as of 10:30 p.m.

The temblor was centered in waters 362.5 kilometers southeast of the bureau's Suao seismic observation station in the northeastern county of Yilan at a depth of 60 kilometers, the CWB's Seismology Center said in a statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to field Asian Games roster in Intercontinental Cup
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 22:40:45 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will field 12 of its Asian Games baseball players at the 2010 IBAF Intercontinental Cup tournament slated to be held in central Taiwan later this month, the team's manager said Monday.
The Chinese Taipei Amateur Baseball Association announced on Monday its 24-man roster for the Intercontinental Cup, which will be held in Taichung and Douliou Oct. 23-31.
Taiwan's 24 players will consist of 11 pitchers, three catchers, six infielders and four outfielders, manager Yeh Chih-hsien announced at a press conference.

Of the 24 players on the roster, only Hsiao Poh-ting, an infielder, was not on the country's preliminary 45-member national team roster for the Asian Games scheduled to be held in Guangzhou City in November, Yeh said.
Twelve members of the International Cup squad are on the current 24-man roster for the Asian Games.
Taiwan will be the defending champions at the 2010 Guangzhou Asian Games after winning the title in Doha in 2006.

A total of 10 teams will participate in this year's Intercontinental Cup. Aside from host Taiwan, the field will consist of teams representing Cuba, the Czech Republic, Hong Kong, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, Nicaragua, South Korea and Thailand.

Because the CPBL (Chinese Professional Baseball League) championship series overlaps with the Intercontinental Cup for a day, players with the Sinon Bulls and the Brother Elephants were not included on the roster, according to Yeh.
Uni-President Lions pitcher Wang Ching-ming was also excluded because of his arm injury, which might need an operation, Yeh said.

The team is scheduled to play two training games with the Sinon Bulls at the Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium Oct. 11-12 and three other warm-ups against Cuba, the Netherlands and Japan at the Tienmu Baseball Stadium in Taipei City on Oct. 18, 19 and 20, respectively.
The complete 24-man roster for Taiwan's national team is as follows:
Pitchers (11): Pan Wei-lun, Hsu Ming-chieh, Huang Chih-lung, Chen Hung-wen, Lo Chin-lung, Lin Yi-hao, Liao Wen-yang, Lin Yu-ching, Chen Kuan-yu, Lin Chen-hua and Lai Hung-cheng.
Catchers (3): Kao Chih-kang, Chen Chun-hsiu and Lin Kun-sheng.
Infielders (6): Kao Kuo-ching, Lin Chih-sheng, Chen Yung-chi, Kuo Yen-wen, Lin Han and Hsiao Poh-ting.
Outfielders (4): Lo Kuo-hui, Lin Che-hsuan, Chung Chen-yu and Liu Fu-hao.
Taiwan finished third in the last Intercontinental Cup held in Taichung in early November 2006, and soon after won the title at the Asian Games held in Doha later that month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Drill held to simulate science park being hit by earthquake
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/10 23:00:04 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior staged a drill Monday to simulate a massive earthquake hitting the Hsinchu Science Park, Taiwan's "Silicon Valley," in northern Taiwan.

Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said the drill was set up to respond to a simulated magnitude 6.8 earthquake caused by movement of the Hsincheng Fault, which affects the Taoyuan, Hsinchu, and Miaoli areas.
Jiang said the Hsinchu Science Park is the powerhouse of Taiwan's high-tech industry with a great number of laboratories and chemical plants.
Damage control and management have become more important, especially after the fire at a Nan Ya Plastics Corp. factory in Chiayi County a day earlier, he said.
"If one Nan Ya plant can have such an impact, we can imagine the tremendous impact if the entire science park is affected," he added.
He said that although 70-80 percent of earthquakes in the area hit eastern Taiwan, the heaviest casualties often occur in western Taiwan.

"We should not take the impact of earthquakes on densely populated areas lightly, " he said. "Compared with Hualien or other areas in southern Taiwan, Hsinchu may not have as many faults, but any fault could move,"

The drill was divided into two stages. The first stage covered the first six hours, with the park being engulfed in flames after explosions, railway trains being stopped at Jhunan, toxic gases being released into the air and buildings collapsing.

During the second stage, between the seventh and 30th hour, outbound traffic and communications of remote townships were cut off, serious damage to reservoirs occurred, and urban areas were engulfed in fire.

The drill was performed to mark National Disaster Prevention Day, which is normally held on Sept. 21 to mark the 7.3 magnitude earthquake that killed more than 2,400 people and devastated central Taiwan on that day in 1999.
This year's drill was postponed because of Typhoon Fanapi, which landed on Taiwan Sept. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 5, 2010, or the 28th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1830: Chester A. Arthur, the 21st president of the United States, is born. Arthur became president after the assassination of James A. Garfield.
1908: Bulgaria declares its independence from the Ottoman Empire with Ferdinand I assuming the title of czar of Bulgaria.
1922: Tsao Kun is elected president of the Peking government.
1930: The first Balkan Conference is held in Athens, with representatives from countries from the Balkan Peninsula and Turkey taking part.
1941: Chinese forces heavily defeat Japanese invaders near the Milo River in northern Hunan Province, killing or wounding nearly 80,000 Japanese troops.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek accepts General George C. Marshall's proposal for a 10-day cease-fire to pave the way for a resumption of peace talks. Marshall arrived in Chungking on Dec. 22, 1945 as U.S. President Harry Truman's special envoy.
1951: The Republic of China's Legislative Yuan passes regulations providing farmland to soldiers.
1958: The United States delivers a batch of "Hercules" ground-to-air missiles, known in Taiwan as the "Goddess of Victory" missiles, to help improve the ROC's national defense.
1970 Anwar Sadat becomes the president of Egypt following the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Togo.
1973: Taiwan's first case of coronary artery surgery is performed at National Taiwan University Hospital.
1974: The third World Chinese Christian Conference opens in Taipei.
1976: The fifth World Chinese Tourism Amity Conference opens in Taipei with E. T. Chu, chairman of the Taiwan Visitors' Association, presiding.
1978: More than 20,000 boy scouts and brownies from Taiwan and 10 foreign countries launch an eight-day series of camping activities in the 5th National Jamboree held in Kaohsiung.
1980: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi arrives in Taipei to take part in the 16th Conference of the Asian Parliamentarians Union.
1983: Poland's Solidarity leader Lech Walesa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: The Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: Premier Lee Huan instructs the Executive Yuan to set up special task forces to study problems concerning law and order, communications, environmental pollution, public housing, and economic crimes.
1991: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev pledges to match the United States in scraping tactical nuclear weapons.
1991: Cheng Kung, the first guided missile frigate built in Taiwan, is launched.
1993: Communist China breaks its moratorium on nuclear testing.
1996: Some 50 countries adopt a declaration calling for the earliest possible agreement on a global ban on anti-personnel land mines.
1998: The Judiciary Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives votes to recommend an impeachment inquiry into President Bill Clinton's action during the Monica Lewinsky case.
1999: The U.S. House of Representatives passes a bill in favor of Taiwan's participation in international organizations, especially the World Health Organization.
2000: Hung Chien-hsiung, a 27-year-old man, donates 60 percent of his liver to his father in a transplant operation that is the only way to save the older man's life.
2001: Gao Xingjian, who won the Nobel Prize in literature in 2000 -- the first Chinese writer to win the prestigious award, shows his other talent by opening an exhibition of his paintings in Taipei.
2001: Republic of China Presdient Chen Shui-bian receives visiting U.S. economist Lester Thurow, exchanging views with him on the economic problems faced by Taiwan and the rest of the world.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The fact that a man is able to confront the spiritual powers of the universe without any doubt, shows that he understands the will of God. The fact that he is prepared to wait a hundred generations after him for the man of perfect divine nature without any misgiving, shows that he understands the nature of man."
