DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan presses for F-16 C/D sale
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/05/10 11:09:29 (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan renewed a call Monday for the United States to approve its request for F-16C/D fighters to help enhance its air defense capability against China's military threat.

Yang Nien-dzu, deputy defense minister of Taiwan, said during the annual U.S.-Taiwan Defense Industry Conference held in Cambridge, Maryland that the security threat faced by Taiwan has not eased despite closer cooperation with China on economic issues.
The situation was highlighted in July when Chinese defense minister Liang Guanglie commented that Taiwan affairs were the main focus of China's military buildup, Yang said.
Taiwan's need to beef up its weak air defense was also publicized in a report on China's military development released earlier this year by the U.S. Department of Defense, he noted.
According to Yang, F-16C/D fighters, along with diesel-electric submarines, are the weapons most urgently needed by Taiwan to maintain a minimum, basic self- defense capability.
Failure to obtain these weapons is like being without an important piece of a jigsaw puzzle and leaves Taiwan's defense deployment incomplete, he said.
The United States has not ruled out selling Taiwan the 66 F16C/D fighters it has requested, but it has dragged its feet on making a commitment of any kind out of fear of angering Beijing.
Some have speculated that Washington might opt to instead provide upgrades of Taiwan's fleet of F16 A/B aircraft.
The U.S.-Taiwan Defense Industry has been held annually since 2002.

U.S. officials participating in this year's Oct. 3-5 conference included Beth M. McCormick, deputy assistant secretary of state for defense, trade and regional security, and Wallace Gregson, assistant secretary of defense for Asian & Pacific security affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Flexible diplomacy shows results

TEXT.P: Following in the footsteps of the United Kingdom, Ireland and Japan, the European Union is expected to include Taiwan in its visa waiver program at the end of this year.
This demonstrates that Taiwan's economic strength has won widespread attention in the international community, which is something Taiwan should take pride in.
The development is also obviously related to the state of detente across the Taiwan Strait.

Since the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou in May 2008, Taiwan and China have stopped their zero-sum confrontation. A "diplomatic truce" mindset has been adopted in dealing with international affairs.

That has resulted in Taiwan attaining observer status at the World Health Assembly, an end to the fierce cross-strait competition for diplomatic allies, and progress in Taiwan's efforts to sign free trade agreements with its trade partners.
The EU's decision to provide visa-free treatment for Taiwan will be yet another major achievement of Ma's cross-strait and foreign policies. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 5, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Central bank takes up fight against hot money

TEXT.P: The Taiwan dollar surged past the so-called "Perng Fai-nan" barrier of NT$31 against the U.S. greenback at one point Monday amid an influx of hot money, but it weakened later in the session to close at NT$31.250, thanks to the intervention of the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan).

Central bank Governor Perng Fai-nan reportedly chaired a brainstorming session with the heads of the bank's currency affairs and market research departments Monday evening to assess the direction of hot money flows.
They also plotted new strategies on working with other Asian central banks to protect the local currency from hot money attacks.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Economic Daily News:
Banking sources said the central bank pumped at least NT$20 billion into the foreign exchange market Monday to stabilize the Taiwan dollar's exchange rate against the greenback.

The local currency appreciated NT$0.3 to hit NT$30.976 -- the highest level since August 2008 -- at one point, but then weakened amid central bank intervention. At the end of the day, the local currency had only gained NT$0.06 over the previous trading session to close at anearly 25-month high of NT$31.25.

Local currency dealers said the Taiwan dollar has ranged between NT$31 and NT$34 to the greenback over the past two years, indicating that the central bank will not stand aside and allow the currency to spike past NT$31, a level known as the "Perng Fai-nan" barrier.

When asked about her view of the Taiwan dollar's recent upward trend, Christina Liu, chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that given Taiwan's steady economic recovery, it was only natural for the Taiwan dollar to appreciate because currency values tend to reflect countries' economic situation.

Market analysts said a combination of factors have contributed to the Taiwan dollar's appreciation in recent days. A major cause was the central bank's decision to raise its key interest rates by 0.125 percentage points from Oct. 1.
That fueled an influx of hot money because other Asian countries such as South Korea and Malaysia have suspended interest rate adjustments.

Another factor is that the local currency has appreciated by only 2.44 percent against the dollar since the beginning of this year, a range far smaller than the Japanese yen's rise of 10.46 percent, the Thai baht's appreciation of 8.9 percent and the Korean won's rise of 3.57 percent.

According to economic officials, the Taiwan dollar's 1.5 percent rise in value over the past two weeks has helped cushion domestic inflationary pressures fueled by recent hikes in raw materials prices in global markets. (Oct. 5, 2010).
Commercial Times:
With a listless greenback, Asian central banks have had a hard time protecting their currencies from appreciating too drastically amid an influx of hot money.
Market sources said signs have become more palpable that Asian central banks might be losing the battle to prevent hot money attacks on their currencies.
On Monday, the Korean won rose to a five-month high of 1,122.3 against the greenback, breaking the Korean central bank's target of keeping the won below the 1,130 level.
Despite the Thai central bank's intervention, the baht still surged past the 30.15 barrier to hit a 13-year high of 30.05 Monday.
In Taiwan, central bank officials are working on new strategies to cooperate with other Asian central banks to stabilize the Taiwan dollar's exchange rate, senior bankers said.
According to statistics released by the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) , inbound foreign exchange remittances amounted to US$2.35 billion in September, a five-month high.
Accumulated capital inflows for the first nine months of this year hit US$157.78 billion, according to FSC statistics. (Oct. 5, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA urges Taiwanese tourists to keep alert over superbug
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 12:24:07 (By Garfie Li and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Tuesday urged Taiwanese nationals visiting India to remain alert to the danger of being infected by drug-resistant bacteria carrying the NDM-1 gene.
The MOFA said Taiwanese citizens who are in India for business or pleasure should pay special attention to disease prevention if they need to be treated at a hospital in the South Asian country.

The MOFA warning came after Taiwan reported its first superbug case Monday -- a cameraman for cable TV news station TVBS who contracted the disease while being treated in an Indian hospital after being shot during a visit to New Delhi in September.
He was confirmed as having a bacterium carrying the NDM-1 gene on Monday, but has not shown any symptoms from the antibiotic-resistant bug.
The Centers for Centers Disease Control (CDC) listed NDM-1, short for New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase-1, as a notifiable disease in September.
The ministry said Taiwanese citizens traveling to India who need any assistance should use the emergency number 9810-502-610 to contact Taiwan's representative office there.

It also advised Taiwanese nationals to closely follow information of the superbug by frequently logging onto the CDC's website or to call the CDC for advice in case they have to get medical care in India.
The CDC has required local hospitals to immediately report any suspected cases of the superbug, especially those in which the patient has received medical treatment in India or Pakistan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- 'B'in Music' writes Taiwan's concert history

TEXT.P: Music enthusiast Ason Chen had such a strong belief that concerts were the future of the music industry that he ended his 20-year career with a noted record company in 2007 to open his own concert promotion business.

Today, Chen's company, known as B'in Music, has emerged as the leading promoter in the field. In July and August alone, B'in Music organized 13 concerts at home and abroad that attracted more than 130,000 music fans, and in the first eight months of 2010, it held over 30 concerts drawing 300,000 people.

Among concert promoters in Taiwan, B'in Music is unrivaled as a concert promoter, organizing at least 50 percent more concerts than any music company in Taiwan. From January to August this year, it totaled NT$80 million (US$2.56 million) in concert and merchandising sales.

Chen joined Rock Records Co. after graduating from college and has planned album promotional campaigns ever since. One of his most successful collaborations has been with the band Mayday, which released its first album in 1999.
His plan to have Mayday to perform on the streets of Taipei City's Ximending for a month when the band first hit the market proved successful in building a fan base.
In a subsequent concert open to anyone who showed up with Mayday's album, 20,000 people attended. It was then that Chen first appreciated the potential of concerts.

Record companies began to feel the impact of online music downloads in 2004 and saw record sales drop sharply in Taiwan from their peak of NT$11 billion. The downward trend eventually created an opening for Chen to pursue his vision.

Because Rock Records was affected by the industry downturn and unable to support all of its singers, Chen and Rock Records colleague Hsieh Chih-fen took several artists with them and set up B'in Music in 2007 after discussions with Rock Records' management.
Believing that "each concert is unique itself as it cannot be recreated once you miss it, " Chen's strategy for B'in Music requires that all of its artists are able to perform in live concerts.
The market for concerts in Chinese-speaking regions, including Singapore and Malaysia, has been growing rapidly since 2003, remaining unaffected by the Internet boom.

Income from concerts currently accounts for nearly 50 percent of B'in Music's revenue, and the company is the only one in the industry that has its own department dedicated to organizing and promoting concerts.

Chou Yu-yang, who heads B'in Music's concert production unit, said the department has grown from three people to the current staff of 11, with "at least two concert projects running at any time and up to five projects at the most." The company also produces concerts of artists from different labels.
Willing to invest money to create the perfect concert experience and keeping ticket prices low are also elements of Chen's strategy that makes his company's concerts stand out from others.
"The goal is to make the audience develop expectations of the next concert right after the conclusion of the one they've just attended," Chen said.

Compared with the NT$2,000 average ticket price of concerts in Taiwan, tickets to B'in Music concerts average NT$1,200 to make them more affordable for students, who account for nearly half of the company's ticket sales.
The gamble that Chen took in 2007 seems to be paying off and has allowed him to further give expression to his passion for music.
"I've always wondered what I would do if the world were to end tomorrow," Chen said. "I think I would want everybody to gather for a concert."

DOC.HEADLINE: Superbug is unstoppable but not easily contracted: health minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 13:18:32 (by M.S. Huang and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Bacteria carrying the NDM-1 gene cannot be blocked but can only be transmitted through open wounds, meaning infection will not occur easily, Taiwan's health minister said Tuesday in trying to ease public anxiety over the superbug.

Taiwan reported on Monday that a TV cameraman who was infected during a hospital stay in New Delhi in September had become the country's first carrier of multi- drug resistant bacteria with the gene mutation known as NDM-1.

But because he was asymptomatic, he was discharged from Taipei Veterans General Hospital Monday, raising fears he could spread the NDM-1 gene carried in the bug to other bacteria, which could eventually infect others.

Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang told reporters prior to a legislative hearing that because the superbug was a category-four notifiable disease, the cameraman, described as healthy and well, was not subject to quarantine by law.
After a discussion with specialists, the carrier was sent home because remaining in the hospital could lead to possible infections of other hospital patients, Yaung said.
"We cannot stop the bug" because there could be an incubation period for healthy carriers, said Yaung, who contended it was safer to return the infected individual to his community.
But Yaung also noted that economic activity could not suddenly be brought to a halt, making it "impossible" to restrict the carrier's daily activities.
The priority now, he said, was to improve hospital infection control practices.
"I have to be frank, it is unstoppable, " Yaung said of the NDM-1 gene, which makes bacteria resistant even to the carbapenem group of antibiotics known as "last resort" drugs.

Yaung said the bug was "definitely unlike" the swine flu, known medically as influenza A (H1N1) . Swine flu, he said, was spread through phlegm and coughing, while the superbug is transmitted through wounds and, like hepatitis B, is not easily transferred to others.
"It is a problem, but it will definitely not become a nationwide public health crisis immediately, " Yaung added, pledging that health officials will keep track of the bacteria.
Meanwhile, Yaung said the DOH has decided to fine the Chinese-language Apple Daily for running a picture of the superbug carrier in Tuesday's paper.
Though the carrier's identity is known, the paper was not allowed to print his picture in the newspaper, Yaung said.
"Maybe Apple Daily has more money than others, so we will fine them," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Casual review of judicial nominations

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan held a public hearing Monday as a pre-screening of the president's judicial nominations. Legislators, however, had collected very limited information about Rai Hau-min, the candidate to lead the Judicial Yuan, obtaining only a biography of Rai with no mention of his ideas for judicial reform.

There is a big difference between Taiwan and the United States in dealing with judicial nomination hearings. On the nomination of Elena Kagan for Supreme Court justice, for example, the U.S. Senate's Judiciary Committee compiled 70 files on Kagan and her opinions and spent four days hearing the testimony of 26 witnesses.
The Legislative Yuan must change its bad habit of goofing around and learn from the serious attitude of the U.S. Senate to be qualified to demand judicial reform. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 5, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Protesters take aim at landfill project in Tainan County

TEXT.P: Over 500 residents of Tainan County's Longci Township smashed chairs, flipped tables, and clashed with police Tuesday to protest the construction of a proposed landfill that they feared will cause irreversible damage to the area's ecosystem.

The project, involving a landfill and an industrial waste management facility in the Longci Industrial Park, has received the green light from the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) and the Tainan County Government, but the protesters were not convinced it will be environmentally sound.

"We are adamantly against the project because we believe the toxic by-products will seep into the ground and taint our water, soil and air, " said Cheng Wen- chien, an environmental specialist at the Longci Township office.
"Although the company has assured us they will keep pollution to the minimum, area residents are still extremely worried."

The protests broke out at a meeting in the township held by the project's contractor, Ocin Environmental Co., to notify local residents of the landfill plan, on which work is scheduled to begin at the end of the year.
Several people were reportedly hurt during the altercations, but the project's contractor insisted that the plan will move forward despite the staunch opposition of local residents.

"The company will continue doing its best to communicate with local residents but there is no plan to suspend the project, " said Hsu Chih-hau, manager of the partially state-owned Ocin Environmental Company, which was awarded the project by the Industrial Development Bureau.

Addressing the protesters' concerns, Hsu told the Central News Agency that his company has planned ample measures to prevent any leakage of toxic products, including using cement-based solidification to treat waste materials and recycling water discharged from the facility.
He also said much of the 41-hectare site designated for the project will retain its original landscape because the landfill and waste management plant will only occupy 14.5 hectares of land.
The project has economic benefits as well, Hsu said.

The company is obligated by law to contribute NT$60 million to the Tainan County government, with 70 percent of the funds going directly to Longci Township to fund local development, the executive said.
In addition, the project will create an estimated 30 to 50 jobs once it becomes operational roughly 10 months after construction begins, Hsu added.
But with local residents becoming more environmentally conscious, Hsu and his company may still face resistance in the future.
One protester, Hsiao Hsiu-hua, said she will fight against the landfill to the end.
"Who in their right mind would accept a garbage dump right in their backyard?" she wondered.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 0.55 percent

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 0.55 percent Tuesday as investors took cues from a Wall Street fall overnight amid lingering concerns over the global economy, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 45.67 points to 8,200.43, after moving between 8,155.30 and 8,217.86, on turnover of NT$116.34 billion (US$3.72 billion).

The market opened down 0.34 percent on the Wall Street losses, and the pressure increased as investors continued to abandon the high-tech sector on fears that a rising Taiwan dollar would undermine the export-oriented sector's global competitiveness, dealers said.
A total of 2,739 stocks closed down and 1,102 finished up, with 255 stocks remaining unchanged.

The foodstuff sector suffered the steepest decline, down 1.92 percent. Textiles shares fell 1.91 percent, plastics and chemical stocks lost 0.66 percent, machinery and electronics shares shed 0.64 percent and financials closed down 0.58 percent.
The paper and pulp sector lost 0.48 percent and the cement sector fell 0.43 percent, while the construction sector rose 0.91 percent.
"After a recent strong showing, the local bourse was susceptible to negative factors at home and abroad as investors tended to take profits," Mega Securities analyst Alex Huang said.

Huang said the worse than expected August factory orders data in the U.S. dampened market sentiment as investors were afraid that further disappointing economic figures would indicate a weak global economy.
"Investors here seized the decline on Wall Street as an excuse to sell," Huang said. "The current high valuation of the local market may encourage more selling to test the 8,100-point level soon."
Huang advised investors to keep their distance from the bellwether electronics sector, in particular the semiconductor segment, as it needs more time to overcome competitiveness concerns.
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. fell 1.29 percent to NT$61.10 and rival United Microelectronics Corp. lost 0.72 percent to NT$13.70.
However, the transport sector outperformed the broader market on increasing cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges, with China Airlines up 2.14 percent at NT$23.90 and EVA Airways up 1.27 percent at NT$27.90.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's urban renewal plan may keep home prices high: analyst
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 16:27:23 (By Chen Yi-chun and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: A new urban renewal plan unveiled by the government will likely keep home prices high by encouraging more funds to flow into the local property market, an analyst said Tuesday.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) approved on Monday a proposal by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) to earmark more than NT$18 billion (US$576 million) in financial assistance to help homeowners remodel or rebuild their properties.
"While the central bank has raised interest rates to cap local property prices, the government continues to pump capital into the market," Hua Nan Securities analyst Lin Cheng-chien said.
"The market has gotten the message. The government does not seem to want to see local property prices fall," Lin said.
The central bank hiked the discount rate by another 0.125 percentage points at a policy-making meeting on Sept. 30, marking the second consecutive quarterly rate hike since June.
The central bank's move was interpreted by market observers as the latest in a series of measures to prevent a property bubble.

Lin said the NT$18 billion urban renewal plan, which still requires approval of the Cabinet, is expected to boost home prices, especially in the Greater Taipei area, where those who participate in the plan will reap relatively higher financial gains.
Home prices in the Greater Taipei area have risen more than 30 percent after the local property market was hard-hit by a global financial meltdown in 2008.
Hu Chung-ying, deputy minister of the CEPD, said the urban renewal plan aims to improve the living standards of the country's urban areas and provide a better living environment for the public.
The government is expected to receive applications from about 20,000 home owners for loans to rebuild or remodel their properties under the plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady to follow Taiwanese Opera troupe on European tour
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 16:35:44 (By Cheng Ching-wen and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: First lady Chow Mei-ching will follow the Ming Hwa Yuan Arts and Cultural Group on its six-country, seven-city European tour later this month as the troupe's honorary director.
The first lady will fly to Berlin on Oct. 10 to join the first leg of the Taiwanese Opera group's tour, Ming Hwa Yuan said in a statement.

Chow will see the group and star diva Sun Tsui-feng start the tour with its most popular production, The Living Buddha, in the German city and then follow the Taiwanese Opera troupe to Prague, Vienna, Paris, London, Edinburgh and Amsterdam.
The tour is scheduled to end on Oct. 22.
Apart from nine formal performances, the troupe also plans workshops at universities to introduce the traditional Taiwanese art form to audiences in Europe, the statement said.

The first lady has made several cultural and humanitarian trips overseas this year, including as honorary director of the Cloud Gate Dance Theatre, a role similar to the one she will play with Ming Hwa Yuan.
She also traveled to Haiti and the Dominican Republic in August as an ambassador for the charity World Vision Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Following the wishes of its 'higher-ups'

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Wu Den-yih said recently that the government could study the possibility of imposing a luxury tax or a capital gains tax targeting wealthy individuals in an effort to narrow Taiwan's growing gap between rich and poor.
The Ministry of Finance (MOF) , however, has been unusually passive about the idea, saying that the government needs to take "timing" into consideration in conducting tax reform.

Over the past two years, the MOF's performance has been disappointing because it has always complied with whatever was dictated by its "higher-ups." We hope this time the MOF's "higher-ups" are serious about promoting reform, because this will greatly increase its chance of success.

In fact, similar reform proposals have undergone numerous studies and discussions, and the government is well aware of whether they are feasible or not. What the government needs now is the determination to put the ideas for reform into practice, rather than conducting more studies. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 5, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: China's Ministry of Commerce delegation to visit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 17:10:56 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Hanna Liu)

TEXT.P: A delegation from China's Ministry of Commerce will attend the 2010 Asia MICE forum in Taipei Oct. 7-8, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said in a statement released Monday.
The delegation will be led by Huo Jianguo, director of the Chinese Academy of International Trade and Economic Cooperation (CAITEC) under the Commerce Ministry, TAITRA said.
CAITEC, which owns the largest Chinese library database in commerce and trade, is a think tank as well as a social science research and consulting institute.
During the conference, Huo will participate in a panel discussion in his capacity as president of the China Convention and Exhibition Society (CEES), TAITRA noted.

The delegation consists of 47 members from the convention and exhibition society, including representatives from companies and organizations such as INTEX Shanghai Co. Ltd. and China National Automotive Industry International Corporation.
Meanwhile, the annual conference will highlight topics including: new development trends of cross-Taiwan Strait MICE industry and incentives for the tourism industry, an official from TAITRA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Transport ministry launches traffic safety quiz

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) launched a quiz Tuesday on traffic safety to call attention to the requirement that road-users should give priority to pedestrians.

The campaign, conducted via the online Facebook social networking website, is a continuing effort to take advantage of such networks to raise public awareness about road safety, according to the Traffic Safety Commission under the MOTC, which launched the quiz.
"We've been trying to target different demographics through various Internet applications, and have found this approach to be effective," said Hsu Tai-sheng, a division chief of the commission.

He added that another ongoing competition, which encourages Internet users to submit home-made video clips about traffic safety to YouTube, has also drawn better participation than traditional campaigns.

The quiz, which will run through Nov. 15, includes five sets of questions in cartoon form and addresses various traffic scenarios. Facebook users who take the quiz are asked to score themselves and compare their results with those of their friends.

Social network sites such as Facebook are becoming increasingly influential in forming and gauging public opinion, and more and more government agencies are becoming aware of this trend and are trying to take advantage of the opportunities presented.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD chief calls appreciation of Taiwan dollar 'not surprising'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 18:41:17 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The recent appreciation of Taiwan's currency was "not surprising at all" because it has simply mirrored the rise of other Asian currencies against the weakening U.S. dollar, Taiwan's top economic planner said Tuesday.

Speaking on the sideline of an economic seminar, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairwoman Christina Liu said most Asian currencies -- and especially the Japanese yen -- have been relatively strong against the greenback recently.

"Although Japan's economy has not yet staged a strong recovery, the U.S. and European economies have not performed so well either, and that resulted in a stronger yen against the greenback and euro and the rise of other Asian currencies," Liu said.
"Therefore, the appreciation of the Taiwan dollar is not surprising at all."

The local currency closed at NT$31.250 against the U.S. dollar Monday, its highest level against the greenback in two years, and even broke the NT$31 barrier during the session before the central bank intervened.
The Taiwan dollar's appreciation of 2.4 percent over the past month has fueled growth concerns because of the country's export-oriented economy.

The electronics sub-index on Taiwan's stock exchange has fallen by 1.8 percent over the last three trading sessions on investor fears that companies in the country's dominant industry could see their margins squeezed if the currency appreciates much further.

Liu said, however, that Asian countries have become less resistant to allowing their currencies to rise over the past six months, because of a growing focus on boosting domestic demand instead of relying heavily on exports.

The appreciation of the local currency would not only benefit domestic-demand sectors, but also benefit manufacturers that need to import raw materials as well as Taiwanese residents traveling abroad, she said.

Liu argued that a country's currency should reflect its genuine value, without favoring specific industries or people, and that its central bank needs to let the market reflect the value of the currency.

That appeared to be at odds with the position of Taiwan's central bank, which has intervened in the market to keep the country's exchange rate against the greenback at relatively stable levels in the face of an influx of hot money.
The central bank's approach has led observers to call the NT$31 exchange rate the "Perng Fai-nan" barrier, referring to the central bank governor.
Taiwan's currency closed relatively unchanged Tuesday at NT$31.252 to the greenback, after moving as high as NT$31.035 earlier in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier vows to deal with freeway collapse issues
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 19:07:00 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday that the government will deal with the issues surrounding a collapse at a construction site on the No. 6 Freeway in central Taiwan in which seven people died, including six runaway Indonesian workers.

The premier said in an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan that the government will investigate to see if there were any flaws in the design and construction at the construction site, as well as probing possible negligence on the part of the contractors.
He was referring to the fatal collapse of a 50-meter tall, 80-meter wide section of scaffolding used in the construction of a freeway interchange last Thursday.
"The government will definitely deal with any contractors who have hired illegal foreign workers," he said.

He noted that there were at one point 90,000 foreign workers unaccounted for and that after efforts by the Council of Labor Affairs and related government agencies, 60,000 have been found and repatriated, leaving 30,000 still unaccounted for.
"The government has to deal with the issue quickly; otherwise, they will still be a potential source of disturbance," he added.
In related news that same day, the sixth and final Indonesian victim of the freeway accident was identified as Mansur Ali, the National Immigration Agency said Tuesday.
The NIA said the man arrived in Taiwan Oct. 21, 2006 and worked as a technician in Taiping, Taichung County before absconding April 15, 2007.

The premier also mentioned three accidents involving the Formosa Plastics Group, one of Taiwan's largest private conglomerates -- two fires and explosions at its petrochemical complex in Mailiao in July and a fire that wreaked havoc at its Nanya plant in Chiayi Sunday.

"The internal management of a company is crucial. The Ministry of Economic Affairs' Industrial Development Bureau and related government agencies will see to it that FPG reviews its safety management," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Philippine police arrest Taiwanese suspects in smuggling case
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 19:34:56 (By Emerson Lim and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Philippine immigration authorities on Monday arrested two Taiwanese men suspected of drug trafficking between Taiwan and the Philippines.
The arrest in the southern Philippines' Davao City was the result of an international operation by Taiwan's Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) and the Philippines Bureau of Immigration.

According to the CIB, one of the two key suspects, surnamed Lin, was involved in a heroin smuggling case in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County in May 2009. Four other suspects in that case, carrying a total of 6 kilograms of heroin, have been arrested in Taiwan.
Lin, who has run a seafood company in Davao since 1999, allegedly gave a boat captain 16 pieces of high-purity heroin of 375 grams apiece, the CIB said.
The other key suspect, surnamed Chang, was also involved in a violation of the Narcotics Endangerment Prevention Act in 2000.
In addition to the two key suspects, authorities also arrested four Taiwanese at Lin's company who were suspected of working in the Philippines without work permits.
Lin and Chang are expected to be extradited to Taiwan within two months if they are not found to be involved in any other criminal cases in the Philippines, the police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Symposium reviews relations with US, Japan, China

TEXT.P: A strong security partnership between the United States and Japan is vital for Taiwan's security and confidence, and China's growing military prowess is aimed at more than just unifying Taiwan, former Japanese and U.S. officials said Tuesday at a symposium.

"A strong U.S.-Japan alliance allows Taiwan to feel secure" and Taiwan's security would be badly damaged if the U.S. could not respond in the region quickly enough due to a lack of presence in Japan, said Dan Blumenthal, a research fellow at the American Enterprise Institute who served as senior country director for China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Mongolia under the U.S. State Department.
Blumenthal was speaking at an international symposium on "50 years of U.S.-Japan Security Alliance and the Security of Taiwan" in Taipei.

The U.S. and Japan signed a treaty of mutual cooperation and security in 1960 to strengthen Japan's relations with the West during the Cold War. At the "two- plus-two" Security Consultative Conference in 2005, the Taiwan Strait was explicitly included for the first time as a common interest.
Blumenthal said, however, that insecurity has often been ignored in Washington and that the current U.S. administration tends to embrace slogans without strategic thinking.

With China's rapidly growing economic and military power, the balance of power in East Asia has changed as China "has unmasked itself," showing that its military expansion means more than just the eventual unification of Taiwan, Blumenthal said. China has clear goals in its military buildup because it is "quite unhappy with many political arrangements in the Asian Pacific region," he said.

China has been trying to throw its weight around in Asia, he said, evidenced by a series of international events this year, including the crisis on the Korean Peninsula and disputes in the East China Sea and the South China Sea.

The U.S.-Japan security treaty was more than just a bilateral partnership but also "public goods" that played a stabilizing role in East Asia and will benefit Taiwan and other countries, Japanese Congressman Shigeru Ishiba, who served as Minister of Defense in the former Liberal Democratic Party administration, wrote in a thesis delivered at the symposium. He did not attend the symposium due to a political commitment in Japan.

Japan and Taiwan have been "sandwiched" between a pair of superpowers -- a rising China and a "declining U.S." -- and both need to find a position that serves their national interests, said Gen Nakatani, a congressman who served as head of the Japan Defense Agency under former Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi.
The inclusion of the Taiwan Strait in the 2005 two-plus-two declaration is Japan's "commitment as a country" and is expected to be kept in place regardless of which party is in power, Nakatani said.
The one-day symposium was organized by the Taiwan National Security Institute and gathered scholars and former officials from Taiwan, Japan and the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: Solar energy association urges government to speed up purchases
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 19:47:35 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Solar power generation system outfitters urged the government Tuesday to speed up the purchasing of solar power generated by private firms to help the sector survive.

Under the Renewable Energy Development Act, the government is allowed to purchase solar power or other renewable electricity generated by the private sector to encourage private enterprises to engage in the green energy business.

Life Lai, head of the Solar Power Generation System Association of the Republic of China, said that the application procedure to seek government purchases of solar power is very complicated, making it difficult for applicants to enjoy the benefits of the incentives. The association comprises companies that design solar energy systems for businesses and government offices.
"It is stunning that since the law was enacted in July 2009, none of the six applications that were filed to seek government purchases have been approved," Lai said.
"Before the government purchases the power, the firms that bought the generation equipment from us will not pay," he said.

Lai said the sticking point is that state-owned Taiwan Power Co., which acts as the only renewable power buyer on behalf of the government, has erected procedural barriers that make the approval impossible.
Lai said an applicant needs to complete an application of about 250 pages before a long reviewing process by five groups inside Taipower.
The government should remove the barriers to allow easier purchases, or the firms that manufacture and sell solar power generation equipment will not be able to survive, he said.
The number of local solar power generation equipment makers has fallen to about 36 from a peak of more than 200 before a global financial meltdown hurt the local economy in 2008.
"The difficulties in landing government purchases of power have made the situation worse, " Lai said. "Without any improvement in the application process, the number will continue to fall."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese movies expected to shine at Pusan film festival: GIO

TEXT.P: A collection of 12 Taiwanese films are ready to take the 15th Pusan International Film Festival by storm this week to show Taiwan's cinematic prowess, the Government Information Office (GIO) said Tuesday, two days before the festival is set to kick off.

Ranging from romantic comedies to suspense thrillers to tearjerkers, the 12 films best represent Taiwan's cinematic creativity and "soft power, " said Chen Chih-kuan, director of the Department of Motion Pictures under the GIO.

"After Cape No. 7 in 2008, Taiwan's film industry has enjoyed a boom period, churning one great movie after another. There is no time like right now to invest in Taiwanese movies, " he said, recalling a dark period for the industry a few years back when a local film was considered a smash if it grossed over NT$3 million (US$96,674).

Paying tribute to the Taiwanese directors and producers who refused to give up their silver screen dreams even during the tough times, Chen said that at present, "a Taiwan-made movie can easily reel in over NT$10 million."
This year, avant-garde director Tsai Ming-liang, who has reached the top tier in filmmaking for his pushing-the-envelope style, will be honored with the title of Asian Filmmaker of the Year.

In addition, six Taiwanese films have been invited to compete in the "A Window on Asian Cinema" category, including Ho Wi-ding's "Pinoy Sunday" which takes a stab at the issue of labor by tickling the audience's funny bone, Arvin Chen's crime-caper-romantic-comedy "Au Revoir, Taipei, " and toe-curling thriller "Zoom Hunting" by Cho Li.

Chung Mong-hong's "The Fourth Portrait" featuring a cast of acclaimed actors, "Taipei Exchanges" by Hsiao Ya-chuan, who is a frequent guest at international film festivals, and Hollywood big-name director John Woo's action-packed "Reign of Assassins" will also be shown.

One of the biggest honors received by Taiwanese filmmakers at this year's event is the chance to present "When Love Comes, " a film that explores the issue of unwanted pregnancy and wedlock by award-winning director Chang Tso-chi, at the festival's Gala Presentation.
Taiwanese actress Yang Kuei-mei has also been invited to be one of the five jurors for the "New Currents" category, which honors up-and-coming Asian filmmakers.
An additional 18 Taiwanese films will be featured in the "Asian Film Market, " an event on the sidelines of the festival aimed at educating the region's next generation of filmmakers.
The festival is slated to take place Oct. 7-15 and Taiwan's representative office in South Korea will host a reception to showcase Taiwan's cinematic achievements, according to the GIO.
The Pusan event is the most prestigious film event in Asia and is expected to attract 150,000 film lovers from around the world this year.
The organizers said the festival will boast a record 103 world premiers among its line-up of 308 films.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan finding it easier to host major meetings: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 20:00:33 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is finding it easier to host international meetings in the wake of the signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) earlier this year, the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Tuesday.

Alice Chou, a project leader of the Meeting, Incentive, Conference and Exhibition Project Office, said one of the most important of these, the annual standards meeting of the Third Generation Partnership Project, will take place in Taiwan for the first time next February.

The annual meeting brings together a number of influential telecommunications standards bodies to produce globally applicable technical specifications, which will help improve Taiwan's telecom industry.

As the convention and exhibition industry is included on Taiwan's ECFA "early harvest" list, several Chinese event organizers have signed memorandums of understanding with Taiwan, Chou said, adding that the two sides will soon co- sponsor various meetings.
There will be a total of 400 international exhibitions held in Taiwan before the end of this year, the number and scale of which has increased since the 200-300 of last year, she said.

As an example, Chou said, an annual gathering of the Lions Club in the Asia- Pacific region, which is expected to draw tens of thousands of participants, will take place in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tablet computers not replacing notebooks: Acer founder

TEXT.P: The founder of Acer Inc., the world's second largest computer maker, said Tuesday that both tablet and netbook computers have opened new markets and are not taking market share from laptop computers.
"Tablet and netbook computers are not replacing notebook computers as their functions are not exactly the same, " Stan Shih said on the sidelines of a local forum.
"(Tablet and netbook computers) represent new markets and new applications," he told reporters.
His remarks came as major electronics companies at home and abroad are jumping on the bandwagon led by Apple's iPad to launch their own versions of tablet computers.
The rising market share of tablet computers will not necessarily result in a fall in the market share of laptop computers in the near future, Shih said.
"The market (for notebook computers) is still growing as a lot of people still need them, " he added.
He pointed out that it took many years for notebook computers to replace desktop models.
"Only when notebook computers started having big screens and when their prices became similar to those of desktops did the market share of desktops started shrinking," Shih said.
When asked to comment on media reports that Acer will launch a tablet computer later this year, Shih said he has not yet looked at the tablet computer and is not aware of any plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: China IT service provider seeks TDR sale
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 20:08:18 (By Tian Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Digital China Holdings Ltd., a Chinese integrated IT service provider, is expected to list its Taiwan depository receipts (TDRs) by the end of the fourth quarter of this year, underwriter KGI Securities said Tuesday.
The securities firm said the Chinese company has filed an application with the Taiwan Stock Exchange for the TDR listing to raise funds as working capital.

Digital China, the largest IT integrated service provider in the greater China area, which has been listed in Hong Kong since June 2001, is planning to issue up to 260 million TDRs, each one of which will represent 0.5 common shares of the company, the underwriter said.

It added that Digital China has tentatively set the issue price at NT$29.4 (US$0.94) to raise no more than NT$7.64 billion to build a technology development park and a distribution center and repay its debts.
Digital China operates regional centers in 19 major cities in China, with a network of more than 10,000 agents in China and strategic partnerships with over 100 leading IT vendors worldwide.

Currently, Digital China is the largest software service provider to the Chinese government, the second-largest provider to the Chinese financial sector and the fourth-largest provider to the Chinese telecom business.
In 2009, the company posted net profits of about HK$824 million (NT$3.32 billion), up 28.57 percent from a year earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: Absconded foreign laborers a loophole in management: Control Yuan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 20:21:34 (By Sophia Yeh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: There are presently around 370,000 foreign laborers in Taiwan and nearly 33,000 have absconded and are unaccounted for, creating a loophole in the management of foreign laborers, the Control Yuan, the nation's top watchdog body, said Tuesday.

Control Yuan members Teresa J. C. Yin and Chien Lin Whei-jun said in an investigation report that the National Immigration Agency (NIA) has no data regarding the overstay period, genders or trades of the absconded laborers.
"Such unaccounted foreign laborers have scattered around Taiwan, resulting in a loophole in the management of foreign workers, " the report said.
The report came after a No. 6 Freeway construction accident on Sept. 30 that killed seven people, including six illegal Indonesian workers.

The report said that according to an analysis of the latest statistics from the Council of Labor Affairs, businesses from which foreign workers abscond said the main reason is the urging of their colleagues (49 percent), followed by the expiration of a hiring date (30.4 percent) and hopes for better pay (17.2 percent).
In terms of trade, the absconding rates in the construction and manufacturing sectors accounted for 21.8 percent and 11.4 percent, respectively.

The report also found that although the council has established a foreign brokerage agency assessment system in a bid to curb the hefty fees charged to foreign laborers, it has not rigorously implemented an "exit" mechanism or a policy of strongly fining offenders.
The council should actively review the issue, the Control Yuan urged.

The report said the number of foreign laborers was around 3,000 in 1991, but it had ballooned to 372,146 by August 2000. The number of construction and manufacturing laborers has gradually decreased, while the amount of caregivers has gradually increased, the report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to take `Digital Mobile Classroom' overseas

TEXT.P: Taiwan plans to apply its experience of using vehicles that can serve as computer classrooms to help bridge the digital divide between urban and rural areas to other countries, with the Philippines likely the first, the Taiwanese head of a regional committee said Tuesday.

Stan Shih, founder of Acer, Inc. -- the world's second-largest computer maker -- and chairman of the ADOC 2.0 Project Non-government Steering Committee under the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, said that the project can benefit the maximum number of people due to its mobility.
"The project can move a classroom to anywhere that needs it, " said Shih on the sidelines of an ADOC 2.0 workshop in Taipei.

Shih said that the vehicles, equipped with 20 computers and wireless communications, can go to designated locations or simply park on the street to allow instructors to teach local people how to use computers.
"We are working to benefit as many people as possible through this project, which we started implementing in Hualien (in eastern Taiwan)," he said.
With three such vehicles so far, the project is aimed at helping 20,000 people in the eastern county within three years of its launch in May this year.
Shih told reporters at the workshop, attended by more than 100 representatives from APEC members, that the Philippines could be the first country outside Taiwan to adopt the project.

He said that a company in the Southeast Asian country has expressed interest in the project and might launch it early next year, using computers, teaching materials and methodology provided by Taiwan.

Taiwan has been helping its APEC peers to bridge their digital divides and turn them into digital opportunities, said the two-day forum's organizer, the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

More than 145,000 visits have been recorded at information and communication courses in 56 centers Taiwan has helped set up in Chile, Indonesia, Malaysia, Mexico, Peru, the Philippines, Thailand, Vietnam and other APEC economies since August 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's 'golden pair' tops world rankings
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 21:11:39 (By Hsiao Pao-Hsian and Hanna Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's "golden" women's badminton duo of Cheng Wen-hsing and Chien Yu-chin are now the world's top-ranked doubles team, according to the latest world rankings released Monday by the Badminton World Federation (BWF).
Cheng and Chien vaulted past China's Ma Jin and Wang Xiaoli to claim the top spot following a bronze medal performance at the Japan Super Series badminton championship in late September.
It was the first time the pair was ranked first in the world since January 2008.

The team that defeated Cheng and Chien in the semifinals of the Japan Super Series event, China's Cheng Shu and Zhao Yunlei, moved up to second in the rankings, while Ma and Wang fell to third because Wang won the Japan event with another Chinese partner, Yu Yang.
Cheng and Chien will compete in the 2010 Asian Games in Guangzhou in November and are considered to be one of Taiwan's best bets for a medal.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA English news budget for Oct. 5 (II)
