superbug

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan CPI slightly up in September
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 22:00:40 (By Y.C. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) rose 0.29 percent year-on-year in September, due mainly to rising fuel prices, according to government statistics released Tuesday.

The tallies compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that Taiwan's CPI increased to 105.77 last month, up 0.1 percent from August. The index rose by an average of 0.91 percent during the first three quarters on a year-to-year basis.

By category, garments registered the largest increase at 3.83 percent in September over the previous year's level, while foodstuff prices recorded the steepest fall of 2.03 percent year-on- year, according to DGBAS statistics.
Excluding prices of vegetables, fruit, fish and energy products, September's core CPI grew 0.03 percent compared to August's figure.

The recent appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar against the U.S. currency and noticeable jumps in imports of international raw materials are set to be reflected in the CPI for the coming months, a DGBAS official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan following WHO guidelines for treating superbug

TEXT.P: The government is following World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines on dealing with a man discovered to be a carrier of the new superbug NDM-1, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Tuesday.
Yaung also said that if the issue is mishandled and causes widespread infections, he will hold himself responsible.

Yaung noted that the antibiotic-resistant bacteria is not transmitted though direct person-to-person contact but through open wounds. If the carrier is isolated in a hospital, not only would the chances of infection rise but more panic would be caused among the public.

Yaung added that the man, who was injured in the Indian capital of New Delhi and possibly picked up the infection through surgery done there, must maintain strict personal hygiene but said that "quarantine is not required."
New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase-1 is an enzyme that makes bacteria resistant to nearly all antibiotics, according to the CDC.
Various countries around the world, including Australia, Belgium, Canada, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States, have reported isolated cases of NDM-1, some of which have been fatal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Experts to focus on city marketing at forum

TEXT.P: About 650 specialists from the conference and exhibition industry will attend the annual Asian MICE Forum on Oct. 7-8 to discuss how to promote cities through the organization of large expos and other major events.

The MICE industry -- referring to meetings, incentive travel, conventions and exhibitions -- has been highlighted as one of the top 10 growing industries expected to draw major investment from the Taiwan government, the organizer said.

The government will put NT$2.19 billion (US$71 million) into the MICE industry from 2010 to 2012 with the goal of creating 130,000 jobs and boosting investment in private enterprises by NT$12.9 billion, according to Ministry of Economic Affairs, which sponsored the project.

Experts from China, Japan, South Korea, Thailand and Singapore will attend the annual forum, now in its fifth year, said the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , which organized the meeting.
Some experts will share their experiences with the Shanghai World Expo, last year's World Games in Taiwan and the upcoming Taipei International Flora Expo, the organizer said.

The forum will also feature discussions on how Taiwan and China can cooperate on exhibitions and company-sponsored tours, as more opportunities are expected in these fields after the recent signing of a trade pact between Taiwan and China, TAITRA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan foreign exchange reserves reach new high in September
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 23:00:21 (By Kao Chao-fen and Christie Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves rose for the 23rd consecutive month in September to reach a record high of US$380.51 billion as of the end of that month, the central bank announced Tuesday.
The nation's foreign exchange reserves were up US$8.44 billion from a month earlier, according to the Central Bank of the Republic of China.

Returns from foreign exchange reserves investment and gains by the euro and other major currencies against the U.S. dollar contributed to the increase, said Lin Sun-yuan, director-general of the bank's Department of Foreign Exchange.
Taiwan is the fourth-largest foreign exchange reserves holder in the world, after China, Japan and Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Breast cancer patients ask NHI to subsidize treatment

TEXT.P: Patients with advanced breast cancer pleaded with the government Tuesday to share the heavy financial burden of cancer treatment at a press conference held by the Foundation of Breast Cancer Prevention and Treatment.

One of the two patients, a 29-year-old surnamed Wang, said that the cost of her treatment was not reimbursed by the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) and that even with a private insurance company covering two-thirds of the cost, she still has to pay around NT$30,000 (US$996.80) per month to stay alive.

Wang was diagnosed with her2-positive metastatic breast cancer, or stage four, in 2008. "I was bereft of hope when I learned that the cancer cells had reached my brain and that trastuzumab was not working," Wang said.
She said she then started taking a different drug, lapatanib, which has stabilized her condition but has burned a hole in her pocket.

Chang King-jen, chairman of the Foundation of Breast Cancer Prevention and Treatment, said that about 80 to 100 of Taiwanese female patients like Wang, who have responded poorly to medicines on the government's subsidized list, have difficulty affording lapatanib, which has proved effective in prolonging patient's lives for at least 14 months.

Lin Wei-chieh, secretary-general of the Taiwan Breast Cancer Friends Association, expressed hope that the government will consider reimbursing the drug, giving breast cancer victims a chance to spend more time with their families and friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suspicious waste found near southern reservoir
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 23:14:51 (Lee Hsien-feng and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Slag from the steel-making industry has been found in a landfill near a major reservoir in southern Taiwan's Tainan County, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Tuesday.

The Tainan County Environmental Protection Bureau has taken samples from the exposed slag at the Yongyang Landfill construction area upstream of the Wushantou Reservoir's catchment region for further examination, amid concern that the water in the reservoir might have been contaminated.
Experts found the slag northwest of the site Oct. 3, said Shen Yi-fu, deputy director of the Department of Water Quality Protection.
Shen added that there are fears heavy metals and dioxin the slag contains might have polluted the reservoir water, Shen added.

Part of the landfill, which is still under construction, lies on a faultline and the underground water in the area flows directly into the reservoir, raising concerns among local residents and environmentalists.
The Tainan Environmental Alliance has monitored the landfill for years, suspecting that toxic waste was being dumped there despite the lack of an operating license.
Groundwater at the site has been confirmed to be polluted, Shen said, although the source of the pollution is unclear.

Shen noted that the establishment of the landfill received approval in 1992 after the Tainan County Environmental Bureau passed an environmental impact assessment. However, the company that runs the landfill has never been allowed to begin operating because of the site's location on a faultline.
The Wushantao Reservoir supplies water for irrigation of the Chia-Nan Plain region, for industry, and for water used by a population of over 1 million in the Tainan area.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC reports youngest case of severe enterovirus infection
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 23:15:21 (By Chen Li-ting and Christie Chen)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Centers for Disease Control (CDC) reported Tuesday a severe enterovirus case in a one-day-old infant, the youngest case of enterovirus ever diagnosed in Taiwan.
Although the infant was in stable condition, she remained under observation in hospital, the CDC said.

The infant, born Sept. 16, was reported to be suffering respiratory dysfunction and a fast heartbeat one day after her birth, and might have contracted the virus in the hospital or through mother-to-child transmission, said Shih Wen-yi, deputy director-general of the CDC.
The infant's family, including her six-year old brother, showed no symptoms of infection, Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civic group urges Nobel Peace committee to award Chinese dissident
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 23:21:24 (By Eva Feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A civic society comprised of professors and academics issued a statement Tuesday calling for this year's Nobel Peace Prize to be awarded to Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo, who is currently serving an 11-year sentence in Beijing.
The Taipei Society issued the statement ahead of the announcement of the winner, due Oct. 8.

China, with its track record of abusing human rights and repressing political dissidents, naturally regards Liu's Charter 08 Initiative and his bid for the peace prize as threats to the legitimacy of its regime, and has warned the Nobel Peace Committee not to award the prize to Liu, according to the statement.
The group said it stands in solidarity with Liu and called on the Nobel Peace Committee to award the prize to Liu, despite China's official warning.

The society said that a Nobel Peace Prize for Liu would mean not only recognition of his long-term dedication to human rights and democratic reforms in China, but would also send a clear message to the Chinese communist regime that the world stands in solidarity with Chinese people who share Liu's vision for a strong, prosperous and democratic China that respects individual freedom and human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor wants truth in probe of irregularities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 23:25:57 (By Johnson Sun and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: With investigators carrying out another search of the residence and office of a high-ranking Taipei city government official Tuesday, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said he respects the judicial process and that he hopes the truth can be revealed as soon as possible.

Agents from the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice, led by prosecutors from the Taipei District Prosecutors Office, conducted searches of 11 sites simultaneously earlier that day, including the city government's New Construction Office (NCO) , as well as the residence and office of its secretary-general, Yang Hsi-an.
As Yang is considered the chief of staff of the city government, a local newspaper reported that the latest search seemed to suggest that the investigation might be getting closer to Hau himself.
Asked by reporters about the search while attending a ceremony in Taipei, Hau said that as far he understood, the searches were just aimed at collecting data.
"We respect the justice system, and hope the prosecutors will demonstrate fair judgment and clarify the truth as quickly as possible," he said.

Investigators had already searched the residences and offices of five senior city government officials Sept. 7 looking for evidence of allegations that they allowed contractors to fleece the city government.

The probe was initiated at Hau's request after several city councilors of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed the city government turned a blind eye to construction companies that inflated the price for improving the city's Xinsheng elevated highway.

Hau, who is facing a serious challenge from a DPP candidate in his bid for a second term in the year-end mayoral election, referred the officials in charge of the project to prosecutors after news of the allegations took a heavy toll on his approval rating.

DOC.HEADLINE: Influenza death toll rises to 22: CDC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 23:43:32 (By Chen Li-ting and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Influenza claimed one more life in Taiwan last week, bringing the total number of flu deaths since July to 22, the center for Disease Control (CDC) reported Tuesday.
The figure was approximately the annual average for seasonal flu fatalities for the period.
The patient, who succumbed to an infection by the AH3 strain of the virus, was a 6-year- old girl from southern Taiwan, CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen- yi said.
The six-year-old was hospitalized Sept. 24, one day after developing symptoms including a cough and a high fever. She died Sept. 29, Shih said.
The victim had not been immunized against flu, nor was she taking the antiviral Tamiflu, Shih said.
According to CDC tallies, 15 of the 22 flu-related deaths were AH3 infections and seven were H1N1 infections.
Shih advised the public get vaccinated through the seasonal influenza inoculation program that was launched Oct. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Experts to focus on city marketing at forum

TEXT.P: About 650 specialists from the conference and exhibition industry will attend the annual Asian MICE Forum on Oct. 7-8 to discuss how to promote cities through the organization of large expos and other major events.

The MICE industry -- referring to meetings, incentive travel, conventions and exhibitions -- has been highlighted as one of the top 10 growing industries expected to draw major investment from the Taiwan government, the organizer said.

The government will put NT$2.19 billion (US$71 million) into the MICE industry from 2010 to 2012 with the goal of creating 130,000 jobs and boosting investment in private enterprises by NT$12.9 billion, according to Ministry of Economic Affairs, which sponsored the project.

Experts from China, Japan, South Korea, Thailand and Singapore will attend the annual forum, now in its fifth year, said the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , which organized the meeting.
Some experts will share their experiences with the Shanghai World Expo, last year's World Games in Taiwan and the upcoming Taipei International Flora Expo, the organizer said.

The forum will also feature discussions on how Taiwan and China can cooperate on exhibitions and company-sponsored tours, as more opportunities are expected in these fields after the recent signing of a trade pact between Taiwan and China, TAITRA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan foreign exchange reserves reach new high in September
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 23:00:21 (By Kao Chao-fen and Christie Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves rose for the 23rd consecutive month in September to reach a record high of US$380.51 billion as of the end of that month, the central bank announced Tuesday.
The nation's foreign exchange reserves were up US$8.44 billion from a month earlier, according to the Central Bank of the Republic of China.

Returns from foreign exchange reserves investment and gains by the euro and other major currencies against the U.S. dollar contributed to the increase, said Lin Sun-yuan, director-general of the bank's Department of Foreign Exchange.
Taiwan is the fourth-largest foreign exchange reserves holder in the world, after China, Japan and Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Breast cancer patients ask NHI to subsidize treatment

TEXT.P: Patients with advanced breast cancer pleaded with the government Tuesday to share the heavy financial burden of cancer treatment at a press conference held by the Foundation of Breast Cancer Prevention and Treatment.

One of the two patients, a 29-year-old surnamed Wang, said that the cost of her treatment was not reimbursed by the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) and that even with a private insurance company covering two-thirds of the cost, she still has to pay around NT$30,000 (US$996.80) per month to stay alive.

Wang was diagnosed with her2-positive metastatic breast cancer, or stage four, in 2008. "I was bereft of hope when I learned that the cancer cells had reached my brain and that trastuzumab was not working," Wang said.
She said she then started taking a different drug, lapatanib, which has stabilized her condition but has burned a hole in her pocket.

Chang King-jen, chairman of the Foundation of Breast Cancer Prevention and Treatment, said that about 80 to 100 of Taiwanese female patients like Wang, who have responded poorly to medicines on the government's subsidized list, have difficulty affording lapatanib, which has proved effective in prolonging patient's lives for at least 14 months.

Lin Wei-chieh, secretary-general of the Taiwan Breast Cancer Friends Association, expressed hope that the government will consider reimbursing the drug, giving breast cancer victims a chance to spend more time with their families and friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suspicious waste found near southern reservoir
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 23:14:51 (Lee Hsien-feng and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Slag from the steel-making industry has been found in a landfill near a major reservoir in southern Taiwan's Tainan County, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Tuesday.

The Tainan County Environmental Protection Bureau has taken samples from the exposed slag at the Yongyang Landfill construction area upstream of the Wushantou Reservoir's catchment region for further examination, amid concern that the water in the reservoir might have been contaminated.
Experts found the slag northwest of the site Oct. 3, said Shen Yi-fu, deputy director of the Department of Water Quality Protection.
Shen added that there are fears heavy metals and dioxin the slag contains might have polluted the reservoir water, Shen added.

Part of the landfill, which is still under construction, lies on a faultline and the underground water in the area flows directly into the reservoir, raising concerns among local residents and environmentalists.
The Tainan Environmental Alliance has monitored the landfill for years, suspecting that toxic waste was being dumped there despite the lack of an operating license.
Groundwater at the site has been confirmed to be polluted, Shen said, although the source of the pollution is unclear.

Shen noted that the establishment of the landfill received approval in 1992 after the Tainan County Environmental Bureau passed an environmental impact assessment. However, the company that runs the landfill has never been allowed to begin operating because of the site's location on a faultline.
The Wushantao Reservoir supplies water for irrigation of the Chia-Nan Plain region, for industry, and for water used by a population of over 1 million in the Tainan area.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC reports youngest case of severe enterovirus infection
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 23:15:21 (By Chen Li-ting and Christie Chen)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Centers for Disease Control (CDC) reported Tuesday a severe enterovirus case in a one-day-old infant, the youngest case of enterovirus ever diagnosed in Taiwan.
Although the infant was in stable condition, she remained under observation in hospital, the CDC said.

The infant, born Sept. 16, was reported to be suffering respiratory dysfunction and a fast heartbeat one day after her birth, and might have contracted the virus in the hospital or through mother-to-child transmission, said Shih Wen-yi, deputy director-general of the CDC.
The infant's family, including her six-year old brother, showed no symptoms of infection, Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civic group urges Nobel Peace committee to award Chinese dissident
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 23:21:24 (By Eva Feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A civic society comprised of professors and academics issued a statement Tuesday calling for this year's Nobel Peace Prize to be awarded to Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo, who is currently serving an 11-year sentence in Beijing.
The Taipei Society issued the statement ahead of the announcement of the winner, due Oct. 8.

China, with its track record of abusing human rights and repressing political dissidents, naturally regards Liu's Charter 08 Initiative and his bid for the peace prize as threats to the legitimacy of its regime, and has warned the Nobel Peace Committee not to award the prize to Liu, according to the statement.
The group said it stands in solidarity with Liu and called on the Nobel Peace Committee to award the prize to Liu, despite China's official warning.

The society said that a Nobel Peace Prize for Liu would mean not only recognition of his long-term dedication to human rights and democratic reforms in China, but would also send a clear message to the Chinese communist regime that the world stands in solidarity with Chinese people who share Liu's vision for a strong, prosperous and democratic China that respects individual freedom and human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor wants truth in probe of irregularities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 23:25:57 (By Johnson Sun and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: With investigators carrying out another search of the residence and office of a high-ranking Taipei city government official Tuesday, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said he respects the judicial process and that he hopes the truth can be revealed as soon as possible.

Agents from the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice, led by prosecutors from the Taipei District Prosecutors Office, conducted searches of 11 sites simultaneously earlier that day, including the city government's New Construction Office (NCO) , as well as the residence and office of its secretary-general, Yang Hsi-an.
As Yang is considered the chief of staff of the city government, a local newspaper reported that the latest search seemed to suggest that the investigation might be getting closer to Hau himself.
Asked by reporters about the search while attending a ceremony in Taipei, Hau said that as far he understood, the searches were just aimed at collecting data.
"We respect the justice system, and hope the prosecutors will demonstrate fair judgment and clarify the truth as quickly as possible," he said.

Investigators had already searched the residences and offices of five senior city government officials Sept. 7 looking for evidence of allegations that they allowed contractors to fleece the city government.

The probe was initiated at Hau's request after several city councilors of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed the city government turned a blind eye to construction companies that inflated the price for improving the city's Xinsheng elevated highway.

Hau, who is facing a serious challenge from a DPP candidate in his bid for a second term in the year-end mayoral election, referred the officials in charge of the project to prosecutors after news of the allegations took a heavy toll on his approval rating.

DOC.HEADLINE: Influenza death toll rises to 22: CDC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/10 23:43:32 (By Chen Li-ting and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Influenza claimed one more life in Taiwan last week, bringing the total number of flu deaths since July to 22, the center for Disease Control (CDC) reported Tuesday.
The figure was approximately the annual average for seasonal flu fatalities for the period.
The patient, who succumbed to an infection by the AH3 strain of the virus, was a 6-year- old girl from southern Taiwan, CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen- yi said.
The six-year-old was hospitalized Sept. 24, one day after developing symptoms including a cough and a high fever. She died Sept. 29, Shih said.
The victim had not been immunized against flu, nor was she taking the antiviral Tamiflu, Shih said.
According to CDC tallies, 15 of the 22 flu-related deaths were AH3 infections and seven were H1N1 infections.
Shih advised the public get vaccinated through the seasonal influenza inoculation program that was launched Oct. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 6, or the 29th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1552: Mateo Ricci, Italian Jesuit missionary in China, is born. He spent the last 30 years of his life in China.
1807: English chemist Sir Humphrey Davy discovers a new metallic element and calls it potassium.
1860: A Franco-British force captures Beijing. China's Ching court is thus compelled to make further concessions in the 1860 Treaty of Beijing.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai forces the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China.
1925: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander in chief of the Canton military government and begins to launch the second eastern expedition.
1927: The International Stock Exchange Center of the New York Stock Exchange is formally opened.
1937: The League of Nations condemns Japanese aggression against China.
1937: The U.S. State Department condemns Japan's invasion of China.
1939: Chinese troops win the first battle of Changsha in Hunan Province against invading Japanese forces.
1946: The Chinese communists turn down Gen. George C. Marshall's cease-fire proposal.
1958: Seawolf, a U.S. nuclear submarine, surfaces off New England's coast after setting a world record by remaining submerged for two months.
1963: President Hubert Maga of Benin and his wife arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The ROC and Uruguay sign a treaty of amity in Taipei.
1973: As Israelis begin to observe Yom Kippur, one of the holiest days in the Jewish calendar, a joint Egyptian-Syrian invasion force begins an attack on Israel on two fronts, triggering the fourth Arab-Israeli war.
1975: The 11th General Assembly of the Asian Parliamentarians Union opens in Taipei with more than 80 delegates and observers from nine countries taking part.
1976: Shiroshichi Kimura, chairman of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for a 16-day visit.
1980: The first World Congress of Chinese Medicine and Pharmacology sponsored by the National Union of the Chinese Medical Doctors' Association opens in Taipei.
1981: Egyptian President Anwar Sadat is assassinated by Islamic extremists while reviewing a military parade in Cairo. He was succeeded by Vice President Hosni Mubarak on Oct. 13.
1986: The ROC's Ministry of Economic Affairs decides to invest NT$1.2 billion in developing anti-pollution technology over the next three years.
1987: The National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center, comprising the National Theater and National Concert Hall, is inaugurated after six years of construction costing NT$7.5 billion.
1991: An Indonesian military plane crashes into a government building in Jakarta, killing 102 people and injuring more than 5,000 others.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin demands the resignation of his opponents in the provinces after putting down rebellious legislators.
1999: Chen Chin-hsing, Taiwan's most notorious criminal who raped and killed the 17-year-old daughter of television celebrity Pai Ping-ping in April 1997, is executed after being sentenced to death for his crimes.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian explains that the "stone" in his earlier comment that "the stone has been removed from the path" of his four-month-old government actually referred to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party itself and not to any specific person.
2001: A local banker urges Taiwan consumers to use "plastic currency" more often amid outrage against increasingly rampant currency counterfeiting.
2001: Some 40 representatives from the overseas chapters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) participates in a three-day joint meeting in Bangkok.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of apprehension, intelligence, insight, and understanding: qualities necessary for the exercise of command."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Wednesday from its previous close, moving up 95.8 points at 8,296.23 on a turnover of NT$4.614 billion (US$146.94 million).
The weighted price index fell 45.67 points, or 0.55 percent, to close at 8,200.43 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$30.908 at 9:30 a.m. Wednesday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.344 from Tuesday's close. ENDITE
