DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Famous fashion designer returns for week-long visit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 11:11:20 (By Chiu Chun-chin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-born fashion designer who rose to global fame in early 2009 after U.S. first lady Michelle Obama wore one of his designs to her husband's inauguration ball returned to Taipei early Wednesday.
"I'm very excited (to return home), " said Jason Wu, speaking to reporters upon his arrival at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, the country's main gateway.

Though Wu returned home mainly to attend his brother's wedding, the designer said he will also meet with President Ma Ying-jeou, whom he said he holds in high esteem, and also with the media to share his experiences as a designer.

After many years of being away from Taiwan, Wu said he misses Taiwanese foods very much, especially quintessential Taiwanese snacks, and he will also visit Taipei's Shilin night market during his stay.
On the wedding gown that he has designed for his sister-in-law-to-be, Wu said it is clean, elegant, fashionable and does not follow any traditional style.
The one-shoulder gown he designed for Michelle Obama for President Barack Obama's inauguration ball has already become a museum piece.
It was donated to the National Museum of American History, where it will join the museum's collection of 24 other gowns worn by U.S. first ladies, including 12 worn on inauguration days.

The 28-year-old designer left Taiwan when he was nine and moved to Vancouver, Canada, where he learned to sew by designing and making doll clothes. He went on to study sculpture in Tokyo and later enrolled at Parsons the New School for Design in New York City.

At age 16, Wu began to make freelance doll clothing designs and later traveled around the world to study fashion design. Four years ago, he launched his own fashion store in New York with earnings from sales of his doll clothes and accessories.
He launched his first full collection in 2006 and won Fashion Group International's Rising Star award in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO Sept. sales down on falling panel prices: analyst
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 12:07:11 (By Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: A fall in flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp.'s sales for September reflected a continued product price decline amid weakening global demand, an analyst said Wednesday.

"The average selling price in the third quarter fell more than 10 percent from the second quarter, worse than the previous estimate of a 5-10 percent fall, " Grand Cathay Securities analyst Jeff Chang said.
AUO Tuesday said it had sales of NT$41.99 billion (US$1.36 billion) in September, down 3.6 percent from August. The September figure, however, was 2.5 percent higher than a year earlier.

Shipments of large-sized flat panels -- panels 10 inches or larger -- fell 4 percent in September from a month earlier to about 9.51 million units, while shipments of small- and medium-sized panels rose 11 percent to 20.14 million units.
"In the global flat panel market, supply exceeded demand in September, leaving inventories at high levels," the analyst said.
Chang said falling demand from China, which accounts for 15-20 percent of AUO's total sales, affected shipments of the company's large-sized products.
Demand is expected to pick up in October, however, as the high-tech sector enters the fourth quarter, considered to be its peak season, Chang said.
"I expect AUO will see an improvement in shipments from October as demand and supply is expected to reach a balance," Chang said.
In the third quarter, AUO shipped 28.67 million large-sized flat panels, down 3.2 percent from a quarter earlier, and 55.59 million small- and medium-sized panels, up 0.3 percent quarter-on-quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to battle for Asian varsity basketball gold

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese university all-star team advanced to the playoff round of the 2010 Asian University Basketball Championship Tuesday, giving it a shot at its first title in the invitational tournament taking place at Kainan University in Taoyuan County.

The host, which has not won gold in the previous two biennial tourneys, won Group A to enter round-robin playoffs along with China's Tianjin Polytechnic University and the top two teams from Group B -- Lebanon's Universite Saint- Esprit De Kaslik and the Mongolia University All-Stars.
Taiwan beat Hong Kong 75-68 to emerge as the Group A winner in a three-way tie with Tianjin Polytechnic University and Hong Kong All-Stars, with two wins and one loss apiece.
Hong Kong, which led the group preliminaries with two wins prior to Tuesday's game, was eliminated because of inferior scoring differentials.

Hong Kong, Myongji University of South Korea and Thailand University All-Stars are slated to play in a series of round-robin classification games to determine the final placing from fifth to seventh place.
The final of the six-day competition will take place Oct. 8.
The invitational was launched in 2006, with Myongji University winning the inaugural title. An Iranian university all-star team took home the championship in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Changes to biotech park project should be applauded

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top academic research institute, is planning to turn a 25.31-hectare site at an abandoned arsenal compound into a biotech development park. Facing environmentalists' demands to save the "last lung of Taipei City, " it has made several changes to its original plan to show its determination to preserve a wetland in the compound while promoting industrial development.

The changes include reducing the area to be covered by the park's facilities from 9.6 hectares to four hectares and pledging to restore a plot of grassland, which was found to have likely been a wetland 100 years ago, to what it once was.

These efforts to compromise with nature, however, have not even gained the slightest hint of approval from the green activists, who rejected them outright. The lesson of the case seems to be that no matter how hard Academia Sinica tries, it has faced a complete veto. Under such circumstances, why even bother compromising on conservation issues?

The future biotech research laboratories and production lines have all been planned to sit on a site that already is home to cement structures from the old arsenal, which begs another question: how could the site that was used to make weapons not be suitable for biotech research laboratories?

Rational environmentalists should articulate their thoughts and opinions on the changes instead of rejecting any possibility that may strike a balance between industrial development and ecological conservation. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 6, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Forex reserves in currency war crossfire

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves continued their upward spiral in September to hit another record high of US$380.51 billion, marking the 23rd consecutive month that they have set a new record.

In September alone, the foreign exchange reserves increased by an amazing US$8.44 billion. The Central Bank of the Republic of China (CBC) attributed the hefty rise to returns on its currency investments and gains by the euro and other major currencies against the U.S. dollar.

Market analysts, however, said the reason for the big gain in foreign exchange reserves was the central bank's buying of the greenback during the month in a bid to prevent the Taiwan dollar from appreciating too drastically against the U.S. currency.

Whether the central bank should continue intervening in the foreign exchange market to keep the local unit's exchange rate at bay has become a new focus of debate, particularly after Japan's central bank surprised investors Tuesday by effectively cutting its main interest rate to zero percent.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
Economic Daily News:

CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan has said on many occasions that the bank cannot be a symbol of Taiwan's economic strength if increases in its foreign exchange reserves mainly stem from the CBC's moves to stabilize the local currency.
He has also repeatedly acknowledged that such a phenomenon will not be a boon to the country's economic health over the long term.

Asked about her views on local electronics makers' remarks that they will be unable to survive if the New Taiwan dollar surges past the level of NT$31 against the greenback, Christina Liu, chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said Tuesday that no country can afford to peg its currency policy to a single industry's well-being.
In the long run, Liu said, Asian countries, including Taiwan, cannot rely solely on exports as the growth engine for their economic development.

While currency appreciation would hobble export competitiveness, it could also help expand domestic demand, Liu said. Asian countries should work to stimulate domestic demand as a new strategy to spur economic growth, she added. (Oct. 6, 2010).
Commercial Times:

The Bank of Japan cut its key interest rate to a range of zero to 0.1 percent Tuesday and said it might set up a 5 trillion yen (US$60 billion) fund to buy government bonds and other assets in an attempt to prop up the country's faltering economy.
Financial market experts said Japan's move could be a prelude to a second round of quantitative easing (QE2) policies around the world since the outbreak of the global financial crisis two years ago.
Foreign wire service reports said the U.S. Fed is likely to follow Japan's lead to announce new QE2 measures in November and that the Bank of England is already warming up for new easing steps.
Some local market analysts said central banks around the world will be in the spotlight this week, particularly on Thursday when the European Central Bank and the Bank of England meet.

But the main focus of the week across all markets will be a run on U.S. economic data that could have a bearing on whether the Fed takes further action to stimulate the U.S. economy. Most important will be Friday's jobs data, as this often sets the market tone for a week or two after release. (Oct. 6, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Intel, Economics Ministry to sign MOU on cloud computing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 14:02:50 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Intel Corp., the world's largest chip maker, will sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Taiwan on cloud computing industry development when its chief executive officer visits Taipei later this month, an official said Wednesday.

Intel President and CEO Paul Otellini is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Oct. 28 and will sign with Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang the third MOU between the company and Taiwan later that day, the official said.

"Otellini and Shih will then host a news conference to reaffirm their commitment on collaboration in developing the cloud computing industry," said the official from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
With Microsoft and IBM expected to set up cloud computing R&D centers in Taiwan, the official said, the MOEA will aggressively try to persuade Intel to set up an R&D center here as well.

The Industrial Technology Research Institute, the Institute for Information Industry, local university data centers and manufacturers in the information industry are also likely to take part in the plan to establish the R&D center, the official said.
He said that as Taiwan is a major supplier of global information technology and equipment, it is understandable that Intel is planning to work with Taiwan to develop cloud computing technologies.
However, Intel is still considering whether to establish a separate R&D center or expand its existing center to include cloud computing, he said.
The MOEA and Intel Taiwan signed two MOUs in 2005 and 2008, respectively, for developing WiMAX wireless technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: Airport criticized for handling of dying traveler

TEXT.P: Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport was criticized Wednesday for sending a traveler who fainted after arriving from China to a regional hospital that lacked key emergency equipment, the latest in a series of complaints about the airport's management.

Family members of Chou Chang Chin-hao, who died on Oct. 3, accused the airport of ignoring their desire to send the 80-year-old woman to Linkou Chang Gung Memorial Hospital after she fainted at the arrival terminal.

They said that when neighbors traveling with the patient asked that she be sent to the biggest medical center in the area, the ambulance driver refused because the airport was bound by a contract with Landseed Hospital, a regional teaching hospital.

The family charged that Landseed Hospital's attitude was poor and complained that it did not have an ECMO (extracorporeal membrane oxygenation) machine that they believe would have given Chou Chang a chance to survive.
Wu Ching-pyng, an attending physician at Landseed Hospital, said the patient did not have any vital signs when she arrived at the facility.
Though he did call other larger hospitals to try to get access to an ECMO machine, Wu said his pleas were rejected because the other hospitals felt the machine would not help the patient.
Chou Chang died of pneumonia-induced septic shock, Wu said.
Lee Wan-lee, vice director of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, said the agency will investigate the family's claims.
The airport, Taiwan's main gateway, has come under fire since late June when a jetway collapsed at the airport's Terminal 2.
In early July, the airport again drew attention for the wrong reason when staffers with the airport's central control room were caught holding a party with alcoholic beverages while on duty.
Repeated bathroom leaks that have left both of the airport's terminals flooded and complaints of defective equipment and unclear signs in terminal lobbies have only compounded the facility's woes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 1.01 percent

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 1.01 percent Wednesday after an overnight surge on Wall Street, with buying focusing on domestic demand-oriented stocks, in particular property firms, whose asset values are expected to be lifted by a rising New Taiwan dollar, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 83.60 points to 8,284.03, after moving between 8,267.61 and 8,301.39, on turnover of NT$148.35 billion (US$4.79 billion).

The market opened up 1.17 percent on a knee jerk reaction to a five-month high on Wall Street overnight after Japan's central bank lowered its key interest rates to stimulate the country's economy, the dealers said.
While old economy stocks got boosted by a rising local currency, the bellwether electronics sector appeared relatively lackluster, which compromised the gains to some extent, they said.
A total of 2,661 stocks closed up and 1,339 were down with 313 remaining unchanged.

The construction sector posted the highest gains, up 3.55 percent. Cement stocks added 2.59 percent, foodstuffs rose 2.41 percent, paper and pulp shares gained 2.19 percent and financial stocks rose 1.1 percent.
The machinery and electronics sector added 0.86 percent, the textile sector rose 0.65 percent and plastics and chemicals closed up 0.34 percent.
"Investors have high hopes that the U.S. Federal Reserve Board will follow its Japanese counterpart and loosen its monetary policy," First Capital Management analyst Edward Chen said.
"Once the Fed cuts interest rates, the world's capital markets will be awash in high liquidity, further lifting share prices," Chen said.

He said this optimism spread to the local bourse, where traditional industrial stocks attracted buyers due to a stronger Taiwan dollar, although the higher local currency stirred up concerns over the global competitiveness of the high tech sector.

Chen said that although the local market posted strong gains Wednesday, "unless the electronics sector stages a significant rebound, it will not be easy for the index to surmount the nearest technical resistance mark of 8,395 points."

In the construction sector, Cathay Real Estate gained 7 percent to close at NT$18.35, Goldsun Development rose 6.91 percent to end at NT$16.25 and Prince Housing added 6.38 percent to NT$25.85 at close of trade.
Among the high tech stocks, personal computer vendor AsusTek closed unchanged at NT$221.00 and IC designer MediaTek fell 0.72 percent to end the day at NT$412.50.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. conducting assessment of Taiwan's defense needs
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/06/10 17:37:37 (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Washington has begun a sweeping assessment of Taiwan's defense needs over the next five to 10 years to determine the types of defensive weapon systems the United States should provide it with, a U.S. business leader said Tuesday.

Rupert Hammond-Chambers, president of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, which groups U.S. companies with interests in Taiwan, made the remarks following the 2010 U.S.-Taiwan Defense Industry Conference that took place in Cambridge, Maryland Oct. 3-5, bringing together more than 140 government officials, scholars, experts and defense company representatives.

The assessment, the most complete and comprehensive of its kind in 10 years, will include an examination of the threat faced by Taiwan from China and Taiwan's capacity to engage in asymmetric warfare, Hammond-Chambers said.

Participants from Taiwan and the U.S. at the annual conference agreed unanimously that although Taiwan and China have concluded an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that is set to further enhance cross- Taiwan Strait economic ties, China's military threat to Taiwan persists and the strait remains "one of the globe's potential flashpoints," according Hammond- Chambers.

Taiwan's deputy defense minister, Andrew Yang, also said in a speech at the conference that the security threat faced by Taiwan from China has not declined because of the ECFA, but in fact has increased.

Hammond-Chambers said that after the assessment is completed in the next one or two years, the U.S. will not "tell" Taiwan what defense systems it is getting, but instead will "begin dialogue with Taiwan" on the contents of the assessment, as well as on Taiwan's ability to afford arms purchases.

On Taiwan's renewed call for the U.S. to sell it F-16C/D fighters, he said that to his knowledge, the U.S. is not thinking so much about whether it should sell Taiwan the advanced jet fighters, but more about the best timing to make the sale.

Hammond-Chambers said it would not surprise him if the administration of U.S. President Barack Obama announces the F-16C/D sale within a year, as well as the upgrading of the F-16A/B fighters currently used by Taiwan's air force.
Yang noted a day earlier that Taiwan has long sought to acquire F-16C/D jet fighters and upgrade its F-16A/Bs to guard the country's airspace and enhance its self-defense capability.
"The purchase of 66 F-16C/Ds and the upgrading of F-16A/Bs are two different cases and they are not alternative cases subject to choice between the two," Yang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Preparing for conundrum

TEXT.P: Japanese National Diet lower house member Gen Nakatani said in Taipei Tuesday that the absence of a NATO-like organization in Northeast Asia has made the existing Japan-U.S. security alliance extremely important and he suggested that Taiwan collaborate with Tokyo and Washington to contain the threat from China.

Nakatani was bold and straightforward to make such a suggestion. His remarks reflect Japan's anxiety over the rapidly growing China threat, as evidenced by the two countries' recent spat over the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands.
In the wake of the rift, both the United States and Japan have come to understand the importance of Taiwan should they ever need to impose a naval blockade against China.
During the Cold War, Taiwan clearly understood that it should side with the U.S. and Japan to fight the China threat. The situation, however, has changed over the past two years.

The latest improvements in cross-Taiwan Strait relations could someday give Taiwan an embarrassing and perilous dilemma of having to choose sides in the race between Washington and Beijing for hegemony in East Asia.

Both the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou and the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party should begin soul-searching on how Taiwan should respond in the event of a military conflict between China and the U.S.-Japan alliance. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 6, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Fund for Children and Families celebrates 60th anniversary
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 18:42:28 (By Chen Ching-ping and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A ceremony redolent with feelings of gratitude was held at the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) in the central city of Taichung Wednesday to celebrate the 60th founding anniversary of the non-profit organization dedicated to helping children in need.

Thank-you cards from children from 22 countries who are being sponsored by Taiwanese donors through a TFCF sponsorship program were displayed at the party, which was attended by Presidential Office Secretary-General Liao Liou-yi, ChildFund Alliance Chairman David Taylor and two sons of the late Glen D. Graber, a priest from the United States who was the TFCF's first chairman.

Liao praised the TFCF for its remarkable achievements in helping underprivileged children and their families, and described its establishment as "one of the brightest pages in the Republic of China's history."
The TFCF began as the China's Children Fund established in 1938 by a group of American Christians in Richmond, Virginia to help thousands of homeless Chinese orphans during the Sino-Japanese War.
In 1950, the organization set up its first family-style orphanage in Taiwan to shelter needy children whose families had been struck by accidents, opening the second chapter of the TFCF's history.

Over the years, the TFCF has opened 23 branches, 28 service offices, three shelters for the physically and mentally challenged, as well as seven shelters for children and teenagers around Taiwan. It has also set up a branch in Mongolia.

It joined ChildFund International -- which was later renamed ChildFund Alliance -- in 2002 to further expand its sponsorship to foreign children in need. So far, it has helped more than 230,000 domestic and foreign children living in poverty with its sponsorship programs, according to the TFCF.
ChildFund Alliance is an alliance of global, developmental child sponsorship organizations that implement lasting and meaningful changes in the lives of impoverished children and families worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: TDRs of China-based textile firm soar on debut
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 18:52:28 (By Wei Shu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan depositary receipts (TDRs) of China-based textile maker China Taisan Technology Group Holdings Ltd. jumped on its debut on Taiwan's stock exchange Wednesday, with demand far outstripping supply.
China Taisan's TDRs rose by the maximum-allowed 7 percent to NT$13.00 (US$0.42) with only 100,000 shares changing hands, while the benchmark weighted index closed up 1.01 percent at 8,284.03.
"Investors embraced high hopes that the fast growing China market will further boost the company's bottom line, " TLG Asset Management analyst Arch Shih said.

Unlike IPO share prices, which can rise or fall freely in the first five days of trading, TDR prices can only rise or fall by a maximum 7 percent from their first day of trading, according to the local bourse's rules.
That kept the volume for China Taisan TDRs low, despite heavy demand. According to the stock exchange, buying orders for the TDRs exceeded 150 million shares.
"The interest is so strong that the TDRs will enjoy further significant gains the rest of the week," Shih said.

China Taisan, which has been listed in Singapore since 2008, is a supplier of performance fabrics used in the production of sportswear and casual wear for international brands such as Reebok, Nike, Adidas, FILA and Lotto, as well as Chinese brands including Li-Ning, Qiaodan and Septwolves.
The company's production facilities are located in Jinjiang in China's Fujian Province. The city is known as China's sportswear hub.
The company said it will expand its production capacity by building new facilities in Jinjiang next year, and the new plant is expected to start operations in the fourth quarter of the year.
In the first half of this year, China Taisan posted net income of 109 million Chinese yuan (NT$505 million), up 192 percent from a year earlier.
The company said net profit for the entire 2010 is expected to reach 225 million Chinese yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the Taiwan dollar Wednesday, dropping NT$0.12 to close at NT$31.132.
Turnover totaled US$1.05 billion during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$31.252 and moved between NT$30.790 and NT$31.260 before the close.

Dealers said the central bank stepped in late in the session to support the U.S. dollar and prevent a quick appreciation of the local currency on fears that a strong Taiwan dollar would hurt exporters' global competitiveness.
The central bank, they said, does not seem to want the U.S. dollar to fall below NT$31.00, prompting its intervention late in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA to help make Taiwan into Asia-Pacific trade center: President
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 18:57:04 (By Li Chia-fei and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou predicted Wednesday that Taiwan will soon become an Asia- Pacific economic and trade hub with the help of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed with China in June.

Speaking during a meeting at the Presidential Office with Looi Kien-Leong, president of the Asian- Oceania Computing Industry Organization (ASOCIO) , Ma said Taiwan's outstanding achievements in the information and communications technology (ICT) industry and the information technology (IT) service business have allowed the country to take the lead in the biotechnology, green energy and solar power industries.

Taiwan's government has also put great efforts into promoting industrial innovation and Taiwan is expected to play an important role in helping countries in the region and improving international exchanges, Ma said.

For his part, Looi expressed gratitude to Taiwan for helping to narrow the digital divide and creating more than 145,000 IT jobs by setting up 56 digital opportunity centers in various countries around the world since 2004.
Looi is in Taiwan to attend the Oct. 5-6 ADOC 2.0 Workshop organized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Council for Economic Planning and Development.
Meanwhile, the ASOCIO will hold an ICT summit in Taipei Dec. 1-3, according to the organization's website.

DOC.HEADLINE: Student teams revitalize small businesses with e-commerce ideas

TEXT.P: A student team that originally quit the competition ended up winning a government-sponsored e-commerce marketing contest by helping a cosmetics company use the Internet to spark to its business, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Tuesday.

Competing in the "E-commerce Creative Marketing Contest" organized by the MOEA, 31 student teams were each assigned to help a small- and medium-sized enterprise that had applied for online marketing assistance to improve sales.

The winning team, composed of students from Shih Hsin University and National Taiwan Normal University (NTNU) , helped improve the online traffic of a cosmetic mask company by 44 percent by using the social networking sites Plurk and Facebook as marketing channels.
But the team almost did not make it to the finish line.
Team leader Huang I-shun said the original group of students from Shih Hsin University quit soon after the contest got underway at the end of May because they could not bear the pressure.

The team was later reorganized, however, with the addition of some students from NTNU, and it eventually won for its contribution to the cosmetic mask company during the two months the contest was held until the end of July.
"As I told the newcomers, it was never going to be easy to go for the championship," Huang said.

It was the first time the MOEA created a category for student groups in the annual contest that was launched in 2000 to encourage online marketing creativity to help smaller businesses expand their reach.
The goal of adding the student category was to enhance the participants' competitiveness before they entered the job market, the MOEA said.
Porsh Tsai, a member of another team that won an excellence award, said his team's project helped a small online vendor recruit 30 retailers to post their products on its sales platform.
"Our project has been extended and funded by another enterprise that is very interested in it," she said.

The MOEA conceived of the idea after finding that most companies in suburban or rural areas rarely promoted their businesses with online tools like electronic direct mail or social networking websites, which are widely used in the student community.

"We hope the prize-winning projects can have a long-term impact on small firms in Taiwan, similar to long-term efforts to promote a sport," said Mei Hua, one of the judges at the contest's awards ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: Korean bank raises first syndicated loan in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Export Import Bank of Korea (Kexim) signed a dollar-denominated syndicated loan worth US$262 million with Taiwan Cooperative Bank (TCB) Wednesday -- the first time a Korean firm has ever raised capital via a syndicated loan in Taiwan.
TCB, the lead bank for the syndicated loan, said that 17 banks took part in the loan, which was over-subscribed by 30 percent against the originally planned amount of US$200 million.
"The number of banks participating in the loan and the over-subscriptions were higher than our expectations, " said a senior official in TCB's syndication department who declined to be named.
The amount of most of the bank's syndicated loans over the past year was less than US$200 million, the official noted.
The official said that many local major banks participated in the syndication because Kexim is a state-run bank with sound credit ratings, and the loan's interest rate is relatively good.

The terms -- interest rates plus up-front fees -- for the syndication were 143 basis points over the 90-day London interbank offered rate (LIBOR) -- which was quoted at 0.2906 percent Wednesday. That resulted in the cost of borrowing at 1.7206 percent, the official said.
Among the participating banks, two are from outside Taiwan: Bank SinoPac's Hong Kong branch and the Singapore branch of Sumitomo Trust and Banking Co.
The official also noted that more international companies are willing to raise capital in Taiwan because of the lower cost of borrowing.
"It would be the first time a lot of foreign companies raised money in Taiwan," she said.
Kexim Deputy President Kim Jin-kyung said that Kexim is not only attracted by the lower cost of funds in Taiwan, but also wants to diversify its capital- raising sources in Asia.
The Seoul-based bank does not collect deposits to fund its loans. Its major source of funds comes from its share capital and international capital markets.
TCB Chairman Liu Teng-cheng said at the loan-signing ceremony that he hopes to attract more foreign customers to seek syndicated loans and explore more business for the bank.
As of the end of September, TCB was ranked second as a book-runner for syndications loans in Taiwan, following Bank of Taiwan, according to statistics provided by the bank.
TCB handled 68 syndicated loan deals worth US$3.482 billion as a book-runner in the first three quarters of this year, translating to a market share of 9.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC's Chang tops most admired entrepreneur list
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 19:44:57 (By Wei Yun-ling and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Morris Chang, chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) , is the most admired entrepreneur in Taiwan, according to a survey conducted by CommonWealth magazine that was released on Wednesday.

The magazine said Chang was a "visionary thinker" who embodied a "charismatic leadership." Respondents agreed that Chang, who heads the world's largest contract chip maker, demonstrated excellent management skills and innovation capacity, allowing TSMC to enjoy an outstanding operation performance.
It was the 14th year Chang topped the survey, which started in 1994, the magazine said.

The survey collected 952 valid questionnaires from local businesspeople after asking them to choose who the entrepreneurs they most admire based on criteria such as management skills, corporate operation performance, business visions, business strategy and innovation capability.
Cher Wang, chairwoman of smartphone maker HTC Corp., was the first female entrepreneur to enter the top 10 in the survey's 16-year history, coming in the eighth position.
Wang was given a thumbs-up for her business strategy thinking and innovation capability, as well as her ability to forge a clear management philosophy.

Little affected by a recent string of suicides by Chinese workers at a factory complex in Shenzhen, Terry Guo, chairman of Hon Hai Group, the world's largest contract electronics firm, took second place, the survey said.
The survey said Landis Hotels and Resorts Group President Stanley Yen, who came in ninth, represented Taiwan's strength in the service sector.

Other entrepreneurs on the list were Acer Group Founder Stan Shih (No. 3), Delta Electronics Chairman Bruce Cheng (No. 4), Yulon Group CEO Kenneth Yen (No. 5), MediaTek Inc. Chairman Tsai Ming-kai (No. 6), Chi Mei Group Founder Hsu Wen- lung (No. 7) and President Group Chairman Kao Ching-yuan (No. 10).

DOC.HEADLINE: Non-English foreign-language online academic platforms available
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 19:54:54 (By Lin Hui-chun & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Several online non-English foreign-language academic platforms have been made available, enabling not only academics but also members of the general public to search for information in a variety of languages, the National Science Council (NSC) said Wednesday.

The NSC said that under a program that began in December 2008, it has provided funds to the National Taiwan University (NTU) library to establish a pool of Japanese-language academic information in the humanities and social sciences.

So far, the NTU platform at http: //jpndbs.lib.ntu.tw/DB/search.jsp has collected 11 Japanese-language databanks, and over 400 free Japanese-language web resources, including Japan Knowledge and an archive of the Daily Yomiuri, Japan's biggest-circulation newspaper.

According to NTU library statistics, the Japanese -language online platform recorded around 7,300 visits between July 29 last year and Sept. 30 this year, with Japan Knowledge, an encyclopedia and dictionary, the most-frequently visited.
Meanwhile, the NSC said, National Chengchi University (NCCU) was given funding to launch German- and French-language academic information platforms in law, literature, linguistics and philosophy.

The NCCU platforms, which now includes 353 German- and 232 French- language databanks, are also free to access and can be found at http;//german2.nccu.edu.tw/ and http: //french2.nccu.edu.tw/, respectively.

Liu Chi-hsuan, the curator of NCCU's library, said the databanks provide a good channel for those learning the languages and cultures of the two countries as they covers official data, media reports and information on daily life.
He said that hits to the German- and French-language platforms have totaled more than 20,000 and 7,500, respectively, since they went online more than a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's office accuses prosecutors of abusing power
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 20:11:58 (By Wang Hung-kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The office of former President Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday accused the Special Investigation Division (SID) under the Supreme Prosecutors Office of abusing judicial power by raiding Chen's office and seizing documents.

SID prosecutors seized 58 cartons of documents from Chen's office on Sept. 15 as part of an investigation into allegations that he took more than 20 boxes of classified files with him when he left the Presidential Office in May 2008.

The prosecutors, along with staff from the Chen Shui-bian Office and officials from the Presidential Office, opened some of the boxes Wednesday at the Taipei Detention Center, where the former president is held. Chen witnessed the opening process in person.

Chen Song-shan, director of the former president's office, said that the suspected embezzling of official documents would fall under a criminal code beyond the jurisdiction of the SID, which is only mandated to conduct investigations into possible corruption by government officials.
"The SID has abused its judicial power as it has no legal right to seize, search or open the documents, " Chen Song-shan said prior to entering the detention center to monitor the opening.

He cited the former president as saying the SID was politically motivated and wanted to divert public attention away from a string of scandals surrounding the Taipei Flora Expo. The Kuomintang-ruled Taipei City government has been accused of procuring materials for the expo at highly inflated prices, which Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin admits has dampened his popularity and clouded his bid for a second term.
Chen Song-shan quoted the former president as saying he is also interested in finding out what documents are in the boxes, as he did not take part in the packing of the cartons.
As for embezzling, he added, the former president said he had no intention or need to commit such crime.
The opening process of the seized documents, which began Wednesday, is expected to take 10 working days, according to SID Director Chen Hung-tah.
The Presidential Office said Sept. 10 that it had instructed Chen's office to return the documents and files after being notified of their existence by Chen's office.
The former president's aides, however, said that they were not in a position to do so and that they would hold onto the documents until Chen was released from detention.
The Presidential Office then filed a lawsuit with the SID alleging Chen' s office had violated the Embezzlement of Public Property Act.
The former president, who has been held since Dec. 30, 2008, has been sentenced to 20 years in prison for embezzling state funds, laundering money, accepting bribes and committing forgery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vietnamese girl thanks Taiwanese public after eye surgery

TEXT.P: A Vietnamese woman expressed her gratitude to the Taiwanese public on Oct. 4 for donations that allowed volunteer doctors to perform an operation in August to help correct an eye disorder called strabismus.
Victims of strabismus have difficulty aligning their eyes with each other.
Born with the condition, Le Bao Ngoc, or "Ruby," said she grew up being bullied, and that her dream was to have the eyes of a normal person.
A 20-year-old university student majoring in tourism, Le told a press conference in Taipei 101 how strabismus had taken away her confidence.
"In Vietnam, people with strabismus and short stature are looked down on. They said I have a double weaknesses, so I am the worst kind," she said.
After the operation in August, Le said she leads a normal life and proudly shows her new glasses to people who teased her before. She said anonymous Taiwanese donors had changed her life.

Le's surgery was part of a fundraising project held by ORBIS Taiwan and Standard Charted Bank in 2009. In less than 10 days, a total of NT$1.3 million (US$31,250) was raised nationwide for 1,200 children in less developed countries with eye problems.

Traveling as far as Tibet to perform volunteer operations on eye patients, said Tsai Jui-fang, superintendent of the Taipei Eye Center, that Taiwan has the capability to save more people like Le who have diseases that are easily treatable and preventable.

Tsai said that there are currently five Taiwanese opthamologists certified by ORBIS who visit developing countries and offer free services to help young people suffering from cataracts, strabismus and blindness.

The programs give the doctors a chance to demonstrate Taiwan's successful medical expertise and train doctors in developing countries, Tsai said, adding that people should never forget to lend a helping hand to those in need.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Face up to issues of antibiotic misuse

TEXT.P: The report of the first case of the NDM-1 "superbug" in Taiwan has inevitably caused a panic in local society. Some scholars have even slammed the Centers for Disease Control for its decision to allow the patient to leave the hospital and go home.

The NDM-1 gene's resistance to antibiotics is worthy of medical community's concern and study. Ordinary people, however, need not panic over the case because chances are low, if not nil, for the "superbug" to trigger an epidemic.
All of the NDM-1 cases reported around the world so far were contracted through surgical operations. To date, the World Health Organization has not listed the NDM-1 as a major communicable disease.

What local public should be concerned are rampant misuse or abuse of antibiotics, which are the culprit of the emergence of drug-resistant bacteria or superbugs, such as the NDM-1. Careless practices in drug supply and use have hastened drug resistance in Taiwan and many other countries around the world. It is truly an issue that should not be ignored any longer. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 6, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: HTC September sales up 11.9 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 20:38:43 (By Tian Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Smartphone maker HTC Corp. posted NT$27.06 billion (US$876.77 million) in sales for September, up 11.9 percent from August and up 129.65 percent from a year earlier, which Taiwan International Securities analyst Michael Chang said Wednesday was lower than an earlier market estimate of NT$30 billion.

HTC said in a statement that September sales were affected by a product transition, with small shipments of new products launched in the month. Shipments of new products will start to expand from October, the statement said.
In the July-September period, HTC recorded sales of NT$75.85 billion, higher than an earlier company estimate of NT$70 billion made in July.
Chiang said the strong showing in third quarter sales reflects HTC's efforts to launch new models and penetrate the huge China market.
"HTC offers a wide range of products catering to consumers in the upper, middle and lower income tiers in China, a strategy that is working well," Chiang said.
In the first nine months of this year, HTC's sales totaled NT$174.76 billion, up 68.79 percent from a year earlier, while net profit reached NT$24.74 billion, up 44.8 percent year-on-year.

DOC.HEADLINE: First major Taiwan education fair to open in Indonesia

TEXT.P: Jakarta, Oct. 6 (CNA ) More than 30 Taiwanese universities will hold a major education fair in Indonesia for the first time from Oct. 7-14, the Taiwan representative office in Jakarta said Wednesday.
The activity has been scheduled since Taiwan's Education Minister Wu Ching-ji met Aceh Province officials during a visit to Southeast Asia in July.

A total of 34 public and private universities, including National Taiwan University, Tsing Hua University and Chung Yuan Christian University, will send officials and delegates to promote their educational and Chinese language programs.

The fair will take place at three universities in Aceh, Jakarta and Yogyakarta starting Oct. 9. The ministry will also host three lectures on life and studying in Taiwan, said Chu To-ming, a secretary at the Bureau of International Cultural and Educational Relations.

A delegation of more than 80, led by the Ministry of Education, also includes representatives from six international academic exchange agencies such as the University Entrance Committee for Overseas Chinese Student.
There are 615 Indonesian students in Taiwan studying for degrees, with more than one-third studying engineering and technology, according to Chu. Nearly 1,000 others are studying Chinese language.

Taiwan's aging society has taken its toll on domestic schools, with many colleges facing insufficient recruitment. Universities have become anxious to attract international students, including Chinese students, to fill the gap caused by the country's low birth rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Late diva Teresa Teng to be remembered at flora expo

TEXT.P: The life and music of Taiwan's legendary songstress Teresa Teng will be featured at the Taipei International Flora Expo, giving the public a chance to pay tribute to the late mega star while enjoying three hectares of floral displays at the Yuanshan Park Area, organizers said Wednesday.

Known for her soothing voice and mastery of an array of genres, Teng is one of the most beloved cultural icons in the global Chinese community. The singer's popularity expands far and wide to Japan, China, Hong Kong and Southeast Asia even after her sudden passing in 1995.

"After a long deliberation, we unanimously agreed that Teng would be the best candidate to be honored at the Celebrity House because she fully embodies the traditional beauty of Chinese cultures, " organizing committee director Chen Hsiung-wen said.

Divided into three halls, the over 100-ping Celebrity House complex -- fashioned after traditional Japanese wooden architecture -- was designed to give visitors a visually and aurally stunning experience, with floral decorations and the flowing melodies of some of Teng's best-known songs.
A ping is a unit of area equivalent to about 3.3 square meters.

Teng's die-hard fans can also cruise down memory lane with over 40 pieces of never-before-displayed personal artifacts, including handwritten notes, stage costumes and even a pair of hot-pink roller skates presented in the halls.
A 38-minute documentary on Teng's career will also be shown at the house, said Frank Teng, the singer's older brother and chairman of the of Teresa Teng Foundation.
The chairman said that Teng had a green thumb and was an avid flower lover who had a particular fondness for lilies and roses.
"She would have been more than happy to take part in this important event that means so much for the country she loved, " he said.

Set to have its grand opening in 31 days on Nov 6, the Taipei City government is aiming to attract at least 8 million spectators to the six-month expo, which will be held in Taiwan for the first time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fubon opens first department store in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 21:01:30 (By Yang Su-min and Hanna Liu)

TEXT.P: Fubon Financial Group, one of the largest financial conglomerates in Taiwan, opened its first department store in the country Wednesday at a ribbon-cutting ceremony in Taipei City's east district.
Fubon last year purchased the building of the former Asiaworld Department Store, located at the intersection of Nanjing East Road and Dunhua North Road, for NT$10 billion (US$321.21 million).

With more than NT$1.1 billion in capital, Fubon spent about NT$200 million on remodeling, with a first-year sales target of NT$1.2 billion, said Lin Chin- feng, president of Fubon Multimedia Technology Co.
Fubon will open another store in Taipei's Xinyi district in 2012, said Daniel M. Tsai, CEO of Fubon Financial Holding, adding that Taichung will be the next step.
Fubon Financial Group is trying to diversify its business, expanding from its core financial business to telecoms, TV and online shopping, and cosmetics and drug stores.

DOC.HEADLINE: Signs show Taiwan's economy recovering: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 21:07:20 (By Wu Chia-Ying and Hanna Liu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that several positive signs show Taiwan's economy has been continuously recovering and the investment environment has improved since the signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.
Taiwan's gross domestic product rose 13.1 percent in the first half from a year earlier as economic expansion keeps its momentum, creating 285,000 jobs, Ma said.
The unemployment rate declined to 5.17 percent in August from 6.13 percent a year earlier, Ma noted.
Foreign investment has surged since signing the ECFA on June 29, Ma said during a speech at the World Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce.
The amount of investment so far is estimated at NT$300 billion (US$9.64 billion), Ma said, urging more businesses to invest Taiwan.

"Although China's market is critical, we're not putting all our eggs in one basket. It's more important for us to aim at global deployment. Taiwan will reach out and open its doors to the world, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chien-Ming Wang to pitch in instructional league

TEXT.P: Taiwanese pitcher Chien-Ming Wang of the Washington Nationals is scheduled to pitch an inning in an instructional league game in Viera, Florida Thursday Taiwan time in what could be one of the most important outings of his U.S. Major League Baseball (MLB) career.

Wang, who has been under rehabilitation for a shoulder injury that occurred before signing with the Nationals for a one-year, US$2 million deal this April, is slated to pitch one inning against the Detroit Tigers minor league team in the Florida Instructional League, a league for minor leaguers to hone their skills.

The 30-year-old veteran was quoted by the Chinese-language Liberty Times newspaper as saying that he will try to work mainly on sinkers -- his most effective weapon -- in the inning. His fastball is now clocked at around 85 miles per hour.

After a rehabilitation of almost 15 months, the right-hander will pitch under the watchful eyes of Mike Rizzo and Jim Riggleman, general manager and manager of the Nationals, which hasn't enjoyed Wang's service since he signed with the team.

Wang's performance Thursday appears to be important for his future with the Nationals, which finished with 69 wins and 93 losses and ranked last in the five-team National League East Division this season. If the team chooses not to offer him a new major league contract, he will become a free agent.

The Nationals had originally hoped Wang, who will be eligible for arbitration this offseason, would make his 2010 debut in mid-June. However, Wang has suffered a shoulder injury that, according to Rizzo, occurred more often to American football players than pitchers, citing New Orleans Saints quarterback Drew Brees, who underwent the same surgery as Wang, as an example.
Wang signed with the New York Yankees in 2001 and was first called up to the mound of a major league game in April 2005.
He was the third player from Taiwan to make it into the MLB after Dodgers outfielder Chen Chin-feng and Rockies pitcher Tsao Chin-hui.

Wang shot to fame in 2006 with his powerful sinkers, scoring 19 wins to tie with Johan Santana of the Minnesota Twins and put him above all other Asian pitchers in the MLB. He secured another 19 wins the following season.
While with the Yankees, Wang suffered a torn right shoulder capsule that was repaired in July 2009, but he has been slow to recover from the injury.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interior minister underlines new mentality of spatial planning

TEXT.P: The Taiwan government needs a new mentality to tackle the vital issue of spatial planning in a challenging time of climate change and financial crisis, Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said Wednesday.

"Taiwan, like any other country in the world, is now at the juncture of having to deal with extreme weather caused by climate change and the task of boosting its economy after the financial crisis, " Jiang said in a speech at Shih Hsin University.

It is a massive challenge from which Taiwan cannot shy away, he told around 200 university students, especially after a series of recent disasters caused huge damages to Taiwanese people, including Typhoon Morakot, the deadliest typhoon in the country's history, widespread flooding caused by torrential rains in southern Taiwan last month.

The cases of controversial farmland expropriation in the central town of Dapu, Miaoli and disputed land takeover in the Central Taiwan Science Park this year have both brought nationwide discontent, the minister said.
"That's why we have to embrace the future with a brand new mentality. It will be difficult, but we have to get it done, " he stressed.

After the disasters and incidents, Taiwan's government has taken a step back to review its national spatial planning policy, which in the past was doomed by administrative failure, systematic errors and negligence, according to Jiang.

To avoid the same mistakes, the ministry has laid out priorities. Jiang said the first priority would be to protect farmers and agriculture with measures such as requiring agricultural agencies to give approval before farmland can be developed for commercial use.
One of the new mentalities also includes more civic participation in the policy- making process, which would ensure all policies are well thought-out before being implemented, he said.

"National spatial planning is important because it always involves people's lives and property, " he said, but lamented that the National Spatial Planning Act has not been screened by the Legislative Yuan.
Government officials will have to make things happen even without the appropriate legislation, he said.
"If we think it's the right thing to do, we will do it and we should do it within our administrative power."
In the future, land development and land expropriation plans will all be reviewed on the basis of fairness, justice and public interest, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to stop leaks before raising water rates
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 22:35:50 (By Yang Shu-min, Lin Huei-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The non-profit Consumers Foundation urged the Water Resources Agency (WRA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs Wednesday to stop wasting water by fixing leaking pipes around Taiwan before raising water rates.

The service water leakage during the transport process had reached 22 percent per year in Taiwan, higher than the global average of 18 percent and much higher than the 7 percent in Japan, the foundation said in a statement.
Its survey found that in 2009, a total of 720 million cubic meters of water leaked from water pipes around Taiwan (except Kaohsiung City) before being transported to consumers.

Using the effective water storage of 200 million cubic meters at the Shihmen Reservoir in Taipei County, northern Taiwan, for comparison, the foundation said the service water lost last year could fill 3.6 Shihmen Reservoirs.

And the leaked water was not just a problem of waste, but could also affect the environment, the foundation said, citing a United Nations warning at the Fifth World Water Forum in March 2009 that predicted nearly half of the world's population would live in areas suffering from a lack of fresh water by 2030.
"The problem of water leakage does not just concern consumers' rights and benefits, but is also a serious environmental protection issue," the foundation said in the statement.

It pointed out that even when the government's project to replace 4,000 kilometers of old water pipes around the country between 2009 and 2012 is complete, it will only decrease the leakage rate to 18.93 percent -- still higher than the global average.
The foundation asked the WRA to find more effective measures to reduce the waste caused by leaking pipes.

Taiwan Water Corp. President Chen Fu-tien confirmed that the leakage of water reached 21.95 percent in 2008. The state-run company began a four-year project that year to replace 4,160 kilometers of old pipes and reduce the leakage.
The budget the company listed for the project, however, was cut by NT$900 million (US$29.14 million) this year to NT$9.9 billion, Chen said.
Because of the budget cut, the length of old pipes to be replaced will be reduced to 4,000 kilometers, lowering the leakage to 19.12 percent by 2011, he said.
Chen said it was up to the government to decide whether or not to raise water rates, which he said were cheap compared with many other countries.

Citing a report by CommonWealth Magazine, a Chinese-language monthly business journal, the Consumers' Foundation said water rates in Taiwan were only higher than in South Korea and China in the region. The annual expenditure on water bills of a family in Taiwan accounted for 0.4 percent of its total household expenditure, far lower than the international level of 4 percent, the foundation added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor council censured for neglecting gas station safety
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 22:39:49 (By Sophia Yeh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) was censured Wednesday by the Control Yuan, Taiwan's top watchdog body, for turning a blind eye to safety problems at gas stations around the country.

The Control Yuan approved the censure proposed by members Cheng Jen-hung, Hung Chao-nan and Yang Mei-ling as a warning to the council for neglecting its duties as a government agency responsible for overseeing workers' rights and welfare.

The censure said that gas station attendants are chronically exposed to cancer- causing agents from the gasoline, especially benzene, but the council has not devised regulations on gas station safety, nor has it come up with a stipulation requiring gas station operators to provide attendants with sufficient health checks.
It also said that the council has not authorized testing on the operational environment at gas stations for the past 11 years.

Cheng said that since gas station attendants sustain greater cancer risks from their workplace than workers in other fields, they are entitled to receive checkups at intervals shorter than the five years stipulated in CLA regulations.

Existing laws are inadequate to protect gas station attendants, Cheng said, urging state-owned petroleum company CPC Corp., Taiwan to make greater efforts to protect the health of workers at the pump.

CPC, the largest fuel processor and distributor in the country, operates 649 gas stations nationwide, with 2,023 workers on its regular payrolls and 8,658 part- time attendants, Cheng said. The number of other privately run gas stations totals 2,073, with about 12,000 part-time attendants, many of them students.
The Control Yuan members also suggested that the Ministry of Economic Affairs come up with a regulation requiring gas stations to do more to prevent the corrosion of underground oil tanks.
They also said the Ministry of the Interior should study the feasibility of introducing technology to build earthquake-resistant gas stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen plans Double Ten group wedding

TEXT.P: A group wedding to mark the 99th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China will be held on the outlying island of Kinmen on Double Ten National Day, the Kinmen County government announced Wednesday.

Eighteen couples will tie the knot on Oct. 10, with three of the couples featuring Chinese brides from southern China's Hainan Island and Chongqing City marrying Taiwanese residents. The ceremony will include traditional rites, such as parade floats and the couples sitting in palanquins and on horses, the county government said.

Kinmen County Magistrate Li Wo-shi will preside over the ceremony at the Kinmen Troop Command of the Qing Dynasty, a historic monument that was built more than three centuries ago, the Kinmen County government said. (By Maia Huang)

DOC.HEADLINE: New Taiwan envoy to Vietnam assumes post
DOC.DATELINE: Vietnam, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 23:07:40 (By Fang Pei-ching and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Newly appointed Republic of China (ROC) representative to Vietnam Huang Chih- peng was greeted by more than 30 office staffers and Taiwanese businesspeople on arrival at the airport in Hanoi to assume his post Wednesday.
Huang, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office, expressed his excitement by saying that it was his dream to live in Hanoi.
"I have read a lot of information about the country, and I am very much looking forward to working and learning from everyone, " he said at the airport in front of his new colleagues.
Vietnam is one of the emerging markets that the government is focusing on to promote economic exchanges by providing assistance to Taiwanese companies there, Huang said.
Huang had served as director general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade since 2002 and helped negotiate the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that Taiwan signed with China in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pioneer AIDS researcher addresses Academia Sinica on AIDS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/10 23:13:07 (By Lin Szu-yu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Nobel laureate and pioneer AIDS researcher Francoise Barre-Sinoussi of France shared her experiences studying AIDS and offered insight into the prevention of the deadly disease at Academia Sinica in Taipei Wednesday.

Barre-Sinoussi, co-discoverer of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) as the cause of AIDS, delivered a speech titled "What can we learn from the diverse spectrum of HIV/SIV infections? " at Taiwan's top research institute.
The virologist discussed two prominent models of interest with respect to HIV resistance -- human HIV controllers and African Green Monkeys.
She also talked about the prospects of AIDS vaccines and possible research directions in the future.

Barre-Sinoussi is currently director of the Regulations of Retroviral Infections Unit at the Pasteur Institute in Paris where her team focuses on regulation of HIV/SIV (Simian Immunodeficiency Virus) infection.

Noting that the spread of the AIDS virus knows no borders, she said that if the world fails to help AIDS-plagued, resource-scarce countries today, the virus could spread quickly to other parts of the planet, and mutation of the virus could trigger uncontrollable disasters.
She said education and information sharing are good ways to keep AIDS at bay. Education allows people to know AIDS better, influencing them to change their behavior, she said.
Barre-Sinoussi called for those infected with AIDS not to be too shy to seek medical attention in time.
In 2008, she won the Nobel prize in Medicine or Physiology, together with Luc Montagnier, for their identification of HIV as the cause of AIDS.

The pair paved the way for rapid cloning of the HIV-1 genome, leading to an understanding of how the virus interacts with its host and development of methods to diagnose infected patients and screen blood products.
In addition to her scientific study, she has been deeply involved in promoting the integration of research and action in countries with limited resources.

At the invitation of the Sayling Wen Cultural and Educational Foundation as well as the French Institute in Taipei, Barre-Sinoussi also gave a speech at National Tsing Hua University in Hsinchu Monday and another at National Yang Ming University in Taipei Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 7, or the 30th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1900: Heinrich Himmler, head of the Gestapo, and from 1929, Adolf Hitler's second-in-command, is born.
1913: Henry Ford, the leading manufacturer of U.S. automobiles in early 1900's, creates the world's first assembly line to build the model T cars.
1919: KLM, the national airline of the Netherlands and the world's first airline, is established, and flights are scheduled to begin in 1920.
1949: East Germany, or the German Democratic Republic, is proclaimed, with Wilhelm Pieck as president and Otto Grotewohl as prime minister.
1950: Communist Chinese troops enter Tibet.
1958: Communist Chinese begin to launch a mass movement in Tientsin to make iron and steel, in which about 100 million people would eventually participate. The movement, which proved to be a waste of both human and material resources, resulted in the loss of 100 billion yuan in industrial production.
1959: Mario Lanza, U.S. tenor and film actor, dies at the age of 38. His films included "The Great Caruso."
1961: Two Communist Chinese pilots, Shao Hsi-yen and Kao Yu-tsung, arrive in Taipei from Seoul.
1974: A 90-member Japanese calligraphic mission led by Akira Koyama arrive in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: U.S. President Gerald Ford, already under fire for pardoning the disgraced Richard Nixon, tells the public on prime-time television that "there is no Soviet domination of eastern Europe and there never will be under a Ford administration."
1982: Jimmy Wei, the national policy advisor to President Chiang Ching-kuo and former president of the Central News Agency, dies of a heart attack at the age of 77.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo tells Katherine Graham, head of the board of the Washington Post and Newsweek, in an interview that the Republic of China government will soon propose lifting martial law to actively promote democracy, but adds that new political parties should abide by the ROC Constitution and anti-Communist policy. He also emphasizes the ROC will never negotiate with the Communist Chinese.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of the society.
1998: Thousands of Russians take to the streets to protest against unpaid wages and to call on President Boris Yeltsin to resign.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan confirms that the Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau will formally phase out its controversial "political surveillance" work soon.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of magnanimity, generosity, benignity, and gentleness: qualities necessary for the exercise of patience."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Thursday from its previous close, moving up 20.88 points at 8,304.91 on a turnover of NT$3.675 billion (US$118.55 million).
The weighted price index rose 83.6 points, or 1.01 percent, to close at 8,304.91 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$30.789 at 9:30 a.m. Thursday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.343 from Wednesday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Chien-Ming Wang pitches shutout inning in instructional league
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 10:27:19 (By Chris Wang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese pitcher Chien-Ming Wang of the Washington Nationals threw a shutout inning in an instructional league game in Viera, Florida Thursday (Taiwan time) in his first return to the mound after missing the entire 2010 season while rehabbing from shoulder surgery.
According to a report posted on the masnsports.com website, Wang had a good outing in the game against the Detroit Tigers minor league team in the Florida Instructional League.
Wang faced four batters, walking one and retiring the other three, in the inning. He also hit 85-87 miles per hour with his fastball, which sports experts said was not bad, but not great.
The right-handed pitcher has been rehabbing a shoulder injury that occurred before signing with the Nationals for a one-year, US$2 million deal in April.
The Florida instructional league appearance was seen as one of the most important outings of the 30-year-old veteran's U.S. Major League Baseball (MLB) career.

The masnsports website report quoted Wang's agent, Alan Nero, as saying that both the Nationals and Wang are open to a contract for 2011 before the Nationals would have to decide whether to offer Wang arbitration, but are waiting to see how he progresses through the fall.
Wang signed with the New York Yankees in 2001 and was first called up to the mound of a major league game in April 2005.
He was the third player from Taiwan to make it into the MLB after Dodgers outfielder Chen Chin-feng and Rockies pitcher Tsao Chin-hui.

Wang shot to fame in 2006 with his powerful sinkers, scoring 19 wins to tie with Johan Santana of the Minnesota Twins and put him above all other Asian pitchers in the MLB. He secured another 19 wins the following season.
While with the Yankees, Wang suffered a torn right shoulder capsule that was repaired in July 2009, but he has been slow to recover from the injury.
