DOC.HEADLINE: IMF forecasts 9.3% economic growth for Taiwan in 2010

TEXT.P: Taiwan's real gross domestic product (GDP) growth is expected to reach 9.3 percent in 2010 and 4.4 percent in 2011, according to a forecast released by the Washington-headquartered International Monetary Fund (IMF) on Wednesday.

Among other major economies in Asia, China is projected to post 10.5 percent growth in 2010 and 9.6 percent in 2011; Hong Kong 6 percent in 2010 and 4.7 percent in 2011; and Japan 2.8 percent in 2010 and 1.5 percent in 2011, the IMF's World Economic Outlook showed.

The growth in South Korea is predicted to reach 6.1 percent in 2010 and 4.5 percent in 2011; Singapore 15 percent in 2010 and 4.5 percent in 2011; and India 9.7 percent in 2010 and 8.4 percent in 2011.
The report stated that Asia is continuing to lead the global recovery.

It added, however, that activity is projected to moderate from the second half of 2010 and in 2011 in line with the winding down of stimulus policies and tightening measures in economies facing demand pressures, as well as downdrafts from policy adjustments in advanced economies.
Overall, Asia is projected to grow by 7.9 percent in 2010 and 6.7 percent in 2011, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MediaTek Q3 sales down 6.13 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 11:46:52 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Integrated circuit designer MediaTek Inc. said Thursday it posted NT$28.13 billion (US$913 million) in sales for the third quarter of this year, down 6.13 percent from a quarter earlier.

While the third quarter figure was higher than the company's estimate of NT$25.4 billion to NT$27.5 billion, analysts said the 6.13 percent decline was worse than the market expectation of an up to 5 percent fall.
In September, MediaTek recorded NT$9.86 billion in sales, down 1.82 percent from August, also lower than a market estimate of no less than NT$10 billion, they said.
"MediaTek was faced with fierce price competition in China, where rivals were trying hard to grab business by cutting prices, " Hua Nan Securities analyst Henry Miao said.

Cell phone chips are MediaTek's major source of revenue and about 75 percent of its cell phone chip sales come from China, where makers of unbranded, or "bandit" cell phones, are the company's biggest customers.
Miao said MediaTek had previously planned to upgrade its cell phone chips to 3G from the current 2.5G-2.75G to alleviate the impact from the price war.
"But it seems that the upgrade is not going smoothly. To my knowledge, MediaTek is making some adjustments in the upgrade and the benefits are not expected to be seen until next year," Miao said.
Miao said a successful technology upgrade is likely to maintain the company's gross margin.

In the second quarter, MediaTek's gross margin fell 1.7 percentage points from the first quarter to 55 percent. The company has forecast that its gross margin will fall to between 51.5 percent and 53.5 percent in the third quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Absurd stance toward Tiaoyutais

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office issued a statement Oct. 5 saying that Taiwan had not collaborated with China in the latest protest against Japan over the Tiaoyutai issue. Throughout the statement, however, the Presidential Office tried to link Taiwan to China, which runs seriously counter to the perception of the majority of Taiwanese.

The statement said the Tiaoyutai Islands were discovered and named by the Chinese during the Ming Dynasty and that the island group was covered by China's coastal defense during the Ming and Ching dynasties. The fact is that according to international law, discovering a place is not equal to holding sovereignty over it. Moreover, what does "discovery by the Chinese" have to do with Taiwan?

The Presidential Office further said that the Tiaoyutais were merged into Japanese territory following the Ching Dynasty's defeat in the Sino-Japanese War of 1894. It argued that the islands should have been handed over to the Republic of China in 1945 when Taiwan was returned to the ROC following "Japan's surrender to the ROC" at the end of World War II. The fact is Japan was surrendering to the Allied Powers, not the ROC. Although the Treaty of San Francisco of 1951 renounced Japan's rights to Taiwan, it did not say that Taiwan was to be returned to the ROC.

Since the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou claimed the Tiaoyutais belong to the ROC, the ROC government should expel any non-Taiwanese fishing boats that enter the Tiaoyutai territorial waters. Why does the Presidential Office say there is not an issue of Taiwan and China protesting against each other over the Tiaoyutais, even when the latest diplomatic standoff between Japan and China was caused by the intrusion of a Chinese fishing boat into the region?

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- CBC battles 'vulture' investors
DOC.DATELINE: The Central Bank of the Republic of China (CBC) 10/07/10 13:53:33 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: has tightened monitoring of capital inflow to prevent international "vulture" investors from speculating on the Taiwan dollar's exchange rates amid a looming global currency war.

Banking sources said daily inbound capital remittances jumped past US$600 million Wednesday, prompting the central bank to launch a special inspection into the operations of a major foreign bank's local branch.

Since the beginning of this year, the central bank has adopted a series of measures to stabilize the Taiwan dollar's value, including prohibiting banks from selling huge amounts of U.S. dollars late in the trading session.

In recent days, the sources said, the central bank has usually allowed the local currency to appreciate sizably in the morning session, but intervened late in the session by buying U.S. dollars to prevent speculators from scoring windfalls in same-day trading.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the currency issue:
United Daily News:
Japan's announcement of new quantitative easing measures Tuesday invoked a global currency war, drawing an influx of hot money into Asia and driving major Asian currencies to new highs.
With U.S. authorities deliberately allowing the greenback to plunge, the ongoing currency war also spread to Europe Wednesday, with the euro gaining 0.6 percent to approach the barrier of US$1.39.

In the face of the current financial market turbulence, Premier Wu Den-yih said during a meeting with local industry executives Wednesday that he is confident the CBC will be able to cope well under the leadership of Governor Perng Fai- nan, who has been rated as one of the world's most competent bankers. (Oct. 7, 2010).
Economic Daily News:
The central bank and the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) have been collaborated closely to crack down on currency speculation in recent days amid the currency warfare.
In addition to monitor the flow of inbound capital remittances, the CBC has also advised local companies not to engage in reckless forward currency trading to avoid unnecessary losses.
The FSC has been inspecting commercial banks' trading in derivatives to prevent any irregularities, financial sources said. (Oct. 7, 2010).
Commercial Times:
International Monetary Fund (IMF) Chairman Dominique Strauss-Kahn warned in an interview against countries using currencies as "policy weapons."

In comments to the Financial Times published on Tuesday, Strauss-Kahn said: "Translated into action, such an idea would represent a very serious risk to the global recovery... Any such approach would have a negative and very damaging longer-run impact."
He made the comments to the paper on Monday ahead of annual IMF and World Bank meetings in Washington this weekend.

The comments also came a day before the Bank of Japan's cut to its key interest rates and its outline of a fund to buy assets to boost liquidity, the announcement of which briefly weakened the yen Tuesday.

Meanwhile, Nobel Prize-winning U.S. economist Joseph Stiglitz also warned Tuesday that the U.S. Fed's and the European Central Bank's constant raises of liquidity have begun destabilizing the global financial market, including causing chaos in foreign exchange markets and enhancing the risk of asset bubbles. (Oct. 7, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: End exploitation of foreign workers

TEXT.P: The death of six illegal foreign workers at a construction site on the No. 6 Freeway last week highlighted the problem of runaway foreign workers, which number more than 35,000.
In fact, the unreasonable labor brokerage fee system is responsible for the situation, in which many legal foreign workers opt to abscond.

According to the Taiwan International Workers' Association, foreign workers intending to work in Taiwan are required to pay as much as NT$80,000 (US$2,603)-NT$250,000 in brokerage fees. With other miscellaneous fees included, these payments represent at least 18 months-worth of wages.

It is little wonder, therefore, that so many foreign workers run away near the expiration date of their employment contracts so that they can continue to stay in Taiwan and work illegally to at least try to cover their costs.
If the Council of Labor Affairs is to deal with the problem, it should target these unscrupulous brokers who are exploiting the foreign workers. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 7, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: New department store attracts hundreds of early birds

TEXT.P: Uni-President Hankyu Department Store opened its second Taiwan branch in Taipei's bustling Xinyi shopping district Thursday morning, attracting thousands of shoppers who waited in line hours ahead of the opening.
Scores of workers were busy guiding the thronging crowds, most of whom were there for the grand opening of the country's first UNIQLO shop, a Japanese casual wear retailer.
Bill Chou and Philip Wu, college students who arrived at around midnight for a place at the head of the entrance line, said it was their first time to do such a thing.
"But it's worth it. The jeans we want to buy will save us NT$1,000 (US$32.50) , so it's like we save NT$100 per hour, " they said, adding that their budget for the day was about NT$8,000.
Customers streamed in and out of the seven-story building after the 10:00 a.m. opening, but not everyone was in the mood to take part in the frenzy.
"There are too many people. It's as if everything was free, " a passerby named Alice Chen complained. "There must be some great discounts, but I definitely don't want to be in the middle of it."
The new department store is a joint venture between Taiwan's Uni-President Group, which runs the local 7-Eleven store chain, and Japan's Hankyu Department Store.

A lot of effort was put into promoting the opening, especially to pink-collar workers and teens. The store planned to hold a fashion show Thursday evening with some of the country's best-known models, including Janel Tsai and Yuli Lin.

"I want to make it the best in the commercial district, " said Wang Po-ming, Uni-President Hankyu Taipei's general manager, pointing out that there are eight other department stores or malls in the area.
Wang told reporters the newly opened store, co-constructed with an MRT transfer station, was expected to attract 150,000 customers and generate NT$100 million in sales on its opening day.
Uni-President Hankyu Department Store opened its first Taiwan store in the southern port city of Kaohsiung in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign ministry issues low-level travel alert for Sweden

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a low-level travel alert for Sweden over concerns of possible terrorist attacks, a ministry official said Thursday.

The gray alert -- the lowest on the ministry's four-color system -- came after the Swedish Security Service changed its five-scale terrorist attack threat from the second grade of "low threat" to the third level of "elevated threat, " Thomas Chen, director-general of the Bureau of Consular Affairs under the ministry, said in a press briefing.
A gray level alert advises tourists to "travel with caution."

Threat of a terrorist attack in Sweden is still lower than that in some European countries, and an "elevated threat" doesn't mean a terrorist attack is imminent, Chen said, adding that "however, Sweden has never been considered the target of a terrorist attack before."
In related news, the ministry said the travel alert for Thailand remained at the second-lowest yellow level, which advises tourists to travel with caution and reconsider their itinerary.

According to the ministry, four Thai provinces -- Bangkok, Nonthaburi, Samut Prakan and Prathum Thani -- were still in a state of emergency and the possibility of an extremist attack in the Southeast Asian country remains high.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close little changed

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed little changed Thursday on profit-taking after the market briefly hit the nearest technical resistance level of around 8,300 points, dealers said.
The weighted index closed down 0.11 points at 8,283.92, after moving between 8,270.31 and 8,310.80, on turnover of NT$129.17 billion (US$4.19 billion).

The market opened up 0.25 percent on follow-through buying, but investors became increasingly cautious, in particular in late trading, to pocket profits ahead of a U.S. jobless report due Friday, the dealers said.
A total of 2,087 stocks closed down and 1,746 were up, with 349 remaining unchanged.

The paper and pulp sector suffered the heaviest selling, down 2.03 percent. Construction shares fell 1.21 percent, machinery and electronics stocks lost 0.08 percent and textile shares closed down 0.02 percent.
The cement sector rose 1.76 percent, foodstuffs gained 1.1 percent, the financial sector added 0.57 percent and plastics and chemicals closed up 0.11 percent.
"Without turnover expanding to NT$14 billion or even NT$15 billion, the market is unlikely to overcome the technical hurdles ahead of 8,300 points," Concord Securities analyst Allen Lin said.
Lin said the pullback from the early gains in the late trading was evidence of the cautious mood.

"Range trade is expected to keep dominating market movements on a lack of fresh incentives, " Lin said. "Even if rotational buying will boost the index, profit- taking will emerge to compromise the gains," he added.

Among the construction stocks that had been lifted by a rising New Taiwan dollar but saw their recent gains eroded during the session, Prince Housing shed 3.48 percent to NT$24.95 and Kuo Yang Construction fell 3.13 percent to NT$23.20.
The financial sector benefited from bargain-hunting, with Taiwan Business Bank up 4.90 percent at NT$10.70 and Mega Financial up 2.62 percent at NT$19.60.

DOC.HEADLINE: Intel declines to confirm report of CEO's visit to Taiwan

TEXT.P: Intel Corp., the world's largest chip maker, declined on Thursday to comment on reports that its chief executive officer will visit Taiwan later this month.
Intel's Taiwan branch told the Central News Agency that it has not confirmed a date or details regarding a visit from Intel President and CEO Paul Otellini.
"Taiwan is an important market and our executives visit regularly to meet customers and government, " Rachel Liu, a spokeswoman for Intel Taiwan, said in an e-mail message.
"But we have nothing specific to say in response to this rumor, " she said.
Local media have attached great importance to whether Otellini will visit Taiwan after Intel dismissed its WiMAX Program Office (WPO) in late June.
The move was interpreted as Intel withdrawing support for the development of WiMAX broadband wireless technology in Taiwan.
Intel, however, has repeatedly said that the closure of the office was "simply a small internal restructuring plan" and does not signal any change in its commitment to WiMAX.

Liu's remarks came one day after Taiwan's Chinese-language Economic Daily News reported that Otellini would visit Taiwan at the end of this month and meet local leaders in the information and communications technology industry.

Later Wednesday, an official at Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs told CNA that Otellini was due to arrive in Taipei Oct. 28 and would sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the ministry on the development of the cloud computing industry.
It would mark the third MOU between the company and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Service sector to offer 11,000 jobs: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 16:45:45 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The service sector, including retailers, real estate agents and restaurant chains, will offer 11,000 jobs for future expansion as the local economy has staged a strong rebound, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.

According to the MOEA, a job fair on Oct. 16 will include 100 employers, including property agent Sinyi Realty, fast food chains McDonald's, KFC and Mos Burger, retailer Carrefour, convenience store FamilyMart, 85 Degrees C Cafe, Friday's restaurant, and President Group, which operates a wide range of food and retailing businesses.
Among the job fair participants, Sinyi Realty is expected to recruit more than 3,000 newcomers, while McDonald's will hire over 800 employees, the ministry said.
Apart from job openings for waitstaff, these employers will also hire management professionals and offer competitive compensation, it said.
The ministry will hold a news conference Friday to announce details about the job fair.

The government has raised its forecast for Taiwan's 2010 gross domestic product (GDP) growth to 8.24 percent from the previous estimate of 6.14 percent, after a 13.71 percent GDP increase for the first quarter and a 12.53 percent rise for the second quarter.

The island suffered its worst ever economic contraction of 9.06 percent in the first quarter of 2009 amid a global financial meltdown before emerging from a recession in the fourth quarter of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: China-based healthcare provider seeks TDR listing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 17:18:55 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Golden Meditech Holdings Ltd., a Chinese integrated healthcare service provider, has filed an application with the Taiwan Stock Exchange to list Taiwan depositary receipts (TDRs) on its main board, officials said Thursday.

According to the company's prospectus, Golden Meditech is planning to issue up to 90 million TDRs, each one of which will represent two common shares of the company, to raise up to NT$1.08 billion (US$351 million).

For the TDR listing, the company will issue up to 120 million new shares and sell up to 60 million existing shares to the public, which are expected to account for 9.86 percent of its enlarged share capital.

Golden Meditech said the proceeds from the TDR listing will be used to repay bank loans of about NT$640 million, while the company will set aside NT$80 million to set up a representative office in Taiwan.
The company said that if everything goes smoothly, the TDRs will be listed in six weeks at the earliest.

Golden Meditech, which has been listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange since 2001, produces and sells medical devices and herbal medicine and provides medical care services, including the processing, separation and storage of blood stem cells.
Golden Meditech Chairman Kam Yuen said that "we are confident that the TDR issue will increase public awareness of the group and promote the group's corporate image in Taiwan."
"This will enhance our competitiveness and presence in the China market and benefit our future business development initiatives in Taiwan," he said.
In the April 2009-March 2010 period, the company posted NT$460.54 million in net profit, up 104 percent from a year earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-death penalty group organizes film festival to seek change

TEXT.P: An anti-death penalty group announced an annual film festival Thursday and called for the abolition of capital punishment, three days before the Oct. 10 World Day Against the Death Penalty.

Taiwan Alliance to End the Death Penalty (TAEDP) Executive Director Lin Hsin-yi announced that the 2010 Murder by Numbers Film Festival will screen nine death penalty-related films from Germany, Japan, Iran, Hong Kong, France, India, Taiwan and the United States in Taipei, Hsinchu and on university campuses around the country from Oct. 8-24.

"We would like to call for an immediate moratorium on executions and implementation of reasonable punishment and victim protection, as well as call attention to the importance of judicial justice and scientific analysis, " she said.

The film festival will serve as a platform for dialogue between those who support and those who oppose the death penalty, Lin said, adding that the dialogue mechanism is especially needed after heated debate about the issue earlier this year.

Taiwan's execution of four prisoners April 30, which ended a five-year moratorium on the death penalty, drew criticism from various countries and international organizations and ignited nationwide discussion on the Internet and in the media, she said.

The festival is also intended to focus on the issue of state violence by reviewing the triangular relations between the government, its people and the death penalty, Yen Chueh-an, a professor at National Taiwan University, said in a press conference organized by the TAEDP and other civic groups.
Kao Yung-cheng, head of the Judicial Reform Foundation, said he was happy to see that discussion of the issue has become more intense.

According to Kao, "executions have been halted for now, but I'm not sure what will happen after the European Union approves visa-free privileges in the Schengen Area for Taiwanese travelers," he said.

The EU expressed disappointment with Taiwan after the April 30 executions. It has said that the visa-free treatment and the death penalty are separate issues, but there have been assumptions in Taiwan that the prolonged review process of the privileges is related to the executions.

World Day Against the Death Penalty was launched in 2003 by the World Coalition Against the Death Penalty. The program this year focuses on the United States, one of the few developed countries that has refused to abolish capital punishment.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to hold seminar on British offshore wind power technology
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 17:53:33 (By Lin Hui-chun and Hanna Liu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday it will hold a seminar Oct. 18 on British developments in offshore wind turbine technology and wave and tidal marine energy.
British experts in wind and marine energy fields will speak at the seminar to share their knowledge and experience with local counterparts, the ministry said in a press statement.
According to the ministry, Britain is a world leader in wind turbine technology and the marine energy industry.
With a wealth of wind power resources and coastlines for offshore wind power, Taiwan has potential to develop a strong wind energy sector, the ministry's Bureau of Energy said.

As of the end of September, Taiwan had an accumulated wind power generation capacity of 490,300 kilowatts, which can turn out an estimated 1.226 billion KWh annually to meet the demand of 306,000 households, the bureau said.
Statistics indicate that wind power generation has helped cut 763,600 tons of carbon emissions, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the Taiwan dollar Thursday, dropping NT$0.09 to close at NT$31.042.
Turnover totaled US$947 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.132 and moved to a low of NT$30.675 before rebounding.
Dealers said the central bank stepped in again to boost the U.S. dollar in late trade to prevent the local currency from appreciating too quickly.

However, they said the central bank's efforts could only slow down the pace of the Taiwan dollar's appreciation, but could not reverse the upswing trend, as other Asian currencies are also rising against the greenback.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promises more low interest loans for small businesses
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 18:31:25 (By C.Y. Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih promised Thursday that the government will continue granting low interest loans to Taiwan's small and medium-sized businesses as part of efforts to improve the investment climate.

Speaking at the closing ceremony of the International Small Business Congress, Wu said that in June the government achieved its goal of lending an additional NT$150 billion (US$4.77 billion) to Taiwan's small enterprises. The figure exceeded NT$200 billion by the end of August, he added.
The loans were part of a Financial Supervisory Commission policy put in place at the beginning of this year that required local banks to increase lending to small businesses.
Wu described small and medium-sized businesses as the growth engine of the economy, adding that they account for 98 percent of the country's enterprises and help create 77 percent of the jobs.

"It is one of the government's unavoidable responsibilities to provide low interest loans to small and medium-sized companies to help them increase their competitiveness in the wake of signing the tariff-slashing economic cooperation framework agreement with China," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA aims to make e-commerce trillion-dollar business by 2015
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 18:36:27 (By Lee Ming-Chung and Hanna Liu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday that it will invest up to NT$450 million (US$14.62 million) in e-commerce by 2015 in a bid to develop the industry into a NT$1 trillion business.

The proposed "Mandarin Chinese e-commerce development plan" will help create eight e-commerce businesses, each of which will be able to post more than NT$10 billion in annual sales, providing a total of 82,000 jobs, the ministry said.

After a briefing on the e-commerce development plan at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Premier Wu Den-yih said he believed the program would help many local small and medium-sized enterprises to expand their business in the Mandarin e-commerce market, eventually making Taiwan a hub for global Chinese-language e-commerce.
Citing official statistics, Wu said Taiwan's e-commerce has been growing at an annual rate of 20 percent in recent years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Senior judge impeached for whoring, gambling
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 18:38:02 (By Sophia Yeh and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan impeached Taiwan High Court Judge Yang Ping-chen Thursday for whoring and gambling while on duty.
Thirteen members of the country's highest watchdog body unanimously approved a proposal submitted by yuan members Huang Huang-hsiung and Shen Mei-chen to impeach Yang.
After being impeached, Yang will face punishment by the Public Functionary Disciplinary Commission.
According to the impeachment, Yang has been using prostitutes for many years, even during office hours, and he also has a habit of gambling frequently, sometimes even with defendants.

"Yang's behavior has seriously marred the reputation of the judiciary and has undermined the public's trust in the country's judicial system," it said. Yang was suspended by the Judicial Yuan on charges of corruption in August.
According to a statement from the operator of a high-priced call-girl ring that was raided by law enforcement officials a day earlier in Taipei, the judge was a regular patron of the hookers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan working toward reclaiming title as top 'dragon': CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 18:42:44 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to work toward the goal of reclaiming the top position among Asia's "four little dragons, " a goal which according to the latest forecast by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) could be attained in 2012, an economic official said Thursday.

According to Council for Economic Planning and Development's Chairwoman Christina Liu, the economic benefits to be brought about by the tariff-slashing trade agreement Taiwan signed with China in June and the foreign investment attracted to Taiwan by the trade pact will together give Taiwan's economy a strong boost.
However, Taiwan needs to keep working hard to turn the forecast into reality, Liu said.

According to the IMF's World Economic Outlook released on Wednesday, Taiwan's real gross domestic product growth is expected to reach 9.3 percent in 2010, which is the highest forecast by an international organization so far.
The projected growth is also the second fastest growth rate forecasted among the "four little dragons, " behind only Singapore's 15 percent.

Also known as the "Four Asian Tigers," the "four little dragons" are Taiwan, Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea - economies that saw exceptionally high growth rates and rapid industrialization from the '60s to '90s.
For 2011, the IMF forecast that Taiwan's economy will grow by 4.4 percent, trailing Hong Kong's 4.69 percent, Singapore's 4.55 percent and South Korea's 4.48 percent.

During the four-year period between 2012 and 2015, Taiwan's economic growth is projected at 4.69 percent, 4.9 percent, 4.95 percent and 5 percent, respectively, all of which are highest among the "four little dragons."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT vice chairman meets Tory politicians
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/07/10 18:47:56 (by Jennifer Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The vice chairman of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , Chiang Pin-kung, made a speech at a luncheon he hosted on the sidelines of the British Conservative Party's annual Oct. 3-6 conference in the city of Birmingham.

Chiang, who doubles as chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, Taiwan's quasi-official intermediary body for exchanges with China, networked with heavyweights of the Conservative Party, which formed a ruling coalition with the Liberal Democratic Party in May this year, as well as with political leaders from other countries, during the conference.

He met with Geoffrey Clifton-Brown, chairman of the Conservative Party's International Office, and explained Taiwan's existing economic and political situation, including cross-Taiwan Strait relations, which have warmed up since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in 2008.
Clifton-Brown lauded the pragmatic approach that Taiwan has adopted toward China over the past two years and expressed his support for closer business and trade ties between Britain and Taiwan.

During his luncheon, attended by 16 British members of parliament and European politicians, including Cheryl Gillan, secretary of state for Wales, and Charles Bannock, chairman of the European Parliament-Taiwan Friendship Group, as well as Katharine S.Y. Chang, Taiwan's representative to the United Kingdom and KMT Legislator Lin Yu-fang, Chiang talked about Ma's "modus vivendi" diplomacy over the past two years that has expanded Taiwan's diplomatic horizons, as well as the improved cross-strait relations.

He told his audience that the closer cross-strait economic ties, particularly since Taiwan and China concluded an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) in June this year, have helped defuse tension across the strait.
Gillan, who has visited Taiwan, gave a thumbs-up to the KMT's efforts to mend relations with China and wished the KMT a landslide victory in the municipality elections slated for Nov. 27.

Chiang also met briefly at a cocktail party with Secretary of State for Justice Kenneth Clarke, who praised Taiwan's democratic and economic development and the government's efforts to improve ties with China.

It was the second time Chiang had attended the Tory party conference on behalf of President Ma, who doubles as KMT chairman. The KMT and the Conservative Party are not only allied members of the International Democrat Union (IDU), they are are also sister parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Evergreen's Chang to be named `Newsmaker of the Year'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 18:58:36 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest shipping company Evergreen Group said Thursday it has been informed that the group's chairman Chang Yung-fa will be named "Newsmaker of the Year" by Lloyd's List.

Lloyd's List is a London-based international marine publication which provides information and analysis on the global shipping industry. It has scheduled an awards ceremony in Singapore for Thursday night to announce Chang being named. The honor to be bestowed on Chang will be one of the 17 Lloyd's List Asia Awards for 2010.
Evergreen said the award showed Chang was recognized for having made the greatest impact on the development of the global shipping industry and of world trade over the past 12 months.
A recent exclusive interview with Chang by CNBC's "Managing Asia" made Chang one of the most impressive newsmakers in the shipping industry, the company said.

In the CNBC interview, Chang elaborated on his efforts in establishing Evergreen Marine and then expanding to the airline and hotel businesses, the group said. Chang's efforts have won positive response from the global business sector, it added.

In the previous years when the shipping industry was booming, Chang defied the trend followed by other shippers which ordered many large container ships. He believed such expansion would raise operating costs and impact the bottom line, according to the group.

When the world's economy was hard hit by the global financial meltdown in 2008, the world's shipping industry encountered falling cargo volume and declining shipping rates, and suffered financial difficulties due to the idle capacity from the aggressive expansion.
However, due to Chang's decision not to expand, Evergreen, which issued no orders to build new ships and was sitting on low debt, encountered less financial pressure, the group said.
The group added that Chang's foresight has been well recognized by the industry and media.
In 2006, Chang was the first Asian to be awarded the "Lifetime Achievement Award by Lloyd's List."

The Evergreen Group is a Taiwan-based conglomerate that encompasses shipping, transportation, and associated service companies. The group was formed in 1975 from the diversification of the original Evergreen Marine Corp., which was founded in 1968 and is one of the world's largest containerized- freight shipping companies.

Besides the Evergreen Marine Corp., other companies in the Group include: Evergreen International Corp., EVA Airways, Evergreen Aviation Technologies Corp., Evergreen Air Services Corp., Evergreen Air Cargo Services Corp., and Evergreen International Storage and Services Corp. Other subsidiaries include Uniglory Shipping Corp. and Uni Airways.

DOC.HEADLINE: Airport to launch food fair to boost image

TEXT.P: Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport will launch a food festival on Friday as part of efforts to improve the airport's reputation for poor food service, an airport spokesman said Thursday.

The two-week event features what organizers called "a showdown" of delicacies, inviting gourmets and celebrities to rate the food served at the airport, including beef noodles, coffee and Taiwan's traditional "luroufan" (rice with stewed pork).
During the first two days of the event, travelers can try free samples from participating vendors in Terminal 1.
The fair is the latest effort to boost the airport's image as travelers frequently complain about the airport's food service, spokesman Chao Shao-lien said.
In a poll conducted in August, foreign travelers gave the airport low ratings for facilities, food prices and staff conduct.
"But if you fall off your horse, get right back on it," Chao said of the airport's renewed efforts.
A new evaluation system that determines whether food providers can extend their contracts with the airport will be put in place soon, he said.
Those who score lower than 70 points will not have their contracts renewed the following year and will be barred from entering the bidding for three years, the spokesman said. (By Hsin-Yin Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's exhibition industry expected to grow
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 19:06:52 (By Jeffrey Wu and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is likely to see a further boost in its exhibition and conference industry thanks to the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China and the rapid economic recovery in Asia, trade officials said Thursday.

Chao Yuen-chuan, president and CEO of the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , said at the Asian Meeting, Incentive, Conference and Exhibition (MICE) forum, which opened in Taipei that day that Taiwan has reported progress in a recent global survey on the number of international exhibitions organized last year.

Taiwan advanced from 35th place in 2008 to 32nd place in 2009 in a global survey released by the International Congress and Convention Association (ICCA) in the middle of this year, as it organized 79 international conferences in 2008 and 91 last year, Chao said.

On city rankings in the Asia-Pacific region, Taipei City moved up to seventh place in 2009 from ninth place a year earlier after holding 52 international conferences in 2008 and 64 in 2009, Chao noted.

"The global financial crisis hit the exhibition industry hard in the past two years, but the situation in Asia is recovering faster than those in Europe and the United States, " Chao said at the forum.
He made the statement based on new International Monetary Fund (IMF) report saying that Asia's economic forecasts this year and next year outshine those of the euro zone and the United States.

Asia is projected to grow by 7.9 percent in 2010 and 6.7 percent in 2011, the report said. In contrast, the euro zone is likely to grow 1.7 percent this year and 1.5 percent next year, while the U.S. is forecast to grow 2.6 percent this year and 2.3 percent next year, according to the report.
"As a result, the global exhibition industry is expected to shift its focus to Asia," he said.

Grace Chiang, an official of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said at the forum that both the ECFA and direct cross-Taiwan Strait flights between the two sides are likely to further boost Taiwan's exhibition and conference industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's detention extended to Dec. 18
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 19:26:50 (By Lai You-chia and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court ruled Thursday to extend former President Chen Shui-bian's detention for two more months to Dec. 18 for his failure to honor a promise to return all the money that he and his family have stashed in foreign counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cold winter in Europe will not directly affect Taiwan: CWB

TEXT.P: Taiwan is likely to experience typical winter temperatures this year and will not be directly affected by a cooling climate system in Europe, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Thursday.

While Polish climatologists have predicted that Europe will face "its coldest winter in 1,000 years, " sparking wide debate over the past few days, the bureau said the chances of Taiwan being affected are slim.
According to the bureau, temperatures in December are likely to fall between 17 degrees Celsius and 18.3 degrees Celsius, a range that is considered normal.
A colder Europe will affect Taiwan directly only if the weather system moves east, said Cheng Ming-dean, director of the CWB's forecast center.

He explained that although Asia lies downstream from Europe in the global climate system, which means it can be impacted by weather there, the effects remain unclear, as factors such as distance and latitude all add to the uncertainty.

However, Cheng also said that the Polish forecasts are worth noting, as extreme weather in Europe can induce global climate fluctuations in the long run, which could cause an energy crisis and food shortages.
From that point of view, he said, Taiwan needs to keep an eye on whether Europe does take a hit of severe cold this winter, as it could lead to sudden rises in local oil prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commemorative passports to be issued for centennial
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 20:07:24 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will issue commemorative passports in December to mark the Republic of China's 2011 centennial anniversary, along with free leather passport cases, the Bureau of Consular Affairs announced Thursday.

The biometric passports, with issue dates of Jan. 1, 2011 (the first day of the 100th year of the Republic of China calendar), will be issued to people who apply in person at the bureau's Taipei office or at three offices elsewhere in the country.

The first 8,000 eligible applicants will also receive a leather passport-holder with a centennial anniversary logo on it. They will also be entered into a prize draw, with prizes of convenience store gift certificates worth NT$3,000, said the bureau's director, Thomas Chen, at a press conference in Taipei.

Chen noted that more than 60 percent of Taiwanese people apply for their passports through travel agencies, and said that the purpose of issuing the centennial passports is also to encourage people to apply in person to boost document authenticity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitung nurse wakes from months-long coma

TEXT.P: A 31-year-old nurse who fell into a coma more than five months ago after being hit by a drunken driver on her birthday, was discharged from a hospital in Taitung County Wednesday after waking up.

Lu Hui-chuan, who woke up from the coma in early September, has undergone 12 operations since being admitted to the Mackay Memorial Hospital Taitung Branch, where she had worked as a nurse in the psychiatry department since 2008.
"My biggest hope is that I will be able to walk again, " she said just before leaving the hospital.
Lu was hit by a drunken taxi driver while riding a motorcycle with her co-worker on their way home May 1 after celebrating her 31st birthday.
She sustained serious head injuries, as well as multiple fractures, when she was flung more than 10 meters after being struck by the taxi in Taitung City. Her colleague suffered only minor injuries.
Although able to speak, Lu is mostly paralyzed below the neck and needs regular physical therapy.
Chang Hung-chang, the hospital's chief neurosurgeon, told CNA that Lu's recovery was faster than expected.
"Lu is young, and she was taken to the hospital right after the accident," Chang noted. "Her recovery is going relatively well."

Lu and her family, from the indigenous Paiwan tribe, have been placed under a heavy burden by the cost of her treatment and with support from the teachers and students of a music class at Taitung's Malan Elementary School, a charity concert has been scheduled for Oct. 11 at the hospital to raise funds for the family.

DOC.HEADLINE: Warm up for Taipei Flora Expo to take place this weekend
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 20:30:42 (By Hung-chin Chen and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: A warm up for the Taipei International Flora Expo will take place this weekend, with participants to be taken on a floral tour in Taipei where they will see dozens of sites, each with a different flower theme, city officials said Thursday.
The tour will be held in concurrence with the Expo's trial run opening. The Expo, scheduled to open in November, will be one of the biggest international events Taipei has ever hosted.

According to Taipei's Department of Cultural Affairs, the Taipei Floral Tour will be launched in 22 cultural or historic attractions all over the city, including the Lin Yutang House, the Guling Street Avant-garde Theatre, and the Taipei Cinema Park.
Twenty two different kinds of flowers have been chosen for every tour site, according to their symbolic meaning, said a press release issued by the department.

For example, the Taipei Cinema Park, which has a coffee garden, will feature "coffee flowers." camelias will be the theme flower for the Grass Mountain Artist Village because former first lady Madame Chiang Kai-shek was said to have often rested under a camellia tree near achateau in the village when she and her husband stayed there.
People are encouraged to join the tour and collect all the 22 flower stamps at every site in exchange for eight different amulets, the department said.
Other plant-themed activities are also scheduled at the various stops on the tour.
The Flora Expo, which is set to run from November 6 to April 25, marks the first time such an exposition will be held in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Firm might face fines for misinforming on human clinical trials
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 20:38:09 (By Kelven Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A clinical research organization (CRO) that placed advertisements on online job placement company websites to solicit volunteers for human trials of new drugs might face serious fines for classifying the trials as "work opportunities, " a Department of Health (DOH) official said Thursday.

The CRO, also described as a contract research organization, could face fines of up to NT$500,000 (US$15,873) for advertising human trials as "work opportunities" and defining volunteers as "part-time student workers" in the ads, said Lu Nien-tsi, a section chief of the Bureau of Medical Affairs under the DOH.
The ads were called to attention by opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Huang Sue-ying in a press conference at the Legislative Yuan.

Huang said that people who would volunteer to undergo clinical trials for new drugs do so based on altruism, more like blood donors, and that such trials should not be falsely described as "work opportunities."
Commenting on the ads, Lu said the CRO was additionally wrong in the first place by running the ads without first applying for DOH approval.

TEXT.P: CT 30. Jason Wu to design gown for first lady Chow Mei-chin 31.Taiwan-Britain revises aviation pact to increase flights 32. Legislator calls for law to regulate online animal trading 33. DOC.HEADLINE: HTC to focus on Asia next year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 21:00:11 (By Jeffrey Wu and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: HTC Corp. will focus more on Asia following successes in Europe and the United States, the company said Thursday at its largest product launch in Asia. HTC is the largest manufacturer of smartphones using Google's Android operating system.
"This year, our business sales in Asia have grown more than 200 percent," HTC chief executive officer Peter Chou said in Taipei. He would not give any sales figures.

"Our team has set a goal of making 2011 the year of Asia for HTC," he told senior telecom executives from Japan, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Australia, South Korea, Singapore, Malaysia and other Asian countries.
The event featured the HTC's new Desire HD and Desire Z, which will be available in Asia in November.
HTC first unveiled these two new smartphones running on Android 2.2, the latest version of the operating system developed by Google, in the United Kingdom in September.
During a press meet later at the event, Chou said that the acceptance of HTC smartphones in Asia is increasingly higher and he saw a great potential in the Asian markets.
Asked if HTC will create an online application store, Chou said that its partners Google and Microsoft have launched similar services.
"There is no added value for HTC if we follow suit," he said.
HTC is now the world's fourth largest smartphone brand with more than 9 percent of the global market share.
In addition, Chou said that HTC has expanded users' experience from smartphones to other devices by entering the field of cloud computing.

HTC launched "HTCSense.com," an Internet platform using the cloud computing technology, to allow users to "manage, control and customize their own smartphones through the Internet," according to a company statement.
The service also allows users to synchronize their content on their smartphones and computers, the statement says.

DOC.HEADLINE: Canada to facilitate trade with Taiwan: Canadian representative

TEXT.P: Canada is trying to facilitate stronger business exchanges with Taiwan through a "block-building" process and to take advantage of the favorable environment following the signing of a cross-Taiwan Strait trade pact, Canada's representative in Taiwan said Thursday.

Canada has "re-positioned Taiwan as an ideal partner in light of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , " said Scott Fraser, Executive Director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei (CTOT), the North American country's representative office in Taiwan.

With direct flights and liberalized trade across the Taiwan Strait, "a lot of people are taking a second look at Taiwan's regional relevancy... (the ECFA) certainly makes Taiwan a much more attractive investment location for Canadian companies and a good base for doing business with China, " Fraser said at a media briefing.

Responding to a reporter's question about the possibility of a free trade agreement (FTA) between Canada and Taiwan, Fraser said neither side has ever raised the issue. He added, though, that Canada is pursuing FTAs with several other countries, including the European Union, South Korea and Singapore.

Speaking on the issue of visa-free privileges for Taiwanese entering Canada, he said that "consultations in Canada are still continuing and we hope a final decision will be made fairly soon." He also noted that the issue is not linked to Taiwan's ban on imports of Canadian beef.
In terms of the beef ban, Fraser said that since the Canadian authorities have provided data and scientific evidence that guarantees the safety of the beef, his office does not understand the ban.
He said Canada hopes to foster closer collaboration with Taiwan, particularly on energy, which could help reduce Taiwan's dependence on foreign energy imports.
Fraser added that Canada also hopes to see positive results on negotiations for avoidance of double taxation and for customs cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's detention extended to Dec. 18 (update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 21:47:57 (By Lai You-chia & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court ruled Thursday to extend former President Chen Shui-bian's detention for two more months to Dec. 18 for his failure to honor a promise to return all the money that he and his family have stashed in foreign counties

Chen and his wife, Wu Shu-chen, were both sentenced to 20 years by the High Court June 11 on charges of embezzling state funds, taking bribes, forgery and money laundering. The former president has been in detention since Dec. 30, 2008.
Chen and Wu have appealed to the Supreme Court, which asked the High Court to hold a hearing Oct. 1 on whether to extend Chen's detention, due to end Oct. 18.

Chen told the hearing that the presiding judge of the panel dealing with his case had previously told him he would stand a good chance of being released on bail if all the money hidden by his family abroad was remitted to bank accounts designated by the prosecutors.
The former president argued that he should be released, as he has returned all the money.

The High Court said in the ruling that Chen's family has remitted US$18.41 million back to Taiwan, over US$3 million short of the total of US$22.42 million that is believed to have been salted away overseas during Chen's eight-year term.

"The former president is to be detained for two more months, as he has been unable to prove that all the money stored in foreign countries has been wired back to Taiwan, and because there is still a possibility that he might flee the country if released, " the court said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fashion designer presents latest creation to first lady
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 21:56:10 (By Garfie Lee and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A New York-based Taiwanese fashion designer who rose to global fame in early 2009 after U.S. first lady Michelle Obama wore one of his designs to her husband's inauguration ball presented one of his latest creations Thursday to Taiwan's first lady Chow Mei-ching.
Jason Wu, who returned to Taipei a day earlier for a week-long visit, asked President Ma Ying-jeou during a meeting at the Presidential Office to pass on his gift to Chow on his behalf.
Speaking to the local media later, Wu said his design for Chow is in a classic, graceful style.
"It is one of my newest creations and I hope it will still be fashionable 20 or 30 years from now," Wu said.
In his meeting with Ma earlier in the day, the 28-year-old fashion designer said he hopes to help bring the local fashion industry into the international limelight.
Wu said Taiwan has had great influence on him and that he looks forward to giving something back to his homeland.
As a Taiwanese, Wu said, he would be very happy if his return could help draw the world's attention to Taiwan's fashion industry.
Responding to a question from Ma about how he became interested in fashion design, Wu said he was "born loving design."
"I don't know how to explain my love for design. It is in my blood, " Wu said. "I began designing costumes and accessories for dolls when I was 5 years old."

Wu said he was grateful for his mother's support, saying that she used to buy him foreign fashion magazines when he was a child, a move that not only helped enrich his knowledge about fashion but also allowed him to become good at English.

The one-shoulder gown he designed for Obama has already become a museum piece. It was donated in March this year to the National Museum of American History, where it joined the museum's collection of 24 other gowns worn by previous U.S. first ladies, including 12 worn on inauguration days.

Wu urged up-and-coming Taiwanese designers to travel extensively and learn from the work of other fashion designers and designers in other fields, which he said will help inspire their own creativity.
On a question from Ma about his design concepts, Wu said he draws from Oriental cultures and colors and that he prefers simple yet elegant styles.

Despite having lived away from Taiwan for most of his life, Wu said he still misses Taiwanese food very much, especially quintessential Taiwanese snacks, and that he will visit Taipei's Shilin night market during his stay. He will also attend his brother's wedding.

Wu left Taiwan when he was nine and moved to Vancouver, Canada, where he learned to sew by designing and making doll's clothes. He went on to study sculpture in Tokyo and later enrolled at Parsons the New School for Design in New York City.

At the age of 16, Wu began to make freelance doll's clothing designs and later traveled around the world studying fashion design. Four years ago, he launched his own fashion store in New York with earnings from sales of his doll's clothes and accessories.
He launched his first full collection in 2006 and won Fashion Group International's Rising Star award in 2008.
In June this year, Wu won the Swarovski Womenswear Designer of the Year award presented by the Council of Fashion Designers of America, which is the top honor in the U.S. fashion industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Filipina workers accuse employer of privacy violation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 21:57:01 (By L.C. Su and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A group of female workers from the Philippines filed a class action complaint Thursday against the company for which they work in Sanchung City, Taipei County, accusing it of violating their privacy by monitoring them with surveillance cameras round the clock.

Accompanied by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Cheng Li-wun and Taiwan International Workers' Association (TIWA) advisor Chen Su-hsiang, the 10 workers alleged at a news conference that they are monitored by the company 24 hours per day, for "management and security reasons."
AVTech Corp. claims to be the biggest manufacturer of digital surveillance video recorders and employs more than 40 Filipinas.

One of the protesters at the news conference said she felt extremely humiliated by being so closely watched by the management in their dormitories, which have cameras even trained on the doors to bathrooms and toilets.
"Some managers have even printed out segments of the images and criticized our moves or bodies," she said.
Tsai Meng-liang, a section chief of the Council of Labor Affairs, stressed that company management must not breach the personal privacy rights of the workers.
If AVTech is found guilty of doing so, it will have violated the Gender Equality Labor Law and Employment Services Act and will be fined in accordance with the law, Tsai said.
The Taipei county government labor affairs bureau has told the company to remove the cameras and will continue to investigate the case, he added.
The 10 women have been taken to a safe haven by the TIWA, according to Tsai, who said they will be shifted to other companies if the allegations against AVTech are proven.

Meanwhile, the company claimed innocence over the allegations, arguing that an outsourcing company is in charge of the management and that the eight monitoring cameras were not aimed at toilets or bathrooms.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-U.K. flights to increase after air pact amendment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 22:04:45 (By Wang Shu-fen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan amended an air pact with the United Kingdom Thursday, allowing for an increased number of passenger and cargo flights between the two countries from March 2011, the Civil Aeronautics administration (CAA) said that day.
Under the new agreement, Taiwanese carriers can operate 14 round-trip weekly flights from Taipei to London, up from the existing 10, effective from March 27 next year.
Manchester will be a new destination under the amended pact, with seven round- trip passenger flights per week.

The number of cargo flights between Taiwan and London will remain at three per week, while the number of cargo flights between Taiwan and Manchester will be increased from the existing three to 10 per week, the CAA said.

According to the new pact, Taiwanese cargo flights destined for Manchester will enjoy the Fifth Freedom of the Air, meaning that Taiwanese carriers can fly cargo from Manchester to destinations elsewhere in the world.
The arrangement will help Taiwanese carriers' plans for expanding their global cargo transport services, the CAA said.
Currently, EVA Airways operates seven weekly passenger flights from Taiwan to London, with stopovers in Bangkok, while China Airlines (CAL) operates three non-stop flights.
EVA Airways operates three weekly cargo flights between Taiwan and London, while CAL operates three such flights between Taiwan and Manchester.
CAL said Thursday that it will try to find greater opportunities to operate more non-stop passenger flights between Taiwan and London.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei residents face bigger hurdle in buying a home

TEXT.P: Buying a home in Taiwan's capital has become harder for ordinary wage earners, as property prices have continued to rise in the first half of this year, but their incomes have not, according to findings of a government survey revealed Thursday.

In Taipei City, where soaring property prices have recently prompted the government to launch tightening measures, the property purchase price is 10.87 times the average buyers annual income, according to the survey released by the Interior Ministrys Construction and Planning Agency.
This means Taipei residents would have to save all their salary for nearly 11 years to be able to afford a home.

The ratio between the home purchase price and the average annual income has been rising from 8.89 in the first half of last year, to 9.06 in the second half of last year, and then to the current ratio, Chang Chin-oh, who is in charge of the survey, told a news conference.
This is a big problem for residents in Taipeias housing prices are continuing to go up, but incomes are not going up,he said.

The semi-annual survey, which was conducted in July, found that 50.19 percent of the respondents in Taipei City considered the government's measures to rein in the housing market to beapparently ineffective.

Since June, Taiwan's central bank has launched a series of tightening moves on bank lending to curb the upward spiral of housing prices. Soaring prices have ignited complaints and fears that many local residents would not be able to buy a home.
More than 77 percent of Taipei's residents think that property prices are eithervery unreasonableorunreasonable, Chang said.
Chang noted that a healthy property market is conducive to economic growth.
A healthy housing market will help spur economic growth. After all, the economy should not grow on the back of unreasonable housing prices,he said.
The poll collected 1,840 valid samples from telephone and face-to-face interviews in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: September exports rise 17.5 percent year-on-year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 22:10:05 (By Lin Yi-feng and Christie Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan exported US$22.40 billion-worth of goods in September, representing a 17.5 percent year-on-year growth, the Statistics Department of the Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced Thursday.

Exports declined US$1.65 billion in September compared to the previous month as Typhoon Fanapi and various industrial accidents caused a drop in exports of oil and petrochemical products, said the MOF.

Exports of electronic products reached a second monthly high of US$6.81 billion, second only to the record high of US$6.87 billion in August, while exports of information and communication products reached US$1.22 billion, the highest since December 2004, according to MOF statistics.
Imports, meanwhile, reached US$20.63 billion, an increase of 25 percent from a year earlier, leaving Taiwan with a trade surplus of US$ 1.77 billion in September, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Double Ten parade to include `Prides of Taiwan'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 22:40:22 (By Cheng Ching-wen and Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: Several "Prides of Taiwan" will be included in the Double Ten National Day celebration parade to mark the 99th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China, the organizers said Thursday.

Council for Cultural Affairs Minister Emile Sheng said in a press conference held at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall that some outstanding Taiwanese individuals have been invited to take part in the parade this year, such as vegetable vendor Chen Shu-chu, one of Time magazine's 100 Most Influential People of 2010.

In addition, Taiwanese opera actresses Tang Mei- yun and Liao Chiung-chih as well as Taekwondo Olympic gold medalist Chu Mu-yen, the Jingmei Girls High School's tug-of-war team, which won three golds in Italy and South Africa's tug- of-war championships in February and September, and Kaohsiung's Fu-Hsing Little League team, which won third place in the Little League World Series this year, will march in the parade, Shen said.

The parade will be the grandest ever, Sheng added. There will be a folk art performance presented by the Sixth Army Corps and the Chinese Acrobatics Troupe from National Taiwan College of Performing Arts. In addition, the Jyou-Tian Folk Drum and Arts Group will parade with 100 local deities and 200 Harley-Davidson motorcycles.

"The main theme of the parade is Taiwan's originality, adventurousness, dreams and spirit, " said Lee Yung-feng, the executive director of the Paper Windmill Foundation and general director of the parade.
Model Patina Lin of the Eelin Model Company will also lead a team of 101 models in the parade, Lee said.
The parade will include 35 floats sponsored by official units and businesses, and more than 20 performing groups. It is estimated that it will reach a length of three kilometers.
The parade will start at the Chiang Kai- shek Memorial Hall at 2 p.m. and will end at 6 p.m. at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County to stage environmental art festival in Danshui
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 22:56:48 (By Liu Li-jung and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Taipei County government officials said Thursday that the 2010 International Environmental Art Festival will take place Oct. 9-23 in the county's seaside township of Danshui.

The county government has invited foreign groups to perform during the annual event for the first time, and more than 2,000 local residents have volunteered to participate, said county official Huang Hsiang-yueh.
Huang said local artists will help the volunteers, who will be formed into around 60 groups, to produce artworks made from recyclables, with theme subjects thought up by the volunteers themselves.

Ching Min-liang, director of the Taipei County Cultural Affairs Bureau, said the festival, in which the county government is working with the Danshui Township Office, Taiwanese artists and local schools to revitalize local culture and lifestyles, will demonstrate "community spirit."
The festival will include a series of free street performances, art exhibitions and plays on environmental protection and will take place in the township's Guan Chao Art Plaza and Huwei Fort.

DOC.HEADLINE: No need to isolate superbug patients: health minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 23:10:47 (By C.F. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: There is no need to isolate patients infected with the NDM-1 superbug who have not shown any symptoms, Department of Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang reiterated Thursday.

"It is even more dangerous to keep such patients in hospitals, as the bacteria are most easily transmitted through medical procedures, "Yaung said in a report delivered at the Legislative Yuan's Social Benefits and Health and Environment Committees on preventive measures for the superbug NDM-1 (New Delhi metallo beta-lactamase).

Chang Feng-yee, director-general of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control (CDC), also contended that preventing superbug patients from leaving hospitals lacks a legal basis in Taiwan and poses a violation of their basic human rights.
In line with World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines on dealing with people found to be carriers of NDM-1, hospitals need not isolate such people as long as they show no symptoms, Chang explained.

Various countries around the world, including Australia, Belgium, Canada, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States, have reported a total of more than 200 NDM-1 cases, all from the Indian subcontinent, he noted. Judging from this, it is possible that a recently identified Taiwanese carrier picked up the bacteria through a hospital procedure in India rather than in Taiwan, he added.
The CDC will talk on the telephone with officials of the Indian hospital in an effort to trace the origin of the man's infection, Chang said.

Former CDC Director-General Su Ih-jen, who is now vice president of National Cheng Kung University Hospital, said it is extremely important to keep the superbug NDM-1 from entering Taiwan, and infected patients who are discharged from hospitals must conduct periodic self-health examinations at home.

Following Yaung's decision, a Taiwanese cable TV station cameraman was discharged by a local hospital after having been infected at an Indian hospital where he had been received treatment for gunshot wounds sustained in a terrorist attack in New Delhi.
Yaung said he will hold himself responsible if the issue is mishandled and causes widespread infections.

DOH Deputy Minister Chang Shan-chwen said earlier that same day that the Indian hospital is the most likely source of the infection, as no one else in his TV crew were infected and he was the only one to have undergone surgery at the hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislator calls for law to regulate online animal trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 23:22:43 (By Huang Ming-hsien and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) said Thursday that there are no laws to regulate online trading in many wild animals, as some species sold on the Internet are not included on the list of protected species.

Legislator Ting Shou-chung said the current Wildlife Conservation Law only prohibits the sale of endangered animals, but some animals sold online are not considered endangered, which he said could result in a potential threat to the environment should such animals later be abandoned.
Ting said the government should provide an effective mechanism for animal trading, better quarantine conditions for all species and should pass laws on animal protection and online marketing.

Michelle Chou, a spokeswoman for the Life Conservation Association, told CNA that the association has found 66 websites in Taiwan selling a total of 263 species of animals, of which only 71 are protected by law.
Chou said reptiles are the most common pets sold online, followed by mammals and arthropods.

While stores have a policy of taking back abandoned pets such as hedgehogs, for which there was once a fad in Taiwan, Internet operators have no responsibility to face or deal with the issue, she said.

Lee Tao-sheng, deputy director-general of the Forestry Bureau, said the bureau, which is responsible for regulating animal trading, has done its best with insufficient human resources, noting that it has cracked down on 25 illegal online trading cases, rescuing 113 animals and arresting 27 people since 2009.
Lee agreed to meet with experts in a month's time to further discuss the possibility of including species traded online in the conservation law.
He said the bureau will make a comprehensive review of the law and study how best to regulate animal imports and trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese fishing boat feared hijacked in Mauritius: MOFA

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese fishing boat might have been hijacked off Mauritius waters in the Indian Ocean, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said in a press release Thursday.

The ministry said it was informed by the Council of Agriculture's Fishery Agency at noon time Wednesday that the Feng-guo 168, which registered in the southern port of Tungkang, Pingtung County might be hijacked in the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) of the island country.
Crew members of the longliner included a Taiwanese captain, eight Vietnamese, two Indonesians and three Chinese, the MOFA said.

In addition to trying to gather the latest information about the ship through its representative office in South Africa and France as well as Taiwanese fishery officials in Mauritius, the foreign ministry said it has also sought the assistance of the Malaysia-based Piracy Reporting Center of the International Maritime Bureau, a subsidiary under the International Maritime Organization, and the maritime liaison office of America's Bahrain-based 5th Fleet.
A France patrol aircraft has arrived at the scene and has located the boat, according to the ministry.
The incident was believed to be the first hijack case in the Mauritius EEZ, the MOFA said.

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/10 23:22:43 (By Huang Ming-hsien and Maia Huang)

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 8, or the first day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: John Hay, U.S. statesman and diplomat, is born. As secretary of state from 1898 to 1905, he promoted the "Open Door Policy" toward China.
1858: The "Arrow Incident" occurs, in which a Hong Kong-registered ship, the Arrow, is searched in Kwantung by Ching soldiers and 12 of the vessel's sailors are arrested. The incident led to an Anglo-French expedition against Peking and the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1869: Franklin Pierce, 14th president of the United States, dies at the age of 65. He was unable to reconcile the issue of slavery that divided his country.
1895: Queen Min of Korea, who had tried to stem the tide of Japanese domination, is assassinated in her palace at the instigation of the Japanese.
1897: Dow Jones & Co., Inc., a New York news agency, comes up with the novel idea of charting general trends in the trading of stocks and bonds on Wall Street. The agency computes a daily industrial average by using a list of 12 stocks and dividing their total price by 12.
1912: Montenegro declares war on Turkey, starting the first Balkan War.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the National government of the Republic of China.
1954: Communist Vietnamese forces occupy Hanoi.
1960: Lei Chen, publisher of the "Free China" monthly magazine, is sentenced to 10 years in prison for involvement in an insurrection.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Senegal.
1965: The Asian Christian Anti-Communist Conference is opened in Taipei.
1967: Clement Attlee, British politician, dies at the age of 84. As Labour prime minister from 1945 to 1951, he established the National Health Service, expanded public ownership of industry, and granted independence to India and Burma.
1970: Russian novelist Alexander Solzhenitsyn is awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature.
1973: Thai Air Force Marshal Boon Choo Chandrubekas arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1974: Economic Minister Y.S. Sun leaves for the United States to attend the China Week Celebration at Expo 74 in Spokane, Washington.
1974: Eisaku Sato, Japanese politician who served as prime minister from 1964 to 1972, is awarded the 1974 Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts toward nuclear disarmament.
1981: A team of 10 divers recovers 431 gold bars worth US$83 million from the wreckage of the "Edinburgh," a British cruiser sunk by German destroyers and a U-boat in the Barents Sea in 1942.
1981: Costa Rican President Rodrigo Carazo Odio, Madame Carazo, and their 12-member entourage arrive in Taipei for a five-day official visit.
1984: Beijing announces a plan to make primary school education compulsory by 1990 and to eradicate adult illiteracy by 1995.
1992: A chartered plane carrying tourists from Taiwan, Europe, and China crashes in northeast China, killing 13 people and injuring four others.
1995: A strong earthquake rocks Sumatra, Indonesia, killing more than 100.
1997: Tung Chee-hwa becomes the first Chinese leader to address Hong Kong's Legislature, 100 days after Britain ceded the territory to Communist China.
1998: The U.S. House of Representatives approves the launching of a formal impeachment inquiry against President Bill Clinton, only the third such investigation against a U.S. president in the country's history.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei says the ROC is determined to proceed with a plan to develop its own anti-missile defense even with no outside aid in the face of Beijing's growing missile threat.
2000: Direct air links between Taipei and Manila resume after a protracted dispute over air rights.
2000: Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen throws his weight behind the island's controversial fourth nuclear power plant despite the fact that the Cabinet seems determined to stop its construction.
2001: Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao reaffirms that the Republic of China government is opposed to any form of terrorism and that it will "actively participate" in the anti-terrorism campaign launched by the United States.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian receives Japanese Lower House member Sadanori Yamanaka, the head of a Japanese delegation for the ROC National Day celebrations.
2001: The National Police Administration (NPA) instructs police to strengthen protection of foreign personnel stationed in Taiwan following the attacks on Afghanistan by the U.S.-led anti-terrorism coalition.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of originality, energy, strength of character and determination: qualities necessary for the exercise of endurance."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Friday from its previous close, moving up 22.4 points at 8,306.32 on a turnover of NT$4.475 billion (US$144.35 million).
The weighted price index closed down 0.11 points at 8,283.92 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Economic Daily News: A crazy world

TEXT.P: Since the outbreak of the global financial crisis in 2008, major economies, led by the United States, have lowered their interest rates to near zero and at the same time have adopted a quantitative easing of their monetary policies. Instead of stimulating a global economic recovery, however, the measures have led to liquidity overflows that are blamed for the stock and property bubbles in many countries.
Amid the hot money flood, the worst thing a country can do is raising its interest rates, because this attracts more speculators to the country for arbitrage trading.

Taiwan is exactly such an example. Just when hot money is making a fierce attack on emerging markets, especially those in East Asia, Taiwan's central bank has bravely increased its key interest rates by 0.125 percentage points twice since June, and claims that interest rates "must be restored back to normal levels."
As a result, the central bank has been busy fighting the influx of hot money day after day since the interest rate hikes.
A country must have a way to protect itself in such a crazy world. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 8, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$30.820 at 10:00 a.m. Friday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.222 from Thursday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai shares up on record sales
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 11:08:07 (By Chang Liang-chih and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. Inc., the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, were higher in early trading Friday, bucking a downturn on the broader market as buying interest was ignited by its record-high September sales figure, dealers said.
Hon Hai rose 1.27 percent to NT$119.50 (US$3.88) at one point, with 20.4 million shares changing hands, while the benchmark weighted index fell 0.33 percent to 8,256.56.

"Investors have been upbeat about the company's earnings outlook, in particular after it reported a record monthly high in September sales for the second consecutive month, " Taiwan International Securities analyst Michael Chiang said.
The previous day, Hon Hai announced NT$253.48 billion in sales for September, up 18 percent from August and up 69.62 percent from a year earlier.
In the third quarter, the company's sales rose 29.1 percent from the previous quarter to NT$664.45 billion.
"The higher September sales largely reflected strong demand in China due to a buying spree ahead of the country's extended Oct. 1 National Day holiday," Chiang said.
Looking ahead, Hon Hai is expected to enjoy a good fourth quarter as the company has secured large orders from global high-tech giants, Chiang said.
The September sales also surpassed a previous estimate of NT$232 billion by Merrill Lynch, which maintained a buy recommendation on the stock.
Merrill Lynch said Hon Hai's two wage hikes for its Chinese workers in June, effective from October, are expected to impose little impact on the company's bottom line.

Chiang agreed, saying that as the company is relocating its China operations from coastal Shenzhen to the inland Henan Province, the relatively lower labor costs there will alleviate the impact on the company's operating costs.
Chiang said Hon Hai is expected to continue to attract buying, and gave a target price of NT$130.00-NT$132.00 for the stock.
