DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. supports Taiwan's ICAO participation: official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/08/10 11:28:55 (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States expressed explicit support Thursday for Taiwan's bid to take part in the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) , in which Taiwan is seeking "meaningful participation" as an observer.

"The United States supports Taiwan's meaningful participation in international organizations where appropriate, including ICAO, " an unnamed State Department official told CNA in a telephone interview.

In a daily press briefing held earlier that day, Mark Toner, acting deputy spokesman for the State Department, said it is "for those international organizations to decide" upon what "meaningful participation" entails.
Taiwan is not an ICAO member, although it handles a large flight information volume, with 49 carriers flying more than 1 million flights over its flight information zone every year.
In addition to bidding for ICAO observer status, Taiwan is also hoping to gain a presence in various ICAO technical seminars, workshops and conferences.

To achieve that goal, Taiwan has asked its diplomatic allies and other friendly nations to speak up for the country during the 37th session of the ICAO Assembly that opened Sept. 28 in Montreal, Canada and will run through Oct. 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislators vote on Judicial Yuan nominees
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 11:29:11 (By Su Lung-chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Legislators began casting their ballots Friday on President Ma Ying-jeou's nominations for the top two leadership positions in the Judicial Yuan.
On Aug. 24, Ma nominated Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Rai Hau-min as president of the Judicial Yuan, with law professor Su Yeong-chin as his vice president.
The voting was scheduled to close at around noon, with the results expected to be announced later in the day.

The two posts became vacant after Lai In-jaw and Hsieh Tsay-chuan resigned in July as president and vice president, respectively, to take responsibility for a scandal in which three senior judges were detained for alleged corruption.

According to the Constitution, the president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan are appointed by the country's president from among 15 justices of the Constitutional Court, and confirmed by the legislature.
The lawmakers also cast their ballots Friday for Ma's nominations for two Examination Yuan minister-without-portfolio posts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature confirms Judicial Yuan leadership nominations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 12:15:50 (By Su Lung-chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved President Ma Ying-jeou's nomination of Central Election Commission Chairman Rai Hau-min as head of the Judicial Yuan Friday, with a vote of 71-36.
The ruling Kuomintang-controlled legislature also passed Ma's nomination of Su Yeong-chin, a law professor, as vice president of the Judicial Yuan, with a vote of 73-34.
Lawmakers from across the political spectrum took part in the polling, which closed at 11 a.m.

The two Judicial Yuan posts became vacant after Lai In-jaw and Hsieh Tsay-chuan resigned in July as president and vice president, respectively, to take responsibility for a scandal in which three senior judges were detained for alleged corruption.

According to the Constitution, the president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan are appointed by the country's president from among 15 justices of the Constitutional Court, and confirmed by the legislature.

The lawmakers also cast their ballots that same day for Ma's nominations for two Examination Yuan minister-without-portfolio posts. As of press time, the results of those votes had not been announced.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese visitor numbers double for first week of October
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 12:28:39 (By Feng Chao and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan in the first week of October -- a long holiday in China in celebration of its national day -- reached 20,000 people this year, nearly double the level of the same period of last year, according to government statistics.

The tallies released by the Tourist Bureau Thursday show that 20,206 Chinese tourists arrived in Taiwan in the Oct. 1-7 period, marking a growth of 92.5 percent compared with the same period of 2009, when 10,498 Chinese tourists arrived.

Based on the assumption that most visitors stay for 6.5 days and spend NT$7,141 (US$232) per day, Taiwan earned NT$960 million by hosting the Chinese visitors in the so-called "October golden week" this year, the bureau said.
Thanks to the recent appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar, the revenues represent an increase of over 70 percent compared with the same period of a year ago, it added.

The bureau also said that while Sun Moon Lake in the central county of Nantou continued to top the list of tourist attractions for Chinese tourists during the holiday week, with the Taipei 101 building in second place, Sizihwan Bay in Kaohsiung City squeezed out the National Palace Museum in Taipei for third place.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Taiwan dollar slows rise after central bank flags risks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 12:52:41 (By Lin Yi-fong and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slowed its appreciation against the U.S. dollar during morning trading Friday, due to a statement released by the central bank a day earlier that it might launch further measures to curb an inflow of foreign funds, dealers said.

The central bank quoted Nobel Prize-winning economist Joseph Stiglitz as saying Oct. 5 that ultra-loose monetary policies by the U. S. Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank are throwing the world into chaos rather than helping the global economic recovery.

It also noted Brazil's Oct. 4 doubling of a tax on foreign bond purchases that was seen as aiming to curb an inflow of foreign cash that has pushed up the value of the Brazilian currency to its highest level in two years.
Local markets interpreted the central bank's move as suggesting that it might also launch short-term capital control measures to attack speculators if they keep pushing up the local currency.
The U.S. currency opened higher at NT$31.100 on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, and then dropped back to NT$30.790 at noon, falling NT$0.252.
The U.S. dollar hit a low of NT$30.675 a day earlier before the central bank intervened late in the day to boost the greenback to close at NT$31.042.
Dealers said, however, that after the central bank released the statement, the market was reluctant to push the greenback lower Friday.

"The effect of the central bank's `new instructions' was quite obvious, " a dealer at a local bank said. "The drop of the U.S. dollar against the local currency in early trading was not as much as it has been in the last few days," he added.

The central bank underlined in its statement Stiglitz's contention that the recent actions by those countries to curb the strength of their currencies were "necessary, " and that they are natural in that context, as they cannot allow their exchange rates to appreciate and destroy their export strength.

It also pointed out that the difference of 4.6 percentage points between the year-on-year growth rate of U.S. dollar-denominated import prices at 12.74 percent in the first nine months of this year, and the year-on-year growth rate of New Taiwan-dollar-denominated import prices at 8.14 percent in the same period, reflected the appreciation of the local unit against the U.S. currency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Hon Hai Group posts record sales

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Group, the world's largest electronics contract manufacturer, also known as Foxconn Technology Group, reported record sales of NT$253.476 billion (US$8.18 billion) for September Thursday, surpassing consensus market expectations for revenues.

The group's robust business performance will give a badly needed shot in the arm to the local downstream electronics sector, which has seen its stock prices plunge in recent days over the New Taiwan dollar's appreciation.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the development:
Economic Daily News:
Hon Hai's September sales marked an increase of NT$38.67 billion, or 18 percent over its August sales, and represented a whopping 69.62 percent year-on-year growth.
The group's overall sales for the first nine months of the year have already exceeded NT$1.6 trillion, for a hefty 62.97 percent year-on-year gain.
Market analysts forecast optimistically that Hon Hai will emerge as the first Taiwan-based conglomerate to post more than NT$2 trillion in annual sales by the end of this year.
Hon Hai spokesman Edmund Ding said consumer electronics remained the strongest of the company's three major product lines in September, followed by personal computers and communications technology.
Financial analysts said frenzied sales of the Apple iPad contributed greatly to Hon Hai's remarkable business record for September. Hon Hai is the sole contract maker for the iPad.

Major local electronics stocks, including those of Hon Hai, have remained weak in recent days due to rises in the local currency's exchange rate against the greenback amid hot money attacks fueled by domestic interest rate hikes. Stock market analysts said Hon Hai's encouraging sales record will not only help boost its stock price but will also help stabilize the stocks of other electronics giants such as Quanta and Compal. (Oct. 8, 2010).
Commercial Times:
On Thursday, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) released the country's foreign trade statistics for September that show a 6.8 percent decrease in exports from the August level.
MOF officials attributed the monthly decline in export value mainly to the onslaught of Typhoon Fanapi and a string of industrial accidents that caused a drop in petrochemical sector exports.
Compared with the year-earlier level, September exports posted a 17.5 percent growth, according to MOF statistics.
The accumulated exports for the third quarter of this year amounted to US$70.35 billion, a new quarterly record in the country's foreign trade history, MOF officials said.
They also forecast that the country's total exports for 2010 will be able to hit the government's projected target of US$272.9 billion.

Total exports for the first nine months of the year stood at US$202.25 billion, up 40.6 percent from the same period of last year, while imports for the nine- month period increased an even more impressive 51.4 percent to top US$184 billion. As a result, the country's trade surplus declined 17.9 percent to US$18.25 billion for the first three quarters of the year. (Oct. 8, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Accomplices to corruption

TEXT.P: Yang Ping-chen, a judge of the Taiwan High Court, was impeached by the Control Yuan Thursday for whoring and gambling while on duty, as well as for running an antique business. Both the judicial system and bureaucratic culture have a responsibility for Yang's descent into disrepute.

How could a judge have so much money to buy luxury housing and antiques and even gamble? If the Legislative Yuan had amended the Act on Property Declaration by Public Servants early to criminalize unexplained wealth, Yang could have been brought to justice long ago.

Meanwhile, the strict seniority-based hierarchy within the judiciary has strengthened the culture of bureaucrats sticking up for one another, which makes exposure of corruption in their ranks difficult. In addition, the large amount of discretion enjoyed by sentencing judges means that it is very easy to bribe them.

Another reason for the prevalent corruption within judicial circles is the lack of checks and balances of the judicial branch. In other words, Yang was not thrown into disrepute by chance. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 8, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: HTC mum on tablet plan

TEXT.P: The chief executive of HTC Corp., the world's largest maker of smartphones using the Google and Microsoft operating systems, declined to confirm or deny Thursday the company's reported plan to join the global rush to launch a tablet computer early next year.

Speaking to reporters at HTC's biggest product-launch event in Asia, CEO Peter Chou said he would not comment on reports speculating that HTC will launch a Google Android-based tablet computer in the first quarter of next year.
He said an overwhelming number of companies have been trying to occupy a share of the booming market.
More than 100 companies said at this year's Consumer Electronics Show that they will launch e-readers or tablets, Chou said.
This makes the tablet computer market "less appealing," he added.
Chao also expressed belief that there is still great potential for smartphone growth and he predicted that annual sales of the devices will reach 500 to 600 million units in two or three years.
Chou confirmed that HTC sold 16 million smartphones in the first three quarters of this year, which is higher than its total sales of 11 million units last year.
At the launch event, HTC introduced its new Desire HD and Desire Z, which run on Android 2.2, the latest version of Google's operating system, and which will be available in Asia in November.

Chou forecast that more than 1 million units for each new smartphone will be sold by the end of this year, as most of the previous models launched earlier this year have seen sales of at least 1 million units each.

In the Asian market, he said, the company's sales grew 200 percent this year. The goal is to boost the Asian market's share of HTC's total revenues to 33 percent, with the U.S. and European markets accounting for the rest, he added.
HTC is now the world's fourth-largest smartphone brand, with nearly 10 percent of the global market share.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elpida plans R&D center in Taiwan: Economic Ministry
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 14:05:20 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Elpida Memory Inc., a Japanese-based chipmaker, is planning to set up an R&D center in Taiwan, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Thursday.
Wu Ming-chi, director of the Department of Industrial Technology under the MOEA, said Elpida is likely to invest more than US$100 million to establish the DRAM chip development center.
Wu said he has held preliminary talks with the Japanese company regarding the investment, but he added that the investment plan still needs more time to be finalized.
He said that if everything goes smoothly, Elpida is expected to become the first foreign company to open such a large-scale DRAM research hub in Taiwan.

Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said that while he had not been informed about the planned Elpida investment, the R&D center could become an alternative way for Taiwan to develop its DRAM industry now that the ministry has shelved a plan to start operations of Taiwan Innovation Memory Co. (TIMC) due to opposition from the Legislative Yuan.
The government set up TIMC in August 2009 as part of its efforts to restructure the local DRAM industry, which was hit hard by the global financial meltdown.

However, the Legislative Yuan decided in November 2009 that the Cabinet-run National Development Fund should not be allowed to pour operating funds into TIMC, against the government's previous expectations.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Jung-chiou said Elpida's planned investment is simply a business consideration, as the Japanese firm wants to collaborate with Taiwan to compete with South Korea, which has taken the lead in production technology in the global DRAM industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: President seeks advice from Nobel Prize-winning economist
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 14:46:24 (By Garfie Li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou met at the Presidential Office Friday with James Alexander Mirrlees, winner of the 1996 Nobel Prize in economics, and asked his advice on how best to lead Taiwan out of the shadow of the recession.

Mirrlees, who is currently Master of Morningside College at The Chinese University of Hong Kong, was visiting Taiwan to give two lectures at Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top academic research institute, and National Taiwan University on Oct. 8 and Oct. 9, respectively.

The Scottish economist is known for his analytic research on economic incentives in situations with incomplete, or asymmetrical, information. He shared the 1996 Nobel Prize with William Vickrey of Columbia University.

Ma told Mirrlees that although Taiwan has bottomed out of the global recession triggered by the financial storm that began in 2008 after taking a series of financial and economic measures, "the country's economic outlook is not so clear."
Taiwan is still being affected by the aftermath of the recession, with an imbalance of income distribution and high unemployment, he said.
Ma asked Mirrlees how Taiwan, an export-reliant country, can maintain its economic development, and how it can avoid the influence of the withering European and American markets.
Mirrlees' responses were not available, as the meeting at that point became closed-door, so that reporters were no longer present.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 0.47 percent

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 0.47 percent Friday amid lingering fears that a strengthening local currency could undermine the island's global competitiveness, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 39.73 points to 8,244.19, after moving between 8,232.02 and 8,309.91, on turnover of NT$114.44 billion (US$3.72 billion).

The market opened up 0.27 percent and moved to the day's high before selling emerged, focusing on flat panel display makers, to reverse early gains on currency concerns. Investors also pocketed recent profit by unloading select old economy stocks and financial shares, dealers said.
A total of 2,565 stocks closed down and 1,227 up, with 293 unchanged.

The textile sector suffered the heaviest pressure, down 1.46 percent. Cement stocks shed 1.06 percent, financials lost 1.09 percent, construction shares dropped 0.55 percent, paper and pulp stocks fell 0.54 percent, and foodstuffs closed down 0.48 percent.
The plastics and chemical sector fell 0.42 percent and the machinery and electronics sector closed down 0.32 percent.

"A stronger Taiwan dollar still weighed on market sentiment," Hua Nan Securities analyst Stan Chang said. "Along with the upside of other Asian currencies against the greenback, the Taiwan dollar could not be isolated. The local bourse was affected accordingly."
Chang said turnover was reduced, with many investors sidelined ahead of a U.S. job report for September scheduled to be released later Friday.
Investors in Taiwan were afraid that Wall Street will go choppy if the September jobless rate disappoints U.S. markets, Chang said.
"For the moment, it was wise for investors to keep cash and adjust their portfolios to cushion the possible impact," Chang said.
He said he expects the local bourse to move between 8,200 points and 8,400 points next week on lingering currency worries.
Among flat panel makers, Chimei Innolux fell 4.53 percent to NT$41.05 and AU Optronics shed 3.91 percent to NT$30.70.
In the old economy sector, Far Eastern New Century lost 2.41 percent to NT$41.50 and Taiwan Cement dropped 1.58 percent to NT$34.35.
Hon Hai Precision, the world's largest contract electronics product maker, closed up 0.42 percent at NT$118.50, off a high of 121.50, after it posted record-high sales for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hopes to expand e-reader market at Frankfurt Book Fair
DOC.DATELINE: Frankfurt, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/08/10 16:39:42 (By Lin Yu-li and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's electronics hardware industry has made a foray into publishing at the Frankfurt Book Fair 2010, with the "Taiwan Pavilion" including an e-reader section for the first time.

Electronics manufacturers and digital publishers from Taiwan including Qisda, Moker Information Technology, and Newtonkids shared the results of applying e-books to digital learning at the world's biggest book fair.

"As long as technology cooperates with the culture and creative industry, there will be a lot of room for e-publishing in Taiwan to grow, " said Wang Jung-wen, chairman of the Taiwan Book Fair Foundation.
Wang, who heads local publisher YLib, said most e-readers around the world are made by Taiwanese producers, which suggests the country has a favorable environment to develop the device.

Qisda Vice President Alpha Tsai, who led a group to promote his company at the event from Oct. 6- 10, said publishing had its cultural and linguistic boundaries, making it necessary for e-reader device makers to work with publishers in different countries to open local markets.
Taiwan-based personal computer vendor Acer Inc. will launch its e-reader sales through German book service provider Libri in October, according to an announcement last month.

"E-books will probably have two major potential reader groups in the future. People over 40 years old who are used to reading paper books are likely to buy text e-readers with e-paper display," Tsai said.
On the other hand, "young people who have grown up with multimedia would rather choose devices with interactive content, " he said.
This year, the exhibition attracted 7,533 exhibitors from 111 countries, with over 309,000 books on display, according to statistics from fair organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Candidates should support mentally challenged: welfare group

TEXT.P: A welfare organization held a press conference Friday in which it urged candidates running in the Nov. 27 five special municipality elections to put forward concrete policies and set aside budgets for the mentally challenged.

Taipei Life of Heart Association Director-General Chin Lin said the organization operates several projects contracted from the government and that without a long-term budget and concrete development plan, the benefits for the mentally challenged will be at risk.
"The voices of the mentally challenged are often overlooked by politicians, " said Liu Li-ju, director-general of the Taipei County Mental Rehabilitation Association.
"I once asked a mayoral candidate about his plans for the mentally challenged when I attended his book signing party, " said Liu. "I was not at all surprised to receive no answer."

According to Chin, the Department of Health will in 2011 stop funding a home visit service, a mechanism that sends social workers to the homes of the mentally challenged at regular intervals to provide regular consultation and assistance.

"We are afraid that the service will disappear for good if government officials keep on neglecting this issue, " said Chin, noting that about 90 percent of the mentally challenged live in the community rather than being confined to medical institutions, and often need help with their daily lives.
The service has benefited people like "Mr. Bright" (not his real name) , a 40 -year-old who has suffered from schizophrenia since the first year of high school.

"He used to shun people and lock himself away in his home, " said Liu Hsiao-yu, a social worker who has been working with him for some time. Since receiving the weekly visits, she said, he has learned to care for his family and his community.

Liu said that Mr. Bright, who has an obsession with memorizing words in the dictionary, has even developed English to Chinese translation skills, thanks largely to the encouragement of the social workers.

Displaying a printed statement of support she wanted the candidates to sign, Chin urged voters to ensure that their chosen candidate supports the rights of the mentally challenged before casting their votes in the year-end elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF head speaks on cross-Taiwan Strait ties at EU think-tank
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/08/10 16:53:38 (By Tsao Yu-fan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with China delivered a speech at a leading European think-tank Thursday on Taiwan's cross-strait policy and its efforts to strengthen economic ties with other countries.

Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , Taiwan's quasi-official intermediary body for exchanges with China, encapsulated the policies that President Ma Ying-jeou's administration has adopted over the past two years to ease tensions across the Taiwan Strait and improve "people-to- people" ties across the strait.

During his speech at the European Institute for Asian Studies, one of the major think-tanks in Europe, Chiang said that cross-strait relations have been hoisted to a much higher level of engagement since Taiwan signed an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China in June this year.

He said that the signing of the ECFA has led other Asian countries, including Japan and Singapore, to become interested in entering closer economic ties with Taiwan, and has given Taiwan a boost in its pursuit of signing free trade agreements with other countries.

Responding to a Singaporean scholar's question on whether the ECFA will lead to a unification of Taiwan and China, Chiang said that reunification with China and Taiwan independence were sensitive matters in Taiwan society, and that the public was not in consensus on the issue.
He said that Ma would continue his "three noes" policy of no reunification, no independence and no use of force, meaning Taiwan will pursue a policy of maintaining the cross-strait status quo.

When an official with the Japanese embassy in Belgium asked about Taiwan's plans to sign free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries, Chiang said that Taiwan and Singapore agreed in August to begin bilateral talks on the feasibility of signing an FTA-like economic cooperation agreement.
Chiang, a vice chairman of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , arrived in the Belgian capital Wednesday after attending the British Conservative Party's annual Oct. 3-6 conference in Birmingham.
He is currently on a six-day visit in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central bank auctions NT$100 billion in NCDs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CAN) 10/08/10 17:15:59 (By Lin Ye-fong and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The central bank said Friday it auctioned NT$100 billion (US$3.25 billion) in 364-day negotiable certificates of deposit (NCDs) to drain excessive funds from the market.
The NCD sale attracted total bids worth NT$322.11 billion from financial institutions such as banks, credit cooperative associations and Chunghwa Post, the central bank said.
The NCDs were sold at an average interest rate of 0.715 percent, it added.

The central bank said it has sold NT$700 billion worth of 364-day NCDs since April in its monthly NCD auctions, and the fund absorption in the seven auctions was equivalent to a hike of 2.72 percentage points in the deposit reserve requirement ratio.

Banks are required to set aside a certain portion of their deposits and place the funds with the central bank. The central bank raises or cuts the deposit requirement reserve ratio to tighten or loosen money supply.
Dealers said the market is awash in idle money, with continued inflow of funds from overseas. The value of the bids in the latest auction clearly demonstrated the high liquidity level, they added.

The local market's funds remain ample because the central bank repeatedly intervenes in the foreign exchange market by buying U.S. dollars to shore up the value of the greenback against the Taiwan dollar, the dealers said.
The latest NCD auction was consistent with the central bank's plan to tighten its monetary policy after the local economy staged a strong rebound, they added.
On Sept. 30, the central bank raised the discount rate by 0.125 percentage points to 1.50 percent, marking the second consecutive quarterly rate hike.

The government has raised its forecast for Taiwan's 2010 gross domestic product (GDP) growth to 8.24 percent from the previous estimate of 6.14 percent, after a 13.71 percent GDP increase for the first quarter and a 12.53 percent rise for the second quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to send tech delegation to Middle East

TEXT.P: The semi-official Institute for Information Industry is leading an information and communications technology delegation of experts and executives to the Middle East to explore business opportunities there.

The delegation of representatives from a dozen Taiwanese firms and institutes, led by the institute's chief executive, Lee Chih-kung, will depart on its trip to Oman, Qatar and Kuwait Friday night, the institute said in a statement.
It will be the second time the institute has led a delegation to the Middle East.

During the visit that will end on Oct. 13, the institute will sign a memorandum of understanding with a major research institute in Kuwait to expand collaboration in the fields of technology, environmental protection, security and medical care, the institute noted.
It also hopes to help Taiwanese companies cash in on business opportunities created by the three countries' efforts to improve their infrastructure, according to the institute.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the Taiwan dollar Friday, gaining NT$0.053 to close at NT$31.095.
Turnover totaled US$1.16 billion during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$31.100 and moved between NT$30.739 and NT$31.110 before the close.

Dealers said declines in other currencies, in particular the Korean won, against the U.S. dollar prompted investors to sell some of their Taiwan dollars to lock in profits from the local currency's recent appreciation.
Taiwan's currency has gained 2.8 percent against the greenback in the past month after remaining roughly at NT$32 to the dollar for much of the year.
On Thursday, the central bank implied it would apply further measures to curb inflows of foreign funds to prevent a rapid upswing in the local currency.
Dealers said the central bank's announcement had an impact on the market and served as another force driving investors to cut their Taiwan dollar holdings.

The selling of the Taiwan dollar in exchange for the greenback came largely from foreign banks, which had accumulated large Taiwan dollar positions to back their bet that the local currency would appreciate further, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Keeping fans from displaying national flag inappropriate: SAC

TEXT.P: The organizers of an international basketball tournament who stopped fans from displaying Taiwan's national flag at a game Thursday night acted "inappropriately" and misinterpreted the "Chinese Taipei" formula, Taiwan's top sports administrator said Friday.

The Sports Affairs Council (SAC) said in a statement that it was a "pity" to learn of the action taken by officials of the Chinese Taipei University Sports Federation (CTUSF) at a game between Taiwan University All-Stars and China's Tianjin Polytechnic University at the 2010 Asian University Basketball Championship.
It described the handling of the incident by the CTUSF, the tournament's organizer, as inappropriate.

The competition, being held in the northern township of Luzhu, Taoyuan County, from Oct. 3-8, is an official international tournament and must follow the "Chinese Taipei" formula set up by the International Olympic Committee (IOC).

The formula was devised in 1981 by the IOC to enable Taiwan to participate in the Olympics under the name of "Chinese Taipei" after the People's Republic of China was admitted to the organization in 1979.
Since then, Taiwan has participated in almost all international sporting events and some international organizations under the name.

"Though the formula has been in place for years, some sports administrators still don't quite understand the regulations and principles. We want to make sure this will not happen again, " said Chou Jui, head of the SAC's International Sports Department.
Chou explained that the Chinese Taipei formula regulates protocols in areas such as competitions, training, meetings and ceremonies and also covers personnel, including athletes, officials and staff.
Taiwanese event organizers, for example, are not allowed to hang the country's national flag (which differs from Taiwan's Olympic flag) at competition venues.
The formula, however, does not regulate spectators and what happens in the stands unless organizers announce specific restrictions prior to a competition.
SAC Deputy Chairman Chen Hsien-tsung said the council has contacted the CTUSF to explain the regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health department plans Patient Safety Awareness Week

TEXT.P: This year's Patient Safety Awareness Week will center on building an interactive partnership between doctors and patients, an official from Department of Health said Friday.

The event is an annual health care safety education campaign in the third week of October. This year it will run from Oct. 10 to Oct. 16 and feature seminars and activities in Taipei and seven other municipalities for both patients and physicians.

Wang Tsung-hsi, deputy director-general of the Bureau of Medical Affairs at the health department, said that most Taiwanese patients are too shy to speak out to doctors, when in fact they should engage in dialogue about their symptoms and notify doctors of any possible mistakes.
"It is proven in Western countries that patient awareness campaigns can efficiently reduce false diagnoses, death rates and re-infection rates," Wang said.
Throughout the year, 50 hospitals nationwide will cooperate to improve communication between patients and doctors, he said.
Patient awareness is also one of the factors in hospital evaluations, Wang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC, UMC post higher sales for Q3
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 18:31:37 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) and United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC), the world's top two contract chip makers, both said Friday that they posted growth in sales for the third quarter of this year.

TSMC said it recorded NT$112.25 billion (US$3.64 billion) in sales for the third quarter, a quarterly record high, up 6.94 percent from the second quarter, while UMC registered NT$32.65 billion, a record high since the third quarter of 2004 and up 9.77 percent from the previous quarter.
In September, TSMC sales rose 0.7 percent from August to NT$37.64 billion, while UMC saw sales for the month grow 0.53 percent from the previous month to reach NT$10.94 billion.

"As the two companies operated at full capacity in the third quarter on the back of strong demand for consumer electronics, the quarterly growth came as no surprise, " Grand Cathay Securities analyst Julian Wang said.

However, as the global foundry business has entered the fourth quarter -- traditionally a slow season for the sector -- Wang said he expects both TSMC and UMC will see sales declines over the next three months.
He said TSMC, which commands a lead in production technology, is likely to fare better than UMC during the cyclical downturn.
Wang said he expects TSMC will see a 3 percent-5 percent quarterly decline in sales for the fourth quarter, while UMC is likely to suffer a 7 percent-10 percent fall in revenue.
"It is unlikely that the two companies will enjoy full capacity operations in the fourth quarter, due to slowing demand," Wang said.

He said the market should watch closely how fast the New Taiwan dollar rises against the U.S. dollar, as the pace of the appreciation is expected to impact the high-tech sector's global competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: Company denies invading privacy of Filipina workers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/08/10 18:43:30 (By Wei Shu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: AVTech Corp. on Friday denied allegations that it invaded the privacy of a group of Filipina workers by watching them around the clock with surveillance cameras.

Tien Cheng-ping, president of the manufacturer of digital surveillance video recorders, said in a news conference that surveillance cameras had been installed at the workers' dormitories for security reasons.
Tien said all the cameras were aimed at entrances, with none aimed at toilets or bathrooms.
He denied worker allegations that company management had printed out images in which they were scantily dressed, circulated the photos at meetings, and criticized their behavior or bodies.
The accusations were made a day earlier by 10 Filipina workers from AVTech's plant in Sanchung, Taipei County.
The county's Labor Affairs Bureau has launched an investigation into the incident.
Tien said the workers were making false allegations in retaliation for the company's decision not to renew their employment contracts, which expired at the end of September.

The workers have been trying to pressure the company to renew their contracts since July, he said, adding that the Labor Affairs Bureau has hosted a number of mediation meetings over the past two months to try to reconcile the dispute.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese visitors attributed to Palace Museum's souvenir sales growth
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 19:41:59 (By Kuo Mei-lan, Lin Heng-li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Sales of the National Palace Museum's souvenir shop grew 10 percent in the first week of October compared with the same periods of August and September, the general manager of the museum's souvenir department said Friday.

Ho Chun-huan told CNA that although the number of Chinese tourists who visited the museum in the Oct. 1-7 period -- the long national day holiday called "golden week" in China -- did not appear to be an obvious rise from the previous two months, souvenir sales were up.
Most of the tourists spent between NT$1,400 (US$45.27) and NT$1,500 on souvenirs at the museum in the week-long period, higher than the NT$1,000-NT$1,200 they spent in August and September, she said.
One of the tourists spent a whopping NT$1.06 million in a single day, making him the biggest spender the store has seen since Taiwan opened its doors in 2008 to tourists from China, Ho said.

The National Palace Museum was one of five most popular tourist destinations in Taiwan among Chinese visitors during the week-long holiday, behind Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County, the Taipei 101 building and Sizihwan Bay in Kaohsiung City, according to the Tourism Bureau.
However, shops and vendors in the Sun Moon Lake scenic area said nothing had changed during the week, with no discernible increase in the number of Chinese visitors.
Tea egg vendor Chou Chin-pen complained of low business throughout the holiday, especially in the last three days.
"We were so idle we could fall asleep in the daytime," she said.
According to statistics compiled by the Sun Moon Lake National Scenic Area Administration, Chinese tourist arrivals in the first week of October were not as numerous as expected.
As of the end of September, the number of Chinese visitors to Sun Moon Lake had reached nearly 840,000 people, which breaks down to 3,100 per day, the administration said.
The peak for arrivals was in April and May, with a daily average of 4,756 Chinese visitors per day, it said.
In comparison, the golden week tallies reached only 3,169 people per day, it added.

China is one of Taiwan's biggest sources of tourists. In 2009, 560,000 Chinese people visited the country, while the first seven months of the year saw 740,000 Chinese tourist arrivals, according to Tourism Bureau statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Airport to consider new criteria in future food vendor tenders
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 19:51:12 (By Hsin-Yin Lee and Chiu Chun-chin)

TEXT.P: New criteria will be used to evaluate bids to provide food services at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, Transportation and Communications Minister Mao Chi-kuo said Friday, a move aimed at improving the airport's much-maligned food services.

Speaking at the opening of a two-week "airport food festival, " Mao said quality, price and customer satisfaction rather than the amount of the rights fee bid will determine who is selected to sell food at the airport.
The new policy, Mao said, addresses concerns that the food services provided by vendors have been constrained by the excessively high rights fees they have had to bid to win airport concessions.

In response to public complaints that food vendors' prices are too high, the airport will adopt a differentiated pricing strategy to give travelers a complete range of low-, medium- and high-end choices, Mao added.
Also under the new policy, existing vendors will be subject to a new evaluation system that requires them to meet certain performance standards if they want to have their contracts renewed.
The quality and prices of the food sold at the airport have been among a litany of complaints that have tarnished the facility's image in recent months.
The food festival, held to restore the airport's image, has invited participating vendors, such as Ever Rich, Honbaryu and Tasa Meng, to showcase their best dishes until Oct. 22.
Besides food services, Mao said, the airport is also working to improve its trolleys, toilets and transit facilities, which have also drawn criticism from the public and passengers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prize-winning vibration sensor helps detect landslides
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 19:58:08 (By Chen Shou-kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An optical fiber vibration sensor that won a silver medal at the 2010 Taipei International Invention Show in late September, has proved effective in monitoring and providing early warnings of landslides, an academic source said Friday.

The sensor, developed in 2008 by a research team from National Kaohsiung First University of Science and Technology, was able to detect landslides or rockslides that were about to occur during flood seasons, said Tsair-Chun Liang, dean of the university's College of Electrical Engineering and Science, who guided the project.
The sensors have been installed and tested since 2009 in a river watershed in central Nantou County's Shenmu Village, an area vulnerable to landslides during heavy rains.
"The sensors have been working as well as similar products from abroad, but cost only about one-seventh as much as imported models, " he said.
They also are more reliable than traditional monitoring sensors, whose cameras are easily disabled during flash floods, he said.

The device's sensors capture vibrations between rocks and in the ground and then the vibration frequency and vibration amplitude is transmitted to a monitoring station scale through the optical fiber system.
The station can then issue warnings to people in areas where there are potentially dangerous vibrations so that they can evacuate their homes or move to safe ground.
The 6-cm-long, 3.5-cm-wide and 4.5-cm-high device stored in a stainless steel case can also be used to monitor earthquakes, Liang said.

The university has applied to patent the product, developed by its Graduate Institute of Electro-Optical Engineering with the support of the Council of Agriculture's Soil and Water Conservation Bureau, according to Liang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Envoy urges Malaysia to grant Taiwan visa-free access
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 20:08:20 (By Soon Thean Bee and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to Malaysia on Friday urged the Southeast Asian country to grant Taiwanese citizens visa-free privileges as a gift to mark the 99th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China, which falls on Oct. 10.
Luo You-chung, head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Kuala Lumpur, made the appeal during a speech to about 550 guests at a cocktail party celebrating Taiwan's National Day.
Taiwan has allowed Malaysians visa-free entry since 2002, he said, adding that Malaysia already grants the privilege to visitors from more than 100 countries.

Luo said visa-free travel helps boost economic and cultural relations. Since Britain opened visa-free entry to Taiwanese in March 2009, the number of visitors from Taiwan has risen by 37 percent, while trade has grown 40 percent, he said.
As for Malaysia, investment by Taiwanese corporations from 1987 to June this year exceeded US$10.5 billion, making Taiwan the fifth-largest foreign investor in Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: New judicial head vows to wipe out 'bad apples'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 20:12:35 (By Garfie Lee, Kevin Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The incoming Judicial Yuan president on Friday reaffirmed his commitment to carry out sweeping judicial reforms, eliminate corrupt judges and restore public trust in the country's court system.

"We need to protect and respect competent, conscientious judges while also working to get rid of the unethical ones in a clear-cut, no-nonsense manner, because one rotten apple can spoil the whole barrel, " Central Election Commission Chairman Rai Hau-min said after his nomination was approved by the Legislative Yuan earlier in the day.

Rai, a veteran lawyer versed in criminal procedure law, criminal policy and constitutional law, said he will direct the formation of a national judicial reform committee. The group, to be composed of representatives from all walks of life, will draft a reform agenda within one year after he assumes the post, Rai added.
With district courts around the country as the "home base of judicial reform," Rai said integrity, professionalism and trust will be the top goals of the reform programs.
Rai outlined his plan during a visit to the legislature to thank lawmakers for supporting his nomination.
On Aug. 24, President Ma Ying-jeou nominated Rai as the new Judicial Yuan head, with law professor Su Yeong-chin as his deputy.
Of the 112 incumbent legislators, 107 took part in the confirmation vote on Friday morning and Rai obtained 71 "yes" ballots.
Su, widely known as one of Ma's confidants who once served as chairman of the National Communication Commission, also saw his nomination passed with a vote of 73-34.

The two Judicial Yuan posts became vacant after Lai In-jaw and Hsieh Tsay-chuan resigned in July as president and vice president, respectively, to take responsibility for a scandal in which three senior judges were detained for alleged corruption.

According to the Constitution, the president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan are appointed by the country's president from among 15 justices of the Constitutional Court, and confirmed by the legislature.
Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said Ma was grateful for the legislative support of his nominations for the Judicial Yuan posts.
"The president is also hopeful that Rai and Su will work determinedly and efficiently to complete a judicial overhaul and meet public expectations," Lo said.

On Friday, the legislature also approved President Ma's nominations for two Examination Yuan minister-without-portfolio posts -- professor Kao Yung-kuang of the Graduate Institute of Development Studies at National Chengchi University and Chang Ming-jue, chairperson of the Civil Service Protection and Training Commission under the Examination Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Google remembers singer John Lennon

TEXT.P: Search giant Google Inc. began commemorating the 70th birthday of murdered singer John Lennon Friday by displaying a special YouTube video logo on its home page.
The design was aimed at celebrating the singer's achievements and contributions, Google Taiwan said in a statement.

The English singer-songwriter was born on Oct. 9, 1940. He rose to worldwide prominence as a founding member of the Beatles and was later known as a peace activist. Lennon was shot to death in 1980 at the age of 40.
Google has been making decorative changes to the logo on its website since 1999 to celebrate holidays, anniversaries and the lives of famous artists and scientists.
This is the first time Google has featured a YouTube video as part of its logo.
The John Lennon video appeared on Google's home page at noon Taiwan time and will remain there for 48 hours, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flat panel maker AUO names acting chief executive

TEXT.P: Flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) named an acting chief executive in a management reshuffle Friday, two months after its top executives were banned from leaving the United States due to price-fixing charges.
AUO has appointed executive vice president Max Cheng as acting CEO and will ask him to help expand the companys solar energy business, the company said in a statement.

CEO Chen Lai-juh would continue to lead the company's solar energy business, AUO added. In August, a U.S. court ordered Chen and two other senior executives to remain in California after they appeared in a hearing on the case.

The executives, along with AUO, its U.S. subsidiary and other senior managers were indicted in June by the U.S. Department of Justice for allegedly conspiring to fix the prices of TFT-LCD panels from Sept. 14, 2001 to Dec. 1, 2006.

Chen and AUO Vice Chairman Chen Hsuan-bin remain in San Francisco to manage AUO's business interests there, while former AUO Executive Vice President Hsiung Hui takes up temporary residence in San Diego.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese basketball team pulls out of tourney over Taiwanese flags

TEXT.P: A visiting Chinese university basketball team withdrew Friday from a tournament being playing in Taoyuan County after seeing hundreds of Taiwanese national flags displayed outside the arena.

After arriving Friday afternoon at Kainan University Arena, where the 2010 Asian University Basketball Championship was being held, the bus carrying the Tianjin Polytechnic University basketball team turned around and left.
The team missed its game against a Mongolian All-Star team, and was officially credited with a 20-0 loss.

Though nobody from the Chinese delegation commented on its pull-out, the team may have been angered by the hundreds of Taiwan national flags displayed in and around the parking lot and along the road leading to the arena that greeted their bus.

They were put there by a "national flag rally" organized by two local university students in protest of a move the night before by an official from the tournament's organizer, the Chinese Taipei University Sports Federation (CTUSF) , to stop a fan from displaying the country's national flag in the stands.
The students were incensed by reports that the CTUSF official, Lee Hung-chi, clamped down on the fan at China's insistence, though subsequent reports indicated Lee acted of his own volition.
"This is a silent protest to the Chinese team that made the flag issue a big deal, " said one of the two student protest organizers identified only by his surname Hsieh.
The other organizer, surnamed Hsu, said the protest was "non-political" and was held to express "freedom of speech."
Lee described the Chinese team's withdrawal as "silly, " but he himself was criticized by the Sports Affairs Council (SAC), Taiwan's top sports administrator, for going after the fan.

In a statement released Friday, the SAC called Lee's move inappropriate and said he had misinterpreted the "Chinese Taipei" formula, devised in 1981 by the International Olympic Committee to enable Taiwan to participate in the Olympics after the People's Republic of China was admitted to the Olympic movement.
Under the convention, Taiwan participates in international competitions under the name "Chinese Taipei, " and uses an Olympic flag that differs from its national flag.

Organizers of competitions in Taiwan are not allowed to fly the country's national flag at competition venues, but the convention does not regulate spectators and what happens in the stands unless organizers announce specific restrictions prior to a competition.
Previous sporting events in Taiwan against Chinese teams have seen fans wave small national flags during the competition, generally without incident.

Meanwhile, Taiwan beat Universite Saint-Esprit De Kaslik of Lebanon 85-77 Friday, the tournament's final day, to capture the title. Even with its forfeit to Mongolia, China finished third in the seven-team tourney.

DOC.HEADLINE: Loans to SMEs exceed annual target: FSC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 21:10:54 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Hanna Liu )

TEXT.P: Under a special program in cooperation with the government, local banks had lent NT$235.5 billion (US$76.4 billion) to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) as of the end of August, already beating the 2010 target of NT$150 billion, the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said Friday.

Total loans from local banks to SMEs had reached NT$3.44 trillion by the end of August since the special SME financing program was launched in July 2005, accounting for 43.71 percent of total business loans, the FSC said.
According to the FSC, the accumulated loans to SMEs marked an increase of NT$1.73 trillion or 45.34 percent over the amount before the implementation of the special credit program.
Meanwhile, it said, the average non-performing loan ratio for SMEs had fallen to 1.3 percent by the end of August, showing that the loan risk was under control.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan congratulates Liu Xiaobo on winning Nobel Peace Prize

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government on Friday congratulated Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo for winning the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize and urged the Chinese government to engage in the promotion of human rights as its economic power grows.
President Ma Ying-jeou said in a press release Friday that Liu's award was "not only an individual honor but also has great historical significance for the development of human rights in China."

Quoting his own speech of June 4, Ma urged China to treat dissidents with lenience because "it would convince people throughout the world that the rise of mainland China contributes not only to the cause of peace, but is also a positive development from the standpoint of the universal values of freedom, democracy, and human rights."
Premier Wu Den-yih told reporters that Taiwan and Liu Xiaobo both promote freedom and human rights.

"With China's economic development and integration into the world, the ideals of freedom, the rule of law and human rights will be accepted by the majority of its people in the future, " he predicted.
Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Liu's honor underlined the importance of human rights as a universal value.
Taiwan "looks forward to China's good faith in promoting human rights and advancing political reform," she added.
The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called for the immediate release of Liu and voiced its support for China's democratization.
Political commentator Paul Lin, formerly a Chinese professor who specialized in the history of China's Communist Party of China and now a naturalized Taiwan citizen, also praised the award.
"Justice has prevailed. And Liu Xiaobo has now become the new-generation torchbearer of China's democracy and freedom movement," he said.
Liu's award is indicative of the global trend of most countries believing that a rising and powerful China still needs thorough reforms, Lin said.
He praised the Norwegian Nobel Committee for upholding the true value of the award and fending off Chinese pressure.

"The ball is now back in China's court. Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao, who pledged political reform, should publicly voice his support for Liu, who also called for reform 'within the system' rather than a flat-out revolution. If not, Wen's pledge was questionable, " he said.
Lin said he did not expect the Chinese government to release Liu in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Status of hijacked Taiwanese boat remains unclear: MOFA

TEXT.P: The status of a Taiwanese fishing boat suspected of being hijacked in the Indian Ocean not far from Mauritius remained unclear as of Friday evening, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official has said.

The ministry was informed by the Council of Agriculture's Fisheries Agency at noon Wednesday that the vessel "Feng Guo 168, " with a Taiwanese captain, eight Vietnamese, two Indonesians and three Chinese on board, might have been hijacked in the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) of the island country.
The ministry was still unsure whether the boat had been hijacked by pirates or its own crew on board, MOFA spokesman James Chang said.
France, which sent a reconnaissance aircraft to locate the ship and has monitored its course since Wednesday, has agreed to continue its assistance, Chang said.
The vessel is now heading south to Mauritius after sailing north Thursday.
The MOFA also officially requested the assistance of Mauritius' government to ensure safety of the longliner in the country's EEZ.
The ministry said it has been trying to gather information about the ship through its representative offices in South Africa and France as well as Taiwanese fishery officials in Mauritius.
It has also sought the assistance of the Malaysia-based Piracy Reporting Center of the International Maritime Bureau and the maritime liaison office of America's Bahrain-based Fifth Fleet.

DOC.HEADLINE: No Chinese workers allowed in name of training: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 22:09:29 (By Su Lung-chi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not allow Chinese citizens to enter Taiwan for employment under the guise of receiving training or attending courses, Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday.

Wu was responding to ruling Kuomintang Legislator Chen Chieh at a general administrative interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan. Chen said he was worried about a news report Friday that said some Taiwanese companies had taken advantage of legal loopholes to hire Chinese citizens to work in Taiwan.
The premier suggested companies or organizations inviting Chinese citizens to Taiwan for training should have them wear special vests to prevent people from "trying to pass fish eyes for pearls."

Wu quoted tallies from the National Immigration Agency as indicating that 553 domestic companies applied for the entrance of 3,642 Chinese citizens into Taiwan for business workshops or training courses in the first nine months of this year.
A total of 3,591 were approved by the agency and entered Taiwan, Wu said.
"These figures do not look like illegal schemes and I believe a great majority of these people indeed came to Taiwan for training, " he said.

Speaking at the interpellation, Council of Labor Affairs Minister Wang Ju-hsuan said that the council had never issued a work permit to a citizen of the People's Republic of China under stipulations of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.
According to Article 95 of the statute, introducing workers from China into Taiwan would require approval by the Legislative Yuan, Wang said.

Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said that according to Taiwan's regulations, training sessions that mainland Chinese take in Taiwan should not be longer than three months, but most trainees actually stayed for about one month.
These people, numbering no more than 20 in each group, should not receive payment from any Taiwanese company during their stay, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Accused company did not violate law: Investment Commission
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 22:14:11 (By Lin Hui-chun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese company accused by local media of illegally employing Chinese workers in Taiwan did not violate government regulations, the Investment Commission said Friday.

The commission said that Young Fast Optoelectronics Co. (YFO) filed six applications to host 101 technicians from its manufacturing operations in China for technical training in Taiwan over the past nine months.
All of the technicians came to Taiwan to learn advanced touch panel manufacturing and processing procedures, the commission said.

Although they were approved to stay 60 days or 70 days for the training sessions, the first two groups -- one of five people, and the other of 20 -- returned to China after 29 days and 59 days, respectively, according to the commission. The other four groups are still receiving training in Taiwan.
Regulations stipulate that Taiwanese companies with manufacturing operations in China may apply to train Chinese employees in Taiwan for up to three months, the commission said.
Local media had reported that YFO was illegally paying Chinese employees to work in Taiwan.

The commission said it dispatched inspectors, along with officials from the National Immigration Agency, to the YFO plant in Taoyuan and found that the Chinese technicians received training or attended classes eight hours a day and had not worked as regular staff at the company.
YFO is one of the world's leading manufacturers of small to medium-sized touch panel sensor products. It is a key supplier for HTC Corp. and Samsung Electronics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Investment welcome, but not hot money: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 22:31:35 (By L. C. Su and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: With Taiwan facing financial inflows that have pushed the local currency higher in the past month, Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday that Taiwan will guard against "hot money" but still welcomes foreign investment in the country's infrastructure.

Answering questions at a legislative hearing on a possible "hot money tax, " Wu said the government will take measures to curb the inflow of speculative funds to avoid a repeat of the 1997-1998 Asian Financial Crisis.

The crisis was precipitated by speculators aggressively driving down the values of many Asian currencies that left some countries on the verge of bankruptcy and dependent on bailouts from international organizations.
"However, foreign investment in Taiwan's infrastructure development will be more than welcome," Wu stressed.
Perng Fai-nan, the governor of Taiwan's central bank, was reserved about imposing a "hot money tax, " and he said that doing so was beyond his bank's power and required the legislature's approval.
Fueled by a weakening U.S. dollar, large amounts of speculative funds have been entering Asian markets, including Taiwan, to profit from the expected appreciation of currencies in the region.

The Taiwan dollar has appreciated by nearly 3 percent over the past month. It closed at NT$31.095 to the greenback Friday, slightly down from its 28-month closing high of NT$31.042 to the U.S. dollar a day earlier.

The signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement with China, a rising Chinese yuan and a depreciating U.S. dollar have created room for Taiwan's currency to appreciate against the U.S. unit, said Huang Yin-ji, chief economist at SinoPac Financial Holdings Co.

Perng stressed Thursday that measures by governments around the world to allow a gradual appreciation of their currencies have been necessary, but he hinted that his bank might intervene to stop any rapid upswing in the Taiwan dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Airline maintenance worker killed on Taoyuan airport apron
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 23:42:30 (By Chiu Chun-chin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A China Airlines maintenance worker was killed while on duty on the apron of Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport when he was hit by a vehicle.
The 40-year-old victim, identified only by his surname of Fang, was killed while inspecting a Japan Airlines plane that had just arrived from Osaka's Kansai International Airport.

Witnesses said the accident took place at around 12: 25 p.m. amid the usual bustle when the ground crew inspects a plane. The aircraft had yet to shut down its engines, making it hard for ground personnel to hear.

The driver of the aircraft ground power unit, which supplies power to planes while on the ground, has worked at the airport for seven or eight years as an employee of airport contractor, Taoyuan International Airport Co.
He was suspected of having run over Fang accidentally while backing up his vehicle.
The cause of the accident and who should be held responsible have yet to be determined.

Fang's death was the first fatality on the airport's apron in the 32-year history of the facility and just the latest in a series of problems that have plagued the airport's management in recent months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Airline maintenance worker killed on Taoyuan airport apron
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/10 23:42:30 (By Chiu Chun-chin and Lilian Wu)
