DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 9, 2010, or the second day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1192: King Richard the Lion-hearted abandons the Holy Land after an unsuccessful Crusade, leaving Jerusalem in Muslim hands.
1701: Yale University is founded in New Haven, Connecticut.
1944: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill arrives in Russia to talk with Joseph Stalin in the Third Moscow Conference.
1944: The United States, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and the Republic of China promulgate a draft for the Charter of the United Nations.
1958: Pope Pius XII, originally Eugenio Pacelli, dies at the age of 82. He headed the Roman Catholic Church during World War II.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Congo Republic.
1962: Uganda gains formal independence after nearly 70 years of British rule.
1965: ROC Ambassador to the United States and Representative to the United Nations Tsiang Ting-fu dies of liver cancer in New York at the age of 71.
1967: Ernesto "Che" Guevara, the Argentine-born revolutionary who helped Fidel Castro gain power in Cuba, is shot dead after being captured by Bolivian army troops. He was 39.
1967: Indonesia severs diplomatic relations with Communist China.
1970: Dissident Soviet writer Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize for literature, turns down an invitation to Stockholm to attend the award ceremony in December.
1970: Cambodia declares itself the Khmer Republic.
1972: Prime Minister Tupua Tamasese Lealofi IV of Western Samoa arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: Mayor Chang Feng-shu of Taipei leaves for Honolulu to attend a council meeting of the Asian and Pacific Area Conference of Mayors.
1974: A two-day post-congress symposium of the first conference of the World Nuclear Medicine Federation opens in Taipei.
1975: Soviet dissident and human rights activist Andrei Sakharov is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Alberto Nogues Perez, foreign minister of Paraguay.
1983: South Korean President Chun Doo Hwan escapes unharmed when 17 members of his entourage, including Foreign Minister Lee Bum Suk, are killed in a bomb blast in Rangoon.
1984: A famous Cantonese opera performer from mainland China, Hung Hung, 40, announces her defection in a press conference held at the Free China Relief Association in Taipei.
1986: The Executive Yuan passes the Program for Taroko National Park, in which NT$4 billion is to be invested in developing the park over six years.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Task Force approves the first draft of the Temporary Provisions Governing Relations between the People of the Mainland Region and Taiwan Region.
1998: Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi's government resigns after losing its 31st vote of confidence.
1999: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui urges mainland China to promote relations with Taiwan based on a "special state-to-state relationship."
2000: Haitian President Rene Preval and his wife, leading an official delegation, arrive in Taipei to attend celebration activities marking the ROC's Double-Ten National Day.
2001: The American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taiwan holds a party to mark the 50th anniversary of its founding.
2001: The five-day 2001 Taipei International Electronics Show kicks off with the number of international buyers in the first day down significantly compared with the previous year's figures.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of dignity, noble seriousness, order and regularity: qualities necessary for the exercise of self- respect."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
United Daily News: Difference between Liu Xiaobo and Wen Jiabao

TEXT.P: Liu Xiaobo, who just won the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize, has been called a Chinese dissident. We think it would be more appropriate to refer to him as a democracy activist.

There are shocking similarities between recent remarks advocating political reforms by Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao and Charter 08 -- a manifesto calling for free elections, greater freedom of expression and human rights co-authored by Liu in 2008 that led to his arrest and imprisonment.
While Charter 08 identifies what the Chinese government "has failed to do," Wen states what the government "ought to do."

For example, Charter 08 says the absence of political reforms "has restrained the development of the Chinese nation and the progress of human civilization." Wen says without political reform as protection, the achievements of economic reforms will slip away.
Also, Charter 08 urges the Chinese government to "end the criminalization of free speech, " and Wen pledges to "create the conditions to allow people to criticize government affairs."

The greatest difference between Wen and Liu probably lies in their positions. As the premier, Wen can voice his promises for political reforms. Liu, however, was jailed because of his push for political reforms.

At a time when Liu has been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his "non-violent struggle for fundamental human rights in China, " Wen's remarks appear especially stimulating. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 9, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Telecoms carrier to stage concert in central Taiwan

TEXT.P: A local telecommunications operator will hold its third annual concert at a popular tourist attraction in central Taiwan Saturday, and expects to attract more visitors than last year.

The free concert at the scenic Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County will feature songs from operas, such as Turandot and Madama Butterfly, to be performed by Chinese Tenor Mariolin Xu and Taiwanese soprano Mewas Lin, said Taiwan Mobile Co. in a statement.
The two-hour-long event is expected to attract more than the 25,000 visitors seen last year, said the second largest telecoms operator in Taiwan.
People attending the event, which will start at 7 p.m., will also be treated to a five-minute-long fireworks show after the performances.
The event is part of the Sun Moon Lake Music Festival that kicked off Oct. 8 to showcase a series of fireworks and live music shows.
The nearly month-long gala will also feature symphonies, jazz and drumming concerts, and an indigenous dance performance before it ends on Nov. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: Slimming capsules containing sibutramine banned in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 9 (CNA) 10/09/10 13:16:15 (By C.F. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Pharmaceutical firms have been ordered to recall slimming capsules, including Meridia, which contain the substance sibutramine, within a month, after reports showed the weight-loss drug increases risks of cardiovascular disease, the Department of Health announced in a statement issued Saturday.

The health department's announcement came after the U.S. Food and Drug Administration this week demanded Abbotte Laboratories to stop selling its sibutramine-based diet pill Meridia in North America, following the reports.
Sales of the drug have been suspended in the European Union.

Meridia is used in combination with a reduced calorie diet and exercise to help people lose weight and maintain their weight loss. It is in a class of medications called appetite suppressants which act on appetite control centers in the brain to decrease appetite.
In addition to the product recall, the authorities in Taiwan have also decided to annul the approval for 15 kinds of medications containing sibutramine, starting Oct. 11.
Besides Meridia, other sibutramine-based medications that have received regulatory approval include: Reductil, Sytramee, Losfat, Moi-Allison, Sibutil, Shapedesign and Controkilo.

According to statistics from Taiwan's health authorities, 302 people experienced discomfort after taking medications containing sibutramine. Of the cases, 115 were proven related to cardiovascular disease, but no death was reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Hail the Double Ten National Day

TEXT.P: On the eve of the 99th National Day of the Republic of China (ROC) in Taiwan, people on the island are ready to celebrate the special day Sunday with a grand flower floats parade and a dazzling fireworks show.

The theme of this year's National Day celebrations chosen by the government is "Being appreciative and grateful for the blessings, pursuing excellence and maintaining the nation's competitiveness in a sustainable manner."

As a country that has been struggling to gain international recognition as a state with sovereignty, Taiwan is showing that it wants to celebrate its National Day with a spirit of optimism and a positive attitude.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the upcoming event:
United Daily News:

Thousands of users of Facebook, an Internet social networking Website, have replaced their profile photos on their web pages with pictures of the ROC national flag in its three colors of blue, white and crimson, in celebration of National Day.
This was part of a campaign launched by several Facebook users in the hope of attracting at least 10,000 people to decorate Facebook with "a sea of ROC national flags."
As of Friday, the campaign drew five times as many people as the organizers had expected. They hoped the number will double the following day.
"Putting your party flags down, picking our national flag up, waving it and chanting 'Hail the Republic of China', " the initiators of the campaign wrote on their Facebook pages. (Oct. 9, 2010).
China Times:

The National Day celebration will begin Saturday with an evening party at the Taipei Arena. And the biggest event for the celebration will be the grand flower floats parade in downtown Taipei City on Sunday.

A 40 meter-long, 4.5 meter-high caterpillar-style float made by the Paper Wind Mill Foundation will be a highlight of the parade. The foundation was commissioned by the 2010 Taipei International Flora Exposition to make the float to promote the exposition, which will open in November.
The float is a colorful caterpillar made entirely of green materials and recycled objects. It took 10 months and nearly NT$20 million (US$646,200) to make.
The foundation said it hopes the caterpillar will remind people to value their living environment and work together to stop global warming. (Oct. 9, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA English news budget for Oct. 9

TEXT.P: in Taipei

DOC.HEADLINE: Flower farmer keeps roots in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Chen Liang-bin never imagined that booming demand for his anthuriums -- also called flamingo flowers -- could bring him headaches.

Customers in China want to sharply increase orders to 3 million a year -- 300 times the total number of orders last year, said Chen, chief of a floriculture production and marketing group in Neimen Township in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County.

"The demand from China is really too much, " said Chen, who has planted anthuriums in Neimen -- Taiwan's largest plantation zone for the flowers -- for 11 years. "We cannot simply cut our supply to Japan in order to meet the growing Chinese demand -- at least not for now."

Anthuriums rank second on Taiwan's cut flower export list, following orchids. Japanese like to use them for a traditional type of flower arrangement, and have made Taiwan the top source of anthurium imports to Japan.
As of the end of September, anthurium production in Neimen reached 2 million, already surpassing its full-year production in 2009.
Although production is expected to rise to 2.5 million by the end of this year, it is still not enough to meet growing demand from China, Chen said.
A Chinese flower trader offered Chen a down payment of 1 million Chinese yuan (US$149,900) to secure a deal for 3 million anthuriums ayear -- or 250,000 flowers per month.
Chen said, however, that at present his group is only able to supply 50,000 flowers to China per month.
"My Chinese client told me that would not even meet the demand from Shanghai alone," he said.
Chen said that his group will not be able to meet China's orders until 2012, after it expands plantation areas for the flowers.

Although anthuriums are popular in China, they were not included in the "early harvest" list of items that will enjoy preferential tariff treatment under the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed with China in late June, unlike oncidiums and other orchids.

In August, Chen Liang-bin met Chen Yunlin, chairman of China's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), in Tianjin, China. The flower farmer expressed his hope that anthuriums could be included on the early harvest list.
The ARATS chief, however, told Chen to consider moving his people and technologies from Taiwan to China.
"We don't want to go to China. We want to keep our roots in Taiwan, " Chen said, adding that his biggest concern about working in China was unexpected policy changes.
Chen set up a flower store in Shanghai earlier this year to handle his business, but said he would rather ship his flowers to China than be based there.
"With direct cross-strait flights, Chinese orders can be taken in the morning and delivered by late afternoon," he said.
Chen said the planting cost of anthuriums is NT$7-8 per flower, and the average selling price in Taiwan is about NT$20 (US$0.65).
At present, Chen sells his flowers in his Shanghai store at about NT$40 apiece, slightly higher than his flower's wholesale price in Japan.
Before Chen set up his shop earlier this year, traders sold his flowers in China for as much as NT$130 apiece.
Anthuriums grown in China's Yunnan and Hainan provinces are not as good as flowers from Taiwan, which are superior in terms of the color and petal size, Chen said.

Chen's group, which produces 32 colors of anthuriums, has won major awards in local floral competitions, including a "triple crown championship" at a 2008 floral competition in Kaohsiung in which the group won in categories for red, green and pink flowers.

Although the most common color of anthuriums is red, Chen said he is proud of his recent development of a large white anthurium. At about 15 centimeters in diameter, the flowers have sold in Japan for more than NT$100 apiece.
His high-quality green anthurium, at about 17 cm in diameter, fetched over NT$140 on the Japanese market last year.
In addition to demand from Japan and China, Chen was approached recently by a trading company from Singapore that asked him to provide 20,000 flowers a month.
"I was afraid of not being able to meet their demand, so I didn't take the order," Chen said.
He also said that because of holidays such as Christmas and the Chinese New Year, business in Taiwan would soon be picking up.
Though he's unable to take lucrative new contracts at the moment, Chen said he wouldn't be averse to rearranging his orders after a few months.
"My contract with Japanese traders runs through the end of the year, " he said. "I told the Singaporeans that we could talk again on January 1st."
By Fanny Liu, CNA staff writer

DOC.HEADLINE: Flora Expo meets mixed reviews on first day of trial run

TEXT.P: Visitors to the Taipei International Flora Expo on the first day of a trial run gave it a "thumbs-up" Saturday despite complaints about the lack of benches and poor English translations in the 91.8-hectare exhibition grounds.

The expo opened its doors on Saturday morning for more than 5,000 volunteers, residents of two nearby districts, members of the press and invited guests from international schools in Taipei. The trial period will run for 20 days before the grand opening on Nov. 6.
Chang Chien-hua, 73, a long-time Taipei City resident who toured the park with her 83 year-old husband, said she was thrilled to visit the expo, which she had been anticipating for a long time.
"I have loved flowers all my life. Gorgeous flowers always put me in a good mood. I have been walking around the park for almost three hours and I still don't want to go home," she said with a smile.

Walking with the help of canes, however, the elderly couple complained about the lack of benches in the park and said the organizers should set up sitting areas so visitors can relax while enjoying the flowers.

A family of five visiting from South Africa also complained of the lack of rest areas in the park, and suggested covered spaces for people who want to take a breather while sheltered from the sun or rain.

Linda Kuys, a South African expatriate who has been to the Chelsea Flower Show in London, described the Taipei expo as "awesome, " but while giving kudos to the organizers on architectural designs and flower arrangements, she lamented the lack of English-language maps of the park.
The erroneous or "quirky" English translations in the park confused some English-speaking visitors.
For example, a sign that reads "Decoding Pavilion of New Fashion" left visitors from the Dominican International School baffled about the actual content of the pavilion.

One English speaker pointed out that the organizers wrote "tradition's flowers" instead of "traditional flowers, " and a sign reading "Multimate rial Fashions and Environment" left another visitor scratching her head.
Michael Lee, a Singapore-based Taiwanese businessman, said he was impressed by the size of the expo and the selection of flowers, but disappointed at the dullness of colors presented in the park.
"I was expecting to be visually stunned by lots of vibrant colors, but I didn't see that at all. The park is big, but there is not a whole lot of life to it," he said.
Two separate power outages also put an unwelcome kink in Saturday's trial opening.
Expo spokeswoman Ma Chien-hui said the organizing committee appreciated all comments from the fairgoers and hoped the feedback would keep coming ahead of the official kick-off early next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hosts meeting on bluefin tuna quota
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 9 (CNA) 10/09/10 16:40:54 (By Yang Shu-min and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: A six-day international meeting for the southern bluefin tuna industry began in Taipei Saturday, with participants expected to decide policy that will lead to a new total allowance catch (TAC) in 2012, the organizer said.

According to the Fisheries Agency under the Council of Agriculture, the most important mission of this year's meeting is to finalize a management procedure for the the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT) , a quota-setting body comprising Australia, Indonesia, Japan, New Zealand, South Korea and Taiwan.

The management procedure is scheduled to be finalized in 2010 for implementation in 2011. It will be the basis for setting the TAC beginning in 2012, the Canberra-based commission said on its website.
The CCSBT has agreed to reduce fishing of southern bluefin by an average of 20 percent this year and in 2011 from 11,810 metric tons to an average of 9,449 tons.

A total of 90 representatives from the six members of CCSBT, three cooperating non-members -- the Philippines, South Africa and the European Union -- and several non-profit organizations are participating in the meeting.
Participants will take part in a series of meetings from Oct. 9 to Oct. 14.
Annual southern bluefin catches reached 80,000 tons in the 1960s. The commission was set up in 1994 amid declining fish populations.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Don't deny people their civil rights

TEXT.P: The recent controversy surrounding the Ministry of the Interior's plan to introduce absentee voting in the 2012 presidential election highlighted the damage to a democratic society caused by extreme political confrontation.

According to the ministry's plan, people who do not live in their hometowns will be eligible to vote at a more convenient polling station. To reduce the chance of vote-rigging, the ministry decided to exclude citizens living overseas and not to adopt postal voting.

Even so, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has criticized the plan, saying it will facilitate vote buying by the ruling Kuomintang to secure President Ma Ying-jeou's re-election. The DPP's reaction demonstrates that it has become a party that "opposes habitually."

Absentee voting is an issue concerning the public's right to political participation, and partisan interests should carry little weight. The DPP, which hails human rights protection as one of its founding principles, has no reason to oppose the policy. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 9, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows to take responsibility for KMT's past
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 9 (CNA) 10/09/10 17:29:34 (By Garfie Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that he is willing to assume full responsibility for the mistakes committed by the Kuomintang (KMT) in Taiwan in the past, doing whatever it takes to dissolve hostilities.

"No matter what position I am in, I am willing to be held accountable for the past mistakes and suppression by the KMT rulers, such as the 228 Incident, " Ma said at the 10th National Prayer Breakfast ahead of the 99th founding anniversary of the Republic of China on Oct. 10.

The 228 Incident refers to an anti-government uprising that began in February 1947 and led to a brutal crackdown by the then-Kuomintang government, widely believed to have resulted in thousands of deaths.
"Justice must be served to heal the wounds, " said the president, who also serves as KMT chairman.
Over the past decade, Ma has repeatedly apologized for the White Terror -- a crackdown on advocates of communism, Taiwan independence and democratic reforms by the KMT in the 1950s and 1960s.
"I found that family members of many victims have shown a new attitude toward me and toward this country after my sincere apologies," he said.

National Security Council Secretary-General Hu Wei-jen, Control Yuan President Wang Chien-shien and Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin were also present at the annual event to pray for peace and prosperity for Taiwan and across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges Beijing to release Nobel-winning dissident
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 9 (CNA) 10/09/10 17:41:33 (By Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou urged Chinese authorities Saturday to release jailed human rights activist Liu Xiaobo, who was awarded the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize a day earlier.

"If Liu Xiaobo can regain freedom, I believe the Taiwanese people would very much appreciate China's move, " Ma said while addressing a gathering held in Taipei by the Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission for Taiwanese citizens returning for National Day celebrations.
Liu was awarded the prize by the Norwegian Nobel Committee "for his long and non-violent struggle for fundamental human rights in China."
Beijing, however, has called the decision a "desecration" of the peace prize.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kenyan racers dominate Kinmen marathon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 9 (CNA) 10/09/10 17:53:04 (By Ni Kuo-yen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Runners from Kenya won both the men's and women's events in a marathon on Saturday at a national park in the Taiwan-held outlying island of Kinmen off the southeastern coast of China.
Timothy Kibet Chelimo completed the men's full marathon in 2 hours, 24 minutes and 53 seconds to take the first prize.
Taiwan's Chiang Chieh-wen won the second prize by finishing the 42.195-kilometer race in 2: 25:26, while Ho Chih-hung of Taiwan came in third at 2:40:31.

In the women's full marathon event, Chelimo's compatriot Everline Nyamu Antancha grabbed the first prize by finishing the race in 2: 49: 48, followed by Taiwan's Chien Pei-yu at 3: 15: 22 and Tsao Chun-yu at 3:24:21.
It was the first time Chelimo and Antancha competed in a marathon in Taiwan. They each won NT$80,000 (US$2,580).

The Kinmen Round-the-Island Autumn Marathon, with 1,969 domestic and foreign racers, was part of a series of marathons organized by the Ministry of the Interior as part of celebrations for the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China in 2011.
The spring event took place in the Kenting National Park in Pingtung County, southern Taiwan on March 14 and the summer event was held on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei, northern Taiwan, on Aug. 7.
The last of the series is scheduled to take place in Taroko National Park in Hualien County, eastern Taiwan on Nov. 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: Job applicants carry sandbags in hopes of railway jobs

TEXT.P: More than 200 job applicants Saturday lugged 40 kilogram sandbags across a Taipei gym floor in the hopes of landing a job as track maintainer for the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) , a position considered promising amid an economic slump.

The TRA arranged the test to evaluate whether candidates would be able to carry heavy railroad ties and tracks on a regular basis. A total of 206 applicants who had already passed written tests vied for 134 openings with an entry-level salary of NT$33,000 (US$1,066) per month.
The applicants, nine of whom hold master's degrees, had to carry the 40 kg sandbags for 40 meters in 20 seconds or less.
Irene Lee, the only female applicant qualified for the physical test, burst into tears when she found out she passed with a time of 19.2 seconds.
Lee, wearing light make-up, said she didn't think she would succeed.
"I am not a sports person, " the 35-year-old said in a soft voice. "But I spent at least an hour a day weight training for the past month."
A contract worker with the TRA for almost 10 years, Lee said she wants to find a permanent job with a stable income.
The TRA has announced 868 job openings this year, drawing almost 70,000 applicants.
Taiwan's unemployment rate was 5.7 percent in August, and Premier Wu Den-yih has vowed to step down if the government fails to bring it under 5 percent by the end of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Specialist urges expo industry to prepare for virtual meetings

TEXT.P: The global exhibition and conference industry should prepare for the increasing use of virtual meetings as the industry recovers from the global recession, a specialist from Canada said at a forum in Taipei earlier this week.

Barbara Maple, the former president of the International Association of Congress Centres and now the head of a consultancy firm, said at a MICE (meeting, incentive, convention and exhibition) forum on Thursday that the industry had experienced many corporate meeting cancellations and delays in the past two years due to the global economy.

Although the world's economy is improving, the convention industry will face a threat from the continued use of virtual meetings to cut costs, and the industry should turn virtual meetings into "an added value," Maple said.
"Virtual meetings? Is this is a trend for future? It is certainly something much more available now, " she told the audience in a keynote speech.
She said Cisco Systems Inc. recently organized a successful virtual meeting for several thousand employees, sparking concern over the fate of face-to-face meetings.

"Some will be concerned in our industry whether people will continue to meet, continue to go to exhibitions because all this information is readily available over the Internet, " she said. "We need to know how to engage (virtual meetings) in our exhibitions and conferences, use them as an added value as opposed to an alternative to what we do."
Maple told the Central News Agency later in that day that meeting organizers should make virtual meetings part of their services for clients.

"We need to look at virtual meetings as an added value because you can incorporate them into your program, " she said. "So you can use it for attendees that maybe can't come to your exhibition. You can extend the value of that meeting broadly by creating a virtual meeting."
Maple also cited security as an issue that she said should not be seen as "regional" because everyone could suffer from global security concerns.

"Security right now is a concern in the United States because they have a direct threat against them. But I believe that people worldwide, when they hear about security, they start maybe (thinking) 'We won't travel, we won't go to such large exhibitions, '" she told CNA.

"So we globally need to think about that issue and try to look at security as a worldwide problem that we all need to deal with, even though it may be happening in one particular area right now, " she said.
Her remarks came after U.S. authorities recently warned American travelers in Europe of possible terrorist attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flora Expo's first trial day a success despite faults: mayor

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin on Saturday hailed the first trial day of the Taipei International Flora Expo as a smashing success despite several complaints reported by visitors.

Speaking at a press conference seven hours after the Yuanshan Park Area opened its doors for a selected audience, Hau thanked the visitors for their candid comments and asked for more feedback in the coming days.
"The goal of the trial period is to find as many faults as possible so we can resolve them before the grand opening on Nov. 6, and we were able to achieve that goal today," Hau said.
The expo began a 20-day trial period that runs until Oct. 28 in four phases, covering each of the four exhibition areas one at a time.

The organizing committee said the entire 91.8-hectare complex, which includes Yuanshan Park, Fine Arts Park, Xinsheng Park and Dajia Riverside Park, will be open to all visitors between Oct. 25 and Oct. 28.

Hau said the number of visitors to Yuanshan Park Saturday was over 9,350 by 3: 00 p.m., far surpassing the original plan of 5,000. Many people came without being invited, he said, blaming the media for giving out the wrong information.
Earlier reports had said residents of two neighboring districts were welcome on the first trial day, but Hau said organizers had not planned on them attending.
Organizing director Chen Wen-hsiung urged the public not to come to the expo uninvited until the last phase of the trial period.
Two of the major wrinkles on Saturday were traffic congestion on Minzu East and Minzu West roads, and two power outages in the morning.

Many visitors complained about the lack of rest areas in the park as well as insufficient garbage bins at the eatery area -- all of which Hau promised would be ironed out before the official commencement early next month.
The Taipei City Government is aiming to attract at least 8 million visitors to the six-month expo, which is being held in Taiwan for the first time.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges Beijing to release Nobel-winning dissident (update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 9 (CNA) 10/09/10 19:19:06 (By Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou urged Chinese authorities Saturday to release jailed human rights activist Liu Xiaobo, who was awarded the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize a day earlier.

"If Liu Xiaobo can regain freedom, I believe the Taiwanese people would very much appreciate China's move, " Ma said while addressing a gathering held in Taipei by the Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission for Taiwanese citizens returning for National Day celebrations.
Liu was awarded the prize by the Norwegian Nobel Committee "for his long and non-violent struggle for fundamental human rights in China."
Beijing, however, has called the committee's decision a "desecration" of the peace prize, saying that Liu is a criminal who was sentenced to prison for breaking Chinese law.

Liu was arrested in 2008 on charges of "inciting subversion of state power" for co-authoring Charter 08, a manifesto calling for free elections, greater freedom of expression and human rights. He was sentenced in 2009 to 11 years in prison.
Ma said China should release Liu to show benevolence toward its people, and should realize that freedom of speech is a very important foundation of modern society.
The president expressed hope that the Chinese leadership would fulfill its promise for political reforms because they would be "highly significant" to all Chinese people.

Over the past two years, Ma said, Taiwan has worked very hard to improve relations and seek closer economic cooperation with China. The government hopes that the two sides can also close gaps in other areas, such as freedom, democracy, human rights and the rule of law, he added.

In this sense, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, of which both Taiwan and China are signatories, can serve as a common ground on which to bring them together, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor groups protest alleged hiring of Chinese workers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 9 (CNA) 10/09/10 19:46:08 (By Lin Szu-yu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Local labor rights groups staged a demonstration in Taipei Saturday against what they said was the illegal import of Chinese laborers by electronics manufacturers in Taiwan.

According to the groups, the Chinese laborers were brought to Taiwan in the guise of highly skilled professionals, who are legally allowed to stay in Taiwan for extended periods, but had been discovered working in factories operated by Young Fast Optoelectronics Co, ASE Group and AU Optronics Corp.

Chu Cheng-chi, a spokesman for the protesters, said such illegal activities could be behind the sharp increase in Chinese business people and highly skilled professionals visiting Taiwan in recent years.

Citing statistics from the National Immigration Agency (NIA), Chu said 180,000 applications by Chinese business people and professionals to visit Taiwan were approved in 2009, up from 90,000 the previous year.
As of August this year, more than 160,000 such applications had been approved, with the total number expected to top 200,000 by the end of this year, Chu said.

He said the situation, if proven true, would run counter to the government's promise "not to open Taiwan to Chinese laborers," and he demanded that the NIA and the Council of Labor Affairs investigate the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most complaints about Internet involve pornography: NCC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 9 (CNA) 10/09/10 20:00:25 (By Huang Huei-ming and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The government has handled 729 complaints and criminal cases, mostly about online material deemed obscene, since opening a service for reporting inappropriate web content and online crimes, the National Communications Commission (NCC) said Saturday.
In a report, the commission said 54 percent of the complaints were about pornography, 19 percent about online crimes and 15 percent about inappropriate advertising content.
The NCC, the nation's top regulator of the communication service-sector, set up the online service on Aug. 2.

In the past two months, authorities removed or imposed restrictions on 234 websites that were reportedly involved in online crimes or carrying material deemed obscene or otherwise inappropriate, the NCC report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: South African explorer sails into Kaohsiung
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Oct. 9 (CNA) 10/09/10 20:48:21 (By S. F. Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: South African explorer Mike Horn sailed into Kaohsiung Harbor Saturday as part of a four-year journey that began in May 2008.

On the latest leg of his trip, Horn traveled aboard his expedition ship PANGAEA (Pan-Global Adventure for Environmental Action) from Shanghai via Hong Kong to the southern Taiwan port city, where he will stay a week.
Horn expressed keen interest in getting to know Kaohsiung and said he is willing to share his experience in expeditions or environmental activism with local young people.
The Kaohsiung City government will host a welcoming party for Horn Monday and show him the city's efforts to shift toward a low-carbon environment.
After Kaohsiung, the explorer will proceed to Russia, again via Shanghai.
Horn has in recent years explored dangerous lands around the globe, including trips to canoe in the Amazon rain forest, climb the Andes mountains and skateboard around the North Pole.

DOC.HEADLINE: Price cut for cross-strait flights voluntary: China Airlines

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest air carrier said Saturday that the decision to offer discounted cross-Taiwan Strait flights starting Sunday was voluntary and not a concession to government pressure.
China Airlines (CAL) told the Central News Agency that the cut was based on the company's steadily improving performance following the 2008 economic downturn.
"Since the first quarter of this year we have seen our revenue much higher than expected, " said company spokesman Hamilton Liu.
Acknowledging that cross-strait flights have played a major role in generating profits, Liu said the discount was initiated to pay back CAL customers.
Starting Sunday, the fare for popular CAL routes such as Songshan-Hongqiao and Taoyuan-Nanjing will fall to NT$9,500 (US$301) from NT$10,580 for roundtrip tickets with a stay of up to 14 days.
Currently, the carrier provides 61 roundtrip flights to 14 destinations in China every week.

The price cut comes amid public complaints that prices for direct cross-strait flights are excessively high. The government has said it cannot intervene, but launched what it called a "morality advice" campaign to persuade the carriers.
"We have discussed the issue with the carriers five times since early this year, " said Yeh Yung-ching, director of the air transport division of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA).
What the government could do, he said, was use its position as the company's biggest shareholder to urge the airline to lower fares, prompting other carriers to follow suit.
Two other major Taiwanese carriers, EVA Airways and TransAsia Airways, said earlier this month they will cut cross-strait ticket prices from Sunday and Oct. 26, respectively.

As demand for direct cross-strait flights still greatly exceeds supply, both carriers and the travel industry have said the best solution would be to allow more flights, letting the market adjust itself.
"We're limited to 370 flights a week, and you can't expect the fare to be desirable in that case, " said Spicer Lee, a spokesman for the Taipei Association of Travel Agents.
China and Taiwan agreed in May to add 100 new cross-strait direct flights to bring the total to 370.

DOC.HEADLINE: First Taiwanese-American NBA player makes preseason debut
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 9 (CNA) 10/09/10 21:44:50 (By Lee Yu-cheng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Jeremy Lin, the first Taiwanese-American player to sign with a National Basketball Association (NBA) team, made his debut appearance with the Golden State Warriors Saturday (Taiwan time) in a preseason warmup game.
Lin, who signed with the Warriors in August, played for about 11 minutes in the fourth quarter of the game in Oakland, California against the visiting Los Angeles Clippers.
The 21-year-old point guard finished with 7 points, three rebounds and two assists in his team's big win over the Clippers 127-87.
According to CBSSports.com reports, Lin "drew the largest cheers of the night" from more than 10,000 Warriors fans present.
U.S. sports columnist Andrew Bailey forecast recently that Lin
will be a fan favorite in the new NBA season because he grew up
in Northern California.

"Though he's unproven, I believe he'll be an adequate backup for (Stephen) Curry and will excite the crowd with every decent play he makes in Oakland, " Bailey wrote in a recent article posted on the Bleacher Report website.
Lin has already become a celebrity in Taiwan, a status cemented during a trip to Taipei in late July for a charity game featuring NBA players.
The July charity game was organized by Yao Ming, the first Chinese to play in the NBA and a seven-time NBA All-Star.
Lin will become the first Harvard graduate to play in the NBA in 57 years if he makes the Warriors final roster, which is considered highly likely.
