DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- President urges China to remove missiles soon

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Sunday used his Double Ten National Day address to call for China to remove its more than 1,000 missiles targeting Taiwan as early as possible.

"The mainland authorities have recently mentioned the possibility of removing missiles. We think it bears a positive significance for cross-strait ties and hope that it will become a reality as soon as possible," Ma said in his address.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

Ma was referring to remarks made by Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao in New York in late September. During a meeting with the media, Wen mentioned the possibility of the missile problem being resolved at some point.
Government sources said Ma deliberately used his National Day address to recognize Wen's statements as a positive development in cross-strait relations.
Ma was "delivering a message" to Chinese authorities, the sources said.

In his National Day speech at a rally in front of the Presidential Office, Ma stressed that Taiwan conducts cross-strait engagements "under the framework of the Republic of China (ROC) Constitution and on the basis of the '1992 consensus.'"

"Although at this stage the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can not accord de jure recognition to each other, we should nevertheless adopt a pragmatic policy of de facto ' mutual non-denial,'" Ma said.

Pointing out the common cultural origin shared by the people on the two sides of the strait, Ma called on China to "avoid antagonism" and to develop a "virtuous cycle of mutually beneficial, win-win interaction" with Taiwan. (Oct. 11, 2010).
China Times:
Ma said in his National Day address that cross-strait relations have improved significantly and tensions across the strait have eased substantially since he took office in May 2008.

He said, however, that Taiwan could not hinge its security solely on cross- strait detente, and that it is necessary for Taiwan to continue beefing up its defense capabilities by procuring advanced defensive weapons that the country cannot manufacture itself.

"We will also continue to boost multilevel cross-strait economic, cultural and social ties, building confidence and resolving differences, so as to maintain lasting peace across the Taiwan Strait," Ma said.
Stressing that the ROC is a sovereign state, Ma said the country hopes to expand cooperation with mainland China in the international sphere.

"Taiwan is a full democracy. Any agreement that we sign with the mainland must receive public support, and is subject to parliamentary supervision. At the same time, we will maintain the cross-strait status quo of 'no unification, no independence and no use of force' under the framework of the ROC Constitution, uphold the principle of putting Taiwan first for the benefit of its people, safeguard the Republic of China's sovereignty, and maintain Taiwan's dignity.

"In the future, we will continue to strengthen cooperation with all of our diplomatic partners as well as other nations, including the United States, Japan, countries in Southeast Asia, New Zealand, Australia and European Union member states. We will actively seek to participate in international organizations and their activities and, in the spirit of humanitarianism, provide aid to developing partner countries," Ma said in the address. (Oct. 11, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Shanghai Commercial and Savings Bank to open Vietnam branch
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 11 (CNA) 10/11/10 12:28:23 (By Kao Chao-fen and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Shanghai Commercial and Savings Bank said Monday it expects to open a branch in Vietnam by the end of this year.
The bank said it has obtained a green light from Vietnamese authorities to upgrade its representative office in Bien Hoa City, the capital of Dong Nai Province in southern Vietnam, into a branch.
The bank's Bien Hoa office was established in March 2006. It will become the bank's second overseas branch after its Hong Kong branch opened in June 2008.
"Dong Nai Province is Vietnam's industrial zone, where many Taiwanese investors have set up production facilities. We look forward to providing services to them," a bank spokeswoman said.

The bank said the Dong Nai branch will specialize in corporate banking services, providing Taiwanese firms there with deposit, remittance, currency exchange, trade financing and fund management services.
The spokeswoman said that the Dong Nai branch is expected to serve Taiwanese investors in Ho Chi Minh City and its neighboring Binh Duong Province.

Among the Taiwanese firms that operate in the Vietnamese province are Formosa Plastics Group, Tainan Spinning Co., Optical storage media firm Ritek Corp. and Cheng Shin Rubber Industry Co., according to the bank.
As of the end of August, Taiwan had invested a total of US$2.78 billion in Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: How could the DPP oppose absentee voting?

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior has outlined a plan to offer people not living in their hometowns a chance to cast their ballots in the 2012 presidential election, allowing them to vote at a polling station close to where they work, study or serve in the military.

It is a progressive measure that protects people's rights to political participation. Despite the fact the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) advocates democracy and progressiveness, it is against the plan, which it said was an attempt by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to "gather and control" military votes.

It is not a proper reason to oppose a system that can not just save millions of people the trouble and money needed to return to their hometowns to cast ballots, but also increase the public's political participation.

Why would the DPP oppose an absentee voting system that has been implemented in other advanced democratic countries for dozens of years? It is assumed that the party does not want more KMT supporters to have the opportunity to vote, while the DPP can only secure the votes of grassroots supporters who tend to stay in their hometowns.
It is pathetic for a political party to build its dream for power on restrictions against people's right to political participation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will continue to lead foundry business: UMC ex-chief
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 11 (CNA) 10/11/10 14:41:40 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Robert Tsao, the former chairman of United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) , said Monday that he expects Taiwan's technology lead in the global foundry business will not be swayed in the short term.

Tsao, who currently serves as UMC's honorary chairman, said that although Taiwan faces fierce competition from South Korea's Samsung Electronics and U.S.-based GlobalFoundries, Taiwan's better product quality and higher production efficiency will help it maintain the lead.
Market analysts said Samsung and GlobalFoundries are making massive investments this year in an attempt to challenge UMC and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC).
"Production quality and efficiency are the most important factors in the global foundry business, " Tsao said in an interview with the Central News Agency.
"The money to expand production capacity is not the only decisive factor. I do not think Taiwan's status will be easily challenged in the short term," Tsao said.
TSMC and UMC are the top two contract chip makers in the world.
Samsung's capital expenditure for 2010 is expected to total 1.8 trillion South Korean won (US$1.59 billion) , 1.1 trillion won of which will be used for semiconductor production.
For its part, GlobalFoundries is investing US$2.7 billion in capital expenditure for 2010.

Tsao said that GlobalFoundries will largely expand its production capacity in the U.S., rather than in its Asian complex in Singapore, and that he doubts the U.S. production facilities will be efficient enough to compete with Taiwan.

Riding a recovery in the global high-tech sector, TSMC has raised its 2010 capacity expenditure to US$5.9 billion from US$4.8 billion, while UMC has hiked its spending to US$1.8 billion from the previous range of US$1.2 billion to US$1.5 billion.
Meanwhile, Tsao said Taiwan's foundry sector should pay more attention to technology innovation.
Only innovation to upgrade production technology will boost profit margins as the foundry business encounters rising pressure on its bottom line to cut prices, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan moves to reduce national debt accumulation: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 11 (CNA) 10/11/10 15:28:09 (By Kelven Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The government has listed a budget of NT$66 billion (US$2.15 billion) to repay some of the national debt next year, more than the minimum debt repayment requirement, which is estimated at NT$57.6 billion for 2011, the minister of finance said Monday.

The move shows "the government's determination to reduce the degree of state debt accumulation, " said Lee Sush-der. The minimum debt payment requirement is based on the criteria of 5 percent of the annual tax revenues paid to the government, which is estimated at NT$1.16 trillion for 2011.
In a report on the general budget plan for 2011 at the Legislative Yuan, Lee told lawmakers that the NT$66 billion will all be used to repay the debt principal.
Lee noted that in the 2011 budget plan, government borrowing has been limited to a total of NT$225 billion to fund the general budget, less than the liability ceiling of NT$268.4 billion.

An additional NT$204 billion will be raised to finance next year's special budgets for flood control and other infrastructure projects, bringing the total national debt to an estimated NT$4.96 trillion in 2011.
The amount is still within the debt allowance of 40 percent of the mean of the Gross National Products in 2010, 2009 and 2008, Lee said.

Also at the Legislative Yuan, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairwoman Christina Liu reported that the council has listed the special budget for public construction projects in 2011 at NT$159.74 billion.
The projects are expected to increase the Gross Domestic Product next year by 0.88 percent and create 51,000-64,000 jobs, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 0.81 percent in thin trade

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 0.81 percent Monday in thin trade as investors took profits, eroding early gains despite the strong end of last week on Wall Street, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 67.43 points to 8,176.76, after moving between 8,165.20 and 8,277.78, on turnover of NT$95.85 billion (US$3.11 billion).

The market opened up 0.41 percent and reached the day's high on the back of Wall Street's gains, but pressure emerged to reverse the upside after the index moved near technical resistance at around 8,300 points, dealers said.
A total of 2,713 stocks closed down and 1,053 up, with 273 stocks remaining unchanged.

The construction sector suffered the heaviest selling, down 2.19 percent. Cement stocks lost 1.51 percent, plastics and chemical shares fell 1.2 percent, financials shed 1.14 percent, and paper and pulp stocks closed down 0.9 percent.
The foodstuff sector fell 0.82 percent and the machinery and electronics sector dropped 0.49 percent, while the textile sector rose 0.4 percent.

"The reduced turnover showed many investors preferred to keep cash at the moment, waiting for incentives to trade after recent strong gains, " said Mega Securities analyst Alex Huang, referring to upcoming third quarter corporate earnings reports in the U.S. and in Taiwan.

"Although Wall Street stood above the key 11,000 point level Friday, investors remained cautious about the global economic climate," Huang said. "Rising fears about a major pullback in the U.S. market have discouraged investors here to buy at the moment."
Huang said that the technical hurdles remained high ahead of 8,300 points, adding that the relatively small trading volume recently has made it hard for the market to overcome the barriers.
In the construction sector, Prince Housing lost 3.80 percent to NT$24.05 and Kindom Construction fell 3.18 percent to NT$27.40.
Among high-tech stocks, flat panel maker AU Optronics closed down 1.30 percent at NT$30.30 and rival Chimei Innolux fell 2.43 percent to NT$40.05.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese designers to take part in Shanghai fair
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 11 (CNA) 10/11/10 15:57:39 (By Mai-lan Kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Eleven Taiwanese design firms are scheduled to take part in Interior Lifestyle China -- one of the country's leading consumer goods fairs -- slated to take place Oct. 13-16 in Shanghai, the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) said Monday.

Under the banner of "Bravo Taiwan, " the CCA-organized group will display the cream of the latest products from Taiwan's cultural and creative industry at the show, said Hung Shih-fang, a CCA official who will lead the delegation.

Taiwan will operate a 56-square-meter pavilion at the exhibition, displaying the latest designs in areas including ceramics, lighting, furniture and interior decor, with a theme of "oriental chic, " Hung said.

The CCA organized a similar group that attended September's 100% Design London -- one of the world's most important contemporary interior design exhibitions -- where the designers won high acclaim for their products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Economic growth will not spawn democracy in China

TEXT.P: Western countries have long been hoping that China's phenomenal economic growth over the past three decades will lead to the development of Western-style democracy in that country.

Beijing's hysterical reaction to the Norwegian Nobel Committee's decision to award the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize to imprisoned Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo, however, has proved that such an assumption could be wishful thinking and hopelessly unrealistic.

When China began its "reform and opening" measures in 1978, its leaders clearly stated that they would adhere to the tenets of "socialism with Chinese characteristics, " while easing some restrictions in the economic field as part of efforts to transform the country's stagnant, impoverished planned economy into a market economy capable of generating strong economic growth.

Banking on Western technology, capital and market economy concepts, China has emerged as a new economic powerhouse. However, it has not made any of the political progress hoped for by Western countries.

Ever since the communist leadership sent in the military to crush the Tiananmen Square democracy movement in 1989, setting back the regime's relations with its people, the Chinese government has merely been trying to promote nationalism as a unifier rather than making any positive responses to calls for political reform.

The house arrest of the reform-minded late Chinese Premier Zhao Ziyang and the imprisonment of Liu Xiaobo and other pro-democracy activists should serve as wake-up call for those who harbor unrealistic expectations about China's democratization. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 11, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Three Taipei electronics trade shows open together

TEXT.P: Three trade shows highlighting electronics and communication technologies opened in Taipei Monday and are expected to attract more than 70,000 visitors, organizers said.

The 36th Taipei International Electronics Show (Taitronics), the fourth Taiwan International RFID Applications Show and the third Broadband Taiwan will feature a total of 800 local and foreign exhibitors, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said in a statement.

This year marks the second time the three shows will be held together, after a similar arrangement in 2008. They run from Oct. 11-14, with Oct. 11-12 reserved for professionals only. The fairs will open to the public on Oct. 13-14.

Wayne Wu, vice chairman of the semi-official TAITRA, said that Taiwan ranked sixth globally and second in Asia in a study on competitiveness in green technologies. The study was released in July by the International Institute for Management Development in Lausanne, Switzerland.

Wu said the organizers also invited dozens of international buyers that each have an annual business volume exceeding US$50 million, including companies from Japan, the United States, Canada, Brazil, Mexico and Ukraine, to help Taiwanese vendors increase their exports.
The total output of Taiwan's electronics industry amounted to US$177.3 billion in 2009, with two-thirds of the amount coming from key components like wafer processing.
The Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association, the organizer of Taitronics, said the exhibition will include special areas highlighting green power and energy-saving technologies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shulin City Office releases chronicles
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 11 (CNA) 10/11/10 17:59:26 (By Huang Hsu-shen and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The Shulin City Office has released a new edition of the city chronicles to remember the past and preserve local culture before it becomes a district of the Xinbei City special municipality in December, a county official said Monday.

The chronicles record the city's history, which dates back to the Ming dynasty, when the pirate-merchant Zheng Chenggong, better known as Koxinga, came to power in Taiwan, said Shulin Mayor Chen Shih-jung.
Chen said that in addition to history, the chronicles also have entries in other categories including geography, politics, economics, development, education, culture, religion and people.

The Shulin City Office has spent nearly two years editing the chronicles and gathering precious historical photos of aspects of city life such as coal mining and wine making, which were the city's major industries in the past, Chen said.

The city's famous sons noted in the chronicles include Sung Ching-hung, who has been coaching taekwondo for more than 28 years and his son Sung Yu-ling, who won a bronze medal at the 2008 Olympic Games. Huang Chih-hsiung, a student of Sung who won two medals in the 2004 and 2000 Summer Olympics, is also listed.
The city office said a total of 2,000 copies of the chronicles will be distributed to local schools, government organizations and libraries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: CBC should explain exchange rate policy

TEXT.P: With its huge foreign exchange reserves, the Central Bank of the Republic of China (CBC) has managed to make the New Taiwan dollar's value close at below NT$31 against the greenback, no matter how high it had appreciated during the daily trading amid growing hot money inflow over the past week.

The central bank's repeated late-session interventions seem to prove the existence of the so-called "Perng Fai-nan barrier, " which means the CBC will do whatever it can to prevent the local currency's exchange rate from surging past the NT$31 to the U.S. dollar level projected by CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan.

The CBC's market operations have made it difficult for local commercial banks to determine their currency exchange rates at the opening of daily trading because the closing rate no longer reflects the average level of the New Taiwan dollar's exchange rates against the greenback in the previous trading session.

More worrisome is that the CBC's action might prove ineffective in stabilizing the local unit's exchange rate amid the current global liquidity overflows fueled by the U.S. Fed's and the European Central Bank's quantitative easing of their monetary policies.
The central bank should now explain the significance and necessity of upholding the "Perng Fai-nan barrier" if it wants to win more support and trust for its currency policy.

The central bank's priority for the moment should be seeking cooperation with other major Asian countries to adopt joint strategies against a looming currency war ignited by Western countries rather than safeguarding the "Perng Fai-nan barrier" at all costs. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 11, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Monday, dropping NT$0.097 to close at NT$30.998, its lowest level since March 26, 2008.
Turnover totaled US$732 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.095 and moved to a low of NT$30.645 before rebounding.
Dealers said the central bank appeared to have abandoned its recent efforts to maintain the U.S. dollar at a level of above NT$31.000.

They said the market is expecting the U.S. Federal Reserve Board to cut interest rates to stimulate the economy in its November policy making meeting after the country's September jobless rate pointed to a sluggish economic climate.
They added that once the Fed further loosens its monetary policy, the greenback is expected to fall further against the euro and Asian currencies.

A weaker U.S. dollar has become a trend that will be difficult to reverse for the moment, the dealers said, adding that this could be the reason why the central bank changed its mind about keeping the greenback above NT$31.000.
U.S. dollar forex selling was done largely by foreign banks after they witnessed most Asian currencies appreciating against the greenback, the dealers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese vessel 'Feng Guo 168' confirmed safe: MOFA

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese fishing vessel suspected of being hijacked in the Indian Ocean near Mauritius has been confirmed safe, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Monday.

The "Feng Guo 168" has not been seized and arrived in the Mauritius capital Port Louis on Sunday afternoon with all 14 crew members confirmed safe, said Samuel Chen, director-general of the Department of African Affairs under the ministry.

"It was misidentified as a piracy case at first because the vessel's sailing course was strange. There were probably some quarrels between the captain and the crew, " Chen said of the boat with a Taiwanese captain, eight Vietnamese, two Indonesians and three Chinese on board. The vessel headed south to Mauritius after sailing north toward Somali waters.
The crew members contacted their families and the boat owner after reaching Port Louis, Chen said.

The ministry said it was informed by the Council of Agriculture's Fishery Agency at noon on Oct. 6 that the fishing boat, which is registered in the southern port of Tungkang, Pingtung County, could have been hijacked in the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) of Mauritius.
The case was reported as the most southerly hijacking case by Somali pirates since the European Union's anti-piracy mission began in December 2008.

The European Union Naval Forces Somalia, which was established to fight Somali piracy, protect vessels and monitor fishing activities off the coast of Somalia, had reported the boat as safe Oct. 8 after sending out a false report the previous day saying the vessel had been hijacked.
MOFA spokesman James Chang said on the same day that the ministry was still unsure whether the boat had been hijacked by pirates or its own crew.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese delegates to visit Taiwan for cruise liner talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 11 (CNA) 10/11/10 19:28:29 (By Wang Shu-fen and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: More than 1,000 members of the China Ports Association will arrive in Taiwan aboard a cruise liner sailing direct from China for talks on cross-Taiwan Strait cruise liner transport, according to a statement released Monday by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
The 1,300 delegates are scheduled to arrive Oct. 13 in the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung from Xiamen in China's Fujian Province aboard the Costa Romantica cruise vessel.
They are mostly representatives of port operators from Shanghai, Nanjing, Ningbo, and Wuhan on China's east coast, the ministry added.

The delegates, along with the directors-general of Kaohsiung, Taichung, Keelung and Hualien harbors, will attend an Oct. 15 forum for discussions -- the first of their kind -- of issues regarding cross-strait voyages by cruise ships.

Currently, cross-strait direct sea transport is only open to companies that register on both sides, along with certain vessels flying flags of convenience that already sail between offshore shipping centers in China and Taiwan, according to the MOTC.
Direct transport links between Taiwan and China only resumed in 2008 after a ban of more than 50 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: GTSM, HKEx sign cooperation accord
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 11 (CNA) 10/11/10 19:48:29 (By Han Ting-ting and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The GreTai Securities Market (GTSM) , Taiwan's over-the-counter market, said Monday that it had signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Hong Kong Exchange and Clearing Ltd. (HKEx) on future cooperation.

GTSM Chairman Gordon Chen inked the agreement with HKEx Chief Executive Charles Li in Paris a day earlier during the 50th annual meeting of the World Federation of Exchanges (WFE) , of which both exchanges are members.

It became the third cooperation MOU the GTSM had signed with a foreign exchange so far this year after a similar agreement with Bursa Malaysia secured in March and another accord inked with the Hanoi Stock Exchange in July.
Under the terms of the latest agreement, GTSM and HKEx will develop a long-term cooperation mechanism for future information exchanges and mutual visits by officials of both sides.
The two sides aim to enhance the transparency of trading information on each side for the benefit of investors, the GTSM said in a statement.

GTSM said Taiwan and Hong Kong already have close ties in financial exchanges, and with the Chinese market continuing with opening measures, the two exchanges are expected to work together even more closely to seize the growing business opportunities in the Greater China market.
It added that the cooperation is also expected to enhance GTSM's international visibility.
So far, the GTSM has signed similar MOUs with a total of 10 foreign exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP inaugurates Taiwan cloud computing pavilion at electronics expo
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 11 (CNA) 10/11/10 19:52:44 (By Jeff Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew inaugurated the Taiwan Cloud Computing Pavilion at the Taitronics 2010 trade fair Monday in a show of the government's resolve to accelerate the development of cloud computing, which is revolutionizing the information technology (IT) industry.
It is the first time an exhibition pavilion has been devoted exclusively to cloud computing at any IT trade fairs that have taken place in Taiwan.

A total of 40 companies are displaying their technology, products and applications related to cloud computing at the pavilion, part of Taitronics 2010, which opened that day at the Taipei World Trade Center's Nangang Exhibition Hall for a four-day run.

The fair serves to show that cloud computing technology not only makes people's electronic lives more convenient and efficient but also integrates up- mid- and down-stream sectors of the industry to create an industrial clustering effect, said Chunghwa Telecom Co. Chairman Lu Shyue-ching, who doubles as chairman of the Taiwan Cloud Computing Consortium (TCCC), one of the key sponsors of the fair.
"Application services, including hardware, servers and storage, will play a pivotal role in the development process of the cloud computing industry," Lu said at the inauguration ceremony.
Cloud computing, which refers to outsourcing online data storage and applications, effectively lowers companies' operating costs and reduces systematic risk, according to Lu.

Cloud computing provides "highly available" services and data stored on an Internet network (the cloud) that users can access with devices such as desktop PCs, TVs and smart phones connected to the Web, with the advantage that users do not have to install or maintain these services on their devices.

A cloud computing environment provides its users with a distributed computing environment that can handle a massive amount of data and file sharing. It is expected to become the preferred solution in an era of rapid industrial development, experts believe.

Cloud computing is also among the four innovative and strategic industries that the government has spared no efforts to develop. The government and the private sector jointly formed the TCCC in April in a bid to grab a share of the growing market.
The two sides plan to pour NT$24 billion (US$774 million) over the next five years into the development of the cloud computing industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to close land tax loophole used by private developers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 11 (CNA) 10/11/10 20:01:06 (By Lin Yi-fen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The government's plan to limit tax restrictions and exemptions on idle privately held plots of land merely involves closing a tax loophole rather than imposing an "idle land tax" as reported, Deputy Minister of Finance Chang Sheng-ford said Monday.

News reports indicated that the government was trying to levy an "idle land tax" to curb the hoarding of property for resale when land values rise and keep a lid on real estate prices, a measure that has been supported by some property experts.
Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der may have added to the confusion Monday morning at a legislative hearing when asked about the government's plan and the possibility of imposing an idle land tax.
"The narrowing of the land area and definition of tax-exempt land will have the same effect as an 'idle land tax,'" he said.

But Chang later responded that under the new plan, privately held land that has in the past been given tax-exempt status because it provides free access to the public, such as landscaped grounds of properties still waiting to be developed, would once again be subject to the land value tax beginning in 2011.
Only land used as roads or public passageways will continue to be tax exempt, he confirmed.

"In the past, the ministry has allowed many parcels of private land used at no charge by the public to be exempted from taxation. But the preferential treatment has been abused, " he said, necessitating a revision of Taiwan's tax regulations.

Many developers who are sitting on idle land, hoping that its value will rise, have landscaped the plots to avoid having to pay the land value tax, assessed at 1 percent or higher of the land's publicly appraised value.
Chang said the revisions will also fulfill one of the resolutions passed by the Executive Yuan Tax Reform Commission last year that called for amending land tax regulations to broaden the tax base.

He said closing existing loopholes did not amount to levying an "idle land tax, " which would be actually be imposed as a punitive surcharge on the land value tax of a property classified as being for development but not used for that purpose.

DOC.HEADLINE: Red wine makes blood vessels healthier: study

TEXT.P: A study conducted by a Taiwanese hospital has shown that drinking a moderate amount of red wine daily could potentially lower the risk of cardiovascular disease by helping give a boost to cells that repair blood vessels.

A cardiovascular team from Taipei Veterans General Hospital came to the conclusion based on a study that investigated the effect of red wine on endothelial progenitor cells (EPC) , rare cells with the ability to repair damage to blood vessel walls, representatives of the team said at a news conference Monday.

In the study, 80 healthy adult volunteers aged 20 to 40 were divided into four groups, with members of three groups consuming a different alcoholic beverage -- 100 cc of French red wine, 250 cc of beer, or 30 cc of vodka -- and one control group drinking nonalcoholic beverages for three consecutive weeks.

"We discovered that the volume of EPC multiplies after the moderate drinking of red wine, " said Huang Po-hsun, an attending physician involved in the study, suggesting a positive correlation between red wine and repairing injured blood vessels.
Asked whether patients should adopt the habit of drinking red wine, Chen Jaw- wen, a cardiologist at the hospital, was not sure.
"Since the study was done on healthy human beings, we cannot say whether it is equally effective on unhealthy people," Chen said.
In terms of prevention and health care, moderate red wine consumption can make blood vessels healthier, Chen said, but he also warned that excessive drinking could hurt body organs.

Huang said that daily consumption of beverages containing 10 percent alcohol should not exceed 30 cc per day, and individuals with cirrhosis and other chronic diseases should be especially careful about their drinking habits.

Citing another study, the Bureau of Health Promotion also warned that while a small amount of wine consumption could lower the risk of coronary artery diseases, excessive drinking could lead to many other health problems.

The study cited by the bureau found that the risk of a person drinking 250 cc of red wine daily is 1.9 times and 2.9 times at risk of getting oropharyngeal cancer and cirrhosis, respectively, than those who never drink.

Red wine has been widely touted as having beneficial medical properties and attributed by some as the explanation for the French paradox -- the fact that the French have a diet heavy in saturated fats but have a lower incidence of cardiovascular disease.
Other studies, however, have been unable to establish a verifiable link between red wine and improved cardiovascular health.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan developing unmanned aircraft: defense minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 11 (CNA) 10/11/10 20:04:15 (By Su Lung-chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has not put a U.S.-built unmanned aerial vehicle, the RQ-4 Global Hawk, on its arms procurement list, opting instead to have its military-run research institute develop an indigenous unmanned aircraft system, a defense official said Monday.

"The Air Force has identified the need to acquire unmanned aircraft, but has not included the U.S.-built reconnaissance aircraft system on its arms procurement list, " Minister of National Defense Kao Hua-chu said at a Legislative Yuan session.
The minister said the military-run Chung-Shan Institute of Science and Technology is already researching and developing the unmanned surveillance aircraft system.

He made the remarks following a report in the Taipei-based China Times daily that same day that Japan has come up with an RQ-4 Global Hawk procurement plan after the U.S. military formally stationed the aircraft in Guam last month.

The paper also quoted unidentified military sources as saying that the Air Force is conducting an assessment on whether to follow suit and that it will put both F-16C/D jet fighters and the RQ-4 Global Hawk on its priority procurement list.

Asked for his views on the report by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lo Ming-Tsai, Kao said Taiwan has been developing unmanned aerial vehicle for quite some time, with the Chung-Shan institute leading the effort.
The minister also said that it remains unclear whether the United States will agree to sell Japan the advanced RQ-4 Global Hawks.
According to Kao, the Ministry of National Defense's 2011 arms procurement budget will mainly be used to finance items that the U.S. has already agreed to sell to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Idle land tax' speculation weighs down construction shares
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 11 (CNA) 10/11/10 20:17:22 (By Wei Shu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Construction shares faced heavy pressure Monday after reports emerged that the government plans to impose a special tax on privately owned land left idle without any plan for immediate development, dealers said.
Construction stocks closed down 2.19 percent, while the benchmark weighted index fell 0.81 percent to 8,176.76.
Cathay Real Estate fell 3.02 percent to NT$17.65, Kindom Construction shed 3.18 percent to NT$24.05 and Prince Housing shed 3.80 percent to NT$24.05.
Media reports on Monday hinted that the government would impose a land value tax (an annual tax on land holdings) that would actually serve as an "idle land tax" to curb property speculation.
Developers have hoarded many prime lots of land in recent years without developing them, waiting for land prices to rise before selling them for a hefty profit.

This is one of the factors driving up property prices, especially in the Greater Taipei area, and the rumored tax was said to be part of a government strategy to put a lid on such practices, scaring investors.

After the reports surfaced, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) clarified that the planned tax adjustment would only be to narrow the scope of land value tax reductions and exemptions on privately owned land used by the general public.
Many developers currently receive land value tax exemptions when they landscape idle land holdings and give the public access to them.

But under the new plan, only private land used for roads or other passage without payment will receive preferential tax status, while companies "greening" their land and opening it to the public will have to pay land value tax beginning next year, the MOF said.

"Despite the clarification, the first idea that came to investors' minds was that the government would tighten measures to cap high flying property prices, " Hua Nan Securities analyst Henry Miao said.

Miao said the construction sector had recently staged a strong showing on a rising Taiwan dollar against the U.S. dollar on hopes that a higher local currency would boost asset prices in the domestic market.

"Regardless of whether investors misunderstood the MOF's plan or intentionally interpreted the plan as a measure to cap property prices, it was time for investors to pocket the recent significant gains," Miao said.
Miao said rapidly rising property prices in the local market have drawn complaints from the public, and he expected that the government would not sit back to allow the situation to get worse.
A recent indication of that was the central bank's 0.125 percentage point rate hike on Sept. 30, which followed a rate boost in late June.
"Investors should stay on the sidelines before adding property holdings to closely watch what further measures the government will come up with to deal with the local property market," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's largest luxury watch retailer buys bank property

TEXT.P: Hengdeli Holdings, China's largest luxury watch retailer, won an auction Monday to buy a bank property in one of Taipei's busiest shopping areas, a move seen as an attempt to capitalize on Taiwan's future opening to individual Chinese tourists.

Hengdeli's Taiwan branch acquired the 161.68-ping (534.4 square meters) property on Zhongxiao East Road from Taiwan-based EnTie Commercial Bank with a bid of NT$900 million (US$29.3 million) , or NT$5.56 million per ping.
The winning bid was well above the auction's floor price of NT$727 million.
Under the deal, however, EnTie will be able to continue to rent the property for 18 months after the transaction at a rate of NT$720,000 per month.

The rental income will give Hengdeli a rate of return of 0.96 percent, one of the lowest in the bustling shopping area where the average rate of return is closer to 2 percent, said Jessica Hsu, a spokeswoman for real estate brokerage firm H&B Business Group.
Hsu believes the acquisition indicates that Hengdeli plans to expand its presence in Taiwan before the country opens its doors to individual Chinese tourists, which is expected to happen next year.
At present, Chinese travelers can only visit Taiwan in groups.
Hengdeli has opened at least four outlets in northern and southern Taiwan.

Bright Lee, spokesman for real estate agency Evertrust Rehouse Co., said that Hengdeli had been looking to buy a new property since last year to cash in on an expected surge in the number of Chinese tourists in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Plans for all-volunteer military hit snags

TEXT.P: Legislation and funding are crucial if Taiwan is to realize its goal of implementing a completely volunteer-manned military service system by 2014, the premier said Monday.

The volunteer military -- pledged by President Ma Ying-jeou during his 2008 presidential election campaign -- will change the existing military system, which consists of voluntary service and conscription, to a completely voluntary program.

It is "extremely difficult" to turn a civilian into a professional soldier in the current one-year conscription period, which is why an all- volunteer system is the right track, Premier Wu Den-yih said in an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

Wu said the system will only be successful if the Ministry of National Defense (MND) secures sufficient funding and is able to train elite soldiers, to maximize military capability with minimum personnel.

Meanwhile, National Defense Minister Kao Hua-chu said an amendment to the Act of Military Service System will also be necessary if the plan is to advance. He added that the new system would still require males of conscription age to go through four months of basic military training.

Funding appears to be the most serious problem for the new program. In March, the MND's Department of Manpower estimated that the volunteer military service system will increase personnel costs by NT$210 million (US$6.81 million) for every 10,000 servicemen.
Taiwan's 2011 military budget accounts for only 2.6 percent of its national gross domestic production, according to the Executive Yuan.
According to a Control Yuan report in 2008, the MND had planned to cut its military personnel from 275,000 to 215,000.
Last month, Kao told a legislative session that the progress of the program has fallen behind schedule because of recruiting difficulties and insufficient funding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to push inexpensive quality products in ASEAN market
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 10 (CNA) 10/11/10 21:52:54 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will promote mid-priced, high quality consumer products in Southeast Asia, where interest in such items has grown substantially over the past year, a Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) official said Monday.

TAITRA Deputy Chairman Wayne W. Wu, who led a Taiwan trade delegation to Indonesia, Malaysia and Vietnam in late September and early October, said made- in-Taiwan products have enjoyed increasing popularity in those markets because of their good quality and reasonable prices.

Taiwan-made items, from green products, innovative housewares, and information technology goods, to auto parts, hardware, construction materials and health foods, are more competitive in terms of both quality and price in ASEAN markets than similar goods from Japan, Europe and the United States, Wu said.
After the 2008-2009 global economic meltdown, the number of middle class consumers, who generally seek luxury or novelty items at affordable prices, has risen in Southeast Asian nations, he said.

In addition, consumers from the younger generation make up nearly half of the populations of these countries, forming a strong consumer base that Taiwanese exporters and manufacturers should tap into, he added.

Wu told the Central News Agency that the just-concluded trade promotion tour had paid dividends, with Pasaraya, one of the biggest department stores in Jakarta, deciding to devote a section of its store exclusively to Taiwanese cosmetics and beauty products.
Meanwhile, the owner of Taipei-based Aplus Integrated Circuits Inc. said his company would work to explore possibilities related to Koran chanting in the Muslim country.

Kuo Shan-tsan, chairman and CEO of Aplus, a maker of datasheets and voice chips, told the Central News Agency that a majority of Indonesia's 240 million population are mostly Muslims, who pray five times a day chanting verses from the Koran from mosques or their homes in the direction of Mecca.
A handy electronic Koran chanting device the size of a business card developed by Aplus could find success there, Kuo said.
"It would be a US$100 million business if some 10 million Indonesians buy one," he envisioned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top human rights committee to become operational on Dec. 10
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 11 (CNA) 10/11/10 22:01:05 (By Shu-hua Lee and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A human rights committee will be established under the Presidential Office as one of the means to raise the level of human rights in Taiwan, a five-man panel headed by President Ma Ying-jeou announced Monday.

The task force, to be named the Human Rights Consultative Committee under the Office of the President, will become operational on Dec. 10, the day the world observes International Human Rights Day, said Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang.
After a meeting at the Presidential Office, the five-man group made the decision, reaffirming what President Ma proposed the day before during his National Day address, Lo said.

The four other members of the five-man group backing the idea were Vice President Vincent Siew, Premier Wu Den-yih, Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman Chan Chuen-po. President Ma doubles as the KMT chairman.

Siew will serve as the convener of the committee, to be comprised of both public officials and private citizens who will discuss and develop human rights policies and issue regular human rights reports to raise the level of human rights in Taiwan, the president said Sunday.
All of the committee members will serve without pay, Lo said.

The five-man group determined that similar human rights committees will also be established in all Cabinet-level offices and departments, and local governments around the country are also welcome to establish such a committee, according to Lo.

DOC.HEADLINE: Germany, Taiwan launch working holiday program

TEXT.P: Germany became the fifth country to sign a working holiday program with Taiwan when representatives from Germany and Taiwan completed the signing of a joint statement Monday in Taipei, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said in a statement.

According to the statement, Birgitt Ory, director of the German Institute Taipei, signed the joint statement Monday while Wei Wu-lien, representative of Taiwan's office in Germany, signed the statement Sept. 28.

Under the joint statement that took effect immediately, people aged 18-30 from Germany and Taiwan can travel and work in each other's territory for up to one year. Each side has offered a quota of 200 multiple entry visas in the first year of the program.
Taiwan also has working holiday agreements with Australia, New Zealand, Japan and Canada.
Last year, more than 12,000 Taiwanese youths took part in the program, with more than 9,000 going to Australia, which has not set a quota for Taiwanese participants.
Canada has a quota of 700, up from the original 200 due to the popularity of the program, and Japan has a quota of 2,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: President defends timing of call for release of dissident
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 11 (CNA) 10/11/10 22:47:58 (By S.H. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that his stance on human rights issues has been consistent, as he defended making his call for Beijing to free jailed dissident Liu Xiaobo a day after Liu was named this year's Nobel Peace Prize winner.

"As head of state of the Republic of China, I have long been consistent in safeguarding human rights and have always urged China to treat dissidents with greater leniency, " Ma was quoted as saying by Su Jun-pin, head of the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) Culture and Communications Committee, after the ruling party's monthly meeting.

According to Su, Ma also showed a copy of his June 4 statement marking the June 4, 1989 Tiananmen Massacre to prove that he had repeatedly asked Beijing to deal with political dissidents more leniently.

Ma's move to clarify his stance on China's human rights conditions came after the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) criticized him for not urging Beijing to free Liu immediately after Liu was announced as the winner of the award Friday evening.

Ma said he issued a statement congratulating Liu after learning the news. But he did not call for Liu's release until Oct. 9 during a gathering ahead of the country's National Day on Sunday, drawing the opposition's condemnation.
Apart from asking China to set Liu free, Ma said he also made other concrete proposals to Beijing that included asking it to launch political reform and sign international human rights conventions.
"My logic has been consistent in my position on human rights. There's no problem of a fast or slow response as some have charged, "Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HTC unveils five new Microsoft smartphones

TEXT.P: Taiwan's HTC Corp. unveiled on Monday five new smartphones that run on Microsoft's new operating system, hoping to help the U.S. software giant regain some of its dwindling share of the global smartphone operating system market.

HTC, the world's largest maker of smartphones using Google and Microsoft operating systems, said in a statement that these new smartphones -- HTC 7 Surround, HTC 7 Mozart, HTC 7 Trophy, HTC 7 Pro and HTC HD7 -- will be available in markets in North America, Europe and the Asia Pacific region from late October.
Microsoft's new operating system for smartphone is called "Windows Phone 7," "on which HTC is excited to be going big," HTC CEO Peter Chou said.

Microsoft has been losing operating system market share to Google's Android operating system, having seen its 9 percent share a year ago fall to 5 percent today, according to market research firm Gartner.
During that same period, the Android system's share has grown from 2 percent to 17 percent.

HTC, which has partnered with Microsoft for nearly 10 years and produced the first smartphone with Microsoft's mobile platform in 2002, is now the world's fourth-largest smartphone brand, with a nearly 10 percent share of the global market.

The announcement came days after HTC said at a product launch event that its new Desire HD and Desire Z, which run on Android 2.2, the latest version of Google's operating system, will hit the Asian market in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County promotes budget tours

TEXT.P: The Taipei County government is offering day tours to three scenic areas, including a trip to the county's highly popular wetlands, for only NT$199.

Following the enthusiastic response received by the original half-day wetlands tour, the county government has come up with a new plan for a full day tour of scenic sites, and an opportunity to taste some of the region's local pastries and popsicles.
According to the county government, the ticket price includes all travel costs and insurance, a pottery-making activity or a trip on a swan boat.
People on these tours will be taken to Yingge, famous for its ceramics museum, Xindian with its Bitan scenic area, or Bali, a popular tourist destination on the Danshui River estuary.
After taking visitors through the scenic spots, the tours continue on to wetland areas in Fujhou or Wugu to give people a taste of the county's diverse ecological environments.
The tours began Monday and are expected to continue to the start of December, with some 40 groups organized.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 12, 2010, or the fifth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: After a month of experiencing mirages of land, explorer Christopher Columbus and his three ships sight "terra firma" at dawn today.
1822: Brazil becomes independent from Portugal.
1866: Ramsey McDonald, Scottish statesman and first Labour prime minister of Britain, is born.
1870: Robert E. Lee, Confederate general in the US Civil War, dies in Lexington at the age of 63. He won victories at Bull Run (1862), Fredericksburg (1863), and Chancellorsville (1863), before surrendering to Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at Appomattox in 1865.
1899: The Boer states respond to Britain's despatch of troops to South Africa by issuing a declaration of war, and the British military garrison at Mafeking, under Colonel Robert Baden-Powell, is under siege by Boer forces.
1901: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, renames the Executive Mansion "The White House." He won the 1908 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War.
1920: Bertrand A. W. Russell, British philosopher, mathematician, social critic, and writer who won the 1950 Nobel Price for Literature, arrives in Shanghai as a visiting professor. He had profound influence on the development of symbolic ligic, logical positivism, and the set theory of mathematics.
1935: Adolf Hitler bans American jazz from German radio, calling it decadent.
1949: The ROC government moves its seat from Canton to Chungking.
1949: Euginie Anderson is appointed US ambassador to Denmark, becoming the first female US envoy.
1951: Florence Chadwick, US swimmer, breaks the cross-English Channel record with a time of just 13 hours 33 minutes.
1959: The United Nations General Assembly votes for a full-scale debate on Chinese communist bloodshed in Tibet.
1960: Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev, angered during a debate on colonialism at the United Nations General Assembly, takes off his shoe and ponds his desk with it several times.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a frienship treaty in Taipei.
1968: The 19th Olympic Games opens in Mexico City, capital of Mexico.
1968: Equatorial Guinea becomes independent after 190 years of Spanish rule.
1968: Omar Torrijos Herrera, a military officer, takes control of Panama and bigins to rule as a dictator.
1971: Dean Acheson, US politician and secretary of state from 1949 to 1953, dies at the age of 78. He promoted the Marshall Plan and helped established NATO.
1974: Juan Pao-shan, a Chinese student from Taiwan, is stabbed and killed in Los Angeles by leftists at a party in celebration of the Double Ten National Day of the Republic of China.
1976: Communist China's Prime Minister Hua Guofeng becomes chairman of the Chinese Communist Party.
1979: Fidel Castro, head of the Cuban governdment, deliver a speech at the United Nations General Assembly, requesting more UN aid for third world countries.
1983: A Tokyo district court sentences former Japanese Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka to four years' imprisonment for his part in the Lockheed bribery scandal.
1984: In a move to further expand bilataral trade and economic relations, the ROC-Australia Trade Association and the Chinese-New Zealand Business Council are formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1986: A summit meeting between US President Ronald Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev ends in Reykjavik without any agreement on arms control being reached.
1986: During a display of ROC military power in the "Kuokuang Maneuvers," a combat skills exercise is held at a southern naval base.
1987: South Korea adopts a new constitution allowing direct election of the president by the people rather than by the electoral college.
1989: The Republic of China and Belize announce the establishment of diplomatic relations.
1989: Direct telephone links between Taiwan and the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu are completed.
1989: King Mswati III of Swaziland arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1992: Strong earthquake rocks Cairo, killing 552 people and injuring nearly 10,000 others.
1992: Premier Hau Pei-tsun receives Austrian Minister for Economic Affairs Wolfgang Schussel.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The life of the moral man is unobstrusive and yet it grows more and more in significance; whereas the life of the vulgar person is ostentatious, but it losses more and more in significance until it becomes nothingness."

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Reflecting on Taiwan's unemployment problem

TEXT.P: According to a recent study released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Taiwan's Okun coefficient ranged between 0.1 and 0.16 over the past decade. This means that a 1 percentage point increase in Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) corresponds to only a 0.1-0.16 percent decrease in the unemployment rate.
The performance is not only inferior to 14 developed countries but also the worst among the four "Asian Tigers, " trailing South Korea's 0.35, Hong Kong's 0.23 and Singapore's 0.17.

At the most fundamental level, the excessive tilt of Taiwan's industrial structure toward the high-tech sector and increased overseas production by Taiwanese manufacturers are the reasons why GDP growth has failed to boost employment.

Although we have on many occasions called the government's attention to the issue, it has so far not been able to abandon its "high-tech obsession, " with R&D, human resource and administrative resources still concentrating on a small minority of star industries.
With the plight of Taiwan's economic development clearly reflected by the Okun coefficient, the government must seriously examine its industrial policy. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 12, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Weaker Asian currencies slow Taiwan dollar appreciation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 11:39:16 (By Lin Ye-fong and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Weaker Asian currencies Tuesday slowed the pace of the Taiwan dollar's appreciation against the U.S. dollar, dealers said.

They said investors in other regional markets were rushing to sell Asian currencies, including Chinese yuan and Japanese yen, to pocket recent gains against the greenback, but the trend of a falling U.S. dollar in Taiwan remained intact.
At 11 a.m., the U.S. dollar fell by NT$0.106 to NT$30.8920 against the Taiwan dollar.
A stronger U.S. dollar in Asian markets alleviated pressure on the Taiwan dollar to appreciate, in a sharp contrast to the jumps made during trading sessions in recent days, dealers said.
In the local market, dealers said, investors followed the lead of other Asian markets by locking in profits, igniting buying in the U.S. dollar.

Their renewed interest in the greenback gave a breather to the central bank, which had engaged in aggressive intervention to support the U.S. dollar on fears that a rapid appreciation of the Taiwan dollar would hurt the island's export competitiveness.

On Monday, the central bank abandoned its efforts to maintain the U.S. dollar above NT$31.00 to the Taiwan dollar as the market widely anticipated that the U.S. Federal Reserve Board will take further measures to ease the money supply to boost the economy after the U.S. September jobs report pointed to a sluggish economic climate.
Dealers said the Taiwan dollar is expected to consolidate and move in a narrow range for the rest of the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady hails Ming Hwa Yuan as 'Taiwan's pride'
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 12:43:39 (By Lin Yu-li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: First lady Chow Mei-ching Monday praised Taiwanese opera troupe Ming Hwa Yuan -- which was in Berlin, Germany on the first leg of its European performance tour -- as the "pride of Taiwan."

"I feel it is a matter of great pride for Taiwan to be able to watch you perform overseas this time, " Chow, who is accompanying Ming Hwa Yuan on the tour as its honorary director, told the company when visiting its rehearsal.
This is the 80-year-old Ming Hwa Yuan troupe's first performance tour in Europe. It has performed previously in individual European cities, most recently in Paris more than 10 years ago.
In addition to Berlin, the 10-day tour will cover six other European cities -- Prague, Vienna, Paris, London, Edinburgh and Amsterdam.
The opening show, The Living Buddha, is scheduled for Tuesday at the Admiralspalast theater.

Tour leader Sun Tsui-feng said it was not easy for an Oriental opera troupe to get the opportunity to perform in the Western world. She is confident that Ming Hwa Yuan's shows will touch the hearts of Western audiences, despite language differences.
"I feel very honored to be able to take part in the exchanges between Eastern and Western art," Sun said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Indonesia offers Taiwan an island

TEXT.P: A local newspaper reported Tuesday that Indonesia has offered Taiwan an island named Morotai in the hope that Taiwan will help develop the remote islet that has a population of 50,000 people and abundant fishery resources and served as a key military post in World War II.
The following are excerpts from media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:
It all started with Taiwan's signing an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China on June 25 to further promote trade and economic links between the two sides across Taiwan Strait.

The deal created an ECFA effect, attracting the interest of regional economies. First, Singapore resumed free trade agreement talks with Taiwan in August. Now, Indonesia, which has long kept its distance from Taiwan, both politically and economically, has taken the initiative.

A ranking government official who declined to be named said the proposal was presented by Indonesian President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono through his ministers to Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang in early October, during Shih's visit there to study the local economic and trade environment.
The official also disclosed that Indonesian officials will visit Taiwan next month for talks on the proposal. It is hoped there will be concrete details on the deal by early next year, he said.

Morotai, one-fifteenth the size of Taiwan with an area of 2,400 square kilometers, is located on the northern tip of Indonesia (northwest of the island of New Guinea) . Its natural environment remains pristine because of its remote geographic location.

What the Morotai development project represents is more the rise of a "crazy about Taiwan" atmosphere than actual commercial benefits. Such an atmosphere has emerged from the ECFA effect, and Taiwan should cherish and take advantage of it.
Taiwan has finally restored economic and trade links with Indonesia, a member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, after relations soured during the Chen Shui-bian administration.
A Taiwan economic and trade delegation, headed by Shih, won local media attention when it arrived in Indonesia Sept. 30 for a visit.

Officials responsible for economic affairs said Taiwan has listed Indonesia as one of four key investment markets in the region, aside from China, India and Vietnam. Taiwan plans to invest in the automobile, bicycle, textile, electronics and shoes manufacturing sectors there.

Rising labor and land costs in China forced four Taiwanese shoe makers that produce shoes for international brands such as Nike and Reebok to relocate their production lines to Indonesia earlier this year, the officials said. (Oct. 12, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier: Talks needed for Taiwan-Indonesia investment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 14:05:21 (By Justin Su, Chou Yung-chieh and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said on Tuesday that talks with Indonesia are needed to work through the details of a proposal to co-develop one of the Southeast Asian country's islands.

The United Daily News reported on Tuesday that the Indonesian government has invited Taiwan to join a project to develop Morotai Island, the northernmost of the Maluku Islands situated between New Guinea and the Philippines.
The island is heavily wooded, producing timber, and boasts abundant fishery resources.
Wu spoke cautiously about the initiative, saying that what Taiwan is willing to invest in Morotai Island and what the Indonesian government wants Taiwan to invest remain to be seen.
Morotai Island has an area of about 2,400 square kilometers, roughly one- fifteenth the size of Taiwan, and a population of some 50,000 people, according to the report.

Because Morotai Island is not a small island, any joint investment will need further discussion between the Taiwanese and Indonesian governments, Wu said, and he pledged that his Cabinet will conduct a serious and careful assessment of the project.

This latest joint investment initiative, the premier said, is one of many that have emerged after the implementation of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , which was signed with China in late June.

Wu stressed, however, that the government has made investing in Taiwan its top priority while mulling business opportunities overseas and said overseas investments will not drain Taiwan of the capital it needs for development at home.

Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Indonesia, which is full of rich natural resources and gearing up to improve its domestic political and economic climate, has attracted much attention from Taiwanese investors.
But because the Morotai Island project remains in its early stage, Shih said he did not want to talk too much about the issue at the moment. He added that he has never visited the island.
Shih led a delegation to Indonesia for a three-day visit in late September, introducing Taiwan's investment environment and preaching made-in-Taiwan goods.

During the visit, Shih also met with Indonesian officials, including Gita Wirjawan, head of Indonesia's Coordinating Investment Board. It was at that time that the Morotai Island project was first broached.
