DOC.HEADLINE: Delegation to explore co-development offer on Indonesian islet

TEXT.P: A delegation departed for the Indonesian island of Morotai Tuesday as Taiwan mulls the Indonesian government's offer to have Taiwan help develop the island, officials of the two countries said Tuesday.

The Southeast Asian country has contacted Taiwan to participate in developing in the island, which is located between the Philippines and New Guinea and has a population of 50,000 people, confirmed Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman James Chang on Tuesday.
Taiwan welcomed the offer, he said.

Indonesia's representative to Taiwan Harmen Sembiring, officials from the MOFA's Department of Asian and Pacific Affairs and a group of Taiwanese businessmen embarked on a trip to the underdeveloped island Tuesday to conduct a preliminary evaluation, said Irene Pan of the Indonesian Economic and Trade Office to Taipei's Investment Department.
The delegation is scheduled to return to Taiwan Oct. 19, she said.

Pan said Indonesia's Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries first made contact with Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) in September when Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang was in Indonesia at the head of a trade and investment delegation.

"The Indonesian side hopes to attract Taiwanese investment in the sectors of seafood production, fishing, aquaculture and tourism, " said Kuo Fu-chuan, a senior technical specialist in the MOEA's Department of Investment Services.

The evaluation is still in its initial stages, Kuo said, and the Fisheries Agency still needs to gather data on Morotai's hydrology, fish species and fishing regulations before conducting its evaluation.
After that, government agencies will be able to brief local businessmen on investment opportunities.

Indonesia has also offered Taiwan Sugar Corporation and state-run oil refiner CPC Corp. Taiwan the opportunities to establish an oil refinery and development land in other parts of the archipelago country, respectively, Kuo said.
Premier Wu Den-yih said at a legislative hearing Tuesday morning that there is no timetable yet for the development project because further assessment is needed.
The MOEA's Shih said it was still too early to go into the specifics of the project, but he noted that there has been a lot of interest among local businesses to invest in Indonesia.
Taiwan's accumulated investments in Indonesia total US$13.95 billion, according to the ministry.
Morotai is best known as the site of the Battle of Morotai in World War II in 1944 and was used as a springboard for the Allied invasion of the Philippines in 1945.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Taiwan's economic outlook

TEXT.P: According to the latest forecast released last week by the International Monetary Fund, Taiwan's economic growth is expected to reach 9.3 percent in 2010 but will slow down to 4.4 percent in 2011 as stimulus policies in developed economies wind down.
This means that Taiwan will need to increase its domestic demand to support its economic growth next year, and the unemployment rate has to be lowered to boost private consumption.

In terms of increasing private investment, the government should seek to draw foreign investment into the service sector, because investment in the manufacturing sector is likely to slow down as a result of an unstable international economic situation.

Also, the government should make good use of the business opportunities brought by the economic cooperation framework agreement and step up its efforts to attract inflows of Chinese investment and get overseas Taiwanese businesses to return home to invest.
The government's top priority, therefore, is to eliminate existing barriers on investment and improve its administrative efficiency. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 12, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 1.05 percent

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 1.05 percent Tuesday as investors took note of the losses suffered on other regional markets amid concern over the rapid appreciation of Asian currencies, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 86.54 points to 8,090.22, after moving between 8,058.59 and 8,180.39, on turnover of NT$102.14 billion (US$3.30 billion).

The market opened down 0.06 points and selling accelerated after regional markets, including Tokyo, Hong Kong and Seoul, expanded losses to drag the local index down below the 8,100 point support level, dealers said.
A total of 2,820 stocks closed down, 1,065 finished up, and 237 stocks remained unchanged.

The paper and pulp sector encountered the steepest decline, down 1.65 percent. Financials lost 1.18 percent, machinery and electronics stocks dropped 1.17 percent, plastics and chemical shares fell 1.12 percent, and textile stocks closed down 0.94 percent.
The cement sector fell 0.69 percent, the construction sector lost 0.41 percent and the foodstuff sector closed down 0.13 percent.

Taiwan International Securities analyst Michael Chiang said market sentiment has turned cautious as governments in the region, including Taiwan, are taking action to cap the appreciation of their currencies against the U.S. dollar.
"Measures adopted by central banks in the region could limit inflows of foreign funds, and liquidity in the capital market will fall accordingly. Investors do not like that," Chiang said.

"Investors had better watch closely what measures Taiwan's central bank will come up with to curb infusions of hot money, " Chiang said. "Any move by the central bank to handle idle funds is expected to trigger the drainage of liquidity."
Chiang said that with investors cautious, once the market falls below the key 8,000-point barrier, further selling will follow.
"It is time for investors to cut their holdings and raise their cash positions," he said.
Among old economy stocks, Shihlin Paper fell 4.03 percent to NT$71.40 and Nan Ya Plastics shed 3.11 percent to NT$62.30.
In the high tech sector, PC vendor AsusTek dropped 2.06 percent to NT$213.50 and Hon Hai Precision, the world's largest contract electronics maker, fell 3.41 percent to NT$113.00.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County vows to develop English-friendly tourism
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 16:07:17 (By Hong Kuo Wang and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei pledged Tuesday to help bed and breakfast (B&B) owners and taxi drivers learn to speak English in a bid to make the county more attractive to foreign tourists.
Chou made the pledge in a ceremony to honor the county's guest house operators and cab drivers who have received certification from the Executive Yuan for the quality of their English services.
A total of 117 shops, businesses and taxi drivers in the country's most populous county were recognized this year.
According to Chou, few international tourists visit the county, mainly because its tourism sector lacks an English-friendly environment.

To draw more of them to Taipei County, said Chou, "we should put more effort into building English-friendly tourism, reinforcing the English service certification project and giving B&B owners and taxi drivers the opportunity to learn the language."
The county's Tourism and Travel Bureau said it is continuing to encourage the tourism sector to get the English service certificates.
In addition, it is planning to make bilingual signs and to publish information brochures and websites, as well as to boost the English proficiency of tourism sector staff.

DOC.HEADLINE: State-run oil firm mulls investment in Indonesia
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 16:54:02 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run oil company is still mulling a plan to set up an oil refinery in Indonesia, but is expecting the Indonesian government to offer better incentives, a company official said Tuesday.

"We are still assessing various investment conditions in Indonesia, but we need to negotiate with the Indonesian government over, for example, tariff reductions," Quentin Yao, the director of CPC Corp., Taiwan's Department of Joint Ventures, told reporters.

His remarks came in the wake of a report in the United Daily News that same day that CPC Corp. Chairman Chu Shao-hua had confirmed that Indonesia has offered three islands as possible locations for the company to set up an oil refinery.
Chu, however, said the oil company is likely to choose only one of them and he added that the deal will be off if the terms are not good.
Yao said CPC Corp. is still expecting Indonesia to grant preferential measures, including tariff removal and utility bill cuts.
He added that the company will phase out a refinery in Taiwan and could move the old facilities to Indonesia.
Meanwhile, the daily also said that Indonesia has invited Taiwan to help develop its Morotai Island.

An official from Taiwan's Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) told CNA on condition of anonymity that the invitation was made when Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang visited Indonesia Sept. 30.
The COA will send a team to Morotai, which has coal mines and abundant aquatic resources, to conduct an assessment next week at the earliest, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vietnam meddling in Taiwan's National Day celebrations in Hanoi: FM
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 18:07:42 (By Kelven Huang, Tony Fang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang admitted Tuesday that Vietnam's government has interfered with the proceedings of an annual cocktail party held by Taiwan's representative office in Hanoi to celebrate the island's Double Ten National Day since 2007.

The Vietnamese government "has exercised a great deal of pressure" on such a celebration event, banning the office from using Taiwan's official name -- the Republic of China -- and terms like "national day" at the party, Yang said.
He was responding to legislators' questions during a question and answer session at the Legislative Yuan.
Yang added that the authorities in Vietnam have even threatened to block guests from entering the party venue if the office refused to meet its requests.

Yang did not say why Vietnam interfered with Taiwan's celebrations of its National Day. Hanoi has been steadily improving relations with China over the years. Beijing considers Taiwan one of its provinces, to be reunified, and objects to other countries viewing Taiwan as a country.

Vietnam's attitude has not changed over the years despite the ministry's frequent protests, Yang said. "The ministry has never stopped protesting, " Yang stressed, noting that he has instructed Taiwan's liaison office in Hanoi to strongly defend and maintain Taiwan's national dignity.

The problem was reported by a Taiwanese daily newspaper, Liberty Times, Tuesday. The report said Taiwan's representative office in Hanoi has recently yielded to the Vietnamese Ministry of Foreign Affairs' request to take two Chinese characters, which mean National Day celebration, off a banner that reads the "99th Double Ten National Day Celebration Party" in Chinese.
Legislator Lee Chun-yee asked about the report at the legislative session, questioning whether Vietnam's actions only began this year, and if so, who should be held responsible.

In Hanoi, Huang Chih-peng, who took office as Taiwan's top representative to Vietnam on Oct. 6, confirmed that the suppression on the office's national day celebration parties began in 2007. He pledged to try harder to boost communications with Vietnamese authorities.
Officials at Vietnam's Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei could not immediately be reached for comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former vice president to serve as APEC envoy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 18:50:21 (By Garfie Li and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Vice President Lien Chan will attend this year's economic leaders' meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum as President Ma Ying-jeou's special envoy, Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang announced Tuesday.
Lien has been appointed by Ma to serve as his APEC envoy for the third consecutive year since Ma's inauguration in May 2008.
This year's APEC economic leaders' meeting will be held in the Japanese city of Yokohama Nov. 13-14, with the theme of "change and action."

Because of Beijing's opposition, Republic of China presidents have been barred from APEC unofficial leadership summit meetings since the country became a member of the regional grouping in 1991 under the moniker "Chinese Taipei."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the Taiwan dollar Tuesday, gaining NT$0.072 to close at the day's high of NT$31.070.
Turnover totaled US$928 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$31.030 and moved to a low of NT$30.802 before rebounding.

Dealers said the fall in the Taiwan dollar reflected weaker Asian currencies, in particular the South Korean won, as investors in regional markets rushed to pocket the strong gains these currencies made recently against the U.S. dollar.
Losses on Taiwan's stock market also raised selling pressure on the local currency, they said. The benchmark weighted index fell 1.05 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Firm unveils `supersmart' electricity meter
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 19:03:52 (By Wei Shu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based HomeScenario, Inc. unveiled at the Broadband Taiwan 2010 technology fair Tuesday a prototype of its "supersmart" electricity meter that can help homeowners closely monitor their power consumption.

According to HomeScenario, the meter is equipped with censors that detect total power consumption of a home and inform homeowners of the data via their cell phones or personal computers through broadband.

The company said the newly developed meter can also be used to monitor electricity use patterns and the power consumption of individual home appliances. It can also automatically control lighting, air-conditioning, audio-video equipment and door security.
HomeScenario and its partner, National Chiao Tung University, spent more than a year developing the product and are planning to launch commercial production.
HomeScenario is one of 16 Taiwanese and foreign high-tech developers showing their products in the exhibition's theme pavilion titled Broadband Universe.

Apart from the broadband technology, the exhibition, which is organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Industrial Technology Research Institute, also features wireless technology, telecommunications components and equipment.
The fair, which began a day earlier, houses a total of 750 exhibitors in 1,600 booths and will run through Oct. 14, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP lawmakers worried about conscription relaxation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 19:08:43 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A proposal to relax restrictions on exit applications by male citizens of conscription age planning to study in China met with strong opposition from lawmakers of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party Tuesday, who said the move could trigger "a wave of desertions."
According to Legislator Kuan Bi-ling, the proposal would "widely open the doors for deserters."
It would also increase the outflow of local students to China, further battering local university enrollments, which have been declining due to a dropping birth rate, she said.
Earlier in the day, the Legislative Yuan put the draft bill by Kuomintang lawmakers to revise the enforcement regulations of the Conscription Law on the agenda of the next plenary session.

In the draft bill, the legislators said the current regulations impose stricter restrictions on applications for exit filed by those of draft age who want to travel to China to study than similar exit applications by those planning to study in other countries.

The regulations, which restrict the departure of the citizens of conscription age at 18 years old unless they have fulfilled their national service, are greatly inconvenient for draftees who have begun study in China, the lawmakers said.
These young people are either forced to suspend their studies and stay in Taiwan to fulfill their military duties or stay in China for the long term, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dengue fever cases on the rise: CDC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Centers for Disease Control (CDC) urged the country's residents to keep their living environments clean to prevent a full-blown outbreak of dengue fever after reporting on Tuesday a sharp rise in the incidence of the disease recently.

A total of 111 new dengue fever cases originating in Taiwan were reported last week, setting a new single week record, with most of the cases concentrated in southern Taiwan, CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi said at a news conference.

Shih also said four different strains of the virus have emerged, increasing the threat of an outbreak of the more dangerous dengue hemorrhagic fever, which often occurs when a different strain of the virus infects a patient who previously had dengue fever.

To counter the threat, the Department of Health and the Environmental Protection Administration will jointly conduct spot checks of potential breeding grounds for the mosquitoes that spread the virus, Shih said.
He also urged southern Taiwan residents to clean their neighborhoods of standing water to prevent a wider outbreak.

Since August, 483 cases have been reported in Taiwan, of which 300 have occurred in Kaohsiung City and 108 in Tainan City, said CDC medical officer Kuo Tsung- wen, who attributed the rising infection numbers to the high incidence of dengue fever around the world.
Aside from Southeast Asian countries, which are experiencing an increase in dengue fever cases, there were 387 imported cases of the tropical disease in Germany, said Kuo, the highest in its history.
Dengue fever is transmitted by mosquitoes in tropical regions. Its symptoms include fever, headache, dizziness and loss of appetite.

DOC.HEADLINE: Goldman maintains `buy' recommendation on HTC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 19:42:54 (By Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Goldman Sachs said Tuesday that it was maintaining a "buy" recommendation on smartphone maker HTC after the company launched five new models running on Microsoft's new Windows Phone 7 (WP7) operating system.
Goldman said the new models highlight HTC's competitive advantage of being a Microsoft partner in commercializing new technologies.
The brokerage said it does not expect WP7 smartphones to be an immediate growth driver for HTC, but forecast that the benefits will be seen in 2011.

HTC unveiled its five WP7 smartphones a day earlier -- the HTC 7 Surround, the HTC 7 Mozart, the HTC 7 Trophy, the HTC 7 Pro and the HTC HD7 -- and the products will hit markets in North America, Europe and the Asia-Pacific region from later in the month.
"We expect the products to incrementally fuel HTC's momentum in the fourth quarter of this year and beyond," Goldman said.

HTC, which has partnered with Microsoft for nearly 10 years and produced the first smartphone with Microsoft's mobile platform in 2002, is now the world's fourth-largest smartphone brand, taking a nearly 10 percent share of the global market.
Goldman said it expects HTC will launch two to three Android-based smartphones over the next two quarters.
In the third quarter, HTC posted sales of NT$75.85 billion (US$2.44 billion) , higher than an earlier company estimate of NT$70 billion made in July.
Goldman set a 12-month target price of NT$1,000 for HTC stocks.
HTC fell 2.24 percent to NT$699.00 on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expands lighting project to South Pacific
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 19:47:40 (By Li Chia-fei and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that Taiwan's "Lamp for Africa " solar lighting project will be expanded to benefit rural residents of the Solomon Islands in the South Pacific.

Ma noted during a meeting with visiting Solomon Islands Prime Minister Danny Philip at the Presidential Office that Taiwan has signed a cooperation agreement on solar power development with the Pacific ally, under which Taiwan will provide lighting for remote areas of the country.

Ma also congratulated Philip, who was elected prime minister in August, describing him as a leader with vision who can lead the country to making big progress on both the domestic and international stages.
According to Ma, Philip will work on building good relations with Taiwan and made particular mention of the partnership with the Republic of China in his policy white paper.
"Taiwan will play an essential role and provide assistance and support to the new government," Ma said.

Since the two countries established diplomatic relations in 1983, Taiwan has focused on improving exchanges and providing the Solomon Islands with development in the fields of agriculture, medicine and education.

For example, the Solomon Islands' minister of agriculture and livestock is studying at Taiwan's National Pingtung University of Science and Technology, Ma said. He added that providing humanitarian aid, promoting cultural exchanges and creating technological innovations are the key facets of Taiwan's foreign aid policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade deal's positive effect emerging: Taiwan's president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 20:02:01 (By Garfie Li and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that the positive effects of a major trade deal between Taiwan and China is beginning to emerge, with more countries showing interests in cooperating with Taiwan economically.

The president was referring to an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) which Taiwan signed with China on June 29. The agreement reduces tariffs on exports between the two sides and eliminates some non-tariff trade barriers. It was widely seen as a breakthrough in relations as it was one of the most important agreement reached between the two sides in six decades.
Ma's remarks came amid news report that Indonesia intends to invite Taiwan to help develop an island called Morotai, located on its northern tip.
Ma said that after the Taiwan-China trade pact, Southeast Asia, Europe, New Zealand and Australia have "looked at Taiwan with new eyes."
"The signing of the pact has further eased cross-strait tensions and created more trade opportunities," the president said.

He cited as an example that Singapore is talking with Taiwan about signing an economic cooperation agreement, while talks on a trade and investment framework agreement with the United States will resume at the end of the year.
Ma noted that amid warming ties with China, many countries have seen that Beijing is willing to improve relations with Taiwan, and they ask themselves "Why can't we?"
The effect, Ma said, is that Taiwan's friends will no longer have to "take sides," and they can make friends with both Taiwan and China at the same time.

He stressed that his administration will actively seek to sign economic cooperation pacts or free trade pacts with its trading partners, especially countries with whom Taiwan has complementary ties, so as to expand Taiwan's participation in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Electronic garden' to be feature of Flora Expo

TEXT.P: The upcoming International Flora Expo in Taipei will feature a garden in which hundreds of electronic flowers will "dance" to sound and light effects when visitors approach them, the designer said Tuesday.
A total of 438 electronic flowers designed by Asus, the world's fifth largest PC maker, will be highlighted at the "Pavilion of Dreams" of the expo.
A limited number of visitors will get a sneak preview of the flowers dancing during a trial period on Oct. 15-20.
The pavilion will officially open to the public at the formal launch of the expo on Nov. 6.
"We hope that people will reflect on and seek a better relationship with nature by interacting with the electronic plants, " said Mike Tsai, director of the design center in Asus.

The flowers, created by an Asus team of over 10 members, are designed to "dance" to sound and light effects as one approaches them. They can detect approaching spectators with the infrared sensors placed under the floor.
Patrick Chiu, a senior designer of Asus, said the company has spent more than a year and about NT$10 million (US$326,690) to develop the technology.
"We found that everything in nature moves with certain rules, like migratory birds flying in lines," Chiu said.
"We tried to recreate these natural behaviors in the form of technology," he noted.
The Taipei City Government is aiming to attract at least 8 million visitors to the six-month expo, which will be held in Taiwan for the first time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Children should be vaccinated against seasonal flu: DOH

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) urged mothers to get their children vaccinated against seasonal flu Tuesday in the face of low vaccination rates.

Compared to last year, only half of the country's children of pre-school age had received the free seasonal flu vaccination as of that day, said Shih Wen-yi, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC).
The situation was similar for those aged over 65, with the inoculation rate in this group down 30 percent compared to last year's statistics, said Shih.

Asked about the side effects of this year's flu vaccine, Shih said only that "there is no need to be worried" and said parents should be more anxious if their children are not vaccinated against seasonal flu, which has already caused 42 cluster infections this year.
This year's vaccine is good for the prevention of infection by the H1N1 virus, H3N2 virus and influenza B virus, all of which are expected to be common and widespread in the upcoming season.
Shih warned that there have been many cases of children being infected with the flu at school and bringing the virus home to their grandparents, who are also vulnerable.
Rolling up his sleeve to get a shot, Minister of Health Yuang Chih-liang described the seasonal vaccination as effective.
Shih said the center has purchased nearly 3 million doses of seasonal flu vaccine this year, only 720,000 of which had been used since the beginning of the vaccination program 12 days ago.

The free vaccination program runs from Oct. 1 to Nov. 30, for citizens aged over 65, children aged between six months and 10 years, medical personnel in charge of disease control and prevention, poultry breeders and patients with rare or serious diseases, according to Shih.
People who are not on the priority list for free inoculation can still get vaccinated at a cost of between NT$500 (US$15.63) and NT$700 at clinics and hospitals, Shih pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin magistrate calls for open debate on naphtha cracker

TEXT.P: The 40th supervisory committee meeting on the No. 6 naphtha cracker plant ended in deadlock Tuesday with Yunlin Magistrate Su Chih-fen calling for an open debate with Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) over the environmental hazards reportedly caused by the plant since its establishment in 1991.

The plant, located in the southern agricultural county's Mailiao Township has faced a string of incidents in recent months including two major fires in July and two reports of foul odor leaking from the plant last month.

Speaking at the meeting held at the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) headquarters, Su said the county government has repeatedly voiced its concerns over the plant, especially after the two fires, but the pleas have gone largely ignored by the Industrial Development Bureau and the conglomerate.
"Even now, there is no designated lane for the oversized vehicles used by the plant. The plant has become a nuisance for local residents and this is just one of the many examples," said Su.
The county government complained about FPG's failure to reduce the noise, air and water pollution caused by the facility and lambasted it for its shoddy fire control management.

A representative of the Yunlin Fire Department recalled that the July 7 fire lasted for three days before it was completely extinguished, and he blamed the plant's own firefighters of failing to contain the blaze in its initial stages.

Meanwhile, the county's Environmental Bureau said the plant's daily waste water discharge is as high as 180,000 metric tons and the pH level is as low as 6.3 -- barely meeting the legal permitted level of a 6.0-9.0 range for agricultural irrigation use, said the representative.

However, according to experts commissioned by the conglomerate, research shows that the plant does not pose any eco-hazard to the local environment and that the toxic waste emissions, as well as the noise pollution and traffic levels caused by the facility, all fall within legal standards.
The meeting ended without any solid conclusion, but FPG is required to submit an overall health impact assessment report by the end of this month.
The complex was proposed in 1973. In 1991, FPG won government approval to build the petrochemical complex on two offshore industrial zones in Yunlin.

The company was fined NT$1 million (US$32,211) for the foul odor episodes in September and an additional NT$3 million for the two July blazes. The damage caused by the two fires was reportedly estimated at over NT$500 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Major illness accounts for most health care spending: BNHI

TEXT.P: More than 25 percent of the health expenditure in 2009 went on patients with major illness or injury, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI).
There were 783,121 people under the category of major illness or injury in Taiwan last year, whose combined health care costs accounted for 26.99 percent of the total, according to the statistics.

Although individuals with major illness only accounted for 3 percent of the total population, the amount spent on treating these patients was around $130 billion (US$42 million), said Tsai Shu-ling, director of the bureau's medical affairs department.
The statistics also show that clinical fees were highest for patients with cancer, chronic mental disorder, auto-immune disease and hemophilia, as well as those requiring dialysis.
Despite the heavy cost of treatment for major illnesses, Tsai said, it is the bureau's responsibility to take care of these patients.
Tsai also pointed out that patients suffering from cancer and other major illnesses can often return to the workforce after receiving medical treatment, making the cost more worthwhile.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central Science Park sees over 50 percent trade growth in Q3
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 21:10:38 (By Lee Hsi Chang and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: The Central Taiwan Science Park on Tuesday reported an over 50 percent increase in the value of its foreign trade in the third quarter of this year, as the economy continues to show signs of recovery.

The park, located in Taichung city and county, recorded a combined trade value of more than NT$101.2 billion (US$3.267 billion) , a 52.7 percent increase from the same period last year, according to the park's administration.
The park's Q3 export value reached over NT$65.7 billion, while the value of its imports was at NT$35.5 billion.
The optronics industry outperformed all the other industries in both exports and imports, followed by the semiconductor and precision machinery industries, said the park.
The firms in the park mostly export their products to Asia, with Europe and the Middle East being the second and third largest markets, according to the park's statistics.
The science park is Taiwan's third science and industrial park, with 26 corporations, including TSMC, AU Optronics and Taiwan Nitto, having operations there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Cable TV systems top investment for rich

TEXT.P: The most popular investment for Taiwan's wealthy are cable TV systems, with many business tycoons prepared to offer tens of billions of New Taiwan dollars to bid for such companies.

Cable TV system operators' steady cash flow and proven profitability are what attract these billionaires, including Fubon Group's Daniel Tsai and Richard Tsai, Want Want Group Chairman Tsai Eng-meng and Ruentex Group President Samuel Yin.

"For investors with a large capital position, a cable TV system is a good investment target because of its stable cash flow, as such people are unlikely to put capital in a bank, especially when the stock market fluctuates more and property prices are high, " a major shareholder of a cable TV system said.

The industry's landscape has been undergoing great changes since Fubon Group's Tsai brothers announced their NT$65 billion (US$2.06 billion) deal to buy Kbro Co. in July, which makes the previous five major multi-system operators into three groups.

As Fubon Group already owns Taiwan Mobile -- which also has a cable TV operation, the combined market share of Kbro and Taiwan Mobile's cable TV unit will reach 35 percent, making the Tsai family the biggest player in the business.

The second-largest operator, CNS, is also up for sale and the auction process is set to conclude in October, while most of the other operators are managed by Lien Tai-sheng, chairman of ERA Communications Inc., which has its own cable system and channels.
The price tag of the CNS sale is estimated at NT$70 billion and has attracted several groups of investors, including Sony, Yin, the team led by Tsai, Bain Capital Partners and the Macquarie Group.

The most active among them is the Tsai group, which includes former media tycoon Gary Wang and Tsai Chen-yu, who recently sold a 15 percent stake in the family run Cathay Financial Holding. Each of them have different agendas.

Tsai Eng-meng is continuing his expansion in the media industry after his 2008 purchase of the terrestrial broadcaster China Broadcast Co. and CTiTV Inc., which operates several cable channels, while Wang is trying to get back into the business after his involvement in an embezzlement scandal in 2007. Tsai Chen-yu, on the other hand, was approached for the cash he owned from the Cathay stock sales.

However, these high prices might lead to delays in TV digitization, as it is unclear if these investors will be willing to invest in the necessary equipment, which is the major cost for system operators.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism bureau to hold top hotel contest
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 21:57:20 (By Chen Hsieh-shun and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: An online contest featuring Taiwan's hospitality and hotel industry will be held from Wednesday to Dec. 12 in an effort to improve the quality of the country's hotel services, a Tourism Bureau official said Tuesday.

The Tourism Bureau will provide a platform with the theme of "Happy Stay," on which hotel operators can upload video clips, photos and stories to promote their facilities and describe the services they provide to their customers, Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai said.
The competition will be divided into service categories such as the most delicious, the most fun, the most thoughtful and the most creative, Lai said.
The public can then vote for the best tourist hotels and hostels, with polling to start Nov. 13.
A panel of travel experts will select five winners next January, each of whom will get prize money of NT$50,000 (US$1,500).

According to the bureau, there are over 2,600 small hotels, 101 upscale hotels and more than 3,000 guest houses in Taiwan. The online competition can help promote the smaller business operators who have limited budget to invest in advertising, Lai said.
Good service has nothing to do with hardware, according to Jack Wu, general manager of the Caesar Park Hotel in Kenting.
"Service that goes beyond customer expectations will always touch the customer's heart," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Southeast Asia should be Taiwan's strategic focus: scholars

TEXT.P: Southeast Asia rather than Northeast Asia should be high on Taiwan's strategic radar in the wake of the historic cross-Taiwan Strait trade pact signed earlier this year, scholars said Tuesday.

"Taiwan should focus its strategies on Southeast Asia because its participation and impact in Northeast Asia will be limited, " said Alexander Huang, a professor at Tamkang University's Graduate Institute of International Affairs and Strategic Studies.

Huang made the comment in a forum that examined Taiwan's economic and political positions and strategic choices following the June signing of the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China.

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is likely to be the axis and driving force of Asian economic integration, which is why Taiwan cannot afford to overlook the region, said economist Liu Da-nien, who serves as a researcher at the Chung-hua Institution for Economic Research.

Although the ECFA has given Taiwan some leverage, South Korea, Taiwan's fierce trade competitor, is also active in Northeast Asia, Liu said, adding that a South Korea-European Union free trade agreement (FTA) is expected to take effect this year and it could also launch FTA talks with China soon, which would pose a major challenge for Taiwan.

China has put a lot of resources into Southeast Asian countries, said Lin Chien- fu, an economist at National Taiwan university. He added that Taiwan could either develop bilateral relations with ASEAN countries or do so via China's integration with ASEAN.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. names Taiwan institute as car safety partner

TEXT.P: Taiwan's semi-official industrial institute ITRI said Tuesday that it has been selected by the U.S. transport ministry as the only partner in Asia to be part of a program aimed at enhancing the safety of drivers when they are driving.

The U.S. Department of Transportation decided last month to choose Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) to be one of the eight participants in the IntelliDrive Safety program, the institute said in a statement.
The program is aimed at improving connectivity among vehicles and roadway infrastructure in order to significantly raise the level of safety in the U.S. transportation system.

Taiwan's institute said it believes one of the reasons it was chosen to participate in the program is because of its new technology, which can alert a driver to bad road conditions, such as automobile accidents or traffic jams, even when his vehicle is several hundred meters away.
The technology can also help a driver identify various acts of reckless driving to avoid potential threats to the driver in hundreds of metersdistance.
Being selected to take part in the U.S. transportation ministry's program will help ITRI gain a foothold in the U.S. intelligent transportation market, the institute said.
"This major breakthrough means that Taiwan has got a key to the door to the United States' intelligent transport system market, " the institute said.
"The partnership also sets a new example for Taiwan's future overseas cooperation in the field," it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Major construction to start on Kaohsiung underground railway

TEXT.P: The construction of a new main station for Kaohsiung will start next February, marking major progress in a project to put the city's railway underground, the Railway Reconstruction Bureau (RRB) said Tuesday.

The "three-in-one" Kaohsiung Main Station, which will serve the regular railway, the mass rapid transit system, and possibly the high speed railway, is scheduled to start operating by the end of 2017 and is expected to breathe new life into communities along the existing rail corridor and surrounding areas.
"The new station will become the gateway of the Kaohsiung metropolitan area and showcase its image as a port city, " said Chou Yung-hui, deputy director-general of the RRB.
Puttint the railway underground will greatly reduce traffic congestion caused by the five existing level crossings and 13 overpasses, he said.

So far, 37 percent of the NT$82.2 billion (US$2.6 billion) project has been completed. According to the RRB, the 13-kilometer underground railway will serve six new stations in addition to the two major stations of Kaohsiung and Zuoying.

These stations together will enhance local express services, increase rail transport capacity and provide better connections along the north-south corridor of the largest city in southern Taiwan with a population of over 1.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese aero firm eyeing lighter material market
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 22:21:33 (By Jeffrey Wu and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's leading airplane maker said Tuesday that it will inaugurate a production center next month that will produce materials aimed at reducing the weight of airplanes to capitalize on the trend of energy conservation.

"The industry is now working on finding ways to use composite materials to build jets, as these materials can make planes lighter, which as a result reduces energy consumption and carbon emissions, " Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) Chairman Shung Yeou-kuang said at a press conference.

The Taiwan Advance Composite Center in the central county of Taichung is scheduled for completion in mid-November, with production, mainly for 100-seat planes or smaller, expected to begin in January next year.
The center will reach full capacity by 2015, with an annual output value reaching NT$3 billion (US$97 million), according to the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese fine products fair to open in Shandong, China
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/10 22:42:46 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Hanna Liu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese fine products fair is scheduled to open Oct. 28 in the city of Jinan, in China's Shandong Province, with 1,050 booths manned by 450 Taiwanese businesses showcasing around 20,000 items of Taiwanese fine goods and services.

The expo is being jointly organized by the Shandong provincial government and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), Peter W.J. Huang, executive vice president of TAITRA, said Tuesday at a press conference in Beijing.
Huang said that of the 450 Taiwanese exhibitors, about 15 percent are involved in the cultural and creative industry.

The 1,050 booths will be divided into themes that include Taiwanese quality products, high-tech energy-saving products, the cultural and creative industry, fashion clothing and accessories, chain stores and franchises, health care and lifestyle, Huang said.
The expo will also showcase typical specialties from central and southern Taiwan, he added.
According to Shandong Provincial Government Deputy Secretary-General Wang Xu, a large Shandong mission is slated to visit Taiwan next year.
The province's vice governor, Cai Limin, led a 20-strong delegation to Taiwan in May this year and signed letters of intent with Taiwanese manufacturers to purchase US$1.59 billion-worth of products.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC official rebuts rumor about expired H1N1 vaccines

TEXT.P: A senior health official reassured the public Tuesday that no H1N1 vaccines from last year are being administered in the current campaign, as all expired vaccine has been destroyed.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), gave the reassurance after the number of people receiving H1N1 vaccinations was down from last year amid rumors that batches of new vaccine have been mixed with those from a year ago.
"Those eligible can go to appointed hospitals to receive the vaccine for free," said Shih, "There will be no mix-ups."
Compared with the same period of last year, numbers receiving the vaccine in Taipei County alone are down by almost 10,000, said Lin Guo-ning, a Taipei County Health Department official.
"In addition to a decrease in the number of children getting shots, there has been an especially low rate of old people being vaccinated," he said.

Lin confirmed that according to officials who have gone to places where H1N1 vaccinations are available, the lower rate is attributed to the rumor circulating among old people that this year's vaccine has been mixed with old batches.

International vaccines are produced according to seasonal influenza strains, the H1N1 vaccine is commonly produced and safe. There is no possibility that new vaccine has been mixed with old stock, said Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 13, or the sixth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
A.D. 54: Claudius I, 64, Roman emperor and historian, dies after supposedly consuming poisoned mushrooms dished up by his fourth wife, his niece Agrippina. Shortly before his death, Claudius had agreed to acknowledge Nero, Agrippina's son from a former marriage, as his heir instead of his natural son, Britannicus.
1792: U.S. President George Washington lays the foundation stone of the White House.
1812: British forces under Sir Isaac Brock defeat the Americans at the battle of Queenston Heights, helping to put an end to the U.S. attempt to invade Canada.
1884: Greenwich, England, is adopted as the universal meridian from which standard times throughout the world are calculated.
1913: Representatives from China, Britain and Tibet attend a meeting held in Simla, India, to discuss various problems concerning Tibet.
1923: Ankara becomes the capital of Turkey.
1925: Margaret Thatcher, British Conservative politician and prime minister from 1979 to 1990, is born. Her administration was marked by anti-inflationary measures, a brief war in the Falkland Islands (1982), and the passage of a poll tax.
1939: Adolf Hitler tries without success to persuade U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt to mediate peace between Germany, France and Britain.
1943: Italy declares war on Germany, its former Axis partner.
1949: Republic of China government troops evacuate Canton.
1960: The Institute of History and Philology of the Academia Sinica begins excavations at dwellings of the Yin people in Anyang County, Hunan Province, once the capital of the dynasty before 1200 B.C.
1964: Three Soviet cosmonauts operating Voshkod, the world's first multi-seat spacecraft, land safely after a 24-hour journey.
1968: Liu Shao-chi, state chairman of Communist China, is purged at the 12th Plenum of the 8th Chinese Communist Party Central Committee held in Beijing.
1970: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severance of diplomatic relations with Canada.
1974: U.S. Senator Hiram Leong Fong of Hawaii arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1980: President Pieter W. Botha of South Africa is presented with the Key to the City of Taipei by Mayor Lee Teng-hui upon arrival for a state visit.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui presents a Key to Taipei to Mayor Leon Amon of the Ivory Coast's Dimbokro City.
1988: The Shroud of Turin, for centuries regarded as the burial cloth of Jesus Christ, is shown by carbon-dating tests to date from between 1260 and 1390 in the Middle Ages, a period rife with forgeries.
1993: The United Nations Security Council decides to resume an oil-and-arms embargo against Haiti after Haitian military leaders fail to follow an agreement to allow President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to return to office and restore a democratic government.
1995: Joseph Rotblat, the nuclear physicist who devoted his life to trying to ban the bomb he helped create, wins the 1995 Nobel Peace Prize.
1995: France rejects appeals to abandon nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
1998: Daniel Chee Tsui, professor at Princeton University and a member of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, becomes one of the three co- winners of the 1998 Nobel Prize for physics.
1999: A Jordanian Royal Air Force transport plane airlifts 14,600 kilograms of relief goods to Taipei to help surviving victims of the devastating earthquake that rocked Taiwan on Sept. 21.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian hails the decision to grant the 2000 Nobel Prize in literature to self-exiled mainland Chinese writer Gao Xingjian, saying that the honor marks Gao's greatest achievement.
2001: The rampancy of counterfeit bank notes in circulation in Taiwan prompts the Central Bank of China (CBC) to add two items on its Web site's home page to teach the public the different ways to distinguish fake bills from real ones.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The life of the moral man is plain, and yet not unattractive; it is simple, and yet full of grace; it is easy, and yet methodical."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China Times: Don't hinder green energy development

TEXT.P: According to the Statute on Renewable Energy Development enacted in June, the state-run Taiwan Power Company will purchase electricity at NT$11.1883 per kilowatt-hour from households with solar power generation capacity of over 10 megawatts.

The purpose of the measure is to encourage the private sector to engage in alternative energy generation, which will help the company save expenses for power plant construction and land acquisition, lower carbon emissions, and reduce its electricity reserve margin, the amount of unused capacity needed to cover peak demand.

Surprisingly, both Environmental Protection Administration Minister Stephen Shen and Atomic Energy Council Chairman Liang Chi-yuan are concerned that solar power generation could become "overly feverish." Liang has even opposed solar photovoltaic investment by farmers and fishermen in Pingtung County, fearing that this could worsen the government's finances.

If they are serious about fulfilling President Ma Ying-jeou's calls for protecting Taiwan's environment and reducing carbon emissions, those officials should stop playing dirty tricks to try to obstruct the implementation of the statute. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 13, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Wednesday from its previous close, moving up 26.47 points at 8,116.69 on a turnover of NT$2.629 billion (US$84.81 million).
The weighted price index lost 86.54 points, or 1.05 percent, to close at 8,090.22 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese pitcher has second successful outing in rehab stint
DOC.DATELINE: Viera, Florida, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/13/10 10:54:46 (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese pitcher Chien-Ming Wang of the Washington Nationals threw two shutout innings in an instructional league game Tuesday, his second consecutive scoreless outing after missing the entire 2010 season.

Wang needed only 17 pitches to retire all six batters he faced, four on ground outs and two on fly balls. His velocity hit 89 miles per hour (143 kilometers per hour) , his best since taking to the mound in a game situation during his rehab stint.

The Washington Nationals trainer monitoring Wang's progress told the Central News Agency that Wang's shoulder, which was operated on during the 2009 season and kept him out of action for the 2010 season, was recovering quickly.
The trainer also said he was satisfied with the 30-year-old Tainan native's progress, as Wang's velocity had improved from 70 mph when he started throwing to around 90 mph recently.
In his first instructional league outing last Wednesday, Wang hit 87 mph on the radar gun in one inning of work.
Wang's outings in the instructional league -- used by teams primarily to help minor league prospects improve their skills -- are likely to determine his future.

After Wang was plagued by injury in 2008 and 2009 when he was with the New York Yankees, the Yankees decided not to offer him a deal for the 2010 season, and he ended up signing a one-year, US$2 million contract with the Nationals.
The Nationals are waiting to see how Wang progresses before they decide whether to offer him a new contract. If they do not, Wang will become a free agent.
Wang starred for the New York Yankees from 2005-2008, posting a 54-20 record, before suffering a foot injury in June 2008 that kept him out the rest of the year.

He returned in 2009 but performed poorly and suffered a torn right shoulder capsule that required surgery in July 2009. He was expected to return to the mound for the Nationals midway through the 2010 season, but his recovery was slower than anticipated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Implication of Nobel Economics Prize

TEXT.P: Economics is in a serious dilemma as a "science."

Unlike chemistry and physics, which study inanimate objects, economics studies human behavior and its relationship with markets. Yet it still insists in borrowing physics as an analytic tool. This leads to many theories that exist only in a non-human environment.
It is little wonder, therefore, that the world has failed to recover from the global financial crisis over the past two years despite the use of the strongest possible cures prescribed by economists.

Lebanese-born bestselling author Nassim Nicholas Taleb recently threatened to sue the Swedish Central Bank for awarding the 1990 Nobel Prize for Economics to three economists for their risk models, which according to Taleb were responsible for the breakdown of the global financial system.

We welcome Taleb's action, because this allows the world to examine the huge, irremediable gap that exists between economics and reality. Only if we see economics in a calm and rational manner can economics become a true blessing for human society. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 13, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: China Merchants Bank seeks to open office in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 12:35:38 (By Hsieh Jiun-wei and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: China Merchants Bank has filed an application to open a representative office in Taiwan, the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said Tuesday.
"The commission has received the bank's application and will consult with the central bank about the bank's request soon, " FSC Chief Secretary Ling Tung- liang said.
China Merchants Bank, founded in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, in 1987, is the third Chinese bank to seek approval to set up an office on the island.
On Sept. 23, the FSC gave Bank of China and Bank of Communications the green light to establish offices in Taiwan after they had filed applications earlier in the month.

To ensure domestic financial stability, the FSC said, it will review the application from China Merchants Bank and check whether it meets the requirements stipulated by regulations governing financial exchanges and investments across the Taiwan Strait.

According to the FSC, China Merchants Bank had total assets of 2.22 trillion Chinese yuan (US$333 billion) as of the end of June, making the bank the 65th largest in the world. It posted NT$17 billion in pretax profit in the first half of this year.
As of the end of June, the bank had a return on assets of 1.21 percent, a return on equity of 4.27 percent, a non-performing loan ratio of 0.67 percent and a capital adequacy ratio of 11.06 percent.
China Merchants Bank, which operates 52 branches and 738 sub-branches in China, has a branch in New York and another one in Hong Kong.
Under existing regulations, Chinese banks are required to operate a representative office in Taiwan for no less than one year before seeking approval to upgrade the office into a branch.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourists arrive in Kaohsiung on cruise liner
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 12:37:54 (By Chen Chao-fu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A group of more than 1,200 Chinese tourists arrived in Kaohsiung Wednesday aboard a cruise liner.
The group was greeted at the port by indigenous dancers and electronic dance featuring the Chinese deity San Tai Tzu. Stands had also been set up selling local specialties.
According to one of the visitors, cruise vacations to Taiwan are very popular in China because it is an easy way to travel with friends and relatives.
The group's itinerary in Kaohsiung was listed as including popular tourist attractions in the area such as the Lotus Pond and the Fo Guang Shan Monastery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Flora Expo promotion shifts into high gear

TEXT.P: With the curtain set to rise on the Taipei International Flora Expo in 25 days, the city government is making all-out efforts to promote the first-ever event of its kind in Taiwan globally.

On Tuesday, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin invited renowned Taiwan-born singer Betty Pai, better known locally as Pai Chia-li, to serve as "the global publicity ambassador" of the flower expo, which will take place from Nov. 6 through April 25, 2011.
Pai, who now lives in Indonesia, said after accepting a certificate for her new job that she will do whatever she can to help promote the expo, even though she is not in Taiwan.
Meanwhile, the city government said it will host a star-studded concert Oct. 17 at the Taipei City Hall plaza to drum up support for the floral show.
The following are excerpts of the local media coverage of the issue:
China Times:

While conferring the "flora expo ambassador" certificate to Pai, Hau said he hopes the retired singer will use her international reputation and personal charisma to help upgrade the Taipei Flora Expo's global profile.
In response, Pai said it is a great honor for her to serve as the flower show's spokeswoman.

"I take pride in helping promote the event and I will do my utmost to attract as many foreigners as possible to visit the show, " said Pai, who held the reputation of being the "most beautiful TV show host" in her 1970s heyday.

Hau also used the occasion to thank the many heavyweight pop idols and rock bands scheduled to perform at the Sunday concert, including Jay Chou, Wu Bai, Lin Chi-ling, Mayday and S.H.E., for their support for the city government's cause. (Oct. 13, 2010).
United Daily News:

Local people have shown keen interest in the upcoming expo as a larger-than- expected number of uninvited ordinary people have swarmed to the 91.8-hectare exhibition site that has been opened since Oct. 9 for a trial run, city officials said Tuesday.

According to the city government's plan, only certified volunteers and invited guests were to have been allowed to enter the exhibition ground in the first stage of the trial run from Oct. 9-20. However, many uninvited people entered the site in the first four days of the trial run, causing protests from people who have bought tickets for entry after the show is formally inaugurated.
City government spokeswoman Chao Hsin-ping said uninvited citizens were allowed to enter mainly because the invited volunteers did not show up in the numbers expected.
"As the number of people at the exhibition site is capped at 10,000 during the trial period, if the ceiling is not met, ordinary citizens are allowed to enter," Chao explained.

From Friday, the trial period will enter the second stage, in which volunteers with invitation cards will be eligible to enter the exhibition halls, while uninvited people will only be allowed to visit the open-air exhibition grounds, Chao said.

In the first three days of the trial run, Chao said, the city government collected 2,478 responses from invited volunteers to gauge their opinions of the facilities. Among them, 73 percent gave positive responses, she added. (Oct. 13, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: New BOFT director to take office Oct. 18
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 14:06:58 (By Lin shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Cho Shih-chao, who was recently named to take over as director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) , is expected to assume his new post on Oct. 18, the BOFT said Wednesday.

Cho, who at present is Taiwan's representative to Kuwait, will return to Taipei Oct. 17 and take the official seal the next day from BOFT acting director- general Chang Chun-fu, with Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Sheng-chung serving as witness.
Former BOFT Director-General Huang Chih-peng has already assumed his new position as Taiwan's representative in Vietnam and cannot be present at the ceremony.
Chen Ming-shy, head of the economic and trade division of Taiwan's representative office in Spain, will take over as BOFT deputy director-general the same day.

After taking office, Cho is expected to play an important role in pushing for cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations by the end of March 2011 on trade, services, and dispute resolution mechanisms under the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed in late June, the BOFT said.

Before being dispatched to Kuwait, Cho had served as the director of the Department of Investment Services under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the director of the MOEA's Department of Economic Trade Affairs, the BOFT said.

Meanwhile, Huang said in Vietnam that he will do his best to improve ties between Taiwan and Vietnam after the MOFA admitted Tuesday that Vietnam's government has interfered with an annual cocktail party held by Taiwan's representative office in Hanoi to celebrate the island's Double Ten National Day since 2007.
Huang said he will enhance communications with the Vietnamese government to protect Taiwan's interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County to host walking event for Double Nine Festival

TEXT.P: A walking event to promote fitness is scheduled to take place at a park near the Erchong Floodway in Taipei County Oct. 16 to celebrate the Double Nine Festival, the county government announced Wednesday.

It is hoped the event will attract as many as 10,000 participants who will walk through a riverside park at the floodway to celebrate the festival, which occurs on the ninth day of the ninth lunar month to mark respect for the elderly.
Those who take part will receive souvenirs and numbered tickets for a lucky draw, which will offer a car as the first prize, said the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: President confident in outcome of Taiwan-U.S. talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 15:18:20 (By Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed confidence Wednesday that Taiwan will soon reach agreements with the United States on a number of bilateral issues that are under negotiation, including the sale of F-16 C/D fighters to Taiwan.
Other major items on the agenda are the inclusion of Taiwan in the U.S. visa waiver program and the signing of an extradition treaty.

"Although some of the problems cannot be resolved in a short period of time, I believe they will be overcome with mutual trust, " Ma told visiting U.S. congressman Bob Inglis, a senior Republican on the House's Subcommittee on Asia, the Pacific and the Global Environment under the Committee on Foreign Affairs.
Ma said he has worked to restore mutual trust with the United States and improve relations with China since his inauguration in May 2008.
The efforts have produced good results, with Taiwan-U.S. talks under the framework of the bilateral Trade and Investment Framework Agreement set to be resumed at the end of this year, he noted.
With cross-Taiwan Strait ties improving, Washington no longer needs to choose sides between Taipei and Beijing and can develop friendly relations with both at the same time, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor groups pan CLA over reward plan to catch runaway workers

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs' (CLA's) plan to offer a NT$5,000 (US$161.29) reward for catching runaway migrant workers elicited an angry reaction Wednesday from labor rights groups, which accused the council of ignoring the root of the problem.

"The CLA has failed to resolve the crux of the matter, which is the heavy exploitation that many migrant workers are subjected to. Putting a reward on those who run away will not solve the problem, " said Son You-lian, secretary- general of Taiwan's Labor Front.
The CLA on Tuesday said it plans to revamp its reward system by giving informants the NT$5,000 reward for each person they help catch rather than for confirmed reports on runaways.
The council also plans to raise the existing NT$2,000 reward for nabbing illegal employers and unscrupulous brokerage firms by 10 to 25 times.
Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training Deputy-Director Liao Wen-jen said the policy's details will be announced in two weeks.
Son and the Taiwan International Worker's Association (TIWA) also questioned whether the CLA had looked at the issue from the broader perspective of how many foreign workers should be in Taiwan.

"What we want the government to do is examine the legitimacy and practicality of the overall policy of importing workers into Taiwan. Do we really need that many foreign workers in Taiwan?" Son asked.
Unless the CLA has enough safeguards in place to ensure the safety of the migrants' working conditions, he added, the government should think twice before opening Taiwan's doors to them.

The dangers foreign workers face in Taiwan and the problem of runaway workers came into focus again last month when six Indonesian workers -- all undocumented -- were killed in an accident at a construction site off National Freeway No. 6 in central Taiwan.
Speaking to reporters at the Legislative Yuan on Wednesday, Premier Wu Den-yih estimated that there were 30,000 undocumented foreign workers at large in Taiwan,
According to the TIWA, there are actually 33,510 runaway foreign workers from 2005 to the present in Taiwan who are still unaccounted for.
Wu told reporters that the Cabinet has already requested the CLA, the National Immigration Agency, and the National Police Agency to come up with suitable measures to locate the runaways.
The premier added, however, that related government agencies should also handle the matter carefully to ensure that the workers are fairly treated, especially those who were exploited on the job.

CLA Chairwoman Wang Ju-hsuan said at the beginning of October that the council will hold a meeting in two weeks to discuss the possibility of allowing migrant workers to change employers at will -- a policy strongly supported by labor groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.20 percent

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.20 percent Wednesday on a technical rebound from the previous session, but the gains were compromised by selling in large-cap electronics stocks amid renewed concerns over the earnings outlook, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 16.44 points to 8,106.66, after moving between 8,067.87 and 8,143.19, on turnover of NT$104.80 billion (US$3.38 billion).

The market opened up 0.33 percent and buying in select old economy stocks lifted the index to the day's high, while fears of falling global demand for high-tech products capped the gains on the broader market, the dealers said.
A total of 1,680 stocks closed up and 1,975 were down, with 400 remaining unchanged.
The paper and pulp sector scored the highest gains, up 2.13 percent on global rising pulp prices, according to the dealers.
Plastics and chemicals rose 1.39 percent, construction stocks added 0.6 percent, foodstuffs gained 0.44 percent, cement stocks added 0.38 percent and textile stocks closed up 0.08 percent.
The financial sector rose 0.06 percent, while machinery and electronics stocks gained 0.01 percent.

"With recent U.S. economic data pointing to a sluggish economic climate, fears of a slowing fourth quarter for the electronics sector came back to haunt investors, " Concord Securities analyst Allen Lin said.

Lin said a rising New Taiwan dollar further dampened market sentiment as investors were afraid that the local high-tech sector will suffer foreign exchange losses that are expected to impact fourth quarter earnings.

"As the high-tech sector remained lackluster, it was difficult for the market to get out of the current trade range, although some rotational buying boosted the traditional industrial sector, " Lin said.
Lin said that ahead of the strong technical resistance at around the 8,200 point-mark, the market is expected to continue in consolidation mode.
Among the large electronics stocks, smartphone maker HTC fell 4.29 percent to close at NT$669.00 and cell phone camera lens producer Largan Precision shed 6.54 percent to finish at NT$543.00.
In the paper and pulp sector, Shihlin Paper rose 1.62 percent to end the day at NT$72.60 and Chung Hwa Pulp gained 2.55 percent to NT$16.10 at the close of trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: British biochemist to be awarded lectureship in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 17:08:26 (By Lin Szu-yu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: British biochemist Raymond Dwek will be awarded the 2010 K.T. Wang Bioorganic Chemistry Lectureship, the Taiwan-based organizer of the award said Wednesday.
The K.T. Foundation, in honor of Taiwanese biochemist K.T. Wang, was established in 2000 by former Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh and his successor Wong Chi-huey.

Every year, the foundation awards the K.T. Wang Bioorganic Chemistry Lectureship to a world-renowned scholar and invites the recipient to Taiwan to give a lecture and to share his or her research experience.
The presentation ceremony is scheduled for Thursday at National Taiwan University, according to the foundation.
Immediately after the ceremony, Dwek, presently director of the Glycobiology Institute at Oxford University, will give a lecture titled "Glycobiology -- Growing the Oxford Brand," at the same venue.

Glycobiology is the study of the structure, biosynthesis, and biology of saccharides (sugar chains or glycans) , which are widely distributed in nature and are essential components of all living things.
On Friday, he will give another lecture titled "The Glycan Shield of HIV -- An Antiviral and Vaccine Target" at the Academia Sinica, the foundation said.
The K.T. Wang Foundation is dedicated to promoting bioorganic chemistry research.

DOC.HEADLINE: Judges urged to play leading role in judicial reform
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 17:26:50 (By Lai Yu-chia and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Judges should take the lead in judicial reform in order to win back public trust in the country's court system, new Judicial Yuan President Rai Hau-min said Wednesday.

"Judges should act like a 'get-out-the-vote organizer' in an election campaign in order to speed up much-anticipated judicial reform to restore public faith in our judiciary and court system, " Rai said after accepting the post's official seal from the top judicial body's acting president, Hsieh Tsay-chuan, at a changeover ceremony.
In the wake of a spate of scandals involving senior judges that have marred the judiciary's image, Rai said restoring public trust in the judicial system is his priority concern and task.
"Integrity, professionalism and public trust will be our top reform goals," he added.

Rai, a veteran lawyer who once served as chairman of the Central Election Commission, said he will direct the formation of a national judicial reform committee to work out a detailed reform agenda within a year.
"In carrying out reform programs, we will follow the principles of establishing an incorruptible, transparent, responsive and efficient judicial system," Rai pledged.
Also assuming office Wednesday was Judicial Yuan Vice President Su Yeong-chin, a law professor and a confidant of President Ma Ying-jeou who once headed the National Communications Commission.
On Aug. 24, President Ma nominated Rai as the new Judicial Yuan head, with Su Yeong-chin as his deputy.

The two Judicial Yuan posts became vacant after Lai In-jaw and Hsieh Tsay-chuan resigned in July as president and vice president, respectively, to take responsibility for a scandal in which three senior judges were detained for alleged corruption.
The nominations of Rai and Su were confirmed by the Legislative Yuan in two separate votes last Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Wednesday, dropping NT$0.11 to close at NT$30.960.
Turnover totaled US$709 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.070 and moved to a low of NT$30.780 before rebounding.
Dealers said rebounds of other Asia currencies against the U.S. dollar on the same day prompted local investors to buy the New Taiwan dollar, which pressed the U.S. dollar back below NT$30.960.
The greenback rose above the NT$31.000 level a day earlier as investors rushed to pocket strong gains posted by the local unit in recent trading sessions.
The dealers said buying of the New Taiwan dollar resumed as the market opened Wednesday, with investors taking cues from a strong showing of other Asian currencies, in particular the Chinese yuan.
The central bank again intervened in late trading to slow down the pace of the local currency's rise against the U.S. dollar, the dealers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity offers free fish to poor children, elderly
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 18:18:54 (By Lee Hsien-feng and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: An initiative that helps poor families by distributing free fish to them will continue again this year in an effort to bridge the health gap between the rich and the less well-off, an association for the underprivileged said Wednesday.

Under the initiative begun in 2008, at least 50,000 fish will be distributed for children living in poverty and old people living alone in Yunlin, Nantou and Chiayi counties, the Care of Underprivileged Communities Society said at a press conference in Taipei.
Two mothers who have previously been given the free fish attended the event with their children, one of whom said she seldom cooks fish for her child because the family cannot afford it.
"When my kid told me the fish we were given was really delicious, I got mixed feelings. I felt kind of sad but touched by society's warmth," said the young mom known by surname as Lai.
Legislator Chang Chia-chun, one of the initiators of the plan, said the charity drive is expected to continue until next January.
The program was launched out of concern over the gap in development between children in the cities and the countryside, said Yayu Wong, the co-organizer of the project.

Doctors in Taiwan have found that children in disadvantaged communities fall behind their urban peers in physical growth and intelligence due to insufficient intake of fish, which contains nutrients essential to brain development, Wong noted.
He added the society gave away more than 45,000 fish to 4,000 poor families from 2008 through last January.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's film industry ready to make a splash

TEXT.P: From the adventures of a peeping Tom to Chinese martial arts action to the comical yet touching tale of a blind man and his niece, the Taiwanese film industry is posed to tickle funny bones and jerk tears with 15 new films to be released in the next six months.

The wave of new movies signifies the once-waning Taiwanese motion film sector is reviving on a steady and upward pace, Government Information Office Minister Johnny Chiang said at a press conference on Wednesday.

"In recent years, the Taiwanese film industry has been performing extremely well in terms of both quality and quantity. I believe the upcoming 15 films will also be successful blockbusters, " said Chiang, calling on Taiwanese directors and producers to set Hollywood as their ultimate goal.

The 15 films slated to hit the silver screen include "When Love Comes" directed by Chang Tso-chi, who is currently at the Pusan International Film Festival to showcase the movie in the prestigious "Gala Presentation" category. The film has also won 14 Golden Horse nominations, including Best Supporting Actor and Actress.

Oscar-nominated director John Woo's "Reign of Assassins" is a US$10 million action-packed epic set during the time of ancient Chinese warlords and sword fighters. The movie is already set to be distributed in over 60 countries, including the United States, said co-executive producer Tang Chai-yang.

Described by some film critics as a Chinese version of Brangelina's "Mr. and Mrs. Smith, " the film features international superstar Michelle Yeoh and South Korea's Jung Woo-sung as a married couple, with each spouse seemingly unaware the other is a clandestine world-class assassin.

"The movie is completely unique from other Chinese martial arts films such as 'Hero' or 'Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon' because it is not based on any historical figure or event. It is purely about the warrior and fighter society of ancient China," said Tang.

Taiwan's first 3-D animation film "Memory Loss" is scheduled to dazzle moviegoers in January as the audience accompanies the young heroine, Hsiao Ta, on an incredible journey to a magical place where lost memories are stored.

Taiwan's sweetheart Megan Lai will star in the romantic comedy "Will You Still Love Me" with eye candy actor Tony Yang, who is also starring in three other films: "Snowfall in Taipei, " "Tempest of First Love, " and "Dancing Without You, " which features mega singer and actress Vivian Hsu.

One of the most noticeable films in the ensemble of 15 is "My Blind Uncle, " featuring Lin Fu-sheng, who is a 39-year-old visually impaired masseur in real life, and a young Teng Yun-ting, who plays a traumatized niece learning to live with her blind uncle.

DOC.HEADLINE: Subsidy program launched for electric cars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 19:03:30 (By Stacy Wu, Jeffrey Wu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The government launched a subsidy program Wednesday in an effort to increase the number of electric cars on the roads in the next three years as part of a long- term plan to boost the industry.

Woody T.J. Duh, director-general of the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said the government has set aside about NT$2.3 billion (US$74 million) in subsidies for 10 cases, with the aim of getting 3,000 electric cars on the roads by 2013 and increasing the number to 60,000 by 2016.

The bureau said the program -- which offers subsidies of up to 40 percent of the vehicle budgets for the cases whose applications for the subsidies are accepted -- will encourage local companies to use the electric vehicles.

"Taiwan's dense population and short distances between cities make it suitable for developing intelligent electric vehicles, " Duh said during the International Forum of Intelligent Electric Vehicle Pilot Run that took place in Taipei.
The program is expected to generate NT$120 billion in benefit for the manufacturing sector and NT$31.2 billion for the service sector over a six-year period, as well as to provide 24,000 jobs.

Jacques Saint-Marc, general manager of a group that promotes electric vehicles in France, said at the half-day forum that the French public enjoy a subsidy of 5,000 euros plus tax breaks when they purchase an electric car.

Peter Nimmo, chief executive officer of ECOtality Australia, a company committed to developing clean energy technologies, said that more effort should be made that goes beyond just the subsidy program.
"Government support in the early stages is vital," he noted. "For the long term, battery-charging infrastructure should be sustainable without public funding."

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma's daughters not excluded from special service protection: NSB
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 19:14:56 (By Chiachen Hsieh & Brar Lee)

TEXT.P: The National Security Bureau (NSB) said Wednesday that it has offered protection for the safety of President Ma Ying-jeou's two daughters who worked in the United States.

The NSB said in a press release that it has required its U.S. counterparts to offer protection for President Ma's daughters, who have been lived in that country, in their working places and residences.
The NSB's Special Service Center is responsible the safety of Ma's daughters when they return to Taiwan, it added.
