The NSB made the statement in response to a report by the Liberty Times newspaper that same day saying that the Presidential Office and the NSB has reached an agreement to solve a long-term controversy on whom should be protected by the NSB's special service agents.

President Ma has clearly designated the name list of the individuals covered by NSB's special service protection program which excludes Ma's daughters but includes his mother, who doesn't live together with the president, according to the newspaper.
The NSB said that under the Enforcement Regulations of Special Service, the president's family, including his daughters, are subject to protection by the NSB.

DOC.HEADLINE: Solar cell maker expands business to module production
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 19:16:39 (By Maranda Hsu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-based solar cell firm - Motech Industries, Inc - said Wednesday it has extended its foothold to photovoltaic (PV) module production by unveiling two models of poly-crystalline modules under its brand name.

Solar cells are devices that convert sunlight into electricity by the photovoltaic effect. Solar cells are welded together into a matrix, which are sealed with other components to produce photovoltaic modules, also known as solar panels.

The company said its two new models -- IM60 and IM72 modules -- have been certified by Underwriter Laboratories Inc. and International Electrotechnical Commission, and the first shipments have hit the U.S. market.
The two models, powered by Motech's cells, are designed for both residential and commercial markets, the company said.
Motech said the PV module production is the company's efforts to engage in vertical integration and expand its role in the solar energy equipment supply chain.
"Our quest to enter the module business is to provide more value to our customers and help them succeed, " Motech President and Chief Executive Office P.H. Chang said in a statement.

"Our intent is to produce our modules in alignment with the market demand and to also fulfill the requirements of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA) so that our products are made in the U.S," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health education material contest winners awarded

TEXT.P: Several health and medical institutions that entered the 2010 health education material contest organized by the Department of Health (DOH) were awarded Wednesday for their outstanding entries.

This year, a total of 335 health-related materials were submitted by hospitals and clinics, health authorities and non-government organizations as entries in the contest, which has taken place every two years since 2004, said Kung Hsien- lan, deputy director-general of the Bureau of Health Promotion under the DOH.
The materials, divided into four categories -- posters, brochures, booklets and videos -- were evaluated by eight experts in the relevant fields for accuracy, readability and creativity.
Kung said that the winning materials -- 12 awards of excellence and 20 awards of merit -- had already been put online on the Health 99 Education Resource, the bureau's website.
One of the contestants, Lee Li-ting of the John Tung Foundation, said that putting together a promotion brochure on health and medical issues is no easy task.

Lee's team, which won an award of excellence for a simple diagnostic questionnaire for college students with possible depression, spent about one year collecting medical information, consulting psychologists and designing the questions.
The questionnaire is already being used by Tamkang University, Fu Jen Catholic University and Soochow University in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to launch immigrant care network next year: NIA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 19:47:50 (By Ni Kuo-yen and Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: Government agencies, local authorities and social groups will create a care network to help immigrants nationwide from next year, Hsieh Li-kung, director- general of the National Immigration Agency (NIA) , said at a conference in Kinmen County Wednesday.

Hsieh said that the network, which will seek to integrate resources among the agency, local governments and non-governmental organizations, would start a trial run later this year in 10 cities and counties including Kinmen County, Taipei County and Kaohsiung County.
All the nation's 25 local governments will eventually be able to share and benefit from the network, Hsieh said.
"We really want to invite all kinds of resources from every possible channel to demonstrate our commitment to respecting different cultures," Hsieh said.
According to the Ministry of the Interior, the number of foreign spouses in Taiwan had surpassed 430,000 by August, accounting for 1.9 percent of the total population in Taiwan.
Kinmen County Magistrate Li Wo-shi said the new immigrants were a vital part of the county, adding that it would fully support the new integration to help assimilate various cultures to Kinmen.

By the end of this August, new immigrants made up 1,958 of Kinmen's 95,873 residents, or 2.04 percent, the Kinmen County government said. Of the 32,248 households in Kinmen, one in 16.5 includes immigrant family members, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most Taiwanese office workers not happy with job: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 19:52:08 ( By Hsieh Chun-wei and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: A majority of Taiwan's office workers were not happy with their jobs, mainly because of the long work hours and low salary, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.
More than 60 percent of the respondents to the online survey conducted by two job banks, iJob and Jcase, said the longer they worked, the less happy they were.
Fifty-six percent even said they have often put on fake smiles in the workplace, especially when talking to colleagues they do not like.
Almost 80 percent of the office workers even said they get depressed whenever they think about their job.
If the level of happiness could be measured by a 1-to-10-point scale, the office workers would only get an average point of 5.65, the survey said.
The imbalance between wages and work hours have brought down the happiness level, Hsu Chin-huang, general manager of Jcase, said.

The report also indicated that more than 56 percent of the workers said they will feel happy only if they get a pay raise, while nearly 30 percent said they would be happier if the colleagues or managers they loath have been punished or leave the workplace.
In terms of the reasons why the respondents hold negative attitudes against their colleagues, the survey found 87 percent of the office workers have been betrayed at work.

Lin Yu-mei, marketing manager of iJob, said in order to create a harmonious working environment, workers should learn how to deal with stress since it is the main factor causing conflicts between colleagues.
The online survey, carried out from Sept. 13 to Oct. 1, collected a total of 1,314 valid samples with a confidence level of 95 percent and a margin of error of 2.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scenic lake area to open after yearlong recovery from typhoon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 19:56:19 (By Tyson Lu and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Jiaming Lake, a popular hiking spot in eastern Taiwan, will reopen to the public in early November after being closed for more than a year following a major typhoon, a forestry official said Wednesday.
The 11.5 kilometer trail linking the Siangyang National Forest Recreation Area and Jiaming Lake was seriously damaged in August last year by Typhoon Morakot, which claimed more than 700 lives.

The high-altitude lake in Yushan National Park will be open to 70 visitors per day starting in early next month, the Taitung District Office under the Cabinet- level Forestry Bureau told the Central News Agency.
After a yearlong restoration, the oval lake, with sapphire water that is said to be "as beautiful as angels' tears, " has become "even more charming," office director Chang Tieh-chu said.

The hiking trails have been fully repaired, with wildlife such as Formosan yellow-throated martens and Taiwan field mice seen by office staffers in the area. Alishan salamanders, a protected species endemic to Taiwan, have also inhabited a refuge cottage.
To avoid disturbing the restored serenity in the area, the number of visitors will be limited, Chang noted. People who are interested can apply for entrance online with the office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's opera performance enthralls German audience
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 20:08:48 (By Lin Yu-li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese opera troupe Ming Hwa Yuan wowed a packed German audience at the Admiralspalast theater in Berlin Tuesday with its fascinating signature show, The Living Buddha.
It marked the first time that a Taiwanese opera, also known as Gezaixi, has ever been performed on a German stage.

The play was also the opener of the 80-year-old Taiwanese troupe's first-ever performance tour in Europe, although it had performed previously in individual European cities, including in Paris more than 10 years ago.

To help German theater goers understand the plot of the opera, the troupe projected German-language subtitles of the libretto on both sides of the stage. The audience seemed to be very receptive to the show as they often burst into laughter throughout the play. All troupe members received enthusiastic applause during the curtain call.

Kristina Weinert, a German ballet dancer, said that for Europeans, the show was like a fairy tale full of humor that were often seen in real everyday life. Although the show contained cultural elements that were strange to her, Weinert said she found great fascination in it.
Guenter Knabe, a journalist with Voice of Germany's Asian department, said he believes that Gezaixi should not be too difficult for European audiences to understand.

At the end of the show, Taiwan's first lady Chow Mei-ching, who is accompanying the troupe on the tour, stood up from her seat to greet and thank the audience in her capacity as honorary director of the Ming Hwa Yuan troupe.
Speaking at a cocktail reception marking the success of the show, Chow said she takes pride in accompanying the popular opera group on its ongoing six-country European performance tour.
"I hope more Taiwanese performing groups will present shows in Germany to boost cultural exchanges," she added.
Chow also exchanged greetings and chats with German officials, parliamentarians, journalists and diplomats of Taiwan's diplomatic allies stationed in Germany.
In the coming few days, Chow will visit the Berlin municipal library and several tourist attractions before returning to Taipei Oct. 16.
The Ming Hwa Yuan troupe will give one more show in Berlin Wednesday and will then perform in six other European cities -- Prague, Vienna, Paris, London, Edinburgh and Amsterdam.
Apart from formal performances, the troupe will also hold workshops at universities to introduce the traditional Taiwanese art form to audiences in Europe during its 10-day tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu Yen-hsun advances to second round in Shanghai
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 20:22:50 (By Kang Shih-jen & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tennis player Lu Yen-hsun defeated host Wu Di 6-1, 6-4 in a first- round match of the 2010 Shanghai Rolex Masters early Wednesday.
World No. 42 Lu took only one hour and six minutes to beat the world No. 399 Chinese player, landing four aces in the process.
In second-round play, Lu will face world No. 58 Andreas Seppi of Italy, who upset No. 15 Marin Cilic of Croatia 6-2, 6-2.

Lu was originally scheduled to play Wu late Tuesday evening on an outdoor court at Shanghai's Qi Zhong Stadium, but the match was rained out. They faced off on an indoor practice court Wednesday because of more rain.

The Shanghai Masters is one of a series of nine tennis tournaments on the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) tour, which includes Indian Wells, Miami, Monte Carlo, Rome, Madrid, Canada (Montreal or Toronto), Cincinnati, Shanghai and Paris.
The series constitutes the most prestigious tournaments in men's tennis after the four Grand Slam events, and is mandatory for the top male players on the professional circuit.
The Shanghai event has attracted more than 100 tennis professionals this year, including every member of the top 20, headed by world No. 1 Rafael Nadal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tea growers see profits nearly double as quality improves
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 22:17:41 (By Yang Su-min and Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: Tea growers in Taiwan have seen profits nearly double since last year thanks to a government-sponsored program that promotes the growth of high-quality leaves, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Wednesday.

Since late 2009, the council has provided consulting and advanced techniques for applying fertilizer or medicine, helping high-end tea growers obtain certifications including ISO 22000 and HACCP, Tsai Hsien-tsung, director of the COA's Tea Research and Extention Station's Wenshan Branch, said.
Taiwanese tea has become more competitive against foreign teas, Tsai said, noting that Starbucks Beijing and European tea merchants have placed orders.
Tea growers in areas such as Taipei County's Pinglin and Sansia townships, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu County, and Nantou County's Mingjian Jhushan townships have seen profits rise, he said.
Tsai said that as tea grown in the Taipei Sansia area has no pesticide residue, its price has risen from NT$70 (US$2) for 600 grams last year to NT$120 for now.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan welcomes Hong Kong's plan to set up office in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 22:43:05 (By Eva Feng & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Wednesday welcomed a plan by the Hong Kong government to set up its office in the country, according to the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , the government agency in charge of policies toward mainland China.

Hong Kong's Chief Executive Donald Tsang Yam-kuen said in his administrative report to the legislature earlier Wednesday that his government will discuss with Taiwan plans to establish a "comprehensive" office in Taipei.
In response, a MAC official who asked not to be named, confirmed that both sides have begun contacts with each other on the proposed office.

The official said the Hong Kong government will submit a concrete plan, including details about the office's structure, operations and number of personnel, for discussions with Taipei by the end of this year.

The new office will be another breakthrough in bilateral relations between Taiwan and Hong Kong following the establishment of two semi-official organizations -- the Taipei-based Taiwan-Hong Kong Economic and Cultural Cooperation Council and the Hong Kong-based Hong Kong-Taiwan Economic and Cultural Cooperation and Promotion Council -- earlier this year to deepen exchanges between the two sides.

Taiwan-Hong Kong ties only began to warm up following improved relations between Taipei and Beijing after President Ma Ying-jeou took office in 2008. The former British colony returned to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two more Taiwan banks allowed to open branches in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 22:45:43 (By Yu-pin Tien and Jay Chen)

TEXT.P: Two more Taiwan banks have been given approval to set up branches on mainland China, bringing to six the number of local financial institutions that have gotten the green light to do business in the mainland.
Hua Nan Bank and Cathay United Bank hope to open a branch each, in Shenzhen and Shanghai respectively, before the end of the year, bank officials said Wednesday.
The approval, given by China's Banking Regulatory Commission, came about a month after four other major banks of Taiwan were allowed to set up branches in China.

In mid-September, the Chinese banking regulator approved plans by the Land Bank of Taiwan, Taiwan Cooperative Bank, First Bank and Chang Hwa Bank to set up branches in Shanghai and two cities in neighboring Jiansu Province.

No Chinese banks have been allowed to set up branches in Taiwan although the Bank of China and the Bank of Communications have been given permission by Taiwanese regulators to have a representative office here, a usual step prior to officially opening a branch.
A third Chinese institution, China Merchants Bank, has filed an application to establish a representative office on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: Preparations for Taiwan-Singapore pact talks going smoothly: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 22:50:50 ( By Lin Shu-yuan and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Preparations for conducting formal negotiations on an economic cooperation agreement between Taiwan and Singapore have been going smoothly, Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday.
Speaking on the sidelines of a ceremony for the 11th National Standardization Award in Taipei, Wu said the two countries still have more work to do before official talks on the trade deal can begin.
Taiwan and Singapore agreed to explore the feasibility of signing a trade agreement in August this year, and since then they have been in close contact regarding the issue, Wu said.
Taiwan and Singapore still have to decide who will head the negotiations for each side, he said, adding that the two countries would alternate hosting discussions.
According to Wu, Taiwan has also initiated talks with Japan over the signing of an investment protection agreement.
Wu said Taiwan will seek all types of free trade agreements in any field that will help the country develop and prosper.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's lowest housing supply ratio not a problem: official

TEXT.P: Taiwan has recorded the lowest ratio of housing supply to households in the second quarter of this year in 10 years, but that does not mean there is an inadequate supply of housing here, said the Construction and Planning Agency Wednesday.
The ratio of 99.89 to 100 -- meaning there are 99.89 units of housing for every 100 households -- is still a relatively healthy ratio, according to Wang An- Chiang, an official of the agency.
Wang attributed the lower ratio to inconsistency between household registration and residency, which has resulted in an increase in the number of households registered.

For example, he added, some people buy or rent property in a popular school district without actually living there, but they register their kids under that address so that the kids can go to a prestigious school in the neighborhood, practices contributing to inflated household number.
At the same time, the ratio was also affected by an underestimate of the housing supply, Wang said.

More than 7.86 million units of housing were registered in the second quarter. The main reason for the underestimation is that the basic supply figure comes from the last population census taken nearly 10 years ago. Wang said the agency will adjust the number once the next census, scheduled to begin later this year, is completed.
Meanwhile, central Taiwan's Taichung City has the highest ratio of housing units to households - a ratio of 118.37 to 100.
Cities and counties with a housing supply ratio of over 100 percent include Keelung City, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City, and Taipei County, according to the statistics.
The outlying Kinmen Island has the lowest figure of below 50 percent, while Penghu County, Yulin County and Taitung County were all below 90 percent. (By Hsieh Chun-wei and C.Y. Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade-related Taiwan-China dialogue platform to begin this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 23:07:14 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A platform that will allow regular dialogue between Taiwan and China will be set up and put to use before the end of this year, to deal with issues or disputes related to the landmark trade deal signed between the two sides in June, Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday.

Through this dialogue platform, Wu said, the two sides will consult with each other on matters related to the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) , as well as other economic issues of mutual concern.

Despite decades of booming trade between Taiwan and China, as well as billions of dollars of Taiwanese investments in China, no such platform has existed between the two sides for investors or business people to resolve disputes. And since there are no formal ties between the two sides, there were no government representative offices in each other's territory.
Taiwanese investors encountering problems in the mainland, for example, could only go through China's government offices for help, with no representation by Taiwanese authorities.

The ECFA reduces tariffs on exports, eases or lifts non-tariff trade barriers and gives each side greater access to the other's market - which could potentially bring about more trade between the two sides.

The pact stipulates that a "cross-strait economic cooperation committee" should be created to handle follow-up negotiations or disputes. Since the trade deal took effect on Sept. 12, Wu said, the platform should be established, Wu said.

As to when the platform will be inaugurated, the premier said it depends on when the two sides' existing quasi-official intermediary bodies -- the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), finalize their consultations.

According to Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Sheng-chung, the platform or "committee" will comprise several working panels in charge of merchandise trade, service trade, dispute mechanism and investment affairs.
The panels will be headed by department or bureau chiefs under the Ministry of Economic affairs who will meet with their Chinese counterparts biannually, Lin said.
He added that both sides have reached a preliminary consensus that the "committee" will be headed by a vice ministerial-level official from each side.

DOC.HEADLINE: No preconditions attached to peace overture: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 23:35:05 (By M.K. Her and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday that Taiwan would not accept any preconditions from China in its overture to dismantle missiles targeting Taiwan.

"If Taiwan and China want to build mutual trust and ensure peace, neither side should set any preconditions or attach any terms to the cause, " Wu told a legislative committee when fielding questions on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
"The two sides should be fully sincere so as to work best together and guarantee progress toward peace," he added.

Yang Yi, spokesman for the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council, said earlier in the day that both sides of the strait could start contact on military issues, including confidence building measures (CBMs) through appropriate methods.
Yang's remarks came after Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao suggested in late September that Beijing could "eventually" remove its missiles pointing at Taiwan "sometime in the future."
A spokesman for China's defense ministry also said recently that under the "one China" precondition, Beijing would consider removing the missiles it has aimed at Taiwan.
"But how can we accept Beijing's offer if the 'one China' precondition is attached?" Wu asked.

Stressing that conditions are "not yet ripe" for Taiwan and China to hold a political dialogue, the premier said that Taiwan would not agree to proposals calling for the abolishment of the "imaginary border" in the strait, because doing so would leave Taiwan unable to defend itself.

Citing results of a public opinion poll, Wu said around 43 percent of Taiwan's people think the government's pace in handling cross-strait affairs is adequate, while 37 percent, a two-year high, think it is too fast and 12 percent believe it is too slow.
"Judging from this, it is clear that we should not move too fast in dealing with China, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Italian sends tired Lu crashing out of Shanghai Masters

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tennis player Lu Yen-hsun missed out on a chance to advance to the third round of the 2010 Shanghai Rolex Masters with a 7-6, 6-3 loss to world No. 58 Andreas Seppi of Italy on Wednesday night.
Lu, ranked No. 42, appeared tired in his second match that took place just about five hours from his last play during which he beat China's Wu Di 6-1, 6-4.

Lu was originally scheduled to play Wu late Tuesday evening on an outdoor court at Shanghai's Qi Zhong Stadium, but the match was rained out. They faced off on an indoor practice court Wednesday afternoon because of more rain.

The Shanghai Masters is one of a series of nine tennis tournaments on the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) tour, which includes Indian Wells, Miami, Monte Carlo, Rome, Madrid, Canada (Montreal or Toronto), Cincinnati, Shanghai and Paris.
The series constitutes the most prestigious tournaments in men's tennis after the four Grand Slam events, and is mandatory for the top male players on the professional circuit.

The Shanghai event, with a total prize of US$3.24 million, has attracted more than 100 tennis professionals this year, including every member of the top 20, starting with world No. 1 Rafael Nadal. (By Kang Shih-jen & Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: Judges urged to play leading role in judicial reform
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 17:26:50 (By Lai Yu-chia and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Judges should take the lead in judicial reform in order to win back public trust in the country's court system, new Judicial Yuan President Rai Hau-min said Wednesday.

"Judges should act like a 'get-out-the-vote organizer' in an election campaign in order to speed up much-anticipated judicial reform to restore public faith in our judiciary and court system, " Rai said after accepting the post's official seal from the top judicial body's acting president, Hsieh Tsay-chuan, at a changeover ceremony.
In the wake of a spate of scandals involving senior judges that have marred the judiciary's image, Rai said restoring public trust in the judicial system is his priority concern and task.
"Integrity, professionalism and public trust will be our top reform goals," he added.

Rai, a veteran lawyer who once served as chairman of the Central Election Commission, said he will direct the formation of a national judicial reform committee to work out a detailed reform agenda within a year.
"In carrying out reform programs, we will follow the principles of establishing an incorruptible, transparent, responsive and efficient judicial system," Rai pledged.
Also assuming office Wednesday was Judicial Yuan Vice President Su Yeong-chin, a law professor and a confidant of President Ma Ying-jeou who once headed the National Communications Commission.
On Aug. 24, President Ma nominated Rai as the new Judicial Yuan head, with Su Yeong-chin as his deputy.

The two Judicial Yuan posts became vacant after Lai In-jaw and Hsieh Tsay-chuan resigned in July as president and vice president, respectively, to take responsibility for a scandal in which three senior judges were detained for alleged corruption.
The nominations of Rai and Su were confirmed by the Legislative Yuan in two separate votes last Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Wednesday, dropping NT$0.11 to close at NT$30.960.
Turnover totaled US$709 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.070 and moved to a low of NT$30.780 before rebounding.
Dealers said rebounds of other Asia currencies against the U.S. dollar on the same day prompted local investors to buy the New Taiwan dollar, which pressed the U.S. dollar back below NT$30.960.
The greenback rose above the NT$31.000 level a day earlier as investors rushed to pocket strong gains posted by the local unit in recent trading sessions.
The dealers said buying of the New Taiwan dollar resumed as the market opened Wednesday, with investors taking cues from a strong showing of other Asian currencies, in particular the Chinese yuan.
The central bank again intervened in late trading to slow down the pace of the local currency's rise against the U.S. dollar, the dealers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity offers free fish to poor children, elderly
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 18:18:54 (By Lee Hsien-feng and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: An initiative that helps poor families by distributing free fish to them will continue again this year in an effort to bridge the health gap between the rich and the less well-off, an association for the underprivileged said Wednesday.

Under the initiative begun in 2008, at least 50,000 fish will be distributed for children living in poverty and old people living alone in Yunlin, Nantou and Chiayi counties, the Care of Underprivileged Communities Society said at a press conference in Taipei.
Two mothers who have previously been given the free fish attended the event with their children, one of whom said she seldom cooks fish for her child because the family cannot afford it.
"When my kid told me the fish we were given was really delicious, I got mixed feelings. I felt kind of sad but touched by society's warmth," said the young mom known by surname as Lai.
Legislator Chang Chia-chun, one of the initiators of the plan, said the charity drive is expected to continue until next January.
The program was launched out of concern over the gap in development between children in the cities and the countryside, said Yayu Wong, the co-organizer of the project.

Doctors in Taiwan have found that children in disadvantaged communities fall behind their urban peers in physical growth and intelligence due to insufficient intake of fish, which contains nutrients essential to brain development, Wong noted.
He added the society gave away more than 45,000 fish to 4,000 poor families from 2008 through last January.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's film industry ready to make a splash

TEXT.P: From the adventures of a peeping Tom to Chinese martial arts action to the comical yet touching tale of a blind man and his niece, the Taiwanese film industry is posed to tickle funny bones and jerk tears with 15 new films to be released in the next six months.

The wave of new movies signifies the once-waning Taiwanese motion film sector is reviving on a steady and upward pace, Government Information Office Minister Johnny Chiang said at a press conference on Wednesday.

"In recent years, the Taiwanese film industry has been performing extremely well in terms of both quality and quantity. I believe the upcoming 15 films will also be successful blockbusters, " said Chiang, calling on Taiwanese directors and producers to set Hollywood as their ultimate goal.

The 15 films slated to hit the silver screen include "When Love Comes" directed by Chang Tso-chi, who is currently at the Pusan International Film Festival to showcase the movie in the prestigious "Gala Presentation" category. The film has also won 14 Golden Horse nominations, including Best Supporting Actor and Actress.

Oscar-nominated director John Woo's "Reign of Assassins" is a US$10 million action-packed epic set during the time of ancient Chinese warlords and sword fighters. The movie is already set to be distributed in over 60 countries, including the United States, said co-executive producer Tang Chai-yang.

Described by some film critics as a Chinese version of Brangelina's "Mr. and Mrs. Smith, " the film features international superstar Michelle Yeoh and South Korea's Jung Woo-sung as a married couple, with each spouse seemingly unaware the other is a clandestine world-class assassin.

"The movie is completely unique from other Chinese martial arts films such as 'Hero' or 'Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon' because it is not based on any historical figure or event. It is purely about the warrior and fighter society of ancient China," said Tang.

Taiwan's first 3-D animation film "Memory Loss" is scheduled to dazzle moviegoers in January as the audience accompanies the young heroine, Hsiao Ta, on an incredible journey to a magical place where lost memories are stored.

Taiwan's sweetheart Megan Lai will star in the romantic comedy "Will You Still Love Me" with eye candy actor Tony Yang, who is also starring in three other films: "Snowfall in Taipei, " "Tempest of First Love, " and "Dancing Without You, " which features mega singer and actress Vivian Hsu.

One of the most noticeable films in the ensemble of 15 is "My Blind Uncle, " featuring Lin Fu-sheng, who is a 39-year-old visually impaired masseur in real life, and a young Teng Yun-ting, who plays a traumatized niece learning to live with her blind uncle.

DOC.HEADLINE: Subsidy program launched for electric cars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 19:03:30 (By Stacy Wu, Jeffrey Wu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The government launched a subsidy program Wednesday in an effort to increase the number of electric cars on the roads in the next three years as part of a long- term plan to boost the industry.

Woody T.J. Duh, director-general of the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said the government has set aside about NT$2.3 billion (US$74 million) in subsidies for 10 cases, with the aim of getting 3,000 electric cars on the roads by 2013 and increasing the number to 60,000 by 2016.

The bureau said the program -- which offers subsidies of up to 40 percent of the vehicle budgets for the cases whose applications for the subsidies are accepted -- will encourage local companies to use the electric vehicles.

"Taiwan's dense population and short distances between cities make it suitable for developing intelligent electric vehicles, " Duh said during the International Forum of Intelligent Electric Vehicle Pilot Run that took place in Taipei.
The program is expected to generate NT$120 billion in benefit for the manufacturing sector and NT$31.2 billion for the service sector over a six-year period, as well as to provide 24,000 jobs.

Jacques Saint-Marc, general manager of a group that promotes electric vehicles in France, said at the half-day forum that the French public enjoy a subsidy of 5,000 euros plus tax breaks when they purchase an electric car.

Peter Nimmo, chief executive officer of ECOtality Australia, a company committed to developing clean energy technologies, said that more effort should be made that goes beyond just the subsidy program.
"Government support in the early stages is vital," he noted. "For the long term, battery-charging infrastructure should be sustainable without public funding."

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma's daughters not excluded from special service protection: NSB
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 19:14:56 (By Chiachen Hsieh & Brar Lee)

TEXT.P: The National Security Bureau (NSB) said Wednesday that it has offered protection for the safety of President Ma Ying-jeou's two daughters who worked in the United States.

The NSB said in a press release that it has required its U.S. counterparts to offer protection for President Ma's daughters, who have been lived in that country, in their working places and residences.
The NSB's Special Service Center is responsible the safety of Ma's daughters when they return to Taiwan, it added.

The NSB made the statement in response to a report by the Liberty Times newspaper that same day saying that the Presidential Office and the NSB has reached an agreement to solve a long-term controversy on whom should be protected by the NSB's special service agents.

President Ma has clearly designated the name list of the individuals covered by NSB's special service protection program which excludes Ma's daughters but includes his mother, who doesn't live together with the president, according to the newspaper.
The NSB said that under the Enforcement Regulations of Special Service, the president's family, including his daughters, are subject to protection by the NSB.

DOC.HEADLINE: Solar cell maker expands business to module production
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 19:16:39 (By Maranda Hsu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-based solar cell firm - Motech Industries, Inc - said Wednesday it has extended its foothold to photovoltaic (PV) module production by unveiling two models of poly-crystalline modules under its brand name.

Solar cells are devices that convert sunlight into electricity by the photovoltaic effect. Solar cells are welded together into a matrix, which are sealed with other components to produce photovoltaic modules, also known as solar panels.

The company said its two new models -- IM60 and IM72 modules -- have been certified by Underwriter Laboratories Inc. and International Electrotechnical Commission, and the first shipments have hit the U.S. market.
The two models, powered by Motech's cells, are designed for both residential and commercial markets, the company said.
Motech said the PV module production is the company's efforts to engage in vertical integration and expand its role in the solar energy equipment supply chain.
"Our quest to enter the module business is to provide more value to our customers and help them succeed, " Motech President and Chief Executive Office P.H. Chang said in a statement.

"Our intent is to produce our modules in alignment with the market demand and to also fulfill the requirements of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA) so that our products are made in the U.S," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health education material contest winners awarded

TEXT.P: Several health and medical institutions that entered the 2010 health education material contest organized by the Department of Health (DOH) were awarded Wednesday for their outstanding entries.

This year, a total of 335 health-related materials were submitted by hospitals and clinics, health authorities and non-government organizations as entries in the contest, which has taken place every two years since 2004, said Kung Hsien- lan, deputy director-general of the Bureau of Health Promotion under the DOH.
The materials, divided into four categories -- posters, brochures, booklets and videos -- were evaluated by eight experts in the relevant fields for accuracy, readability and creativity.
Kung said that the winning materials -- 12 awards of excellence and 20 awards of merit -- had already been put online on the Health 99 Education Resource, the bureau's website.
One of the contestants, Lee Li-ting of the John Tung Foundation, said that putting together a promotion brochure on health and medical issues is no easy task.

Lee's team, which won an award of excellence for a simple diagnostic questionnaire for college students with possible depression, spent about one year collecting medical information, consulting psychologists and designing the questions.
The questionnaire is already being used by Tamkang University, Fu Jen Catholic University and Soochow University in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to launch immigrant care network next year: NIA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 19:47:50 (By Ni Kuo-yen and Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: Government agencies, local authorities and social groups will create a care network to help immigrants nationwide from next year, Hsieh Li-kung, director- general of the National Immigration Agency (NIA) , said at a conference in Kinmen County Wednesday.

Hsieh said that the network, which will seek to integrate resources among the agency, local governments and non-governmental organizations, would start a trial run later this year in 10 cities and counties including Kinmen County, Taipei County and Kaohsiung County.
All the nation's 25 local governments will eventually be able to share and benefit from the network, Hsieh said.
"We really want to invite all kinds of resources from every possible channel to demonstrate our commitment to respecting different cultures," Hsieh said.
According to the Ministry of the Interior, the number of foreign spouses in Taiwan had surpassed 430,000 by August, accounting for 1.9 percent of the total population in Taiwan.
Kinmen County Magistrate Li Wo-shi said the new immigrants were a vital part of the county, adding that it would fully support the new integration to help assimilate various cultures to Kinmen.

By the end of this August, new immigrants made up 1,958 of Kinmen's 95,873 residents, or 2.04 percent, the Kinmen County government said. Of the 32,248 households in Kinmen, one in 16.5 includes immigrant family members, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most Taiwanese office workers not happy with job: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 19:52:08 ( By Hsieh Chun-wei and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: A majority of Taiwan's office workers were not happy with their jobs, mainly because of the long work hours and low salary, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.
More than 60 percent of the respondents to the online survey conducted by two job banks, iJob and Jcase, said the longer they worked, the less happy they were.
Fifty-six percent even said they have often put on fake smiles in the workplace, especially when talking to colleagues they do not like.
Almost 80 percent of the office workers even said they get depressed whenever they think about their job.
If the level of happiness could be measured by a 1-to-10-point scale, the office workers would only get an average point of 5.65, the survey said.
The imbalance between wages and work hours have brought down the happiness level, Hsu Chin-huang, general manager of Jcase, said.

The report also indicated that more than 56 percent of the workers said they will feel happy only if they get a pay raise, while nearly 30 percent said they would be happier if the colleagues or managers they loath have been punished or leave the workplace.
In terms of the reasons why the respondents hold negative attitudes against their colleagues, the survey found 87 percent of the office workers have been betrayed at work.

Lin Yu-mei, marketing manager of iJob, said in order to create a harmonious working environment, workers should learn how to deal with stress since it is the main factor causing conflicts between colleagues.
The online survey, carried out from Sept. 13 to Oct. 1, collected a total of 1,314 valid samples with a confidence level of 95 percent and a margin of error of 2.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scenic lake area to open after yearlong recovery from typhoon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 19:56:19 (By Tyson Lu and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Jiaming Lake, a popular hiking spot in eastern Taiwan, will reopen to the public in early November after being closed for more than a year following a major typhoon, a forestry official said Wednesday.
The 11.5 kilometer trail linking the Siangyang National Forest Recreation Area and Jiaming Lake was seriously damaged in August last year by Typhoon Morakot, which claimed more than 700 lives.

The high-altitude lake in Yushan National Park will be open to 70 visitors per day starting in early next month, the Taitung District Office under the Cabinet- level Forestry Bureau told the Central News Agency.
After a yearlong restoration, the oval lake, with sapphire water that is said to be "as beautiful as angels' tears, " has become "even more charming," office director Chang Tieh-chu said.

The hiking trails have been fully repaired, with wildlife such as Formosan yellow-throated martens and Taiwan field mice seen by office staffers in the area. Alishan salamanders, a protected species endemic to Taiwan, have also inhabited a refuge cottage.
To avoid disturbing the restored serenity in the area, the number of visitors will be limited, Chang noted. People who are interested can apply for entrance online with the office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's opera performance enthralls German audience
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 20:08:48 (By Lin Yu-li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese opera troupe Ming Hwa Yuan wowed a packed German audience at the Admiralspalast theater in Berlin Tuesday with its fascinating signature show, The Living Buddha.
It marked the first time that a Taiwanese opera, also known as Gezaixi, has ever been performed on a German stage.

The play was also the opener of the 80-year-old Taiwanese troupe's first-ever performance tour in Europe, although it had performed previously in individual European cities, including in Paris more than 10 years ago.

To help German theater goers understand the plot of the opera, the troupe projected German-language subtitles of the libretto on both sides of the stage. The audience seemed to be very receptive to the show as they often burst into laughter throughout the play. All troupe members received enthusiastic applause during the curtain call.

Kristina Weinert, a German ballet dancer, said that for Europeans, the show was like a fairy tale full of humor that were often seen in real everyday life. Although the show contained cultural elements that were strange to her, Weinert said she found great fascination in it.
Guenter Knabe, a journalist with Voice of Germany's Asian department, said he believes that Gezaixi should not be too difficult for European audiences to understand.

At the end of the show, Taiwan's first lady Chow Mei-ching, who is accompanying the troupe on the tour, stood up from her seat to greet and thank the audience in her capacity as honorary director of the Ming Hwa Yuan troupe.
Speaking at a cocktail reception marking the success of the show, Chow said she takes pride in accompanying the popular opera group on its ongoing six-country European performance tour.
"I hope more Taiwanese performing groups will present shows in Germany to boost cultural exchanges," she added.
Chow also exchanged greetings and chats with German officials, parliamentarians, journalists and diplomats of Taiwan's diplomatic allies stationed in Germany.
In the coming few days, Chow will visit the Berlin municipal library and several tourist attractions before returning to Taipei Oct. 16.
The Ming Hwa Yuan troupe will give one more show in Berlin Wednesday and will then perform in six other European cities -- Prague, Vienna, Paris, London, Edinburgh and Amsterdam.
Apart from formal performances, the troupe will also hold workshops at universities to introduce the traditional Taiwanese art form to audiences in Europe during its 10-day tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu Yen-hsun advances to second round in Shanghai
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 20:22:50 (By Kang Shih-jen & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tennis player Lu Yen-hsun defeated host Wu Di 6-1, 6-4 in a first- round match of the 2010 Shanghai Rolex Masters early Wednesday.
World No. 42 Lu took only one hour and six minutes to beat the world No. 399 Chinese player, landing four aces in the process.
In second-round play, Lu will face world No. 58 Andreas Seppi of Italy, who upset No. 15 Marin Cilic of Croatia 6-2, 6-2.

Lu was originally scheduled to play Wu late Tuesday evening on an outdoor court at Shanghai's Qi Zhong Stadium, but the match was rained out. They faced off on an indoor practice court Wednesday because of more rain.

The Shanghai Masters is one of a series of nine tennis tournaments on the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) tour, which includes Indian Wells, Miami, Monte Carlo, Rome, Madrid, Canada (Montreal or Toronto), Cincinnati, Shanghai and Paris.
The series constitutes the most prestigious tournaments in men's tennis after the four Grand Slam events, and is mandatory for the top male players on the professional circuit.
The Shanghai event has attracted more than 100 tennis professionals this year, including every member of the top 20, headed by world No. 1 Rafael Nadal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tea growers see profits nearly double as quality improves
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 22:17:41 (By Yang Su-min and Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: Tea growers in Taiwan have seen profits nearly double since last year thanks to a government-sponsored program that promotes the growth of high-quality leaves, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Wednesday.

Since late 2009, the council has provided consulting and advanced techniques for applying fertilizer or medicine, helping high-end tea growers obtain certifications including ISO 22000 and HACCP, Tsai Hsien-tsung, director of the COA's Tea Research and Extention Station's Wenshan Branch, said.
Taiwanese tea has become more competitive against foreign teas, Tsai said, noting that Starbucks Beijing and European tea merchants have placed orders.
Tea growers in areas such as Taipei County's Pinglin and Sansia townships, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu County, and Nantou County's Mingjian Jhushan townships have seen profits rise, he said.
Tsai said that as tea grown in the Taipei Sansia area has no pesticide residue, its price has risen from NT$70 (US$2) for 600 grams last year to NT$120 for now.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan welcomes Hong Kong's plan to set up office in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 22:43:05 (By Eva Feng & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Wednesday welcomed a plan by the Hong Kong government to set up its office in the country, according to the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , the government agency in charge of policies toward mainland China.

Hong Kong's Chief Executive Donald Tsang Yam-kuen said in his administrative report to the legislature earlier Wednesday that his government will discuss with Taiwan plans to establish a "comprehensive" office in Taipei.
In response, a MAC official who asked not to be named, confirmed that both sides have begun contacts with each other on the proposed office.

The official said the Hong Kong government will submit a concrete plan, including details about the office's structure, operations and number of personnel, for discussions with Taipei by the end of this year.

The new office will be another breakthrough in bilateral relations between Taiwan and Hong Kong following the establishment of two semi-official organizations -- the Taipei-based Taiwan-Hong Kong Economic and Cultural Cooperation Council and the Hong Kong-based Hong Kong-Taiwan Economic and Cultural Cooperation and Promotion Council -- earlier this year to deepen exchanges between the two sides.

Taiwan-Hong Kong ties only began to warm up following improved relations between Taipei and Beijing after President Ma Ying-jeou took office in 2008. The former British colony returned to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two more Taiwan banks allowed to open branches in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 22:45:43 (By Yu-pin Tien and Jay Chen)

TEXT.P: Two more Taiwan banks have been given approval to set up branches on mainland China, bringing to six the number of local financial institutions that have gotten the green light to do business in the mainland.
Hua Nan Bank and Cathay United Bank hope to open a branch each, in Shenzhen and Shanghai respectively, before the end of the year, bank officials said Wednesday.
The approval, given by China's Banking Regulatory Commission, came about a month after four other major banks of Taiwan were allowed to set up branches in China.

In mid-September, the Chinese banking regulator approved plans by the Land Bank of Taiwan, Taiwan Cooperative Bank, First Bank and Chang Hwa Bank to set up branches in Shanghai and two cities in neighboring Jiansu Province.

No Chinese banks have been allowed to set up branches in Taiwan although the Bank of China and the Bank of Communications have been given permission by Taiwanese regulators to have a representative office here, a usual step prior to officially opening a branch.
A third Chinese institution, China Merchants Bank, has filed an application to establish a representative office on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: Preparations for Taiwan-Singapore pact talks going smoothly: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 22:50:50 ( By Lin Shu-yuan and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Preparations for conducting formal negotiations on an economic cooperation agreement between Taiwan and Singapore have been going smoothly, Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday.
Speaking on the sidelines of a ceremony for the 11th National Standardization Award in Taipei, Wu said the two countries still have more work to do before official talks on the trade deal can begin.
Taiwan and Singapore agreed to explore the feasibility of signing a trade agreement in August this year, and since then they have been in close contact regarding the issue, Wu said.
Taiwan and Singapore still have to decide who will head the negotiations for each side, he said, adding that the two countries would alternate hosting discussions.
According to Wu, Taiwan has also initiated talks with Japan over the signing of an investment protection agreement.
Wu said Taiwan will seek all types of free trade agreements in any field that will help the country develop and prosper.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's lowest housing supply ratio not a problem: official

TEXT.P: Taiwan has recorded the lowest ratio of housing supply to households in the second quarter of this year in 10 years, but that does not mean there is an inadequate supply of housing here, said the Construction and Planning Agency Wednesday.
The ratio of 99.89 to 100 -- meaning there are 99.89 units of housing for every 100 households -- is still a relatively healthy ratio, according to Wang An- Chiang, an official of the agency.
Wang attributed the lower ratio to inconsistency between household registration and residency, which has resulted in an increase in the number of households registered.

For example, he added, some people buy or rent property in a popular school district without actually living there, but they register their kids under that address so that the kids can go to a prestigious school in the neighborhood, practices contributing to inflated household number.
At the same time, the ratio was also affected by an underestimate of the housing supply, Wang said.

More than 7.86 million units of housing were registered in the second quarter. The main reason for the underestimation is that the basic supply figure comes from the last population census taken nearly 10 years ago. Wang said the agency will adjust the number once the next census, scheduled to begin later this year, is completed.
Meanwhile, central Taiwan's Taichung City has the highest ratio of housing units to households - a ratio of 118.37 to 100.
Cities and counties with a housing supply ratio of over 100 percent include Keelung City, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City, and Taipei County, according to the statistics.
The outlying Kinmen Island has the lowest figure of below 50 percent, while Penghu County, Yulin County and Taitung County were all below 90 percent. (By Hsieh Chun-wei and C.Y. Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade-related Taiwan-China dialogue platform to begin this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 23:07:14 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A platform that will allow regular dialogue between Taiwan and China will be set up and put to use before the end of this year, to deal with issues or disputes related to the landmark trade deal signed between the two sides in June, Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday.

Through this dialogue platform, Wu said, the two sides will consult with each other on matters related to the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) , as well as other economic issues of mutual concern.

Despite decades of booming trade between Taiwan and China, as well as billions of dollars of Taiwanese investments in China, no such platform has existed between the two sides for investors or business people to resolve disputes. And since there are no formal ties between the two sides, there were no government representative offices in each other's territory.
Taiwanese investors encountering problems in the mainland, for example, could only go through China's government offices for help, with no representation by Taiwanese authorities.

The ECFA reduces tariffs on exports, eases or lifts non-tariff trade barriers and gives each side greater access to the other's market - which could potentially bring about more trade between the two sides.

The pact stipulates that a "cross-strait economic cooperation committee" should be created to handle follow-up negotiations or disputes. Since the trade deal took effect on Sept. 12, Wu said, the platform should be established, Wu said.

As to when the platform will be inaugurated, the premier said it depends on when the two sides' existing quasi-official intermediary bodies -- the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), finalize their consultations.

According to Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Sheng-chung, the platform or "committee" will comprise several working panels in charge of merchandise trade, service trade, dispute mechanism and investment affairs.
The panels will be headed by department or bureau chiefs under the Ministry of Economic affairs who will meet with their Chinese counterparts biannually, Lin said.
He added that both sides have reached a preliminary consensus that the "committee" will be headed by a vice ministerial-level official from each side.

DOC.HEADLINE: No preconditions attached to peace overture: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/10 23:35:05 (By M.K. Her and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday that Taiwan would not accept any preconditions from China in its overture to dismantle missiles targeting Taiwan.

"If Taiwan and China want to build mutual trust and ensure peace, neither side should set any preconditions or attach any terms to the cause, " Wu told a legislative committee when fielding questions on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
"The two sides should be fully sincere so as to work best together and guarantee progress toward peace," he added.

Yang Yi, spokesman for the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council, said earlier in the day that both sides of the strait could start contact on military issues, including confidence building measures (CBMs) through appropriate methods.
Yang's remarks came after Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao suggested in late September that Beijing could "eventually" remove its missiles pointing at Taiwan "sometime in the future."
A spokesman for China's defense ministry also said recently that under the "one China" precondition, Beijing would consider removing the missiles it has aimed at Taiwan.
"But how can we accept Beijing's offer if the 'one China' precondition is attached?" Wu asked.

Stressing that conditions are "not yet ripe" for Taiwan and China to hold a political dialogue, the premier said that Taiwan would not agree to proposals calling for the abolishment of the "imaginary border" in the strait, because doing so would leave Taiwan unable to defend itself.

Citing results of a public opinion poll, Wu said around 43 percent of Taiwan's people think the government's pace in handling cross-strait affairs is adequate, while 37 percent, a two-year high, think it is too fast and 12 percent believe it is too slow.
"Judging from this, it is clear that we should not move too fast in dealing with China, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Italian sends tired Lu crashing out of Shanghai Masters

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tennis player Lu Yen-hsun missed out on a chance to advance to the third round of the 2010 Shanghai Rolex Masters with a 7-6, 6-3 loss to world No. 58 Andreas Seppi of Italy on Wednesday night.
Lu, ranked No. 42, appeared tired in his second match that took place just about five hours from his last play during which he beat China's Wu Di 6-1, 6-4.

Lu was originally scheduled to play Wu late Tuesday evening on an outdoor court at Shanghai's Qi Zhong Stadium, but the match was rained out. They faced off on an indoor practice court Wednesday afternoon because of more rain.

The Shanghai Masters is one of a series of nine tennis tournaments on the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) tour, which includes Indian Wells, Miami, Monte Carlo, Rome, Madrid, Canada (Montreal or Toronto), Cincinnati, Shanghai and Paris.
The series constitutes the most prestigious tournaments in men's tennis after the four Grand Slam events, and is mandatory for the top male players on the professional circuit.

The Shanghai event, with a total prize of US$3.24 million, has attracted more than 100 tennis professionals this year, including every member of the top 20, starting with world No. 1 Rafael Nadal. (By Kang Shih-jen & Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 14, or the seventh day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1890: Dwight D. Eisenhower, U.S. military commander in Europe during World War II and two-term president of the United States after the war, is born.
1912: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, is shot in an attempted assassination prior to his assuming the presidency. He won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese war.
1915: The Ministry of the Interior of the Republic of China government orders a halt to the practice of binding the feet of women.
1920: Oxford University, the oldest university in Britain and one of the world's most famous institutions of higher learning, grants degrees to women for the first time.
1933: Nazi Germany walks out of the Geneva Disarmament Conference and withdraws from the League of Nations.
1939: The British Royal Navy battleship HMS Royal Osk is torpedoed and sunk at Scapa Flow, killing 810 people on board.
1944: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, summons 100,000 young intellectuals to join the army and organizes them into an expeditionary force of 10 divisions.
1944: Field Marshall Erwin Rommel, one of Nazi Germany's finest military leaders known as "Desert Fox," dies at the age of 53.
1947: The Bell X-1 becomes the first aircraft to fly faster than sound when the rocket-powered plane, piloted by U.S. Air Force Maj. Charles Yeager, is taken to a height of 9,700 meters under a B-29 Superfortress mother-plane. The test begins at 22,700 meters and the maximum speed achieved is Mach 1.05, which is held for several seconds.
1964: Martin Luther King Jr., American cleric who formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's, is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1973: Thanom Kittikachorn is forced to resign as prime minister of Thailand after violent clashes between troops and student protesters.
1977: The much-loved entertainer Bing Crosby collapses and dies after completing a round of golf near Madrid. He was 73. One of his most successful films was "High Society, " with Grace Kelly and Frank Sinatra.
1991: Aung San Suu Kyi, Burmese pro-democracy leader held under house arrest for more than two years by Burmese military rulers, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1993: The United Nations General Assembly ends a two-week general debate during which a total of 23 nations express their support for the Republic of China membership in the world body.
1999: A delegation from the Republic of China takes part in the 26th International Small Business Congress held in Toronto, Canada.
2000: Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji says in Tokyo that Beijing will take a cautious attitude to resolve the Taiwan issue peacefully, but he adds that this issue should not be prolonged indefinitely.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man knows that the accomplishment of great things consists in doing little things well. He knows that great effects are produced by small causes. He knows the evidence and reality of what cannot be perceived by the senses. Thus he is enabled to enter into the world of ideas and morals."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Thursday from its previous close, moving up 74.85 points at 8,181.51 on a turnover of NT$3.373 billion (US$108.81 million).
The weighted price index rose 16.44 points, or 0.2 percent, to close at 8,106.66 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China Times: Game plans against currency wars

TEXT.P: Over the past two weeks, the United States has stepped up pressure on China to increase the value of the yuan in a bid to boost U.S. exports and quicken an economic recovery. Emerging markets, on the other hand, have been competing against each other to prevent currency appreciation to try to keep their exports competitive.

A major concern is whether the United States will list China as a currency manipulator and impose punitive tariffs on Chinese exports. If this happens, a global trade war will break out, which would undermine the fragile recovery of the global economy. Unless all countries around the world lose their mind, the likelihood for such a scenario should be low.

It's unlikely Taiwan can do much in the process. Concerned authorities in the government, however, should work out various game plans to cope with all possible scenarios. Keeping the U.S. dollar above NT$31 to the Taiwan dollar should not be the central bank's one and only trick. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 14, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar opened at a low of NT$30.540 Thursday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.42 from Wednesday's close as major Asian currencies, including the Chinese yuan and the Singapore dollar, surged to new highs.
The greenback later rebounded slightly and was traded at NT$30.660 at 10 a.m., down NT$0.3 from Wednesday's close.
