DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares rally after Wall Street gains

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices rose 1.63 percent in Thursday morning trade after investors took hints from Wall Street's overnight gains, dealers said.
As of 10:42 a.m., the weighted index had risen 132.08 points to 8,238.74 on turnover of NT$63.84 billion (US$2.06 billion).

"Interest is rotating to large-cap old economy stocks as a rising Taiwan dollar is expected to impose little impact on these domestic demand-oriented firms, " MasterLink Securities analyst Tom Tang said.
"Judging from the gains posted by these market heavyweights, I suspect the buying came largely from foreign institutional investors," Tang said.
Formosa Plastics rose 5.79 percent to NT$82.20 and Nan Ya Plastics gained 4.85 percent to NT$67.00, while textile maker Far Eastern New Century added 6.02 percent to NT$44.90.
Tang said the gains were a technical rebound after the market consolidated in the past few sessions.
"It's still a liquidity driven rally. I am afraid that concerns over the global economic climate will come back to dampen market sentiment and erode the gains soon," he said.
Tang said strong technical resistance ahead of the 8,300 point level remained intact.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady amuses German children with Chinese legend
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/14/10 11:55:02 (By Lin Yu-li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first lady Chow Mei-ching entertained a group of German children by telling a traditional Chinese story at a community library in an east Berlin suburb Wednesday.
Speaking through an interpreter, Chow told more than 20 children the tale of how 12 animals were chosen for the Chinese zodiac as part of the students' two-week autumn vacation activities.
With lively gestures and body language, Chow drew the schoolchildren into the captivating Chinese legend.
She later talked with German library curators about how to promote reading to young children.

Chow also presented a collection of books, including illustrated books by noted Taiwanese writers Chen Chih-yuan and Liu Ke-hsiang, Yami-language illustrated books and German editions of literary works by Taiwanese authors.
Her gifts to the library also included discs featuring performances by renowned Taiwanese performing troupes, such as Cloud Gate Dance Theatre and U-Theatre.

Liu Ke-hsiang, known for his writings on nature and Taiwan's ecological evolution, accompanied Chow on the library visit as he is serving as a writer in residence in Berlin. He autographed the books presented by Chow to the library.
Chow arrived in Berlin Monday in her capacity as honorary director of the Taiwanese opera troupe Ming Hwa Yuan on the first leg of its 10-day, six-country performance tour.
The first lady is scheduled to visit a Slavic minority ethnic park in eastern Germany Thursday and will tour several other tourist attractions before returning to Taipei Saturday.

The Ming Hwa Yuan troupe performed its signature play "The Living Buddha" at the Admiralspalast theater in Berlin Tuesday and Wednesday. The group will then perform in six other European cities -- Prague, Vienna, Paris, London, Edinburgh and Amsterdam.
Apart from formal performances, the troupe will also hold workshops at universities to introduce traditional Taiwanese opera to audiences in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Risk of Taiwan's policy toward China

TEXT.P: In business management, "risk in decision-making" and "decision-making under risk" are two important concepts. These ideas also apply when it comes to managing a country.

Several recent international incidents can serve as lessons for Taiwan in terms of calculating risk probability. These include China's ban on rare earth metal exports to Japan amid the territorial row over the Tiaoyutai Islands. Another incident is China's delay of its free trade talks with Norway in retaliation against the Norwegian Nobel Committee's decision to award the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize to jailed Chinese human rights activist Liu Xiaobo.

If Taiwan thinks "blood is thicker than water" across the Taiwan Strait and that it will not receive the same treatment as Japan and Norway, it is totally wrong. In a recent meeting with U.S. Secretary of Defense Robert Gates in Vietnam, China's Defense Minister Liang Guanglie again raised concerns about U.S. arms sale to Taiwan.

To Taiwan, China is the greatest external risk that is threatening its survival and development. Therefore, all political and economic policies toward China involve "decision-making under risk." If our government lacks the ability for risk assessment, such a government will become Taiwan's worst internal risk. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 14, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Reward for catching runaway workers

TEXT.P: In light of the continued increase of incidents in which legal foreign workers abscond, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) is planning to revamp its reward system for catching runaway workers. Informants will receive a NT$5,000 reward for each person they help catch, instead of paying the same amount regardless of the number of people involved.
The policy makes no sense at all. Is there a reward for the arrest of drug dealers, murderers, robbers and rapists? Is running away a more serious offense than drug trafficking, murder and rape?

Taiwan's disregard for the rights of foreign workers has already marred the country's human rights record. The latest "head-hunting" campaign will bring great embarrassment upon Taiwan if it becomes known in the international community.

We advise the CLA to call off the campaign because it obviously runs counter to President Ma Ying-jeou's reasoning behind setting up a "human rights advisory committee." (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 14, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Taiwanese firms eye China's new five-year plan

TEXT.P: China is scheduled to unveil its 12th five-year economic plan Friday, which is expected to offer new business opportunities for Taiwanese conglomerates, particularly those in the electronics sector.

Taiwan's Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Huang Chung-chiu will reportedly head a group of industrial heavyweights to China later this month to seek first- hand information about China's new economic development strategies and work agenda for 2011-2016.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Commercial Times:
Huang will head a delegation of electronics industry executives to China Oct. 23 to attend a seminar to be held in Fuzhou, Fujian Province on information technology standardization.

Xi Guohua, deputy minister of China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, will deliver a keynote speech at the seminar on Oct. 24 in which he is expected to describe highlights of China's new plan.

Major Taiwanese electronics magnates, including MediaTek Chairman Tsai Ming- chieh, Kinpo-Compal Group Chairman Hsu Sheng-hsiung and Winbond Electronics Corp. Chairman Arthur Chiao, will attend the seminar.
Market analysts said China's new plan will generate lucrative investment and business opportunities, particularly in the solar energy, smart meter and green building construction sectors.
The plan is also expected to stimulate enormous domestic demand in China, resulting in new trade deals for Taiwanese companies, the sources added.
Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs said it hopes China's plan will provide new growth momentum for its "golden decade" development projects.

The symposium is being co-organized by Taiwan's Sinocon Industrial Standards Foundation (SISF) and the Beijing-based China Communications Standards Association and China Electronics Standardization Association in an effort to promote cross-strait cooperation in information technology standardization.

SISF sources said the foundation has also invited 17 other electronics industry tycoons, such as Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Gou, Quanta Group Chairman Barry Lam and ASUS Chairman Jonney Shih. It remains unclear whether they will attend in person or send representatives to the meeting, the sources said.
The agenda will focus on exploring the feasibility of setting common accredited standards for 3D displays, green energy technologies and other ICT technologies. (Oct. 14, 2010).
Economic Daily News:
Chip foundries will report better-than-expected sales in the fourth quarter, according to market sources.

A spokesman for Globalfoundries, the world's third-largest chip foundry, said Wednesday that the company will post a 3 percent sales gain in the fourth quarter of this year and that its annual growth rate will exceed 5 percent next year.

Meanwhile, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., the world's largest contract chip maker, will also see a less-than-expected decrease in its revenue in fourth quarter, market sources said. The company originally forecast a 6 percent decline in its quarterly sales, but the range could shrink to 2 percent to 4 percent, the sources said. (Oct. 14, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: France not using Lafayette case to deny Taiwan visa waiver: MOFA

TEXT.P: France has not attempted to use the Lafayette frigate dispute to interfere with Taiwan's efforts to be included in the European Union's (EU's) list of countries whose citizens can enter the EU visa free, Taiwan's Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang said Thursday.

"France did express concerns over the percentage of e-passports (electronic passports with fingerprint data) among all Taiwan-issued passports, but it did not formally make additional requirements in Taiwan's Schengen visa-free program, "Yang said in a session of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee.
France did not raise the issue again at the European Parliament's Visa Working Group (VWG) meeting Sept. 15, he added.

Yang made the comment in response of a question posed by Legislator Lin Yu-fang, who said that France has expressed its hope for Taiwan to make concessions on the Lafayette case in exchange for French support for Taiwan's visa-exemption in 28 European countries.

The International Court of Arbitration ruled May 3 to order contractors Thales and the French government to pay a penalty of more than US$591 million to Taiwan for paying commissions on the sale of six Lafayette-class frigates to the country's Navy in 1991, in violation of the contract on the deal.

Lin questioned whether France had used its position in the screening process of the visa-waiver program in the European Parliament as retaliation over Taiwan's refusal to accept an offer for out-of-court settlement.
He also suggested the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) should collaborate with the Ministry of National Defense (MND) on the matter.

The Lafayette court case was launched in 2001 by Taiwan's Navy to investigate claims that much of the US$2.8 billion paid for the warships were for commissions to middlemen, politicians and military officers in Taiwan, China and France, in violation of the procurement contract.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese, European textile groups sign MOU
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 14:10:48 (By Wei Hsu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Textile Federation (TTF) said Thursday it had signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the European Textile and Clothing Confederation (EURATEX) for future business cooperation.
TTF Chairman Wang Wen-yuan and EURATEX President Peter Pfneisl inked the agreement on behalf of the two organizations a day earlier in Taipei, the federation said.
Pfneisl said the MOU is the first cooperation agreement his group has signed with a counterpart in Asia, attracting a lot of attention from the textile sector in Europe.

Wang said that after the implementation of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) Taiwan signed with China in late June, 136 textile products from the island will enjoy tariff-free status from the beginning of 2011, boosting the competitive edge of the local textile industry.
The federation said Pfneisl started pushing for talks on an MOU between the two groups after visiting Taiwan last year.

Under the agreement, both sides will focus on collaboration in trade promotion and investments and efforts to support regulations for developing the textile industry and eliminating trade barriers, the TTF said.
They will also aim to enhance market information exchanges, protect intellectual property rights and cooperate in combating illegal and unfair trade practices, the federation said.

The EURATEX, based in Brussels, Belgium, represents the European textile and clothing industry with the objective of creating an environment in the European Union that is conducive to the manufacture of textile and clothing products.

According to the TTF, the EU is the largest textile and clothing market in the world, with annual consumption of 500 billion euros (US$692 billion) and production value of its textile industry exceeding 200 billion euros annually.
During his stay, Pfneisl visited the 2010 Taipei Innovative Textile Application Show, which began on Wednesday and runs through Friday.
The fair houses more than 300 exhibitors, featuring innovation in environment- friendly production technology and textile materials.

DOC.HEADLINE: France not opposed to Taiwan gaining visa-free entry to EU: FIT

TEXT.P: The French Institute in Taipei (FIT), which is the French government's representative office in Taiwan in the absence of official bilateral diplomatic ties, said Thursday that France is not opposed to Taiwan's inclusion in the Schengen visa-waiver program, which would allow Taiwanese citizens visa-free entry to the EU.
The (Schengen visa-waiver) program, which is now in the midst of a screening process in the EU, involves a negotiation between the EU and Taiwan, not between France and Taiwan, the FIT said.

The institute was responding to an issue raised by Legislator Lin Yu-fang, who said in the Legislative Yuan earlier in the day that France has expressed its hope for Taiwan to make concessions on the Lafayette dispute in exchange for French support for Taiwan's visa-exemption in 28 European countries.

The International Court of Arbitration ruled May 3 to order contractors Thales and the French government to pay a penalty of more than US$591 million to Taiwan for paying commissions on the sale of six Lafayette-class frigates to the country's Navy in 1991, in violation of the contract on the deal.

Lin questioned whether France had used its position in the screening process of the visa-waiver program in the European Parliament as retaliation over Taiwan's refusal to accept an offer for an out-of-court settlement on the Lafayette dispute.
He also suggested the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) should collaborate with the Ministry of National Defense (MND) on the matter.

The Lafayette court case was launched in 2001 by Taiwan's Navy to investigate claims that much of the US$2.8 billion paid for the warships were for commissions to middlemen, politicians and military officers in Taiwan, China and France, in violation of the procurement contract.

Taiwan's Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang told the legislature Thursday that France has not attempted to use the Lafayette frigate dispute to interfere with Taiwan's efforts to be included in the European Union's (EU's) list of countries whose citizens can enter the EU visa free.

"France did express concerns over the percentage of e-passports (electronic passports with fingerprint data) among all Taiwan-issued passports, but it did not formally make additional requirements in Taiwan's Schengen visa-free program, " Yang said in a session of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee.
France did not raise the issue again at the European Parliament's Visa Working Group (VWG) meeting Sept. 15, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan donates funds to help save endangered rhinos
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/14/10 14:54:51 ( By Jennifer Huang and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has donated US$5,000 to Save the Rhino International, a U.K.-based foundation, in a bid to help protect endangered wildlife in Indonesia, a Taiwanese envoy in Britain said Wednesday.

Katharine Chang, Taiwan's representative to the U.K., presented a check for US$5,000 on behalf of the Council of Agriculture's Forestry Bureau to Cathy Dean and Lucy Boddam-Whetham, director and fundraising manager of the foundation in London.
The economic exploitation of rhino habitats and human poaching have caused a catastrophic decline in rhino numbers, Chang said, adding that there are less than 200 Sumatran rhinos left in the wild.
Taiwan's government was touched by the foundation's efforts, Chang said. Save the Rhino has been working to save populations of critically endangered rhinos in Africa and Asia since 1994.
Dean expressed gratitude to Chang for sponsoring the Rhino Protection Unit Programme, which aims at conserving animals in Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park in Indonesia.
"We hope to further cooperate with Taiwan to ensure the global sustainability and diversity of life on earth," Dean said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president invites overseas compatriots to invest in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 15:50:39 ( By Li Chia-fei and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan welcomes overseas compatriots to invest in their homeland, Vice President Vincent Siew said Thursday, noting that the country has become a hot spot for foreign investment in the wake of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed with China in June.

"Many foreign countries have expressed a high level of interests in investing in Taiwan as the trade pact signed with China on June 29 has raised Taiwan's economic status, " Siew said while attending a meeting with representatives of the Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations in Taipei.
The U.S.-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence (BERI) rated Taiwan the fourth lowest-risk country for investment in its business environment risk report released in August 2010, Siew said.

In addition to the ECFA, Taiwan's reduced tax rates and its global investment task force formed by the Executive Yuan in August have encouraged foreign investors to put their money here, according to the BERI.

Overseas Taiwanese will be able to help increase Taiwan's international visibility by bridging communications between the government and world business partners, with their language capabilities and rich interpersonal connections, Siew said.

The ECFA reduces or eliminates tariffs on exports between Taiwan China and opens each side's market wider to the other's investors. It was also widely seen as one of the most important agreements signed between the two former rivals, and an indication of reduced tensions and improved relations between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares post biggest gain since mid-September

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 108.79 points Thursday, marking the largest daily rise since Sept. 13 as buying focused on the old economy sector amid optimism over warming cross-Taiwan Strait business ties, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 1.34 percent to 8,215.45, after moving between 8,178.34 and 8,252.20, on turnover of NT$120.89 billion (US$3.90 billion).

The market opened up 0.92 percent on Wall Street's overnight gains and momentum accelerated during trading, with buyers encouraged by gains in other regional markets including Tokyo, Hong Kong and Seoul, dealers said.
A total of 2,635 stocks closed up and 1,252 down with 355 remaining unchanged.

The textile sector tallied the highest gains, up 4.42 percent. Paper and pulp stocks rose 4.09 percent, plastics and chemical shares added 4.08 percent, cement shares gained 2.36 percent and foodstuffs closed up 2.21 percent.
The financial sector rose 1.11 percent and the machinery and electronics sector gained 0.86 percent, while construction stocks closed down 0.19 percent.
"Investors remain upbeat about the implementation of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) Taiwan and China signed in late June," Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said.

"These old economy stocks, in particular the textile, plastics, cement and food businesses, have already forged close ties with the mainland. The ECFA is expected to further boost their bottom lines, " Hsu said.
A total of 539 products and services from Taiwan, most of which are traditional industry firms, will be granted a preferential tariff status or easier market access to China under the agreement.
Hsu said that while the broader market consolidated in recent trading sessions, the old economy sector has outperformed high-tech firms on institutional buying.
"As the market is awash in ample liquidity, investors tend to park their funds in a safe haven, which is currently the old economy sector," Hsu said.
In the textile sector, Shinkong Synthetic Fiber rose 6.93 percent to NT$14.65 and Far Eastern New Century gained 5.31 percent to NT$44.60.
Among petrochemical stocks, Formosa Plastics added 5.53 percent to NT$82.00 and Nan Ya Plastics rose 4.38 percent to NT$66.70.

DOC.HEADLINE: Orange subsidies to begin earlier than usual
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 16:20:06 (By Lee Hsi Chang, Yang Su-min and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: The Agriculture and Food Agency under the Council of Agriculture will begin a subsidy program for locally grown oranges earlier than usual this year in an effort to stabilize prices, an agency official said Thursday.
Taiwanese oranges are mostly harvested in late November to February, the agency's director-secretary, Hsu Han-ching, said in an interview.
He noted that if the crop hits the market all at once, prices might fall, impacting the profit margin for farmers.
This year's orange harvest, estimated at 200,000 metric tons, has dropped by 10 percent since the agency encouraged farmers not to grow the fruit to avoid a glut, said Hsu.
In addition, the agency will from Oct. 15 subsidize processing factories that buy more than 10 metric tons to the tune of NT$3 per kilo, Hsu added.
The fruit will be used for making various products, including jam, ice cream and essential oil, in a bid to expand the market.
Tainan, Chiayi, Yunlin and Nantou counties are the major producers of the oranges.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese film 'When Love Comes' wins high acclaim in Busan

TEXT.P: Hailed as "a leap in aesthetic and artistic sophistication" by a leading film critic, a Taiwanese film about a complex, polygamous family struggling with societal issues garnered rave reviews at this year's Pusan International Film Festival (PIFF), which runs through Friday in Busan, South Korea.

The 107-minute "When Love Comes" focuses on an uncharacteristic Taiwanese family in which the father, played by Lin Yu-shun, marries into his wife's family. When his wife is found to be infertile, she permits him to take on a concubine whose eldest daughter ends up getting impregnated by an irresponsible boyfriend.

The film outlines a complex love-hate relationship between a woman and her daughter, who despises her mother as nothing but a baby-making machine. It also features an autistic uncle played by Kao Meng-chieh, who is best known for past roles as a ruthless gangster.

Directed by Chang Tso-chi, who is no stranger to the international movie scene, the film is scheduled to premier in Taiwan on Oct. 29. It is also expected to dominate next month's Golden Horse Awards after bagging 14 nominations, including Best Feature Film and Best Cinematography.

Hollywood Reporter's chief reviewer Maggie Lee applauded the movie, saying it is arguably the best among Chang's repertoire and describing it as a "visually splendid and life-affirming" film that "reflects the Chinese philosophy of letting water pass under the bridge."

Festival executive programmer Kim Ji-seok was also enamored with the film, applauding it as the best Asian film presented in the history of PIFF, one of the most esteemed film festivals in Asia since its inception in 1996.
The 15th edition of the festival began on Oct. 7.

The movie will also soon make its mark in Europe at the 54th British Film Institute London Film Festival from Oct. 13-28. Besides "When Love Comes, " three other Taiwanese films will be part of the London event -- "Taipei Exchanges, " "I Wish I Knew" and "A Bright Summer Day." (By Jenny W. Hsu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Indonesian migrants' bodies await papers to be sent home
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 17:20:55 (By Lin Heng-li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The bodies of six Indonesian workers who were killed in a construction site accident in central Taiwan 15 days ago will be allowed to be shipped home so long as Indonesia's liaison office in Taiwan produces relevant documents, a prosecutor said Thursday.

The bodies of the six dead men, all undocumented migrant workers who had fled their previous Taiwanese employers and had overstayed their visas for up to three years, have been kept at a mortuary in Nantou County.

Seven workers, including the six Indonesians, were killed and two others were injured after a sprawling network of scaffolding at a construction site for a No. 6 Freeway exit ramp collapsed on Sept. 30.
A funeral service was held at the home of Chuang Yung-ho, the only Taiwanese worker killed in the accident, in Nantou Thursday morning.

The bodies of the six dead Indonesians, however, remain at the mortuary and cannot be shipped home because none of their relatives have come from Indonesia for DNA comparison to facilitate their identification, which is necessary before the bodies can be sent back to Indonesia, according to Taiwanese authorities.

Prosecutor Huang Chien-ming said that in order to facilitate these dead bodies' repatriation, the Nantou Prosecutors Office has asked the Indonesian Economic and Trade Office in Taipei -- Indonesia's representative office in Taiwan -- to produce documents proving their identities and their families' authorization papers.
So far, the Indonesian office has produced only one family's authorization paper, Huang said.
"These documents are necessary for the dead Indonesians' return and their compensation," Huang noted.

According to Huang, these dead bodies have been kept at the mortuary in accordance with Muslim custom -- in caskets, with their hands crossed on the breast, covered with a white sheet and accompanied with Koran chanting.

There were 151,723 Indonesian workers in Taiwan as of the end of August, according to figures from the Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training under the council. The number accounts for more than 40 percent of the 372,146 migrant workers in Taiwan.

Just over 85 percent of Indonesian workers -- 129,046 out of 151,723 -- were working in Taiwan in August as caregivers, while less than 1 percent were employed in the construction industry, the figures showed.

The accident has raised concerns about the hiring of illegal migrant workers, with Premier Wu Den-yih pledging to enforce a crackdown on undocumented foreign workers as well as on domestic employers and contractors who illegally hire them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to attend APEC food security meeting
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 17:34:55 (By Yang Su-min and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Minister Chen Wu-hsiung will represent Taiwan at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation's (APEC's) first-ever Ministerial Meeting on Food Security slated for Oct. 16-17 in Niigata, Japan, the council said Thursday.
Chen is expected to put forward an initiative to set up an "emergency food reserve system" to enhance regional food security, according to the council.

The COA noted that the issue of food security has drawn worldwide attention following the 2007-2008 food crisis, which was triggered by soaring oil prices that pushed up food prices and global climate change that undermined crop productivity.
It is estimated that agricultural output must increase by over 50 percent to meet the demands of the world's expected population of 9.1 billion in 2050, the council said.
The two main items on the agenda of the meeting are sustainable development of the agricultural sector and the facilitation of investment, trade and markets.
The ministers are expected to sign the "Niigata Declaration on APEC Food Security" and the "APEC Action Plan on Food Security" at the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes down on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the Taiwan dollar Thursday, dropping NT$0.19 to close at NT$30.770.
Turnover totaled US$795 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.960 and moved to a low of NT$30.540 before rebounding.
The Taiwan dollar has gained 3.28 percent against the U.S. dollar in the past month.
Dealers said the Taiwan dollar moved higher against the U.S. dollar in line with the strength of other Asian currencies, in particular the Chinese yuan and the Singapore dollar.
They said local currency gains have become a trend despite central bank intervention during late trade in recent sessions.

The market widely expects the U.S. Federal Reserve Board will further loosen its monetary policy to stimulate the country's economy, a move likely to place further downward pressure on the U.S. dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Chinese banks complete registration in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 17:54:41 (By Hsieh Jiun-wei and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Two Chinese banks have completed commercial registration to open representative offices in Taiwan after obtaining a greenlight from the authorities last month, a high-ranking financial official said Thursday.

Chen Yuh-chang, chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) , said that upon registering in Taiwan, the Bank of China and the Bank of Communications are now allowed to operate representative offices here.
Chen said the two banks are expected to open their offices in Taipei City's Xinyi district, the financial hub of the capital.
The two banks are the first two Chinese banks to get approval from the FSC to establish offices in Taiwan. The permission was granted Sept. 23.

A representative office of a foreign bank in Taiwan is not allowed to conduct profit-making activities but can only liaise with local banks and customers and collect information on the local financial market.
Chen said that as they cannot engage in profit-making activities such as extending loans or taking deposits, there are no concerns that they will be able to obtain customers' credit information.

Under existing regulations, Chinese banks are required to operate a representative office in Taiwan for no less than a year before they can seek approval to upgrade the office into a branch, which can get into profit-making operations.
China Merchants Bank filed an application with the FSC Tuesday to open a representative office, becoming the third Chinese bank to seek a presence in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC most-admired enterprise in Taiwan: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 18:22:58 (By Stacy Wu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), the world's largest contract chip maker, has taken the first spot on the top 10 list of the country's most-admired enterprises, according to the results of a survey released Thursday.
The survey, conducted by CommonWealth magazine, said Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. Ltd. took second place. TSMC and Hon Hai grabbed the top two titles for the second consecutive year.

The poll applied various criteria to assess local companies, including visionary thinking, innovation ability, management skill and efficiency, financial health, talent cultivation, international operations and social responsibility.
Smartphone maker HTC replaced IC designer MediaTek in third place, pushing MediaTek into fourth. Delta Electronics was in fifth place.
Other most-admired enterprises on the list include Acer Inc. (No. 6) , Uni- President Enterprises Corp. (No. 7) President Chain Store Corp. (No. 8) and Formosa Plastics Corp. (No. 9).

China Steel, Taiwan's largest steel maker, returned to the top 10 list, assuming 10th place after dropping out in 2009, as the company made aggressive efforts in production capacity expansion at home and abroad, particularly in Vietnam, according to the survey results.

The survey also revealed the most-admired enterprises in 22 individual business sectors, with TSMC and Hon Hai taking first place in the semiconductor category and the computer category, respectively.

Fubon Financial Holding topped the financial holding category, bike producer Giant took first place in the vehicle manufacturing category, Google Taiwan was first in the software category, and Formosa International Hotels took the top spot in the tourism category, according to the survey results.

DOC.HEADLINE: Second phase of flora expo trial period starts Friday

TEXT.P: The second phase of the Taipei International Flora Expo is ready to kick off on Friday in which two of the expo's four areas will be open for up to 15,000 selected guests and invitees, the organizing committee announced on Thursday.

The Yuanshan Park Area made its debut last week, receiving mixed reviews from visitors. The Xinsheng Park Area which opens Friday, features five pavilions, including a high-tech interactive hall that houses a circle-vision theatre and a 3-D kaleidoscope.

Organizers stressed the allotted daily quota for visitors during the trial period is capped off at 15,000 people. Only selected guests such as expo volunteers will be allowed to enter the area while others will be kindly turned away, said Taipei City Deputy Mayor Allen Chiu at a press conference.
Chiu said the park will be open to the general public only after the ceiling has not been reached.

The problem of allowing individual visitors to the expo became a major source of contention last week when the organizers failed to execute to its policy of only letting in invited groups during the trial run for the Yuanshan Park Area.
The number of visitors soared to over 10,000 during the first day of the trial period, far surpassing the 5,000 limit set by the committee.

Chu said while the city appreciates the enthusiasm and the feedback from the general public, it is important to stick to the scheduled plan in order to really put the expo to the test before the grand opening on Nov. 6.

The second phase will run for six days until Oct. 20 and will be immediately followed by the third phase of the trial period in which Dajia Riverside Area Park will be opened for inspection along with the previous two.
According to the organizers, as of yesterday, 63,109 people have visited the park and 6,832 surveys have been filled out. A total of 5,314 of those who gave feedback gave the expo a thumbs-up.

Judy Peng, a Taipei City resident and one of the invited visitors to the park on Thursday, expressed disappointment over what she saw, saying that of the five international floral expos she has attended in the past 15 years, the Taipei one was the most "unsophisticated."
"There was nothing touching or stunning about the expo. I am unhappy how the city government has spent the publics money to create something so uninspiring," she added.
Peng's husband, however, said he was pleased with the expo and that he is confident the event will only get better after the official commencement.

Foreign minister Timothy Yang told the legislature Thursday that so far at least seven foreign dignitaries, including some heads of states of Taiwan's ally nations in the South Pacific and Latin America, have accepted the invitation to visit the expo once it opens next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to expand textile market share in China

TEXT.P: Taiwan's textile companies will capitalize on their new technologies and a trade pact with China to expand their market share in China before their South Korean rivals get similar tariff-cut treatment from China, a local textile association official said Thursday.

Justin Huang, secretary-general of the Taiwan Textile Federation, said at the International Cotton Advisory Committee (ICAC) International Seminar in Taipei that many Taiwanese participants featured their "functional" textile products at the Taipei Innovative Textile Application Show taking place Oct. 13-15.
Taiwan is way ahead of China in making products that are ultraviolet-resistant, electrostatic-resistant or anti-bacterial, he said in an interview with CNA on the sidelines of the forum.
These products, coupled with the tariff-free treatment, will boost Taiwan's business opportunities in China, he said.

Under the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that took effect earlier this year, 136 textile items exported from Taiwan to China will enjoy first-wave tariff reduction or tariff elimination from the start of next year.
Huang noted that South Korea has yet to receive similar treatment from China, a situation that favors Taiwan.
"As South Korea does not yet get duty-free treatment, Taiwan can take this opportunity to extend its market share in China, " he said.
Earlier at the forum, Vice Economic Affairs Minister Francis Liang said in his opening remarks that Taiwan's textile industry today is still "vital and active."
"It used to be called a traditional industry. But now it's a very modern, high- tech-oriented industry utilizing cutting-edge materials and technologies," he said.

To demonstrate the results of Taiwan's research and development in the field at the trade show, the Taiwan Textile Research Institute showcased a new water- repelling cloth treated with an environmentally friendly coating.
The institute also featured a "textile garden" at the show, in which plants were growing on a textile material.

DOC.HEADLINE: Golf pro dies in late-night brawl
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 19:24:15 (By Sunrise Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese professional golfer Lu Wen-hsiung died early Thursday after trying to stop a drunken brawl in his neighborhood in Tamshui, Taipei County, police said later that day.

Lu, 41, came home at around 1:30 a.m. and encountered two men and two women fighting in a drunken free-for-all at the gate of his residential building. Upon approaching the group and asking what was going on, he was set upon and beaten to the ground by the two drunk men, according to the police.
The golfer was rushed to the Mackay Memorial Hospital in Tamshui for emergency treatment at around 2 a.m., where he was pronounced dead at around 3:20 a.m.
A member of the Taiwan PGA, Lu won a championship trophy in the 2003 Taiwan Prize Cup of the Mizuno Tour. His younger brother, Lu Wen-teh, also won a championship trophy on the tour that same year.
Lu had been scheduled to challenge the 72-hole A-So Cup Golf Tour slated for Oct. 19-22 at the Taiwan Golf and Country Club in Tamshui.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hot money tax will only be possible after cautious assessment: FSC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 19:27:38 (By Hsieh Chun-wei & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Chen Yuh-chang said Thursday that the government will only levy a hot money tax after careful consideration to avoid any undesirable impact, especially on the local bourse.

With a continued inflow of foreign capital, the New Taiwan dollar climbed by up to NT$0.4 against the greenback in the morning session of the Taipei foreign exchange Thursday, triggering an outcry from lawmakers asking whether Taiwan should follow in Brazil's footsteps by imposing a hot money tax in a bid to curb foreign exchange speculation.

Legislator Kao Chih-peng of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, at a session of the Legislative Yuan's Finance Committee, asked whether the FSC will work with the Ministry of Finance on the proposed tax, a hotly debated issue after Central Bank of the Republic of China Governor Perng Fai-nan quoted Nobel economics laureate Joseph Stiglitz as noting that Brazil's move to levy a hot money tax was a means to curb the inflow of speculative capital.
In response, the Ministry of Finance said that if necessary, it will cooperate with relevant agencies to work out measures for levying the tax.
According to Kao, a hot money tax would be a double-edged sword and that the local foreign exchange and stock markets will be deeply influenced if it is imposed.
For his part, Chen pointed out to the lawmakers that Perng has not actually proposed the tax. He also said the FSC will insist that it should only be levied after prudent consideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Doctors remind public about eye care ahead of World Vision Day

TEXT.P: Taiwan's eye doctors on Wednesday drew the public's attention to common eye diseases in response to a World Health Organization (WHO) eye care campaign ahead of World Vision Day.

Ophthalmologists at a press conference pointed out common eye diseases which are often preventable in Taiwan. The press conference was held one day prior to World Vision Day, a program initiated by the WHO to highlight the importance of preventable blindness.

Liu Jung-hung of Cheng Hsin Rehabilitation Medical Center warned the public that cases of age-related macular degeneration, an eye disease which leads to possible blindness, is a common problem in Taiwan among the elderly.

Liu also said that while some eye problems are hard to detect and diagnose, others are often caused by accidents and could be prevented, citing a case of blindness in which one boy mistakenly shot a dart into his brother's eye while playing.

The director-general of the Ophthalmological Society of Taiwan, Lin Hung- yu, said that aside from getting regular eye check-ups and enhancing medical knowledge about eye care, people should do more outdoor activities which are good for their eyes.
To promote the importance of eye care and encourage people to get out and enjoy nature, the society will hold a hiking trip at the end of October at Kuantu, Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Made-in-Taiwan equipment helps in rescue of Chilean miners
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 19:34:36 (By Tian Yu-pin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Chilean-made 'Phoenix' capsule may have contributed largely to the rescue of 33 miners who had been trapped more than 600 meters below the earth's surface for 69 days, but two made-in-Taiwan pieces of electronic equipment also played a part in the successful rescue.

Infrared Internet cameras and media converters, manufactured and distributed by Taipei-based Planet Technology Corp., had been lowered down the tiny boreholes drilled into a collapsed gold and copper mine in Chile to allow the trapped miners to communicate with the world above and their activity to be viewed through the image sensors.
This enabled the miners underground and mining officials and rescue workers above ground to prepare for and plan the details of the heartwarming rescue.

"It was indeed a task to enable the cameras and converters to work under a humid, hot, and dark environment that was 624 meters underground," said Lin Man- zu, a spokeswoman for the company based in Xindian, Taipei.
Amid global acclaim, all 33 trapped Chilean miners had been rescued from the collapsed mine Thursday morning.
Infrared Internet cameras and media converters are usually used by industrial companies for their waterproof and dust-repellent properties.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1.3 children abandoned in Taiwan every day: foundation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 19:41:11 (By Chen Li-ting and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: An average of 1.3 children have been abandoned every day in Taiwan over the past five years, according to a report released Thursday by the non-profit Child Welfare League Foundation (CWLF).

Citing statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior, the report said a total of 2,407 young children have been abandoned since 2005, meaning that an average of 481 children have been abandoned each year, or an average of 1.3 per day.

A further analysis of the official data shows that 54 percent of the 202 children abandoned between August 2009 and July this year were less than 1 year old, 28 percent were aged between 1 and 2 years and only 9 percent were older than 3.

Speaking at a news conference, CWLF Chief Executive Officer Wang Yu-min said the number of phone calls from people seeking to have their children adopted has also been on a steady rise since the foundation inaugurated adoption services in 1993.
In the past five years, Wang said, the foundation has received 3,303 such phone calls, or an average of 1.8 phone calls a day.

Analyzing adoption cases handled by the foundation over the past year, Wang said that 84.2 percent of them were not brought to the foundation by their birth parents and had been staying with either foster families, orphanages, relatives, caregivers, hospitals or other temporary shelters.
Moreover, he went on, 33 percent of them had stayed at more than one institution and 9.3 percent had been placed in three or even more shelters.

Only 43 percent could find adoptive families within one year and nearly 25 percent had to wait for two years to find adoptive families, Wang said, adding that some abandoned children still cannot find a family willing to adopt them even after waiting for five to six years.

Wang said the time taken to locate suitable adoptive families is often related to three issues: vacillation by the birth parents, members of their biological families suffering from drug addiction or mental diseases, and children with special features such as disabilities, advanced years or of indigenous or foreign origin.
Nearly 64 percent of children sheltered by the foundation are in the latter category, Wang said.

Meanwhile, Wang said, the foundation has launched a fundraising campaign with the aim of establishing a NT$15 million (US$483,870) fund to care for abandoned children waiting for adoption. Popular actor Ethan Ruan attended the news conference to throw his support for the foundation's cause.

Wang also urged birth parents and judges to prioritize the interests of children when considering whether to put their children up for adoption or making rulings on changes of guardians so that young children will not need to endure such long waits to find adoptive families.

DOC.HEADLINE: Open debate on naphtha plant more crucial than referendum:activists

TEXT.P: Environmental activists urged Premier Wu Den-yih Thursday to accept their invitation for an open debate on the building of the country's eighth naphtha cracker in central Taiwan's Changhua County, saying that a referendum would be useless in ending the stalemate.

Opposition Green Party Convener Pan Han-sheng scoffed at a proposal by ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Daniel Huang that the issue, which has been deadlocked for years, should be put to a nationwide referendum.

"The people have the obligation as well as the right to make the decision for themselves. You have to trust that the public has the wisdom to make the best choice for their future posterity, " Huang said during an interpellation session at the legislature.
Pan dismissed the plebiscite idea and said that instead, a public debate with the premier should be held on the issue.

"How can people vote on the issue when the government has not fully disclosed all the information on the plant? The most urgent thing at the moment is for the government to be transparent about all the facts, both positive and negative, regarding the complex, " he said.

Spearheaded by the Kuokuang Petrochemical Technology Corp (KPTC), a subsidiary of the Formosa Plastics Group, the project has been criticized by environmental groups as a lethal blow to local agriculture and marine life, such as the nearly extinct indigenous white dolphins.

According to the Ministry of Economic of Affairs (MOEA) , the project is expected to generate revenue of NT$460 billion (US$12.6 billion) and to create 18,000 new jobs directly and 357,000 jobs indirectly.

Meanwhile, the Industrial Development Bureau under the MOEA has said that based on the principle of energy-effectiveness and pollution reduction, the ministry will support the establishment of the plant in the central county to replace the aging fifth naphtha cracker.

The EPA confirmed Thursday that the KPTC has promised to submit supplementary documents on its own health impact assessment report to the agency Oct. 15, for review by the Environmental Assessment Impact Committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: Do not overlook excessive ear wax buildup: doctor

TEXT.P: Excessive ear wax could be an indicator of a developing ear problem, a doctor at Renai Branch of Taipei City Hospital said at a press conference Thursday.

He cited the case of a 9-year-old girl who had excessive ear wax production in her left ear and was later diagnosed with keratosis obturans, a build up of extra skin cells in the ear canal leading to blockage and a decrease in hearing, said Chang Chia-wei, a resident doctor at the hospital's otorhinolaryngological department.

Chang said that 70 percent of the cases occur in teenagers and although only one or two are diagnosed each year, people should not overlook ear disease, which can be recurrent and can cause irreparable hearing damage.
Chang said that while it is not necessary to remove ear wax, which protects the ear from infection and bacteria, people should seek medical advice when they have doubts about their ears.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan won't negotiate international space with China: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's quest for international space and President Ma Ying-jeou's call for "mutual non-denial" will not be on the agenda of any cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations, a senior official responsible for China policy said Thursday.

Liu Teh-shun, vice chairman of the cabinet's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , made the remarks after Legislator Kuan Bi-ling urged the government to negotiate with China on these matters in the next round of high-level talks, to be held before the end of the year.

Kuan, a member of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said Wednesday that the negotiation was necessary because of China 's continued interference in Taiwan's participation in international organizations.

At a weekly press conference, Liu said that the Taiwan side has stated the country's position in past meetings between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin, and will continue to do so.

"As both sides have now deepened relations and institutionalized bilateral exchanges, we hope China understands that if we cooperate in our international participation, both sides will be able to enjoy stronger global influence," he added.

With respect to President Ma's call for "mutual non-denial" between Taiwan and China, Liu said that the two sides have established a "fundamentally solid foundation" on the appeal and have "almost reached" a phase of mutual non- denial, an issue which Liu described as non-negotiable and something which could be carried out in practice.
"Mutual non-denial" is a principle advocated by Ma in a bid to win more international room for Taiwan in the face of Beijing's success in blocking Taiwan from most international organizations.
The president repeated the call on Sunday in a speech marking the National Day.
"Although at this stage the two sides of the Taiwan Strait cannot accord de jure recognition to each other, we should nevertheless adopt a pragmatic policy of de facto 'mutual non-denial,'" he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: New stem cell therapy for heart repair developed by local team

TEXT.P: A research team led by a professor at National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) has succeeded in developing a new therapy for heart repair using stem cells, according to a press release issued Tuesday by the university in southern Tainan City.

Patrick C.H. Hsieh, an assistant professor at the NCKU's Institute of Nanotechnology and Microsystem Engineering, College of Medicine, along with his team, successfully combined self- assembling peptide nanofiber hydrogel with stem cells from autologous bone marrow to treat an acute heart attack, or myocardial infarction.

Their experiment on Lanyu miniature pigs, which have a similar cardiac structure to that of humans, proved successful, making it possible that the new stem cell therapy for treating heart disease -- the first of its kind in the world -- can help boost the regeneration of myocardial muscle.

The discovery of the novel stem cell therapy was published in Circulation, the top international journal in the cardiovascular field, in September 2010, and both foreign and domestic patent applications are being applied for.
In Taiwan, there are approximately 2 million heart disease patients each year and 400,000 people suffer from heart attacks.

According to Hsieh, even if patients are lucky enough to survive, their myocardial cells lack the ability to regenerate. The cells cannot take intraventricular pressure and thus they will gradually expand and become thin, leading to heart failure.

"Even though recent research studies have indicated that many types of stem cells can be used to improve heart function and be clinically effective and secure, there is still room for improvement. For instance, when stem cells are cultured outside the body and injected into the heart, most of them are immediately carried away by the blood flow or else die quickly," he said.

To solve these problems, Hsieh's research team injected the self-assembling peptide nanofiber hydrogel into damaged areas of cardiac infarction, a method that reduces the problems and in addition, takes only 30 minutes to perform.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to invest US$215 million on WiMax project
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 20:29:25 (By Ming-Chung Lee and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is planning to invest NT$6.6 billion (US$215 million) in a new WiMAX development project that will run through 2013, according to the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Thursday.
One of the main goals of the project is to build an environment with more WiMAX wireless services that can be utilized for disaster relief and education, the ministry said.
The other target is to integrate Taiwan's WiMAX industry chain and ultimately build an end-to-end solution to help the industry gain a bigger share of the global market.
The plan is expected to create 20,000 jobs and have a total annual value of over NT$100 billion, said the MOEA.
It is also forecast to bring in NT$50 billion in private investment and attract 2.2 million WiMAX wireless technology users, added the ministry.
The MOEA released the details of the project in a report to Premier Wu Den-yih.
The country's total WiMAX products were valued at NT$9 billion last year. The figure this year is estimated to reach NT$15 billion, ministry's statistics show.

The ministry and Intel Taiwan signed two memorandums of understanding (MOUs) in 2005 and 2008, respectively, for developing WiMAX wireless technology, which suggested the world's largest chipmaker's support for the technology.
Intel's CEO Paul Otellini is scheduled to visit Taiwan on Oct. 28 to sign an MOU on the development of the cloud computing industry with the ministry, a ministry official told CNA earlier this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chunghwa Telecom to offer smartphone tour guide at flora expo

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest telecommunications firm said Thursday that it will launch a mobile service that will allow visitors to the upcoming Taipei International Flora Expo to use their smartphones as tour guides.

Chunghwa Telecom Co., which has more than 9.5 million subscribers to its mobile phone service in Taiwan, will offer a tour guide application, or app, for smartphones using mainly the Android operating system, that allows subscribers to browse pictures and written information on more than 3,300 flower species at the expo.

The company will also offer guide services in which subscribers can dial recorded messages providing information on the expo or scan an identifying bar code that will be set up at various scenic spots to hear or read the information on their phones.
"We hope visitors from abroad will gain more enjoyment from the expo with these applications, " Shih Mu-piao, head of Chunghwa Telecom's Mobile Business Group, said at a press conference.
The information will be available in Chinese, English and Japanese.
The app will be available from Oct. 25 from Chunghwa's online software shop and Apple's App Store, and will work on phones such as HTC, Samsung, Sony Ericsson and Apple.

The smartphones will also be linked through bluetooth technology to a specially designed device called a "dongle, " which will be carried by the user and will display related information on the subscriber's phone when it detects that he or she is in a particular spot.
The company said it will provide 240 smartphones for rental to visitors who do not subscribe to its mobile phone service when the expo formally opens Nov. 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's status said to be unchanged in Society for Risk Analysis

TEXT.P: Taiwan's status in the Society for Risk Analysis (SRA) remains unchanged, the society's top official said Thursday, rebutting a local legislator's claim that the country's status has been downgraded due to objections from China.
According to its website, the SRA is a multidisciplinary, interdisciplinary, scholarly, international society that provides an open forum for all those who are interested in risk analysis.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Kuan Bi-ling told reporters a day earlier that Taiwan used to be categorized by the society as a state until China's SRA representative, Huang Chongfu, described Taiwan as not having sovereign status.
However, SRA President Richard Reiss said in an email that Taiwan's status "has not changed since it was formed."
He pointed out that Taiwan is in fact classed as a regional organization under SRA bylaws that "do not require us to take any position on disputes regarding sovereignty."
"Regional organizations are not necessarily countries but are simply defined as 'geographically-appropriate areas,'" Reiss said.
He further pointed out that there are currently more than 20 SRA regional organizations, including London, Japan, Europe and Latin America.
In response, Kuan said that even though there has been no change in Taiwan's classification as a regional organization, its position has been shifted in a way that denotes degradation.
Taiwan used to be positioned with Japan, Russia and Europe, she said, but now it has moved down the list to be next to cities such as Philadelphia and New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elephants to meet Bulls in Taiwan Series final

TEXT.P: The Brother Elephants will meet the Sinon Bulls in the best-of-seven Taiwan Series of the Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) after surviving a franchise-threatening game-fixing scandal and winning the second half of the season for a shot at the series title.

The Elephants, which lost its manager and almost half of its players to a major game-fixing scandal that came to light in October last year involving more than 40 retired and active players and coaches, won the second half-season championship, finishing with 36 wins and 24 losses, with a team of young and inexperienced players.

It came as a surprise for baseball fans, and even for the first-year Elephants manager Chen Jui-chen, who said in a press conference Thursday that he was nervous on the eve of the finals, which match the winners of both halves of the regular season and will be played Oct. 16-24.

"What I want from my players is for them to do their best, period, " Chen said. Peng Cheng-min, the most popular player on the most popular team in Taiwan, gave credit to the young players, who he described as "playing their hearts out."

For the Elephants to accomplish a dream season, it has to conquer one more opponent -- the Bulls, which won the first half season with 36 wins, 23 losses and one draw, and won the 120-game 2010 regular season with an accumulated record of 65 wins, 53 losses and two draws.

The Elephants is making its third straight run at the title after losing in 2008 and 2009, both times to the Uni-President Lions. It has won a total of six titles, the most among the CPBL teams, in two runs of 1992-94 and 2001-03.

In a joking and symbolic move, Bulls manager Hsu Sheng-ming ate bananas at the press conference, as yellow represents the Elephants' team color. The veteran manager, who is coaching in his sixth Taiwan Series, said he and his team were determined to win and that he "never gave up an opportunity to win since he first put on a baseball uniform as a 10-year-old."
His team won the series in 2004 and 2005.

La New Bears, which also suffered heavy personnel losses to the game-fixing scandal, ranked third with 55 wins, 62 losses and three draws, while three-time defending champions Uni-president Lions finished a disappointing season with 54 wins, 63 losses and three draws to rank last in the four-team league, which was established in 1990.

The Taiwan Series schedule is as follows: Game 1 Oct. 16 17:05 Taichung City Game 2 Oct. 17 17:05 Douliou City, Yunlin County Game 3 Oct. 19 18:35 Taoyuan County Game 4 Oct. 20 18:35 Sinjhuang City, Taipei County *Game 5 Oct. 21 18:35 Taoyuan County *Game 6 Oct. 23 17:05 Kaohsiung County *Game 7 Oct. 24 17:05 Kaohsiung County * - If necessary

DOC.HEADLINE: High Speed Rail criticized for poor services: group

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Speed Rail (THSR) was criticized by the Consumer Foundation Thursday for unfriendly ticketing service and for charging a high transfer fee on customers who do not use debit cards designated by the THSR.
The foundation said the THSR has been ignoring public complaints about these problems since it first began operations in 2007.

For instance, the ticket machines provide only change in coins, said foundation chairman Hsieh Tien-jen. It is very inconvenient for ticket buyers to hold 19 NT$50 coins (US$1.6) and one NT$10 coin given by the ticket machine after they use a NT$1,000 bill to buy a one-way ticket between Taipei City station and Banciao station, which costs NT$40, he added.
"I feel the ticket machines pretty much are like slot machines, which is ridiculous, " Hsieh said.
Another problem, Hsieh said, is that the NT$17 interbank transfer fee charged by the THSR on customers who do not use debit cards issued by certain banks only add to the inconvenience.
In response, the THSR said it does not make a dime from the transfer fee as it all goes to the banks, and that the charges are made according to finance regulations.

As to ticket machines that only provide coins, the THSR admitted the design is not perfect, but said that a new generation of ticket machines that provide change in bank notes will not be available in the near future.
The THSR suggested the public use bill-coin exchange machines installed in every high speed railway stations so that customers can change the coins to bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interior Ministry rules out red-light zones
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 21:54:42 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The administration will take notice of scholars' opinions and will not approve the establishment of red-light zones anywhere in the country, Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said Thursday.

The scholars, who offered their opinions and suggestions in four public hearings and seminars over the past two months on the issue of decriminalization of the adult sex trade, did not agree that red-light zones like those in Amsterdam and Germany's Hamburg should be established in Taiwan, Jiang said.
However, they did agree that adult sex transactions should be decriminalized, meaning that neither prostitutes nor their patrons should be punished for their deals.
They also suggested that once prostitution is decriminalized, the government should publish a list of places where prostitutes and sex trade businesses should not operate, Jiang said.
"The government will craft its policy on the issue based largely on those opinions and suggestions," the interior minister said.

Commenting on Jiang's remarks, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Wu Yu-sheng said that if red-light zones are ruled out, the police will have difficulty cracking down on the illegal sex trade, which he said might result in Taiwan becoming "an island of salacity."

The public hearings and seminars were organized after justices of the Constitutional Court said last November that a provision in the Social Order Maintenance Act allowing punishment for prostitutes but not their patrons is unconstitutional and must be scrapped within two years.

The ruling has forced the Executive Yuan to face the issue, as it must come up with measures within two years to not only revise the law but also establish a set of rules governing adult sex transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's workers unhealthy eaters: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 22:00:35 (By Chen Ching-fang and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's workers consume too much fried food and soft drinks high in sugar, especially blue-collar laborers, high-tech engineers and civil servants, according to the results of a survey released Thursday.

These workers therefore have bigger waistlines than average, according to the Chinese Federation of Dieticians Association, which conducted a survey earlier this year on the eating habits at eight workplaces.
A total of eight companies, including two electronics firms, four government sector facilities and two manufacturing factories, took part in the survey.

The results show that the main course of a meal for many of those polled is mostly fried and that workers also consume too many soft drinks. They do not eat enough fruit or vegetables, with only four workplaces providing fruit or brown rice, said Chin Hui-min, chairman of the association.
Most of the companies have vending machines in the workplace selling sugary beverages, as well as offering soft drinks at every meal, the survey found.

According to the survey, although the employees of the electronics factories are fully aware of the importance of a healthy diet, they scored the lowest in their eating habits and behavior, Chin said.
Most workers also said they do not have time to use the swimming pool, basketball or tennis courts provided by their companies due to their heavy workload, Chin went on.
Employers should provide healthy meals for employees as part of company benefits and use calorie counts to help workers make better choices and eat healthier, said Chin.

DOC.HEADLINE: The Journalist to venture into Chinese news magazine market
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 22:07:01 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Journalist, a Taiwan-based news weekly known for its critical editorial stance, will join forces with an official Chinese media outlet to launch a new magazine for circulation in China, the weekly's chairman said Thursday.

"The new Chinese-language magazine, to be named I Look in English and Kan (look or watch) in Chinese, will feature a news digest of major topics or issues covered by media outlets throughout China, " said The Journalist Chairman Chou Tien-jui, who arrived in Beijing earlier this week to strike the joint-venture deal.

Chou, a veteran journalist and political columnist, said The Journalist will cooperate with the China News Weekly, a subsidiary of China News Service -- the second-largest state-owned news agency in China, trailing the Xinhua news agency -- in launching the new magazine.

The Journalist will invest 12 million Chinese yuan (US$1.8 million) to control a 49 percent stake in the venture, Chou said, adding that the financial cooperation marks a new way for Taiwan to think about China's media industry.
"We hope the joint venture will help lay a foundation for our future forays into the Chinese news market," Chou said.
In China, he said, news media organizations face few restrictions, so long as they do not touch on China's central government policies.
At a time when China is poised to begin reforming its political system, Chou said he believes the new digest magazine will contribute to that goal.
In the future, he added, the magazine might also be distributed in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Affordable housing under way: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 22:18:14 (By M.T. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih instructed several government agencies Thursday to cooperate on building housing for rental to low-income or underprivileged people as part of efforts to help them find places to live in the greater Taipei area.

"I have instructed the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of National Defense to fully collaborate with the Interior Ministry to build houses at affordable prices for low-income households on state-owned land," Wu said following a weekly Cabinet meeting.

President Ma Ying-jeou said a day earlier that the central and local governments will work together to offer fair-priced housing to the public in Taipei City and Taipei County amid widespread complaints that house prices in the greater Taipei area, particularly in the city, are beyond the reach of most people.
According to Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah, the housing will be mainly offered to the physically challenged, victims of domestic violence or elderly citizens who live alone.
"The three ministries are slated to iron out a blueprint on the matter by the end of this month," he added.

Yeh Shih-wen, director of the Construction and Planning Administration under the Ministry of the Interior, said the Executive Yuan has instructed that 5 percent of the 226 hectares of land surrounding the A7 station on the Linkuo MRT line in Taipei County should be reserved for the housing, which will be exclusively used for rental.

House prices in northern Taiwan have shown no signs of abating in recent months and are expected to continue rising amid high hopes in the wake of the implementation of the tariff-slashing economic cooperation framework agreement between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central bank stabilizes housing prices: expert

TEXT.P: The central bank has stabilized housing prices in Taiwan's capital and its neighboring area in the third quarter of this year as more people in those areas see the coming six months as a good time to buy a home, a local real estate agency said Thursday.

Housing prices in the greater Taipei area of Taipei City and Taipei County "could have risen at least 10 percent if the central bank had not launched tightening measures in June, " Yeh Lin-chi, general manager of Evertrust Rehouse Co., said at a press briefing.

Since June, the Central Bank of the Republic of China has launched a series of tightening moves on bank lending to curb the upward spiral of housing prices. The soaring prices have ignited complaints that many local residents can no longer afford to buy a home.
"It is not easy to stabilize housing prices on the back of the bullish market atmosphere and low interest rates," Yeh said.
Taiwan's benchmark interest rate now stands at 1.5 percent.
In the short term, he said, housing prices will not post a large increase, but are also unlikely to fall.

In the long run, he went on, housing prices will continue to rise as an influx of Chinese and other foreign investors invest in the Taiwanese market in the wake of a Taiwan-China pact that took effect earlier this year, paving the way for more liberalized trade.
Also seeing this trend, more people in the greater Taipei area told the company in a quarterly poll conducted Sept. 14-24 that they consider now to be a good time to buy a home.

The poll shows that 40 percent of the respondents in Taipei City -- up 12 percent from the previous quarter -- hold that view, while the percentage of those with an opposing view dropped 6 percent to 52 percent.
In Taipei County, those who said they see the same period as a good time to buy rose 3 percent to 38 percent, while those who disagree grew 4 percent to 55 percent.

Earlier this month, a government survey found that in Taipei City, the average property purchase price is 10.87 times the average buyer's annual income, which means Taipei residents would have to save all their salary for nearly 11 years to be able to afford a home.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ace golfer graces Shanghai Expo Taiwan Pavilion
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 22:54:05 (By Charles Kang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese golfing sensation Yani Tseng witnessed the 660,000th visitor to the Taiwan Pavilion at the 2010 World Exposition in Shanghai Thursday when she acted as director of the pavilion for a day.
Tseng said that despite being offered a major sponsorship deal by a China-based multinational conglomerate, she has never thought about representing China professionally.
"I have not given it much thought. I'm Taiwanese, and all I want to do is surpass myself in world tournaments, " said Tseng, currently ranked fourth in the world in women's professional golf.
She said she will continue working to add to her professional golf triumphs "for the glory of Taiwan."

Tseng, at just 21 the youngest-ever champion of the Ladies Professional Golf Association (LPGA) tournament, said she was proud to have been invited to be director-for-a-day of the Taiwan Pavilion, which showcases Taiwan's "soft power" and the cream of Taiwanese culture.
Tseng returned to Taiwan in September for a short rest after clinching the LPGA Northwest Arkansas Championship for her fifth career title and her third this season.

Of her five LPGA titles, three have been majors. Her latest victory in Arkansas was her first in a non-major this year after wins at the Kraft Nabisco Championship in April and the Ricoh Women's British Open in August.

She won the LPGA Championship in 2008, which means the U.S. Women's Open is the only major she has yet to win. According to the LPGA website, only seven players in history have achieved career grand slams.

The US$300,000 top prize in Arkansas pushed Tseng into second place on the LPGA's official list of winnings, with US$1.42 million in 2010, after Jiyai Shin of South Korea, who has so far won US$1.46 million.
The victory also propelled Tseng past Norway's Suzann Petersen to fourth place in the Rolex world rankings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Breakdown of airport baggage system causes delays

TEXT.P: A breakdown of the baggage-handling system at Taoyuan International Airport's Terminal 2 caused delays of about 30 minutes for five departing flights Thursday.
The breakdown was caused by a computer malfunction, according to airport authorities.

"We dispatched 150 staff to help make sure the baggage was loaded aboard all the flights, " said airport spokesman Chao Shao-lien, who added that this measure prevented even greater delays. He expressed hope that the computer system would be back up and running before midnight.
The airport's current baggage-handling system has been operational since 2000 and this was the first time it had failed as a result of computer problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan aid brings hope to children in Armenia

TEXT.P: Aid from Taiwan is helping to change the lives of children living in the poorest region of the Central Asian country Armenia.

World Vision Taiwan set up a project known as an Area Development Program (ADP) in the town of Aparan earlier this year, with the goal of improving the standard of living of poor children in the area. The town lies in Aragatsotn, an impoverished province in western Armenia.
The province lacks basic water and sewage amenities, with broken and muddy roads, " said Shi-jing Chen, a priest who had been to Aragatsotn to see the problems faced by local children.
"The children there face difficult livesKthey are in need of foreign aid," he said.
After visiting new classrooms and kindergartens sponsored by the World Vision Taiwan, he could see the importance of such donations, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG committed to safety management: group officials
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/10 23:15:02 (By Chao Hsiao-Hui and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) reaffirmed Thursday that the group is committed to safety management in the wake of the recent incidents in some of the group's facilities that have aroused widespread concerns.
High-ranking FPG officials made the remarks on the eve of the second anniversary of the death of the group's founder, Wang Yung-ching.

The group's Nanya Plastics Corp. in Chiayi County went up in flames earlier this month following two fires in its Mailiao petrochemical complex in Yunlin County in July.
