DOC.HEADLINE: First lady visits German minority park to sample culture of Sorbs
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/15/10 11:19:44 (By Lin Yu-li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first lady Chow Mei-ching traveled to the city of Cottbus in eastern Germany Thursday, where she visited an ethnic minority park and museum to sample the culture of the Sorbs, a Slavic ethnic group.
Chow received a warm welcome from senior officials of the Sorbs Affairs Commission upon her arrival at the Slavic ethnic minority community.

Harald Koncak, vice chairman of the Sorbs Commission, briefed Chow on the German government's efforts to preserve Sorb culture and language, including subsidizing ethnic dance groups, using bilingual road signs and name plates of public agencies, teaching the Sorb language at kindergartens and broadcasting Sorb-language radio programs.

Through an interpreter, Chow shared Taiwan's experiences in preserving indigenous tribal languages and cultures, such as encouraging school children to learn aboriginal traditions from tribal elders and document them through writing or painting.
Chow also presented a collection of Tao-language illustrated books, as well as discs featuring Bunnun tribal songs to the museum.
Later in the day, Chow visited the ancient German city of Dresden, where she saw the Frauenkirche Church and a fine art museum known for its collection of Raphael and Rubens paintings.
Chow arrived in Germany Monday in her capacity as honorary director of the Taiwanese opera troupe Ming Hwa Yuan and was scheduled to return to Taipei Saturday.

The Ming Hwa Yuan performed its signature play "The Living Buddha" at the Admiralspalast theater in Berlin Tuesday and Wednesday. The group will then perform in Prague, Vienna, Paris, London, Edinburgh and Amsterdam. In addition to the formal performances, the troupe will also hold workshops at universities to introduce traditional Taiwanese opera.

DOC.HEADLINE: TDR issuers to face delisting for withholding information
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 12:03:59 (By Hsieh Jiun-wei and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Issuers of Taiwan depositary receipts (TDRs) could be forced to delist their stocks from the local stock exchange if they fail to disclose sensitive information simultaneously in Taiwan and in the markets where their primary listings took place, a high-ranking finance official said Thursday.

Chen Yuh-chang, Chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) , said the commission is pushing for a mechanism to enhance trading information disclosure of TDR issuers to protect local investors.
Chen said that under the mechanism, the FSC will impose a range of punishments on TDR issuers based on the degree of violation of disclosure requirements, with delisting as the ultimate penalty.

The stock exchange said it has been drawing up related administrative regulations and is expected to come up with details on the punishments in one or two months. It added that the punishments might include fines of up to NT$5 million (US$163,000) and might also include trade suspensions.

Poor information disclosure has sparked an outcry among investors here as TDRs issued by Hong Kong-listed Kith Holdings Ltd., a China-based packaging product maker, continued to be traded for two days in Taiwan even after trading of the company's shares was suspended on the Hong Kong Exchange in mid-August.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- FSC works with central bank to fight hot money

TEXT.P: As international hot money continues to flow into Asia, the New Taiwan dollar rose further by NT$0.19 to close at a 27-month high of NT$30.77 against the U.S. dollar Thursday.

In a bid to reduce speculation by foreign investors on the Taiwanese currency, the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said it has adopted a proposal by the central bank to designate U.S. dollars as the only acceptable cash collateral for bond borrowing.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Economic Daily News:

FSC Chairman Chen Yuh-chang told the Legislative Yuan's Finance Committee that foreign funds remitted into Taiwan are mainly used for stock investment. However, the investors will sometimes use the money to buy fixed-income instruments after stock sales, a situation the FSC will closely monitor, Chen added.
On the cash collateral for bond borrowing, Chen said that only New Taiwan dollars were acceptable in the past.
In August, however, U.S. dollars were added alongside the local unit as acceptable cash collateral, and the FSC and the central bank recently decided that only U.S. dollars should be used.

According to information obtained by the central bank, international hot money for currency speculation is mostly hidden in current deposit accounts, the bond market and cash collateral for bond borrowing in the New Taiwan dollar.
The move to allow only U.S. dollars to be used is to try to bar the use of bond borrowing as a means of speculating on Taiwan's currency. (Oct. 15, 2010).
Commercial Times:

Also at the legislative meeting, Chen was asked by opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Gao Jyh-peng to comment on the possibility of imposing a hot money tax to curb the inflow of speculative capital, a policy recently adopted by Brazil.

In response, Chen said that while he did not oppose the proposal, cautious assessment should be conducted before imposing such a tax, which he said would inevitably impact foreign investment in the local bourse. (Oct. 15, 2010).
China Times:
The euro's climb above US$1.4 on the back of U.S. dollar weakness spurred an appreciation of non-U.S. currencies Thursday.
After successfully breaking the critical NT$31 mark recently, the New Taiwan dollar further soared by NT$0.19 to NT$30.77 against the U.S. dollar, the highest level in the past 27 months.
According to bank officials, it remains to be seen if the central bank can block the local currency from surging past the NT$30.219 mark. (Oct. 15, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: China's 5th Plenum
DOC.DATELINE: The 17th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) 10/15/10 12:42:15 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: begins its four-day fifth Plenum in Beijing Friday with a number of critical issues on the agenda.

The top concern is its 12th five-year development plan. After three decades of economic reform, China has emerged as a new economic power. In the second quarter of this year, it even overtook Japan to become the world's second- largest economy, trailing only the United States. It is worth watching how China will chart its new five-year plan to realize its goal of building a prosperous society with sustainable and inclusive growth as promised by Chinese President Hu Jintao.

Another concern is China's leadership transition. CPC cadres attending the plenum are expected to approve Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping's appointment as vice chairman of the Central Military Commission, which will be confirmation that he is on track to be the next president of China. If Xi fails to get the post, it could signal elite divisions over succession or possible changes in China's succession model.

Although Hu and Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao have mentioned political reform on many public occasions, it would be unrealistic to expect China to move toward Western-style democracy at this point. Nevertheless, we still look forward to seeing China including political reform in its new five-year plan to offer a bit more freedom for its people and make its administrative system more incorruptible and transparent. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 15, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign labor employment procedures to be streamlined: CLA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 13:36:45 (By Kelven Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has been working to streamline the complicated procedures involved in hiring foreign workers without using brokers, in the hope that the measure will help stem worker exploitation by the brokers, the CLA minister said Friday.

"Direct employment is a very good way of reducing the exploitation of foreign laborers, " Wang Ju-hsuan said outside the Legislative Yuan while answering questions from reporters on a newspaper report that the council is working to expand the existing direct employment system.
She admitted that although the system has been in place since 2007, the application procedures are indeed "far too complicated and frustrate the employers."
Therefore, she said, the CLA's Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training is attempting to work out plans to encourage local employers to hire foreign laborers without going through brokers.

The Taipei-based China Times daily reported that same day that increasing numbers of foreign workers have been absconding from their contracted work places. One of the main reasons for this is the astronomical brokerage bills they are forced to pay every month, which often prompts them to run away and continue working illegally under the radar.

Under the existing regulations on foreign labor employment, each foreign worker is entitled to a two-year residence permit, and allowed to apply for an extension of another year. To get their first permit to work in Taiwan, each applicant has to pay a broker as much as NT$100,000 (US$3,260), the report said.

If they want to keep working here after completing a three-year contract, they have to fly back home and renew the application, which requires them to undergo the same procedures all over again and pay yet another brokerage fee.

To prevent foreign workers from being exploited any longer by these unscrupulous brokers, the government set up the Direct Hiring Service Center three years ago, which is supposed to assist local employers with hiring foreign workers on their own, to save the enormous brokerage charges for both sides.

The services, however, are limited to employers seeking to renew contracts for their existing foreign workers, which the report said is due to the failure of the foreign workers' home countries -- mostly Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand -- to build manpower data banks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Women's rights activists blast sex industry policy

TEXT.P: Women's rights activists accused the government Friday of having failed to make its position clear with regard to its sex industry policy and of making rushed decisions without public consensus.

"We're not sure about the government's position on the sex industry -- does it have an open attitude on adult sex transactions or does it intend to prohibit such activities? " asked Tsai Wan-fen, secretary-general of Taiwan Women's Link, at a press conference organized by the Anti-Sexual Exploitation Alliance, a league of more than a dozen human rights non-government organizations (NGOs).

The alliance voiced its opinion two days after Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said his ministry will not approve the establishment of red-light zones anywhere in the country and agreed that adult sex transactions should be decriminalized.
The Ministry of Interior (MOI) will start formulating its final policy and submit its recommendations to the Executive Yuan before the end of the year, Jiang was quoted as saying.

Tsai said the alliance is firmly opposed to the legalization of adult sex transactions, adding that the government should crack down on the sex industry and penalize those caught running prostitution rings.

The MOI "acted on its own discretion, " with only four public hearings held on the controversial issue. The majority of the six scholars who spoke at those hearings appear to favor the legalization of prostitution, Tsai said.

According to a public opinion survey conducted by the MOI last year, 83 percent of the respondents said they favored the establishment of red-light zones and over 90 percent of the respondents said they disagreed with the legalization of adult sex transactions in private homes, said Cheng Kai-jung, secretary-general of the Taipei Association for the Promotion of Women's Rights.
The results of the survey show that there is no public consensus on the controversial issue and that more dialogue is needed before finalizing the national policy, Cheng added.

Legalization of the sex trade could lead to serious threats to social order and human trafficking due to the potential involvement of organized crime, said Justine Wang of the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation.

Until a final consensus is reached, Wang said, the government should not set a timetable for the issue. If it does decide to legalize prostitution, she went on, it should also consider levying "a social tax on whoremasters, " since their behavior brings extra costs and threats to society.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese bank receives approval for China branch
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 14:07:05 (By Hsieh Jiun-wei and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-based Shanghai Commercial and Savings Bank confirmed Friday that it has obtained a green light from the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) to open a branch in Shanghai.
The bank said it aims to set up the Shanghai foothold through its subsidiary, the Hong Kong-based Shanghai Commercial Bank, which filed the application with the FSC to open the branch.
The establishment of the new branch is still pending approval from the Chinese authorities.

Chiu Shu-chen, deputy director of the FSC's Banking Bureau, said the green light was given as the Hong Kong subsidiary, which operates three branches in the United States and another in Britain, meets the financial requirements set forth by the commission.
The bank is the eighth local bank to obtain approval from the FSC to open a branch in China, according to the FSC.

Since the implementation of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) Taiwan and China signed in late June to grant Taiwanese banks easier access to China, cross-strait financial exchanges have been on the rise.

In June, Land Bank of Taiwan and First Bank were approved by the FSC to set up branches in Shanghai, while the commission agreed to plans submitted by Taiwan Cooperative Bank and Chang Hwa Bank to establish branches in Suzhou and Kunshan, respectively.
In August, Cathay United Bank got approval to open a Shanghai branch and Hua Nan Bank obtained a green light to establish a Shenzhen foothold.
Last month, the FSC allowed Chinatrust Commercial Bank to establish a branch in Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: Emergency task forces to be set up against `centenary bug'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 14:39:17 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs will set up four emergency task forces to help Taiwanese businesses deal with a potential computer glitch that could occur as the Republic of China enters its 100th year in 2011, an official said Friday.
The task forces will operate around the clock from Dec. 1, 2010 to Jan. 31, 2011, said Wu Ming-chi, director-general of the ministry's Department of Industrial Technology.
The problem, known as the "centenary bug, " is similar to the Y2K bug that caused panic prior to the start of 2000 until it turned out to be a false alarm.

The ministry is afraid that there could be a problem in this case because in older computer systems, the year on the ROC calendar is presented in two digits and there is concern that these systems might not be able to cope with three- digit years.

According to the results of a survey conducted by the MOEA among local businesses in August, more than 70 percent of the respondents had already updated their computer systems to prevent the potential glitch.
Most of the businesses that had not done so were small and micro- enterprises with fewer than 50 staff, the results show.
The main obstacles faced by these enterprises were insufficient understanding of the problem and a lack of technical personnel to handle it, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chung-Hua institute ups forecast for economy

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy this year will grow more than previously forecast due to better-than-expected growth in consumption, investment and exports earlier this year, a local research institute said Friday.
The Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research adjusted upward its prediction for the whole-year gross domestic product (GDP) in 2010 from 6.94 percent to 8.15 percent.

"We revised our forecast upward because consumption, investment and exports posted higher levels of growth than expected in the second quarter, " said Wang Lee-rong, director of the institute's Center for Economic Forecasting, at a press briefing.

In the second quarter, private consumption grew 4.41 percent from a year earlier, while domestic investment jumped 30.77 percent from the same period of last year, according to the institute's figures.

"This year's domestic investment will grow by an estimated 17.3 percent, which will mark a new high since 1988, " she said, attributing the reason to a major Taiwan- China trade pact that took effect recently.

The government has been working to attract foreign and overseas Taiwanese investors to Taiwan after the signing in late June of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , which is aimed at further liberalizing trade between Taiwan and China.
The institute's forecast, however, is lower than the 8.24 percent predicted by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

Rick Lo, a senior economist with Fubon Financial Holding Co., said at the press briefing that Taiwan's economic growth might be close to 9 percent this year and 5 percent next year, due to the ECFA and Taiwan's possible increased opening to Chinese tourists.

The economic growth for the second half of this year is expected to be relatively small compared to the same period of last year due to the high growth at that time and a slowing global economy this year, the institute said.

Export-reliant Taiwan's GDP is likely to have grown 6.71 percent in the third quarter of this year and to reach 1.20 percent in the fourth quarter compared to the year-earlier figures. Tallies for these two quarters were not yet available.
For next year, the institute predicted the GDP growth forecast at 4.59 percent after taking into consideration the worrying unemployment and government debt in the United States.
Meanwhile, the institute predicted that the jobless rate might have fallen to 5.16 percent in the third quarter of this year and to 5.06 percent in the fourth quarter.
The unemployment rate for the whole of 2010 will average an estimated 5.29 percent, and is expected to drop to 4.86 precent for 2011, the institute said.
Premier Wu Den-yih has said he will offer his resignation if the jobless rate does not fall under 5 percent by the end of this year.
In addition, the institute believes that the consumer price index, a measure of inflation, will rise 1.08 percent this year and 0.93 percent next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Lessons from miraculous Chilean mining rescue

TEXT.P: The remarkable rescue of 33 Chilean miners trapped 624 meters underground for more than two months is arguably one of the most uplifting events in modern history.
The flawlessly executed operation was an unqualified success that deserves careful study in terms of both the leadership displayed and the supreme skills of the disaster rescue and relief workers.

First and foremost, it shows the power of a common purpose. The rescue was obviously a multinational, multidisciplinary feat, with contributions from various institutions and companies around the world. In pursuit of the unique goal of saving the miners, all the service and equipment providers showed focus and discipline, preventing turf battles from bogging down the whole effort.

The rescue also demonstrates the virtue of always having backup plans. The shaft that ultimately reached the miners was the second of three being drilled. Since no-one ever before had been rescued through such a long shaft, the operation was basically an experiment. Trying several different ways at once raised the odds of success.

The extraordinary rescue of all 33 miners symbolizes the triumph of human spirit and the joy of team pride. It also serves as a reminder that people truly can work together and that every human life is important. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 15, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Traditional markets potential hotbed for dengue fever
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 16:04:57 (By Chang Jung Hsiang and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Traditional markets are a possible source for many of the indigenous dengue fever cases in southern Taiwan's Tainan City, where as many as 130 cases have been confirmed, according to the results of a study by the city government.

The cases have all been reported since Sept. 11, when the first domestic one was confirmed. One case was fatal, with the death caused by dengue hemorrhagic fever, a potentially fatal complication of the disease.

The city health bureau pointed out that many of the people infected had reported going to traditional markets, where standing water is often left in containers or in puddles and gutters, creating ideal breeding conditions for the mosquitoes that carry dengue fever.

The number of cases in the West Central district alone account for 66 percent of all the cases in the city's six districts, according to the bureau. Most of them live in the neighborhood surrounding a traditional market, leading to suspicion that the market might be a source of infection.
The bureau urged the public to wear long sleeves and pants when shopping at traditional markets to prevent mosquito bites.
The Centers for Disease Control said Oct. 12 that since August, 483 cases have been reported in Taiwan, over 80 percent of which have been concentrated in Kaohsiung and Tainan.

The World Health Organization describes dengue fever as a mosquito-borne infection that causes a severe flu-like illness that has the potential to be fatal. The disease is found in tropical and sub-tropical climates worldwide, mostly in urban and semi-urban areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 0.12 percent

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 0.12 percent Friday after a tug of war between rotational buying of select old economy stocks and selling of high-tech sector shares, which were haunted by gloom over the industry's earnings outlook, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 10.15 points to 8,205.30, after moving between 8,184.29 and 8,242.77, on turnover of NT$124.70 billion (US$4.07 billion).
The weighted index opened flat, rising 1.42 points after a lackluster performance on Wall Street overnight.
It seesawed for most of the session, as investors cut their electronics holdings after a fall on the tech-rich NASDAQ while buying textile and petrochemical shares, dealers said.
A total of 2,393 stocks closed down, 1,570 finished up, and 290 remained unchanged.

Cement sector shares suffered the steepest decline, losing 1.02 percent. Machinery and electronics stocks fell 0.64 percent, construction shares lost 0.4 percent and foodstuffs closed fell 0.2 percent.
The textile sector rose 4.04 percent and the plastics and chemical sector gained 1.2 percent, while paper and pulp stocks added 0.33 percent and financial shares rose 0.01 percent.
"Ahead of an earnings report period to start later this month, uncertainty over the electronics sector's profitability continued to haunt high-tech stocks," TLG Asset Management Arch Shih said.

Shih said a rising Taiwan dollar has dampened market sentiment on fears that weakening export competitiveness would further hurt the sector's bottom line at a time when global demand has appeared to slow.
"I suspect foreign institutional investors kept unloading electronics stocks, in particular semiconductor related firms, today," Shih said.
The analyst predicted that amid such cautious sentiment, the market's index would move between 8,100 and 8,300 next week.
Among high-tech stocks, integrated circuit designer MediaTek fell 3.47 percent to NT$390.00 and memory chip maker Nanya Technology fell 3.18 percent to NT$18.20.

Meanwhile, rising product prices continued to boost textile and petrochemical stocks, with Shinkong Synthetic Fiber up 6.83 percent at NT$15.65 and rival Far Eastern New Century up 3.81 percent at NT$46.30.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Friday, gaining NT$0.023 to close at NT$30.793.
Turnover totaled US$563 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$30.820 and moved to a low of NT$30.631 before rebounding.
Dealers said the slower pace of appreciation of other Asian currencies against the U.S. dollar alleviated the downward pressure on the greenback in the local market.
The New Taiwan dollar traded in a relatively narrow range throughout the session, with many investors choosing to remain on the sidelines, they said.
As a result, the central bank did not need to intervene to as great an extent as it had in recent sessions in efforts to stop the local currency becoming too strong, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to promote ministerial-level economic meeting with Vietnam
DOC.DATELINE: Hanoi, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 18:30:03 (By Tony Fang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new representative to Vietnam, Huang Chih-peng, has voiced hope that the two countries can soon begin convening meetings of their ministerial-level officials in charge of economic, commercial and industrial affairs.

"Vietnam is an important economic and trade partner" of Taiwan, Huang said in an interview with CNA, expressing hope that through such meetings, the two sides can discuss ways to boost bilateral links.
Huang, who was director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade before being assigned to head the representative office in Hanoi, assumed office Oct. 6.

In the interview, Huang said Taiwan is Vietnam's second-largest source of foreign funds and that he expects Taiwan to take over the top position soon, once several major investment projects are launched.
For export-reliant Taiwan, Vietnam is an important investment environment, with abundant natural resources and quality manpower, he said.

Turning to his new duties, Huang said his office will help trade and investment activities launched by Taiwanese businesses in Vietnam, while trying to boost Taiwan-Vietnam relations comprehensively by first seeking progress in bilateral links in the fields of culture, education and medical care.

Asked about a recent announcement by Vietnam Chamber of Commerce and Industry (VCCI) Chairman Vu Tien Loc that the group has organized a research panel to study the feasibility of signing an economic cooperation agreement with Taiwan, Huang said that "anything is possible with hard work."

The VCCI is the authority responsible for the management of state-run enterprises and other small and medium-sized enterprises. The top post in the organization is held by a ministerial-level official.
Vietnam is ruled by a communist regime that follows the "one China" policy strictly and as a result, maintains only scant political relations with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Streamlining river management

TEXT.P: After a string of serious flood disasters, the Executive Yuan finally accepted expert advice two years ago to create a cross-agency commission charged with coordinating river management and flood prevention efforts at different levels.

The commission, however, has only met once since its formation. Premier Wu Den- yih did not know its inaction until after opposition Legislator Tien Chiu-chin exposed the flop at a recent legislative session.

It was not only shocking but also distressing for members of the public to learn of the episode. Even more outrageous was that the commission had remained moribund after Typhoon Morakot wreaked havoc in August 2009 and Typhoon Fanabi devastated Kaohsiung last month.

Under current regulations, a number of agencies at local and central levels are in charge of river management. Even the Council of Indigenous Peoples plays a role in administration of reserved land in the upper stretches of some major rivers.
The complicated system of division of labor has often hobbled river cleanup and other flood control projects.

Premier Wu should take Tien's criticism as a driving force to overhaul the river administrative system. When a package of government restructuring rules take effect in 2012, a new river management commission with full power and resources should also be in place to more efficiently protect local people from flooding disasters. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 15, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- 'Uniform queen' shapes Taiwan's 2010 Expo image

TEXT.P: Liao Chia-lin's passion and persistence won her the chance to create the uniform for staff members of Taiwan's pavilion at the 2010 Shanghai Expo, but well before then she had already won the hearts of many people around Taiwan who have worn her uniform designs.
Dubbed the "Uniform Queen" by those who know her, Liao is behind the uniforms of over 70 percent of the saleswomen at department store cosmetic counters and half of the bank tellers in the country.

She has such a loyal following that the wearers of her outfits often say they want to keep them on after work, and it is that customer loyalty that has helped her company, Chorong Industrial Co., recently exceed NT$100 million in annual revenues for the first time.

Her rise in the intensely competitive industry is remarkable, considering her complete lack of knowledge about the textile and apparel businesses when she graduated from college with a degree in tourism management over 20 years ago.
After working in a hotel's public relations office for six months after graduating, she entered the industry as a saleswoman at her friend's company.
Despite her lack of knowledge, she often impressed potential clients with fresh ideas that were based on her interest in fashion design and in-depth research on the customer.
She decided to leave the company, however, because of customer complaints over the poor quality of the delivered uniforms.
Liao was looking for a new job when a former client asked her to design a uniform for some 20 saleswomen for Sonia Rykiel, which had just been introduced to Taiwan at the time.
The deal's success brought more business Liao's way, so she set up her own company named after her daughter Chorong to focus on making uniforms.

Liao stands out in the business for her willingness to invest in customized fabrics that make each client's uniform unique. She often visits textile factories and research institutes such as National Pingtung University of Science and Technology in southern Taiwan to keep up on the latest innovations.
Her meticulous attention to how people feel wearing her uniforms also is a key element in her ability to win over clients.

Her insistence on doing the fittings for every one of her clients has led her to even travel to the outlying Nangan Island (part of the Matsu island chain) to take the measurements of employees at Bank of Taiwan's branch there.
Liao has also insisted on keeping the company's production in Taiwan, and she works with over 50 local suppliers and contractors to maintain the quality that keeps Chorong competitive.

Still, Taiwan's uniform market has been undermined by cutthroat competition, leaving players with narrow margins. Liao has battled this odious environment by generally avoiding open tenders held by corporate clients for uniforms, where prices are often driven to unacceptable low levels.
Only 20 percent of the company's business is derived from open tenders, with the rest coming from contests and clients who seek out her company's services.

Facing another industry challenge -- a shortage of new-generation tailors and skilled craftsmen -- Liao has offered internships to students in recent years to give them a chance to experiment with new ideas.

That may give her an important advantage in one of her long-term goals -- entering the haute couture business. Though specializing in uniform designs, she has shown her talent for more sophisticated dresses.

Her formal dress designs, for example, won the top prize for woman's wear at the 33rd World Congress of Master Tailors in Austria's Salzburg in 2009. Chorong has twice represented Taiwan in the biennial event.
Liang Tung-fu, chairman of Lih-shang Tailor and a veteran tailor who has counted Taiwan's presidents among his clients, believes Liao will achieve whatever goal she sets out to accomplish.
Liao's dedication and persistence, he says, has transformed her from an amateur into "a top professional in the business."

DOC.HEADLINE: MediaTek shares fall to near 16-month low over price war concerns
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 19:36:15 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of integrated circuit designer MediaTek Inc. fell to a nearly 16-month low Friday amid concerns that escalating price competition in China will further impact the stock's bottom line, dealers said.

MediaTek fell 3.47 percent to NT$390.00 (US$12.72) , the lowest level since June 29, 2009, with 13.25 million shares changing hands, while the benchmark weighted index closed down 0.12 percent at 8,205.30.

"There are no signs that a price war in China is going to stop any time soon with MediaTek's rivals continuing to cut prices for a higher share in China's cell phone chip market," Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said.
According to Hsu, MediaTek's share in China's cell phone chip market has fallen to 80 percent from a peak of 95 percent seen earlier this year amid fierce competition.
Cell phone chips account for about 75 percent of MediaTek's total sales and "bandit" or unbranded Chinese cell phone makers are the major buyers of the company's cell phone chips, Hsu said.
"Falling prices are eroding MediaTek's profitability. Investors have been anxious, waiting for the company's third quarter earnings announcement, due later this month," Hsu said.
In July, MediaTek predicted that its gross margin would fall to between 51.5 percent and 53.5 percent in the third quarter from 55 percent recorded in the second quarter.
Hsu said it remained to be seen whether the company would maintain its gross margin within the anticipated range under such unfavorable circumstances.
Hsu said a stronger New Taiwan dollar has further dampened market sentiment toward high-tech stocks, including MediaTek, amid fears that their global competitiveness will weaken.
"I expect that foreign institutional investors will continue to unload MediaTek stocks on the back of a gloomy mood about the company's earnings outlook," Hsu said.
Currently, foreign institutional investors hold some 51 percent of MediaTek's shares, which leaves room for them to lower their holdings, Hsu said.
He added that the stock might fall an additional 10 percent-15 percent before finding technical support.

DOC.HEADLINE: Credit Suisse raises Evergreen Marine target price to NT$31
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 19:48:57 (By Jeff Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Credit Suisse said it has raised its target price for Evergreen Marine Corp., Taiwan's largest shipper, to NT$31 (US$1.01) from NT$25 on an improving earnings outlook.
In a research note, Credit Suisse said it has also maintained a "outperform" rating on the stock, which closed up NT$0.10 at NT$22.60 on Friday.

The brokerage commented that while the company is not particularly transparent, the company's earnings in the first half of this year and sales in recent financial statements pointed to a rebound in line with the global shipping industry.
In the second quarter, Evergreen Marine posted about NT$4.0 billion in net profit, compared with a net loss of NT$87 million registered in the first quarter.
In 2009, Evergreen Marine recorded a NT$9.86 billion net loss on the lingering impact of the global financial meltdown that first battered the world economy in late 2008.
"We believe Evergreen Marine's long-term competitiveness is rising on the new ship orders," Credit Suisse said. "We believe these ships are competitive compared with its peers in terms of cost."
The company has commissioned South Korea's Samsung Heavy Industries Co. to build 20 ships, each of which will have a cargo capacity of 8,000 twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs) , for US$2.06 billion.
The delivery of the new ships will start from 2012.

Credit Suisse has also raised its forecast of Evergreen Marine's net profit to NT$14.36 billion from an early estimate of NT$3.25 billion for 2010, to NT$15.07 billion from NT$6.53 billion for 2011, and to NT$16.64 billion from NT$9.31 billion for 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: Groth, Date Krumm to headline OEC Taipei Ladies Open

TEXT.P: Twelve players ranked in the WTA's (Women's Tennis Association) top 100, including Jarmila Groth of Australia and Kimiko Date-Krumm of Japan, have entered the 2010 OEC Taipei Ladies Open, organizers said Friday.
The top-seeded Groth, who won the tournament in its first year in 2008, has the highest ranking of any player in the field at No. 42, followed by Date-Krumm at No. 56.
They will be joined by local favorites Chan Yung-jan, Chang Kai-chen, Hsieh Su- wei and Chuang Chia-jung in front of hometown crowds at Taipei Arena.
The total purse for the ITF (International Tennis Federation) event is US$100,000, according to the Chinese Taipei Tennis Association (CTTA), which is organizing the tournament.
ITF tourneys are a tier below WTA events, which have minimum purses of US$220,000 and attract higher seeded players.

Forty-year-old veteran Date-Krumm, who retired in 1993 and returned to tennis in 2008, and Alicia Molik, the women's singles bronze medalist at the 2004 Athens Olympics, who ranked as high as 8th and is now 98th, are among a competitive group of players capable of winning this year's event.
Germany's 21-year-old rising star Sabine Lisicki, a women's singles quarterfinalist at Wimbledon in 2009, is expected to wow crowds with serves that can reach nearly 200 kilometers per hour.
Alla Kudryavtseva of Russia, Romani Oprandi of Italy, Ayumi Morita of Japan and China's Peng Shuai are among other notable foreign competitors.

Chan Yung-jan, the highest-ranked Taiwanese player on the women's tour at No. 81, enters the tournament as the defending champion after defeating Morita 6-4, 2-6, 6-2 in the women's singles final last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will not recognize Chinese diplomas retroactively: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 20:01:09 (By Lin Szu-yu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih reaffirmed Friday that Taiwan's government will not retroactively recognize Chinese diplomas that were obtained before Sept. 3, when Taiwan began implementing a policy to recognize diplomas from China.

The issue of recognizing Chinese diplomas is a contentious one, with critics, including those from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, expressing concerns that it would hurt Taiwanese graduates and job seekers.

Wu said Friday that for people who earned diplomas from Taiwan-recognized Chinese universities before that date but after 1992, the government is considering certifying their academic qualifications through an examination or verification process.
The process would be different from "automatic recognition" of their diplomas, Wu said during a question and answer session in the Legislative Yuan.

Wu was responding to concerns by opposition lawmakers that such a plan, which is being drafted by the Ministry of Education (MOE) , could violate the principle of non-retroactivity for Chinese diploma recognition.

The legislature passed an amendment to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area in August to pave the way for the recognition of Chinese diplomas. The amended law was implemented on Sept. 3.
A total of 41 top Chinese universities are currently recognized by Taiwan.

Minister of Education Wu Ching-ji explained that the plan to certify the academic qualifications of graduates of these 41 Chinese universities is aimed at protecting the rights of Taiwan's residents who received education in China after the statute was enacted in 1992.
According to the MOE's plan, the diploma holders will need to meet certain requirements before their academic qualifications can be certified by the government.

For bachelor's degree holders, they have to prove that they studied eight semesters and stayed 32 months in China. The requirements for master's degree holders is two semesters and eights months, and those for doctorate degree holders are four semesters and 16 months, Wu said.
Those who earned their degrees through correspondence programs will not get certification, he added.
Also Friday, Deputy Minister of Education Lin Tsong-ming said the certification requirements will apply not only to diploma holders who are Taiwanese but also to Chinese and other foreign nationals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's public least happy with police services: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 20:06:11 (By Ming-Chung Lee and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's public has given the government a satisfaction rating of 77.6 percent in terms of the quality of public services provided, with police services given the lowest rating, the latest government survey has found.

Survey results showed that respondents were most pleased with the household registration services, giving it a satisfaction rating of 95.1 percent. Household registration services include issuing new ID cards or registering marriages.

Three other public services enjoyed satisfaction ratings of over 90 percent. They were the mass rapid transit systems (94.2 percent) , the Taiwan High Speed Rail (93.3 percent) , and public arts and cultural institutions (90.1 percent).
On the other hand, police and employment services got the worst satisfaction ratings, 68.9 percent and 69.3 percent respectively, according to the poll.

The results also showed 78.7 percent of the respondents were happy about public employees' attitudes, but only 63.5 percent of the respondents thought the government agencies they had dealt with were operating efficiently, the telephone survey found.
The Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) under the Executive Yuan commissioned the study. The study was conducted between September 28 and 30 by the Taiwan Real Survey Co. Ltd.
Questionnaires were collected from a total of 1,087 adults, age 18 or older. The survey has a sampling error of plus or minus 2.97 percentage points and a confidence level of 95 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: 21 percent of local toys tested found unsafe: Standards Bureau
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 20:22:26 (By Lin Shu-yuan and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Nearly 21 percent of locally sold toys tested in a recent survey contained an excessive level of plasticizers and 15 percent lacked the proper labeling, the Bureau of Standards, Metrology, and Inspection revealed Friday.

Of 52 items tested, including bathtub toys and inflatables, 11 contained a level of phthalate ester that exceeded the national standard of 0.1 percent of a toy's weight, said Huang Lai-ho, the bureau's deputy director-general.
The amount of the plasticizer in the 11 products found to be substandard ranged from 0.14 percent to 38.79 percent, according to the bureau's test results.
The bureau said it ordered the manufacturers of the defective items to recall them within a set timeframe or face fines ranging from NT$100,000 to NT$1 million.

Plasticizers are additives used in plastic products to increase their flexibility or plasticity. It is believed that they disrupt a child's hormone system, with a link to feminization among boys and breast cancer in women.
Meanwhile, eight of the toys checked either did not have safety labels or labels with complete product information in Chinese, Huang said.

Companies selling products without the required safety labels can be fined between NT$200,000 and NT$2 million, and those offering goods without acceptable Chinese product labels are subject to fines of NT$100,000 to NT$1 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA News Budget for Oct. 15 (II)

TEXT.P: international organizations

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan presents silver plates to rescued Chilean miners
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 20:30:51 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has presented congratulatory letters and silver-coated plates to 33 rescued Chilean miners for their bravery and ingenuity while trapped in a collapsed mine in northern Chile, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.

Taiwan's representative office in Chile has also conveyed the warmest wishes of the government and people and their admiration for the remarkable rescue effort to Chilean Foreign Minister Alfredo Moreno, the ministry said in a statement.

The representative office said in its letter to Moreno that Chile's government should be recognized and congratulated for the professional, compassionate and efficient manner in which it handled the unprecedentedly complex rescue under the leadership of President Sebastian Pinera.
The miners' ordeal of surviving being trapped 624 meters underground for 69 days was an inspirational feat of endurance and resilience and a triumph of the human spirit, the letter said.
Meanwhile, the ministry said the congratulatory letters and gifts for the 33 miners were forwarded through a proper Chilean channel.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Taiwan dollar might appreciate further next year

TEXT.P: A local research institute forecast Friday that Taiwan's currency will rise from this year's annual average of NT$31.68 to NT$30.42 against the U.S. dollar next year on the back of speculative capital inflow into Taiwan.
The Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research predicted that the New Taiwan dollar will average an estimated NT$31.68 against the greenback for the whole of 2010, up 4.17 percent from last year.

The institute believes the currency will continue to rise next year, "but to a relatively lesser extent, " said Wang Lee-rong, director of the institute's Center for Economic Forecasting, at a press briefing.
At the press conference, Kuo Nai-fong, an economist at Taipei's Shih Hsin University, said the forecast for next year's exchange rate is "underestimated."
"It's very likely that the currency will appreciate (against the greenback) more than this forecast," he said.
Speculative capital seeking short-term profits has been flowing into Asia, prompting the local unit to hit NT$30.77 against the dollar a day earlier, marking a new high in more than two years.
Kuo predicted bigger fluctuations in Taiwan's exchange rate next year, which will make local companies face a greater level of uncertainty.
This, he added, will increase the jobless rate.
Rick Lo, a senior economist with Fubon Financial Holding Co., forecast that the New Taiwan dollar will hover at around NT$30.50 to NT$31.00 against the dollar next year.
He added that the greenback will become stronger by the second quarter of next year at the earliest if the U.S. can stabilize its economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to promote four local delicacies abroad
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 20:42:22 (By Ming-chung Lee and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The public has selected stinky tofu and three other Taiwanese delicacies as most representative of Taiwanese tastes and flavors, the Government Information Office said Friday.
The contest, which also selected three other Taiwanese snacks - oyster omelet, braised meat rice and bubble tea - was organized to promote Taiwanese cuisine.

A total of 8,117 people voted online in an activity sponsored by the GIO to select the four most representative snacks among four groupings -- stinky tofu vs. pork blood cake, oyster omelet vs. Taiwan meat ball, mini steam bun vs. braised meat rice and bubble tea vs. mango shredded ice.
GIO Minister Johnny Chiang will host a prize drawing and local delicacy tasting event on Monday to kickoff activities to promote the snacks overseas.
Meanwhile, Taiwanese entertainer Jacko will accompany 10 foreigners to a Taipei night market to experience Taiwanese delicacies and an English-friendly environment on Friday night.

This was part of the government's efforts to encourage more shops to provide English language service to tourists. If the shops do so, they will be given an English service emblem, which indicates the shops have bilingual menus or English signs as well as English-speaking staff.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travel agencies protest sale of air tickets at convenience stores

TEXT.P: A group representing the country's travel agencies criticized a domestic airline for selling tickets through convenience stores, which they said violated the law and their exclusive rights.

The 7-Eleven convenience store chain began offering UNI Air e-tickets on Sept. 28, and the Travel Agent Association of R.O.C. Taiwan (TAAT) contended that the travel industry has suffered considerably because of it.

TAAT Chairman Yao Ta-Kuang said the behavior of the carrier and convenience store chain violated the Act for the Development of Tourism, which stipulates that only travel agencies are authorized to sell "land, sea, or air transportation tickets" on a commission basis.
"We can't tolerate the airline's attempt to manipulate the market, " Yao said, warning that travel agencies would take strong action to protest if the airline did not shut down the ticketing system.
Yao contended that by selling cheaper airline tickets at the convenience stores, the airline has threatened both the market mechanism and the livelihood of Taiwan's 2,800 travel agencies.

UNI Air responded that it had reported the system to Taiwan's aviation regulator, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA), and said the convenience stores only provided access to the carrier's website rather than actually selling tickets on its behalf.
According to UNI Air, the average number of tickets sold through its website via convenience store links ranged from 150 to 180 daily.

The airline said the new service had mostly benefited soldiers on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, where sales accounted for more than 90 percent of the tickets sold through convenience stores.
The Tourism Bureau said it had asked the airline and 7-Eleven to explain the issue and pledged to investigate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese pitcher nominated for 'Setup Man of the Year'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 21:49:54 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese pitcher Kuo Hong-chih has been nominated for the "Setup Man of the Year" award for 2010, according to a report posted on the Los Angeles Dodgers official website Friday.

Kuo, who concluded the best MLB season of his career Oct. 3 by securing the Dodgers record for lowest ERA based on a minimum of at least 50 innings pitched, has already won the "Setup Man of the Year" once, in 2008.
Given his remarkable performance during the 2010 season, Kuo is likely to clinch the honor again this year, Dodgers.com reporter Ken Gurnick wrote.
The left-hander started the season injured but later emerged as the Dodgers' best reliever and the only one in Major League Baseball to record at least 10 saves and 20 holds during the 2010 season.
It was his best season since first making the Dodgers roster in 2005. He struck out 73 while yielding only 29 hits and 18 walks in 60 innings pitched.
Aside from his record-setting ERA, his WHIP (walks and hits per inning pitched) was an astounding 0.78. Anything below 1 is considered outstanding.
The 29-year-old pitcher started the 2010 season as a setup man but was installed as a closer in mid-August in place of the struggling Jonathan Braxton.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visiting Japanese taiko drummers enjoy farm tour
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 22:34:55 (By Pokai Huang and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: A group of Japanese high school students, in Taiwan to perform on taiko drums, took advantage of some time off after a performance recently to visit a farm in Tainan County Friday.

The Japan Sanyo Daiko Dan, a group from Sanyo Senior High School in Hiroshima, made the visit four days after putting on a show at the 2010 Nanying International Folklore Festival, which is taking place in the southern Taiwan county from Oct. 9 to Oct. 17.
The group made its way to Houbi Township's Jing Liao Community, made famous after serving as the backdrop of a prominent 2004 documentary about rice farming called "Let It Be."
Farmer Huang Kun-bin, the protagonist in the film, showed the Japanese students around the village to get a feel for life in the old-time farming community.

The sixteen boys in the group rode on a water buffalo carriage, a traditional means of transportation for Taiwanese farmers, and they enjoyed a special meal that included the village's award-winning rice.
"We sprinkled sesame on the rice today to make them feel especially at home," the 77-year-old Huang said.
The group's teacher Makoto Sasaki complimented the local rice, saying it tasted similar to Japan's sushi rice.
The teenagers were also excited to touch a buffalo's horns and head.
"It is the first time my students saw a water buffalo grazing and rode on a carriage pulled by the animal, " Sasaki said.
Let It Be was the most popular film of its kind in 2004 and sparked a heated debate about the impact on agriculture of Taiwan's ascension to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: "Green Island Elephant" spreads message of unity, eco-friendliness

TEXT.P: An orange "elephant" from Green Island off Taiwan's southeastern coast arrived in northern Taiwan Friday in what its owner called a fulfillment of its dream to travel around Taiwan.

The elephant, actually an old playground slide designed in the shape of the animal, is serving as a cultural ambassador that embodies the environmental spirit of Green Island and hopes to unify all of Taiwan's townships, said the slide's owner Lee Meng-fa.
"I hope my elephant can make a lot of friends throughout his journey," Lee said. "He is the guardian angel of Green Island and the friend of every Taiwanese."
Lee said the elephant's journey north was made to raise environmental awareness and encourage eco-friendliness, as the elephant slide itself barely escaped the fate of being discarded last year.

When Green Island Primary School tried to throw away the 24-year-old playground fixture -- the object of precious childhood memories of many of the island's 3,000 residents -- Lee reached out and bought it for NT$100.
Determined to turn it into a public art work and a landmark of Green Island, Lee worked with students of Taitung Gungguan Primary School to paint the slide and give it a new face.

Transporting the 3-meter long, 2-meter wide by 1.5-meter high elephant was no easy task. After being shipped by ferry from Green Island to Taiwan's eastern Taitung County, it changed cargo trains twice as it proceeded up the east coast before arriving in northern Taiwan's Yingge Township at 8 a.m.

Unable to accompany his "elephant" in the cargo train, Lee drove himself north to wait for his prized animal at the Yingge station, and when the 80 kilogram elephant finally arrived, its fans and the station master cheered.
Lee plans for the elephant to visit Taipei City Zoo on Oct. 16 and also to cheer on the Brother Elephants, one of Taiwan's most popular professional baseball teams.
The "Green Island Elephant" has gained fame on Facebook with almost 3,000 fans, and Lee believes it has plenty more to give as an icon for unity and environmentalism and a landmark of Green Island.
"A small NT$100 can create a big dream far beyond our imagination, " Lee said. "Who said it can't be the icon of Taiwan just like the Little Mermaid symbolizes Denmark? "

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiyen Biotech develops heat sink with special properties
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/10 23:45:47 (By S. C. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiyen Biotech Co., Taiwan's former salt monopoly, will soon expand into the optoelectronics sector after successfully developing and manufacturing high- performance heat sinks, Taiyen Biotech Chairman Hung Hsi-yao announced Friday.

Hung said his company has begun producing aluminum nitride (AIN) heat sinks that dissipate heat 10-times faster than traditional aluminum oxide models because of their relatively high thermal conductivity, ideal for a number of high-tech products.

"My company has signed a letter of intent with Forworld Electronics Co. to begin commercial production of the high-power heat sinks, which will be installed in Forworld's blue-ray DVD players, " Hung said.
"This is part of Taiyen Biotech's efforts to make inroads into the consumer product market."
Mass production will help bring down the price of the AIN heat sink, enabling it to compete with devices made of other materials and even Japanese products, Hung added.
Taiyen is applying for a patent for its AIN heat sink in both Taiwan and China, Hung noted.

Forworld Chairman Gorden Teng said his company will change to AIN heat sinks in the future because they will effectively help reduce temperatures in its blue- ray DVD players by six to seven degrees Celsius.

Apart from manufacturing and selling salt products such as edible, industrial, agricultural and fishery salts, Taiyen Biotech has over the past decade diversified into manufacturing fields such as cosmetics, microbial pesticides and toner-cartridge components.
