An electronics shop with 18 branches nationwide upon hearing of their difficulty purchased 600 to 700 sock rabbits to give to shoppers who spent over NT$2500 on certain appliances between Oct. 8 and Oct. 24.

Our business partners were very surprised when we chose to work with the foundation to promote charity. The main reason was the sock bunnies were much more expensive than most additional gifts, which cost around NT$50 to NT$100, said Chen Hsin-hong, a special assistant in the companys business planning department.

Because information and technology months take place every December, October is a relatively low season for electronic stores. We hope to cooperate with charity groups every October to engage the public in philanthropic work,said Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei thanks Indonesian workers with concert

TEXT.P: Thousands of Indonesians gathered in Taipei Sunday to enjoy an annual blow-out party organized by the city's Department of Labor (DOL) as a token of appreciation to migrant workers from the southeast Asian country.

With hands waving high in the air and cameras flashing, many screaming fans went wild as members of Relix, a band composed of Indonesian nationals, jumped up and down and sang their hearts out for the audience.
The concert was one of many events that took place during this year's Indonesian Cultural Day.

We want to express our highest appreciation and gratitude for the contributions made by Indonesian workers to Taiwan. The welfare of foreign workers is an important matter to us, and this is why we set up a Foreign Workers Affairs section in August to better ensure the rights of our foreign friends, said department director-general Chen Yeh-shin.

The highlight of the day-long festivities held in Taipeis 228 Memorial Park was the performance by Pinkan Mambo, a beloved Indonesian pop diva whose appearance caused an instant uproar from the crowd.

I am so happy for today because I am here with my friends, and I have a chance to enjoy music from my country. I like Taiwan so much, said Saraswati, a domestic worker who has been working in Taipei for three years.
Amy Cheng, who has been married to a Taiwanese man for six years, said events such as this help her to connect with home even though she is so far away.
According to the DOL, there are over 25,000 registered Indonesian nationals currently working in Taipei City, as well as around 400 Indonesian women married to Taiwanese men.

The latest figures from the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics show that Indonesian workers account for the largest percentage of the nation's migrant workforce with 39.7 percent or 139,404 people, followed by workers from Vietnam and the Philippines. (By Jenny W. Hsu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Eastern Taiwan hit hard by heavy rains

TEXT.P: Eastern Taiwan has been hit by heavy rains, with accumulated precipitation reaching 100 millimeters from midnight to 6 p.m. Sunday at several weather observation stations in Hualien County.
Hualien's Xiulin Township has recorded the island's highest precipitation of 169 millimeters, said the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
The heavy rain, a result of the combined effects of strong seasonal winds from the northeast and Typhoon Megi from the southeast, has claimed one life in Hualien County in the past two days.
Around a hundred gorge walkers were surprised by the sudden floods and trapped during their trip Saturday. Although they were later evacuated, the group's coach fell into a stream and died.
In another incident, a car also fell into a river and one passenger is currently missing.
A total of 118 people have been evacuated to prevent further causalities, the Hualien Couty Fire Department said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 18, or 11th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1405: Pope Pius II, originally named Enea Silivio Piccolomini, is born. He was noted for his unsuccessful attempt to lead a crusade against the Turks.
1860: Invading British troops burn the Yuanmingyuan, the imperial summer palace in Beijing, to the ground.
1867: The United States purchases Alaska from Russia for US$7.2 million.
1873: Delegates from Columbia, Princeton, Rutgers, and Yale universities meet and formulate the rules for American football.
1898: The United States takes possession of Puerto Rico from Spain.
1907: The first plans are announced for an International Court of Justice to be set up in The Hague.
1922: Tsai Yuan-pei, a scholar and the president of Peking University, resigns in the wake of student protests against an extra levy on professor's handouts.
1926: The will of Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian founder of the Bolshevik party, leader of the Russian Revolution and first head of the USSR, is made public to the world in the New York Times.
1931: Thomas Alva Edison, America's most prolific inventor, dies at the age of 84. His inventions include the phonograph, the microphone and the kinescope.
1941: General Hideki Tojo becomes prime minister of Japan and begins planning for war against the United States.
1944: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt cables Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government and supreme commander of the China theater of war, regarding his decision to appoint Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China theater of war to succeed Gen. Joseph Stilwell.
1946: The Chinese communists reject the government's latest peace offer presented by Chiang Kai-shek on Oct. 16.
1967: Venera 4, a Soviet spacecraft, enters the atmosphere of Venus and transmits data back to earth.
1970: Vice President Yen Chia-kan, who concurrently holds the post of premier, leaves Taipei for New York to attend the 25th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations.
1974: Acting for President Chiang Kai-shek, Vice President Yen Chia-kan accepts the credentials of Maj. Gen. Ismael D. Lapus as the Philippines ambassador to the Republic of China.
1974: The ROC national taekwondo team returns from Seoul after taking second place in the First Asian Taekwondo championships.
1976: Chinese-American scientist Samuel Chao Chung Ting and his colleague Burton Richter share the 1976 Nobel Prize for physics for their discovery of an elementary nuclear particle called the "psi," or "J particle."
1987: The United States attacks an Iranian oil rig in revenge for strikes against its shipping operations by gunboats.
1989: Erich Honecker, 77, East Germany's hardline ruler who failed to respond to the desire among East Germans for change, is ousted from the post he held for the previous 18 years.
1989: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a World Cup qualifying soccer match in Guatemala. Eighty- three people are killed and nearly 200 others are injured.
1990: The Mainland Affairs Council is established under the Executive Yuan to formulate and implement mainland policy, with Vice Premier Shih Chi-yang serving as its chairman.
1998: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC's Straits Exchange Foundation, crowns a six-day visit to mainland China by meeting with President Jiang Zemin, marking the highest-level contact between the two sides since 1949.
1999: Two more Knox-class frigates leased from the United States are commissioned in order to help beef up the Republic of China's naval defense capabilities.
2000: A seminar on trade and economic cooperation among the three Chinese communities -- Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong -- opens in Beijing.
2001: "President A-bian's Electronic Paper, " an online newspaper published by the Presidential Office is formally launched.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian reiterats the long-standing relations between the Republic of China and Paraguay when he receives visiting National Asuncion University President Paul Battilana.
2001: Several hundred Falun Gong practitioners from Taiwan, Europe and the United States gathers in front of the mainland Chinese embassy in Belgium to protest Beijing's suppression of the movement.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, by living a life of simple truth and earnestness, alone can help to bring peace and order in the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan shares open slightly higher

The weighted price index lost 10.15 points, or 0.12 percent, to close at 8,205.3 Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Banker gets 9 year jail term for financial scam

TEXT.P: Jeffrey Koo Jr., former vice chairman of Chinatrust Financial Holding Co., was sentenced to nine years in prison Monday for his role in a financial scandal.

The Taipei District Court found Koo guilty of violating the Securities and Exchange Act and the Banking Act with regard to irregularities in transactions of structured notes linked to Mega Financial Holding during the period 2005-2006.
The financial scam allowed an offshore paper company, Red Fire Developments, which was set up by Koo's trusted subordinates, to pocket a windfall and caused losses for Chinatrust Financial.
The scam, known locally as the Red Fire Case, surfaced following prosecutors' intensive investigations into a bid by Chinatrust Financial to take over Mega Financial.
Koo can appeal the ruling of the district court. (By Lai Yu-chia, Lin Chang-sen and Frances Huang)/MH

DOC.HEADLINE: Heavy rain warning issued for eastern, northeastern Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 12:16:17 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a warning for people in eastern and northeastern Taiwan Monday, reminding residents in Hualien and Yilan counties to take precautions against torrential rain as the island came under the influence of the outer rim of an approaching typhoon in addition to strong seasonal winds from the northeast.
The CWB issued the warning at 9: 40 a.m. Earlier, it reported Typhoon Megi would make landfall on northern Luzon in the Philippines at noon.

As of 8 a.m., Megi was located 570 kilometers south-southeast of Eluanbi in Pingtung County, southern Taiwan, moving westward at a speed of 17 kilometers per hour. The storm was packing maximum sustained winds of 234 kph, with gusts of up to 288 kph.
The bureau forecast that the center of the typhoon would be 570 km south- southwest of Eluanbi by 8 a.m. Tuesday.

Although the storm radius had expanded from 250 km to 280 km in the past few hours, the strong typhoon was not expected to batter Taiwan due to its distance from the island, meteorologists at the bureau said.
But Taiwan would experience the combined effects of the storm's outer rim and seasonal winds from the northeast, they said.
Sea transport services between Taitung and two outlying islands off eastern Taiwan, Lanyu and Green Island, have been suspended for Monday and Tuesday due to strong winds and high waves.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Job-hopping soars as economy regains momentum

TEXT.P: With the domestic economy continuing to gather steam after the 2008-2009 global financial crisis, an exceptionally strong job-hopping trend is hitting the local employment market, according to recent government surveys.

The Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) classifies those who have not yet landed a new job after quitting their original positions due to discontent with working conditions as "job hoppers."

In terms of this definition, the number of "job hoppers" has been on a steady rise since the beginning of this year, making it the longest uninterrupted upward spiral in local history, DGBAS officials said.
The following is an excerpt from a local newspaper's coverage of the trend:
United Daily News:

In the past, local people tended to resign after receiving year-end bonuses or at the end of the lunar new year holiday, and the number of job-hoppers normally declined steadily after the second quarter of the year.
"The continued rise in the number of job-hoppers in the first eight months of this year was rare in our job market, " said a DGBAS official.

Moreover, he said, the number of job-hoppers hit 153,000 in August, also a historic record. The number of job-hoppers rose steadily from 123,000 in January, 125,000 in February, 126,000 in March, 133,000 in April, 141,000 in May, 142,000 in June to 148,000 in July, according to DGBAS statistics.

Ho Chi-sheng, a 111 Job Bank executive, said many local white-collar workers have endured "double stress" from increased workload due to work force trimming and potential threat of layoffs amid economic slowdown over the past two years.
"Against this backdrop, many of them want[/] to change jobs to seek better working terms now that the general economic situation has improved to offer better job prospects," Ho said.

Hsin Ping-lung, a professor at National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of National Development, said the local employment market will definitely see a stronger job-hopping trend this year because there are far more openings than those available in the previous two years.
In his view, Hsin said younger office workers with little or no financial burden to support their families are more likely to join the "job-hopping" group of people. (Oct. 18, 2010). ed/MH

DOC.HEADLINE: Banker gets 9-year jail term for financial scam (update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 13:02:02 (By Lai Yu-chia, Lin Chang-sen and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Jeffrey Koo Jr., former vice chairman of Chinatrust Financial Holding Co., was sentenced to nine years in prison Monday for his role in a financial scandal.

The Taipei District Court found Koo guilty of violating the Securities and Exchange Act and the Banking Act with regard to irregularities in transactions of structured notes linked to Mega Financial Holding Co. during the period 2005-2006.
The ruling of the district court can be appealed.

The financial scam allowed an offshore paper company, Red Fire Developments, which was set up by Koo's trusted subordinates, to pocket a windfall and caused losses for Chinatrust Financial, according to the indictment.
The scam, known locally as the Red Fire Case, surfaced following prosecutors' intensive investigations into a bid by Chinatrust Financial to take over Mega Financial.

Koo was indicted in December 2009 on suspicion of masterminding the scam. The trial in the district court started in February 2010 and Koo was barred from leaving the country out of fears that he would avoid the trial.

Koo was accused of instructing China Financial's unit Chinatrust Commercial Bank to buy structured notes linked to Mega Financial from issuer Barclays Bank PLC without approval from the board of directors.

During the trial, Koo repeatedly denied the accusations, saying the takeover of Mega Financial and the purchase of the structured notes were simply financial investments and he had no knowledge of the transaction with Red Fire Developments.

Through its branch in Hong Kong, Chinatrust Commercial Bank bought a total of US$390 million worth of structured notes and then sold the securities at a lower price to Red Fire in what prosecutors deemed a non-arm's length deal so that the paper company, which had been capitalized at just US$1, garnered about NT$1 billion (US$32.61 million) in profit.
After the transaction, Red Fire wired the proceeds to several other offshore companies to avoid possible tracing of the illegal funds, prosecutors said.
ed/MH

DOC.HEADLINE: Average wage poised to further increase: labor affairs minister

TEXT.P: The average wage in Taiwan is expected to increase in the next few months to a figure that is higher than that of before the global economic crisis, Council of Labor Affairs Minister Wang Ju-hsuan said Monday at the Legislative Yuan.

Wang told reporters that according to the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics (DGBAS) , a record number of 153,000 people switched jobs in August, an indication of a high level of confidence among the workforce.
During the global economic crisis, she said, many people were apprehensive about changing jobs.

"However, right now the situation favors the workers, because we are at a point where we don't have enough people to fill the current job vacancies. Furthermore, improvements in wages and working conditions allows job seekers to have a wider range of options," Wang said.

She noted that the average wage for the first seven months was NT$47,000 (US$1,516.13) , up from the 2007-2008 figure of NT$44,000, and well up from the NT$42,000 average last year during the peak of the global economic downturn.

The latest jobless rate reported by the DGBAS in August was 5.17 percent and Wang expressed confidence that the figure will drop below the 5 percent mark by the end of the year as promised by Premier Wu Den-yih.

DOC.HEADLINE: New foreign trade bureau chief sworn in

TEXT.P: The new head of the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) was sworn in Monday and is expected to lead a new round of trade negotiations with China in the coming months.

Cho Shih-chao, Taiwan's former representative to Kuwait, said in his new capacity as director-general of the BOFT under the Ministry of Economic Affairs that foreign government officials and business leaders have changed their attitudes toward Taiwan since the signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China on June 29.
"I felt an obvious difference in the attitudes of foreign officials before and since the signing of the ECFA when I was posted overseas, " he said during a press meet after his swearing-in ceremony.
"Before cross-Taiwan Strait relations improved, foreign government officials tried to avoid me," Cho added.
"However, in the wake of the signing, many are now glad to talk with me about future developments," he said.
Asked about his thoughts on upcoming Taiwan-China trade talks, he said he needs more time to study the details, pointing out that he had just returned home a day earlier.

Taiwan and China are expected to negotiate deals on cargo trade, service trade, investment protection and dispute settlement within the six-month period from mid-September, when the trade pact took effect.
Cho's predecessor, Huang Chih-peng, left the BOFT to assume his new post as Taiwan's representative to Vietnam earlier in the month.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Judicial reforms need more than lip service

TEXT.P: When Judicial Yuan President Rai Hau-min assumed office last week he pledged determination and effort to speed up much anticipated judicial reform in order to win back people's trust in the court system.

His strategies for achieving this goal included promulgating legislation of a draft Judge Act to make it possible to fire incompetent judges, and promotion of a system allowing public participation in the trial process.

Though a mechanism for dismissing poorly performing judges is essential for maintaining the professionalism and independence of judicial personnel, the other side of the same coin is promotion of a system that cultivates good judges.

More than half Taiwan's judges are under 30 years of age having entered the profession by passing national certification examinations targeted at graduates from law schools. Are these young judges really capable of winning public trust?

As for the proposal for public participation, while the goal is laudable the means is still a mystery. The Judicial Yuan seems disinclined to introduce a U.S.- or U.K.-style jury system, nor does it plan to adopt public or expert participation, which could violate existing laws stipulating judicial procedures should be closed-door to ensure independence.
It is hoped that the country's top judicial authority can produce concrete, effective and achievable measures capable of realizing its promises of judicial reforms. (Oct. 18, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei human milk bank recognized by U.K. association

TEXT.P: A human milk bank in Taipei has won recognition from an English association, making it the first internationally certified milk bank in Asia, officials of the Taipei City Hospital, Branch for Women and Children said Monday.

Since its establishment in December 2004, the milk bank has collected more than 10 million cc of breast milk from 1,008 donors nationwide, benefiting 1,244 infants born prematurely or who have infectious diseases or feeding intolerance, said Fang Li-jung, head of the hospital's pediatrics department.
Fang said that with the milk bank certification by the United Kingdom Association for Milk Banking, the safety of the donated milk is assured.
In an effort to recruit more breastfeeding mothers willing to donate surplus milk, Fang introduced Lee Chen-yi, a regular donor from Hsinchu City, to talk about being a milk donor.
Dubbed a "milk donor master" for having donated 98,080 cc of milk, Lee said she feels proud to be able to help other children in need and that she has even lost 22 kg thanks to donating her milk.

"Whenever my friends or family members have a problem with breastfeeding, they come to me for help. While teaching them how to express milk, I also encourage them to enter the donor program," said Lee, who sends her frozen milk to Taipei every two weeks via a delivery service paid for by the bank.
"Breast milk is the gift of nature and the best nutrition for babies, especially sick ones who need their immune systems boosted," said Yuan Chiou-chung, the hospital's superintendent.

Yuan added that there are cases in which newborns cannot get milk from their mothers and must rely on the milk bank for help, such as when their mothers die in childbirth or when their mothers have AIDS.

The milk bank, working with the Bureau of Health Promotion, established a milk bank station at Taichung Hospital in 2009 to make donating milk more convenient for women living in southern parts of the country.
Fang said that while prior to the opening of the Taichung milk station, 80 percent to 90 percent of the donors were from northern regions, there has now been a rise in the number of southern donors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 1.76 percent

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 1.76 percent Monday as pressure focused on the bellwether electronics sector amid lingering concerns over weakening global demand for high-tech products, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 144.76 points to 8,060.54, after moving between 8,057.12 and 8,209.39, on turnover of NT$113.35 billion (US$3.69 billion).

The market opened up 4.09 points on a mixed performance on Wall Street at the end of last week. Selling followed to drag down high-tech firms, in particular large-cap stocks, on fears that a slower global economy will hurt the bottom line in the fourth quarter of this year, dealers said.
A total of 3,130 stocks closed down and 795 were up, with 214 remaining unchanged.

The construction sector suffered the steepest decline, down 2.6 percent. Paper and pulp stocks fell 2.3 percent, textile shares lost 2.2 percent, financials shed 2.0 percent, and machinery and electronics stocks closed down 1.9 percent.
The plastics and chemicals sector fell 1.6 percent, the cement stocks lost 1.3 percent and foodstuffs closed down 0.6 percent.

"The heavy selling has made the market technically weak, " Taiwan International Securities analyst Benson Huang said. "It is possible the index will test the key 8,000-point level soon amid cautious sentiment," he added.

Huang said there have been signs that liquidity is draining out of the market as the central bank has stepped up measures to shore up the U.S. dollar to prevent a rapid appreciation of the local currency.

Huang said the electronics sector needs more liquidity to push itself out of the current downward trend, in particular as a gloomy mood over earnings has already haunted share prices of high-tech stocks.
"But, with more and more investors retreating from the trading floor, the hopes for a meaningful rebound in the sector were dimmer," he said.
Huang said he suspected that the selling came largely from foreign institutional investors who dumped large-cap electronics and semiconductor stocks.
Smartphone maker HTC fell 6.87 percent to finish at NT$624.00 and integrated circuit designer MediaTek shed 3.59 percent to end at NT$376.00.
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. lost 2.26 percent to close at NT$60.50 and United Microelectronics Corp. fell 2.20 percent to end the day at NT$13.35.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese rock band well received in Paraguay

TEXT.P: A rock and reggae band from Taiwan has been well received during a South America tour that included two performances in Paraguay, according to Taiwan's embassy there.
Arrangements for the band, Matzka, to play two shows in Taiwan's only South American diplomatic ally were made by the Government Information Office of Taiwan, the embassy said in a press release.

The performances were part of ongoing celebrations to mark the 200th anniversary of Paraguay's independence and the 100th anniversary of the establishment of the Republic of China, both of which take place next year.
The band played in the Paraguayan capital of Asuncion Oct. 14 and in the nearby town of Luque the following day.

The musicians made friends at both shows with their carnival-like performances. Fans surrounded them seeking autographs and photographs and asking when they could buy the group's music, according to the embassy.

After congratulating the band, Carlos Amarilla, governor of the Central Department of Paraguay, expressed hope that it can return next year for the Independence Day celebrations. Each band member was also given a piece of the traditional Paraguayan lace called nanduti.
Matzka, founded in eastern Taiwan's Taitung County by four young aboriginal men, left Taiwan Oct. 5 on a tour that also took them to Peru and Panama. It was scheduled to return Oct. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to open doors to independent Chinese visitors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 16:45:18 (By Maranda Hsu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is set to accept independent Chinese visitors, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said Monday.

Speaking at a legislative session, Mao said the Cabinet had determined in principle that Taiwan would open its doors to three categories of Chinese visitors -- tourists, business visitors and visitors to outlying islands -- but that details of the opening were still in the pipeline.
Management would differ for these three categories, Mao said in response to questions raised by two Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers.

Details would be publicized in the near future, he said, but for example, management of general Chinese tourists would be strictest, and would include restrictions on the number allowed to enter Taiwan each day.
At present, Chinese travelers can only visit Taiwan in organized groups.
Operators in the local hospitality industry reacted positively to the government's initiatives to open Taiwan to independent Chinese travelers.

Chen Jung-hui, assistant manager with the Ambassador Hotel Taipei, said five- star tourist hotels had not benefited greatly to date from the country's opening to Chinese tourist groups because of the cost factor.
"We look forward to independent Chinese visitors, who will be more likely to check into hotels of higher rates," Chen said.

For Liu Chun-hao, marketing manager with the Leofoo Group, the soon-to-open independent visitor program had already improved business for the group, with Chinese travel agencies booking rooms and restaurants at its up-scale facilities such as the Westin Taipei and the Leofoo Resort.

In related news, Mao responded to a complaint by KMT Legislator Tsai Chin-lung regarding high ticket prices for non-stop flights across the Taiwan Strait compared to those of transit flights. Addressing the issue for the first time, the minister said it was wishful thinking to expect non-stop tickets to be as cheap as commuter flights, and that a small fare increase was justifiable.

DOC.HEADLINE: First child care center fined for not reporting enterovirus

TEXT.P: A child care center in Songshang district, Taipei City, was fined for not reporting suspected cases of enterovirus, Taipei City government announced Monday, adding that this was the first time the city had issued a fine for this reason.

A tip-off from the public led to an on-site investigation Sept. 16 that confirmed three unreported enterovirus infection cases at the center, said Ou Chia-ling, assistant director of the city's Division for Disease Control and Prevention. She noted that the center will be subject to a fine of NT$3,000 (US$94).

In a regulation announced June 15, kindergartens, child care centers, and all schools in the city up to high school level must report suspected cases exhibiting hand, foot and mouth disease, herpangina and enterovirus within 48 hours of detection.

Ou said that cases of mild enterovirus infection had been discovered recently, and that parents should pay attention to environmental sanitation, and whenever possible, disinfect the surroundings with 1:100 dilution of household bleach.

DOC.HEADLINE: Global experts gather in Taiwan for physics and computing forum
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 17:07:34 (By Lin Szu-Yu and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: The International Conference on Computing in High Energy and Nuclear Physics (CHEP) opened in Taiwan Monday, the first time the meeting has been convened in the country since first held in 1985.

Some 500 physicists and computing professionals from 27 countries are attending the five-day conference at Academia Sinica, Taiwan's leading research institute. They are scheduled to present 465 papers covering seven major themes.

This year's conference comes at an important time in the world of physics. It is the first global forum to be held since the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) run by the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) was launched again in March, said convener Simon Lin, an associate research fellow at Academia Sinica.
The LHC, a huge particle accelerator said to be able to recreate the moments following the Big Bang, is expected to challenge previous understandings of how the universe works.
Teams involved in four detector experiments using the collider -- ATLAS, CMS, ALICE and LHCb -- will present their latest data and explain their tools of analysis at this week's forum, Lin added.
Taiwan is one of the 34 countries participating in the operation of the Worldwide LHC Computing Grid (WLCG) , a distributed computing and data storage infrastructure, according to CERN's website.

Speaking further on Taiwan's efforts in basic research and scientific development on the opening day of the conference, Vice President Vincent Siew said the government was committed to building Taiwan into an e-Science center in Asia and promoting scientific collaboration in the Asia-Pacific region.

He said applied science development was not possible without a solid foundation in basic science, which is why Taiwan has increased its funding for scientific research at local universities and research institutes to 2.8 percent of gross domestic product in recent years, close to the 3 percent seen in developed countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Banker to appeal guilty ruling: lawyer
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 17:34:33 (By Lin Chang-sen, Tien Yu-pin, and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Jeffrey Koo Jr., former vice chairman of Chinatrust Financial Holding Co., will appeal a ruling issued by the Taipei District Court to put him behind bars for his role in a financial scandal, his lawyer said Monday.

Koo was sentenced to nine years in jail by the court earlier Monday as the court found him guilty of violating the Securities and Exchange Act and the Banking Law in relation to transactions of structured notes linked to Mega Financial Holding Co.

The ruling found that Koo and other executives of Chinatrust Financial masterminded the illegal transactions which allowed offshore paper company Red Fire Developments to pocket US$30.47 million and caused losses for Chinaturst Financial.
The scam, known locally as the Red Fire Case, surfaced following prosecutors' intensive investigations into a bid by Chinatrust Financial to take over Mega Financial.
Red Fire Developments, capitalized at US$1, was set up in Hong Kong under Koo's instruction, the ruling said.
Yeh Chien-ting, a member of Koo's legal team, expressed regret over the ruling and said Koo would definitely appeal the case.
Chinatrust Financial said that, as Koo now held no post at the company, the litigation was his personal affair, and the ruling would have no impact on the company's operations.

According to the ruling, Koo, without approval from the board of directors, bought the structured notes linked to Mega Financial from issuer Barclays Bank PLC and then sold the securities in a non-arm's length transaction to Red Fire Developments, which garnered the windfall from the deal.

The ruling said that Koo embezzled US$9.57 million out of Red Developments' windfall to cover his donations to former President Chen Shui-bian in the period 2002-2005, but which he could not report to his company as having spent. He is said to have then remitted the remaining US$20.90 million to overseas units of Chinatrust Financial.
The court also ruled that Koo manipulated Mega Financial's share price before official approval of China Trust Financial's request to take over Mega Financial had been made public.

Yeh claimed the US$9.57 million had been largely appropriated by Steven Cheng, another former executive of China Trust Financial who is also Koo's brother-in- law, and that Koo had no knowledge of the use of the fund.
Cheng is on Taiwan's wanted list as he has fled the island to avoid trial.
Yeh added that Mega Financial's share price was based on market mechanisms, and Koo lacked the power to directly or indirectly influence the price.
During the trial, which started in February, Koo repeatedly denied the allegations and insisted on his innocence.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the Taiwan dollar Monday, gaining NT$0.092 to close at the day's high of NT$30.885.
Turnover totaled US$876 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.843 and moved to a low of NT$30.670 before rebounding.
Dealers said the local currency turned weaker against the U.S. dollar in line with declines in the euro and other Asian currencies as the greenback staged a rebound.

They said investors cut their holdings of Asian currencies after the U.S. Treasury decided on Friday to postpone the anticipated release of its twice- yearly currency report that may have labeled China as a currency manipulator.
The U.S. Treasury's move prompted investors in Asia's foreign exchange markets to speculate that Washington had softened its stance on pushing for the appreciation of the Chinese yuan, they added.

The stronger U.S. dollar eased the pressure on Taiwan's central bank, which had repeatedly intervened in the foreign exchange market in recent weeks to cap the Taiwan dollar's appreciation on fears that a stronger local currency would hurt Taiwan's exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should reinforce its soft power: President
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 17:55:02 (Chen Yi-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan must strengthen its soft power if it wants to stand on the world stage, President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday in a speech to business leaders from Chinese societies around the world.

Ma explained that soft power is a country's ability to get others to accept or recognize its goals by "persuading, attracting and cooperating, " citing a definition by Joseph Nye, a Harvard University scholar of politics who coined the phrase in the mid-1980s.

Ma delivered his speech, which also addressed Taiwan's economic strategies in the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) era, at the opening of the two-day 8th Annual Global Business Forum organized by the Taipei-based Chinese- language monthly business magazine Global Views.

Hundreds of enterprise leaders from around the world attended the gathering, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Chairman Morris Chang and Stan Shih, founder of the Acer Group and chairman of the iD SoftCapital Group.

Ma said the ECFA Taiwan signed with China in late June to boost bilateral trade exchanges is a shot in the arm for Taiwan, which he said can create 60,000 jobs in the country and increase production value by NT$190 billion.
"However, the ECFA is not a cure-all but more like a pair of light sports shoes that help an athlete's performance," he said.
"If an athlete is weak, it won't matter how good his shoes are, " Ma said, noting that Taiwan must reinforce its power before making inroads into the global market.

Citing the remarkable performances of Taiwan's North Pole marathon runner Chen Yen-po, tennis player Lu Yen-hsun and philanthropist vegetable vendor Chen Shu-chu, who was selected as one of Time magazine's 100 most influential people of 2010, Ma said they are all examples of Taiwan's soft power.

Taiwanese enterprises should seize the moment when such people throw Taiwan into the international spotlight to grab international market share by creating their own brand names and developing the country's services sector, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: No decision yet on replacing death penalty with life sentence: MOJ
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 18:00:31 (By Lai Yu-chia and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has not yet decided to adopt an expert proposal to replace the death penalty with a "special life sentence," a senior official said Monday.

"Some scholars recommended the proposal last Friday at a meeting of the ministry's special panel tasked with studying the feasibility of gradually phasing out the death penalty," MOJ Deputy Minister Chen Shou-huang said at a news conference.
The proposal will serve as reference for the MOJ in formulating policy, but it has not yet become established policy, as was reported by a local newspaper, Chen said.

The United Daily News reported last weekend that the MOJ's "death penalty research panel" had reached a consensus a day earlier to recommend the adoption of a "special life sentence" system in place of capital punishment.
According to the report, the proposed "special life sentence" system will stipulate that inmates given the special penalty will not be eligible for parole.
The report raised the concerns of some crime victims and their families, who staunchly oppose abolishing the death penalty, prompting the ministry to call a news conference to clarify its stance.
Chen said the report was not fully correct because the ministry had yet to endorse the recommendation.

"The proposal will serve as a reference in deciding whether to revise our existing law to pave the way for the abolition of the death penalty, but it has by no means been established as official policy," he said.

"Our policy has been that existing laws on the death penalty will remain in place until after a national consensus has been forged on the issue, public misgivings over abolishing capital punishment have been eased, and a reasonable alternative has been worked out."

The ministry's executions of four death row inmates on April 30 ended a de facto moratorium on capital punishment that had lasted for over four years, triggering heated debate locally on whether the death penalty should be phased out, in line with a growing world trend.
After the executions, the European Union urged Taiwan to resume its de facto moratorium pending eventual legal abolishment.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for outdoor regulations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 18:07:50 (By Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou instructed the Executive Yuan Monday to revise existing regulations and build new ones covering outdoor activities to ensure the safety of the public, particularly during typhoon and flood seasons.

Ma, who doubles as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), said during a KMT meeting that the Executive Yuan should come up with regulations that restrict outdoor activities in times of typhoon or flood to avoid putting unnecessary pressure on rescue or disaster prevention resources, according to Su Jun-pin, director of the KMT's Culture and Communications Committee.

The president instructed the Executive Yuan to work with the Ministry of the Interior, the National Fire Administration and the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) and to jointly come up with relevant policies to dissuade people from going outdoors during typhoons or when there is a threat of flooding, according to Su.

Ma issued the instructions after learning that a man, a river tracing guide, fell to his death in eastern Hualien County over the weekend while trying to escort his clients to safety after the river rose suddenly, while 26 people in 11 cars were stranded on an island in a river in the northeastern county of Yilan Sunday.

In related news, meanwhile, the CWB issued a warning for people in eastern and northeastern Taiwan Monday, warning residents in Hualien and Yilan counties to take precautions against torrential rain as the island came under the influence of the outer rim of Typhoon Megi, in addition to strong seasonal northeasterly winds.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign representatives sample Taiwanese delicacies

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) invited foreign dignitaries to sample Taiwanese delicacies Monday at the prize draw ceremony held to conclude the Taiwan's Yummy Snacks online contest.
GIO Minister Johnny Chi-chen Chiang served stinky tofu, pig blood cake and eight other specialty foods to foreign representatives, media and other participants.

Asked by local journalists how today's stinky tofu tasted, Ambassador William Manuel Tapia Aleman of Nicaragua said that though the stinky tofu sold at Shilin night market had a more pungent smell, both tasted equally good.

Trying pig blood cake for the first time, he said it was much like eating a popsicle. Representatives from the Jordan commercial office declined to try this unusual delicacy, which was voted top in a contest of ten weirdest foods by a U.K. travel website last year, but naturally this was due to religious reasons.
The Nicaraguan ambassador added that his favorite Taiwanese cuisine was braised pork with rice because its texture reminded him of a similar dish at home.
Chiang personally made an oyster omelet, which got the thumbs up from Ambassador Carlos Martinez Ruiz Diaz of Paraguay.

DOC.HEADLINE: Veteran coach honored with lifetime achievement award
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 18:30:17 (By Hsu Chih-wei and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: An honorary professor at National Taiwan Sport University was honored with a sports lifetime achievement award by the Ministry of Education Monday in recognition of his achievements in cultivating numerous local athletes.

An award-presentation ceremony was held at the ministry earlier in the day, in which Yeh Hsieh-ching's achievements were cited, including his service as a teacher in many different public schools in a 46-year career, as well his work as a track and field coach, which he did without remuneration at these schools for 33 years.
Yeh has also published more than 100 theses and reviewed the physical education given at 404 elementary, junior high and senior high schools around the country, according to the ministry.
Asked about his long years of service as an unpaid sports coach, Yeh said he considered coaching to be simply part of his job as a teacher.
One of Yeh's more remarkable achievements include coaching an injured javelin thrower into a record-breaking shot putter.
Lu Ching-yi broke the national record in the shot put event at the Hiroshima Asian Games in 1994.

DOC.HEADLINE: Impact of appreciating currency within expectations: TSMC

TEXT.P: Morris Chang, chairman of the world's biggest contract chip maker Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Co. (TSMC) , said Monday that the impact of the Taiwan dollar's recent appreciation was within his expectations.
The Taiwan dollar closed Friday at NT$30.793 to the U.S. dollar, up 4.1 percent against the greenback since the beginning of September.
Economists fear that the currency's appreciation could hurt the exports of the country's electronic companies, such as TSMC.

"The appreciation has in fact had an impact on TSMC's operations, but it was within the range that I expected, " Chang said after his speech at the 8th Annual Global Views Business Forum held in Taipei.

The two-day forum, held annually since 2003 and this year focusing on integrating Chinese talent and resources, is being attended by business representatives from the United States, Singapore, China and Taiwan, organizer Global Views Monthly said.

The TSMC chairman acknowledged, however, that TSMC was structurally different from others in the electronics industry because of its capital intensive foundries, which help generate a 50 percent gross margin compared with 8 percent for other players.
The high gross margin, he said, was generated by the chip sector's high added- value derived from the development of technology and capital.

Chang suggested that small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) should tie their operations more closely together to cooperate on technological development and attract investment to create well-paid jobs.

Earlier on the same occasion, President Ma Ying-jeou pointed to the importance of SMEs in creating jobs. He said 76 percent of Taiwan's employment openings were from its SMEs, which account for 98 percent of the total number of companies in the country.
Taiwan's industrial structure, he added, needs to be adjusted to help narrow the gap between rich and poor in the country.
Asked if the leaders of Taiwan and China would meet face-to-face in 2011 or 2012, Ma said with a smile that he would "seriously consider the idea."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan unruffled by Chinese funding of investment in allied country

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Monday that Taiwan-Dominican Republic relations remain firm despite growing financial ties between Taiwan's Caribbean ally and China and hints of a possible interest in changing allegiance.

Bank of China and China's Foreign Trade Bank were reported on Oct. 15 to have agreed to extend US$462 million in financing for an exclusive tourism complex in Punta Perla in the eastern part of that country being developed by Spanish investors.

Dominican Republic Tourism Minister Francisco Javier Garcia was quoted as saying that the deal created a precedent that will open the doors for Chinese financing of Dominican Republic development projects, but Taiwan appeared to take the news in stride.

"There are many foreign investments in the Dominican Republic. Our embassy will closely monitor the situation. However, the Republic of China does not oppose trade relations between the private sectors of our allies and those in China," said MOFA spokesman James Chang.
Taiwan had already received a jolt earlier this month when Garcia intimated during a visit to Shanghai that his country was hoping for full relations with China "sooner than later."
"We aspire sooner than later, our relations with the People's Republic of China are complete relations and absolutas, " he was quoted as saying by online news service Dominican Today on Oct. 5.

Chang said the Taiwanese embassy in Santo Domingo immediately raised concerns with the Dominican Republic government regarding Garcia's comments, but stressed that Taiwan's longstanding friendship with the Dominican Republic remains unshaken.
"The Dominican Republic's foreign policies are directed by its president," Chang added.

In July, President Ma Ying-jeou received an official delegation led by Dominican Secretary of Defense Pedro Rafael Pena Antonio and expressed hope for further bilateral agricultural, educational, security and economic cooperation in the future.
Ma also commended the Caribbean ally for playing a vital role in assisting Haiti, another one of Taiwan's allies, in the post-quake efforts.
On Oct. 11, the MOFA thanked the Dominican Republic as one of 17 allied countries that backed Taiwan's bid to join the International Civil Aviation Organization as an observer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense Ministry to review French-built fighter jets
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 20:18:36 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: National Defense Minister Kao Hua-chu said Monday that he will ask for an overall review of the country's French-made Mirage fighter jets after a lawmaker pointed out that the flight hours of the fighters have been reduced due to concern about a possible engine problem.

Legislator Lin Yu-fang of the ruling Kuomintang told a legislative committee that during maintenance operations in May 2009, the engine rotors were found to have cracks, resulting in reduced flying hours.
In May this year, a Mirage fighter jet belonging to the French Air Force crashed in southwestern France, possibly due to the same engine fault.
For this reason, the total flying hours of Taiwan's Mirage jets were reduced to less than 5,000 this year from the original target of more than 10,000 hours.

"The flying hours of the Mirage pilots were also reduced from the standard 15 hours per month to 10 hours, even lower than the 12 hours per month logged by Chinese fighter jet pilots, " Lin said, adding that this has affected the nation's air defenses.
Taiwan purchased 60 Mirage-2000s fighter jets from France in 1992, the last batch of which was delivered in 2001. Fifty-six of the planes remain in service, with four having been lost in crashes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese guitarist clinches 4th top award in Europe this year
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 17 (CNA) 10/18/10 20:19:29 (By Lin Yu-li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A young guitarist from Taiwan beat seven other finalists to bag first prize in the International Guitar Competition and Festival Berlin Sunday.

It was 22-year-old Lin Chia-wei's fourth championship title won in Europe so far this year, following successes in Veria, Greece in April; in Nuertingen, Germany in July; and in Vienna, Austria earlier this month.

He played pieces by Astor Piazzolla and Mauro Giuliani in Sunday's final, which won him a hand-made guitar worth 2,500 euros and the coveted opportunity to serve as a judge in next year's contest and to give a recital.

Lin began learning guitar with his father at the tender age of 4 and has chalked up countless awards in Taiwan and in international competitions. He realized his childhood dream of going abroad to study last year when he was admitted to the Koblenz Conservatory beside the Rhine River and became a student of noted German guitar educator Hubert Kaeppel.
Asked why he enters so many competitions, Lin said he hopes to accumulate his performance experience and reach out to as many guitar lovers and artists as possible.

"I tend to get information from the Internet and if time permits, I travel by train by myself to take part in the contests. This way, I can test my guitar competence and cultivate my presence in the guitar world, in addition to earning prize money to help finance my tuition," he said.

Earlier this month, Lin won the top prize in a competition sponsored by the prestigious University of Music and Performing Arts in Vienna to secure the opportunities to perform in Vienna and in St. Petersburg in Russia.
For a young guitarist, Lin said, these could mark an important turning point in his career.
For him, Lin went on, Germany provides an ideal learning environment because it boasts a large cluster of top-notch guitar mentors and guitarists from around the world.
"I hope to gain admission to the Cologne Conservatory of Music next year to further hone my skills, and my career goal is to become a soloist with a quintessential presence in Europe," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HTC shares dive on Windows operating system glitch concerns
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 17 (CNA) 10/18/10 20:32:44 (By Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of smartphone maker HTC Corp. took a hit Monday amid concerns over glitches in the Windows Phone 7 (WP7) operating system on which five of the company's new models will run, dealers said.
HTC closed down 6.87 percent at NT$624.00, the lowest level since Sept. 3, with 12.94 million shares changing hands, while the benchmark weighted index fell 1.76 percent to 8,060.54.
"The glitches made investors here very cautious, as they are afraid that the technical problem will affect HTC's shipments in the fourth quarter," TLG Asset Management analyst Arch Shih said.

Last week, HTC unveiled the five new models based on the WP7 operating system -- the HTC 7 Surround, the HTC 7 Mozart, the HTC 7 Trophy, the HTC 7 Pro and the HTC HD7 -- which will hit markets in North America, Europe and the Asia-Pacific region from later in the month.
While HTC clarified during the trading session that it had noted the problem and was taking action to resolve it, selling extended until the end of the session.
"The market had expected that the company would post significant sales for the fourth quarter. But the technical problem dampened investor sentiment," Shih said.
Taiwan International Securities analyst Benson Huang agreed, saying that investors fear HTC will not meet a market expectation of 8.8 million units shipped for the fourth quarter.
Huang said the market is also worried about HTC's falling gross margin amid fierce price competition.
"The market anticipates that the new models will lend some support to its gross margin, " Huang said. "The possible impact on shipments from the technical problem has unnerved investors."

DOC.HEADLINE: Uniform-invoice prize money to be increased
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 20:41:21 (By Kao Chao-fen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The budget for uniform invoice prize money will be raised to the tune of NT$7.9 billion (US$255.83 million) next year, meaning that consumers will have the chance of winning bigger prizes from their receipts from 2011, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Monday.
The MOF is still pondering whether the additional budget should be used to increase the number of prizes or to boost the amount of individual prize money, said Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der.
The 2010 budget for uniform invoice prize money totaled NT$5.262 billion, according to the MOF.
Last year, holders of 13.75 million uniform invoice receipts won prizes, claiming a total of NT$4.663 billion from the MOF in prize money.
Of the total, 139 people won the grand prize of NT$2 million, according to the MOF.
In addition to its role as a print record of commercial transactions and a lottery ticket, the invoice has another role -- as an important source of income for local charity groups.
Uniform invoice donation boxes can be seen in shops and businesses around Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait education MOU could be signed by year's end: MOE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 20:54:39 (By Meng-kuei Ho and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is hoping to sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with China to pave the way for cross-Taiwan Strait dual-degree programs, Education Minister Wu Ching-ji said Monday at the Legislative Yuan.

In response to a question from Kuomintang legislator Yang Chiung-ying, Wu said a draft of the MOU had been submitted to the Executive Yuan for consultation with other agencies, such as the Mainland Affairs Council.
The ministry hoped to sign the MOU at the end of this year at the earliest to regulate double-degree and other exchange programs between education institutions of the two sides, added Wu.

Students in a cross-strait double-degree program would be able to study at two participating universities, one in Taiwan and the other in mainland China, to earn degrees from both in a shorter time than studying separately.

Taiwan's universities are keen on developing such dual-degree programs with their Chinese counterparts after the door opened to admit Chinese students, National Taiwan University President Lee Si-chen said Monday.
Due to differences in the educational systems of Taiwan and China, however, they have difficulties promoting dual-degree partnerships, Lee said.

The initiative was made possible by the passage in August of three amendments to the Law Governing Relations Between the People in the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, the University Law and the College Law.
The revisions allowed Chinese students to pursue master's and doctoral degrees in Taiwan from next March at the earliest.

DOC.HEADLINE: State-run oil company to decide on overseas plans by end of year

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run oil company will soon decide if it will set up an oil refinery in Indonesia or elsewhere, a company executive said Monday.
"We hope that we can make the decision by the end of this year, " CPC Corp. Taiwan Vice President Paul Chen said at a news conference.
Chen said many other countries were also trying to solicit investment from the oil company, but he declined to identify them.
His remarks came days after Indonesia's government invited Taiwan to establish an oil refinery on three of the Southeast Asian country's islands.

"We are still assessing various investment conditions in Indonesia, but we need to negotiate with the Indonesian government over, for example, tariff reductions," said Quentin Yao, one of the oil company's directors, on Oct. 12.
CPC Corp. Taiwan Chairman Chu Shao-hua has said the deal will be called off if the terms are not good.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu's ranking climbs to new career high
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 21:06:27 ( By Li Yu-cheng and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tennis player Lu Yen-hsun has achieved the highest ranking of his career after picking up valuable points in this past week's Shanghai Masters in China, according to the latest weekly rankings issued by the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) Monday.

After climbing to No. 39 in the world, edging past his previous best of 40th in mid-August, Lu expressed his excitement over his latest milestone on his official website and said he hopes to crack the world's top 20 or 30 in the future.

Lu was able to move up in the rankings after earning 45 ranking points this past week for reaching the second round of the 2010 Shanghai Masters. He defeated Chinese qualifier Wu Di in straight sets before falling to Italian Andreas Seppi in the second round.

Dirk Hordorff, Lu's coach and overseas agent, said cracking the top 40 is not easy for any Asian player, and he attributed the 27-year-old's success to his fighting spirit and his capacity for hard work.
Lu is entered this week in a second-tier ATP Challenger event in Seoul, where he will be the top seed.
His first round opponent is Korean Chung Hong, and if he takes care of the Korean as he is favored to do, he could face compatriot Yang Tsung-hua in the second round.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to hold low-carbon expo

TEXT.P: Taiwan will open an exhibition on Thursday to showcase new eco-friendly technologies and products and educate people on how to lead a low carbon emission lifestyle.
More than 200 companies, government agencies and institutions will take part in the ECO Taiwan Expo, which will be held for the first time Oct. 21-23.
The expo will feature a new-generation smart grid that can help monitor how much electricity is being used at home, said the Bureau of Energy, which co-organized the event, in a statement Monday.
The smart grid, if combined with the Internet and other systems, can help identify old home appliances that consume a significant amount of power and need to be replaced, the bureau said.
The bureau will also display a motor driver that can enhance the efficiency of the equipment used to power freezers, vehicles or air conditioners, helping save energy as a result.
The government has vowed to build 50 low-carbon communities by 2011 and six low- carbon cities by 2014 in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Volunteers to help reduce digital gap in Taipei County

TEXT.P: Taipei County formed a volunteer team Monday to help further narrow the digital gap among county residents after more than 100,000 people benefited from a similar program launched three years ago.

The team will promote digital learning in more towns and communities in the county, with more than 100 volunteers teaching residents basic skills, such as surfing the Internet and setting up blogs, according to a statement released by the county government.

The formation of the volunteer team will enable people to obtain practical skills, such as learning how to use the Internet and then marketing local specialties online, said Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei at a ceremony at Shihmen Elementary School to launch the team.
Chou also announced that as part of the initiative, used computers from government agencies will be given to disadvantaged families.

In addition, the county has set up 30 "Digital Outposts of Hope" in 29 towns to provide free computer classes and Internet access, according to Wang Chen- shiuen, chairman of the county's Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bulls coach faces penalty for failure to appear at press conference

TEXT.P: In a case unprecedented in the 20-year history of post-season baseball in Taiwan, the manager of the Sinon Bulls will be fined for not appearing at a post-game press conference, Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) said Monday.

Bulls manager Hsu Sheng-ming failed to meet with reporters Sunday after his team lost to the Brother Elephants 3-1 in Douliou, Yunlin County, to go two games down in the CPBL's best-of-seven Taiwan Series.
Hsu will be fined NT$10,000 (US$324.33) according to CPBL rules, the league announced.

In a telephone interview with the Central News Agency, Hsu said he was not sure whether the press conference would take place and was already on the team bus eating his dinner when league officials came to find him.
"We were halfway through our meal, " explained Hsu. "It didn't seem reasonable under the circumstances."
"I will explain (the situation) to the league, and it's up to them to determine if they can accept it."
The series resumes Tuesday night in Taoyuan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma has no plan to meet Chinese president at present: spokesman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 22:16:32 (By Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has no plan at this point to meet his Chinese counterpart, Hu Jintao, Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said Monday.

President Ma has reiterated on many occasions that the time is not yet ripe for the leaders of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to meet in person, Lo said, in response to a report that Ma said he would "seriously consider" a call to hold talks with Hu in 2011 or 2012.
"The president's stance on this issue remains unchanged, " Lo said.

The United Evening News reported Monday that C. V. Chen, president of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, said at the opening session of the 8th Annual Global Views Business Forum earlier in the day that he hopes the leaders of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can meet as soon as possible.
Responding to the appeal, "Ma said he was willing to give the idea serious consideration," the paper said.

Lo, however, clarified that Ma was responding to Chen's proposal that the issues of promoting competent and incorruptible governance as well as corporate integrity be included in the agenda for a next round of cross-strait talks on topics related to the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed in June.
"Ma's response was not directed at Chen's suggestion for a cross-strait leadership meeting," Lo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan may follow new CPR guidelines
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 23:18:59 (By Chen Li-ting and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan may adopt new guidelines for CPR that were introduced recently by the American Heart Association, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Monday.

Agreeing with the new guidelines of "first compressing the chest and then breathing into the victim's mouth, " Shih Chung-liang, director of the DOH's Bureau of Medical Affairs, said research conducted in the past showed that fast chest compressions were more useful for sudden cardiac arrest than mouth-to- mouth resuscitation.

At the same time, he said, many people, including both professional rescuers and bystanders, did not know how to give mouth-to-mouth resuscitation correctly or were hesitant about breathing into strangers' mouths, leading to delays in administering CPR.
Noting that CPR guidance has been revised in the West in recent years to put more emphasis on chest compressions, Shih suggested that Taiwanese rescuers follow the new guidelines.
He said his bureau will collect relevant information on the new CPR guidelines before referring them to the Emergency Medical Services under the National Fire Administration for discussion.
"Taiwan is expected to adopt the new CPR guidelines next year at the earliest," he forecast.

The new guidelines ditch the old ABC training -- airway-breathing- compressions -- that called for rescuers to give two breaths first, then alternate with 30 presses, said Michael Sayre, co-author of the guidelines issued by the American Heart Association Monday.
Sayre said the ABC approach took time and delayed chest presses, which keep the blood circulating.

Also recognizing the value of the new CPR method, Chen Wei-kung, director of Taichung-based China Medical University Hospital's Emergency Treatment Department, said the last breath victims take before sudden cardiac arrest leave some oxygen in their blood.
If their heart were massaged before help arrives, the oxygen in the blood could be pumped to the brain, helping lower the chances that the victims will suffer a brain death, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu's ranking climbs to new career high
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 21:06:27 ( By Li Yu-cheng and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tennis player Lu Yen-hsun has achieved the highest ranking of his career after picking up valuable points in this past week's Shanghai Masters in China, according to the latest weekly rankings issued by the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bulls coach faces penalty for failure to appear at press conference

TEXT.P: In a case unprecedented in the 20-year history of post-season baseball in Taiwan, the manager of the Sinon Bulls will be fined for not appearing at a post-game press conference, Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) said Monday.

Bulls manager Hsu Sheng-ming failed to meet with reporters Sunday after his team lost to the Brother Elephants 3-1 in Douliou, Yunlin County, to go two games down in the CPBL's best-of-seven Taiwan Series.
Hsu will be fined NT$10,000 (US$324.33) according to CPBL rules, the league announced.

In a telephone interview with the Central News Agency, Hsu said he was not sure whether the press conference would take place and was already on the team bus eating his dinner when league officials came to find him.
"We were halfway through our meal, " explained Hsu. "It didn't seem reasonable under the circumstances."
"I will explain (the situation) to the league, and it's up to them to determine if they can accept it."
The series resumes Tuesday night in Taoyuan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma has no plan to meet Chinese president at present: spokesman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 22:16:32 (By Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has no plan at this point to meet his Chinese counterpart, Hu Jintao, Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said Monday.

President Ma has reiterated on many occasions that the time is not yet ripe for the leaders of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to meet in person, Lo said, in response to a report that Ma said he would "seriously consider" a call to hold talks with Hu in 2011 or 2012.
"The president's stance on this issue remains unchanged, " Lo said.

The United Evening News reported Monday that C. V. Chen, president of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, said at the opening session of the 8th Annual Global Views Business Forum earlier in the day that he hopes the leaders of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can meet as soon as possible.
Responding to the appeal, "Ma said he was willing to give the idea serious consideration," the paper said.

Lo, however, clarified that Ma was responding to Chen's proposal that the issues of promoting competent and incorruptible governance as well as corporate integrity be included in the agenda for a next round of cross-strait talks on topics related to the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed in June.
"Ma's response was not directed at Chen's suggestion for a cross-strait leadership meeting," Lo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan may follow new CPR guidelines
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/10 23:18:59 (By Chen Li-ting and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan may adopt new guidelines for CPR that were introduced recently by the American Heart Association, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Monday.

Agreeing with the new guidelines of "first compressing the chest and then breathing into the victim's mouth, " Shih Chung-liang, director of the DOH's Bureau of Medical Affairs, said research conducted in the past showed that fast chest compressions were more useful for sudden cardiac arrest than mouth-to- mouth resuscitation.

At the same time, he said, many people, including both professional rescuers and bystanders, did not know how to give mouth-to-mouth resuscitation correctly or were hesitant about breathing into strangers' mouths, leading to delays in administering CPR.
Noting that CPR guidance has been revised in the West in recent years to put more emphasis on chest compressions, Shih suggested that Taiwanese rescuers follow the new guidelines.
He said his bureau will collect relevant information on the new CPR guidelines before referring them to the Emergency Medical Services under the National Fire Administration for discussion.
"Taiwan is expected to adopt the new CPR guidelines next year at the earliest," he forecast.

The new guidelines ditch the old ABC training -- airway-breathing- compressions -- that called for rescuers to give two breaths first, then alternate with 30 presses, said Michael Sayre, co-author of the guidelines issued by the American Heart Association Monday.
Sayre said the ABC approach took time and delayed chest presses, which keep the blood circulating.

Also recognizing the value of the new CPR method, Chen Wei-kung, director of Taichung-based China Medical University Hospital's Emergency Treatment Department, said the last breath victims take before sudden cardiac arrest leave some oxygen in their blood.
If their heart were massaged before help arrives, the oxygen in the blood could be pumped to the brain, helping lower the chances that the victims will suffer a brain death, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 19, 2010, or the 12th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1216: King John of England, known as John Lackland, dies at the age of 49. During his reign, the English lost most of their possessions in France. The nobility rose up against John and forced him to sign the Magna Carta, a cornerstone of English political and civil liberties.
1781: General Charles Cornwallis, British commander, unwittingly delivers his 8,000 troops into the hands of the besieging American forces at Yorktown in Virginia, allowing Gen. George Washington to win the War of Independence for the American colonists.
1812: Tsar Alexander's refusal to negotiate, along with renewed Russian military activity to the south of Moscow, leaves Napoleon Bonaparte with no alternative but to begin retreating from Moscow, which was captured by the French.
1872: The Holtermann Nugget, a slate weighing 235.14 kilograms, is found in New South Wales, Australia. It contains 82.11 kilograms of gold, the largest single mass of gold ever found.
1901: Alberto Santos Dumont, a Brazilian aviator, circumnavigates the Eiffel Tower in his airship to win the Deutsche Prize, the first aviation prize.
1925: Chiang Ching-kuo leaves Shanghai for Moscow to study at Sun Yat-sen University.
1935: The League of Nations imposes sanctions against Italy following its invasion of Ethiopia.
1936: Chou Shu-jen, a modern Chinese writer who used the pen name Lu Hsun and was admired most by the Chinese communists, dies of illness in Shanghai at the age of 56.
1937: Ernest Rutherford, New Zealand-born British physicist who won the 1908 Nobel Prize in chemistry, dies at the age of 66. He is regarded as the founder of modern atomic theory.
1940: The Burma road is reopened after the British had closed it for three months.
1947: The Taiwan Provincial Government opens Keelung and Kaohsiung as international seaports.
1950: The North Korean capital of Pyongyang falls during the Korean War.
1960: The U.S. State Department establishes an embargo on Cuban-bound shipments of all goods except medicine and foodstuffs.
1960: Mauritania proclaims independence from France.
1963: Sir Alec Douglas-Home succeeds Harold Macmillan as British prime minister.
1968: Republic of China athlete Chi Cheng wins a bronze medal in the women's 80-meter low hurdle event with a time of 10.4 seconds at the 19th Olympic Games held in Mexico City.
1973: Dr. Li Yuan-zu is appointed president of National Chengchi University.
1975: A total of 5,462 athletes begin seven days of competition at the Second Taiwan Area Games in Taipei.
1979: Lord Killanin, chairman of the International Olympic Committee, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1981: San Antonio Mayor Henry Cisneros declares that the historic city in Texas will establish sisterhood ties with the city of Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan.
1987: Wall Street experiences the worst day in its history, known as "Black Monday," with the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeting a record 508.32 points, knocking US$500 billion off share values. The decline is 22.6 percent, almost 10 percent greater than the stock market crash of 1929, which heralded the Great Depression.
1990: Mikhail Gorbachev, leader of the USSR, wins parliamentary approval for a plan to switch the centrally planned Soviet economy to a market economy.
1999: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew thanks overseas Chinese for their enthusiasm in providing assistance to Taiwan's earthquake victims.
2000: The ROC's opposition Kuomintang expels Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin- yi from the party, chiding him for "severely opposing KMT policies and impeding the interests of the people."
2001: Vice President Annette Lu receives 1998 Nobel laureate in medicine, Dr. Ferid Murad, at the Presidential Office.
2001: U.S. President George W. Bush tells reporters that in a meeting with his mainland Chinese counterpart, he reiterated Washington's stance on the Taiwan issue, namely "one China" and "a resolution of differences through peaceful means."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the Book of Songs it is said: `I keep in mind the fine moral qualities which make no great noise or show.'"
