DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Show resolve to curb housing prices

TEXT.P: Many people think the government lacks the determination to curb skyrocketing housing prices in northern Taiwan partly because it talks a lot but does very little.

The government probably thinks any problem can be solved as long as the economy recovers rapidly. But despite the high economic growth seen this year, the unemployment rate has not come down significantly, and workers' pay has not increased much, either.

Under these circumstances, the government has recently put forward plans that are aimed at helping low-income citizens buy or rent homes. But these plans have been criticized for their poor feasibility.
The idea to build affordable housing in places far away from Taipei City, for example, is believed to be very unfair to poor people.
The fundamental objective of the government's housing policy should be to prevent an unreasonable rise in housing prices and a potential housing bubble.

The government, for instance, should reject advertisements run deliberately by private developers to fuel consumer expectations of further spikes in housing prices. Only that and other actions will convince the people that it is determined to stabilize prices in the residential real estate market. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 19, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Strange talk

TEXT.P: At an annual conference for ethnic Chinese business leaders held in Taipei Monday, Chen Charng-ven, president of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, expressed hope that President Ma Ying-jeou could attend the 2011 or 2012 conference to be held in Beijing or Shanghai and meet his Chinese counterpart Hu Jintao.
Chen also said that if Ma is not able to meet Hu within the next two years, he hoped that Ma would continue to be president after 2012.
It is hard to believe that a lawyer would make such a comment, which runs counter to the common sense of democracy.

There are many people in Taiwan who adore Chinese officials, and they often like to compare who has met the more senior Chinese officials. Chinese leaders are well aware of the vanity of the Taiwanese and are using the issue as a tool to control and divide them.

Should Ma feel depressed for failing to meet China's top leader? Should Taiwanese voters allow him to win a second term just for this reason? What on earth is the logic behind this? (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 19, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Tourism boom spurs hotel investment fever

TEXT.P: A sharp rise in the number of tourist arrivals and the anticipated opening to Chinese tourists not traveling in tour groups has helped fuel a new investment craze in the local hotel and leisure sector.

Britain's Intercontinental Hotels Group and Singapore's Hong Leong Group have launched new investment projects to expand their presence in Taiwan and a number of other hotel operators are also following suit.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the trend:
Economic Daily News:
In a report delivered to the Executive Yuan Monday, the Tourism Bureau said Taiwan had 4.02 million overseas visitors in the first nine months of this year, a 27.01 percent rise year-on-year.
During the period, China overtook Japan to become the largest source of visitors to Taiwan, with a record 1.193 million Chinese arrivals, a 73.52 percent increase from the year-earlier level.

The bureau attributed the hefty jump to a combination of factors, including continued opening to China, expansion of direct cross-strait flight services and optimism generated by the signing of the bilateral economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) in June.
Japan fell to a distant second as a source of visitors, with Japanese nationals making 782,000 visits to Taiwan between January and September.
Arrivals from Malaysia posted the highest growth of any inbound tourist market during the period, growing 86 percent to reach 185,000, according to official statistics.
To cash in on the boom, Intercontinental Hotels announced Monday that it will realize its goal of opening at least 10 hotels around Taiwan by 2012.

The group, which has more than 4,500 hotels under its ownership or management around the world, currently operates four Holiday Inns in Taiwan -- Holiday Inn East Taipei, Holiday Inn Express Taoyuan, Holiday Inn Express Taichung Park and Crowne Plaza Kaohsiung E-DA World -- with a total of 1,214 hotel rooms.
It is now preparing to open at least four new Holiday Inns in Taipei and other Taiwanese cities and to acquire rights to manage several other hotels.

Meanwhile, Asia's largest hotel holding group Hong Leong, which already operates Grand Hyatt Taipei, said it will launch three new joint venture hotel projects in Taiwan in November, including a hotel in the famous Sun Moon Lake scenic area.

Howard Plaza Hotel, the Sherwood, Lih Pao Group, China Metals Property Group and E-United Group are also planning new investment projects that call for a combined capital injection of more than NT$110 billion (US$3.548 billion). (Oct. 19, 2010).
Commercial Times:

With the value of the Japanese yen surging to new historical highs, the Executive Yuan on Monday directed the Tourism Bureau to come up with new tour packages to draw Japanese tourists to Taiwan, mainly targeting elderly people, Muslims and surfing enthusiasts.

The tour packages should link major scenic destinations with special cultural, sporting or leisure activities to cater to the special tastes of various segments of the Japanese population. (Oct. 19, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Coface upgrades Taiwan's country rating
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 12:47:23 (By Kao Chao-fen and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Coface has raised Taiwan's country rating to A1 from A2 because of the country's strong economic rebound, the international credit insurance and credit management service group said Monday.

In a statement, Coface said Taiwan has benefited from its expansionary economic policies put in place after the global financial meltdown and the revival of growth in China and United States to post 13.71 percent and 12.53 percent growth rates in the first and second quarters, respectively.
Although the central bank began tightening its monetary policy in June, Coface said Taiwan's economy is still expected to grow 7.7 percent in 2010.
Taiwan's government has raised its GDP growth forecast for the country to 8.24 percent from the previous estimate of 6.14 percent.
According to Coface, its country rating, based on economic, financial and political data, aims to evaluate the average credit risk of companies in a given country.

The A1 rating indicates the political and economic situation and business environment quality are very good with a positive influence on corporate payment behavior, and as a result, average corporate default probability is very low.

Coface said progress has been made on financial cooperation across the Taiwan Strait, including the opening of the local bourse to Chinese investors and giving financial institutions easier access to each other's markets.

"This trend is expected to continue in 2010-2011 with the conclusion of the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) in June 2010," said Richard Burton, regional managing director, Coface's Greater China division.
Coface said Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves are likely to remain "very high" in 2010 to protect the island from a foreign currency liquidity crisis.
At the end of September, the island's foreign exchange reserves rose for the 23rd consecutive month to reach a record high of US$380.51 billion.
"Under this favorable economic condition, corporate payment behavior in Taiwan is expected to improve," Burton said.
Meanwhile, Coface has also raised Hong Kong's country rating to A1 from A2, while leaving the rating on China unchanged at A3.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan investigating reported China-Japan deal on disputed islands

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday it was not aware of a reported "secret deal" between China and Japan on the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, but confirmed that it was gathering information on the matter.

The ministry has instructed its office in Japan to follow-up on the report that Japan had an agreement with China on the islets as early as 2004, said Huang Ming-lung, secretary-general of the Association of East Asian Relations, which is in charge of Taiwan-Japan ties.

"We have not heard of the deal but we're now investigating and trying to gather information, " he said of the report, which appeared in the Japanese weekly magazine AERA, published by Asahi Shimbun newspaper.

The Tiaoyutai Islands, which lie about 100 nautical miles off Taiwan's northeastern tip in the East China Sea, are controlled by Japan and claimed by China and Taiwan. They are known as the Diaoyu Islands in China and Senkaku Islands in Japan.

According to the magazine report, Japan and China agreed in principle following a conflict in 2004 that China should keep activists from sailing out to the islands and that Japan would not detain those who land on the islets.
But if the agreement between Japan and China does exist as reported, it was still not able to prevent a recent skirmish in the area.

Japan arrested a Chinese fishing boat skipper after his trawler collided with two Japanese Coast Guard vessels on Sept. 7. The incident led to a diplomatic row between the two countries, and the United States also became involved.
Taiwan's Foreign Ministry took a long-term view of the Tiaoyutai dispute Tuesday.

"The Tiaoyutai issue is not an issue that can be solved immediately, but we believe that its impact on Taiwan-Japan relations will be limited. And I assure you that Taiwan will not cooperate with China on handling the issue, " Huang said in response to a reporter's question at a press briefing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Robots benefit industry, ageing society: VP

TEXT.P: Robots could be beneficial to both industry and an ageing society, Vice President Vincent Siew said Tuesday at the opening of a robot show in Taipei.

Sixty-six companies and research institutions mounted a total of 296 booths exhibiting entertainment, industrial and other robot applications at the Taipei International Robot Show (TIROS), which runs through Friday.
In his opening remarks, Siew said robots could bring about breakthroughs in life quality and industrial development.
"Robots can greatly assist industries upgrade themselves, improve efficiency and enhance competitiveness," he said.
"Robots can also be used in the service industry, such as in the medical-care sector, especially when the population is ageing, " Siew added.

He predicted that robots would likely help precision machinery become Taiwan's third largest industry after semiconductors and flat panels, with output valued at more than NT$1 trillion (US$32.5 billion) per annum.

That robot development is taking root in Taiwan was evidenced by the 30-percent rise in service robots presented at TIROS, said Eric Chuo, director-general of the Robotics Association Taiwan, which organized the fair.

DOC.HEADLINE: China-based high-tech firm to list Oct. 29
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 15:06:21 (By Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: TPK Holding Co. Ltd., a China-based touch panel technology application provider, is scheduled to list on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSWE) Oct. 29, the TSWE said Tuesday.

The stock exchange said TPK is expected to become the second foreign company to launch a primary listing on the local main board after U.S.-based integrated circuit designer Integrated Memory Logic made its debut in May.

According to the company's prospectus, TPK, founded in 2005 and capitalized at NT$1.96 billion (US$63.61 million) , intends to issue 28 million new shares, of which 4.2 million will be reserved for company employees and the remaining 23.8 million will be sold to the public.

Underwriter Yuanta Securities said the indicative range of the listing price is set at NT$200 to NT$220 and the share sale is expected to raise up to NT$6.16 billion for the company, which was set up by Taiwanese in China.

TPK said in the prospectus that it will use the proceeds of the listing as working capital to fund research and development, purchases of raw materials for production and day-to-day operations at its base located in Xiamen, Fujian Province.
The company said the funds are also expected to help it expand, as the global touch panel market is growing.
TPK's touch panel technology application is largely used in consumer electronics products, such as smartphones, handheld devices, and tablet PCs.
In 2009, TPK posted net earnings of NT$2.32 billion, compared with NT$388 million recorded the year earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 0.17 percent in thin trade

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 0.17 percent in thin trading Tuesday as profit taking continued to drag down old economy stocks despite a rally on Wall Street overnight, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 14.31 points to 8,046.23, after moving between 8,018.31 and 8,074.68, on turnover of NT$87.74 billion (US$2.84 billion).

The market opened down 0.19 percent and remained weak throughout the session as investors ignored Wall Street's rise and continued to pocket the strong gains recently posted by non-high-tech firms, dealers said.
A total of 2,294 stocks closed down and 1,274 finished down, with 369 stocks remaining unchanged.

The paper and pulp sector saw the biggest drop, falling 1.42 percent. Textile shares fell 1.12 percent, foodstuff shed 1.02 percent, cement stocks dropped 0.95 percent, and plastics and chemical shares closed down 0.43 percent.
The financial sector fell 0.13 percent, while construction stocks gained 0.62 percent, and machinery and electronics shares rose 0.08 percent.
"After Monday's steep fall, market sentiment has turned very cautious, " MasterLink Securities analyst Tom Tang said. "Investors, therefore, tended to leave a higher Wall Street behind."
The reduced turnover was evidence that many investors have been pushed to the sidelines by the gloomy mood.
On Monday, the local bourse fell 1.76 percent amid heavy selling in large cap stocks and semiconductor firms.
Tang said selling focused on the old economy sector Tuesday, while the high-tech sector failed to stage a meaningful rebound to boost the broader market.
"The market has become technically weaker after Monday's hit. Further selling is very likely and a fall below the key 8,000 point level is just a matter of time," Tang said.
Among old economy stocks, Taiwan Pulp and Paper fell 3.05 percent to NT$17.50 and textile maker Far Eastern New Century lost 1.56 percent to NT$44.10.
In the high-tech sector, smartphone maker HTC gained 2.40 percent to NT$639.00, while Hon Hai Precision, the world's largest contract electronics firm, fell 0.88 percent to NT$112.00.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese charity group helps Mongolian children combat poverty
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 15:53:41 (By Lee Hsi-chang and Elizbeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Since the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) opened its first overseas branch in Mongolia in 2004, positive results have been achieved in helping poverty-stricken children and families there escape their plight.

In a recent review of its activities in the central Asian country, the TFCF said it had provided aid to over 6,000 poor children and helped more than 1,000 Mongolian children from impoverished families become self-reliant.

As might be expected, the charity organization's operation in Mongolia differs markedly from its set-up in Taiwan and goes beyond simply providing financial assistance to needy children, said Hsieh Yi-ju, the TFCF worker responsible for the aid-to-Mongolia program, on Tuesday.

The organization there has worked with the local government to build traditional shelters, or "yurts, " a water supply station, a kindergarten, and a shelter "village" for homeless single-parent families.
In the village, "we have not just provided financial aid but also offered counseling services and vocational training," Hsieh said.

At its peak, the village sheltered 20 households, but under TFCF's guidance, five of the families have been able to move out after gaining the skills needed to maintain their own home and support themselves, Hsieh said.

One of them, led by a single mother named Chi Chi Ke, moved into the TFCF shelter village in 2007. But thanks to the skills she learned in the village, she was able to secure a job and build a yurt for her family in Ulan Bator, and moved out of the village this year.
Hsieh said Chi Chi Ke told the charity organization that "TFCF helped her discover self-confidence and see the future."
The TFCF operates 23 branches, 29 service offices, three shelters for the physically and mentally challenged, and eight shelters for children and teenagers around Taiwan.
Since it opened its first family-style orphanage in Taiwan in 1950, it has helped more than 230,000 poor children at home and abroad with different sponsorship programs, according to the TFCF.

DOC.HEADLINE: Autistic riders enter fourth day of round-island cycling trip
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 16:09:31 (By Huang Kuo-fang and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: A group of autistic cyclists continued a round-Taiwan journey from Chiayi City Tuesday, three days after they left Taipei on a road trip organized by the Autism Society of Taiwan.
The event, the third of its kind, kicked off Oct. 16, with six autistic cyclists setting off on the journey with their families and volunteers.
The only girl rider in the group, Hsu Yu-mei, has enjoyed riding a bicycle since childhood, said her father, who accompanied his 15-year-old daughter on the ride.
"She might get hurt. However, seeing that she was so looking forward to the journey, I decided to fulfill this dream with her, " said Hsu in an interview with CNA.
The team of 20 riders stayed in the southern city for the night before heading further south to Tainan on the fourth leg of their 11-day trip.

They will ride all the way down to the southernmost county of Pingtung before heading across the island to the east coast and traveling north. They expect to return to the capital city Oct. 26, completing an expedition of some 1,200 kilometers, according to the society.

DOC.HEADLINE: Currency appreciation has no major impact on Acer

TEXT.P: Appreciation of the New Taiwan Dollar had only minor impact on Acer Inc., the world's No. 2 PC vendor said Tuesday, because the company had taken precautions to avoid the risk.

"The impact can be sometimes negative and sometimes positive depending on the portfolio management of our assets," Acer Chairman J.T. Wang said after attending an international forum in Taipei. "We make daily efforts to avoid this risk, such as by buying foreign currencies, he added.
He declined to comment, however, when asked about the forecast for notebook sales in the fourth quarter, preferring to wait until Acer's shareholder meeting on Oct. 29.
The Taiwan dollar has gained more than 4 percent against the U.S. dollar since the beginning of September.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Tuesday, gaining NT$0.015 to close at NT$30.900.
Turnover totaled US$976 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.885 and moved to a low of NT$30.680 before rebounding.
Dealers said the continued weakness in other Asian currencies, including the Chinese yuan, imposed further selling pressure on the New Taiwan dollar.
The selling came largely from foreign banks and exporters to lock up recent strong gains posted by the local unit against the U.S. dollar, they said.

There were signs that foreign investors moved funds out of Taiwan during the session to keep the New Taiwan dollar weaker after they lowered their holdings in the local stock exchange, the dealers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Singapore court orders middleman to return US$29.8 million to Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Supreme Court of Singapore offered up a ruling Tuesday in which it ordered Ching Chi-ju to return US$29.8 million that he embezzled from Taiwan during an abortive attempt to help the island forge diplomatic links with Papua New Guinea in 2006. Ching was the middleman in the deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Command center to fight dengue fever in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: A central epidemic command center (CECC) will be set up within the next two days in light of the worsening dengue fever situation in southern parts of the country, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Tuesday.

The statement came after 132 new indigenous cases of dengue fever were reported last week, setting a new single-week record for the past four years, with most cases concentrated in the Tainan and Kaohsiung area of southern Taiwan, CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi said in a weekly report.

With 615 reported indigenous cases of dengue infection from Aug. 1 to Oct. 16, Shih said, the Executive Yuan has agreed to establish one command center in Taipei and another in the south to assist local governments with disease control procedures.
"We hope to keep the disease under control before the seasonal drop in temperature," Shih said, adding that if the virus progresses into early next year, it will be more difficult to combat.

Shih added that according to CDC statistics, two cases of the more serious dengue hemorrhagic fever have been reported so far. Both patients are senior citizens living in Kaohsiung City, the municipality that has reported the most cases of dengue this year.
One, a 79 year-old man, had already been discharged from hospital after receiving treatment, while the other, a 65-year-old woman, was still in hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier confident China's next leader will stick to peace policy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 19:00:06 (By Ho Meng-kuei, Kelven Huang, Justin Su and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih expressed confidence Tuesday that China's next leader would continue to pursue the peaceful and stable development of relations with Taiwan, which he called a "direction that should not be reversed."

"We believe and expect the future leader of China will continue to deal with Taiwan based on the principles of sincerity, equality and dignity and follow the path of cross-Taiwan Strait peace and stability, " Wu said during an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan, when he was asked to comment on the designation of Xi Jinping as China's fifth-generation leader.
Xi, currently China's vice president, was named vice chairman of the Central Military Commission on Monday during the fifth plenum of the 17th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China.
The position, which overseas the People's Liberation Army, is considered a stepping stone to China's top leadership post.
Wu said he did not know Xi, but he hoped the next leader of China would follow in the footsteps of incumbent Hu Jintao and promote policies that are in the interests of Taiwan and its people.

Asked about the possibility of a meeting between President Ma Ying-jeou and Hu or one between himself and his Chinese counterpart Wen Jiabao, Wu said meetings between leaders across the Taiwan Strait should take place at a proper time and occasion.
According to Wu, a stronger consensus on the issue needs to be built within Taiwan and a higher level of goodwill developed between the two sides before such meetings could be held.
Wu said, however, that he welcomed any contacts between the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and China as long as such contacts are beneficial to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to promote `360 Project' among South-Pacific allies
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 19:06:29 (By Lee Shu-hua and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed his wish Tuesday that the government's "360 Project, " which was implemented this year to help Taiwan's diplomatic ally Nauru improve its agricultural productivity, will be extended to other South Pacific allies.
Ma mentioned the project -- part of his administration's overseas relief efforts -- at a meeting with visiting Nauruan Minister of Foreign Affairs Kieren Keke at the Presidential Office.

The project is named after its planned goals -- helping the Oceanian island- state increase its annual output of six agricultural products in a three-year period to the degree that it will no longer need to import them to meet local demand.

The number three refers to the three-year period. The six refers to six kinds of crops, including leafy vegetables, pumpkins, tomatoes, cucumbers, watermelons and eggs. The zero refers to zero imports.
Ma told Keke that he is paying attention to the project and inspected its progress during a visit he made to Nauru in late March.
Ma also described the project as a "meaningful plan that can bear fruit in a short time."

Keke arrived in Taiwan Oct. 17 for a five-day visit. The goal of his visit, his fourth to Taiwan, is to sign a bilateral agreement on visa exemptions for holders of diplomatic and official/service passports.
Ma said such an agreement will play a significant role in the promotion of Taiwan-Nauru relations.
Nauru is one of six countries in the South Pacific that maintain diplomatic links with Taiwan, along with Palau, Tuvalu, Marshall Islands, Solomon Islands and Kiribati.

DOC.HEADLINE: Quality of future leaders key to Taiwan-China relations: scholars

TEXT.P: The abilities and experience of the next generation of political leaders on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait would be key to future relations, a scholar said Tuesday in Taipei following indications of Vice President Xi Jinping as likely successor to China's incumbent President Hu Jintao.

Xi was appointed Monday as vice chairman of the Central Military Commission at the fifth plenary session of the 17th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China. He and other members of the party's "fifth generation" had been cultivated for decades as potential leaders, said Alexander Huang, a professor at Tamkang University's Graduate Institute of International Affairs and Strategic Studies.

Huang's comments came during a discussion that followed a live webcast that featured the United States Ambassador to China Jon Huntsman and was hosted by the U.S.-based National Committee on U.S.-China Relations. Local scholars, journalists and business leaders were invited to the Taipei discussion by the local American Chamber of Commerce, which organized the event.

Huang predicted this new generation would be tough in its negotiations with Taiwan and the U.S., because they grew up in the era of Red Guards and the Cultural Revolution, and had experienced posts at different levels of government before taking on greater responsibility.

This was a different picture from that in Taiwan, which was characterized by a shorter career span for government officials, especially at Cabinet level, Huang said. He predicted that Taiwan's next president would probably be one of the five special municipality mayors who would be elected in November.
Huang said he was not against a democratic system, but worried that Taiwan's future leaders could lack the time and experience needed to train them to a higher level.

Speaking at the same occasion, Bruce J.D. Linghu, director-general of the Department of North American Affairs at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said he was optimistic about the quality of Taiwan's leaders.

"The current leaders are highly-educated and full of democratic ideas. I believe they will have no problems dealing with their rivals across the strait. But for the next generation of leaders, I'm not quite sure, " Linghu said.

In the 45-minute webcast, Huntsman talked about various issues including the strategic mistrust and potential currency war between the U.S. and China, as well as U.S. concern for Nobel Peace Prize winner Liu Xiaobo's well-being.

DOC.HEADLINE: Singapore firm to list TDRs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 19:27:53 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Officials of BH Global Marine Ltd, a Singapore-based marine electrical product provider, said Tuesday that the company was scheduled to list its Taiwan depositary receipts (TDRs) on the Taiwan Stock Exchange the following day.
In an investor conference held in Taipei, the company said the listing price has been set at NT$17 (US$0.55).

For the listing, BH Marine said, it has issued 30 million TDRs to raise NT$510 million and the sale has received a warm welcome from Taiwanese investors with the security more than four times oversubscribed.
One TDR represents two of BH Marine's common shares, the company said.

BH Marine will be the fourth Singapore-listed company to list TDRs on the local bourse so far this year after Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (Holdings) Ltd., instant coffee maker Super Group Ltd. and textile firm China Taisan Technology Group Holdings Ltd.

The company, which provides marine electrical equipment and marine consumables to the shipbuilding, ship repair, petrochemical, and offshore oil and gas industries, has been listed on the Singapore Exchange since 2005, with market capitalization worth about US$100 million.
Company CEO Vincent Lim said the proceeds of the TDR sale will be used to invest in a galvanized steel firm in Oman, while some funds will be also set aside for bank loan repayments.
The investment in Oman will total US$10 million, Lim said.
The Middle East galvanized steel firm, which will churn out materials to produce covers for marine cables, is expected to start operations at the end of next year, he added.
Lim said he has high hopes that the TDR listing will enhance the value of the company's shares, as the Taiwan stock market enjoys higher valuation than its counterpart in Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Steel to take 5 percent stake in Korean firm
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 19:33:43 (By Lawrence Chiu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: China Steel Corp., Taiwan's largest steel maker, said Tuesday that it plans to acquire a 5 percent stake in Dongbu Metal Co. Ltd. of South Korea for 47.80 billion Korean won (NT$1.33 billion).
The board of directors has approved the investment project and both sides will enter into talks to iron out further details of the acquisition, China Steel said.
"China Steel aims to stabilize the supply of ferroalloy, one of the important ingredients in steel production, through the investment, " China Steel Vice Chairman L.M. Chung told CNA.
Ferroalloy is the main product of Dongbu Metal, and the Korean company has supplied the material to China Steel for about two decades, according to Chung.
"The investment is a kind of strategic alliance for both companies," Chung said.
Dongbu Metal, part of the Dongbu Group conglomerate, which includes metal production, agriculture, electronics, construction and trade, is the largest ferroalloy maker in South Korea.
Chung said it is the first time China Steel has acquired a stake in the South Korean metal sector.

Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said the acquisition shows that China Steel has engaged in vertical business integration by stepping into the upstream sector, in particular in value-added materials such as ferroalloy.
"The investment also indicates that China Steel remains optimistic about the outlook for the global steel business, " Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should put emphasis on service industry: vice premier

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Sean C. Chen said Tuesday that Taiwan should put more emphasis on developing the service industry to benefit more people.
Chen said the country's past economic development can be attributed to the labor-intensive industries, to which many people contributed labor and in return shared the benefits.

Taiwan has recorded shining economic growth recently, mainly from its highly developed technology- and capital-intensive industries, which benefit mostly those who provide either capital or technology, rather than people who can offer only labor.
Taiwan chalked up second-quarter gross domestic product (GDP) growth of 12.53 percent, and its 2010 GDP growth is forecast by the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research at 8.15 percent.

However, the gap between rich and poor has been widening, and according to figures released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics Aug. 20, the average income of the richest 20 percent of the population was 8.22 times that of the lowest income group in 2009, representing a record high.

"A cure for the problem is for the country to adjust its economic structure, with the service industry -- which can create many jobs -- being the priority, " Chen said in a speech delivered at the 8th Annual Global Views Business Forum held in Taipei.
He put forward the idea of "SMILE" -- service, market, innovalue, life and economy -- as the focus of Taiwan's future economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taxi drivers furious after government decides to withdraw subsidies
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 19:53:52 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Representatives of taxi associations and taxi drivers' unions around Taiwan accused the government Tuesday of breaking promises after the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) announced that it will withdraw subsidies for hybrid vehicles next year.

They said the government launched the subsidy program in 2008 when former President Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party was in power, to encourage people to purchase or remodel their vehicles into "gasoline-liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) hybrids" to save energy and cut carbon emissions.

At that time, the government also promised to build 150 gas stations supplying the much-cheaper liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) fuel around the country within five years as an incentive to attract drivers to run hybrids.
It also set a goal of raising the number of hybrid vehicles to 150,000 units in a five-year period, they said.
"However, there are now only 41 LPG refueling stations, not even close to 30 percent" of the stated goal, said Chen Teng, chairman of the National Federation of Taxi Associations.
"Most taxi drivers are so poor, they will not be able to survive any longer. The decision to withdraw the subsidies will force them to commit suicide, " Chen said.
The government subsidy gives taxi drivers NT$2 per liter of LPG fuel.
According to federation statistics, there are currently 89,708 yellow cabs in Taiwan, 22,000 of which are hybrids.
Ting Ping-ho, an executive of the Taipei City Taxi Drivers' Association, complained of a high vacancy rate of cabs in the capital. "Taxi drivers are suffering from low incomes," he lamented.
According to the state-run CPC Corp., Taiwan, the largest gasoline and fuel supplier in the country, the LGP price currently stands at NT$19.7 per liter, considerably less than the cost of gasoline.

The NT$2 subsidy helps the drivers, said Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the ruling Kuomintang, who accompanied the protesters during a coordination meeting with EPA officials held at the Legislative Yuan earlier in the day.

"Although it was the policy of the previous government, the current government is obliged to maintain it," Ting said, noting that neighboring countries like Japan and South Korea have promoted hybrid vehicles for many years.

In the coordination meeting, EPA Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen promised to study the problem with the Ministry of Economic Affairs, which is the authority responsible for matters concerning the construction of LPG stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acer chairman to meet Intel CEO

TEXT.P: Acer Inc. Chairman J.T. Wang said Tuesday he would discuss business with Intel Corp. chief executive Paul Otellini on Oct. 28 during the latter's visit to Taiwan.

"We have cooperated many times with Intel. As a very important client to Intel, we will discuss business affairs during his one or two-day stay," Wang told reporters after speaking at an international forum in Taipei.

Wang noted that he will meet Otellini on behalf of Acer, the world's second largest PC vendor, and not of the Taipei Computer Association, a promoter for WiMAX in Taiwan, for which he also serves as chairman.

Asked if Intel was reducing its support for WiMAX -- an advanced wireless broadband technology -- Wang said he had recommended Intel increase its cooperation with Taiwanese companies, since strong consumer demand for wireless broadband meant the technology had favorable prospects.

Otellini's visit is highly anticipated in Taiwan following Intel's closure of its WiMAX Program Office in June sparked speculation, including Wang's serious concern, that it was withdrawing support for the broadband wireless technology in which Taiwan has made significant investments.
Otellini will visit Taiwan as part of his Asian trip to business partners, the Taiwan branch of the world's largest chipmaker announced Oct. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA English news budget for Oct. 19 (II)

TEXT.P: Taiwan 23.Taiwan should put emphasis on service industry: vice premier 24.Taipei County launches green development center 25.Taiwan to show advanced piano robot in Tokyo 26.Third terminal planned for Taoyuan International Airport: CAA 27.Taxi drivers furious after government decides to withdraw

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Panama-flagged ships sink off Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 20:35:49 (By Shen-hsu Lin, Kuo-fang Huang, Sophia Chen and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Two Panama-registered cargo ships sank off Taiwan's west coast, leaving one crewman dead and three missing late Monday and early Tuesday as super typhoon Megi churned up huge waves in the Taiwan Strait, the Coast Guard reported.
Xin Yi, a cement carrier scheduled to sail from China to Brunei, broke down off Hsinchu at around 10:30 p.m. Monday.

As of Tuesday morning, 18 of the vessel's 22 crewmen had been rescued by Legend of the Seas -- a cruise ship near the scene -- the Coast Guard, Air Force and National Airborne Service Corps. A body was retrieved by one of the ships, the Coast Guard said, and three people were still missing.
The crew included 17 Burmese, four Indonesians and one Taiwanese. The Taichung Harbor Bureau said the victim was Burmese.

In the early hours of Tuesday morning, less than three hours after the first accident, another Panama-flagged freighter, Dili Star, sunk off Kaohsiung County, according to the Air Force's Chiayi Base and the Southern Coastal Patrol Office.
The 12 crewmen abandoned the sinking ship by lifeboat and were rescued by helicopter. None was seriously injured, said the Air Force.
Typhoon Megi, which made landfall in the Philippines Monday, brought heavy rain and strong winds to Taiwan as its outer band crossed part of the island, the Central Weather Bureau reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: Third terminal planned for Taoyuan International Airport: CAA

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Tuesday that it is planning to spend NT$60 billion (US$1.9 billion) building a third terminal at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in response to the increasing amount of Asia- Pacific air travel.

"The global share of the air-travel market in the Asia-Pacific region will climb from the current 32 percent to 41 percent in 2028, which explains our vision quite clearly, " said Yin Chen-pong, director-general of the CAA.
The new terminal, which will have a total floor area of 421,000 square meters, is likely to start operating in 2018, according to the CAA.
It is expected to transport 43 million travelers a year, which is around three times the amount that can be handled at Terminal 1 and about twice the capacity of Terminal 2.

The CAA also hopes that the airport, with a bigger and more modern terminal, will help realize the urban development plan of Taoyuan Aerotropolis, a global trading and logistics project that is expected to attract NT$1.2 trillion in business investment.
The government is expected to invest a total of NT$2.4 trillion in the aerotropolis by 2020.
The project is projected to have an annual production value of NT$600 billion and to create over 80,000 jobs, according to the Taoyuan county government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Singapore court orders middlemen to return US$29.8 million to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 21:28:12 (By Tang Pei-chun & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Supreme Court of Singapore ruled Tuesday in favor of a request from Taiwan to retrieve a total of US$29.8 million embezzled by two middlemen and kept in a Singapore bank account following a 2006 scam.
In the fraud case, the Taiwanese authorities were persuaded by the two men to part with the cash in return for supposed diplomatic relations with Papua New Guinea (PNG).

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) under the administration of former President Chen Shui-bian wired the money to an account at Singapore's OCBC Bank jointly held by the two brokers, Ching Chi-ju, a Taiwanese with an American passport, and Wu Shih-Tsai, a Singaporean, as funds in return for forging diplomatic relations between Taiwan and PNG.

The MOFA asked Wu and Ching for a statement of account in early 2008 after finding that as of Dec. 1, 2006, the money in the joint account had disappeared without any progress having been made on the initiative with PNG.
Wu, without knowing that the MOFA was already aware of the fraud, produced a false bank statement from his own notebook computer and gave it to the ministry.
He was arrested by the Taiwanese authorities when the scandal came to light at the end of President Chen Shui-bian's second term in 2008, but Ching managed to flee to the United States.
Wu was sentenced to 28 months in jail by a Taiwanese court late that year for making a false bank statement, and is now serving his time in a Taipei prison.
The Foreign Ministry filed a civil suit with the Singapore Supreme Court via Taiwan's representative office in 2008 against Wu and Ching, demanding repayment of the sum in full.
In a previous ruling handed down in May, the court said Taiwan is entitled to recover all the funds illegally kept by the two brokers, but it allowed the defendants to appeal.

Chen Shou-han, a division chief with the MOFA's Department of Treaty and Legal Affairs who represented the ministry at the court session, praised the ruling as "belated justice" and said his ministry will do its best to make sure all the stolen funds are returned to the national coffers.
So far, about US$6 million of the total has been retrieved, including properties bought by Wu in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Maestro piano robot makes global debut

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese robot capable of playing the piano with both hands made its global debut at the Taipei International Robot Show (TIROS) on Tuesday, marking another milestone in the development of Taiwan's precision machine industry.
"Up to now, other types of robots have used only one finger to play the piano," Enid Tsai, spokeswoman for Hiwin Technologies Corp., told CNA.
"Our robot uses 10 fingers and can play a complex melody, " she said, noting that it was the first in the world to do so.

Using key components manufactured by Hiwin including linear motors, linear guideways and ball screws, the robot will appear next at the Japan International Machine Tool Fair Oct. 28- Nov. 2, before returning home for a starring performance at the Taiwan International Machine Tool Show in Taichung on Nov. 3.
Since 2008, Hiwin has also encouraged local universities to design robots for different applications.
For example, as Taiwan faces the problems of an aging society, the company wants to see robots take care of old people or patients, Tsai said.
The 10-finger robot is among many entertainment, industrial and other robot applications displayed by 66 exhibitors in a total of 296 booths exhibiting at the (TIROS), which runs through Friday.
Vice President Vincent Siew attended the opening and had a brief interaction with V Baby, a robot spokesman for the Taipei International Flora Expo, which begins next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County opens green industry development center
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 22:19:41 (By Wang Hong-kuo and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taipei County government will help businesses adopt clean production technology in a bid to build the county into a green and eco-friendly one, Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei said Tuesday.
Chou made the remarks as he presided over the opening ceremony for a green energy industry development center in the county, the first of its kind in Taiwan.

Chou said Taiwan's industrial development will be hampered if it does not adopt clean production methods, adding that his county has taken the lead in setting up the center with the aim of providing the industry with related resources and technology.

Li bin, director-general of the county's Economic Development Bureau, also said that green energy is the future trend, adding that the center will assist businesses with clean production and installing energy-saving equipment.

If clean production technology and processes are adopted in the county, carbon emissions will be reduced by around 17,029 metric tons per year, while the energy saved will be equivalent to planting one tree for every one of the county's citizens, he estimated.

DOC.HEADLINE: No timetable for cross-strait political dialogue: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that no timetable has been set for cross- Taiwan Strait political talks, rebutting a foreign media report that said he plans to launch a formal political dialogue with China if he wins re-election in 2012.

He made the remarks in an emergency press conference to clear up what Ma said were erroneous points made by the Associated Press in an article on an interview with him that took place earlier in the day.
The AP report stated that during the interview, Ma "suggested" that "political talks could start as early as a second four-year term if he wins re-election in 2012."
"I never made any connection between my second term and political issues," Ma said.
Ma said that all he told the reporter was that all current cross-strait talks are based on the mutual understanding of "first the economy, then politics."
"At the moment, the talks on economic issues have just begun. Therefore, we will not discuss any political issues with China before the negotiations on economic issues have been completed," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: More rain expected as Megi turns north

TEXT.P: Typhoon Megi has turned north earlier than expected, which is likely to prolong the heavy rain throughout Taiwan because of the combined effects of the storm's outer rim and seasonal winds from the northeast, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Tuesday.

Megi was located 640 km south-southwest of Eluanbi, Taiwan's southernmost point, as of 2 p.m. and was expected to pose further threats of heavy rain in the next few days as it moves closer to Taiwan, the bureau said.
The CWB said that as Megi moves north, its speed is likely to decrease while its strength increases.
According to the bureau's forecast, the rain could continue throughout the weekend.

In related news, meanwhile, Yilan County and Taipei County, with accumulated precipitation topping the island for the past 24 hours, had already set up local emergency centers, the National Fire Agency said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elephants one win away from seventh Taiwan pro baseball title

TEXT.P: The Brother Elephants shut out the Sinon Bulls 3-0 Tuesday in game three of the 2010 Taiwan Series of the Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) in the northern city of Taoyuan to move within one win away from its seventh title and a new record.

The Elephants, which lost its manager and almost half of its players to a major game-fixing scandal that came to light in October last year, could wrap up the best-of-seven series as early as Wednesday night, when game four is played in Sinjhuang City, Taipei County.

A title win would be a special one for first-year manager Chen Jui-chen and his team, which consists mainly of young and inexperienced players brought on board after the scandal last year. At one point, owner Hung Jui-ho said that he was considering whether to disband the team.
Starting pitcher Orlando Roman shut out the Bulls in nine strong innings with seven strikeouts and allowed only three hits.

Yeh Chun-chang, who played for Sinon for 10 years before being released in 2009, had an RBI (runner batted in) single in the bottom of the third inning as Chang Chih-hao, who had a double in the previous at-bat, scored.
The Elephants added three hits, including Huang Shih-hao's triple to the centerfield in the bottom of the eighth.

Arguably the most storied franchise in the four-team CPBL, the Elephants is making its third straight run at the title after losing in 2008 and 2009, both times to the Uni-President Lions. It has won the title six times, a record among the CPBL teams, with the last one coming in 2003.
The Bulls' starting pitcher Lin Ying-chieh suffered his fourth straight loss in the Taiwan Series. The Bulls won the series in 2004 and 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rice wine issue is matter of Taiwan's credibility: ECCT

TEXT.P: Taiwan must follow the international standards that it has previously agreed to, such as those it agreed to in the case of rice wine, if it wants to become a bigger international player, the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) said Thursday upon the release of its annual position paper.

The European Union and the U.S. objected strongly in August to the Legislative Yuan's approval to reclassify rice wine from a distilled spirit to a common cooking ingredient, describing the move as a direct violation of World Trade Organization (WTO) standards.

The move will greatly reduce the tax on a 0.6 liter bottle from NT$29.25 (US$0.96) to N$5.4 and according to the ECCT, the legislature's decision undermines the positive perception of Taiwan internationally and reduces the European business community's desire for increased trade and economic links with Taiwan.

ECCT committee members said the matter goes beyond merely the price of rice wine and that its backtracking on WTO obligations rather shows Taiwan's credibility and accountability as a global trading partner.

"If we want to be an international player... there are certain rules and regulations that are created and we have to follow those, regardless of whether you are from the U.S., Japan, or Taiwan, " said ECCT Chairman Peter Weiss.

The group also made other suggestions in the 211-page paper, such as forging a Trade Enhancement Measure (TEM) with the European Union, improving the country's English environment, normalizing trade relations with China, strengthening trademark protection and discouraging a Luxury Tax, which the ECCT believes will adversely affect the foreign car market in Taiwan.

In the meantime, the ECCT suggested that both sides could explore interim measures based on mutual interests, such as more effective implementation of government procurement agreements, investment flows and standards.
Taiwan should also show more goodwill by removing Taiwan-only standards and adopting best international trading practices, it added.

The group's Pharmaceutical Committee said that as Taiwan is mulling a revamp of its national health coverage system, it should also stop its policy of lowering foreign-made drug prices before international pharmaceutical companies decide to pull out of the country altogether.

The group also raised concerns over Taiwan's Intellectual Property Court, questioning its fairness. Many trademarks of international brand names are still commonly used by local businesses such as hotels, KTVs and even betel nut stands, the committee said.

On Taiwan-China trade relations, the ECCT, while applauding the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed this June, continued to urge Taiwan to fully normalize trade relations with China by lifting its import ban on over 2,000 Chinese manufactured products.
The ban, said the group, has "diminished the willingness of multinational corporations to maintain or increase their investments in Taiwan."

In response, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairwoman Christina Liu thanked the ECCT for the suggestions and said the central government will encourage various agencies to speed up the adoption of international standards.

Moreover, the country is stepping up efforts to bolster trade links with the international community, including re-examining the option of opening its doors wider to more Chinese goods, under the condition that Taiwan's national security remains unaffected.
According to the CEPD, the EU is Taiwan's fourth-largest trading partner.

DOC.HEADLINE: American rock act might play Taiwan next year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 23:05:37 (By Tsai Hsin-hua and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The American rock band Bon Jovi might stage a concert in Taiwan next year, 15 years since the band's last visit in 1995, Universal Music said in a press release Tuesday.

Jon Bon Jovi, the lead singer of the band, has expressed the hope of visiting Taiwan in 2011, depending on the band's schedule, according to the press release. The band has played in Taiwan twice, in 1993 and 1995.
The band, formed in 1983, has performed more than 2,600 concerts in over 50 countries for more than 34 million fans and is considered in some circles as the most successful band in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-made rocket launched
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 23:19:22 (By Yang Sz-ruei & Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A hybrid rocket designed and developed by National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) was launched recently, the university in Tainan, southern Taiwan announced Tuesday.

Chao Yei-chin, director of the university's Aerospace Science and Technology Research Center and head of the research team, said the rocket was launched Oct. 13 from a beach area of Mudan Township in Pingtung County, also in the south of the county.
Chao said the 68-kg rocket reached an altitude of 8,000 meters and had a flight duration from take-off to disappearing from the remote tracking sensors of about 90 seconds.
"Our team will next challenge the altitude of 100 kilometers, " with the aim of exploring the lower thermosphere, Chao said, adding that he expects the goal to be reached in three to five years.

He said the concept of the hybrid rocket originated around 1930 and that the first successful launch took place in 1994, followed by subsequent research and development and launches of hybrid rockets by many universities, including Stanford University in the United States, Hokkaido University of Japan, and the College of Aerospace Engineering at Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics.
NCKU is the first to conduct research and development of a hybrid rocket system in Taiwan. A 30 kg hybrid rocket was launched by NCKU in May 2009.
NCKU President Michael Ming-Chiao Lao said the successful launch of the rocket, entirely designed and manufactured by the university, is a "significant moment" in the school's history.
In addition, he said, the cost of rocket manufacturing is low -- a mere NT$300,000 (US$9,710) -- in comparison to military rockets or space exploration rockets, which cost millions of dollars each.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Long-term care insurance will be tough to

TEXT.P: Taking care of the elderly is more complicated than most people imagine. Nevertheless, Taiwan's government must avoid writing a blank check for the long- term care insurance scheme set for introduction in 2011 by improving both software and hardware infrastructures.

Public attention has focused on the issue of how senior citizens are cared for since elderly residents were left for hours up to their chests in water at a care facility in Kaohsiung County last month when Typhoon Fanapi caused serious flooding.
There were two reasons that care institutions of such poor quality could remain in business, suggested Tsai Yi-hsuan, head of the Mennonite Social Welfare Foundation's southern service center.

First, although Taiwan had sufficient care facilities in total, their distribution was uneven, Tsai said. A poor quality establishment would still be able to attract people if it was the only care facility in its region.
Second, competition on price could lead to the cutting of staff and hence to worsening conditions.

But care homes are not the only option for taking care of the elderly. In fact, of Taiwan's 2.47 million people aged over 65, only 41,000 of them stay in institutions, according to statistics announced by the Ministry of the Interior for the end of June.

Facing an estimated rise in over-65s to around one-fifth of the total population by 2025, the government began a 10-year plan on long-term care in 2007, said Huang Pi-hsia, director-general of the ministry's Department of Social Affairs,
This plan budgets NT$81.7 billion (US$2.64 billion) for non-governmental organizations to provide care services to communities and homes where seniors can maintain normal lives.

In order to improve long-term care, the government has plans for a new insurance system, similar to the current National Health Insurance scheme, in which young people will pay a premium so as to enjoy care services at a reasonable price in their old age.
But experts are also worried at the insufficiency of care providers and organizations, and about the system needed to deliver welfare services.

Although government figures claim there are over 62,000 trained caregivers, Tsai said that only 16,000 were actually providing care services. She believed this was because Taiwan's foreign-worker policy was too open.
The lower pay given to foreign workers, and some employers' expectations that caregivers should help with domestic chores were both factors influencing trained caregivers from taking up jobs.

In facing the issue of Taiwan's aging society, the government cannot just rely on the proposed insurance scheme but should try to resolve these other problems hindering the development of long-term care.

Taiwan should also show more goodwill by removing Taiwan-only standards and adopting best international trading practices, it added.

The group's Pharmaceutical Committee said that as Taiwan is mulling a revamp of its national health coverage system, it should also stop its policy of lowering foreign-made drug prices before international pharmaceutical companies decide to pull out of the country altogether.

The group also raised concerns over Taiwan's Intellectual Property Court, questioning its fairness. Many trademarks of international brand names are still commonly used by local businesses such as hotels, KTVs and even betel nut stands, the committee said.

On Taiwan-China trade relations, the ECCT, while applauding the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed this June, continued to urge Taiwan to fully normalize trade relations with China by lifting its import ban on over 2,000 Chinese manufactured products.
The ban, said the group, has "diminished the willingness of multinational corporations to maintain or increase their investments in Taiwan."

In response, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairwoman Christina Liu thanked the ECCT for the suggestions and said the central government will encourage various agencies to speed up the adoption of international standards.

Moreover, the country is stepping up efforts to bolster trade links with the international community, including re-examining the option of opening its doors wider to more Chinese goods, under the condition that Taiwan's national security remains unaffected.
According to the CEPD, the EU is Taiwan's fourth-largest trading partner.

DOC.HEADLINE: American rock act might play Taiwan next year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 23:05:37 (By Tsai Hsin-hua and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The American rock band Bon Jovi might stage a concert in Taiwan next year, 15 years since the band's last visit in 1995, Universal Music said in a press release Tuesday.

Jon Bon Jovi, the lead singer of the band, has expressed the hope of visiting Taiwan in 2011, depending on the band's schedule, according to the press release. The band has played in Taiwan twice, in 1993 and 1995.
The band, formed in 1983, has performed more than 2,600 concerts in over 50 countries for more than 34 million fans and is considered in some circles as the most successful band in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-made rocket launched
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/10 23:19:22 (By Yang Sz-ruei & Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A hybrid rocket designed and developed by National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) was launched recently, the university in Tainan, southern Taiwan announced Tuesday.

Chao Yei-chin, director of the university's Aerospace Science and Technology Research Center and head of the research team, said the rocket was launched Oct. 13 from a beach area of Mudan Township in Pingtung County, also in the south of the county.
Chao said the 68-kg rocket reached an altitude of 8,000 meters and had a flight duration from take-off to disappearing from the remote tracking sensors of about 90 seconds.
"Our team will next challenge the altitude of 100 kilometers, " with the aim of exploring the lower thermosphere, Chao said, adding that he expects the goal to be reached in three to five years.

He said the concept of the hybrid rocket originated around 1930 and that the first successful launch took place in 1994, followed by subsequent research and development and launches of hybrid rockets by many universities, including Stanford University in the United States, Hokkaido University of Japan, and the College of Aerospace Engineering at Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics.
NCKU is the first to conduct research and development of a hybrid rocket system in Taiwan. A 30 kg hybrid rocket was launched by NCKU in May 2009.
NCKU President Michael Ming-Chiao Lao said the successful launch of the rocket, entirely designed and manufactured by the university, is a "significant moment" in the school's history.
In addition, he said, the cost of rocket manufacturing is low -- a mere NT$300,000 (US$9,710) -- in comparison to military rockets or space exploration rockets, which cost millions of dollars each.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Long-term care insurance will be tough to

TEXT.P: Taking care of the elderly is more complicated than most people imagine. Nevertheless, Taiwan's government must avoid writing a blank check for the long- term care insurance scheme set for introduction in 2011 by improving both software and hardware infrastructures.

Public attention has focused on the issue of how senior citizens are cared for since elderly residents were left for hours up to their chests in water at a care facility in Kaohsiung County last month when Typhoon Fanapi caused serious flooding.
There were two reasons that care institutions of such poor quality could remain in business, suggested Tsai Yi-hsuan, head of the Mennonite Social Welfare Foundation's southern service center.

First, although Taiwan had sufficient care facilities in total, their distribution was uneven, Tsai said. A poor quality establishment would still be able to attract people if it was the only care facility in its region.
Second, competition on price could lead to the cutting of staff and hence to worsening conditions.

But care homes are not the only option for taking care of the elderly. In fact, of Taiwan's 2.47 million people aged over 65, only 41,000 of them stay in institutions, according to statistics announced by the Ministry of the Interior for the end of June.

Facing an estimated rise in over-65s to around one-fifth of the total population by 2025, the government began a 10-year plan on long-term care in 2007, said Huang Pi-hsia, director-general of the ministry's Department of Social Affairs,
This plan budgets NT$81.7 billion (US$2.64 billion) for non-governmental organizations to provide care services to communities and homes where seniors can maintain normal lives.

In order to improve long-term care, the government has plans for a new insurance system, similar to the current National Health Insurance scheme, in which young people will pay a premium so as to enjoy care services at a reasonable price in their old age.
But experts are also worried at the insufficiency of care providers and organizations, and about the system needed to deliver welfare services.

Although government figures claim there are over 62,000 trained caregivers, Tsai said that only 16,000 were actually providing care services. She believed this was because Taiwan's foreign-worker policy was too open.
The lower pay given to foreign workers, and some employers' expectations that caregivers should help with domestic chores were both factors influencing trained caregivers from taking up jobs.

In facing the issue of Taiwan's aging society, the government cannot just rely on the proposed insurance scheme but should try to resolve these other problems hindering the development of long-term care.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 20, or the 13th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1818: Britain and the United States establish a border along the 49th parallel west of the Great Lakes.
1827: The Battle of Navarino in Greece comes to an end as British, French and Russian fleets annihilate the Turkish and Egyptian fleets.
1890: Sir Richard Burton, British explorer, soldier, diplomat and scholar, dies of a heart attack in Trieste at the age of 69. He discovered Lake Tanganyika and translated the 16-volume "Arabian Nights".
1891: Sir James Chadwick, English physicist, is born. He won the 1935 Nobel Prize in physics for the discovery of the neutron.
1935: Mao Tse-tung and his communist forces end their so-called "Long March" in Yenan in Shensi Province. On Oct. 10, 1934, the main forces of the Chinese communists fled their bases in Kiangsi Province to the northwest, launching the "Long March."
1935: Arthur Henderson, British politician and founder of the Labor Party, dies at the age of 72. He won the 1934 Nobel Peace Prize for his contributions as president of the World Disarmament Conference.
1943: The Republic of China signs a new Sino-Belgium Treaty and a new Sino- Luxembourg Treaty in Chungking.
1943: The United Nations War Crimes Commission is formed.
1944: U.S. Gen. Douglas MacArthur returns to the Philippines with 250,000 troops to fulfill his promise of returning that he made at the time when his forces were forced to retreat in the face of advancing Japanese forces.
1949: Britain recognizes the People's Republic of China under Mao Tse-tung.
1950: The ruling Kuomintang sets up the Taiwan Province Reform Commission with Nieh Wen-ya serving as its chairman.
1951: Governor Wu Kuo-chen of Taiwan presides over a ceremony marking the completion of the Akungtien Reservoir in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan.
1955: President Chiang Kai-shek permits self-renewal for General Sun Li-jen, former commander-in-chief of the ROC Army, without taking disciplinary action against him after an investigation commission submitted a report on a sedition case.
1957: President Chiang Kai-shek is reelected Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang.
1962 Some 20,000 Chinese troops launch an offensive on Indian military posts along the Himalayan border.
1964: Herbert C. Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, dies at the age of 90. After the stock market crash of 1929, he was unwilling to finance employment through federal intervention and lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932.
1968: Jackie Kennedy, widow of late U.S. President John F. Kennedy, marries multi-millionaire Aristotle Onassis.
1971: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts at improving relations between communist and non-communist nations.
1973: Queen Elizabeth II officially opens the Sydney Opera House in Australia.
1973: Yang Liang-kung, new president of the Examination Yuan, assumes office, while Liu Chi-hung takes office as vice president.
1975: The Fourth Pan-Pacific Conference on Regional Science opens in Taipei with more than 100 experts from Japan, the United States, Singapore and the ROC attending.
1982: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a soccer match in Moscow. A total of 340 people are killed.
1999: The ROC government extends its congratulations to Indonesian President-elect Abdurrahman Wahid for his election victory.
2000: Tseng Chu-wei, a professor of finance at National Chengchi University, urges the Democratic Progressive Party government to stop presenting any new policy initiatives in order to revive public confidence and maintain domestic stability.
2000: The U.S. Senate passes by a unanimous vote a House concurrent resolution in support of Taiwan's participation in the United Nations.
2001: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) says that the "no haste, be patient" policy on investment in mainland China is outdated and vows to replace it with a more aggressive approach.
Confucius lesson of the day: "Among the means for the regeneration of mankind, those made with noise and show are of the least importance."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Wednesday from its previous close, moving down 52.8 points at 7,993.43 on a turnover of NT$2.458 billion (US$79.29 million).
The weighted price index lost 14.31 points, or 0.17 percent, to close at 8,046.23 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$30.950 at 9:45 a.m. Wednesday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.05 from Tuesday's close. ENDITE

DOC.HEADLINE: Moderate earthquake hits eastern Taiwan

TEXT.P: A magnitude 4 earthquake jolted eastern Taiwan's Taitung County Wednesday, but there were no reports of damage, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said.

The tremor occurred at 6:32 a.m., with its epicenter located 5.2 kilometers northeast of the bureau's Lidao seismic observation station in Taitung County. It struck at a depth of 8.6 km, CWB officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Challenges for China's next leader

TEXT.P: Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping was recently named vice chairman of the Central Military Commission, which confirmed his status as the country's next leader after Hu Jintao.

A true challenge faced by China's fifth-generation leadership will be its people's demand for freedom and democracy. The presentation of the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize to jailed human rights activist Liu Xiaobo is only one of the signs.

On the diplomatic front, China's faces a currency war with the United States and territorial disputes with other countries in the region. How China is going to deal with other world superpowers will be another challenge that the country's new leaders will not be able to avoid.

The establishment of a system for leadership succession in China signifies that there is an institutionalized decision-making mechanism. Major policies, including those related to Taiwan, will be the result of collective decision- making by the Central Politburo.

To predict the future direction of China's policy toward Taiwan, Taiwan should study the overall background of the new leadership, instead of focusing on Xi's personal traits and leadership style alone.
We must also not overlook the possibility that Hu, who might want to leave behind a legacy, will remain the prime mover behind cross-Taiwan Strait relations during the final years of his tenure.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Decriminalizing the sex trade

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior recently unveiled a plan to decriminalize the adult sex trade. It was reported that the ministry would permit residence-based sex services offered by self-employed sex workers.

To the general public, the greatest concern is not whether prostitution should be banned or whether the rights of sex workers are protected, but whether the communities they are living in are invaded by the sex industry. It would be too naive to think that Taiwan's problem can be resolved by randomly introducing a new model from other countries.

Despite the obvious existence of rampant, illegal sex businesses in Taiwan, the government has done nothing about it. The public is justified, therefore, in worrying that the opening of residence-based sex services would allow the sex industry to spread like wildfire around the country.

The government's top priority now should be to remove legal discrimination against sex workers. It should also take action to show its ability to crack down on underground human trafficking rings to allow sex workers to enjoy true autonomy. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 20, 2010)
