DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan dollar falls after China interest rate hike
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 11:39:56 (By Lin Ye-fong and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan dollar weakened against the U.S. dollar in Wednesday morning trading after China's surprise move to raise its benchmark interest rates on Tuesday, dealers said.
At 10:45 a.m., the Taiwan dollar traded at NT$30.933 to the U.S. dollar, compared with Thursday's close of NT$30.900.

The People's Bank of China raised its deposit and lending rates for the first time in 3 years Tuesday, a move intended to curb inflation and prevent an asset- price bubble, especially in the property market.

The Taiwan dollar opened lower against the U.S. dollar and was unable to rebound early as foreign banks rushed to restore their U.S. dollar positions after recent massive selling of the greenback, dealers said.
The U.S. dollar had appeared stronger against the Taiwan dollar in recent trading sessions as traders pocketed profits from strong gains posted by the local currency, dealers said.
The interest rate hikes in China have further boosted buying in the greenback, they added.

Dealers said there have been concerns that other central banks in the region will follow China's step to tighten monetary policies to prevent rapid appreciation of their currencies against the U.S. dollar.

They said the Taiwan dollar is expected to move within a narrow range of NT$30.90 to NT$31.00 against the U.S. dollar for the rest of the trading session Wednesday as market sentiment remains cautious.

DOC.HEADLINE: Snail-paced Typhoon Megi keeps rain coming in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 12:31:23 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: All of Taiwan is expected to get rain on Wednesday, with Taipei and Yilan counties especially hard hit, as Typhoon Megi edges north after battering the northern Philippines, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said.
As of 8 a.m., Megi was located 640 kilometers south-southwest of Eluanbi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, moving north-northwest at a speed of 7 kilometers per hour.
Though weakened after making landfall in the Philippines, the storm was still packing maximum sustained winds of 173 kph with gusts of up to 209 kph.
Taiwan has experienced heavy rains in the past two days under the influence of the storm's outer rim and seasonal winds from the northeast.
With Typhoon Megi moving slowly, the CWB maintained its warning against torrential rain for northern and eastern Taiwan, as well as the Hengchun Peninsula at the island's southern tip.

According to CWB data, in the period from midnight to noon Wednesday, the highest levels of precipitation were observed in Taipei County's Shihding (124.5 millimeters) and Pingsi (124 mm) , Taipei City's Wenshan District (123.5 mm).
Meanwhile, a yellow-coded landslide warning was issued earlier in the day for 11 rivers in four villages in Yilan County's Datong Township.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two banks to supply Chinese yuan banknotes from Oct. 26
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CAN) 10/20/10 13:29:40 (By Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Bank of Taiwan (BOT) and Mega International Commercial Bank will begin to directly supply Chinese yuan bank notes from Oct. 26, a move expected to lower foreign exchange costs and supply the currency more cheaply to banks and consumers, the banks said Wednesday.
The two banks began to take orders placed by financial institutions on Wednesday and will negotiate the purchase of the yuan with the Hong Kong branch of Beijing-based Bank of China (BOC), they said.

The state-run BOT and partially government-owned Mega Bank signed cash settlement agreements with BOC's Hong Kong branch in July that made them the first two domestic banks able to supply Chinese yuan banknotes to Taiwanese customers.

The move by the two banks to take the orders came after Taiwan's central bank approved their applications to provide Chinese yuan cash settlement services in collaboration with the BOC's Hong Kong arm.

In the past, local financial institutions had to go through HSBC and Bank of America to get Chinese yuan notes, but the supply from the two foreign banks was not very stable, the banknotes were often old, and the cost of procuring the banknotes was relatively high.
Local buyers will now be able to place their orders for Chinese yuan banknotes with BOT and Mega Bank once a week and are expected to get the notes they need a week later, according to the two banks.

On Wednesday, BOT and Mega Bank were quoting a reference price for Chinese yuan banknotes of about NT$4.8 per Chinese yuan. The two banks said the actual rate used in final transactions will depend on negotiations with BOC's Hong Kong branch based on supply and demand.
The banks believed, however, that the Chinese currency is expected to become cheaper than before.

Based on Wednesday's cross exchange rates, the NT$4.8 quoted by the two banks represents a relative high 3.5 percent mark-up against the two currencies actual values, which partly reflects the high currency settlement costs.
The central bank said previously that the new settlement services would have three advantages: new yuan notes, cheap exchange costs and a stable supply.
The central bank had also estimated the direct supply could lead to savings of about NT$1,000 on every procurement of 20,000 Chinese yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Ma: It's better not to meet than to meet

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou twice denied Tuesday that he has any intention to meet his Chinese counterpart, Hu Jintao, anytime soon.
Responding to a question by some foreign-based ethnic Chinese business executives about the timing for a "Ma-Hu meeting, " the president said there is "no hurry" for such a meeting.

"The government's policy toward cross-Taiwan Strait relations is 'economy first, politics later, '" Ma told the executives at the Presidential Office. "Until all major cross-strait economic issues are resolved, it's better not to meet than to meet."
Later that day, Ma called an emergency news conference to clarify an Associated Press report that suggested Ma plans to launch a formal political dialogue with China if he wins re-election in 2012.

"I never made any connection between my second term and political issues, " Ma said at the mews conference held at Taipei International Airport upon his return from a community outreach visit to the southern city of Tainan.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

According to an AP report Tuesday, Ma said in an interview with the news agency that he is open to a political dialogue with China once remaining economic issues are resolved, though he gave no timetable for when those discussions might start.

In between the poles of union and separation, the AP report quoted Ma as saying that his government is prepared to discuss political agreements, including security issues, as soon as the priority economic issues are dealt with.
"He suggested that those political talks could start as early as a second four- year term if he wins re-election in 2012, " the AP report said.
Ma said, however, that he did not mention any time frame in his interview with the AP.
When asked if he would move to political talks in a second term once economic issues are dealt with, Ma said he just responded: "It depends on how fast we move."
"I did not mention anything about 2012," Ma contended.

The Presidential Office asked the AP to correct its report, but the agency only filed a backgrounder in response instead of deleting the paragraph reading, "his government is prepared to discuss political agreements, including security issues" as requested by the Presidential Office.
Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang later expressed regret and voiced a protest against the AP report. (Oct. 20, 2010).
China Times:
Ma clarified at the hastily called news conference that he neither mentioned "political dialogue" or any "timetable" in his interview with the AP.
The president stressed that "economy first, politics later" has been and consistently remains the crux of his administration's cross-strait policy.
Although some pundits have urged his government to speed up engagement with China, Ma said he sees no need to do so because the current pace is appropriate.
"Our cross-strait policy should meet our national needs, win public support and proceed under legislative supervision, " he added. (Oct. 20, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese companies exhibiting at Vietnam trade fair

TEXT.P: Nearly 20 Taiwanese companies are exhibiting at a trade fair which opened in Hanoi Tuesday, making the Taiwan contingent one of the biggest among all countries represented.

Two hundred domestic and 60 foreign companies were represented at the 2010 Vietnam International Industrial Fair. The Taiwanese group features Taiwantrade, an e-trading website sponsored by the Bureau of Foreign Trade, Shihlin Electric and Showfou Electric Machine Company.
Some Taiwanese companies which have had an operation in Vietnam for many years are also participating.

Huang Chih-peng, Taiwan's new representative to Vietnam visited the Taiwanese exhibitors and promised to provide assistance to their trade and investment activities. Huang was director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade, part of Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs, for eight years before taking up his new post in Hanoi on October 6.
Other countries represented at the trade fair, held from Oct. 19 to 23, include South Korea, the Czech Republic, Russia and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Control Yuan impeaches two senior judges for lobbying illegally
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 15:54:59 (By Sophia Yeh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan impeached two senior judges Wednesday for allegedly lobbying other judges to rule favorably in a case involving one of the accused's family members.

The body, the branch of government that monitors the behavior of government officials and civil servants, impeached Supreme Court judge Hsiao Yang-kuei by a vote of 12-1 and High Court judge Kao Ming-che by a vote of 11-2, said Control Yuan Minister without Portfolio Lee Fu-dien.

The two judges were found to have lobbied other judges illegally and violated laws regulating public servants and the judges' code of conduct, in the process "damaging the image of justice," Lee said.

Following the Control Yuan's decision, Hsiao and Kao will be disciplined by the Public Functionary Disciplinary Sanction Commission. They had already been suspended from their posts before the Control Yuan acted on Wednesday.
The case in question involved Hsiao's son, Hsiao Hsien-lun, who was accused of committing a hit and run in 2008.
The junior Hsiao was found guilty of the crime and sentenced to six months in prison and two years of probation by the Keelung District Court.
The High Court changed the ruling on appeal, however, to "not guilty."

Citing the results of their investigation, Lee said he found that Hsiao had attempted to lobby the judges hearing the cases at both the district and high court levels and that Kao, an old friend of the senior Hsiao, had also lobbied for a "not guilty" judgment.
Though the two judges both claimed their innocence, the Control Yuan decided "not to take that into account, " Lee noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hot money for currency speculation estimated at NT$370 billion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 16:56:13 (By Kao Chao-fen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central bank estimated Wednesday that NT$370 billion in international hot money is in Taiwan to speculate on the local currency.

The amount includes NT$120 billion in inward remittances that have not been used to invest in stocks but remain in transaction accounts, and another NT$250 billion that has been used to purchase two-year government bonds, central bank Governor Perng Fai-nan told the Legislative Yuan's Finance Committee.

According to Perng, given that the interest rates for two-year government bonds are lower than those for U.S. dollar deposits, the true purpose of the purchases is likely to be to speculate on the appreciating Taiwanese currency.
Perng said the central bank and Financial Supervisory Commission have made an effort to combat the impact of hot money on Taiwan's currency, including in the equities market.
The government, for example, recently forbid foreign investors to use Taiwan dollars as cash collateral for securities lending and borrowing, allowing only U.S. dollars to be used for the purpose.
That has helped decrease the amount of suspected hot money hidden in the sector from NT$120 billion to NT$60 million, Perng said.

On China's Tuesday decision to raise its deposit and lending rates by a quarter point, Perng said he believes the measure will help stabilize China's economy and reverse its negative real interest rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.97 percent

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.97 percent Wednesday as bargain hunters emerged to recoup early losses resulting from China's surprise raising of benchmark interest rates the previous day, dealers said.
Taiwan's weighted index closed up 78.39 points at 8,124.62 after moving between 7,992.81 and 8,131.19, on turnover of NT$105.06 billion (US$3.41 billion).

The market opened down 0.66 percent on a reflex response to China's rate hike, but as investors witnessed a rebound on the Shanghai market, sentiment improved and they resumed buying, with high-tech stocks particularly favored, dealers said.
A total of 2,359 stocks closed up, 1,529 fell and 286 remained unchanged.

The machinery and electronics sector scored the highest gains, up 1.56 percent. Plastics and chemical stocks rose 1.2 percent, textile firms gained 1.0 percent, cement shares closed up 0.56 percent, the construction sector rose 0.31 percent and the paper and pulp sector added 0.05 percent.
Fallers included foodstuffs down 0.81 percent and financial stocks down slightly at 0.09 percent.
The People's Bank of China Tuesday raised its deposit and lending rates for the first time in 3 years, a move believed to curb inflation and prevent an asset bubble.
Taiwan International Securities analyst Michael Chiang said investors' initial response showed they feared the rate hike would compromise China's economic growth.

"But, as inflation remains a concern in China, the mainland still has room to tighten its monetary policy," Chiang said, "So, further rate hikes are possible to attract more foreign funds into China or even into the Asian market."
"Liquidity is likely to go higher in the long run, as this is one of the things the stock market likes best," Chiang said.

Electronics looked cheap to investors who wanted to find a safe haven to park their money, he said, noting that investors resumed buying electronics stocks which had earlier been hit by fears of falling global demand.

It remained to be seen, however, whether the electronic sector's strength would continue amid the cautious mood ahead of the third-quarter-earnings reports due to kick off later this month, Chiang said.
It would not be easy for the bourse to overcome strong technical resistance ahead of the 8,200-8,300 point range anytime soon, he warned.
Following recent heavy losses, Smartphone maker HTC rose 5.01 percent to NT$671.00, and optical lens firm Largan added 5.71 percent to NT$592.00.
Similarly PC vendor Acer gained 2.68 percent to NT$80.50 and Hon Hai Precision, the world's largest electronics maker, rose 1.79 percent to NT$114.00.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Wednesday, gaining NT$0.03 to close at NT$30.930.
Turnover totaled US$780 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.970 and moved between NT$30.840 and NT$30.990 before the close.
Dealers said investors throughout East Asia, in particular foreign banks, sustained their interest in U.S. dollars seen in recent days.
The trend was highlighted by the weakness of the Chinese yuan to the greenback Wednesday after Beijing's surprise move Tuesday to raise its key interest rates.
The People's Bank of China raised its deposit and lending rates for the first time in three years, a move intended to curb inflation and prevent an asset bubble.

Dealers said that while the gains on the local bourse lent some support to the Taiwan dollar, market sentiment remained cautious on fears that governments in the region would take action to prevent rapid appreciation of their currency against the U.S. dollar.
The benchmark weighted index closed up 0.97 percent on bargain hunting.

Dealers said a stronger U.S. dollar has alleviated pressure on the central bank to intervene in the foreign exchange market. The central bank has been worried that an appreciating local currency would hurt the island's global competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: Autistic riders complete nearly half of round-the-island trip
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 17:47:54 (By Ja-fo Chen and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Six autistic bike riders on a trip around Taiwan arrived in the southern city of Kaohsiung Wednesday, four days after setting off from Taipei and braving the elements down the island's western coast.
The riders, aged 13 to 30, are being accompanied by family members and volunteers on the third round-the-island cycling journey organized by the Autism Society Taiwan, R.O.C.
The group stopped briefly in Kaohsiung City before getting back on their bikes to head for Pingtung, Taiwan's southernmost county.
"No one has complained about how difficult the trip has been despite the heat and rain, " said one of the parents accompanying the riders.

After biking to Pingtung County, the group will head to Taiwan's eastern coast and then travel north. It expects to return to the capital city on Oct. 26 and complete the trip of over 1,200 kilometers in 11 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Game 4 of Taiwan Series rained out

TEXT.P: Game 4 of the Taiwan Series between the Brother Elephants and the Sinon Bulls scheduled for Wednesday in Taipei County's Sinjhuang City has been postponed due to heavy rain, according to Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL).

The potential series clincher has been rescheduled for Thursday in Sinjhuang, weather permitting. The Elephants will be trying to complete a sweep of the Bulls in the best-of-seven series and win the seventh CPBL title in the team's history.
Jim Magrane, who won Game 1 of the series, will start for the Elephants while Dominican left-hander Juan Pena will take the mound for the Bulls.
The CPBL said that if a Game 5 is necessary, it will be played in Taoyuan County Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese film Monga named Best Asian Film in Hawaii festival
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/20/10 17:57:59 (By Leaf Jiang and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Monga, the film Taiwan is nominating for Best Foreign Language Film at the Academy Awards next year, won the Best Asian Award at the Hawaii International Film Festival Tuesday.
Lee Tai-kuai, an official with the Culture Center of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Los Angeles, accepted the award on behalf of the film's producers.

The gangster movie set in Taipei's old Wanhua district was a huge local box office success when released in January, setting a single day record for a domestic film, according to the online Business Weekly.
It also helped stimulate tourism in that part of the city.
The award given at the festival was established by the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema (NETPAC), a pan-Asian film cultural organization involving film production professionals.
Au Revoir Taipei, a romantic comedy set in Taipei's capital city, also won a NETPAC prize at the Berlin International Film Festival in 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: Third terminal targeting transit passengers: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 18:32:47 (By Kelven Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The government's plan to build a third terminal at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport aimed to transform the airport into a hub in Asia and to attract more transit passengers, Minister of Transportation Mao Chi-kuo said Wednesday.

Mao was responding to a question from Legislator Yeh Yi-ching of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party who questioned the need for a third terminal at Taiwan's main airport, citing a continuous decline in the nation's population.
The volume of passengers handled by the airport was expected to surpass the 20-million mark this year, Mao told lawmakers on the Legislative Yuan's transportation committee.
"If airports in Taiwan only serve local people, they will have no future," he said. "They must be able to attract transit passengers."
Mao explained that the ministry was preparing for demand in the year 2018 and thereafter.

The government was convinced that the two existing terminals would not be able to meet the expected surge in demand following the opening last year of transport links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, he said.
Asked about the reported budget of NT$60 billion (US$1.9 billion) for the project, Mao said that sums outlined by the media merely represented the ministry's rough calculations.

Earlier in the day, Mao responded to media inquiries by saying the government had not yet drawn up a budget for the project. Noting that it was still in an opinion-collecting phase, he said nevertheless that the government hoped construction of the terminal would be finished by 2018.
Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, located some 30 kilometers to the south of Taipei, is one of the country's major international airports and by far the busiest.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County offers free hearing tests for neonates

TEXT.P: All newborns aged three days to one month with at least one parent registered as a Taipei County resident can get a free hearing test at one of the 12 designated hospitals or clinics located in the county, the county's Public Health Bureau said Wednesday.
Foreign nationals can also enjoy the service as long as one of the newborn's parents can prove residency in the county, said Chia Shu-li, a section chief at the bureau.
Chia said that since Taipei County began offering the service last month, a total of 998 infants were checked and 22 cases of abnormal hearing detected.

Studies have shown that one in every 500 newborns will end up needing a hearing aid during their childhood, but if hearing problems are detected within a child's first six months of life, many infants can eventually restore their hearing to a normal level, the bureau said in explaining the rationale behind the program.

The 12 medical centers include well-known hospitals such as Far Eastern Memorial Hospital, Taipei Medical University Shuang-ho Hospital, Sijhih Cathay General Hospital, Mackay Hospital Danshui, and Buddhist Tzu Chi General Hospital Taipei Branch.

A detailed list can be found on the Taipei County government's website. Chia noted that infants' families will still need to pay the regular registration fee but that the checkup itself will be free of charge.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to set up central command center to curb dengue fever
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 18:55:48 (By Ching-fang Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A central epidemic command center will be set up this week to stem the spread of dengue fever as the mosquito-borne disease has been rapidly spreading in the country, the Department of Health (DOH) said Wednesday.

DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang said at the Legislative Yuan that he and Stephen S.H. Shen, minister of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), will head the command center, which will be set up Thursday exclusively to curb the spread of the disease.

The center will also establish ad hoc command centers in Taiwan's southern counties of Kaohsiung and Tainan, the hardest hit areas, said Chang Feng-yee, director-general of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, who was also present at the Legislative Yuan's Q-and-A session.

According to the DOH, the number of indigenous cases of the disease rose by 132 last week alone. As of Tuesday, the number of imported cases totaled 138 since August. From August to date, the total number of indigenous cases has reached 643 nationwide, the DOH said.
This has led the DOH to speculate that the number of indigenous dengue fever cases will probably surpass 1,000 this year.
There is no vaccine for dengue fever. The disease causes severe flu-like symptoms and has the potential to be fatal.

Yaung said one of the reasons for the increase in cases in Taiwan is that the spread of dengue fever has been raging in Southeast Asia this year, indirectly causing the numbers of both imported and indigenous cases to go up in Taiwan.
Another reason is that some residents have been opposed to health workers spraying insecticide in their neighborhood, Yaung said.
"The central epidemic command center will do its best to stem the disease, but I cannot promise that it will be eradicated once and for all," Yaung said.

He was responding to questions raised by ruling Kuomintang Legislators Hou Tsai- feng and Hsu Shao-ping, both of whom criticized the government for not doing a good enough job in preventing the spread of dengue fever in the past two months.
Hsu accused the DOH and the EPA of not cooperating with the local governments of Kaohsiung and Tainan to clean up the environment to facilitate the eradication of mosquitos.

DOC.HEADLINE: Time not ripe for Ma-Hu meeting: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 19:53:27 (By Lee Ming-Chung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih reiterated Wednesday that the time was not ripe for a meeting between the leaders of Taiwan and China, despite their warming ties.
Before such a meeting could be held, Wu said, a stronger consensus on the issue needed to be built in Taiwan, and higher levels of goodwill and mutual trust developed between the two sides.

"At present, we do not see an opportunity (for such a meeting), " he said while receiving a delegation of the New York-based Committee of 100, which was in Taiwan to attend the 8th Global Views Business Forum held Oct. 18-19 in Taipei.

Wu was apparently responding to a proposal raised at the forum by ROC Red Cross Society President Chen Charng-ven who said the annual event could be a venue for a meeting between President Ma Ying-jeou and his Chinese counterpart Hu Jintao.
Chen suggested that Ma and Hu could both be invited to the 2011 or 2012 forums, to be held in Beijing and Shanghai, where they could then meet each other.

According to Wu, improved relations across the Taiwan Strait were a good sign for ethnic Chinese around the world, and Taiwan's freedom, democracy and rule of law were providing an ideal model for China.
He likened economic development and democratization to a person's two legs, which should grow at an equal pace to achieve a balanced development.

Wu said he believed the Chinese leadership was well aware it could not resist the trends of political reform and opening up, which was the reason Hu had put forward the goal of constructing a "harmonious society" and Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao had recently called for political reform.

During the reception, Wu urged members of the Committee of 100 to help lobby the U.S. government to approve Taiwan's request to buy F-16 C/D fighters, saying that such arms procurement was necessary for Taiwan to maintain its self-defense capabilities.
The Committee of 100, composed of prominent Chinese Americans, is a group concerned with issues in Sino-American relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's rate hike means end to economic stimulus measures: CEPD

TEXT.P: Tuesday's hike in China's key interest rate would be a prelude to suspension of its economic stimulus measures, Christina Liu, chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said Wednesday.

Referring to the rise of 0.25 percentage points in China's benchmark lending rates, its first increase since onset of the global economic crisis, Liu said this came as no surprise, given that Beijing had already raised its deposit reserve ratio several times.

The rate hike, which included rises to 5.56 percent on a one-year loan and to 2.5 percent on one-year deposits, was aimed at lowering inflation pressure, Liu said at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Economic Affairs Committee.
China experienced an inflation rate of 3.5 percent in August, which exceeded the 3-percent ceiling deemed acceptable by the Beijing authorities, she noted.

The hike would also mean the beginning an end to the 4,000-billion-yuan (US$585 billion) stimulus measures introduced in 2008 to help weather the global economic crisis, she predicted, calling on Taiwanese businesses operating in China to better prepare for further withdrawal of the measures.

For example, Liu said that export-oriented China-based Taiwanese enterprises should shift their market focus to China instead of the United States or Europe, and that they should also establish an information-sharing mechanism on China's domestic market.
In related news, China's rate hike was described as "healthy" by Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) Governor Perng Fai-nan.
Speaking at Legislative Yuan's Financial Committee meeting, Perng said it would help maintain a stable economic development for China in the long as well as middle term.
Perng declined to say whether China's higher interest rate would influence Taiwan's stock market. "It's a highly sensitive issue, and I am not in a position to make any comment," he said.

Similarly, on whether it would affect Taiwan's monetary policy, Perng said that policy would be made by the bank's board of directors and supervisors based on considerations of the domestic and global macroeconomic situation. (By Hsieh Chun-wei & Bear Lee) ed/MH

DOC.HEADLINE: Singapore firm's TDRs jump on first day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 20:08:19 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan depositary receipts (TDRs) of BH Global Marine Ltd., a Singapore- based supplier of marine and offshore electrical products, soared Wednesday on the first day they were traded on optimism over the global shipping sector, dealers said.
BH Global Marine rose 6.76 percent to NT$18.15 (US$0.59) with 84,000 shares changing hands, while the benchmark weighted index closed up 0.97 percent at 8,124.62.

The company, which provides marine electrical equipment and marine consumables to the shipbuilding, ship repair, petrochemical, and offshore oil and gas industries, has been listed on the Singapore Exchange since 2005.
"The company is the first marine equipment maker to list its shares on the local bourse. It appeared unique to investors here, " Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said.
"With the rebound in the global shipping business, investors have become more interested in the stock," Hsu said.

Being based in Singapore also gives the company an advantage, the analyst said, because the city state's status as a transportation hub makes it an ideal location for developing marine-related businesses.
Last year, Singapore accounted for 78 percent of the company's NT$2.4 billion in total revenue, with other countries in Asia and the Middle East accounting for the rest.
The listing price of BH Global Marine's TDRs was set at NT$17, higher than the previously planned NT$15, after the stock was more than four times oversubscribed in the underwriting stage.

Hsu said that because price-earnings ratios in Taiwan's stock market were generally higher than in Singapore's market, investors here expected that the price of BH Global Marine's TDRs would climb further.
"It is possible for the stock to rise an additional 10-15 percent in the short term as a honeymoon period remains in place, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Co-development of Indonesian islet under discussion: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/20/10 20:16:05 (By Lee Ming-chung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih confirmed Wednesday that Indonesia is preparing to offer one of its islets to Taiwanese businessmen to develop and that discussions have been underway.

"The administration is more than willing to help as long as the cooperation project is Taiwan-centric and good for the people, " Wu said after meeting a group of outstanding overseas Chinese and Taiwanese business leaders at the Executive Yuan.

He said that the Indonesian government is preparing to offer the Indonesian islet of Morotai to Taiwanese businesses and Taiwanese citizens maintaining business operations in China so they can jointly develop it with the Indonesian government and local partners.
"A number of Taiwanese businessmen have visited Morotai and more are planning to go to explore the co-development offer, " Wu said.

According to local media reports, the Indonesian government has offered recently to have Taiwan help develop Morotai, an island with an area of about 2,400 square kilometers and a population of 50,000 people, located between the Philippines and New Guinea.
Indonesian officials will come to Taiwan in November for further discussions on the matter, a local newspaper said.

A group of Taiwanese businessmen, under the escort of Indonesia's representative to Taiwan Harmen Sembiring and officials from Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOEA) , embarked on a week-long trip to the underdeveloped island on Oct. 12 to conduct a preliminary evaluation.

Indonesia's Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries first made contact with the MOEA in September about the project when Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang was in Indonesia at the head of a trade and investment delegation.

"The Indonesian side hopes to attract Taiwanese investment in the sectors of seafood production, fishing, aquaculture and tourism, " said Kuo Fu-chuan, a senior technical specialist in the MOEA's Department of Investment Services.

Indonesia has also offered state-run CPC Corp. Taiwan and Taiwan Sugar Corporation the opportunity to establish an oil refinery and develop land, respectively, in other parts of the country, Kuo said.
Morotai is best known as the site of the Battle of Morotai in World War II in 1944 and was used as a springboard for the Allied invasion of the Japanese- controlled Philippines in 1945.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Futures Exchange signs cooperation MOU with Singapore's SMX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 20:22:54 (By Wei Shu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Futures Exchange (TAIFEX) said Wednesday it has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the Singapore Mercantile Exchange (SMX) for future cooperation.
The TAIFEX said the MOU has provided both sides with a mechanism to forge closer links by coordinating and sharing information in derivative product design, business development and market concepts.
The exchange added the two partners are expected to soon set up a process for regular bilateral meetings between senior executives to increase understanding between the two sides.

The SMX, which runs a clearing house -- the Singapore Mercantile Exchange Clearing Corp. --, became operational on Aug. 31, 2010 as the first pan-Asian multi-product commodity and currency derivatives exchange.
Its products include futures and options contracts on precious metals, base metals, agriculture commodities, energy, currencies and indices.
Financial Technologies (India) Ltd, which has established 10 exchanges across India, Dubai, Singapore, Africa, Mauritius and Bahrain, is the SMX's major shareholder.
The SMX is the second exchange from Singapore to sign a cooperation MOU with the TAIFEX after the accord inked with the Singapore Exchange (SX) in December 2007.

So far, a total of 16 exchanges worldwide have signed similar agreements with the TAIFEX, including the Tokyo Financial Exchange, Tokyo Commodities Exchange, Korean Exchange, Chicago Mercantile Exchange, Osaka Securities Exchange and Warsaw Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stages first dementia documentary

TEXT.P: Taiwans first documentary film depicting life stories of dementia patients would make its debut in late November, an organization for Alzheimers patients announced Wednesday.

Thanking the public for raising NT$8.2 million (US$256,000), the Catholic Foundation of Alzheimers Disease and Related Dementia (CFAD) and Allianz Taiwan Life Insurance Company said at a press conference that the money raised over a five-month period had assisted production of "The Long Goodbye" and would also provide care for elders suffering from dementia.

The film, which took nearly three years to complete and was directed by Golden Horse Award winner Yang Li-chou, aimed to help people understand more about Alzheimer and teach them how to interact with sufferers of the disease.

A case in point was 96-year-old Eva, one of the film's five main characters, said Pauline Wang, nursing director of the Alzheimers disease community center run by CFAD. Eva had taught at the English Department of the National Taiwan Normal University.

Seven years ago, at the request of her family, we gave Eva a fake teaching title and asked her to come daily for volunteer teaching at a Catholic English school, said Wang, whose tasks include customizing patients' schedules on the basis of their interests.

Eva is one of 64 dementia sufferers at the center and one of 120,000 patients nationwide who were in need of respect and meaningful lives, said Chen Chun-yu, chief of CFADs social work department. She encouraged the public to raise their awareness of the disease, which is growing rapidly among the Taiwan's aging population.
The film was an inspiring work that was guaranteed to move audiences to both tears and laughter, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former U.S. president Clinton to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Former U.S. president Bill Clinton will visit Taiwan in mid-November, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official confirmed Wednesday.
Clinton is scheduled to deliver a speech in Taipei Nov. 14 in an invitational Asian tour, which was organized by a Singaporean business, MOFA spokesman James Chang said.

Clinton, who served as U.S. president from 1993-2001, will arrive in Taiwan for a private, business trip, Chang said, but the foreign ministry will provide necessary assistance and security service during Clinton's stay based on the request made by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , the U.S. representative office in Taiwan in the absence of official bilateral diplomatic ties.
Chang said he was not aware of details of the tour and declined to comment on whether Clinton will meet with President Ma Ying-jeou or other Taiwanese officials.

The visit will be Clinton's sixth visit to Taiwan and his first since February 2005 as a former U.S. president. He met with then- Taiwanese President Chen Shui-bian and then-Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan during the 22-hour whirlwind tour in 2005, which was sponsored by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy.
Clinton also visited Taiwan four times when he served as the Governor of Arkansas from 1979-1981 and 1983-1992.
The AIT declined to comment on the upcoming visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Young soybean plantation revived on fallow land in southern Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 21:01:33 (By Yang Sz-ruei and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Thanks to the government's policy of reviving fallow land, the output of young soybeans -- immature soybeans known as "maodou" in Chinese -- in Sinshih Township, southern Taiwan's Tainan County has nearly doubled this year from the previous year, a representative of local farmers said Wednesday.

Lee Chao-tang, chief executive of the Sinshih Township Farmers' Association, said the land area used for young soybean plantation has doubled to 100 hectares. He attributed the growth to the government's subsidies for farmers to grow crops on fallow land.
To convince farmers to grow maodou, the association has also taken efforts to develop new soybean-based products, Lee said.

He noted that they have successfully developed products like maodou noodles, maodou ice cream and maodou sauce. The ice cream has turned out to be a big hit in the local catering market, according to Lee.
The emerging soybean industry, which helps increase the demand for the crops, has raised farmers' interests in growing the young soybeans, he added.
According to Lee, Sinshih was once one of the major soybean production areas in Taiwan since the plantation of the crops began in the years between 1986 and 1988.
Back in the old days, the soybeans were one of the sources of protein for the local people. The plantation scale once reached 500-600 hectares in Sinshih, Lee said.

Planting of the crop, however, waned many years ago due to the high cost of harvesting the soybeans by hand and the construction of the Southern Taiwan Science Park, which turned some farmland into high-tech factories.
"Young soybean fields had once disappeared in Sinshih" after some farmers would rather leave their land fallow than grow the soybeans, Lee said.
Farmers began to grow the soybeans again in recent years, he noted.
Boiled soybean in the pod is a common dish in Chinese and Japanese restaurants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Microsoft says smartphone shipments unaffected

TEXT.P: Microsoft Corp., the world's largest software company, said Wednesday that shipments of new smartphones using its operating system were unaffected despite concerns over glitches in the system.

"The entire plan for the shipments of Windows Phone 7 (WP7) is going smoothly, including those from Taiwanese manufacturers and others, "said Zhang Ya-qin, corporate vice-president in charge of Microsoft's research and development activities in China, at a press conference in Taipei.
"I have used the phone for some time and it has never crashed, " he added.
But Microsoft's WP7 had reboot problems for unknown reasons, according to the Apple Daily. The Chinese-language newspaper said this would affect shipments of the software giant's latest product.

Taiwanese original design manufacturers (ODM) could increase their revenues, Zhang suggested, by developing software applications on the basis of cloud computing, an Internet-based technology for resource sharing and one of the highlighted features of WP7.

DOC.HEADLINE: Next Chinese leader familiar with Taiwan affairs: NSB chief
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 21:18:12 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Sofia wu)

TEXT.P: The man in line to be China's next leader was no stranger to Taiwan affairs, but he was not expected to compromise on any sovereignty- and territory-related issues, Taiwan's National Security Bureau Director Tsai Teh-sheng said Wednesday.

"Xi Jinping, China's vice president who is widely believed to be the anointed successor to Chinese President Hu Jintao, is known to be versed in Taiwan affairs as he had extensive contact with Taiwanese businessmen during his years as communist party boss in Shanghai and the eastern provinces of Fujian and Zhejiang, all of which have large clusters of Taiwan-owned companies," Tsai said at a legislative session.
Nevertheless, Tsai said Xi's rich knowledge about Taiwan would not necessarily make him a "Taiwan-friendly" leader after he took power.
For one thing, Tsai reminded members of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Defense Committee present at the session that Xi could not solely formulate China's future policy toward Taiwan.

"China now adopts a collective leadership system instead of a one-man rule as seen in the Deng Xiaoing era," Tsai said. "Therefore, China's future Taiwan policy will not be dictated by any single figure but will reflect the collective views and wills of a number of Chinese leaders."
In the past, Tsai continued, Chinese officials were branded as "dove faction" and "hawk faction" in terms of their stances toward Taiwan.
"Such a characterization is meaningless. As far as the sensitive sovereignty and territorial issues are concerned, all Chinese leaders are hard-liners and nationalists," he said.
Tsai also recalled that during a previous visit to a Hispanic country, Xi publicly criticized some foreign pundits critical of China's human rights policy as meddling in its domestic affairs.
Meanwhile, Tsai confirmed for the first time that a brother of Xi's wife Peng Liyuan is living in Chiayi in southern Taiwan.

Peng, a major general with the People's Liberation Army's General Political Department, is very well-known in China as a folk singer. According to Tsai, she made an eight-day visit to Taiwan in 1997 for the purpose of cultural exchanges.

On China's leadership transition, Tsai said Xi's succession to Hu has been on track since he became vice president in 2008. His recent appointment as vice chairman of the Central Military Commission -- China's top military body -- would allow him to consolidate his influence over the military and enhance his political stature, Tsai said.

Without a transparent electoral process, Tsai said, the Communist Party of China could utilize Xi's new appointment to the powerful military committee to show that its leadership transition is going ahead smoothly as Hu is expected to step down as party chief in 2012 and as president the following year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asian countries 'troubled' by hot money: CEPD head
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 21:26:28 (By Hsieh Chu-wei & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Most Asian counties have been troubled by appreciation of their currencies as a result of the United States increasing its issuance of bank notes, Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairwoman Christina Liu said Wednesday.

"Almost all Asian counties are suffering an overheated economic climate due to the massive inflow of hot money, and they will not be able to withstand further waves of speculative capital if other countries join the U.S. in issuing more bills, " said the economist- turned head of the CEPD, which is responsible for charting the nation's economic development.

Media reports suggested the U.S. was poised for another round of "quantitative easing monetary policy" in a bid to help prop up its sluggish economy, a move that could devalue the greenback and prompt further cross-border flows of speculative money.
Japan had already followed the U.S. in issuing more bills as part of its efforts to re-energize its economy, the reports stated, and Britain was likely to follow suit.

Concerned about the impact of the hot money, Legislator Lai Shyh-bao of the ruling Kuomintang raised the possibility of a recurrence of the 1997 Asian monetary crisis if the world's three leading economies kept issuing money without limit.
Liu responded that, if properly managed and if transferred to funds for foreign direct investment (FDI) , then hot capital would contribute to a country's economic development.
While the CEPD was not responsible for managing the flow of capital, Liu said that personally she was in favor of imposing controls on the hot money.
"It will be very dangerous if we fail to deal with speculators appropriately," she said.
In related news, Taiwan's central bank estimated Wednesday that NT$370 billion of international hot money was in Taiwan to speculate on the local currency.

That amount included NT$120 billion in inward remittances that had not been invested in stocks but remained in transaction accounts, and another NT$250 billion that had been used to purchase two-year government bonds, central bank Governor Perng Fai-nan told the Legislative Yuan's Finance Committee. ed/MH

DOC.HEADLINE: World's largest nanoelectronics institute sets up Taiwan R&D center

TEXT.P: Interuniversity Microelectronics Centre (Imec), the world's largest nanoelectronics research institute based in Belgium, set up a research and development center in Taiwan Wednesday to focus on bioelectronics and green electronics.

"The creation of the ITIC (Imec Taiwan Innovation Centre) , two years after having established a representative office in Hsinchu, Taiwan, is essential in our continued efforts to create value for our current and future partners in Taiwan, " Imec CEO and President Luc Van den hove, told reporters at a signing ceremony.
ITIC, co-funded under a project of the Ministry of Economic Affairs to encourage foreign enterprises to set up research and development centers in Taiwan, is Imec's first R&D center outside Europe.

Explaining why Imec chose Taiwan, the chief executive said that his company has a long-term partnership with local companies, such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) , the world's largest contract chip maker, and United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC).
"We have already a very long relationship with companies in Taiwan, " said Luc Van den hove. "It's very clear that Taiwan is one of the leading countries in this domain."
"The strategy of Imec has always been that, if we want to be the No. 1 R&D provider, we need to work with the No. 1 companies in the world," he added.
The ITIC will focus on information and communications technology, health care and green electronics, the chief executive said.
Asked by reporters if Imec will establish a fab in Taiwan, the chief executive said that there is no such a plan at the moment.
"Of course, we never say never," he added, however.
Luc Van den hove declined to confirm local media reports saying that Imec will invest NT$150 million (US$4.9 million) in the new research center.
The research institute will hire more than 40 specialists in Taiwan over the next three years, said Wu Hsiang-wei, general manager of Imec Taiwan.
Imec, which employs about 1,800 people, has offices in the Netherlands, the United States, China and Japan. In 2009, Imec's revenue was 275 million euro.

DOC.HEADLINE: Food products in Taiwan contain high sodium levels: group
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 21:58:19 ( By Yang Shu-min and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The sodium content of 85 percent of the food products sold in Taiwan is much higher than the recommended intake of 800 milligrams per meal, the Consumers' Foundation said Wednesday.
The foundation said 34 out of 40 products tested in January this year exceeded the average sodium intake suggested for an adult per meal.
Of the products tested, eight packaged products (around 20 percent of the total) even contained a higher sodium level than the average daily sodium intake of 2,400 milligrams, the foundation said
In addition to testing food products, the foundation also tested 17 types of snack products and found that 12 of them contained more than 800 milligrams of sodium.
Seven samples of instant noodles and hamburgers tested all exceeded the suggested sodium level.
The foundation also found that eating 100 grams of three types of canned food tested will give consumers a sodium intake of 1.2 to 1.9 times the recommended amount.
Meanwhile, seven out of eight condiment packages and microwave food products tested contained 1,200 milligrams of sodium-- more than half of the recommended average daily intake.
The foundation urged the Department of Health to set sodium limits in instant noodles and snack products and order food suppliers to reduce the sodium content in food by 30 percent.
Food companies should also properly label food packages to help customers make better choices and live healthy lifestyles, the foundation said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's exports post record high in September

TEXT.P: Taiwan's monthly export orders marked a record high in September as shipments reflected changes in exchange rates, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday.
Taiwan's export orders for September totaled US$35.98 billion, a year-on-year gain of 16.68 percent.
IT and telecom products posted an increase of US$1.71 billion, up 22.17 percent, with notebook computers and Apple products posting the biggest gains, according to the ministry.
Electronics orders followed with a 15.84-percent growth of US$1.22 billion, while chemical-product orders increased by US$600 million or 44.53 percent.
Orders from America totaled US$8.807 billion, compared with US$19.542 billion from Asia -- primarily Japan, China and Hong Kong -- while orders from Europe totaled US$6.970 billion.
Export orders for the entire third quarter reached a total value of US$104.69 billion, up 19.32 percent from a year earlier, the MOEA statistics showed.
The overall good figures resulted from restocking demands and Taiwan's advantage in currency exchange rates, said Huang Ji-shih, head of the MOEA's statistics department.

The euro had risen against the Taiwan dollar since June, leading to September's rapid growth in exports to Europe, just as orders from Japan probably escalated due to take off by the Japanese yen, Huang suggested. (By Lin Hui-chun and C.Y. Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: Dodgers reliever Kuo to return to Taiwan for vacation

TEXT.P: Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher Kuo Hong-chih, who is coming off the finest season of his Major League Baseball (MLB) career, is scheduled to return to Taiwan Thursday, the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association (CTBA) has announced.
Kuo will arrive in Taipei Thursday and attend an international baseball competition Saturday as a VIP, the CTBA said in a press release.

He will throw the first pitch of the opening game between Taiwan and South Korea Saturday in the 2010 Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament, which will be played at the Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium in the central Taiwanese city of Taichung, according to the CTBA.
The lefthander finished the 2010 season with three wins, two losses and 12 saves in 56 appearances and became the first Taiwanese player to earn a spot in the MLB mid-season All-Star Game.
Kuo, who had four surgeries on his elbow, also broke the Dodgers franchise record of the lowest ERA (earned run average), finishing the season with an ERA of 1.20. He struck out 73 in 60 innings.

Kuo will enjoy a competition-free off season in Taiwan after the Dodgers rejected the CPBL's request to include the 29-year-old in the Taiwan national team roster for the upcoming Asian Games, which will be held in Guangzhou, China from Nov. 12-27.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's procurement deals aim to promote unification: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 22:26:54 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China has sent 62 procurement missions to Taiwan since May 2008, signing letters of intent to purchase US$16.2 billion worth of locally made products, Taiwan's intelligence chief said Wednesday.

This year alone, 14 Chinese procurement missions have visited Taiwan, National Security Bureau Director Tsai Teh-sheng said at a closed-door session of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Defense Committee.
Many of those deals have not yet been substantiated, however, and some of them would require a long period of time to complete delivery, Tsai said.

Grilled by opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Hung-liang on whether China's procurement contracts were part of its efforts to woo Taiwanese people and build up interpersonal connections and social networks in Taiwan to promote its ultimate goal of unification, Tsai Teh-sheng responded: "It probably is."
Chinese procurement missions inevitably carry primary and secondary missions, the intelligence chief added.
The NSB director refrained, however, from making a direct response to Tsai Hung- liang's question about whether China's dispatch of purchase missions was mainly for unification promotion.
He instead said the bureau has already alerted President Ma Ying-jeou about China's ulterior purposes behind its seemingly commercially motivated deals.
Meanwhile, Tsai was quoted as having revealed at the meeting that the number of Chinese missiles targeting Taiwan has risen to 1,410 from 1,328 recorded during the previous DPP administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Free movies in Taipei County starting Friday

TEXT.P: The second annual "Movies Under the Stars" festival is set to make its debut starting this Friday, the Taipei County Government announced on Wednesday, inviting the public to enjoy six films from the U.S., Japan and Taiwan completely free of charge at a park in Banciao from Oct 22 to the 27.

The six films include two Hollywood movies: "Confession of a Shopaholic," a romantic comedy starring Isla Fisher and Hugh Dancy as well as the teenage blockbuster "The Sisterhood of Traveling Pants 2" with Blake Lively and America Ferrera.

Although these two young actors are not yet household names in Taiwan, many festival goers might recognize their faces because of Lively's role in the popular television series "Gossip Girls" and Ferreira's award-winning portrayal of a fashionably-awkward secretary in "Ugly Betty."

Also showing at the make-shift outdoor theater are two Taiwanese films: the black comedy "Mr. Bedman" about a quirky love triangle of an over-imaginative mattress salesman, and "Close to You" depicting the stories of two boxers with differing motivations.
Those who liked Sandra Bullock's laugh-out-loud movie "Miss Congeniality" might want to check out "Beauty on Duty, " a Hong Kong remake of the Hollywood original.

The only Japanese movie to be showcased in the six-day event is "Tokyo Sonata," a tear-jerker about a father who struggles to come to grip with the fact that he has been laid off. The movie has been lauded for telling the tales of many Japanese men who have to conceal their joblessness from their families in order not to lose face in front of their loved ones.

All the movies will be shown at the Wangping Metropolis Park located close to the Banciao MRT Station. Organizers said the event will be held irrespective of the weather; in the case of light rain, tents and plastic chairs will be set up for the audience. (By Jenny W. Hsu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Former U.S. President Clinton to visit Taiwan in November (update)

TEXT.P: Former U.S. President Bill Clinton will visit Taiwan in mid-November, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official confirmed Wednesday.
The former president is scheduled to deliver a speech in Taipei Nov. 14 as part of an invitational tour of Asia, organized by a Singaporean firm, MOFA spokesman James Chang said.

Clinton, who was U.S. president from 1993 to 2001, will arrive in Taiwan for a private business trip, Chang said, but the foreign ministry will provide necessary assistance and security during his stay based on a request made by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , the U.S. representative office in the absence of official bilateral ties.

Chang said that he was not aware of the details of the tour and declined to comment on whether Clinton, husband of U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, will meet with President Ma Ying-jeou or other Taiwanese officials.

The ex-president will share with the audience his views on Taiwan's economic development and preview the country's economic outlook beyond 2010 in a topical speech, to be delivered at Taipei International Convention Center, the organizer UNI Strategic (Taiwan) Ltd., a subsidiary of the Singapore-based Universal Network Intelligence, said in a press release late Wednesday.

A moderated question and answer session will be conducted after the speech, the organizer said, adding that 10 percent of the total proceeds of the event will be donated to the Clinton Foundation, which was established by the former president to tackle issues including fighting AIDS, climate change and promoting democracy throughout the world.
Members of the public will be charged between NT$1,800 and NT$12,000 to listen to the speech.

It will be Clinton's sixth visit to Taiwan and his first since February 2005, when he first came to Taiwan after stepping down as president. He met with then President Chen Shui-bian and then chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Lien Chan during a 22-hour whirlwind tour, which was sponsored by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy.
Clinton also visited Taiwan four times when he was Governor of Arkansas from 1979 to 1981 and from 1983 to 1992.
The AIT declined to comment on the upcoming visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Green technologies to showcase in Taipei

TEXT.P: Companies from Taiwan, the United States and Europe will showcase the results of their research into green technologies at an exhibition in Taipei next week.

The Taiwan International Green Industry Show (TiGiS), now in its second year, will be held Oct. 25-28 with a total of 180 companies occupying some 320 booths -- increases of 20 percent and 19 percent respectively.

Taiwan's industry "has evolved over the past decade to meet soaring global demand for green technology and alternative energies," the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , co-host of the event, said in a statement.

In terms of its green technology capability, Taiwan ranks sixth globally and second in Asia, behind Japan, according to a survey released by the Lausanne- based Institute for Management Development in July.
Taiwan is already one of the world's top producers of energy-saving light- emitting diode (LED) lights, according to the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
One of the green products to be featured at the show is an LED street lamp that relies on solar energy for power during daytime and wind power during nighttime or when it rains, the organizers said.
The organizers will also erect a two-story building using green construction materials and technology applications, which is a warm-up event for next years show that will focus on green buildings.

The Conference of the Electric Power Supply Industry (CEPSI) , which will be attended by power companies in the Asia Pacific region, and the Taiwan International Photovoltaic Forum and Exhibition (PV Taiwan), the largest of its kind in Asia, will be held in conjunction with TiGiS during the same period.
These three shows altogether are expected to attract more than 30,000 specialists from 53 countries, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese Go prodigy continues to hold triple titles
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 23:53:03 (By Mike Chang and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese Go player Hsieh Yi-min defended the Honinbo title Wednesday with a 3-0 victory over Chiaki Mukai in Tokyo, thereby retaining her status as the only triple-title holding female in the sport in Japan.
The 20-year-old also became the second female player to win the title for four years in a row in the best-of-five series.
"I am exhausted after the game. But I am glad to have defended the
title and will soon inform my family of the good news by phone, " Hsieh said at a post-game interview.
Hsieh added that she was now focusing on preparation for the Asian Games that will be held Nov. 12-27 in Guangzhou, China. Hsieh is a member of Taiwan's national team for the games.

As the holder of three titles -- a feat she achieved by winning the Kisei tournament on Jan. 28 this year after having also won the Meijin tournament since 2008 -- she is currently considered the top female Go player by the Japanese media.
Women and men compete in separate tournaments at Go.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dodgers reliever Kuo to return to Taiwan for vacation

TEXT.P: Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher Kuo Hong-chih, who is coming off the finest season of his Major League Baseball (MLB) career, is scheduled to return to Taiwan Thursday, the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association (CTBA) has announced.
Kuo will arrive in Taipei Thursday and attend an international baseball competition Saturday as a VIP, the CTBA said in a press release.

He will throw the first pitch of the opening game between Taiwan and South Korea Saturday in the 2010 Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament, which will be played at the Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium in the central Taiwanese city of Taichung, according to the CTBA.
The lefthander finished the 2010 season with three wins, two losses and 12 saves in 56 appearances and became the first Taiwanese player to earn a spot in the MLB mid-season All-Star Game.
Kuo, who had four surgeries on his elbow, also broke the Dodgers franchise record of the lowest ERA (earned run average), finishing the season with an ERA of 1.20. He struck out 73 in 60 innings.

Kuo will enjoy a competition-free off season in Taiwan after the Dodgers rejected the CPBL's request to include the 29-year-old in the Taiwan national team roster for the upcoming Asian Games, which will be held in Guangzhou, China from Nov. 12-27.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's procurement deals aim to promote unification: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/10 22:26:54 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China has sent 62 procurement missions to Taiwan since May 2008, signing letters of intent to purchase US$16.2 billion worth of locally made products, Taiwan's intelligence chief said Wednesday.

This year alone, 14 Chinese procurement missions have visited Taiwan, National Security Bureau Director Tsai Teh-sheng said at a closed-door session of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Defense Committee.
Many of those deals have not yet been substantiated, however, and some of them would require a long period of time to complete delivery, Tsai said.

Grilled by opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Hung-liang on whether China's procurement contracts were part of its efforts to woo Taiwanese people and build up interpersonal connections and social networks in Taiwan to promote its ultimate goal of unification, Tsai Teh-sheng responded: "It probably is."
Chinese procurement missions inevitably carry primary and secondary missions, the intelligence chief added.
The NSB director refrained, however, from making a direct response to Tsai Hung- liang's question about whether China's dispatch of purchase missions was mainly for unification promotion.
He instead said the bureau has already alerted President Ma Ying-jeou about China's ulterior purposes behind its seemingly commercially motivated deals.
Meanwhile, Tsai was quoted as having revealed at the meeting that the number of Chinese missiles targeting Taiwan has risen to 1,410 from 1,328 recorded during the previous DPP administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: No serious oil spill found after the sinking: EPA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/21/10 00:28:33 ( By Lee Shien-feng and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: No evidence of serious oil pollution had been found following sinking Monday of the Panama-registered cargo ship Xin Yi off the coast of Miaoli in western Taiwan, an official from the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Wednesday.

Chen Lung-chu, section chief of the EPA's Department of Water Quality Protection, conjectured that as little as 10 percent of the vessel's 300 tons of heavy fuel oil might be found in the sea, for which he offered two explanations.

First, northeast monsoon winds might have helped 90 percent of the oil evaporate within 24 hours of sinking, and second, since the cement carrier's oil tanks were located in various parts of the ship, not all of them might have cracked open.
Three crewmen are still missing and one died when the cargo ship sailing from China to Brunei sank due to huge waves in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 21, or the 14th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Ferdinand Magellan, Portuguese navigator, and his expedition team are blown by storms into a strait that separates South America from Tierra del Fuego and other islands south of the continent and that also connects the southern Atlantic and Pacific oceans. The strait now bears his name.
1727: The Ching court and Russia sign a new border treaty at the trading town of Kiakhta in Outer Mongolia.
1833: Alfred Nobel, Swedish industrialist and chemist who invented dynamite, is born. He founded the Nobel Prize to award to the world's leading scientists, artists and peacemakers.
1879: Thomas Alva Edison, U.S. inventor, successfully tests an electric incandescent lamp with a carbonized filament at his New Jersey laboratory.
1934: Government troops capture Juichin, the Chinese communist's capital in Kiangsi. The main force of rebels is wiped out and the remaining ones flee to the northwest.
1938: Japanese troops finally capture the Chinese city of Canton after months of bombing.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government, and Madame Chiang arrive in Taiwan for the first time for an inspection tour.
1950: Communist Chinese forces begin their occupation of Tibet.
1952: The first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference opens in Taipei.
1953: The first Overseas Chinese Day is celebrated in Taipei.
1954: The United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France agree to end the Allied occupation of Germany.
1958: John Foster Dulles, U.S. secretary of state, arrives in Taipei for a visit. He pursued a policy of opposing the USSR largely through economic and military aid to U.S. allies.
1960: Queen Elizabeth II launches the HMS Dreadnought, Britain's first nuclear submarine.
1960: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Mali.
1964: Yang Chuan-kuang, the ROC decathlon champion who won the ROC's first Olympic silver medal in 1960, announces his retirement after winning fifth place at the Tokyo Olympics.
1973: The fifth general meeting of the Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations opens in Taipei with more than 400 delegates from 50 countries and areas participating.
1975: The second naphtha cracking plant of the Chinese Petroleum Corporation begins production.
1976: Ding Mou-shih, director general of the Government Information Office, returns from a week's visit to the Republic of Korea.
1979: Israeli Prime Minister Moshe Dayan resigns over the government's refusal to negotiate with Palestinians.
1979: Willy Brandt is elected chancellor of West Germany.
1987: Ho Ying-chin, a Chinese general who received the formal surrender of Japanese forces in China from Gen. Okamura in Nanking on Sept. 9, 1945, dies at the age of 97.
1994: The United States and North Korea sign a landmark deal under which Pyongyang is to freeze and then dismantle its nuclear program.
1999: Far East Transport Corp. begins flight services between Taipei and Kota Kinabala in Malaysia.
2000: Chinese Taipei's Chiang Chih-chung breaks the world record in men's Class 12 javelin with a throw of 57.228 meters to capture Taiwan's first gold medal at the Sydney Paralympics.
2001: Asia-Pacific leaders pledge to prevent "all forms of terrorist acts" and to strengthen cooperation to catch those who carry out such crimes in a joint statement after ending a two-day informal leadership summit in Shanghai.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In another place in the Book of Song it is said, `His virtue is light as hair.' Still a hair is something material. `The workings of Almighty God have neither sound nor smell.' There is nothing higher than that."

DOC.HEADLINE: Weather bureau issues sea warning for Typhoon Megi
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 09:43:00 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea warning for Typhoon Megi early Thursday, calling on all maritime traffic south of Taiwan and in the Taiwan Strait to prepare for strong winds.

The bureau issued the warning at 2:30 a.m. as the typhoon entered waters south- southeastern of the Taiwan-held Dongsha Islands in the South China Sea at 2 a.m. and steadily headed northward toward the Dogsha Islands, the Bashi Channel and the Taiwan Strait, meteorologists said.
As of 8: 30 a.m., Megi was located 440 kilometers southwest of Eluanbi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, moving north-northwest at a speed of 10 km per hour, according to the latest weather report.
The storm packed maximum sustained winds of 173 kph with gusts of up to 209 kph, the report said.

With the typhoon approching, high waves have hit the Hengchun Peninsula at Taiwan's southern tip as well as the outlying island of Penghu and other southestern coastal regions. The weather bureau urged local people not to visit those areas for safety concerns.

The bureau also maintained its warning against torrential rain for northern, northeastern and eastern Taiwan after these regions experienced heavy rains in the past few days under the influence of Megi's outer rim and seasonal winds from the northeast.
Megi regained strength after wreaking havoc across the northern Philippines earlier this week, destroying thousands of homes and killing at least 15 people, according to foreign wire service reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Thursday from its previous close, moving up 10.95 points at 8,135.57 on a turnover of NT$3.095 billion (US$99.84 million).
The weighted price index rose 78.39 points, or 0.97 percent, to close at 8,124.62 Wednesday.

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$30.789 at 10:15 a.m. Thursday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.141 from Wednesday's close.
