DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Global money-printing competition

TEXT.P: With outstanding public debt hitting a record high and interest rates dropping to near zero, the United States is prepared to launch a new wave of "quantitative easing" programs to further increase the money supply. Many countries, meanwhile, are forced to join the money-printing competition to fight against the influx of hot money.

In Taiwan, central bank governor Perng Fai-nan has defended the government's efforts to intervene in the appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar to keep its exports competitive, citing recent criticism by Nobel Prize-winning economist Joseph Stiglitz who said the U.S. monetary policy is "causing chaos over the rest of the world."

Thanks to the central bank's intervention, the Taiwanese currency had risen by only 3.93 percent in value since the start of this year until Oct. 14. The level is lower than the 4.79 percent recorded by its main export competitor, South Korea, and other Asian countries other than China.

Stan Shih, founder of the world's second largest computer vendor Acer Inc., however, has warned that refusing to allow the New Taiwan dollar to appreciate, as other countries allow their currencies to rise, could hurt the purchasing power of local consumers.

In other words, when trying to protect Taiwan's export competitiveness, the central bank must also ensure that the interests of the people are upheld. No country is sure to win in this unprecedented money-printing competition, but a country is sure to lose if it does not act cautiously. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 21, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Dodgers reliever returns to Taiwan after great season
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 12:00:30 (By Chiu Chin-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Los Angeles Dodgers' Taiwanese pitcher Kuo Hong-chih returned to Taipei Thursday for a vacation after coming off the greatest season of his Major League Baseball (MLB) career.
Kuo was all smiles when he met reporters at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport. He said he was very happy with his performance in the just-concluded MLB season.
The lefthander started the 2010 season as a setup man but was installed as a closer in mid-August in place of the struggling Jonathan Braxton.
Asked if he is looking forward to becoming a closer in the coming season, Kuo said it would be great for him to remain healthy and pitch throughout the whole season.
On salary and contract issues, Kuo, who has four surgeries on his elbow, said it's up to negotiations between his agent and the Dodgers franchise.

Kuo will throw the first pitch of the opening game between Taiwan and South Korea Saturday in the 2010 Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament, which will be played at the Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium in the central city of Taichung.
The 29-year-old pitcher finished the 2010 season with three wins, two losses and 12 saves in 56 appearances and became the first Taiwanese player to earn a spot in the MLB mid-season All-Star Game.
He also secured the Dodgers record for lowest ERA of 1.20 based on a minimum of at least 50 innings pitched. He struck out 73 while yielding only 29 hits and 18 walks in 60 innings pitched.

It was his best season since first making the Dodgers roster in 2005. Aside from his record-setting ERA, his WHIP (walks and hits per inning pitched) was an astounding 0.78. Anything below 1 is considered outstanding.
Kuo has been nominated for the "Setup Man of the Year" award for 2010. He won the honor for the first time in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acer shares sharply higher on record operating profit in Q3
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 12:12:20 (By Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of personal computer vendor Acer Inc. rose sharply in Thursday morning trade as interest was triggered by the company's record high operating profit for the third quarter of this year, dealers said.
At 11: 21 a.m., Acer was up 2.36 percent at NT$82.40 (US$2.67) with 23.42 million shares changing hands, while the benchmark weighted index fell 0.15 percent to 8,112.05.
Acer reported Wednesday it posted NT$5.28 billion in operating profit for the July-September period, marking a quarterly record high, up 11 percent from a year earlier.

The company said the third quarter's operating margin also hit a record high at 3.16 percent. It was the first time that Acer's operating margin rose above 3 percent as it had stepped up effective measures to control marketing expenses.
In the third quarter, Acer's net profit totaled NT$4.29 billion, up from NT$3.47 billion a year earlier, the company said.
"Acer was still doing a good job in Europe by taking advantage of its lead in the particular market," MasterLink Securities analyst Tom Tang said.
"It seemed that the competition of Apple's iPad did not impose much impact on Acer's PC sales, " Tang said. "Investors felt relieved to some extent about the company's latest earnings report."
In the first nine months of this year, Acer posted NT$11.2 billion in net profit, up from NT$7.84 billion recorded a year ago, according to the company.

However, with competition in the global PC market getting fiercer than ever, Tang said he expects Acer's operating margin in the third quarter would fall, while the company did not disclose the figure.
In the third quarter of last year, Acer's operating margin stood at about 10 percent.

Boosted by the positive earnings news, the company's stock has overcome the strong technical resistance at around NT$81.00, while the breakthrough was also because it had consolidated for some time to digest pressure, according to Tang.
"But Acer is moving closer to the new technical barriers at about NT$85.00. There is limited room for upside and investors had better trade the stock cautiously," Tang said.
He said the market is waiting for the guidance the company will give in its investor conference scheduled for Oct. 29 to paint a clearer picture about the outlook for the fourth quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Panama president arrives in Taiwan for state visit

TEXT.P: Panama President Ricardo Martinelli arrived in Taiwan Thursday for a three-day state visit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said in a press release.
Martinelli is the first president from Panama to visit Taiwan in six years, according to the MOFA.

The 58-year-old president is leading a high-ranking delegation which also includes vice president Juan Carlos Varela, who also serves as the Central American country's foreign minister, and Deputy Minister of Commerce and Industries Jose Domingo Arias.

The delegation is scheduled to meet President Ma Ying-jeou, Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan and other government officials, as well as local businessmen, the MOFA said.
It added that the delegation will also visit the Taipei International Flora Exposition, which will officially open in early November, and Nangang Software Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Cross-strait investment protection

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China are currently negotiating an investment pact that is likely to be signed at the end of this year.

For Taiwan, the goal of signing the agreement should be to obtain greater protection for China-based Taiwanese businesses than that provided under China's existing investment protection law. Issues that need to be addressed urgently include compensation for land acquisition, strengthening the protection of investors' physical safety, setting up an arbitration mechanism between investors and the government, and expanding the protection to cover investments in the contract, franchise and intellectual property rights sectors.

For China, its main objective is probably pushing for further liberalization of existing restrictions on Chinese investment in Taiwan. Although Taiwan is obviously reluctant to link the issue with the investment protection pact, it needs to prepare properly to deal with the situation.

At present, there is not a law in Taiwan that governs the govenrment's obligations to implement investment protection agreements. It is equally urgent for the country to set up a related system. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 21, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County chief arrives in India
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 13:27:43 (By He Hung-ju and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The magistrate of central Taiwan's Changhua County Cho Po-yuan arrived in New Delhi Thursday for a visit to seek business cooperation opportunities between Taiwan and India.

Right after his arriving, Cho told the Central News Agency that India, one of the booming economies of the world, is an emerging country as well as a huge market with a population of 1.18 billion people, the second largest in the world, with great potential for growth.
He said further enhancement of bilateral economic ties is expected to deliver mutual benefits to Taiwan and India.

Cho, who led a delegation to promote Changhua County's products and investment environment, is scheduled to participate in the Global Investors Summit to be held in Khajuraho in the state of Madhya Paradesh on Friday and Saturday.
He will meet with Shri Shivraj Singh Chouhan, Chief Minister of Madhya Paradesh on Oct. 22 to push for future cooperation between Changhua and the Indian state.
Meanwhile, Cho will invite the chief minister to visit Taiwan, as part of Changhua's efforts to strengthen relationships between Taiwan and India through such city-to-city exchanges.
"We aim to boost Changhua's international visibility and also allow the county to have a better understanding of the world, " Cho said.
Cho's delegation will visit the state's Indian business representatives from the agriculture, food processing, bicycle manufacturing and machinery sectors.

The magistrate will also visit Taiwan's Economic and Culture Center in New Delhi, India's Ministry of External Affairs and the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry as well as Taiwan-based Delta Electronics' Indian branch on Oct. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan on alert as Typhoon Megi approaches

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central government has mobilized 31,610 soldiers nationwide to be on alert as Typhoon Megi moves near the island on its way to China, the Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC) said Thursday.
The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) has earlier issued a sea warning and projected Megi will be the closest to Taiwan in the next 48 hours.
As of 11: 30 a.m., Megi was located 430 kilometers southwest of Eluanbi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, moving north-northwest at a speed of 10 km per hour, according to the latest report.
The storm packed maximum sustained winds of 173 kph with gusts of up to 209 kph, the report said.
The central government has been taking precautions especially in northeastern and southern Taiwan, having 10,744 and 8,343 troops on alert, respectively, according to the emergency operation center.

The center forecast that in the next 48 hours, accumulated rainfall caused by Megi can reach 250-500 millimeters in the Taipei area, 400-600 millimeters in the nearby Yilan area, 300-500 millimeters in southern Taiwan's Hualien area, and 200-400 millimeters in eastern Taiwan's Taitung area.
Mountainous area of northeastern Taiwan, however, could experience heavier rain ranging from 600-1,000 millimeters, said the center.
Meanwhile, the Council of Agriculture has also issued warnings about a high possibility of creeks overflowing and landslides occurring in Tatung township of northeastern Taiwan's Yilan County.

Ferry service and other maritime traffic between Pingtung county's Donggang township and Liuqiu island has been suspended after 8 a.m. Thursday as high waves hit the Hengchun Peninsula at Taiwan's southern tip.

The CWB also maintained its warning against torrential rain for northern, northeastern and eastern Taiwan after these regions experienced heavy rain in the past few days under the influence of Megi's outer rim and seasonal winds from the northeast.

Typhoon Megi left at least 19 people dead in the Philippines earlier in the week, according to foreign wire service reports. It has weakened as it moves closer to the southern coast of China and is expected to make landfall near China's Shantou city, Guangdong province on Oct. 23.

Megi was the strongest typhoon in recent years to hit the Philippines, where it is estimated to have caused more than US$100 million in damages to infrastructure, agriculture, fisheries and schools, foreign wirse service reports said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close little changed

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed little changed Thursday amid cautious sentiment before bellwether electronics makers report their third-quarter earnings later this month, dealers said.
The weighted index gained 6.61 points or 0.08 percent to 8,131.23, after moving between 8,109.79 and 8,171.49, on turnover of NT$120.48 billion (US$3.91 billion).

The market opened up 0.13 percent and moved in a narrow range throughout trading as pressure focused on select high-tech firms on outlook concerns, while buying in old-economy stocks prevented the broader market from suffering losses, dealers said.
A total of 1,894 stocks closed up, 1,950 fell and 336 remained unchanged.

The textile sector scored the highest gain, up 3.48 percent. Paper and pulp stocks rose 1.69 percent, cement firms added 1.1 percent, plastics and chemical stocks gained 0.97 percent, foodstuffs closed up 0.25 percent, and the construction sector rose 0.18 percent.
Losers included the machinery and electronics sector, down 0.22 percent, and the financial sector, which lost 0.31 percent.
"Unless investors gather more information about the high-tech sector's fundamentals, they remain reluctant to add electronics holdings," Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said.

Hsu said the market is watching closely how electronics heavyweights, such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) and flat panel maker AU Optronics, would report their third-quarter earnings and give guidance for the fourth quarter.
After a technical rebound staged on Wednesday, the local bourse had fallen into consolidation ahead of stiff technical resistance at around the 8,200 point, Hsu said.
"Without a strong electronics sector, it is unlikely that the index will jump over the hurdle," he said.
Among large-cap high-tech firms, TSMC, the world's largest contract chip maker, closed unchanged at NT$61.00, while AU Optronics fell 2.68 percent to NT$29.10.
In the textile sector, Far Eastern New Century rose 3.75 percent to NT$47.00 and Shinkong Synthetic Fiber added 6.98 percent to NT$16.10 amid optimism toward their business ties with China.
endite/MH

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan donates funds to UK-based conservation group

TEXT.P: Taiwan's forestry bureau made a donation of US$45,000 Wednesday to a UK-based bird-conservation group to help fund its projects protecting forests and birds in Asia and the Americas.
Taiwan's contribution was presented to Bird Life International's chief executive Marco Lambertini by Katharine S.Y. Chang, the country's representative to the UK.

The donation would be used to assist the organization's projects for endangered- bird conservation in Sao Tome and Principe, and Brazil, and to help protect forests in northwestern Cambodia, said the group.
Taiwan's interests in bird species and the diversity of related research were impressive, Lambertini said at the Taipei Representative Office in the U.K.
He expressed gratitude for Taiwan's long-term support of the organization, and hoped to have the opportunity to tell people about Taiwan's efforts and contributions.
Taiwan has more than 500 bird species, Chang noted, so the country completely understands the importance of environmental protection and bird conservation. (By Jennifer Huang and C.Y. Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: Energy-saving LED street lamps light up on Kinmen

TEXT.P: A new system of LED street lamps has gone into operation on Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen as part of the county's low carbon energy-saving efforts.

Sixty-nine automated LED lamps were installed on a section of the island's Huandao East Road, replacing the previous sodium and mercury street lamps, after the county government was awarded a grant by the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Bureau of Energy to finance the plan, county government officials said as the lights were switched on Wednesday.
It is a pilot program for the use of LED technology, which will be expanded island-wide by 2014 in a project that is estimated to cost NT$365 million (US$11.87 million).

According to the county government, the system is linked to the Central Weather Bureau, making it able to adjust to changes in the length of daylight hours. It can also collect and analyze data to report when lamps are broken or malfunctioning, thereby improving efficiency and saving energy.
Kinmen was chosen as one of six low-carbon areas designated by the Council of Economic Planning and Development as part of a government energy-saving and carbon reduction program.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH denies introduction of presbyopia treatment this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 17:27:46 (By Ching-fang Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) categorically denied media reports Thursday that it had approved the import of laser equipment to correct presbyopia and that clinical trials were expected to begin in Taiwan by December.
Shih Chung-liang, director of the DOH's Bureau of Medical Affairs, said he had not signed any document approving the import of laser vision-correction machines for the treatment of presbyopia.
If no such equipment was being imported, how could clinical trials begin in December, Shih asked.

Similarly, Pei-weng Tu, a senior specialist with the DOH's Food and Drug Administration, said that no individual or company had filed an application permit for laser vision- correction equipment for treatment of the condition.
Moreover, no existing laser vision-correction equipment in use in Taiwan had added a function for treatment of presbyopia, Tu said.

Their comments came in response to a foreign wire-service report Wednesday that laser surgery, presently used for treatment of short- sightedness, was being tested as a cure for presbyopia, a long- sightedness that develops with age. If successful, it could dramatically reduce the need for reading glasses.
Findings of the latest research, from three laboratories in Europe and the United States, would be presented at the American Academy of Ophthalmology's annual conference this week, the report stated.

There is, however, one type of laser vision-correction equipment that can be used to treat presbyopia if its computerized operational program is modified, said a Taipei-based ophthalmologist who declined to give his name.
He said that many medical centers around Taiwan have planned to purchase presbyopia-treatment laser equipment.

"Given Taiwan's increasingly graying society, the number of patients who would pay to have their presbyopia treated far exceeds the number paying for laser correction of short-sightedness, " the ophthalmologist said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dengue fever command center established

TEXT.P: A central epidemic command center was established Thursday in a bid to curb an outbreak of dengue fever in southern regions of Taiwan after more than 600 indigenous cases were reported since August, the Department of Health (DOH) said that day.

According to the two commanders-in-chief -- DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang and Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen -- the preliminary goals of the center are to encourage the public to get rid of containers of standing water in which the dengue-carrying mosquitoes breed and to eradicate other possible breeding sites.

According to the number of households and residents in a community, an estimate of the number of containers in the community can be calculated, said Shih Wen- yi, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC).
Shih added that it is important to stop the spread of dengue fever before the seasonal drop in temperature, or else the disease will be more difficult to combat.

To enhance cooperation between the central and local governments, two southern command centers were set up simultaneously in Kaohsiung and Tainan in a ceremony attended by Shih and Lai Chien-jung, an official from the EPA's southern division. Shih had traveled south the previous day to get a better understanding of the local situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Thursday, shedding NT$0.061 to close at NT$30.869.
Turnover totaled US$672 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$30.930 and moved to a low of NT$30.630 before rebounding.
The U.S. dollar became weaker across Asian markets after an upside seen in recent trading sessions, and trading of the greenback to the New Taiwan dollar followed suit, dealers said.
They said foreign banks rushed to cut their U.S. holdings right after the local foreign exchange market opened, pocketing the gains posted over the past few days.

Market sentiment toward the U.S. has become very cautious prior to a gathering of finance ministers and central bank governors from the Group of 20 nations in South Korea Friday and Saturday, the dealers said.
They said investors are watching closely to see what of comments these financial mandarins make about the global currency market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Game 4 of Taiwan Series rained out again

TEXT.P: Game 4 of the Taiwan Series between the Brother Elephants and Sinon Bulls scheduled for Thursday in Sinjhuang City, Taipei County, was postponed due to heavy rain, according to Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL).

The potential series clincher, originally scheduled to be played Wednesday, had been rescheduled for Thursday in Sinjhuang. The Elephants are seeking to complete a sweep of the Bulls in the best-of-seven series and thereby win the seventh CPBL title in the team's history.
American Jim Magrane, winning pitcher of Game 1 of the series, will start for the Elephants, while Dominican left-hander Juan Pena will take the mound for the Bulls.
Games 5, 6 and 7 would be played in Taoyuan County Sunday and Kaohsiung County Monday and Tuesday if necessary, announced the CPBL.

DOC.HEADLINE: French brokerage maintains `buy' recommendation on Acer
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 18:16:57 (By Jeff Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: French brokerage BNP Paribas said Thursday that it was maintaining a "buy" recommendation on Acer Inc. after the personal computer vendor reported higher- than-expected operating profit for the third quarter of this year.
The brokerage reiterated a target price of NT$92.00 (US$2.98) for Acer.
A day earlier, Acer announced it posted NT$5.28 billion in operating profit for the July-September period, marking a quarterly record high and up 11 percent from a year earlier.
The company said its net profit during the same period totaled NT$4.29 billion, up from NT$3.47 billion a year earlier, on sales of NT$167.2 billion.
In a research note, BNP Paribas said it expects Acer's sales for the fourth quarter to grow 5 percent from the third quarter, with shipments of notebooks expected to grow at a similar magnitude.

The brokerage also said that Acer's cooperation with the Founder Group, a Chinese counterpart, which has become effective in mid-October, will contribute about NT$500 million, or 3 percent of Acer's sales, in the fourth quarter.
Looking ahead, the ties with Founder could generate NT$600-NT$700 million in sales, representing a contribution of 3 percent to 3.5 percent of Acer's total sales contribution every quarter.

The deal allows Acer to take advantage of Founder's comprehensive distribution network to sell Acer products in tier 4-6 Chinese cities -- which have populations of less than 20,000 -- and rural areas, while targeting corporate and government clients.
Founder is also working with Acer to design and develop Founder-branded products, including notebooks, netbooks and mobile Internet devices such as e-readers.
BNP Paribas said it expects that "Acer's operating margin will continue to grow but is unsure whether it will be able to reach 3.5 percent by the year-end."
In the third quarter, Acer's operating margin stood at 3.16 percent, hitting a quarterly record high on successful efforts to control marketing costs, according to the company.
The brokerage said it "remains positive" about Acer's market share gain, in particular in China, as well as the prospects for its tablet computer business.
Acer closed up 3.11 percent at NT$83.00 on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Higher poverty line to help disadvantaged families: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 18:34:47 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The government's efforts to relax the eligibility requirements for public assistance, including raising the poverty line, highlight its resolve to help disadvantaged families, Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said Thursday.
Jiang was reporting to the Legislative Yuan's Social Welfare, Environment and Health Committee, which had convened to review proposed amendments to the Public Assistance Act.

At present, public assistance is mainly available to low-income households, defined as those whose total income divided by the number of individual members is lower than the minimum cost of living, or poverty line, which varies from region to region in the country.
The minimum cost of living is currently calculated as 60 percent of the annual consumption expenditure per capita for the latest year.
According to a proposal put forward by the Ministry of the Interior, the formula would be changed to 60 percent of median monthly disposable income per capita.
Jiang explained that the new formula would ensure that assistance was available to more disadvantaged families.

In addition, the bill expanded coverage of assistance to include lower-middle- income households whose total income divided by the number of individual members was less than 1.5 times the minimum cost of living, Jiang said.
This group of families would receive government subsidies for National Health Insurance premiums and tuition fees, he said.
The bill also relaxed other criteria for determining eligibility for public assistance, such as who should be considered as members of a single household.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese golfer inducted into Asia-Pacific Golf Hall of Fame
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 18:48:02 (By Namita Lin and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese former golfer Lu Liang-huan was inducted into the Asia-Pacific Golf Hall of Fame during a golf summit in Bangkok, Thailand Wednesday, for his achievements on the course.

The 73-year-old, known as "Mr. Lu" due to his elegance and demeanor, was honored along with Thai golfer Boonhcu Ruangkit, American legend Jack Nicklaus, South Africa's Gary Player, former world number one Greg Norman of Australia and Swede Annika Sorenstam.

" (Taiwan) should develop its golf and train more young players so that they can compete around the world. Now, we have some very good ones such as Yani Tseng, " said Lu, who rose to global fame when he finished runner-up to Lee Trevino by just one stroke at the British Open in 1971.
Tseng, 21, won the Ricoh Women's British Open in August.

Born into a poor family, Lu began working at a golf course after elementary school, which sparked his interest in the game. Bamboo sticks and little guavas used to be his substitutes for real clubs and balls, said Lu, one of Taiwan's earliest globally recognized professional golfers.
After years of working as a caddie at a course near Taipei, Lu learned how to play, and took three "Caddie Cup" victories in a row.

Lu, who was happy to meet some old friends at the summit, is considered Taiwan's best ambassador of golf through his exchanges with players from other countries during his professional career between the late 1950s and the 1980s.

DOC.HEADLINE: Major video game piracy ring busted
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 19:00:03 (By Sunrise Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A cross-Taiwan Strait video game piracy ring, the largest of its kind in history, was broken recently, the Intellectual Property Rights Police Team (IPRPT) reported Thursday.
Officers of the IPRPT under the National Police Agency raided a warehouse in Sanchong City, Taipei County Sept. 27, arresting four suspects and thousands of pirated copies of video game discs.
The games, totaling 140,000 discs for PS2, Wii and X-Box, had a total street value of some NT$260 million (US$8.39 million), the IPR police said.
"Nearly all of the pirated disc inventory in Taiwan was busted in that operation," said an IPRPT official.
"There must be a shortage on the market now, " he said.

According to the IPRPT, the four suspects, surnamed Chou, Wang, Wu and Liu, had shuttled between Taipei and China's Guangzhou, where the factory forging the discs is located, took delivery of shipments at the airport, or played the part of customers by placing orders with stores for games, which the ring itself would then supply, to make transaction records appear legitimate.
It took the IPR police nearly seven months to trace the ring after game developers or game owners tipped them off about the counterfeits.
However, the police said that the only way to root out piracy once and for all is to eradicate the source -- the factories in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Absentee voting will not apply to overseas citizens
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 19:08:49 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's absentee-voting system, set for introduction in 2012, will exclude citizens living overseas, Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said Thursday.

For such people to become eligible for absentee votes, the Constitution would need amending, Jiang explained, since it currently requires overseas citizens to return to Taiwan to cast their votes in elections.
Certain technical problems would also need to be overcome with regard to postal or online voting, he added.

Under Ministry of the Interior proposals, absentee voting will be implemented for the first time in Taiwan during the 2012 presidential election, allowing people not resident in their hometowns to apply to vote at a more convenient polling station.
To reduce the chance of vote-rigging, the ministry decided not to adopt postal or online voting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Largan Precision expects sales to grow in Q4
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 19:29:36 (By Han Ting-ting and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Largan Precision Co. Ltd., the world's largest cell phone camera lens maker, said Thursday that it expects sales in the fourth quarter of this year to continue to grow on rising global demand for smartphones.
Largan Chairman Chen Shih-ching said the company will see its sales hit a monthly high in December for this year, with the China market expected to contribute a solid increase in revenue.

The company announced during an investor conference that its sales totaled NT$3.48 billion (US$113 million) in the third quarter, up 24.19 percent from the second quarter and up 42.11 percent from a year earlier.
During the same period, its net profit reached NT$1.24 billion with earnings per share at NT$9.5, which was within market expectations.
The company's gross margin stood at 47.11 percent in the July-September period, slightly down from 47.21 percent from the second quarter.

However, Chen said that despite the expected sales growth in the fourth quarter, the gross margin is expected to continue to fall due to higher purchasing costs in voice coil motors (VCMs) , one of the components of cell phone cameras, and the impact of a rising New Taiwan dollar.
According to the company, its gross margin is expected to drop 1 percentage point-1.5 percentage points whenever the U.S. dollar falls NT$1 against the local currency.
Since the beginning of September, the greenback has fallen 3.84 percent, or NT$1.233, against the New Taiwan dollar.
Meanwhile, Chen said, 5-8 megapixel lenses accounted for more than 50 percent of the company's total sales in the third quarter, adding that the ratio is expected to rise in the fourth quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Export orders, overseas production hit new highs

TEXT.P: Taiwanese manufacturers received a total of US$35.98 billion in export orders in September, a single-month high, but the ratio of overseas production also hit a record 50.93 percent during the month, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Wednesday.

Huang Chi-shih, director-general of the MOEA's Statistics Department, said the high overseas production ratio has led to a scenario in which the growing export orders are contributing little to improvements in joblessness and wages at home.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Liberty Times:
September's export orders marked a year-on-year increase of 16.68 percent, or US$5.14 billion in value, according to MOEA statistics.

Huang optimistically forecast that accumulated export orders for this year could reach US$410 billion, exceeding the average annual level of US$350 billion posted before the 2008-2009 global financial crisis.

Nevertheless, market analysts said the growth in export orders will mainly benefit only business owners or shareholders because the overseas production ratio has continued to rise and has already hit an all-time high of 50.93 percent.
Increasingly prevalent overseas production will also hinder growth in domestic job opportunities and wage hikes, the analysts said.

In September, information and communication technology products accounted for the lion's share of export orders received in the month, totaling US$9.4 billion and representing a 22.17 percent hike from the year-earlier level.

Export orders from the United States, Europe and the Association of Southeast Asia Nations all set new single-month records in September, amounting to US$7.71 billion, US$6.97 billion and US$3.44 billion, respectively.
Orders from Japan also reached US$4.24 billion in September, the second-highest amount in history. (Oct. 21, 2010).
United Daily News:
Huang attributed September's remarkable growth in export orders mainly to a relatively smaller rise in the value of the New Taiwan dollar during the first nine months of the year.

In the January-September period, the currency appreciated 3.5 percent against the U.S. greenback, compared to a 12.7 percent rise in the value of the Japanese yen and a 13.4 percent appreciation of the euro.
As a result, orders from Japan and the euro-zone have spiked significantly during the period.
However, with economic recovery slowing down in the United States and the euro- zone, Huang said, export orders for local manufacturers might show a decline in October. (Oct. 21, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, EU discuss design patents

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the European Union shared experiences of design protection at a seminar in Taipei, the organizers said Thursday.

Legal frameworks and design patents were the main themes covered at the event, held jointly by Taiwan's Intellectual Property Office (IPO), the European Economic and Trade Office (EETO), and the Taiwan Design Center (TDC).
"Design is the outward appearance of a product. But such a design has its value to the product," said Guy Ledoux, head of the EETO, the European Commission's permanent presence in Taiwan.
In the EU, he noted, design protection was regulated both at EU level and national level, meaning that designs had equal right to protection in all member states.
Taiwanese design firms would do well to strengthen their understanding of such legal systems and patent rights, said TDC Chief Executive Tony Chang.
"The better a design is, the more it should be protected," he said.

Taiwan's expanding role in global design is evidenced by the increase in local designs winning recognition at the four major annual international design awards, which had increased from 16 in 2003 to 260 this year, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: President should demand AP report correction: scholar

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou is right to demand that The Associate Press (AP) correct a report claiming that during a recent interview, he hinted at a possible timing for sensitive political talks with Beijing or tied such talks to his bid for re- election in 2012, according to a local political scientist.

Yang Yung-ming, a political science professor at National Taiwan University, wrote in an article carried on the op-ed page of the United Daily News Thursday that it is understandable that Ma has insisted on a correction of its report on the interview conducted at the Presidential Office earlier in the week.

"As cross-Taiwan Strait political talks involve numerous complicated issues and contain political tricks or traps, they should be tackled with great caution and require meticulous preparations. Setting any timetable for such a task would be inappropriate and dangerous, and no sensible Taiwanese political leader should ever do such a thing," Yang wrote.

After poring over the lengthy transcription of the interview recording, Yang wrote, it seems that the AP interviewer already had preconceived notions and tried hard to derive meaning from Ma's words that he could fit to his own views.

In the interview, Yang continued, the reporter repeatedly grilled Ma on whether he will move on to political talks with Beijing, should he be re-elected to a second term, once all economic issues have been dealt with.
Such an interviewing style is rarely adopted by major international news media, according to Yang.
"Most controversial was that the interviewer did not correctly report Ma's remarks and instead distorted them to fit his own opinions," he went on.

"Since the AP report said in its lead that Ma gave no timetable for when a political dialogue with China would start, it is self-contradictory that the report said later that Ma `suggested' that political talks could start as early as his second four-year term if he wins re-election in 2012."

The controversy has also shown how seriously AP distorted Ma's remarks, Yang wrote. The agency originally wrote that Ma had said in the interview that he is "ready" for a political dialogue with China, but changed the wording to read that Ma "is open to" such talks following Ma's protest.
In his article, Yang also questioned the wisdom of a suggestion that Ma should give interviews only in Chinese instead of English to avoid this kind of confusion.
"Such an idea is not appropriate because translation could lead to even more controversy, given the delicate and contentious nature of cross-strait issues," he wrote.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$700m required for private entities to build new airports: CAA

TEXT.P: Private entities will need to have at least NT$700 million (US$22 million) in capital if they want to construct and operate new airports in Taiwan, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Thursday.
The required capital will differ in accordance with the annual passenger capacities at the new airports, the CAA said as it passed a draft plan under the Civil Aviation Act.
For passenger throughput of over 10 million people per year, the minimum capital will be NT$46 billion, while for under 750,000 people, the minimum capital will be NT$700 million.
The application process will be subject to close scrutiny, since the project is a matter of public interest, said CAA Director-General Yin Chen-pong.
According to the plan, interested private enterprises will need to have been in operation for at least five years and to have a minimum annual operating revenue of NT$60 million.

In addition, more than half of the company's stocks will have to be owned by corporations or individuals holding Taiwanese citizenship, while no more than 25 percent of the shares should be owned by any single foreign individual.
The CAA in 2007 amended the Civil Aviation Act, allowing private entities to apply to construct and operate new airports. However, it lacked details such as the required capital amounts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan well-positioned to benefit from low-carbon economy: BTCO

TEXT.P: Taiwan is in good position to benefit from the transition to a low-carbon economy because of its highly educated population, technological expertise and leadership in the Asia-Pacific region, a visiting British official and the top British diplomat in Taiwan said Thursday.

The United Kingdom is keen to share its experience with Taiwan since both sides are expected to benefit from collaboration in the climate-change issue and in the green-energy sector, said David Campbell, director of the British Trade and Cultural Office in Taiwan (BTCO) , the de-facto embassy in the absence of official diplomatic ties, at a press briefing.

In terms of Taiwan's desire to participate in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) , Campbell said the European Union has always supported Taiwan's meaningful participation in international organizations, but that it will not be solely the U.K.'s decision.

The important question, however, is not just about participation in the UNFCCC, Campbell said. If Taiwan-- which accounts for about 1 percent of global emissions of climate-change gases -- carefully formulates and implements its energy policy, it will be able to transform into a low-carbon economy with reduced carbon emissions, and this would benefit the nation's employment, he continued.
The green-energy sector is one of few sectors able to maintain positive growth and create new jobs during the economic downturn, Campbell said.

Though the U.K. is a signatory to the Kyoto Protocol, it was not until the country decided to tackle the climate-change issue head-on with thorough reviews, dialogues, policy-making and legislation that things started to change, he said.

By 2012, U.K. emissions will be down 23.5 percent from their 1990 level, which will be a greater decrease than committed to in its Kyoto pledge, said Thomas Phipps, policy officer of the Climate Change and Energy Group under the U.K.'s Foreign and Commonwealth Office.

Phipps said he has seen positive signs and developments during his stay in Taiwan, where he met with Frances Liang, deputy minister of economic affairs, and Stephen Shen, minister of the Environmental Protection Administration. He also visited the Taiwan Power Co., the state-owned power-supply company.

"I feel like they wanted to know more about how to turn energy-intensive sectors into a part of low-carbon economy, " Phipps said of his hosts, adding that he also saw positive signs in the legislation and passage of Taiwan's Greenhouse Gas Reduction Act, because parts of the act are similar to the U.K.'s regulations.

It took the U.K. a decade to make significant progress in cutting carbon emissions, Phipps noted, but added that Taiwan could take much less time to achieve the same result by sharing the U.K.'s experience.

DOC.HEADLINE: Weather bureau issues land warning for Typhoon Megi

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning for Typhoon Megi Thursday after putting out a sea warning earlier in the day, and said the typhoon poses a strong threat to southern Taiwan and the outlying islands.
The bureau issued the warning at 5: 30 p.m. as Megi continued its northward track toward the Taiwan Strait at 10 kph, packing maximum sustained winds of 173 kph with gusts of up to 209 kph.

As of 5 p.m., Megi was centered 380 km west-southwest of Eluanbi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan. The bureau forecast that Megi would be located 220 km southwest of Taiwan's offshore Penghu County in 24 hours.
According to the reports, the areas most likely to be affected include southern Taiwan's Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Tainan areas, as well as the outlying islands of Penghu and Kinmen.
The CWB also warned residents in southwestern Taiwan to prepare for possible sea water intrusion, as the typhoon is coinciding with seasonal high tides.

According to foreign wire service reports, the death toll from Megi had risen to 27 in the Philippines. The typhoon is expected to make landfall Oct. 23 near Shantou City in China's Guangdong Province.
According to the reports, at least 160,000 people were evacuated in southern China Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait talks to include fishery issues
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 22:08:08 (By S. M. Yang, L.C. Su and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Fishery issues would be included in upcoming cross-strait talks as part of government efforts to protect Taiwan fishermen's rights and safety in the face of illegal and rampant intrusions by China's steel-hulled ships, Chen Wu-hsiung, minister of the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday.

"Relevant matters will be discussed at the upcoming seventh round of negotiations between the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), " Chen told the Legislative Yuan's Economics and Finance Committee.
Chen said he believed the situation could be brought increasingly under control as the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) had been working hard to that end.
"So far this year, the CGA has dispersed over 7,600 Chinese steel-hulled vessels that unlawfully entered Taiwan's waters, " he continued.

Lawmakers from both ruling and opposition parties were gravely concerned about the issue and demanded the government come up with more effective measures to safeguard Taiwanese fishing boats operating in the Taiwan Strait.

According to Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Lee Ching-hua, fishermen from Taipei County's Jinshan and Wanli townships had complained about their poor catches of crabs this year due to rampant harassment by Chinese ships.
"Crab prices have surged by 30 percent on the local market due to the tight supply," he said.

"China's steel-hulled boats are running amok in the Taiwan Strait, destroying Taiwan fishermen's crab-catching cages and poaching all resources, " Lee said, asking how the government had allowed the situation to deteriorate to this point.
CGA Minister Wang Ginn-wang admitted that illegal intrusions by these vessels were taking place and promised to raise the scale of measures taken to expel them from Taiwan's waters.

"Since September the CGA has sent more vessels to protect Taiwanese fishing boats operating in that area," he said, noting that "Chinese ships illegally trespassing on Taiwan's waters will be apprehended and dealt with in compliance with the law."

DOC.HEADLINE: `Green' night market key attraction at low-carbon expo
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 22:40:10 (By Hsu Chih-wei, Chao Hsiao-hui and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's night markets, part of the country's unique culture in which food takes center stage, can also be environmentally friendly, the organizers of an ecological expo said Thursday.
Night markets are on the "must visit" list for foreign tourists, particularly those from China.

A "low-carbon" night market on the sidelines of the ECO Taiwan Expo 2010 that opened in Taipei that day can provide the public with an opportunity to learn how to lead a low-carbon lifestyle in daily life, said Sisy Chen, a renowned TV talk show host and an adviser to the expo.

While showcasing local signature foods and products from various cities and counties, the low-carbon night market pushes the energy-saving and emission- cutting causes, said Wang Hsing-kai, chief organizer of the night market.

At the night market, which brings together 61 companies, the pork is sourced from a pig farm that raises its stock in high, dry pens that use much less water and electricity than traditional hog farms, with lower discharge of methane, according to Wang.
The food stand operators at the night market use groceries sourced from the Taipei area only to cut transport costs and time, he added.
Meanwhile, he noted, only biodegradable food containers and tableware are used, while consumers are also encouraged to bring their own chopsticks and spoons.

Addressing the opening of the ECO Taiwan Expo 2010, Chen Cheng-hsiung, chairman of the Taiwan Printed Circuit Association, the major sponsor of the expo, said the fair, featuring seven theme halls in seven areas, is designed to rekindle people's awareness of the degradation of the environment and to build up a habit of leading a low carbon lifestyle.

Another attraction at the expo is the offer of free rides in the Luxgen electric vehicle developed by a spin-off of Taiwanese veteran automaker Yulon Motor. The cars are touted by the company as "the world's first intelligent electric vehicles."
More than 200 companies, government agencies and institutions are taking part in the ECO Taiwan Expo, which is being held for the first time Oct. 21-23 at the Nankang Exhibition Center.

The expo features a new-generation smart grid that can help monitor how much electricity is being used in the home. The smart grid, if combined with the Internet and other systems, can help identify old home appliances that consume a significant amount of power and need to be replaced, the expo organizer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourists stranded on Suhua Highway due to landslides

TEXT.P: A total of 24 travel groups comprising 542 tourists were stranded following landslides on Taiwan's eastern Suhua Highway between the townships of Suao and Dongao late Thursday, according to tourism bureau officials.
The tourism bureau confirmed that 231 of the tourists, in 12 groups, are from China, with another group of 19 Chinese tourists unaccounted for.
A series of landslides occurred shortly after midday, interrupting the journey of the groups.

The Directorate General of Highways (DGH) said it had deployed manpower, heavy machinery and tools to clear the way for rescue efforts. Military personnel stationed in the area have been mobilized to provide assistance.
DGH Chief Secretary-General Mile N. Chen said the bureau was hopeful that the road could be cleared by Friday morning.

It is likely to take longer to repair some other damage, however. A section of the roadway, over 400 meters long, sank about 20 meters between the 115th and the 116th kilometers of the scenic coastal highway, according to the DGH.
Several of the tourists complained about what they described as snail-paced rescue efforts.
One tour leader who declined to give her name told reporters that her group of 34 travelers from China's Yunnan Province had been trapped since noon and were hungry and tired.

"I called the Yilan county government and related authorities until 2 p.m. but they said they could do nothing because of the bad weather, " she said. The best help they could offer was to "find a convenience store," she added.

The landslides were triggered by heavy rain, which has battered much of eastern Taiwan for the past few days, a result of the combined effects of Typhoon Megi's outer rim and seasonal winds from the northeast.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academia Sinica researchers selected fellows of world academic body
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 23:16:00 (By Lin Szu-yu & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Four fellows and a researcher with Academia Sinica have been elected fellows of the Academy of Sciences for the Developing World (TWAS), the country's highest research institute said Thursday.

Academia Sinica said the five, including Yao Meng-chao, director of it's Institute of Molecular Biology, were announced as 2010 TWAS fellows at its annual meeting a day earlier in the Indian city of Hyderabad.

"Being elected as TWAS fellows is recognition of not only the individual's academic achievements but also the support and assistance that Taiwan has offered to developing countries," Academia Sinica said.
Yao is famous for his research in gene amplification, DNA rearrangements and chromosome instability in eukary.

The other Taiwanese winners of the honor are Academia Sinica fellow Kenneth K. Wu, who is also president of the Taiwan National Health Research Institute and a noted specialist in the prevention of blood clotting. Paul Tseng-pu Ho is director of Academia Sinica's Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics and specializes in radio astronomy and spectrography.

C.Y. Cyrus Chu, fellow and also president of the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research, is a prestigious scholar in population economics, public economics and regional economics, while Ovid Tseng, a fellow and also a minister without portfolio, is an expert psychologist.
The other awarded researcher, Soo-Chen Cheng, also of Academia Sinica, is famous for her studies in the molecular mechanism of the pre-mRNA splicing reaction.
Founded in 1983 in Trieste, Italy with the aim of promoting scientific development in developing counties, TWAS has about 1,000 fellows from around 90 countries in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense Ministry: No plans to mothball Mirage fighters
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/21/10 23:27:55 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Thursday that it has no plans to mothball its French-made Mirage fighter jets at present.
The ministry was responding to a lawmaker's suggestion after he pointed out the problems and high maintenance costs related to the plane.

Legislator Lin Yu-fang of the ruling Kuomintang told a legislative committee earlier this week that during maintenance operations in May 2009, the engine rotors of the some of the fighters were found to have cracks, resulting in reduced flying hours.
In May this year, a Mirage fighter jet belonging to the French Air Force crashed in southwestern France, possibly due to the same engine fault, Lin said.
Wang Cheng-hsiao, chief of staff of the air force, said Thursday that after strenuous efforts, the flight readiness of the aircraft has been improved to 72 percent.
"In the interests of military investment, there is no plan to mothball the Mirage fighters," he said.
Taiwan purchased 60 Mirage-2000s fighter jets from France in 1992, the last batch of which was delivered in 2001. Fifty-six of the planes remain in service, with four having been lost in crashes.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4-year-old confirmed youngest case of dengue fever this year

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) has confirmed the youngest case of dengue hemorrhagic fever so far this year along with two other new cases in southern Taiwan.

CDC Deputy Director-General Lin Ting announced Thursday that a 4-year-old girl was confirmed as an indigenous dengue fever case on Oct. 18 and is being treated in intensive care. The child, from Kaohsiung, is the youngest patient to be diagnosed with dengue hemorrhagic fever this year.

A 69-year old man from Tainan City was unconscious and in intensive care, said Lin. The man, confirmed as a dengue fever case on Oct. 18, has a history of diabetes and high blood pressure. He developed symptoms on Oct. 12 and was reported to the CDC six days later.
The third confirmed case, an 8-year-old boy also from Tainan City, was in intensive care but conscious.
The three new cases bring the number of recorded indigenous cases to 658 since August, with 256 imported cases since the beginning of the year.
The CDC deputy director called on the public to increase their efforts in getting rid of breeding grounds of the dengue-carrying mosquito, particularly water containers after heavy rainfall.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's elderly see exercise as weapon against depression: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 23:41:14 (By Nancy Sha and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: More than 80 percent of senior citizens aged over 60 who responded to a recent survey agreed that exercise can help reduce stress and ease depression, according to the poll results released Thursday.
The John Tung Foundation, which has been dedicated to reducing depression among the public since 2000, said regular exercise is the most effective and cheapest way to fight depression.

The foundation conducted the survey between Sept. 1 and Oct. 14, collecting 10,309 valid replies regarding the relationship between mental health and exercise, and another 5,639 samples on the respondents' mental health.

While 83.7 percent of the grey-haired citizens show the strong support of the importance of exercise, more than 70 percent of which said they do up to 30-minute exercise three times per week, the survey found.

Some 68.6 percent of the respondents said exercise helps fight depression, but 26.3 percent said they have not done any sport for more than three months, compared to 50 percent who said they often do exercise to relieve stress.

The survey found around that 21.2 percent of the respondents were emotionally stable, while some 22.2 percent were relatively unstable, said Vivian Yeh, director of the foundation's metal health division.
The foundation found that 44.9 percent of the respondents were at breaking point, with 11.8 percent requiring professional help.
Among them, women suffer higher levels of depression than their male counterparts, the survey found.
Yeh noted that almost 80 percent of the workers in the service industry were under high levels of pressure and more than 30 percent of the jobless and students suffered from mental problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: Artificial reefs boost eastern Taiwan's fishery
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/10 23:41:42 (By Su-min Yang and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: An artificial reef off Taiwan's east coast has yielded a harvest of more than 230 metric tons so far this year, with value of the catch expected to grow further, the Fisheries Research Institute under the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday.

The catch, worth more than NT$20 million (US$650,000) in the first nine months of the year, was the result of a new reef floating 20-60 meters underwater off Taitung's Hsinkang Pier, the institute announced.
Offshore artificial reefs function similarly to ocean driftwood in attracting fish, the COA website explained.

The catch was particularly good in February and March, averaging more than 180 kilograms per ship per day and with top catches exceeding 400 kg, the institute reported. Even during the low season of June, the average haul of the 30 vessels was around 60 kg.
Use of the reefs also shortens the distances boats need to travel, it also noted, saving about 15 percent on fuel costs.

There are now six such facilities along the east coast, helping to increase the gross value of the east-coast fishing industry, the institute responsible for developing Taiwan's fishing-related technologies and research said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Endangered turtles sent to U.S. for new life
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/21/10 23:48:32 (By Leaf Jiang and Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: A total of 50 rare yellow- headed temple turtles arrived in the U.S. city of Atlanta Wednesday for new life through a cooperative effort by Eva Airways, the Taipei Zoo and the U.S.-based Turtle Survival Alliance, according to airline officials.
The Eva Airways flight carrying the turtles left Hong Kong Oct. 19 for Atlanta via Taipei.
The animals will be sent to the Turtle Survival Alliance, which will arrange for them to be distributed among various shelters around the country.
The officials said after being notified of the rescue mission through the zoo's Conservation and Research Center, the carrier agreed to help transport the 600-kg cargo for only a nominal fee.
The turtles were among a haul of 1,300 smuggled freshwater turtles that were seized by Hong Kong marine police in February.
The yellow-headed temple turtle, the largest freshwater turtle in Asia, is an endangered species.
Without the assistance of EVA Air, the turtles would have been destroyed in Hong Kong because their origin could not be identified, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 22, or the 15th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1721: Peter I, known as "Peter the Great," is proclaimed Emperor of all of Russia. He extended his territory around the Baltic and Caspian shores and reformed the administration of the state.
1835: Sam Houston, U.S. politician and general who fought in the Texan struggle for independence from Mexico, is sworn in as president of the Republic of Texas.
1873: The emperors of Russia, Germany and Austro-Hungary form an alliance.
1906: Paul Cezanne, French painter and leading post-impressionist figure, dies at the age of 67. His most famous paintings include "Mont Sainte-Victoire" and "The Card Players."
1909: Elise de Laroche, French aviator better known as Baronne de Laroche, becomes the first woman to fly solo.
1944: The Military Committee of the National government begins drafting young intellectuals for military service after Chairman Chiang Kai-shek on Sept. 14 urged 100,000 young men to enter the army.
1947: Pakistan and India begin a war over Kashmir.
1947: Japanese spy Yoshiko Kawajima is sentenced to death by a Chinese military court.
1950: Popular elections of magistrates are held in Taiwan Province, with Yang Chung-ching being elected chief of Hualien County and Chen Chen-chung being elected chief of Taitung County.
1951: A strong earthquake rocks Hualien, killing 43 people and destroying many houses.
1953: Laos gains independence from France.
1962: U.S. President John F. Kennedy makes his first major move in the showdown with the USSR over the building of ballistic missile sites in Cuba by announcing that Cuba will be placed under a naval "quarantine" -- a blockade -- until the Soviets remove the missiles.
1964: Jean-Paul Sartre, French writer, rejects the Nobel Prize for literature by saying it would reduce the impact of his writing.
1966: KGB master spy George Blake, who had spied for the Russians for 12 years and in 1962 had been sentenced to 42 years in prison, escapes from the maximum security wing of Wormwood Scrubs prison in west London.
1975: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and philosopher, dies at the age of 86. His "Study of History" explores patterns of growth and the decay of civilization.
1976: The 34,000-ton tanker Tsaineng (Talent) calls at Taichung port, becoming the first vessel to enter Taiwan's fourth international seaport.
1977: The first generator of the first nuclear power plant in Taiwan becomes operational.
1978: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea agree to exchange information on the development and preservation of energy resources at their 13th annual ministerial economic conference.
1986: Yeh Chien-ying, one of the senior leaders of Communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 89. With the support of Yeh, who commanded a wide following in the army and among senior cadres in 1976, Hua Kuo-feng was able to purge the "Gang of Four" and become Mao Zedong successor.
1992: Belgian Foreign Trade Minister Robert Urbain visits Taipei to relay a message of welcome to Taiwan business leaders intending to invest in Belgium. He also pledges support for the ROC's bid to join GATT.
1993: Boris N. Yeltsin, president of Russia, signs a decree governing private farms, paving the way for the breaking up of state-controlled farms and the move toward a free market economy.
1995: Independent presidential candidate Chen Li-an names Wang Ching-feng, a Control Yuan member, as his running mate.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew rushes to Chiayi immediately after a magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck the southern city at 10:19 a.m. and injured more than 320 people.
2000: Industrial sources say that Taiwan's exports in personal and notebook computers have increased by more than 40 percent over last year, with local notebooks accounting for 60 percent of the global market.
2001: After years of preparations, a group of scholars, social workers and medical specialists form the "Taiwan Health Reform Foundation" to monitor the operations of the nation's medical system.
2001: Lien Chan, chairman of the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), urges the public during a video shot for an ad to put their love of Taiwan into action by joining volunteer services.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
United Daily News: Help SMEs tap into Chinese market

TEXT.P: China has vowed to expand its domestic demand and enhance private consumption to account for 36 percent of its gross domestic product under its newly unveiled 12th five-year economic development plan.
The decision is like an invitation to Taiwan's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to make forays into the vast Chinese market.

Since the exodus of the local export-processing sector that began 25 years ago, Taiwan's industrial chain has seen a huge gap. While the country has outstanding upper- and mid-stream companies providing fine-quality materials and components, it lacks downstream manufacturers to provide brand-name finished products for the global consumer market. This deficiency has been a fatal defect in Taiwan's race against South Korea for global market share.

China's new five-year plan could be a godsend for Taiwan to mend the gap. The government should now integrate design and marketing manpower in the upper- and mid-stream industries to develop high-end consumer products.

In addition, it should cultivate an environment capable of attracting well- managed China-based Taiwanese downstream companies to relocate to Taiwan now that many of them are being troubled by rising wages in China.

President Ma Ying-jeou said recently that the signing of the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement offers Taiwanese companies good opportunities to market brand-name products in China. His administration should act to make these opportunities into reality. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 22, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Megi brings heavy rain around Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 11:07:53 (By Lin Kun-hsu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Heavy rain was expected to continue in many areas of Taiwan Friday as Typhoon Megi churned its way up the island's southwestern coast, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said that day.
Landslides triggered by the intense and prolonged rainfall have been reported in eastern regions.

In Yilan County, 402 motorists and passengers were stranded between the 115 km and 116 km marks on the section between Suao and Dongao townships of the Suhua Highway, according to the Central Emergency Operation Center.
The travelers, all of whom were reported safe, were aboard 32 vehicles, including 12 tour buses, the center said.
Another group of 19 Chinese tourists, however, remained unaccounted for, it added.
Data released by the CWB shows that from Thursday until 10 a.m. Friday, rainfall totalling 1,093 mm had been recorded in Suao.

Due to the combined effect of Typhoon Megi's outer rim and seasonal wind, torrential rain or extremely torrential rain, defined as 24-hour rainfall exceeding 200 mm and 350 mm, respectively, were expected in the Yilan, Taipei and Hualien areas Friday, forecasters said.
Other areas that also likely to experience heavy rainfall included Keelung, Taitung, Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Tainan, they said.
As of 10 a.m., Megi was centered 300 km south-southwest of Penghu in the Taiwan Strait, moving north at 9 kph toward China's southwestern coast.

The storm, packing maximum sustained wind of 162 kph and gusts of 198 kph, had struck Taiwan's southwestern coast and was posing a direct threat to the area, as well as to the outlying islands of Penghu and Kinmen, according to the CWB.

DOC.HEADLINE: National coffers inherit property from late veterans
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 11:23:25 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Over the past 10 years, the government has taken over NT$10 billion (US$324 million) -worth of property of deceased military veterans who died intestate, according to a report released Friday by the Veterans Affairs Commission (VAC).

Statistics show the state has inherited NT$9.4 billion, US$1.23 million, HK$26,000, 44,000 Chinese yuan and gold weighing a total of 88,760 grams, as well as 1,008 units of real estate in the period between 1999 and 2010 from veterans who died single and had no family, the report said.
In this year alone, the government got NT$638 million and US$13,000, as well as 9,000 grams of gold and 199 units of real estate, said the VAC.
VAC officials expressed deep respect for the retired veterans, who they said have made great contributions to the country by serving both the military and society.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: China's interest rate hikes

TEXT.P: China unexpectedly announced a quarter-point increase in its deposit and lending rates this week, inviting various speculation about the reasons behind the move.
The main concern here is what kind of chain reaction will follow after the hikes and in particular, whether China will continue to raise its interest rates.
If Beijing does so, it will attract an influx of hot money that will push up the value of the Chinese yuan.

Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao has previously warned that the country's export sector could collapse if the yuan appreciates by 20 percent to 40 percent against the U.S. dollar. And this situation should worry Taiwan the most because many Taiwanese products are manufactured in China and exported from there to other markets.

A warning sign already emerged in the third quarter of this year when the value of export orders from China dropped by 2.66 percent from the previous quarter despite a 2.73 percent increase in the overall value. Taiwan must keep close watch of the movement of the Chinese currency and react to it rapidly. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 22, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares of PV inverter maker dive on investigation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 12:42:14 (By Hseih Jiun-wei and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of Ablerex Electronics Co. Ltd., a Taiwanese photovoltaic inverter supplier, stumbled in Friday morning trading on the over-the-counter (OTC) market after financial authorities announced a day earlier that they will probe its recent price volatility for signs of possible manipulation, dealers said.
As of 11: 52 a.m., Ablerex had fallen 4.11 percent to NT$268.00 (US$8.71) with 877,000 shares changing hands, while the OTC index had risen 0.58 percent to 138.12 points.

The recent violent fluctuations in the company's share prices after the stock was listed on the OTC market Sept. 9 has attracted the close attention of the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) , the dealers said.
The stock's listing price was set at NT$185 Sept. 9 and rose sharply in the following trading sessions to hit a peak of NT$565.00 Sept. 14.
However, after the peak, the stock took a dive and hit a low of NT$258.00 Oct. 19 before rebounding.
Taiwan International Securities analyst Michael Chiang said after the news of the FSC's probe surfaced that the selling of the stock came as no surprise.
"Investors are afraid they will suffer more if they hold on to the stock, " Chiang said. "It is wise for them to keep their distance from the stock at the moment."
Chiang said the FSC suspects institutional investors have manipulated Ablerex's share price at the cost of retail investors.
"The investigation is necessary for the authorities to maintain market order and protect investors," Chiang said.

Chiang said investors should be alert when buying into high-tech stocks like Ablerex, as optimism over their earnings outlook paves the way for their underwriters to exaggerate company prospects to move share prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tour buses buried by landslides on Suhua Highway

TEXT.P: Two tour buses were buried when landslides hit the coastal Suhua Highway in northeastern Taiwan's Yilan County late Thursday, Interior Minister Jiang Yi- huah said Friday.
Two other buses, reportedly hit by falling rocks, remained unaccounted for, Jiang said at a news conference held at the Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC).

Quoting initial reports from rescuers, Jiang, who concurrently serves as CEOC commander, said one of the buried buses was located at the 113.5 km mark of the highway and the other was located at the 116 km mark.
Rescuers were still checking two buses that witnesses said were hit by falling rocks, Jiang said.
A total of 32 automobiles carrying 402 people remained stranded Friday following the landslides, Jiang said. Twelve of the stranded vehicles were tour buses, he added.
The landslides also caused a 500-meter long section of the roadbed to sink about 20 meters between the highway's 115 km and 116 km marks, Jiang said.

The landslides were triggered by heavy rain that has battered much of eastern Taiwan for the past few days, a result of the combined effects of Typhoon Megi's outer rim and seasonal winds from the northeast.
According to the Central Weather Bureau, Megi was continuing its northward track toward the Taiwan Strait and its strength was weakening as its speed had dropped to 9 kph.
The Council of Agriculture had as of press time issued 96 warnings about a high possibility of creeks bursting their banks and landslides occurring in Taipei City, Taipei County and Yilan County.

Meanwhile, accumulated precipitation in Yilan County's Suao Township had reached 1,064 mm as of 9 a.m. Friday, breaking the previous record of 808.5 mm recorded in Dawu Township, southern Taiwan, during Typhoon Morakot in August 2009.
Due to the heavy rain, 50 houses in Suao were destroyed by landslides, the CEOC said. No casualties were reported as all residents had already been evacuated, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA approves two R&D center projects
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 13:32:22 (By Lin Hui-chun and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Friday that it has approved applications filed by Hewlett-Packard and Interuniversity Microelectronics Centre (IMEC) to set up research and development centers in Taiwan.
The establishment of the two R&D centers is under a MOEA incentive program to encourage foreign high-tech companies to set up research footholds in the country, the ministry said.

According to the incentive program, which has been in place since 2002, a total of 32 foreign companies, including Microsoft and IBM, have established 46 R&D centers in Taiwan with financial aid from the MOEA.
The MOEA said that after the approval, the two R&D centers are expected to start operations in three months.
However, the ministry declined to comment on the size of the subsidies it will provide to the two firms, saying that further details need to be ironed out first.
HP is one of the world's largest PC suppliers, while IMEC is a Belgium-based nanoelectronics research institute.

The ministry said the new HP R&D center is aimed at integrating the company's existing resources in Taiwan and expanding its operations to cover supply chain and quality management, in a bid to turn the center into a global policymaking hub for the firm.

Meanwhile, the IMEC R&D center is expected to become the company's first research base outside Europe and will take advantage of Taiwan's strength in information and communications development for its future operations, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei 101 confident it can become world's tallest green building
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 14:30:13 (By Wu Chia-ying and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei 101 building is sure to win its platinum-degree Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) certification -- the highest level -- by next June, making it the world's tallest green building, its top official said Thursday.

Taipei 101, also known as the Taipei Financial Center, "was the world's highest building; now we hope to make it the world's tallest green building with the highest LEED platinum certification, " said Taipei 101 Chairman Lin Hong-ming.
In the past year, the board has been dedicated to improving the soft- and hardware facilities of the building to green it comprehensively, Lin said.

The results show that compared with the previous year, Taipei 101 reduced its carbon dioxide emissions by 10,000 tons, saved 3.3 million kilowatt hours of electricity and used 30 percent less water this year.

Overall, the building has achieved 7 percent energy-saving this year, Lin said, noting that Taipei 101 earned a score of 86 points given by the building's foreign consultants hired to give a green evaluation, which means it has reached the LEED platinum degree that requires at least 80 points on a 100-point measurement scale.
Judging from the score, the building's board of directors "is confident the building will achieve the LEED certification, " Lee said.
Taipei 101 ranked officially as the world's tallest building from 2004 until the opening of the Burj Khalifa in Dubai earlier this year.

LEED is an internationally recognized green building certification system, providing third-party verification that a building or community is designed and built using strategies aimed at improving performance across all the parameters that matter most: energy saving, water efficiency, CO2 emissions reduction, improved indoor environmental quality and stewardship of resources and sensitivity of their impacts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tiaoyutai issue flares up again

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday that the Executive Yuan will respect a legislative resolution for a visit by legislators to the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands next month that could add a new twist to an already-tense controversy over the islets.

The internal administration committee of the Legislative Yuan passed a resolution Thursday to launch an inspection visit Nov. 4 to the Tiaoyutais, which lie about 100 nautical miles off Taiwan's northeastern tip in the East China Sea. The islands are controlled by Japan and also claimed by China and Taiwan. They are known as the Diaoyutais in China and as the Senkaku Islands in Japan.

Responding to a question in a legislative session the previous day, Wu said the Executive Yuan will respect the decision. However, he added, given the complexity of the issue, the visit should be confined to waters within the "temporary enforcement line," as suggested by Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng.

As the claimed exclusive economic zones (EEZs) of Taiwan and Japan overlap near the islands, Taiwan established the temporary enforcement line for the EEZ in 2003 in order to provide safe fishing grounds for Taiwanese fishermen and gain an area of maritime jurisdiction.

The planned visit comes amidst a diplomatic row between China and Japan sparked by Japan's arrest of a Chinese fishing boat skipper after his trawler collided with two Japanese coast guard vessels in the area Sept. 7.
Wu reiterated that Taiwan claims full sovereignty over the islands, but has no intention of becoming embroiled in the issue, which could affect its overall relations with Japan and the United States.

He said Taiwan does not recognize Japan's administrative jurisdiction over the islands and that the government considers them to be under the administrative jurisdiction of Toucheng Township in Yilan County, although he conceded that in fact, the islands are indeed controlled by Japan.
