He was responding to a local media report that Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang said in a legislative session of the Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee Oct. 14 that Japan has administrative jurisdiction of the Tiaoyutais, which was handed over by the U.S. to Japan in 1972.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) responded to the report in a press release Thursday, saying that the ministry filed a protest after the U.S. handed the administrative jurisdiction of the archipelago to Japan and that its position has remained consistent over the years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourist group remains missing: Tourism Bureau

TEXT.P: Twenty Chinese nationals, one Taiwanese tour guide and two drivers remained unaccounted for after an all-night rescue effort on the Suhua Highway during a torrential rainstorm brought on by Typhoon Megi, the Tourism Bureau said Friday.

The missing persons included one Chinese tour leader and a Taiwanese bus driver from Hong Tai Tour Company as well as 19 Chinese nationals, a Taiwanese tour guide and bus driver from Harula Tour Company.
The government was exerting all efforts to ascertain the safety of those stranded, Premier Wu Den-yih told the press.
The Tourism Bureau said it was still tabulating figures for Taiwanese and other international tour groups. Around 500 people had been stranded on the highway by the storm.
As of Friday afternoon, 290 people had been rescued and relocated to nearby hotels, the bureau said, but a total of 250 Chinese tourists were still stranded.

The National Freeway Bureau (NFB) had already dispatched rescue teams and necessary equipment to bring the people to safe ground. But due to the harsh road and weather conditions, many of the rescue team members had been forced to enter the disaster zone on foot.
This was the worst damage ever sustained by the winding scenic route connecting Yilan and Hualien County, the NFB said. Most of the rock slides occurred between the 112- and 116-kilometer markers.

The Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits on Friday morning sent a letter to its Taiwanese counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation, to express concern for the Chinese nationals affected by the massive rain and landslide on highway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rainfall waning in northeast, increasing in south
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 15:41:05 (By Lin Szu-yu, Chen Chao-fu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Although rain was continuing in northeastern Taiwan Friday, it was beginning to abate, while rain and wind was increasing in the south with the approach of Typhoon Megi.

However, residents in parts of Yilan, Taipei and Hualien counties were warned to remain alert to the danger of torrential rain or extremely torrential rain, defined as 24-hour rainfall exceeding 200 mm and 350 mm respectively, due to the combined effects of Typhoon Megi's outer rim and seasonal wind, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said.
The CWB reported that as of 2 p.m., Megi was centered 250 km south-southwest of Penghu -- an outlying island off southwestern Taiwan -- moving north at 9 kph toward China.

The storm, packing maximum sustained wind of 155 kph and gusts of 191 kph, was affecting Taiwan's southwestern coast and was posing a direct threat to that area and to the outlying islands of Penghu and Kinmen, according to the bureau.

In Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, the local government announced that classes and public services were suspended for the rest of the day. It also ordered all city fire fighters, police and rescue personnel to stand by for any possible contingencies.
In addition to Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County, Tainan City and Pingtung County also announced class and office closures for the remainder of the day.

Meanwhile, the government updated its red-coded landslide warning earlier in the day, reporting that the number of rivers in danger of bursting their banks and causing landslides downstream had been reduced from 96 to 43, all in Yilan County.
The report also said the number of yellow-coded rivers had been increased from 142 to 195, all of which were in either Yilan County, Taipei County or Taipei City.

According to CWB statistics, from Thursday midnight to 11 a.m. the following day, precipitation had reached 1,097 mm in Yilan's Suao, 685 mm in Chingtienkang in the Shilin district of Taipei City, 568 mm in Taiping, Taipei County, 406 mm in Chishan, Pingtung County and 294 mm in Wudu, Keelung City.

DOC.HEADLINE: Panama president hails ties with Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 16:19:10 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng, Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Visiting Panama President Ricardo Martinelli likened the close ties between his country and Taiwan Friday to "a brotherhood."

Taiwan is a "true friend" of Panama and "blood is thicker than water" between the two countries, Martinelli said while addressing a ceremony hosted by President Ma Ying-jeou in Taipei, where he was welcomed with a military salute.

Martinelli is leading a delegation that also includes Panama Vice President Juan Carlos Verela on a three-day state visit to Taiwan. He is the first president from the Central American country to visit Taiwan in six years.

In a meeting with Martinelli at the Presidential Office immediately after the welcoming ceremony, Ma said he was deeply touched when he heard Martinelli mention the brotherly relations between the two countries.

Ma noted that Martinelli last visited Taiwan 10 years ago, at which time he was a businessman. His current visit as president symbolizes the close friendship between the two countries, according to Ma.
Ma also recalled that Panama's economic achievements impressed him deeply when he visited in June 2009 to attend Martinelli's inauguration.
The two heads of state were scheduled to sign a joint communique at the Presidential Office later that day.

During his stay, Martinelli is scheduled to visit the Nangang Software Park and the Taipei International Flora Expo, which will officially open Nov. 6. He will also host a conference to promote trade and investment opportunities in Panama.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan striving to become world's Hakka cultural hub: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 16:58:01 (By Garfie Li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that Taiwan, with 25 percent of its population of Hakka descent, has been striving to become the world's Hakka cultural center.

Speaking in the Hakka dialect to address the opening of a world conference of city leaders of Hakka descent, Ma told the conference that he himself has Hakka blood and that he is pleased to see that policies mapped out in his Hakka cultural development platform have been implemented one after another over the past two years.

Those policies that have been realized include the passage of a Hakka Basic Law, which allows the administration to use national resources in an ambitious plan to turn Taiwan into a global Hakka culture research and interaction center, Ma said.

There has been a 20-percent increase in the annual budget for Hakka affairs and trailblazing progress has also been made in efforts to conserve Hakka culture, including zoning certain cities and townships into key Hakka culture development districts, creating a "Hakka affairs and administration" category in the national tests for prospective civil servants, and developing a system that certifies the qualification of Hakka-dialect teachers, he added.
According to a 2008 Council for Hakka Affairs survey, there are nearly 5.79 million Hakkas in Taiwan if a broad definition of the term is used, or about 25 percent of the country's population.

Hakka, a Cantonese word which translates literally as "guest families, " comprise a unique ethnic group of Han Chinese who fled famine and wars in central China in centuries past and eventually settled in southern and eastern China, predominantly in the provinces of Guangdong, Jiangxi and Fujian.

There are an estimated 80 million Hakkas spread out around Southeast Asia, East Africa, Europe and the Americas, although the number of Hakka speakers is considerably lower. Former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra is one of the most notable, while the late Mauritius Prime Minister Sir Moilin Jean Ah-Chuen (1909-1991) , another eminent Hakka, has his picture printed on his nation's currency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over half of office workers bearish about investment: poll

TEXT.P: More than half of Taiwan's office workers were pessimistic about Taiwan's investment climate despite the recovering economy, a local poll showed Friday.
Asked if they were optimistic about the investment climate in the short term, 59 percent of white-collar workers surveyed by the Taipei-based 1111 Job Bank responded negatively.
Similarly, 52 percent of respondents said they did not have improved willingness to invest in the near term.

Given that Taiwan's economy had posted a second double-digit quarterly growth in a row this year -- 13.71 percent in the first quarter and 12.53 percent in the second quarter ending June 30 -- Henry Ho, the online employment agent's public relations director, blamed the pessimism on a lack of wage increases.
"Although it is generally believed that the business climate has improved a lot, many local wage earners have not enjoyed a pay raise and are not that optimistic as a result," he told reporters.

Ho said that 39 percent of office workers polled said they had not received a pay raise in at least three years. Of the 47 percent who had seen their wages grow over the same period, three-fifths had received pay raises of less than 5 percent, he added.

The poll also showed that 31 percent of people surveyed said their annual wage level had not yet returned to the 2008 level when the global financial crisis hit, with another 44 percent saying they now earn as much as they did in 2008

If other sources of income were included, however, 56 percent of respondents said their annual income was yet to return to its pre-crisis level. Twenty-nine percent of workers polled admitted to additional sources of income.
The poll indicated that 89 percent of respondents were dissatisfied with their current annual income.

Regarding the lack of wage increases, Peter Wu, director of human resources at realtor Evertrust Rehouse Group, told reporters that the recent increase in company profits did not necessarily lead to employees' pay raises as companies also had to take costs into consideration.
Using his own company as an example, Wu said that Evertrust focused on employees' welfare instead by investing more in training, company tours and annual bonuses.

DOC.HEADLINE: President orders quick delivery of food to stranded travelers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 17:27:57 (By Johnson Sun, Sunrise Huang, Worthy Shen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou asked rescuers Friday to find a way to deliver food, water and warm clothing to a group of motorists and tourists stranded on the Suhua Highway in eastern Taiwan by landslides triggered by Typhoon Megi.
"The supplies should be delivered to the victims as soon as possible, either by airlift or by road," Ma said during a visit to the Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC).
He also ordered the military to consider if additional forces should be deployed to speed up the rescue operation.

According to information obtained by the CEOC, 402 stranded travelers were found between the 115 km and 116 km marks on the section of highway between Yilan's Suao and Dongao townships that was hit by landslides Thursday amid intense and prolonged rainfall caused by the typhoon, coupled with a seasonal weather front.
The victims, all of whom were reported safe, were traveling in 32 vehicles, including 12 tour buses.
As of Friday afternoon, the National Airbone Service Corps (NASC) had rescued 33 of them and had airlifted them to three hospitals in Yilan and Hualien counties.
At 2: 45 p.m., a tour bus that had been damaged by falling rocks was found 100 meters down a ravine at the 112.8 km mark of the highway. No people were inside, rescuers said.

The NASC had tried to launch several airlift missions from Hualien to try to deliver food and water to the stranded travelers since Friday morning, but all the missions were aborted due to poor visibility over Hualien.

Two S70 helicopters dispatched by the military from Taipei, carrying dried food and mineral water, managed to reach the 114 km mark of the highway at around noon. A CH47 helicopter with a larger load capacity also made a flight that afternoon to help evacuate the stranded travelers, the National Defense Ministry said.

Meanwhile, ground forces were sent to the 112 km, 114 km and 116 km marks of the highway to deliver bread and dry food to the victims via line throwers. Insulin was also sent to two diabetics among the stranded people, according to the ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Rainstorm wreaks havoc in northeastern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Torrential rains brought by Typhoon Megi rattled northeastern Taiwan Thursday, triggering serious rockslides on the coastal Suhua Highway that stranded more than 400 travelers, including Chinese tourists.
According to newspaper reports, a Chinese tour leader and a Taiwanese driver were killed when falling rocks hit a Hong Tai Tour Co. bus near Dongao in Yilan County Thursday.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the storm disaster:
United Daily News:
Twenty-three Chinese tour groups consisting of 274 tourists were stranded on the Suhua Highway overnight as landslides and rockslides blocked traffic.
The Yilan County Fire Department received reports late Thursday that three vehicles fell off cliffs along the seriously damaged roadway, but the department had yet to confirm the reports.

Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo traveled to the county's Suao Township to take command of disaster relief operations as about 30 vehicles with 96 people were trapped in the nearby Nanfangao area.
A Chinese tour leader who was leading a tour group of 16 people from Guizhou and Hubei provinces said he and his group were scared when mudslides hit their tour bus.
"We broke windows to get out just before mudflows buried our bus," said the tour leader identified only by his family name Fan.
Heavy downpours began battering southern Yilan County at 10 a.m. Thursday. Flash floods soon submerged Suao's downtown area, with its main streets turned into rivers.
Scared residents had to rush to the third-or-higher floors of residential buildings to wait for assistance.

The county government did not announce the closure of public offices and schools until 2 p.m. Thursday. By then, several elementary schools had already been swamped by floodwaters, forcing students and teachers to stay on the premises until late at night when rescuers finally helped evacuate them. (Oct. 22, 2010).
China Times:
Three Yilan townships -- Suao, Nanao and Yuanshan -- were the hardest-hit regions. Suao's downtown district became a "ghost town" after all residents were evacuated amid torrential downpours.
Yilan County Magistrate Lin Tsung-hsien said the deluge was stunning and rarely seen in a century.

More than 1,000 passengers were stranded at Yilan County's Yunglo station for five hours Thursday after the Taiwan Railway's North-Link Line suspended service due to flooding. The passengers were not sent back to Hualien County in eastern Taiwan until late in the day.

Due to the convergence of Typhoon Megi's periphery and seasonal winds, Suao received 939 millimeters in rainfall between midnight Wednesday and midnight Thursday, the most ever in Taiwan for a single day.
The previous record was recorded on Aug. 8, 2009 at the Dawu weather station in Taitung County, when Typhoon Morakot devastated southern and southeastern Taiwan. (Oct. 22, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Friday, gaining NT$0.041 to close at NT$30.910.
Turnover totaled US$578 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.919 and moved between NT$30.662 and NT$30.922 before the close.
The U.S. dollar appeared weaker during most of the trading session as foreign banks and exporters continued to cut their holdings, dealers said.
However, the greenback staged a mild technical rebound in the latter part of the session to recoup the earlier losses against the local currency, they said.

The trading range of the two currencies remained narrow amid cautious sentiment as investors continued to await the conclusion to be reached on the global currency market at the ongoing meeting of central bankers and financial ministers of the Group of 20 nations held in South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: Renowned Hakka fiction now has English version

TEXT.P: An English translation of novelettes by Lai He, the "father of Taiwanese new literature," was published Friday in an attempt to introduce early Taiwanese literary works to a wider international audience, announced the Council for Hakka Affairs (CHA).

"Lai He Fiction" contains 21 short stories penned by Lai, a renowned author of Hakka ancestry who, because of his sympathy for the poor during the Japanese colonial period, was also nicknamed the "Matsu of Changhua" in reference to the compassionate Taoist deity.
His works also offered valuable insights into society at that time, said CHA Minister Huang Yu-chen.

"Lai He was an important figure in the development of Taiwan literature because his work dug into the lives of Taiwanese commoners and his persistency in writing reminded us of the Hakka spirit," said Huang.

"I often heard people say that Lai's work wasn't easy to read. The language shifts repeatedly between Mandarin and Hoklo Taiwanese, and a good knowledge of the socio-historical background is required of readers," admitted Lai Yueh-yen, the author's eldest grandson and founder of the Lai He Museum.

Readers of this English version are fortunate, therefore, that its translator is Joe Hung, veteran journalist, social commentator and educator, who has just such a deep knowledge of Taiwan's social history.

"We are pleased to say that Central News Agency (CNA) Chairman Joe Hung, who is well versed in English, Chinese and Japanese, did a wonderful job in presenting this Taiwanese classic to English readers, " Huang said, noting that this was the first English publication of stories by Hakka authors sponsored by the CHA.
Prior to its publication by the CNA, the work appeared in series in Hung's old newspaper, the China Post, five days per week for six months.
"It was well received by readers," said the Post's director and publisher, Jack Huang. "We used to get calls from our readers asking why the stories are not printed on weekends."

This was a big step forward for Hakka authors whose writings deserve international attention, said Huang Yu-chen, explaining that Hakka literature might even be recognized for the Noble Prize in Literature if translated into English.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses in eastern Taiwan surpass NT$11 million
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 19:00:33 (By Yang Shu-ming, Lin Szu-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The heavy rains brought by Typhoon Megi had caused NT$11.3 million in losses in the agricultural sectors of Taiwan's three eastern counties as of 8 a.m. Friday, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said.
Losses totaled NT$9 million in Hualien County, NT$1.58 million in Taitung County and NT$700,000 in Yilan County, which experienced the heaviest rainfall of any county in Taiwan on Thursday.

Torrential rains caused by the convergence of the periphery of the typhoon and seasonal winds from the northeast led to the flooding of 76 hectares of farmland in the counties, which damaged 47 percent of the crops worth an estimated NT$3.96 million grown on that land.

The persistent rainfall in northern and eastern Taiwan that began Tuesday affected vegetable prices in Taipei's wholesale market Friday, with the average price rising by 24.9 percent to NT$29.1 per kilogram, from NT$23.3 per kilogram the previous day.

The volume of vegetables sold at the market fell by 18.7 percent Friday, which Agriculture and Food Agency Secretary-General Hsu Han-ching attributed to a shortfall of supply from agricultural parts of Yilan County.
"Cabbages produced in Yilan generally could not be shipped to Taipei because roads in the area were cut off by storm damage, " he said.
The heavy rainfall also caused damage to 19 schools around Taiwan, mostly in Yilan County, the Ministry of Education reported.
As of Friday noon, affected schools in Yilan had reported NT$4.17 million in damage, with some facilities still being evaluated, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Intercontinental Cup baseball tourney to open Saturday in Taichung

TEXT.P: Defending champion Cuba and host Taiwan are among 10 teams that will battle it out in the 2010 Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament, which opens Saturday in Taichung City.

Cuba, Taiwan, South Korea, Czech Republic, Hong Kong, Japan, the Netherlands, Thailand, Italy and Nicaragua will compete in the IBAF (International Baseball Federation) tournament, which will be played at Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium until Oct. 31.

Cuba, which has won 10 of the past 16 Intercontinental Cups, enters the competition as one of the favorites. It will be joined by Taiwan, South Korea, Czech and Hong Kong in one of the two round-robin groups.
Taiwan, which also hosted the tournament the last time it was played in 2006, is scheduled to meet perennial rival South Korea in the opening game Oct. 23.
Kuo Hong-chih, the Los Angeles Dodgers' Taiwanese pitcher, will throw out the ceremonial first ball.
Japan, the Netherlands, Thailand, Italy and Nicaragua are in the other preliminary group.
Taiwan finished third in the 2006 tournament, matching its best previous showing in the tournament, a bronze medal performance in 1983.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon-related agricultural losses over NT$45 million: COA

TEXT.P: Torrential rains from Typhoon Megi had caused an estimated NT$45.86 million in agricultural losses in four counties of Taiwan as of 3 p.m. Friday, the Council of Agricultural (COA) reported.

According to the COA, crop losses had totaled NT$22.54 million as of Friday afternoon, with 271 hectares of farmland in Taipei, Yilan, Hualien, and Taitung counties affected by the rain storm that dumped record amounts of precipitation on parts of Yilan on Thursday.
The storm was also responsible for the deaths of 231 pigs and 21,200 chickens, causing NT$8.64 million in losses to the livestock sector, the COA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TDRs of Singapore water-treatment firm soar on debut
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 20:14:42 (By Maranda Hsu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan depositary receipts (TDRs) of United Envirotech Ltd., a water- treatment firm from Singapore, rose sharply higher on the first day of trading on an upbeat mood toward its business in China, dealers said.
United Envirotech closed up 6.71 percent at NT$16.70 (US$0.54) with 52,000 shares changing hands, while Taiwan's benchmark weighted index rose 0.45 percent to 8,168.06.

"Most of the company's sales are generated from China, " Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said. "The wastewater-treatment market in China is growing rapidly on rising demand for this particular business in a booming economy."
Noting that the local high-tech sector was losing luster amid concerns over earnings outlook, investors were targeting safe havens, like United Envirotech, to park their money, Hsu said.
"The gains are expected to continue over the next few sessions as the interest is expected not to fade very soon," he said.
So far this year, China has accounted for 88.94 percent of the company's total revenues, up from 80.03 percent in 2008, according to the company.
Before the listing, the company's 32 million TDRs were about 44 times oversubscribed in the underwriting stage, indicating investor enthusiasm toward the stock.
United Envirotech's major customers in China include China Petroleum & Chemical Corp. (Sinopec) , China National Offshore Oil Corp., China National Petroleum Corp. and various city governments.
During the April 2008-March 2009 period, United Envirotech posted S$14.85 million (NT$352.01 million) in net profit, compared with S$3.66 million recorded a year earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: History Channel to explore Taiwan's forgotten histories
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 20:18:10 (By Amy Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: History Channel Asia will premiere its new series, Hidden Cities, later this month with four episodes on cities in four Asian nations, including Taiwan.

Starting Oct. 24, Hidden Cities will explore some of Asia's many secrets, from forgotten palaces and old buildings with undiscovered histories, to underground fortresses that shelter incredible relics and untold stories, announced the TV channel through a Taipei public relations company on Friday.

In the first four episodes, the network's first series produced in Asia, host Anthony Morse travels to China's capital of Beijing; Malaysia's northwest states of Penang, Ipoh and Kedah; Java in Indonesia; and various places around Taiwan.

For the Taiwan episode, Morse went to the mausoleum of presidents Chiang Kai- shek and his son, Chiang Ching-kuo, at Cihu (Lake Mercy) in Taoyuan County. He also met with Weng Yuan, who served as a member of the staff at the late presidents' residences.

Weng told Morse that Chiang Kai-shek liked to stroll and sit beside the lake around 5 p.m. each evening to contemplate and enjoy a quiet moment. Once forbidden to outsiders, the lake has opened to the public in recent years.

Morse and his camera crew next explored Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen, also known as Quemoy, the anti-communist bastion where, more than five decades ago, Taiwan troops fought the last battle against the Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA).

The crew explored Kinmen's maze of underground tunnels dating from the Cold-War standoff, savored the island's famous sorghum liquor, and learned how to make kitchen knives out of PLA bombs dropped on Kinmen, which is located as close as 2 kilometers to the Chinese mainland.

Morse finally visited a beach village in Hualien on Taiwan's east coast that was once off-limits to Taiwanese people as it was home to Japanese prisoners and their dependants in the aftermath of World War II.

The Taiwan episode is scheduled to be screened Nov. 14, according to the public relations company. The 30-year-old Morse, born to an American father and Burmese mother, will come to Taiwan Oct. 31 to promote the series, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.45 percent in range trade

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.45 percent Friday in a narrow range as buying rotated to select the stocks of large-cap old-economy firms on renewed optimism toward their closer business ties with China, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 36.83 points to 8,168.06, after moving between 8,148.26 and 8,174.03 on turnover of NT$103.35 billion (US$3. 36 billion).

The market opened up 0.40 percent, and interest in bellwether petrochemical stocks, in particular the firms under the conglomerate Formosa Plastics Group, continued on hopes that their bottom lines would be boosted by China investments amid increasing cross-strait exchanges, dealers said.
A total of 1,894 stocks closed up, 1,815 down, and 403 remained unchanged.

The plastics and chemical sector witnessed the largest gains, up 0.91 percent. Cement firms rose 0.72 percent, machinery and electronics stocks added 0.57 percent, financial shares gained 0.16 percent, and construction stocks closed up 0.09 percent.
Among those falling, the textile sector fell 1.4 percent, foodstuffs lost 0.65 percent, and paper and pulp stocks closed down 0.56 percent.
"Ahead of the strong technical resistance at around 8,200 points, the market remained in consolidation mode despite the gains," Arch Shih of TLG Asset Management said.

Shih said market sentiment remained cautious as investors have been waiting to see what central bankers and financial ministers of the Group of 20 nations will conclude on the global currency market in a meeting to be held in South Korea Friday and Saturday.

While large-cap petrochemical stocks, such as Formosa Plastics and Nan Ya Plastics, posted gains, their strength was not sufficient to pull the broader market out of the current range trade, Shih said.
"The market still lacks a mainstream sector to make a breakthrough, " Shih added, referring to a lackluster electronics sector.
Formosa Plastics rose 1.56 percent to NT$84.50, and Nan Ya Plastics gained 1.19 percent to NT$68.20.

Largan Precision, the world's largest supplier of lenses for cellphone cameras, rose 1.81 percent to NT$618.00, after the company said sales for the fourth quarter would continue to grow on higher demand for smartphones.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rescue footpath carved out for stranded travelers: official

TEXT.P: A rescue footpath was constructed to bypass the Suhua Highway between the 112 and 114 kilometer markers, thereby allowing travelers stranded on the northern section to walk to a nearby aid station, Mile N. Chen, chief secretary-general of the Directorate General of Highways (DGH) said Friday.
As for the wounded, the weak and those remaining stranded on the southern section of highway, a preferable option would be the use of helicopters, Chen told a news conference.

The DGH said it hoped to restore a 20-meter-long collapsed section of roadbed around the 113km mark within a week, while clarifying that another collapsed section around the 116km mark, initially reported to be 500 meters in length, proved to be just 70 meters long. The rest of the section was found to be blocked by rocks and mud.
Ambulances and cars, along with bottled water and 200 meal servings, were ready for the stranded travelers at the aid station, Chen noted.
"We will first evacuate the stranded travelers to Suao Harbor Bureau and then transport them to different destinations," he added. enitem/MH

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese group coming to handle missing tourists issue
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 20:36:54 (By Hsu Chih-wei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A delegation representing families of a 21-member tour group from southern China's Guangdong Province that has remained unaccounted for since Thursday is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Saturday, a spokesman for Harula Tour Co. said Friday.

The group was last known to be traveling aboard a tour bus on the coastal Suhua Highway in Yilan County Thursday when the northeastern county was rattled by a torrential rainstorm brought by Typhoon Megi.

The spokesman for Harula, local host of the missing group, said the company has informed the families of the Chinese tourists. As the situation remained unclear, he said, the company could not apply for entry permits for their family members to come to Taiwan at this point.
After representatives of the Chinese travel agency arrive in Taipei on Saturday afternoon, they will immediately go to Yilan to get first-hand information about the missing group.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's adjusted jobless rate falls again in September
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 20:49:54 (By Yi-chun Chen and James Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate fell for the 13th consecutive month in September, helped by a drop in the number of people left jobless because of downsizings or company shutdowns, the country's statistics agency said Friday.
The adjusted employment rate fell to 5.08 percent, down 0.03 percentage points from August, said Liu Tian-shy, deputy director of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

The nominal jobless rate in September fell to 5.05 percent, down 0.12 percentage points from August, and Liu said it could meet the government's stated goal of falling below 5 percent by the end of the year.

The number of people left jobless because of company downsizings or closures totaled 199,000 in September, 16,000 fewer than in August and the first time the figure had fallen below 200,000 since October 2008, when the global economic meltdown was just beginning.
The number reached a peak at 355,000 in June 2009.

The September decline in the overall jobless rate matches the trends of previous years, Liu said, and he estimated that the number of unemployed would have to fall by 4,000 for the jobless rate to fall below 5 percent by the end of 2010.

Despite the improving unemployment figures, Taiwan's jobless rate is still higher than that of the other Asian Tigers. Unemployment is at 3.7 percent in South Korea, 2.2 percent in Singapore and 4.2 percent in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: Back in Taiwan, Kuo reflects on breakout season

TEXT.P: Back home for the first time since the end of the Major League Baseball season, Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher Kuo Hong-chih attributed his record-setting season to "pure luck" and said he hoped to help his team get back into the playoffs next year.

"I would like to return to Taiwan at a later date next year," Kuo said at a press conference attended by some 100 reporters, alluding to his desire to have the Dodgers remain active into the post-season in 2011.
The Dodgers finished the season 80-82, fourth in the five-team National League West Division, after having made the National League Championship Series the previous two seasons.

But the team's drop-off was not because of Kuo. The 29-year-old left-hander had his best year since first making the Dodgers roster in 2005, finishing with a 3-2 record and 12 saves in 56 appearances and becoming the first Taiwanese player to earn a spot in the All-Star Game.
His ERA of 1.20 was also the lowest in franchise history for pitchers with at least 50 innings pitched, and he was nominated for the "Setup Man of the Year" award.

Responding to questions posed by fans in an online Internet chat room, which was opened at the same time as the press conference, Kuo politely attributed his success to "pure luck" and said he was happy as long as he was able to play the game after nearly having his career ended by four elbow operations.
Kuo said his most memorable performance of the year was a two-inning outing in a 3-1 win over the Arizona Diamondbacks on July 4, when he struck out all six batters he faced.
Reflecting on his experience in the All-Star Game, Kuo said he was nervous because he didn't know what to do and where to go.
"I felt like I became a fan again and was busy taking photos with those big-name players, " he said.

The 29-year-old gave credit to first baseman James Loney and pitchers Chad Billingsley and Jonathon Broxton for their friendship, which helped him get through the long season. He added that fan support was also a big help.

"I thought of giving up, honestly. But I'm not a person who gives up easily, and I always tell myself that I have to keep fighting because I represent my country of Taiwan in the MLB to some extent, " Kuo said.

The left-hander, who started the 2010 season as a setup man but was installed as a closer in mid-August in place of the struggling Braxton, said he would not mind shifting between the two roles next year, even though "being a closer brings you so much pressure because you're supposed to finish it off."
Kuo said he hopes to continue playing in the United States for another 5-10 years, but "the most important thing for me, first and foremost, is to help my team win."

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier apologizes for incident on Suhua Highway
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 21:40:05 (By Jenny W. Hsu, JohnsonSun)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih apologized Friday for the poor upkeep of the Suhua Highway and said construction of the Suhua Freeway could began next year providing the project passes the environmental impact assessment by the end of this year.

Built in 1932 during the period of Japanese rule, the highway was now in a shoddy condition, the premier acknowledged at an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan. This made it susceptible to collapse, frequent rock slides and blockage by fallen debris, particularly during inclement weather, he said.
"I must offer my sincere apology to the people stranded on the highway for the inadequate maintenance of the Suhua Highway, " said Wu.
The main highway in eastern Taiwan was struck by landslides Thursday, causing casulties and hundreds of travlers to be stranded or trapped.
As of late Friday afternoon, a 21-person Chinese group touring Taiwan with the Harula Travel Co. and last known to be traveling on the highway remained unaccounted for.
In a separate incident, a Chinese tour leader and a Taiwanese driver with the Hong Tai Travel Company were also still missing.

Parts of their tour bus had been located along the highway, said the Interior Minister Jiang Yi-hua, who speculated the pair might have fallen out of the bus as it tumbled. The 19 Chinese tourists in the group were safe.

Around 400 people had been stranded on the popular scenic route, and by 7: 00 p.m. Friday, 330 had been transported by vehicle or helicopter to shelters, the Tourism Bureau announced, quoting the latest figures from the Central Emergency Operation Center. Of those rescued, 233 are tourists from mainland China.
The military dispatched 90 rescuers to the location as the torrential rainstorm brought by Typhoon Megi continued to pound the area.
Harula Travel Co. said that families of the missing Chinese tourists had been contacted, and a group representing the families will arrive at Taiwan tomorrow.

A new Suhua Freeway project has been fiercely opposed by environmental groups, who argue that the construction will jeopardize local ecosystems. They suggest the government should instead invest in a train route, which would relieve traffic as well as producing 90 percent less carbon emissions than cars.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sending delegation to solicit U.S. investment

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government is sending a delegation to the United States on Sunday that it hopes will secure investment commitments from a number of American companies.

The delegation, headed by Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Sheng-chung, expects to sign letters of intent with representatives from a dozen U.S. companies in the fields of green energy, cloud computing, semiconductors, optoelectronics and biotechnology.

During the eight-day trip, the delegation will meet with Noveda Technologies Inc., Air Products and Chemicals Inc., Veeco Instruments Inc., Celgene Corp., A10 Networks Inc., Lam Research Corp. and others in Silicon Valley, San Diego, New York and elsewhere in the U.S.
"We will sign letters of intent with a number of the companies we will visit," Lin said at a press briefing Friday.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs expected some of these companies to introduce their technologies to Taiwan or set up research and development centers on the island, he said.
The ministry has set a goal of soliciting investment of NT$30 billion in Taiwan over the next two years from the companies being visited on the upcoming trip.
In September, the ministry signed letters of intent with more than 20 foreign companies, including Hewlett-Packard Co. (HP) , for combined investment of NT$108.25 billion (US$3.5 billion) in Taiwan.
The U.S. is Taiwan's largest source of foreign investment, having invest US$21.58 billion in Taiwan between 1952 and September 2010.
Most of the investment is focused on the manufacturing of electronics and chemical products, but U.S. companies have increasingly invested in the financial and insurance sectors in recent years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Improve railways before roads in eastern Taiwan: environmentalists
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 21:49:59 (By Lee Shien-feng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Thursday's deadly disruptions to traffic on the Suhua Highway caused by torrential rains have rekindled interest in improving the accident-prone roadway, but environmentalists said Friday that priority should be given to expanding eastern Taiwan's railway line.

"There are many ways to get home, " said Tsai Chung-yueh, the spokesman for an alliance opposing the construction of a freeway along the scenic coast between Yilan and Hualien counties out of concern for the environment.

Tsai said that while the heavy rain completely blocked traffic on the Suhua Highway and left 23 people unaccounted for on Thursday and Friday, it only caused the railway connecting Taipei and Hualien to shut down for half a day on Thursday before resuming service.

He said that was because the construction of a railway has a smaller impact on the surrounding terrain than a roadway, and he advocated prioritizing plans to expand the railway system rather than pumping more money into improving the Suhua Highway.

Earlier in the day, lawmakers urged the government to launch as soon as possible a planned project to upgrade the mountain section of the windy highway, which is highly vulnerable to rockslides and landslides during stormy weather.
"The government is obliged to build a road that allows Hualien residents to travel home safely, " said Legislator Wang Ting-son of the ruling Kuomintang.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications originally planned to build a new freeway between Suao and Hualien that would have bypassed the old highway, but it was nixed after drawing strong opposition from environmental activists.
The agency then proposed its plan to upgrade the existing road, reinforcing it where possible and bypassing some of the most dangerous sections with tunnels or other new roads.
The proposal is currently undergoing an environmental impact assessment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sudden downpour stymied precautionary measures

TEXT.P: The Directorate General of Highways (DGH) on Friday blamed the suddenness of the heavy downpour for landslides that stranded hundreds of travlers on a major highway in eastern Taiwan, some of whom are still unaccounted for.

DGH Chief Secretary-General Mile N. Chen admitted that there is room for improvement when asked by reporters why the authority didn't close the Suhua Highway as the area was battered by torrential rain Thursday.
A recently-installed geographic information system (GIS) couldn't have warned motorists in advance because it was unable to determine the extreme nature of the rainfall in time to issue an alert.

It usually takes us two to three hours to collect the data but the heavy rain really came all of sudden,Chen said, adding that the DGH's rescue capacity has been overwhelmed by extreme weather when similar incidents happened in recent years.

According to the Central Weather Bureau, the hourly accumulated precipitation in Suao skyrocketed to 181.5 mm between 1 to 2 p.m. Thursday, around the time when a series of landslides took place along the highway between the townships of Suao and Dongao.
The precipitation marked the third highest record for the nation, the CWB said.
Chen said that the DGH might consider setting up several barricades along the highway in the future under similar circumstances so they could deploy manpower to close off sections of the road.
Given the length of the highway, which is 118 km, Chen said that management of any mandatory closure would be highly challenging.
There have been around 200 blockings on the Suhua Highway due to bad weather since 2002, according to DGH data.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stranded tourists expect to be evacuated by midnight
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 22:13:03 (By Johnson Sun, Tang Hsiao-tien and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Seventy of the 400 people stranded on the Suhua Highway in eastern Taiwan by storm-triggered landslides were airlifted to safety by 5:30 p.m. Friday, with the rest expected to be evacuated by midnight, the Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC) said.
Those among the 70 people rescued who needed medical attention were airlifted to Tzu-Chi Buddhist General Hospital in Hualien City, according to the center.
Efforts to get the remaining 330 people to safety was continuing through Friday night, and the center hoped that the operation would be completed by midnight.
Aside from the 400 stranded individuals, another 23 thought to be on the highway when traffic was disrupted by landslides, were considered missing, with few clues as to their whereabouts.
All of the 330 people waiting to be evacuated Friday evening were on the 114 kilometer to 115.5 kilometer section of the highway between Yilan's Suao and Dongan Townships.
That section was blocked Thursday by landslides triggered by prolonged torrential downpours from Typhoon Megi and another weather system from the northeast.
Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said at a press conference held at the center that an emergency road giving greater access to rescue vehicles had been opened at the 112.8 km marker by 4 p.m.

Escorted by SWAT team members, whose number had increased from 30 to 90 as of Friday noon, the 330 people still to be rescued walked in the direction of the 112.8 km marker, where they were to board vehicles that would take them to safety in Yilan City, Jiang said.
As of 10 p.m., all but 53 had reached the 112.8 km marker.
The victims, about two-thirds of whom were Chinese nationals touring Taiwan, were traveling in 32 vehicles, including 12 tour buses, and were reported to be safe.

DOC.HEADLINE: Job openings on the rise for 11 consecutive months: job bank

TEXT.P: The number of job openings available in Taiwan have grown on a year-on-year basis for 11 consecutive months, a local online employment agency said Friday.
The Taipei-based 1111 Job Bank declined to offer specific job figures, however, citing business confidentiality.
The agency said in a statement that the number of job openings available during the past seven months, have posted average year-on-year monthly growth of 30 percent.

The number of jobs available grew especially sharply in a few specific industries, rising 80.28 year-on-year in the old economy manufacturing sector, 77.65 percent in the restaurant, hairdressing and beauty care sector, and 64.35 percent in the construction and real estate sector, the job bank said.

The statement came hours after Taiwan's statistics agency reported that the country's adjusted unemployment rate fell for the 13th consecutive month to 5.08 percent in September, helped by a drop in the number of people left jobless because of downsizings or company shutdowns.
Despite the prolonged decline in the jobless rate, however, it has remained stubbornly above 5 percent, even with the many job openings that have become available in 2010.

Henry Ho, the agency's public relations director, said the disparity showed that the majority of jobs available in Taiwan are created by only a limited number of sectors, making it hard to match job openings to job seekers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 97-year-old living healthy life after surviving breast cancer
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 23:14:20 (By Ching-fang Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Wang Tung-ming, a 97-year-old amateur Peking Opera singer and Tien Gow (Heaven Nine Game) player, was anything but the average breast cancer patient.
But after having the tumor removed surgically in April 2009, she has led a happy and healthy life, she said on Friday.

At a press conference marking the opening of a photography exhibition on breast cancer at Taipei Cinema Park, Taiwan's oldest breast cancer patient ever to survive surgery said she opted for the operation after she was diagnosed with cancer in her left breast in March 2009.
Though she said she was not afraid to die, the possible torment of having to suffer through terminal stage cancer convinced her to deal with the disease surgically.

Chang Chin-chien, a professor in the Department of Surgery at National Taiwan University's College of Medicine, said Wang's case was rare, with the rate of people aged over 80 being afflicted with breast cancer at under 5 percent.

Even fewer people at that age opted to have the cancer surgically removed, he said, but National Taiwan University Hospital decided to perform the surgery on Wang after determining that her health and strength would enable her to make it through the operation.
"Although she lives alone, Wang understands how to organize her daily life. She really is full of sunshine," Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Megi leaves 7 dead in Suao, 23 missing on coastal highway

TEXT.P: Seven people were killed by a mudslide and another 23 traveling on a coastal highway remained unaccounted for as of Friday night after northeastern Taiwan was battered by heavy rains brought by Typhoon Megi.
The Central Emergency Operation Center said seven corpses were recovered from a house in Suao that was buried by a mudslide.
The missing people were on the Suhua Highway connecting Yilan and Hualien counties when traffic on the roadway was disrupted by torrential rain and landslides Thursday.

Those listed as missing included a 19-person tour group from southern China's Guangdong Province, which was last known to be traveling aboard a tour bus on the highway during Thursday's blinding rainstorm.
The group's Taiwanese tour guide and its Taiwanese bus driver also have been listed as missing.
The Chinese leader of a tour group from Beijing and its Taiwanese bus driver were also unaccounted for after their bus was buried by a landslide on the highway.
The buried bus was located by rescue workers, but neither of the two were found inside.
The rockslides and mudslides along the highway triggered by the torrential rains brought by Typhoon Megi also stranded around 430 travelers overnight Thursday.

The Defense Ministry mobilized hundreds of soldiers and SWAT team members to remove rocks and build an emergency road to evacuate those stranded. Helicopters also helped airlifted scores of travelers to safety during the day.
By Friday evening, most of those not airlifted to safety walked approximately 1.2 kilometers to the entry of the emergency road and were driven to Yilan City.

Fifty-three others decided, however, not to walk the distance, electing instead to spend another night at a safe location on the highway accompanied by SWAT teams and be airlifted away the following day.
Premier Wu Den-yih apologized Friday for the poor upkeep of the highway built in 1932 during Japanese colonial rule.

Speaking at a legislative session, Wu also said that a project to improve the more vulnerable sections of the highway Yilan County and neighboring Hualien County in eastern Taiwan could begin next year providing the project passes an environmental impact assessment.

Meanwhile, the Directorate General of Highways admitted Friday that there was room for improvement when asked why the agency did not close off the accident- prone highway before the area was hit by torrential rains.
It also forecast that the highway would not be fully repaired until Nov. 20.
Due to the convergence of stormy weather on Typhoon Megi's periphery and seasonal winds from the northeast, Yilan County has received a staggering amount of rainfall in the past few days.
The county's Suao area received 939 millimeters in rainfall between midnight Wednesday and midnight Thursday, the most ever in Taiwan for a single day, the Central Weather Bureau said Friday.
The previous record was recorded on Aug. 8, 2009 at the Dawu weather station in Taitung County, when Typhoon Morakot devastated southern and southeastern Taiwan.
Many parts of the county were submerged in flash floodwaters Thursday.

As of 3 p.m. Friday, Typhoon Megi-related agricultural losses were estimated at NT$45.86 million in four counties around Taiwan, according to the Council of Agriculture. (By Wang Shu-fen, Chen Shun-hsien, Liu Chia-tai, Jenny Hsu, Hsin- Yin Lee and Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Bus driver provides warmth for stranded Chinese tourists

TEXT.P: Chinese tourists expressed their gratitude Friday to the driver of a Taiwanese tour company who helped them pass the night after they were left stranded on a coastal highway in eastern Taiwan.

The 23 Chinese nationals from Harbin were travelling with the Zhi Jian tour company when they were trapped at the 114-kilometer marker of the Suhua Highway late Thursday morning, said tour guide Zhu Guo-ming.
During the night, driver Wu Tie-nan opened up biscuits which were meant as a gift for his family and shared them along with his own water to help the group members ward off hunger and thirst.
His generosity was received with heartfelt thanks by the Chinese tourists even though each of them got only two pieces of biscuit and a little bit of water, said Zhu.
According to Zhu, they weren't able to sleep and spent the night keeping up each other's spirits waiting for rescue.
They were finally lifted to safety by helicopter at 3.30 pm Friday.
The group's plan to visit the National Palace Museum in Taipei has been rescheduled to Saturday morning, after which they will return to China.
They are just one of a number of groups of Chinese nationals who needed rescuing from a section of the Suhua Highway destroyed by landslides after heavy rainfalls from Typhoon Megi.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Friday, gaining NT$0.041 to close at NT$30.910.
Turnover totaled US$578 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.919 and moved between NT$30.662 and NT$30.922 before the close.
The U.S. dollar appeared weaker during most of the trading session as foreign banks and exporters continued to cut their holdings, dealers said.
However, the greenback staged a mild technical rebound in the latter part of the session to recoup the earlier losses against the local currency, they said.

The trading range of the two currencies remained narrow amid cautious sentiment as investors continued to await the conclusion to be reached on the global currency market at the ongoing meeting of central bankers and financial ministers of the Group of 20 nations held in South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: Renowned Hakka fiction now has English version

TEXT.P: An English translation of novelettes by Lai He, the "father of Taiwanese new literature," was published Friday in an attempt to introduce early Taiwanese literary works to a wider international audience, announced the Council for Hakka Affairs (CHA).

"Lai He Fiction" contains 21 short stories penned by Lai, a renowned author of Hakka ancestry who, because of his sympathy for the poor during the Japanese colonial period, was also nicknamed the "Matsu of Changhua" in reference to the compassionate Taoist deity.
His works also offered valuable insights into society at that time, said CHA Minister Huang Yu-chen.

"Lai He was an important figure in the development of Taiwan literature because his work dug into the lives of Taiwanese commoners and his persistency in writing reminded us of the Hakka spirit," said Huang.

"I often heard people say that Lai's work wasn't easy to read. The language shifts repeatedly between Mandarin and Hoklo Taiwanese, and a good knowledge of the socio-historical background is required of readers," admitted Lai Yueh-yen, the author's eldest grandson and founder of the Lai He Museum.

Readers of this English version are fortunate, therefore, that its translator is Joe Hung, veteran journalist, social commentator and educator, who has just such a deep knowledge of Taiwan's social history.

"We are pleased to say that Central News Agency (CNA) Chairman Joe Hung, who is well versed in English, Chinese and Japanese, did a wonderful job in presenting this Taiwanese classic to English readers, " Huang said, noting that this was the first English publication of stories by Hakka authors sponsored by the CHA.
Prior to its publication by the CNA, the work appeared in series in Hung's old newspaper, the China Post, five days per week for six months.
"It was well received by readers," said the Post's director and publisher, Jack Huang. "We used to get calls from our readers asking why the stories are not printed on weekends."

This was a big step forward for Hakka authors whose writings deserve international attention, said Huang Yu-chen, explaining that Hakka literature might even be recognized for the Noble Prize in Literature if translated into English.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses in eastern Taiwan surpass NT$11 million
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 19:00:33 (By Yang Shu-ming, Lin Szu-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The heavy rains brought by Typhoon Megi had caused NT$11.3 million in losses in the agricultural sectors of Taiwan's three eastern counties as of 8 a.m. Friday, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said.
Losses totaled NT$9 million in Hualien County, NT$1.58 million in Taitung County and NT$700,000 in Yilan County, which experienced the heaviest rainfall of any county in Taiwan on Thursday.

Torrential rains caused by the convergence of the periphery of the typhoon and seasonal winds from the northeast led to the flooding of 76 hectares of farmland in the counties, which damaged 47 percent of the crops worth an estimated NT$3.96 million grown on that land.

The persistent rainfall in northern and eastern Taiwan that began Tuesday affected vegetable prices in Taipei's wholesale market Friday, with the average price rising by 24.9 percent to NT$29.1 per kilogram, from NT$23.3 per kilogram the previous day.

The volume of vegetables sold at the market fell by 18.7 percent Friday, which Agriculture and Food Agency Secretary-General Hsu Han-ching attributed to a shortfall of supply from agricultural parts of Yilan County.
"Cabbages produced in Yilan generally could not be shipped to Taipei because roads in the area were cut off by storm damage, " he said.
The heavy rainfall also caused damage to 19 schools around Taiwan, mostly in Yilan County, the Ministry of Education reported.
As of Friday noon, affected schools in Yilan had reported NT$4.17 million in damage, with some facilities still being evaluated, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Intercontinental Cup baseball tourney to open Saturday in Taichung

TEXT.P: Defending champion Cuba and host Taiwan are among 10 teams that will battle it out in the 2010 Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament, which opens Saturday in Taichung City.

Cuba, Taiwan, South Korea, Czech Republic, Hong Kong, Japan, the Netherlands, Thailand, Italy and Nicaragua will compete in the IBAF (International Baseball Federation) tournament, which will be played at Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium until Oct. 31.

Cuba, which has won 10 of the past 16 Intercontinental Cups, enters the competition as one of the favorites. It will be joined by Taiwan, South Korea, Czech and Hong Kong in one of the two round-robin groups.
Taiwan, which also hosted the tournament the last time it was played in 2006, is scheduled to meet perennial rival South Korea in the opening game Oct. 23.
Kuo Hong-chih, the Los Angeles Dodgers' Taiwanese pitcher, will throw out the ceremonial first ball.
Japan, the Netherlands, Thailand, Italy and Nicaragua are in the other preliminary group.
Taiwan finished third in the 2006 tournament, matching its best previous showing in the tournament, a bronze medal performance in 1983.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon-related agricultural losses over NT$45 million: COA

TEXT.P: Torrential rains from Typhoon Megi had caused an estimated NT$45.86 million in agricultural losses in four counties of Taiwan as of 3 p.m. Friday, the Council of Agricultural (COA) reported.

According to the COA, crop losses had totaled NT$22.54 million as of Friday afternoon, with 271 hectares of farmland in Taipei, Yilan, Hualien, and Taitung counties affected by the rain storm that dumped record amounts of precipitation on parts of Yilan on Thursday.
The storm was also responsible for the deaths of 231 pigs and 21,200 chickens, causing NT$8.64 million in losses to the livestock sector, the COA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TDRs of Singapore water-treatment firm soar on debut
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 20:14:42 (By Maranda Hsu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan depositary receipts (TDRs) of United Envirotech Ltd., a water- treatment firm from Singapore, rose sharply higher on the first day of trading on an upbeat mood toward its business in China, dealers said.
United Envirotech closed up 6.71 percent at NT$16.70 (US$0.54) with 52,000 shares changing hands, while Taiwan's benchmark weighted index rose 0.45 percent to 8,168.06.

"Most of the company's sales are generated from China, " Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said. "The wastewater-treatment market in China is growing rapidly on rising demand for this particular business in a booming economy."
Noting that the local high-tech sector was losing luster amid concerns over earnings outlook, investors were targeting safe havens, like United Envirotech, to park their money, Hsu said.
"The gains are expected to continue over the next few sessions as the interest is expected not to fade very soon," he said.
So far this year, China has accounted for 88.94 percent of the company's total revenues, up from 80.03 percent in 2008, according to the company.
Before the listing, the company's 32 million TDRs were about 44 times oversubscribed in the underwriting stage, indicating investor enthusiasm toward the stock.
United Envirotech's major customers in China include China Petroleum & Chemical Corp. (Sinopec) , China National Offshore Oil Corp., China National Petroleum Corp. and various city governments.
During the April 2008-March 2009 period, United Envirotech posted S$14.85 million (NT$352.01 million) in net profit, compared with S$3.66 million recorded a year earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: History Channel to explore Taiwan's forgotten histories
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 20:18:10 (By Amy Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: History Channel Asia will premiere its new series, Hidden Cities, later this month with four episodes on cities in four Asian nations, including Taiwan.

Starting Oct. 24, Hidden Cities will explore some of Asia's many secrets, from forgotten palaces and old buildings with undiscovered histories, to underground fortresses that shelter incredible relics and untold stories, announced the TV channel through a Taipei public relations company on Friday.

In the first four episodes, the network's first series produced in Asia, host Anthony Morse travels to China's capital of Beijing; Malaysia's northwest states of Penang, Ipoh and Kedah; Java in Indonesia; and various places around Taiwan.

For the Taiwan episode, Morse went to the mausoleum of presidents Chiang Kai- shek and his son, Chiang Ching-kuo, at Cihu (Lake Mercy) in Taoyuan County. He also met with Weng Yuan, who served as a member of the staff at the late presidents' residences.

Weng told Morse that Chiang Kai-shek liked to stroll and sit beside the lake around 5 p.m. each evening to contemplate and enjoy a quiet moment. Once forbidden to outsiders, the lake has opened to the public in recent years.

Morse and his camera crew next explored Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen, also known as Quemoy, the anti-communist bastion where, more than five decades ago, Taiwan troops fought the last battle against the Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA).

The crew explored Kinmen's maze of underground tunnels dating from the Cold-War standoff, savored the island's famous sorghum liquor, and learned how to make kitchen knives out of PLA bombs dropped on Kinmen, which is located as close as 2 kilometers to the Chinese mainland.

Morse finally visited a beach village in Hualien on Taiwan's east coast that was once off-limits to Taiwanese people as it was home to Japanese prisoners and their dependants in the aftermath of World War II.

The Taiwan episode is scheduled to be screened Nov. 14, according to the public relations company. The 30-year-old Morse, born to an American father and Burmese mother, will come to Taiwan Oct. 31 to promote the series, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.45 percent in range trade

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.45 percent Friday in a narrow range as buying rotated to select the stocks of large-cap old-economy firms on renewed optimism toward their closer business ties with China, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 36.83 points to 8,168.06, after moving between 8,148.26 and 8,174.03 on turnover of NT$103.35 billion (US$3. 36 billion).

The market opened up 0.40 percent, and interest in bellwether petrochemical stocks, in particular the firms under the conglomerate Formosa Plastics Group, continued on hopes that their bottom lines would be boosted by China investments amid increasing cross-strait exchanges, dealers said.
A total of 1,894 stocks closed up, 1,815 down, and 403 remained unchanged.

The plastics and chemical sector witnessed the largest gains, up 0.91 percent. Cement firms rose 0.72 percent, machinery and electronics stocks added 0.57 percent, financial shares gained 0.16 percent, and construction stocks closed up 0.09 percent.
Among those falling, the textile sector fell 1.4 percent, foodstuffs lost 0.65 percent, and paper and pulp stocks closed down 0.56 percent.
"Ahead of the strong technical resistance at around 8,200 points, the market remained in consolidation mode despite the gains," Arch Shih of TLG Asset Management said.

Shih said market sentiment remained cautious as investors have been waiting to see what central bankers and financial ministers of the Group of 20 nations will conclude on the global currency market in a meeting to be held in South Korea Friday and Saturday.

While large-cap petrochemical stocks, such as Formosa Plastics and Nan Ya Plastics, posted gains, their strength was not sufficient to pull the broader market out of the current range trade, Shih said.
"The market still lacks a mainstream sector to make a breakthrough, " Shih added, referring to a lackluster electronics sector.
Formosa Plastics rose 1.56 percent to NT$84.50, and Nan Ya Plastics gained 1.19 percent to NT$68.20.

Largan Precision, the world's largest supplier of lenses for cellphone cameras, rose 1.81 percent to NT$618.00, after the company said sales for the fourth quarter would continue to grow on higher demand for smartphones.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rescue footpath carved out for stranded travelers: official

TEXT.P: A rescue footpath was constructed to bypass the Suhua Highway between the 112 and 114 kilometer markers, thereby allowing travelers stranded on the northern section to walk to a nearby aid station, Mile N. Chen, chief secretary-general of the Directorate General of Highways (DGH) said Friday.
As for the wounded, the weak and those remaining stranded on the southern section of highway, a preferable option would be the use of helicopters, Chen told a news conference.

The DGH said it hoped to restore a 20-meter-long collapsed section of roadbed around the 113km mark within a week, while clarifying that another collapsed section around the 116km mark, initially reported to be 500 meters in length, proved to be just 70 meters long. The rest of the section was found to be blocked by rocks and mud.
Ambulances and cars, along with bottled water and 200 meal servings, were ready for the stranded travelers at the aid station, Chen noted.
"We will first evacuate the stranded travelers to Suao Harbor Bureau and then transport them to different destinations," he added. enitem/MH

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese group coming to handle missing tourists issue
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 20:36:54 (By Hsu Chih-wei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A delegation representing families of a 21-member tour group from southern China's Guangdong Province that has remained unaccounted for since Thursday is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Saturday, a spokesman for Harula Tour Co. said Friday.

The group was last known to be traveling aboard a tour bus on the coastal Suhua Highway in Yilan County Thursday when the northeastern county was rattled by a torrential rainstorm brought by Typhoon Megi.

The spokesman for Harula, local host of the missing group, said the company has informed the families of the Chinese tourists. As the situation remained unclear, he said, the company could not apply for entry permits for their family members to come to Taiwan at this point.
After representatives of the Chinese travel agency arrive in Taipei on Saturday afternoon, they will immediately go to Yilan to get first-hand information about the missing group.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's adjusted jobless rate falls again in September
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 20:49:54 (By Yi-chun Chen and James Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate fell for the 13th consecutive month in September, helped by a drop in the number of people left jobless because of downsizings or company shutdowns, the country's statistics agency said Friday.
The adjusted employment rate fell to 5.08 percent, down 0.03 percentage points from August, said Liu Tian-shy, deputy director of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

The nominal jobless rate in September fell to 5.05 percent, down 0.12 percentage points from August, and Liu said it could meet the government's stated goal of falling below 5 percent by the end of the year.

The number of people left jobless because of company downsizings or closures totaled 199,000 in September, 16,000 fewer than in August and the first time the figure had fallen below 200,000 since October 2008, when the global economic meltdown was just beginning.
The number reached a peak at 355,000 in June 2009.

The September decline in the overall jobless rate matches the trends of previous years, Liu said, and he estimated that the number of unemployed would have to fall by 4,000 for the jobless rate to fall below 5 percent by the end of 2010.

Despite the improving unemployment figures, Taiwan's jobless rate is still higher than that of the other Asian Tigers. Unemployment is at 3.7 percent in South Korea, 2.2 percent in Singapore and 4.2 percent in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: Back in Taiwan, Kuo reflects on breakout season

TEXT.P: Back home for the first time since the end of the Major League Baseball season, Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher Kuo Hong-chih attributed his record-setting season to "pure luck" and said he hoped to help his team get back into the playoffs next year.

"I would like to return to Taiwan at a later date next year," Kuo said at a press conference attended by some 100 reporters, alluding to his desire to have the Dodgers remain active into the post-season in 2011.
The Dodgers finished the season 80-82, fourth in the five-team National League West Division, after having made the National League Championship Series the previous two seasons.

But the team's drop-off was not because of Kuo. The 29-year-old left-hander had his best year since first making the Dodgers roster in 2005, finishing with a 3-2 record and 12 saves in 56 appearances and becoming the first Taiwanese player to earn a spot in the All-Star Game.
His ERA of 1.20 was also the lowest in franchise history for pitchers with at least 50 innings pitched, and he was nominated for the "Setup Man of the Year" award.

Responding to questions posed by fans in an online Internet chat room, which was opened at the same time as the press conference, Kuo politely attributed his success to "pure luck" and said he was happy as long as he was able to play the game after nearly having his career ended by four elbow operations.
Kuo said his most memorable performance of the year was a two-inning outing in a 3-1 win over the Arizona Diamondbacks on July 4, when he struck out all six batters he faced.
Reflecting on his experience in the All-Star Game, Kuo said he was nervous because he didn't know what to do and where to go.
"I felt like I became a fan again and was busy taking photos with those big-name players, " he said.

The 29-year-old gave credit to first baseman James Loney and pitchers Chad Billingsley and Jonathon Broxton for their friendship, which helped him get through the long season. He added that fan support was also a big help.

"I thought of giving up, honestly. But I'm not a person who gives up easily, and I always tell myself that I have to keep fighting because I represent my country of Taiwan in the MLB to some extent, " Kuo said.

The left-hander, who started the 2010 season as a setup man but was installed as a closer in mid-August in place of the struggling Braxton, said he would not mind shifting between the two roles next year, even though "being a closer brings you so much pressure because you're supposed to finish it off."
Kuo said he hopes to continue playing in the United States for another 5-10 years, but "the most important thing for me, first and foremost, is to help my team win."

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier apologizes for incident on Suhua Highway
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 21:40:05 (By Jenny W. Hsu, JohnsonSun)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih apologized Friday for the poor upkeep of the Suhua Highway and said construction of the Suhua Freeway could began next year providing the project passes the environmental impact assessment by the end of this year.

Built in 1932 during the period of Japanese rule, the highway was now in a shoddy condition, the premier acknowledged at an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan. This made it susceptible to collapse, frequent rock slides and blockage by fallen debris, particularly during inclement weather, he said.
"I must offer my sincere apology to the people stranded on the highway for the inadequate maintenance of the Suhua Highway, " said Wu.
The main highway in eastern Taiwan was struck by landslides Thursday, causing casulties and hundreds of travlers to be stranded or trapped.
As of late Friday afternoon, a 21-person Chinese group touring Taiwan with the Harula Travel Co. and last known to be traveling on the highway remained unaccounted for.
In a separate incident, a Chinese tour leader and a Taiwanese driver with the Hong Tai Travel Company were also still missing.

Parts of their tour bus had been located along the highway, said the Interior Minister Jiang Yi-hua, who speculated the pair might have fallen out of the bus as it tumbled. The 19 Chinese tourists in the group were safe.

Around 400 people had been stranded on the popular scenic route, and by 7: 00 p.m. Friday, 330 had been transported by vehicle or helicopter to shelters, the Tourism Bureau announced, quoting the latest figures from the Central Emergency Operation Center. Of those rescued, 233 are tourists from mainland China.
The military dispatched 90 rescuers to the location as the torrential rainstorm brought by Typhoon Megi continued to pound the area.
Harula Travel Co. said that families of the missing Chinese tourists had been contacted, and a group representing the families will arrive at Taiwan tomorrow.

A new Suhua Freeway project has been fiercely opposed by environmental groups, who argue that the construction will jeopardize local ecosystems. They suggest the government should instead invest in a train route, which would relieve traffic as well as producing 90 percent less carbon emissions than cars.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sending delegation to solicit U.S. investment

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government is sending a delegation to the United States on Sunday that it hopes will secure investment commitments from a number of American companies.

The delegation, headed by Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Sheng-chung, expects to sign letters of intent with representatives from a dozen U.S. companies in the fields of green energy, cloud computing, semiconductors, optoelectronics and biotechnology.

During the eight-day trip, the delegation will meet with Noveda Technologies Inc., Air Products and Chemicals Inc., Veeco Instruments Inc., Celgene Corp., A10 Networks Inc., Lam Research Corp. and others in Silicon Valley, San Diego, New York and elsewhere in the U.S.
"We will sign letters of intent with a number of the companies we will visit," Lin said at a press briefing Friday.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs expected some of these companies to introduce their technologies to Taiwan or set up research and development centers on the island, he said.
The ministry has set a goal of soliciting investment of NT$30 billion in Taiwan over the next two years from the companies being visited on the upcoming trip.
In September, the ministry signed letters of intent with more than 20 foreign companies, including Hewlett-Packard Co. (HP) , for combined investment of NT$108.25 billion (US$3.5 billion) in Taiwan.
The U.S. is Taiwan's largest source of foreign investment, having invest US$21.58 billion in Taiwan between 1952 and September 2010.
Most of the investment is focused on the manufacturing of electronics and chemical products, but U.S. companies have increasingly invested in the financial and insurance sectors in recent years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Improve railways before roads in eastern Taiwan: environmentalists
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 21:49:59 (By Lee Shien-feng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Thursday's deadly disruptions to traffic on the Suhua Highway caused by torrential rains have rekindled interest in improving the accident-prone roadway, but environmentalists said Friday that priority should be given to expanding eastern Taiwan's railway line.

"There are many ways to get home, " said Tsai Chung-yueh, the spokesman for an alliance opposing the construction of a freeway along the scenic coast between Yilan and Hualien counties out of concern for the environment.

Tsai said that while the heavy rain completely blocked traffic on the Suhua Highway and left 23 people unaccounted for on Thursday and Friday, it only caused the railway connecting Taipei and Hualien to shut down for half a day on Thursday before resuming service.

He said that was because the construction of a railway has a smaller impact on the surrounding terrain than a roadway, and he advocated prioritizing plans to expand the railway system rather than pumping more money into improving the Suhua Highway.

Earlier in the day, lawmakers urged the government to launch as soon as possible a planned project to upgrade the mountain section of the windy highway, which is highly vulnerable to rockslides and landslides during stormy weather.
"The government is obliged to build a road that allows Hualien residents to travel home safely, " said Legislator Wang Ting-son of the ruling Kuomintang.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications originally planned to build a new freeway between Suao and Hualien that would have bypassed the old highway, but it was nixed after drawing strong opposition from environmental activists.
The agency then proposed its plan to upgrade the existing road, reinforcing it where possible and bypassing some of the most dangerous sections with tunnels or other new roads.
The proposal is currently undergoing an environmental impact assessment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sudden downpour stymied precautionary measures

TEXT.P: The Directorate General of Highways (DGH) on Friday blamed the suddenness of the heavy downpour for landslides that stranded hundreds of travlers on a major highway in eastern Taiwan, some of whom are still unaccounted for.

DGH Chief Secretary-General Mile N. Chen admitted that there is room for improvement when asked by reporters why the authority didn't close the Suhua Highway as the area was battered by torrential rain Thursday.
