A recently-installed geographic information system (GIS) couldn't have warned motorists in advance because it was unable to determine the extreme nature of the rainfall in time to issue an alert.

It usually takes us two to three hours to collect the data but the heavy rain really came all of sudden,Chen said, adding that the DGH's rescue capacity has been overwhelmed by extreme weather when similar incidents happened in recent years.

According to the Central Weather Bureau, the hourly accumulated precipitation in Suao skyrocketed to 181.5 mm between 1 to 2 p.m. Thursday, around the time when a series of landslides took place along the highway between the townships of Suao and Dongao.
The precipitation marked the third highest record for the nation, the CWB said.
Chen said that the DGH might consider setting up several barricades along the highway in the future under similar circumstances so they could deploy manpower to close off sections of the road.
Given the length of the highway, which is 118 km, Chen said that management of any mandatory closure would be highly challenging.
There have been around 200 blockings on the Suhua Highway due to bad weather since 2002, according to DGH data.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stranded tourists expect to be evacuated by midnight
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 22:13:03 (By Johnson Sun, Tang Hsiao-tien and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Seventy of the 400 people stranded on the Suhua Highway in eastern Taiwan by storm-triggered landslides were airlifted to safety by 5:30 p.m. Friday, with the rest expected to be evacuated by midnight, the Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC) said.
Those among the 70 people rescued who needed medical attention were airlifted to Tzu-Chi Buddhist General Hospital in Hualien City, according to the center.
Efforts to get the remaining 330 people to safety was continuing through Friday night, and the center hoped that the operation would be completed by midnight.
Aside from the 400 stranded individuals, another 23 thought to be on the highway when traffic was disrupted by landslides, were considered missing, with few clues as to their whereabouts.
All of the 330 people waiting to be evacuated Friday evening were on the 114 kilometer to 115.5 kilometer section of the highway between Yilan's Suao and Dongan Townships.
That section was blocked Thursday by landslides triggered by prolonged torrential downpours from Typhoon Megi and another weather system from the northeast.
Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said at a press conference held at the center that an emergency road giving greater access to rescue vehicles had been opened at the 112.8 km marker by 4 p.m.

Escorted by SWAT team members, whose number had increased from 30 to 90 as of Friday noon, the 330 people still to be rescued walked in the direction of the 112.8 km marker, where they were to board vehicles that would take them to safety in Yilan City, Jiang said.
As of 10 p.m., all but 53 had reached the 112.8 km marker.
The victims, about two-thirds of whom were Chinese nationals touring Taiwan, were traveling in 32 vehicles, including 12 tour buses, and were reported to be safe.

DOC.HEADLINE: Job openings on the rise for 11 consecutive months: job bank

TEXT.P: The number of job openings available in Taiwan have grown on a year-on-year basis for 11 consecutive months, a local online employment agency said Friday.
The Taipei-based 1111 Job Bank declined to offer specific job figures, however, citing business confidentiality.
The agency said in a statement that the number of job openings available during the past seven months, have posted average year-on-year monthly growth of 30 percent.

The number of jobs available grew especially sharply in a few specific industries, rising 80.28 year-on-year in the old economy manufacturing sector, 77.65 percent in the restaurant, hairdressing and beauty care sector, and 64.35 percent in the construction and real estate sector, the job bank said.

The statement came hours after Taiwan's statistics agency reported that the country's adjusted unemployment rate fell for the 13th consecutive month to 5.08 percent in September, helped by a drop in the number of people left jobless because of downsizings or company shutdowns.
Despite the prolonged decline in the jobless rate, however, it has remained stubbornly above 5 percent, even with the many job openings that have become available in 2010.

Henry Ho, the agency's public relations director, said the disparity showed that the majority of jobs available in Taiwan are created by only a limited number of sectors, making it hard to match job openings to job seekers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 97-year-old living healthy life after surviving breast cancer
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/10 23:14:20 (By Ching-fang Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Wang Tung-ming, a 97-year-old amateur Peking Opera singer and Tien Gow (Heaven Nine Game) player, was anything but the average breast cancer patient.
But after having the tumor removed surgically in April 2009, she has led a happy and healthy life, she said on Friday.

At a press conference marking the opening of a photography exhibition on breast cancer at Taipei Cinema Park, Taiwan's oldest breast cancer patient ever to survive surgery said she opted for the operation after she was diagnosed with cancer in her left breast in March 2009.
Though she said she was not afraid to die, the possible torment of having to suffer through terminal stage cancer convinced her to deal with the disease surgically.

Chang Chin-chien, a professor in the Department of Surgery at National Taiwan University's College of Medicine, said Wang's case was rare, with the rate of people aged over 80 being afflicted with breast cancer at under 5 percent.

Even fewer people at that age opted to have the cancer surgically removed, he said, but National Taiwan University Hospital decided to perform the surgery on Wang after determining that her health and strength would enable her to make it through the operation.
"Although she lives alone, Wang understands how to organize her daily life. She really is full of sunshine," Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Megi leaves 7 dead in Suao, 23 missing on coastal highway

TEXT.P: Seven people were killed by a mudslide and another 23 traveling on a coastal highway remained unaccounted for as of Friday night after northeastern Taiwan was battered by heavy rains brought by Typhoon Megi.
The Central Emergency Operation Center said seven corpses were recovered from a house in Suao that was buried by a mudslide.
The missing people were on the Suhua Highway connecting Yilan and Hualien counties when traffic on the roadway was disrupted by torrential rain and landslides Thursday.

Those listed as missing included a 19-person tour group from southern China's Guangdong Province, which was last known to be traveling aboard a tour bus on the highway during Thursday's blinding rainstorm.
The group's Taiwanese tour guide and its Taiwanese bus driver also have been listed as missing.
The Chinese leader of a tour group from Beijing and its Taiwanese bus driver were also unaccounted for after their bus was buried by a landslide on the highway.
The buried bus was located by rescue workers, but neither of the two were found inside.
The rockslides and mudslides along the highway triggered by the torrential rains brought by Typhoon Megi also stranded around 430 travelers overnight Thursday.

The Defense Ministry mobilized hundreds of soldiers and SWAT team members to remove rocks and build an emergency road to evacuate those stranded. Helicopters also helped airlifted scores of travelers to safety during the day.
By Friday evening, most of those not airlifted to safety walked approximately 1.2 kilometers to the entry of the emergency road and were driven to Yilan City.

Fifty-three others decided, however, not to walk the distance, electing instead to spend another night at a safe location on the highway accompanied by SWAT teams and be airlifted away the following day.
Premier Wu Den-yih apologized Friday for the poor upkeep of the highway built in 1932 during Japanese colonial rule.

Speaking at a legislative session, Wu also said that a project to improve the more vulnerable sections of the highway Yilan County and neighboring Hualien County in eastern Taiwan could begin next year providing the project passes an environmental impact assessment.

Meanwhile, the Directorate General of Highways admitted Friday that there was room for improvement when asked why the agency did not close off the accident- prone highway before the area was hit by torrential rains.
It also forecast that the highway would not be fully repaired until Nov. 20.
Due to the convergence of stormy weather on Typhoon Megi's periphery and seasonal winds from the northeast, Yilan County has received a staggering amount of rainfall in the past few days.
The county's Suao area received 939 millimeters in rainfall between midnight Wednesday and midnight Thursday, the most ever in Taiwan for a single day, the Central Weather Bureau said Friday.
The previous record was recorded on Aug. 8, 2009 at the Dawu weather station in Taitung County, when Typhoon Morakot devastated southern and southeastern Taiwan.
Many parts of the county were submerged in flash floodwaters Thursday.

As of 3 p.m. Friday, Typhoon Megi-related agricultural losses were estimated at NT$45.86 million in four counties around Taiwan, according to the Council of Agriculture. (By Wang Shu-fen, Chen Shun-hsien, Liu Chia-tai, Jenny Hsu, Hsin- Yin Lee and Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Bus driver provides warmth for stranded Chinese tourists

TEXT.P: Chinese tourists expressed their gratitude Friday to the driver of a Taiwanese tour company who helped them pass the night after they were left stranded on a coastal highway in eastern Taiwan.

The 23 Chinese nationals from Harbin were travelling with the Zhi Jian tour company when they were trapped at the 114-kilometer marker of the Suhua Highway late Thursday morning, said tour guide Zhu Guo-ming.
During the night, driver Wu Tie-nan opened up biscuits which were meant as a gift for his family and shared them along with his own water to help the group members ward off hunger and thirst.
His generosity was received with heartfelt thanks by the Chinese tourists even though each of them got only two pieces of biscuit and a little bit of water, said Zhu.
According to Zhu, they weren't able to sleep and spent the night keeping up each other's spirits waiting for rescue.
They were finally lifted to safety by helicopter at 3.30 pm Friday.
The group's plan to visit the National Palace Museum in Taipei has been rescheduled to Saturday morning, after which they will return to China.
They are just one of a number of groups of Chinese nationals who needed rescuing from a section of the Suhua Highway destroyed by landslides after heavy rainfalls from Typhoon Megi.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rain fails to dampen Golden Bell party for Rainie Yang, Wu Cheng-di

TEXT.P: Heavy rains could do little to dampen the spirit of Taiwan's television elites as the star-studded Golden Bell Awards proceeded without a hitch Friday night.

In two of the most anticipated awards, pop star Rainie Yang won Best Actress in a Dramatic Series for her portrayal of a tomboy in "Hi, My Sweetheart" while first-time nominee 15-year-old Wu Cheng-di nabbed the Best Actor award, leaving many fans of pop artist Show Luo and heartthrob James Wen disappointed.
Adventure aficionado and the face of "Fun Taiwan, " Janet Hsieh, failed to win the award for Best Travel Show Host, beaten out by Xiao Ma, a former comedian turned travel show host.
Taiwanese opera star Lin Mei-chao won Best Actress in a Mini series and Tang Chuang went home with Best Actor in the same category for his role in "Seafaring Men," which also won Best Mini Series.

Prior to the ceremony, the red carpet was graced by a throng of household names despite the heavy rain. They included child star Little Bin, veteran comedian Zhu Ge-liang, actress Tien Hsin, and the cast of "Super Party, " a popular political satire show.
It was the second time this year that heavy rain had arrived uninvited during a major award ceremony in Taiwan, though the Golden Bells did a better job of keeping its stars dry.

Back in May during the Golden Melody Awards, several stars, including the multi- talented Hong Kong diva Karen Mok, were drenched from head to toe in their expensive gowns when the organizers failed to provide nothing more than umbrellas for them.

During the awards ceremony, now in its 45th year, former talent show contestant and now international star Lin Yu-chun won roaring applause from the audience with his performance of a medley, including his famous rendition of Whitney Houston's "I Will Always Love You."
Some of the most heated battles for prizes included the Best Variety Show, in which two highly popular singing contest shows "Million Stars" and "Super Idol" went head to head for the honor.
But in a major upset, the award eventually went to "Million Dollar Primary School, " a quiz show patterned after the U.S. program "Are you Smarter than a Fifth Grader?"
This year, the bell tolled loudly for Zhu Ge-liang and Rene Hu, the "beauty and the beast" duo whose near-perfect chemistry won them the honor of Best Variety Show hosts.
The award marked a major milestone for Zhu after he had disappeared from the small screen for over a decade because he was on the run from his creditors.
This year, a total of 132 nominations competed for the Golden Bell in 32 categories. Each winner will receive a cash award of NT$100,000, the Government Information Office said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 23, 2010, or the 16th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1812: An anti-Napoleonic faction in Paris headed by Gen. Claude Francois de Malet tries to mount a coup d'etat, believing Napoleon to be dead in Russia.
1924: During China's warlord era, Feng Yu-hsiang, Hu Ching-yi and Sun Yueh form an allied force to launch a military coup that results in the resignation of Tsao Kun who was elected president of the Beijing government Oct. 5, 1923.
1926: Leon Trotsky is expelled from the Soviet Communist Party.
1928: The Republic of China government formally establishes the Ministry of Education.
1948: Changchun, a city in Kirin Province, northeastern China, falls to communist troops.
1952: Ukrainian-born microbiologist Selman A. Waksman wins the Nobel Prize for physiology or medicine for discovering the antibiotic streptomycin, an agent effective in the treatment of tuberculosis.
1955: Ngo Dinh Diem is elected president of South Vietnam.
1956: Hungarian students and workers demonstrate in Budapest against the Soviet occupation.
1957: ROC Vice President Chen Cheng is elected deputy director general of the Kuomintang.
1958: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek and U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles issue a joint communique reaffirming solidarity between the two countries and stating that the islands of Kinmen and Matsu are "closely related" to the defense of Taiwan and Penghu under present conditions.
1966: The Ministry of the Interior proclaims today (the ninth day of the ninth lunar month) as Double Nine Festival, also known as the Chung Yang Festival, to honor senior citizens.
1968: Nigerian President Hamani Diori arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1969: The United States starts pulling its troops out of Vietnam.
1973: The ROC suspends diplomatic relations with Upper Volta following Ouagadougou's recognition of Beijing.
1974: Brig. Gen. Abboud Salem Hassan, commander in chief of the Royal Jordanian air force, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: The first Chung Cheng Cup Martial Arts Tournament opens at the Taipei Athletic College with Wang Sun-teh, president of the Taipei Martial Arts Association, presiding.
1980: An economic cooperation agreement is signed in Taipei between La Chambre de Commerce of D'Industrie de Marseilles of France and the Far East Trade Service of the ROC.
1982: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize in literature, delivers a speech entitled "To Free China" at Taipei City Hall.
1983: Muslim suicide bombers blow up the U.S. and French headquarters in Beirut, killing more than 200 U.S. marines and French paratroopers.
1992: Emperor Akihito of Japan arrives in Beijing for a six-day visit.
1997: Hong Kong's stock market falls victim to Southeast Asia's economic turmoil, with the Hang Seng index falling more than 10 percent in its biggest crash in history.
1998: A Tokyo court hands down the first death sentence to a member of the Japanese doomsday cult that carried out the 1995 Tokyo subway gas attack.
1999: Taiwan finishes second with 15 medals at the 1999 Pan Pacific Master Swimming Championship held in Perth, Australia.
2000: The 15th Belgium-Republic of China Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Brussels to discuss ways of bolstering economic cooperation between the two countries.
2001: Paraguayan Vice Foreign Minister Rigoberto Gauto Vielman arrives in Taipei at the start of a five-day visit to the Republic of China.
2001: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung agrees to call mainland China "the People's Republic of China (PRC) " rather than "communist China."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Nine confirmed dead in Suao mudslide
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/10 10:15:58 (By Johnson Sun, Sunrise Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Rescuers recovered two more bodies Saturday from the wreckage of a house buried in a mudslide triggered by Typhoon Megi-induced heavy rain in the northeastern county of Yilan, raising the confirmed death toll at the site to nine.

The fatal mudslide occured Thursday in the township of Suao, at the northern end of eastern Taiwan's scenic Suhua Highway, part of which was destroyed by landslides after the area was battered with record-breaking downpours.

At the site of one landslide on the highway connecting Yilan and Hualien counties, the final group of 54 stranded motorists and passengers were evacuated Saturning morning, according to the Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC).
A total of 435 people have been rescued from the site, located between Yilan's Suao and Dongao townships, since Friday, the CEOC said.
Rescue workers continued to search for 23 people reported missing on the highway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Megi leaves 11 dead 23 missing in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Twenty-three people on two Chinese tour groups were still missing Saturday morning after 435 stranded people had been brought to safety in the non-stop rescue effort on the Suhua Highway in eastern Taiwan, authorities said.

With the skies clearing and the rainstorm brought on by Typhoon Megi subsiding, six helicopter sorties airlifted the remaining 54 people stranded at the 114th- km mark of the highway in the county of Yilan, according to the Central Emergency Operation Center.
According to the Tourism Bureau, as of 7: 45 am Saturday, a total of 272 people on Chinese tour groups have been rescued.
A group of 21 people, including 19 Chinese nationals from Guangdong Province and their local tour guide and driver with Harula Tour Company, remained unaccounted for.
A female Chinese leader of a group from Beijing and a Taiwanese bus driver with Hong Tai Travel Company were also missing.

Their badly damaged tour bus was found partly buried under heaps of rocks and debris. It is believed that the two might have rolled out of the vehicle as it tumbled into the valley. Tourists on this group managed to got off the bus in time.

A group of representatives is scheduled to arrive from China Saturday on behalf of the families of the missing tourists from Guangdong. The National Immigration Agency will assist in expediting their entry by streamlining the visa process.
In the coastal town of Suao in Yilan County, a total of nine dead bodies have been dug out after Bai Yun Temple and houses nearby were hit by mudslides during the heavy rainstorm.
Two more bodies were recovered elsewhere in the township Saturday, bringing the death toll to 11.
Transportation Minister Mao Chih-kuo said the most important task now is to find the missing individuals and to clear up the roads.
President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Wu Den-yih are expected to survey the damage and to visit with those affected by the typhoon on Saturday.

Typhoon MegiXthe strongest Pacific rainstorm since 1990Xwreaked havoc across Taiwan dumping more than 1,200 mm of rain in just over 48 hours, mostly in the northern and eastern parts of the country. The typhoon left 36 people dead in the Philippines and was making her way to southern China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Institutions awarded for hiring the disadvantaged

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has awarded 48 public and private institutions for employing a sufficient number of mentally and physically challenged workers.

This is the eighth year the Golden Wingspan Award has been given to encourage the hiring of this group of disadvantaged people, said CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsun at the award presentation ceremony Friday.

The award recipients in the public sector range from police departments to local libraries. They share a commonality -- their hiring of disabled people amount to at least 3 percent of every 34 employees hired by them, said Su Chao-ju, deputy chief of Disabled Persons Employment and Training at the CLA's Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training.
However, Su said that the new employment system is more relaxed for private businesses, which are required to have only 1.5 disabled workers per 100 employees.
The employment policy was adopted in July 2008. In less than a year, 12,000 mentally and physically challenged people have successfully entered the job market, said Su.
The laborers are able to fulfill many kinds of work tasks, Su added.
Aside from the policy, the rewarded institutions were reviewed in terms of creating a barrier-free environment, providing adequate counseling service, and offering long-term employment contracts.

DOC.HEADLINE: AP responds to Taiwan government's protest

TEXT.P: The Associated Press responded Saturday to protests by the government of Taiwan over alleged distortions of President Ma Ying-jeou's comments in an exclusive interview, saying that the controversy involved "mainly matters of emphasis".

Based on an interview with the president, the AP reported on Tuesday, among other things, that Ma "suggested that those political talks (with China) could start as early as a second four-year term if he wins re-election in 2012". The president and other officials said this was not what Ma had said.

"We understand that this is a very sensitive and important issue for the government and people of Taiwan. We believe that a fair reading of the interview transcript and the article shows that the AP conveyed the essential facts about Ma's views. However, we understand the issues that have led to the complaint, " said John Daniszewski, the AP's Senior Managing Editor.

"President Ma's position is that any opening for talks on political issues with China should move in step with the public and parliament in Taiwan, that he has no timetable, and that resolving all outstanding economic issues are his priority, "Daniszewski was quoted as saying in an AP dispatch from Taipei.

In response, Johnny Chi-Chen Chiang, minister of Taiwan's Government Information Office, said that "by having the president's remarks clarified, people get to know where the issues lie and can better understand Taiwan's position on cross-strait policies".
The AP article came after Chiang sent a letter to Daniszewski on Wednesday demanding that the agency clarify the matter by issuing a correction of its report.

Instead of an apology, the article said that "the government of Taiwan has objected to an AP dispatch based on an interview Tuesday with President Ma Ying- jeou, saying that certain paraphrases used in the article distorted the president's message and contained errors of emphasis and fact".

"The disputed passages concerned the degree to which the president is open to a political dialogue with Beijing, the likelihood of such talks in the near future, and specifically whether he suggested a dialogue on political issues could take place as soon as his second term of office, if he is re-elected in 2012," it said.
"The objections cited by Chiang and other government officials were mainly matters of emphasis," Daniszewski was quoted as saying.
The article compared the main points contained in the earlier report with what Taiwan officials said should have been the important message.

The earlier article prompted Ma to hold a hastily arranged press conference on Tuesday night, at which he said that economic issues should take precedence over political issues in terms of Taiwan's relationship with mainland China and that there was no timetable for political talks.
During the interview, he did not make any connection between a possible second term and discussions with the Chinese on political issues, said the president.

Despite his clarification and similar statements by other officials, some commentators insisted that the AP report showed Ma's intention to start political negotiations with Beijing if he wins re-election.

The issue is controversial because there are concerns among certain segments of Taiwanese society that after the two sides signed a landmark free-trade agreement in June, Ma's administration will face pressure from Beijing to begin a political dialogue, which they believe would ultimately include discussions about Beijing's goal of eventually unifying with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows not to give up on any possible landslide survivors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/10 14:15:27 (By Jenny W. Hsu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou ordered rescuers Saturday to step up the search for possible survivors in the landslide disaster triggered by Typhoon Megi on the Suhua Highway in eastern Taiwan.
"We won't give up any hope of finding survivors, " Ma said during a visit to a disaster response center in Yilan County, which was hardest hit by the heavy rainfall brought by the storm.
Transportation Minister Mao Chih-kuo said the foremost important task now is to find the missing individuals and to clear up the roads.
In addition to 11 people confirmed killed in the typhoon, Taiwan's authorities and rescue teams are searching for 26 missing people.

Among the missing, a 21-person tour group that included 19 Chinese tourists from China's Guangdong Province, their tour guide and bus driver were still unaccounted for as of Saturday morning. They were believed to have been traveling on the Suhua Highway -- a major highway on Taiwan's eastern side, connecting Yilan and Hualien counties, when heavy rain and rockslides caused a section of the highway to collapse.

A Taiwanese bus driver and a Chinese tour group leader from another tour bus, belonging to Hong Tai Travel Co., were also missing. Pieces of the tour bus has been located buried beneath heaps of debris. It is believed that the tour guide and driver might have rolled out of the vehicle as it tumbled into the valley. The tourists in the group managed to get off the bus in time.

A group of five representatives is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan from China this afternoon on behalf of the families of the missing Chinese tourists. The National Immigration Agency will assist in expediting their entry by streamlining the visa process.

Meanwhile, Yilan County firefighting officials have also reported that a couple in a small truck and a driver from a small passenger vehicle were also missing. Earlier, rescue teams successfully evacuated 435 people in the non-stop, two- day rescue effort on Suhua Highway, the Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC) said Saturday.

As the rain brought on by Typhoon Megi has subsided, visibility has improved, enabling the SWAT team to dispatch six helicopters on Saturday morning to airlift the remaining 54 people left stranded at the 114 kilometer section of the highway.

Typhoon Megi -- the strongest Pacific rainstorm wreaked havoc across the country by dumping more than 1,200 mm of continuous rainfall, mostly in the northeastern parts of Taiwan in over 48 hours. The typhoon has already killed 36 people in the Philippines and is making her way to southern China.

Of the more than 400 people who were stranded, 274 were Chinese tourists. As of 7: 45 a.m. Saturday, 272 of the 274 Chinese tourists and their tour guides and drivers have been rescued, according to the Tourism Bureau.

In terms of the 11 people confirmed dead, nine of them were buried when a house located next to Bai Yun temple in the coastal town Suao in Yilan County, collapsed during the heavy rainstorm. Their corpses have been dug out. A small- sized excavator has been mobilized to aid the rescue team in its search effort.
Two other bodies were found elsewhere in the township -- one inside a residential home and another near a naval port.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon-related agricultural loss over NT$48 million: COA

TEXT.P: The agricultural damage brought on by Typhoon Megi was NT$48.36 million (US$1.56 million) as of Saturday morning, said the Council of Agriculture (COA) Saturday in its latest updates.

The COA said that due to the convergence of Typhoon Megi's periphery and seasonal winds, since Oct. 17, a total of 146 hectares of farmland in Taipei, Yilan, Hualien, and Taitung have been destroyed by rainwater.
The monetary loss for crop goods was at least NT$23.85 million. Most of the damages were done to leeks, green onions, and rice paddies, the council said.
Damages to live stock were reported at NT$8.52 million. A total of 21,200 fowls were reportedly killed in the heavy rain.
The fishery industry also suffered a loss of NT$8.04 million, said the council.
Another update is expected to be released later this afternoon.

The powerful rainstorm and strong gust of Typhoon Megi have triggered fatal mudslides and floods in mostly northeastern Taiwan. The latest death toll reported by the Central Emergency Operation Center was 11, with 26 people, including a 20-person Chinese tour group, still missing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Road traffic to east enters dark age

TEXT.P: The Suhua Highway, a vital road to Taiwan's "backyard garden" Hualien on the scenic eastern coast, was broken off by deadly rockslides Friday after it was pounded by record-breaking downpours from Typhoon Megi.

The central government was blasted by furious Hualien residents, who have been yearning for a "safe road home" for many years but kept being disappointed. For the poor upkeep of the highway built in 1932 during the Japanese colonial rule, Premier Wu Den-yih apologized.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the latest misfortune of the scenic winding coastal road connecting two eastern Taiwan counties -- Yilan and Hualien:
United Daily News:

After Typhoon Megi battered the Suhua Highway Thursday, eastern Taiwan has begun the longest "road-locked month" in its history. Directorate General of Highways (DGH) said the section between Suao and Dongao of the road was hit by several serious rockslides. "The highway cannot be fixed until Nov. 20 at the earliest, " it noted.
Hualien county chief Fu Kun-chi asked President Ma Ying-jeou to at once begin the long-anticipated construction project aimed at improving the accident-prone roadway.

Fu denounced that such a fragile but vital road "is not only a problem that concerns 23 million Taiwan people's traffic and life, it has harmed the country's national dignity, " referring to the death of some 100 people every year on the cliff-edge highway to Hualien County which he described as a showcase of Taiwan's tourism.
Liberty Times:
"If construction improvements won't begin before the end of the year, the Hualien County government will do it by itself," Fu said.

Responding to the call, Premier Wu underlined at the Legislative Yuan Friday that it is the government's firm policy to fix roadways, promising that as soon as the highway improvement project passes environmental impact assessments, the government will begin construction.

However, Green Party convener Pan Han-sheng criticized Fu for being too emotional. Judging from the road breaks caused by "indirect attacks" of a typhoon, the fact proves that the surrounding terrain on the highway is very vulnerable, he said.

As the global climate changes, any construction work on the Suhua Highway in the future is expected to face tough challenges due to the extremely arduous climate condition, Pan said. He suggested the government should prioritize plans to expand the existing railway system to the east.
China Times:

DGH Secretary-General Chen Mao-nan stressed that the Suhua Highway is not so fragile as many people have described. It was damaged so badly only because the rainfall was too heavy in a short time, he said.
In the future, traffic on the road will be suspended whenever the agency detects unusual amounts of rainfall, Chen noted.

In the Ministry of Transportation and Communications-initiated improvement project, the Suao-Tongau section, which suffered the most severe damage during the Megi-triggered rockslides, will be the first to be improved, with plans to build a 3.5 kilometer-long tunnel and a 3.5 kilometer-long bridge to bypass the dangerous highway.

The construction, however, cannot be completed before 2018 if it starts next year even if there are no glitches. This means travelers must wait for at least eight years to have a safe road to Hualien. (Oct. 23, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Megi the fierce catfish

TEXT.P: Typhoon Megi, which means "catfish" in the Korean language, brought massive rainfall to Yilan County in northeastern Taiwan over the past two days, leading to serious flooding around the county and severe landslides on the Suhua Highway, which connects the county with Hualien in the east of the country.
The disaster can be attributed to damage of Yilan's natural flood prevention capacity in recent years, due to a vast area of farmland that has been used to build luxury houses.

Statistics compiled by academic groups reveal that over the past five years, an average of 300 luxury homes are built on farmland in the county every year. It is estimated that 400 hectares of flood prevention areas have been lost as a result.

Forecasts on Typhoon Megi issued by the Central Weather Bureau have also been criticized as inaccurate because they failed to predict the heavy rainfall in Yilan. In addition, the current practice in which typhoon warnings focus mainly on the intensity of wind rather than rain does not match the reality that drastic rainfall is far more of a problem.
Megi, the fierce catfish, has taught us another painful lesson.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese opera troupe displays `soft power' in Britain
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/23/10 16:02:33 (By Jennifer Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The leader of the renowned Ming Hwa Yuan Gezai opera troupe from Taiwan hailed British audiences as "bosom friends" Friday and voiced hope that the troupe will have another chance to perform in the U.K. capital to bolster in-depth cultural exchanges between the two countries.

"Britain has a very rich and profound cultural industry, which is something Ming Hwa Yuan has long yearned for," Sun Tsui-feng told CNA one day after the troupe performed at Rose Bruford College in southeast London on its first visit to the British capital.
"We have noticed the European people's love and appreciation for culture. As performers, we love such audiences," she said.

Ming Hwa Yuan also performed in the Scottish capital of Edinburgh before visiting London. In the two cities, the troupe performed specially designed short versions of two dramas -- "Lovebirds Spears" and "General of the Empire."
Ming Hwa Yuan staged shows in Germany, the Czech Republic and Austria before traveling to Britain and will proceed to the Netherlands on the last leg of its 10-day European trip.
The London college's website described the show as "a feast of splendor, with music, theater, martial arts, dance and traditional art forms."
Rose Bruford College Principal Michael Earley praised Ming Hwa Yuan's presentation.
He said he hoped to visit Taiwan next year and to see Ming Hwa Yuan perform the full showings of the two dramas.

Katharine Chang, Taiwan's representative to Britain, described the performance as "marvelous and very successful" and said she would invite the group to perform again in London next year to "allow the international community to get to know such splendid groups from Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's representative to Vietnam visits Ho Chi Minh City
DOC.DATELINE: Hanoi, Vietnam, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/10 16:41:46 (By Tony Fang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new representative to Vietnam traveled Friday to Ho Chi Minh City, an economic center in the southeast Asian country, for a two-day visit to Taiwanese businesses operating there.
It was Huang Chih-peng's first visit to Ho Chi Minh City in southern Vietnam since the former director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade took office Oct. 6 as the de facto ambassador to Vietnam.
In a meeting with Taiwanese entrepreneurs later that day, Huang promised that his office will do its utmost to remove barriers to investment and help obtain the best possible business benefits.

Taiwan maintains no diplomatic relations with the socialist country, but sees Vietnam as an important economic and trade partner in the region. According to Huang, Taiwan is Vietnam's second-largest source of foreign investment.
Taiwan's government statistics show that Taiwan exported US$6.3 billion-worth of products to Vietnam last year and imported goods from the country worth US$1.1 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Fixing broken tax system

TEXT.P: In his Oct. 10 National Day address, President Ma Ying-jeou pledged to build a just society and stressed that the government will not overlook fairness while pursuing economic growth.
To honor its promise, the government must make sure every citizen pays the taxes they ought to pay, which is the basic requirement for a just society.

Taiwan's tax system, which is tilted excessively in favor of the wealthy, is responsible for the widening wealth gap in this country. In 2009, the income of the richest 20 percent of families in Taiwan was 8.22 times that of the poorest 20 percent, the widest gap since records began.

At present, individual income tax accounts for 30 percent of the government's revenue, and salary earners pay as much as 75 percent of these taxes. Rich people who generate their wealth from stock dividends, business profits or rental housing, contribute only 25 percent.

Under these circumstances, the government should increase the tax rates on securities and property transactions, as well as overseas income, in order to create a redistribution of wealth. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 23, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign minister to review cooperative ventures in Africa
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/10 17:15:38 (By Emmanuel Tseng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang departed for Africa late Friday to review cooperation projects with two of Taiwan's diplomatic allies there, the Foreign Ministry said Saturday.
According to the ministry, Yang will visit Burkina Faso and Sao Tome and Principe, both of which maintain full diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
While there, Yang will chair an Oct. 27 meeting in Sao Tome with Taiwanese diplomatic personnel in Africa to evaluate the effectiveness of the country's missions there.
Taiwan co-sponsors loans, village development and medical care projects with the Burkina Faso government. In Sao Tome and Principe, it is helping to eliminate malaria and narrow the digital divide.

DOC.HEADLINE: No travel warning for Chinese tourists: tourism association

TEXT.P: The China-based Cross-Strait Tourism Exchange Association rebutted Saturday media reports that China had issued a travel alert for Taiwan after 21 Chinese tourists were still unaccounted for in northeastern Taiwan following landslides caused by Typhoon Megi.

The association's Taipei office director, Fan Gueishan, said the Beijing-based National Tourism Administration only issued a reminder to all Taiwan-bound Chinese tourists to pay close attention to the movement of the typhoon and to make "reasonable" arrangements in order to minimize any possible typhoon-related harm.
He stressed that contrary to the reports, the administration had not listed Taiwan as a travel warning area.

According to the Tourism Bureau, Fan arrived a day earlier in Yilan County, the worst-hit area, to meet with the Chinese tourists evacuated from the landslide- struck Suhua Highway. As of Saturday afternoon, a 21-member tour group from Guangdong Province, including one Taiwanese bus driver and a Chinese tour leader from another group, were still unaccounted for. All the other 272 Chinese tourists stranded on the highway had been rescued.
Fan said the situation should not affect any future travel by Chinese nationals to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Megi downgraded to tropical storm
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/10 17:42:04 (By Wang Shu-fen, Ni Kuo-yen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Typhoon Megi was downgraded to a tropical storm Saturday following its landfall in China's southeastern province of Fujian, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said that day.
Forecasters said the storm remained a threat to the outlying island of Kinmen, although warnings had been lifted for Taiwan and the Penghu archipelago.
However, heavy rain was also expected to continue Saturday in Tainan, Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Penghu counties, they said.
As of 4 p.m., Megi was centered 80 km west-southwest of Kinmen, packing maximum sustained wind of 101 kph and gusts of 126 kph. It was moving north at 11 kph, according to the CWB.

In light of the rough sea conditions caused by the storm, Kinmen's Harbor Bureau decided to continue the previous day's suspension of ferry services between Kinmen and the Chinese cities of Xiamen and Quanzhou.
Air services linking Kinmen and Taiwan also remained suspended.

DOC.HEADLINE: Human error blamed for 2008 CAL flight incident
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/10 17:58:00 (By Wang Shu-fen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: An accident involving a China Airlines (CAL) flight destined for the Indonesian island of Bali Sept. 20, 2008 that injured 24 passengers and cabin crew was caused by pilot error, according to an investigative report released Friday by the Aviation Safety Council (ASC).

The report on the two-year investigation said the two pilots of flight CI-687 were found responsible for flying the Boeing 747-400 plane into powerful turbulence over the South China Sea after misreading the plane's radar.
The cabin chief and one passenger sustained serious injuries in the incident, and three other cabin crew and 19 passengers were slightly injured.

The ASC also concluded in the report that the Civil Aeronautics Administration should reinforce its checks on the cabin operations of all local airlines after finding that the CAL's cabin crew guide lacks clearly-defined standard rules for handling turbulence.
The ASC is an independent government agency established to investigate and prevent re-occurrence of civilian air incidents and accidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Officials offer comfort to stranded Chinese tourists

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Deputy Chairman Liu Teh-hsun on Saturday visited three Chinese tourists who sustained minor injuries when they were trapped on the typhoon-battered Suhua Highway the previous day.
Liu expressed the government's concern for their welfare and said it is doing everything it can to locate other tourists who remained unaccounted for.
He said the government will closely monitor the progress of the injured tourists and promised that it will provide all necessary support to ensure their full recovery.
The tourists were hospitalized at Luodong's Poh-ai Hospital in Yilan County, the area worst-affected by the typhoon.

As of press time, 272 stranded Chinese tourists had been safely evacuated from the landslide-hit highway, while the fate of another 21 Chinese nationals still remained unknown. Rescue teams, military personnel and excavation equipment were working hard at the scene to get everyone accounted for.
Responding to criticism that the government was putting the safety of the Chinese tourists ahead of Taiwanese or other foreign tourists, the Tourism Bureau said the accusation was unfounded.

An official denied that there was any preferential treatment during the rescue process and explained that the reason the bureau only included the Chinese tourists on its tally of people rescued was "because they are the only tourists that are required to report their exact whereabouts while in Taiwan."

Chen said that Taiwanese travelers and tourists from countries other than China are not required to report their itineraries to the bureau and pointed out that there was therefore no way of knowing how many non-Chinese were involved in the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese steelmaker to show eco-friendly results

TEXT.P: China Steel Corp., Taiwan's biggest steelmaker, will show how it has contributed to reducing carbon emissions and recycling waste material at a green technology show slated to open Oct. 25.

"Car makers are trying to make their cars lighter to save energy. Therefore, China Steel has created high-intensity steel for vehicles," Andrew Sung, vice president of the company's Production Division, told CNA Saturday.

This type of strong steel can be made thinner, which can help reduce the weight of a vehicle by 10 percent. The weight loss will lead to a 6 percent to 8 percent decrease in gasoline consumption, he said during the run-up to the Taiwan International Green Industry Show (TiGiS) scheduled to take place Oct. 25-28.

In addition, the company has developed high-quality electrical steel that can enhance motor efficiency. Each metric ton of such steel is able to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 1.51 metric tons, Sung said.
China Steel, in which the government has a stake, also supplies its surplus steam to 11 neighboring factories at a relatively low cost, which greatly reduces these factories' use of their boilers.
"We supplied a total of 2 million metric tons of steam to these companies last year, which can be translated into 440,000 metric tons in carbon cuts per year," he said.
The company also produces 13,500 metric tons of pure water made from waste water on a daily basis.
Meanwhile, the steelmaker has been working to turn its other by-products of the iron-smelting process -- slag and coal tar -- into valuable assets.
Sung said that using slag to make cement can reduce carbon emissions by 1.4 metric tons, while coal tar can be processed for use in lithium batteries used to power electric vehicles.
"The transformation has hugely increased the value of our coal tar, as it is now 60 times more expensive than before," he said.
China Steel will display these technologies at the TiGiS, which will have a total of 180 companies occupying some 320 booths.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan beats South Korea in baseball Intercontinental Cup

TEXT.P: An outstanding performance lifted Taiwan to an 11-5 win over South Korea in the opening game of the 17th Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament in central Taiwan's Taichung City Saturday.
Taiwan, which also hosted the tournament the last time it was played in 2006, defeated its perennial rival with a total of 15 hits, including a solo home run by Lin Chih-sheng in the 3rd inning.
Taiwan was set to face the Czech Republic the following day in one of the two round-robin groups. The best three teams in each group will enter the second round.
Outfielder Lin Che-hsuan hit a single at his first bat, sparking a two-run attack for Taiwan and building up an early lead.
Taiwan then went big in the 5th inning as Chen Chun-hsiu slammed a three-run homer to pull up to 7-1.
However, South Korea made a comeback in the 7th inning, pulling the team back to 5-7.
Taiwan then answered with five back-to-back hits in the 8th inning, extending its lead to 11-5, which it maintained to the end of the game.
The game marked Taiwan's 10th win against South Korea in the tournament, including six in a row since 1991.
The Korean roster was mainly composed of young players from the professional farm league.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon-related agricultural damage over NT$55 million: COA

TEXT.P: The latest total for typhoon-related agricultural damage in Taiwan had reached NT$55.71 million (US$1.8 million) as of Saturday, the Council of Agricultural (COA) said that day.

Most of the damage was to farmland, which sustained NT$26.97 million in losses, with over 404 hectares of crops in Taipei, Yilan, Hualien, and Taitung counties suffering at least 44 percent destruction due to the heavy rain brought by Typhoon Megi since Oct. 17.

A total NT$8.59 million of damage to livestock was recorded, while the fishery sector faced NT$12.21 million in losses. The COA said fish farms raising white prawn, tilapia and groupers were the hardest-hit.
Losses of usable farmland were estimated at NT$7.83 million, with another NT$110,000-worth of poultry facilities destroyed.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 dead, 26 missing as Typhoon Megi leaves Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/10 19:38:38 (By S. H. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Twelve people were confirmed dead and 26 remained missing Saturday as Typhoon Megi moved toward China after causing serious damage in northeastern Taiwan, especially in Yilan County.

As of 5 p.m., 12 people in Yilan County had been confirmed dead, including nine buried by a mudslide that inundated the Bai Yun temple in Suao Township, the Central Emergency Operation Center reported.

According to Interior Minister Jiang Yih-huah, 26 people -- 20 Chinese and six Taiwanese -- remained unaccounted for, including 20 Chinese tourists, a Taiwanese tour guide and two Taiwanese tour bus drivers.
The three other missing Taiwanese people were a car driver and a couple driving a small truck.
By around 7 p.m., the small truck had been found by rescuers, but whereabouts of the couple remained unknown. The car and one of the two tour buses were still missing.
After an all-night rescue effort, a total of 435 people trapped on the Suhua Highway linking Yilan and Hualien counties had been evacuated.
Meanwhile, two teams of fire fighters and rescuers were still searching the rugged area of the Suhua Highway section between the 114 km mark and 116 km mark.
Earlier in the day, President Ma Ying-jeou inspected the disaster response center in Yilan County and ordered the relevant authorities to do their utmost to rescue the missing people.
A day earlier, Premier Wu Den-yih offered an apology to the people stranded on highway for failing to keep the road in good condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ministry counters academic over naphtha plant

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs dismissed an allegation Saturday that its decision not to hold an administrative hearing on a controversial plan to build the country's eighth naphtha cracker on coastal wetlands in central Taiwan was illegal.

The private investment project initiated by the Kuokuang Petrochemical Technology Co. (KPTC) does not require approval from the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Industrial Development Bureau, the bureau's director-general, Woody Duh, told CNA in a telephone interview.
"Since no approval is required, there is no need for the ministry to hold an administrative hearing," he said.
His remarks came one day after a local professor demanded that the ministry hold an administrative hearing on the investment project in line with the Administrative Procedure Act.
More than 1,200 local university professors and academics have expressed opposition to the project and on Aug. 3 released a joint petition stating their objections.
The academics vowed to stage a demonstration next month if the ministry fails to organize an administrative hearing on the issue.
The ministry said that it organized a public hearing on the environmental impact of the project in February in Changhua County, in which the plant is slated to be located.
The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration is now conducting an assessment on the environmental impact of the proposed plant, it added.

KPTC, a joint venture by the state-owned oil refinery CPC Corp., Taiwan and several other private companies, plans to invest up to NT$400 billion (US$12.66 billion) to construct a 4,000- hectare petrochemical complex on Changhua County's coastal wetlands near the estuary of the Jhuoshui River.

Environmentalists are strongly opposed to the project on the grounds that it will hurt the area's ecosystem, which includes migratory birds, fiddler crabs, mudskippers, mud shrimps and the almost-extinct Indo-Pacific humpback dolphin.
According to the ministry, the project is expected to generate revenue of NT$460 billion and create 18,000 jobs directly and 357,000 jobs indirectly.

The bureau has said that based on the principle of energy-effectiveness and pollution reduction, the ministry will support the establishment of the plant in the central county to replace the aging fifth naphtha cracker.

DOC.HEADLINE: Festival begins to celebrate Songshan-Haneda direct flights

TEXT.P: A two-day festival to celebrate the upcoming launch of direct flights between Taipei's Songshan Airport and Tokyo's Haneda Airport began in Taipei Saturday, drawing the attention of large crowds of people.

The Songshan-Haneda flights, scheduled to begin Oct. 31, are expected to boost the number of people traveling between the two countries each year from the current 2 million people to 3 million, according to the Japan Interchange Association (JIA) , the organizer of the fair.

The event, held in Taipei's Xinyi shopping district, featured an exhibition of the traditional Japanese tea ceremony, a Japanese taiko drum performance and a rock concert, as well as a lucky draw and various promotions by travel agencies and air companies to generate interest in the new flight services.

"The launch of Songshan-Haneda flights will help promote the 2010-2011 Taiwan- Japan tourism exchange year, " said Tadashi Imai, head of the JIA Taipei office, which acts as Japan's representative office in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties.
Imai was referring to a campaign designed to promote cultural and artistic exchanges between Japan and Taiwan after the third Taiwan-Japan Tourism Summit Forum that took place in March.
All four carriers that will provide Songshan-Haneda flights -- China Airlines (CAL) , EVA Airways, Japan Airlines (JAL) and All Nippon Airways (ANA) -- also touted their offerings at the fair.
According to the carriers, they will each offer two flights from Songshan to Haneda per day, with fares of around NT$14,000 (US$454) for round-trip tickets, with stays of up to 30 days.

Songshan Airport, which used to be the country's main gateway, served direct flights to Haneda until 1979, when international flights were relocated to Chiang Kai-shek Airport, now known as Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China miss glittering event in Tokyo over name issue
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/10 21:47:50 (By Yang Ming-chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese and Chinese movie stars missed a glitzy Oscar-style event at the opening of the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival Saturday due to a dispute over Taiwan's name.

Shortly before celebrities began to walk a green carpet to mark the start of the festival, the head of the Chinese delegation, Jiang Ping, told organizers that the Taiwanese delegation must not attend under the name "Taiwan" but should use the designation of "Taiwan, China" or "Chinese Taipei" -- the title Taiwan uses when participating in the Olympic Games.
Jiang said that if his demand was not met, the Chinese delegation would boycott the green carpet walk and other festival-related events.
The Taiwanese delegation, headed by Chen Chih-kuan, director of the Government Information Office's Department of Motion Pictures Affairs, however, refused to accede to the Chinese demand.
Chen said the delegation applied to attend this year's event under the name of Taiwan as it has in past years. "We have no reason to make a concession this time around," he added.
"We will respect the arrangements made by the organizers under the prerequisite that our national dignity is not undermined, " Chen said.
With both sides sticking to their guns, the green carpet walk finished without them and none of the stars from either side took part in the glittering "green carpet walk."
Noted actors and actresses from both sides said they were surprised and frustrated by the dispute.

After an 18-year hiatus, the film festival will feature a special Taiwan section in which six Taiwanese box-office hits, including Monga, Juliets, the Fourth Painting, Let the Wind Carry Me, Zoom Hunting and Taipei Exchanges -- will be screened.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese tennis player advances to final in Seoul
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/10 22:26:36 (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tennis player Lu Yen-hsun advanced to the final of the Samsung Securities Cup in Seoul, South Korea Saturday after defeating Florent Serra of France 6-3, 6-4 in a semi-final match.
World No. 39 Lu credited his good performance to tips from his German coach before the match.
The 27-year-old will face world No. 66, South Africa's Kevin Anderson, in Sunday's final.
Lu climbed to No. 39 in the world -- the highest ranking of his career -- after picking up valuable points in the Shanghai Masters in China earlier this month.

Dirk Hordorff, Lu's coach and overseas agent, said last week that cracking the top 40 is not easy for any Asian player, and he attributed Lu's success to his fighting spirit and his capacity for hard work.

The Samsung Securities Cup is a professional tennis tournament played on outdoor hard courts. It is currently part of the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) Challenger Tour and has been held annually in Seoul since 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon-related agricultural damage over NT$55 million: COA

TEXT.P: The latest total for typhoon-related agricultural damage in Taiwan had reached NT$55.71 million (US$1.8 million) as of Saturday, the Council of Agricultural (COA) said that day.

Most of the damage was to farmland, which sustained NT$26.97 million in losses, with over 404 hectares of crops in Taipei, Yilan, Hualien, and Taitung counties suffering at least 44 percent destruction due to the heavy rain brought by Typhoon Megi since Oct. 17.

A total NT$8.59 million of damage to livestock was recorded, while the fishery sector faced NT$12.21 million in losses. The COA said fish farms raising white prawn, tilapia and groupers were the hardest-hit.
Losses of usable farmland were estimated at NT$7.83 million, with another NT$110,000-worth of poultry facilities destroyed.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 dead, 26 missing as Typhoon Megi leaves Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/10 19:38:38 (By S. H. Huang and Flor Wang)

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 24, or the 17th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1632: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the Dutch microscopist who was the first man to see bacteria, is born.
1648: France and the Holy Roman Empire sign the Treaty of Westphalia, ending the Thirty Years' War.
1861: The chief justice of California sends the first U.S. transcontinental telegram from San Francisco to President Abraham Lincoln in Washington.
1901: Ann Edison Taylor, 43, a teacher, is unhurt after going over Niagara Falls in a padded barrel to raise money to help pay her mortgage.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung is opened to traffic. An inauguration ceremony is held at the Taichung Park.
1922: The Irish parliament adopts a constitution for an Irish Free State.
1929: Share prices collapse as nearly 13 million shares change hands in panic selling on the New York Stock Exchange in what became known as "Black Thursday."
1931: Notorious Chicago gangster Al Capone, who has dominated organized crime for the past six years, receives an 11-year sentence and an US$80,000 fine for tax evasion.
1931: The Council of the League of Nations adopts a resolution urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: New Zealand aviator Jean Batten breaks the record by flying from Australia to England in just five days, 18 hours, and 18 minutes.
1944: The Japanese battleship "Musashi," one of the largest ever built, is sunk by U.S. planes during the Battle of Leyte Gulf.
1945: The United Nations Charter, adopted by the San Francisco Conference in June 1945 and ratified by 26 nations, formally comes into force.
1945: Vidkun Quisling, former head of the puppet government established in Norway by the Nazis in 1940, is executed at Akershus Fortress in Oslo.
1957: French fashion designer Christian Dior dies at the age of 52. He was noted for his "New Look" of 1947 that emphasized narrow shoulders, tight waists, and long, full skirts.
1960: Communist China and Mali establish diplomatic ties.
1964: Northern Rhodesia becomes independent from Britain as the Republic of Zambia, with Kenneth Kaunda as president.
1976: Mainland China's Chiang Ching, who was dragged from her bed by armed guards Oct. 6 and charged with treason, finds the going rough now that her late husband Mao Tse-tung is no longer around to protect her.
1986: Cheng Tsai-tien, 26, a communist Chinese pilot, lands his MiG-19 jet fighter in South Korea after flying it from mainland China's Shantung peninsula to seek asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: American television preacher Jim Bakker is sentenced to 45 years in jail and fined US$500,000 for swindling his followers out of millions of dollars.
1990: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes a partial revision of the Corporate Law.
1999: Gerardo Rocha, rector of the University of Santo Tomas in Chile, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
2000: The Asian Wheelchair Sports Federation is formally established, with Lai Fu-huan, deputy chairman of the ROC's National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, elected as its chairman.
2000: Former ROC Premier Hau Pei-tsun issues a statement expressing regret that three of his former colleagues in the ROC Navy have been impeached by the Control Yuan for their connection with an arms purchase scandal 10 years ago.
2001: The Kaohsiung city government holds a ground-breaking ceremony attended by President Chen Shui-bian for the southern Taiwan city's first mass rapid transit (MRT) system.
2001: The 2001 Taipei Nuclear Insurance Pools Forum opens for a three-day discussion with 31 representatives from 21 national nuclear insurance pools around the world participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman of spirit or a man of moral character will never try to save his life at the expense of his moral character. He would prefer to sacrifice his life in order to save his moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Economic Daily News: Tertiary education competitiveness

TEXT.P: In April this year, Beijing announced that Taiwan's top-scoring high school graduates can enter China's top universities without having to sit entrance examinations.

Some of these top scorers have chosen to enter Peking University or Tsinghua University in Beijing. This has been interpreted by some opinion leaders as a loss of competitiveness in Taiwan's tertiary education system.
The core of the problem, however, is not how many Taiwanese students head to China for college education. The problem is how many Chinese people choose to come to Taiwan for their college education.
A closed economic entity is unable to grow sustainably and a closed education system is even worse -- it cannot possibly nurture talent of internationally competitive caliber.
Just as a closed-door economic policy is not conducive to raising Taiwan's industrial competitiveness, a closed-door education policy will eventually dent the country's soft power.

Over the past decade, Taiwan -- which shares a common language and culture with China and is located close by -- has missed the crucial opportunity of making itself a China study stronghold, and very few Taiwanese teachers or students cross the Taiwan Strait for research or study.
Prior to 2008, Taiwan's tertiary education system had failed to adopt policies that respond to the needs of Taiwanese society, particularly the business and industrial sectors.
Luckily, the Ministry of Education has opted for further relaxing restrictions since President Ma Ying-jeou began pushing for the opening-up of cross-strait education exchanges.
The opening, however, has not been efficient enough so far. Clear educational exchange strategies and implementation measures should be mapped out. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to host Asia's largest forum on solar power

TEXT.P: A forum on solar power that will take place in Taipei Oct. 26-27, the biggest ever held in Asia, is expected to bolster the development of Taiwan's green energy industry, according to the organizers.

The 2010 Taipei Summit and PV Taiwan Forum, which has the aim of helping improve solar energy cooperation between Taiwan and various other Asian countries, will be attended by more than 90 officials from the Philippines, Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, Singapore, Germany and Taiwan, the Bureau of Foreign Trade said in a recent statement.

Taiwan is now the second-largest solar cell producer after China and has increased its solar cell production by 20 percent over the last five years, indicating that Asia has become the center of solar cell production, according to the PV Status Report 2010 released by the European Union in September.

The heads of such local solar cell makers as Motech Industries Inc., Gintech Energy Corp. and Topcell Solar International Co., will deliver speeches on the global development of solar energy at the two-day forum, the bureau said in the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: There must be 'safe road home'

TEXT.P: Seven sections of the winding cliff-edge Suhua Highway to Taiwan's "backyard garden" -- Hualien, on the scenic eastern coast -- were cut off after the region was pounded by record-breaking downpours from Typhoon Megi Friday.
At least 500 meters of the coastal highway crumbled into the Pacific Ocean, with more than 400 motorists and tourists left stranded, 23 of whom were still unaccounted for as of Sunday.
Traffic along the highway has been disrupted by landslides 210 times over the past seven years and in 2007 alone, the highway was closed 90 times, indicating the degree of its vulnerability.

Over the past several days, the latest misfortune, the worst landslides in the highway's nearly 80-year history, has sparked heated debate among politicians, environmental activists and the central and local governments, as well as local residents, on the poor upkeep of the highway, how should it be fixed or whether a new road should be built.
Some argue that the highway should be abandoned once and for all, since there is a railway system, which is much safer.
But highways and railways are not mutually replaceable, particularly since trains cannot provide door-to-door service as can road vehicles.

It is an incontrovertible truth that residents living in the two eastern counties of Yilan and Hualien need a "safe road home, " which makes it necessary to prioritize a long-anticipated construction project aimed at improving the accident-prone road as soon as possible.
Because of global climate change, any construction work on the Suhua Highway is expected to face even tougher challenges in the future due to the extremely arduous conditions there.

Another highway should be built exclusively for tourists, and this road should be managed more strictly and closed whenever unusual amounts of rainfall are detected. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 24, 20100

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese tennis player wins Samsung Cup
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/10 15:33:53 (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tennis player Lu Yen-hsun won the Samsung Securities Cup in Seoul, South Korea Sunday by trouncing Kevin Anderson of South Africa 6-3, 6-4 in the final.
After defeating Florent Serra of France 6-3, 6-4 in the semi-finals the previous day, Lu, currently the World's No. 39, finished Anderson in two straight sets. Anderson is the world's No. 66.
The 27-year-old Lu climbed to No. 39 in the world -- the highest ranking of his career -- after picking up valuable points in the Shanghai Masters in China earlier this month.
The Samsung Securities Cup is on the Challenger Tour of the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) and is played on outdoor hard courts. The tournament has been held annually in Seoul since 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Name row mars opening of Tokyo film festival

TEXT.P: Taiwanese and Chinese movie stars failed to walk the green carpet at the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival Saturday due to a dispute over Taiwan's name.

Shortly before the walk to mark the start of the festival, the head of the Chinese delegation, Jiang Ping, told organizers that the Taiwanese delegation must not attend under the name "Taiwan" but should use the designation of "Taiwan, China" or "Chinese Taipei" -- the title Taiwan uses when participating in the Olympic Games.
The Taiwanese delegation, headed by Chen Chih-kuan, director of the Government Information Office's Department of Motion Pictures Affairs, flatly refused to accede to the Chinese demand.
The row resulted in both delegations missing the glitzy event.

Taiwan, after an 18-year hiatus, is represented at the film festival this year with a special section in which six Taiwanese box-office hits -- "Monga, " "Juliets, " "The Fourth Painting, " "Let the Wind Carry Me, " "Zoom Hunting" and "Taipei Exchanges" -- are to be screened.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the name row:
United Daily News:

Taiwanese officials said the government will insist on upholding Taiwan's sovereignty and will not rule out the possibility of bowing out of the festival in the worst-case scenario. On the other hand, it will seek to resolve cross- Taiwan Strait hurdles to solicit greater space for Taiwan in the international community.

Cross-strait relations have become warmer since the signing of a major trade pact in June. But at a sensitive time, when relations between China and Japan are tense over the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, over which Taiwan also claims sovereignty, the government is watching closely to see what China's next move will be.

Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Johnny Chiang said Saturday that the GIO stands behind the Taiwanese delegation. He added that it will not budge, as sovereignty is involved in the matter.
Although the delegation missed the walk, it attended a banquet hosted by the organizers later.

Taiwan has also encountered China's interference in its participation in the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission, showing that Beijing's squeezing has extended from intergovernmental organizations to non-governmental organizations, officials said, adding that "bilateral hurdles still exist." (Oct. 24, 2010) China Times:

Taiwanese delegation leader Chen Chih-kuan said his Chinese counterpart Jiang Ping made the name-change demand before the opening of the film festival, but Chen said that he "could not accept it because the issues of sovereignty and dignity are involved."
He said he has attended many international film festivals in the past, but has never encountered such an unreasonable demand.
The organizers were also frustrated, thinking that the arts and politics are separate and that one should not interfere with the other, according to Chen.
"The films we make are aimed at the Mandarin-speaking market, as well as the Asian, European and American markets, and not just the Chinese market," Chen added.

Meanwhile, many Taiwanese lauded Chen on the Internet and panned China for its childish gambit, with some pointing out that it is a film festival, which has nothing to do with the Olympics. (Oct. 24, 2010) Liberty Times:
China's oppression of Taiwan is omnipresent, even in the arts.

Jiang not only demanded that the Taiwanese delegation walk the green carpet with the Chinese delegation at the same time, but also challenged Chen in a high- handed tone, asking: "Are you still trying to sell your films to China? Are you not Chinese?"
The organizers were frustrated by China's move, saying that such a problem has never occurred before. They asked the two sides to "coordinate between themselves."

Each year, China sends big stars to attend the event, but this year, stars such as Zhang Ziyi declined to attend, presumably due to bilateral tension over the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea.
Beijing was also probably miffed because of the screening of the Taiwanese films and the large Taiwanese delegation. (Oct. 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: One body identified, 25 missing in Suhua Highway disaster
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/10 17:27:01 (By Jenny W. Hsu and Chou Yung-chieh)

TEXT.P: The woman was identified by her family as 54-year-old Liu Yun-jun, a special education teacher who was lauded by her colleagues as a compassionate and selfless individual. Her body was found near the 112.8 km mark of the highway at around 9 am, three days after Typhoon Megi thrashed northeastern Taiwan.

The death toll as of that day stood at 13, with 25, including a 21-person Chinese tour group from Guangdong Province and Tien Yuan, a Chinese tour leader working for the Hong Tai Travel Co., still reported missing.Military personnel and rescue teams had been working for nearly three days non-stop to comb the area for the missing. The government said the operation will not stop until all measures have been taken.
A day earlier, a delegation from China representing the missing tour group arrived in Taiwan to help with the search effort.
"All I want is to find my daughter as soon as possible, hopefully today," said Tien's mother. Tien's husband reportedly went inside the disaster zone to help locate his missing wife, but to no avail.
The searchers had found some broken vehicle parts suspected to belong to the bus used by the Hong Tai group and some reports said personal belongings such shoes and shirts had also been found.
The heavy rain brought by Typhoon Megi also fiercely battered nearby residential areas in the county. Thousands of homes in Suao Township lost power and hundreds of hectares of crops were destroyed.
The Yilan County government has put out a call for help asking the public to donate goods such as diapers for children and adults, disposable underwear, oatmeal and personal hygiene kits.
Several non-government organizations such as the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and World Vision Taiwan have dispatched volunteers to help with the massive clean-up work.
The latest typhoon-related agricultural losses in Taipei, Hualien, Yilan, and Taitung counties reported by the Council of Agricultural amounted to NT$58.56 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan defeats Czech in Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament

TEXT.P: Taiwan took advantage of a slow start by the Czech Republic to clinch a 6-0 victory Sunday, its second win in the Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament being held in Taichung City, central Taiwan.

The Czech Republic team, also known as AVG Draci Brno and a 16-time champion in that country's professional baseball league since 1995, seemed to be off-form, giving up 11 hits and six runs through the first four innings.

It was held scoreless by Taiwan's starting pitcher Pan Wei-lun, who threw four strikes in three innings, and the team struggled to make its first hit until Zyma Petr knocked out a single in the sixth inning.
