DOC.HEADLINE: Parent-child activity targets diabetic children

TEXT.P: A series of health education activities were held Sunday for children with diabetes to address the importance of self-monitoring of blood sugar levels and maintaining a healthy lifestyle, the organizers said that day.

Fifty families with type 1 diabetic children were invited by the Taiwan Association for Diabetic Children (TADC) to learn more about diabetes management through interactive dramas, games, exercises and lectures, said TADC Director- General Lo Fu-sung.

"There are 400 to 500 new cases of juvenile diabetes, or type 1 diabetes, detected in Taiwan each year, " said Lo, who is also a pediatric doctor at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Linkou. "Regular checking of blood sugar levels is vital for preventing the development of diabetic complications," he said.
TADC Secretary-General Wu Chih-ching noted that child patients are different from adults in that children usually do not understand the severity of the problem and fail to get medical treatment.

Speaking from her own experience, Wu said that her son, diagnosed with diabetes at the age of 6, used to run around the house four to five times a day whenever it was time to prick his finger for a drop of blood. "I had to warn him: If you want to live, you have to do this," she said.

One female patient who has struggled with diabetes since the age of 10, said that "little kids are afraid of needles but they have parents to look after them. When older, teenagers skip blood monitoring because they don't want to be labeled as freaks by their classmates."

The patient, surnamed Lai, developed retinal deterioration and kidney illness at the age of 24 because of her carelessness in monitoring her blood sugar levels and maintaining a healthy lifestyle over the years.

"We hope that all children, with or without diabetes, can learn more about the disease, because there is a chance they could meet a diabetic friend at some point in their lives, " said Wu, who also complained that there is not enough information available about diabetes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Families of missing Chinese tourists to come to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/10 18:59:27 (By Chen Shun-hsieh, Kuo Mai-land and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Family members of 19 Chinese tourists from China's Guangdong Province who remained unaccounted for Sunday are expected to arrive in Taiwan Tuesday and Wednesday, according to a travel agency source.
The Guangdong tourist group, hosted by Taipei-based Harula Tour, was supposed to have left for home Friday, according to Wu Chao-ping, a Harula Tour manager.

The tour bus carrying the 19 tourists was believed to have been traveling north on the Suhua Highway -- a scenic cliff-edge highway on Taiwan's eastern coast that connects Yilan and Hualien counties -- when heavy rain and rockslides caused several sections of the highway to collapse.
Five officials from China Travel Service's Gongbei branch, which organized the tourist group, flew into Taiwan Saturday in the aftermath of the disaster triggered by Typhoon Megi.

Seven city officials from Guangdong's Zhuhai City were also scheduled to arrive in Taiwan by nightfall Sunday to provide assistance. Of the 19 missing Chinese tourists, eight are officials working with the Gongbei Land Taxation Bureau in Zhuhai, according to the Taiwan Association of Travel Agents.
Meanwhile that day, three high-ranking officials from the Beijing-based Cross Strait Tourism Association (CSTA), departed from Beijing for Taiwan.

In related news, a Taiwanese bus driver and a Chinese tour group leader from another tour bus, belonging to the Taipei-based Hong Tai Travel Co., were also missing. Pieces of the tour bus were located buried beneath heaps of debris and it was believed the tour guide and driver might have been thrown from the vehicle when it tumbled into a ravine. The tourists in the group managed to get off the bus in time.
Three family members of the missing Chinese tour group leader, identified as Tian Yuan, also arrived in Taiwan Saturday.
Typhoon Megi wreaked havoc across Taiwan Oct. 21-22, dumping more than 1,200 mm of continuous rainfall in 48 hours, mostly on northeastern parts of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suhua Highway improvement plan to be expedited: EPA

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Sunday that it will convene a second committee meeting on a road improvement plan for the Suhua Highway and expressed hope that the process will be expedited in order that work can begin on the landslide-stricken highway as soon as possible.

The Suhua Highway was constructed in the 1930s and serves as the main road connection for the eastern counties of Yilan and Hualien. The 180-km winding route touted for its beautiful natural scenery is one of the most popular destinations for foreign tourists.

However, the road is often subject to landslides, especially during periods of heavy rain. A government plan to build a Suhua Freeway has met with strong opposition from environmental groups, which argue that such a major infrastructure project will cause long-lasting eco-hazards to the local landscape. According to these groups, improving the rail system would be a more efficient and environmentally friendly solution.
Green groups have also suggested that the government limit use of the road by heavy vehicles.

Speaking to the press, EPA Minister Stephen Shen, who traveled to Yilan County to lead a massive clean-up operation following severe flooding in Suao Township, said the second environmental impact assessment committee meeting will be held Nov. 1.

According to the law, all members of the review committee must be notified at least seven days ahead of such a meeting, but Shen said that due to the urgent need to improve the highway, an exception will be made in this case.
The EPA released a statement expressing sympathy for the victims who were killed or injured on the highway and promised to help construct a safer road.

As of Sunday, 13 people had been confirmed dead and 25 people, including a 21-person Chinese tour group and a Chinese tour leader were still missing. Search and rescue workers were continuing to comb the area for survivors and bodies. That afternoon, seven divers from the Marine Corps were also deployed to help with the search.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien hoteliers worried about tourism after highway disaster
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/10 20:05:39 (By Andrew Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Hualien hotel operators expressed grave concern Sunday about the outlook for tourism in the region after the major road traffic route in eastern Taiwan, connecting YiIan and Hualien, was closed due to several landslides.

Torrential rain brought by Typhoon Megi battered northeastern Taiwan Oct. 21-22, triggering serious landslides on the coastal Suhua Highway that stranded more than 400 travelers, including Chinese tourists. Most of them had been rescued as of Sunday, but 25 were still missing.
The occupancy rates of hotels in Hualien are normally maintained at over 80 percent, but the rates have plunged since the storm.

The manager of a hotel in downtown Hualien City, identified only by his surname Hu, said that he originally had a full occupancy rate for Saturday, but the rate fell to only half after the road closed.

Hu said the impact on business class guests was not too bad, but added that the impact on bookings by domestic tourists and groups, as well as Chinese tourists, was serious, and that "the follow-up negative effect is building."
A manager of another Hualien hotel, which mainly caters to Chinese tourist groups, said the hotel's occupancy rate also dropped immediately after the incident.
"The willingness of people to travel to Hualien has indeed been seriously impacted, " said the manager, identified by his surname Tseng.
But what really worries the operators is not the short-term effects of the typhoon.
"The really serious problem is the confidence of tourists about the safety of traveling to Hualien," Hu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua county chief promotes agriculture during India visit

TEXT.P: Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan met Friday with Shivraj Singh Chouhan, chief minister of the Indian state of Madhya Pradesh, and promoted the expertise of his county's agricultural sector.

Cho shared his experiences during the meeting of how the Changhua County government increased the county's agricultural production value. The meeting was also attended by Taiwan's representative to India, Wenchyi Ong.
Cho later gave a speech at the Global Investors Summit being held in the Indian state of Madhya Pradesh.
Cho used both opportunities to promote Changhua's agricultural sector, describing the county's quality produce, skill in establishing and marketing brands, and developing links to business.
It was the first time Cho had carried out official exchanges with India in his role as county magistrate and Chouhan showed a high degree of interest in the discussion.
In addition, Minister Shri Kailash Vijayvarjiya of Madhya Pradesh's Department of Commerce, Industry and Employment, is planning a visit to Changhua next year.

To encourage educational exchanges, company representatives from Changhua that traveled to India in a delegation led by Cho promised scholarships for the most gifted students from the Indian state to allow them to study at universities in the county.
The delegation arrived in New Delhi Oct. 21 and its members were scheduled to have several meetings their Indian counterparts with the aim of boosting cooperation between Changhua and India.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan urges China to separate politics from movies

TEXT.P: A distinction between politics and movies should be made and respected, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Johnny Chiang said Sunday.

He made the remark one day after a Taiwanese delegation at the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival (TIFF) was unable to walk the green carpet at the event's glittering opening ceremony due to vehement opposition by the Chinese delegation over the delegation's use of the name "Taiwan" rather than "Chinese Taipei" -- the name Taiwan is forced to use in the Olympics.
Chiang urged the Chinese delegation to stop using politics as an excuse to sabotage Taiwan's right to participate in international film events.

Premier Wu Den-yih also slammed the Chinese as "arrogant," saying the Chinese delegation's leader, Jiang Ping, made a serious mistake by sticking to the antiquated rhetoric that there is only one China. This sentiment, he said, is contrary to the peaceful cross-Taiwan relations of recent years.

GIO Department of Motion Picture Affairs Director and delegation head Chen Chih- kuan said Taiwan applied and was accepted to participate in the film event using the name "Taiwan" and will not deviate.
"No concessions will be made this time around," he insisted.

The Taiwanese delegation includes singer/actress Vivian Hsu, who enjoys a high degree of popularity in Japan, as well as up-and-coming actors Mark Chao and Ethan Ruan, whose blockbuster movie "Monga" will be one of six Taiwanese films featured in the festival. The absence of the Taiwanese delegation left many waiting fans in utter disappointment, according to reports from Tokyo.

The TIFF will run through Oct. 30. The movie "Social Network, " about the founder of Facebook, ushered in the annual event, while Ben Affleck's latest work "The Town" will be the closing film. Some of the big names attending the festival this year are French actress Catherine Deneuve, award-winner screenwriter Aaron Sorkin and the world's most lovable ogre, Shrek.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier hopes highway improvement project can start at year-end
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/10 21:24:05 (By Shen-hsu Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih expressed hope Sunday that an improvement project of the Suhua Highway in eastern Taiwan can pass an environmental impact assessment so that construction can start at the end of this year.
The improvements will result in bypasses for the most accident-prone sections of the twisty Suhua Highway, which connects Yilan and Hualien counties.

He said the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) had submitted the project to the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) for review and the EPA, after an initial review by specialists Oct. 18, asked the MOTC to make certain revisions.
"The Cabinet will not interfere with the environmental impact assessments and will respect the EPA's professionalism to ensure safety," Wu said.
He also said the assessment should be conducted "in a fair manner" so that tender bidding and construction can begin by the year's end.
He said the improvement project will take into consideration environmental protection, will reduce the danger on the highway, and will cut the travel time by 48 minutes.

The premier said the most immediate task is to repair the highway, seven sections of which were cut off after it was battered by record-breaking downpours from Typhoon Megi, which had left 13 dead and 25 missing as of Sunday.
"This is because the improvement project will not be completed until 2016 at the latest, so between now and then, the highway must still serve its mission as a major artery," he added.
He said that after the highway is repaired, the government will install soil movement monitoring systems on the adjacent slopes.
"In the event of downpours and soil movement, a ban on traffic will be enforced immediately to avoid accidents," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Name row mars opening of Tokyo film festival

TEXT.P: Taiwanese and Chinese movie stars failed to walk the green carpet at the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival Saturday due to a dispute over Taiwan's name.

Shortly before the walk to mark the start of the festival, the head of the Chinese delegation, Jiang Ping, told organizers that the Taiwanese delegation must not attend under the name "Taiwan" but should use the designation of "Taiwan, China" or "Chinese Taipei" -- the title Taiwan uses when participating in the Olympic Games.
The Taiwanese delegation, headed by Chen Chih-kuan, director of the Government Information Office's Department of Motion Pictures Affairs, flatly refused to accede to the Chinese demand.
The row resulted in both delegations missing the glitzy event.

Taiwan, after an 18-year hiatus, is represented at the film festival this year with a special section in which six Taiwanese box-office hits -- "Monga, " "Juliets, " "The Fourth Painting, " "Let the Wind Carry Me, " "Zoom Hunting" and "Taipei Exchanges" -- are to be screened.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the name row:
United Daily News:

Taiwanese officials said the government will insist on upholding Taiwan's sovereignty and will not rule out the possibility of bowing out of the festival in the worst-case scenario. On the other hand, it will seek to resolve cross- Taiwan Strait hurdles to solicit greater space for Taiwan in the international community.

Cross-strait relations have become warmer since the signing of a major trade pact in June. But at a sensitive time, when relations between China and Japan are tense over the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, over which Taiwan also claims sovereignty, the government is watching closely to see what China's next move will be.

Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Johnny Chiang said Saturday that the GIO stands behind the Taiwanese delegation. He added that it will not budge, as sovereignty is involved in the matter.
Although the delegation missed the walk, it attended a banquet hosted by the organizers later.

Taiwan has also encountered China's interference in its participation in the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission, showing that Beijing's squeezing has extended from intergovernmental organizations to non-governmental organizations, officials said, adding that "bilateral hurdles still exist." (Oct. 24, 2010) China Times:

Taiwanese delegation leader Chen Chih-kuan said his Chinese counterpart Jiang Ping made the name-change demand before the opening of the film festival, but Chen said that he "could not accept it because the issues of sovereignty and dignity are involved."
He said he has attended many international film festivals in the past, but has never encountered such an unreasonable demand.
The organizers were also frustrated, thinking that the arts and politics are separate and that one should not interfere with the other, according to Chen.
"The films we make are aimed at the Mandarin-speaking market, as well as the Asian, European and American markets, and not just the Chinese market," Chen added.

Meanwhile, many Taiwanese lauded Chen on the Internet and panned China for its childish gambit, with some pointing out that it is a film festival, which has nothing to do with the Olympics. (Oct. 24, 2010) Liberty Times:
China's oppression of Taiwan is omnipresent, even in the arts.

Jiang not only demanded that the Taiwanese delegation walk the green carpet with the Chinese delegation at the same time, but also challenged Chen in a high- handed tone, asking: "Are you still trying to sell your films to China? Are you not Chinese?"
The organizers were frustrated by China's move, saying that such a problem has never occurred before. They asked the two sides to "coordinate between themselves."

Each year, China sends big stars to attend the event, but this year, stars such as Zhang Ziyi declined to attend, presumably due to bilateral tension over the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea.
Beijing was also probably miffed because of the screening of the Taiwanese films and the large Taiwanese delegation. (Oct. 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: One body identified, 25 missing in Suhua Highway disaster
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/10 17:27:01 (By Jenny W. Hsu and Chou Yung-chieh)

TEXT.P: The woman was identified by her family as 54-year-old Liu Yun-jun, a special education teacher who was lauded by her colleagues as a compassionate and selfless individual. Her body was found near the 112.8 km mark of the highway at around 9 am, three days after Typhoon Megi thrashed northeastern Taiwan.

The death toll as of that day stood at 13, with 25, including a 21-person Chinese tour group from Guangdong Province and Tien Yuan, a Chinese tour leader working for the Hong Tai Travel Co., still reported missing.Military personnel and rescue teams had been working for nearly three days non-stop to comb the area for the missing. The government said the operation will not stop until all measures have been taken.
A day earlier, a delegation from China representing the missing tour group arrived in Taiwan to help with the search effort.
"All I want is to find my daughter as soon as possible, hopefully today," said Tien's mother. Tien's husband reportedly went inside the disaster zone to help locate his missing wife, but to no avail.
The searchers had found some broken vehicle parts suspected to belong to the bus used by the Hong Tai group and some reports said personal belongings such shoes and shirts had also been found.
The heavy rain brought by Typhoon Megi also fiercely battered nearby residential areas in the county. Thousands of homes in Suao Township lost power and hundreds of hectares of crops were destroyed.
The Yilan County government has put out a call for help asking the public to donate goods such as diapers for children and adults, disposable underwear, oatmeal and personal hygiene kits.
Several non-government organizations such as the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and World Vision Taiwan have dispatched volunteers to help with the massive clean-up work.
The latest typhoon-related agricultural losses in Taipei, Hualien, Yilan, and Taitung counties reported by the Council of Agricultural amounted to NT$58.56 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 25, or the 18th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1825: The Erie Canal, which connects the Great Lakes with New York City via the Hudson River, is opened, assuring the future prosperity of the upper Midwest region of the United States.
1825: Austrian composer Johann Strauss the Younger is born. He is best known for his waltzes, such as the ever-popular "The Blue Danube," and for operettas such as "Die Fledermaus."
1881: Pablo Picasso, Spanish painter, sculptor, graphic artist, ceramist, and designer, is born. He became one of the greatest and most versatile 20th-century artists.
1909: Prince Ito Hirobumi, former Japanese premier and resident-general in Korea, is assassinated by a Korean nationalist.
1914: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founding father of the Republic of China, marries Soong Ching-ling in Tokyo, Japan.
1928: The Republic of China Nationalist government begins to implement the five- yuan system -- Executive Yuan (the Cabinet), Legislative Yuan, Judicial Yuan, Examination Yuan, and Control Yuan.
1936: Leaders from Germany and Italy meet to form the Berlin-Rome Axis, providing mutual assistance and opposition to communism.
1938: Chinese troops evacuate Wuchang and Hankow during the War of Resistance against Japan.
1938: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini formally declares Libya a part of Italy after years of slowly colonizing the country.
1945: Taiwan is formally retroceded to China after 50 years of Japanese occupation. Chen Yi receives the formal surrender of Japanese rulers at a ceremony held at the Chung Shan Hall. The Nationalist government declares Oct. 25 as Taiwan Retrocession Day.
1945: In order to obstruct ROC troops from entering Manchuria, the Soviet Union "voluntarily" pulls out its garrison troops from Yingkow, and allows Chinese communist troops to occupy the city in southern Liaoning Province.
1949: ROC government troops win a victory at Kinmen against a communist Chinese attack.
1950: Beijing launches a movement to resist U.S. aggression and to aid North Korea and Chinese communist "volunteer-troops" formally entering North Korea to join the Korean War.
1951: The Korean conflict truce talks, which began July 10 at Kaesong after Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, acting on instructions from Washington, suggested a meeting between Allied and communist military officers to discuss a truce, are moved to Panmunjom.
1952: The United States blocks communist China's entry into the United Nations for the third year in a row.
1966: The first open school in Taiwan is inaugurated at the Provincial Taipei College of Business.
1976: An eight-member ROC delegation leaves for the United States to attend the first World Conference on Agricultural Education for Youth and Adult Leaders.
1979: Military personnel and civilians on Kinmen celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Kuningtou victory.
1985: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to implement health insurance for farmers.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek returns from the United States for a celebration to mark the centennial anniversary of the birth of the late president.
1988: A comprehensive farmer health insurance plan is initiated in Taiwan.
1996: Israel begins redeployment of its West Bank troops to further a peace deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1999: Former U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger says in Taipei that Taiwan should make its own decisions and the United States has the obligation to help Taiwan with its defense capabilities.
2000: National Science Council Chairman Weng Cheng-i says that the ROC will gradually open its doors wider to mainland Chinese science-technology professionals.
2001: Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue affirms Pope John Paul II's statement regarding past Catholic "errors" in China.
2001: Government agencies mobilizes over 1,000 military, medical, police and environmental protection personnel in their second joint exercise staged at a Taipei subway station to simulate possible responses against a chemical attack.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "A great man is one who has not lost the child's heart."

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Timing for Ma-Hu meeting

TEXT.P: The row over Taiwan's name at the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival last weekend highlights the real hindrance to a potential meeting between the top leaders of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

China's reluctance to recognize the existence of the Republic of China (ROC) as a sovereign state prompted its official to block Taiwanese film workers from joining a star-studded green carpet walk in Tokyo under the name of Taiwan.
This same mentality is also the real cause preventing a meeting between ROC President Ma Ying-jeou and his Chinese counterpart, Hu Jintao.
It is an issue that must be addressed if the two sides want to break new ground in their bilateral engagements following the signing of the landmark Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement in June.
Creative thinking will be needed for the two sides to jointly craft a solution to this thorny issue.

Since Beijing has defined the current cross-strait status quo as a hangover from the Chinese Civil War, the two sides should work out a "pragmatic and parallel identity framework" based on this definition to pave the way for Ma and Hu to meet in their official capacities.

Presidents of East Germany and West Germany called each other "president" when they met, and such a move did not prevent their "countries" from reunifying eventually. North Korean President Kim Jong-il similarly addressed the South Korean leader Kim Dae-jung as president when they met in 2000.

At a time when Beijing is undergoing a leadership transition and wide-ranging social restructuring, Hu should seriously consider how to develop an "identity framework" for the presidents of the ROC and the People Republic of China to meet in parity. That would be the best legacy he can leave his successor. Such a framework could also make a Ma-Hu meeting a reality. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 25, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics minister declines to confirm Volkswagen-Yulon deal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 12:40:15 (By Lin Hui-chun and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang declined Monday to confirm a deal between German carmaker Volkswagen and Taiwan-based Yulon Motor Co. Ltd.
"To my knowledge, the two sides have met, but I cannot disclose anything more," Shih told reporters.
Volkswagen has listed Taiwan as its priority location in looking for an overseas production base, Shih said, but the final decision is up to the two companies.

The comments came after the Chinese-language Economic Daily News reported the same day that Volkswagen and Yulon, Taiwan's largest auto maker, are expected to strike a deal in which the local company would assemble cars for the German firm.
The report cited sources from Swire Motors, an agent for Volkswagen in the Taiwan market, as saying that Yulon is expected to produce two Volkswagen models, including the Golf, in an initial phase.
The two sides are discussing details such as assembly costs and production volume, and were likely to reach a deal by the end of November, the report said.
Volkswagen plans to use the Taiwanese production base to target both the Chinese and Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) markets, it stated.
Yulon was not immediately available for comment on the report.

Shih said as any investment deal between private companies was companies' confidential business information, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) could not speak for them unless given their permission.

"The MOEA welcomes foreign investments in Taiwan, " the minister said. "Foreign investments are 'a good thing' for the island's economy and the ministry will do its best to provide assistance to facilitate the investments, such as finding land for factory construction."
In addition to the possible deal with Yulon, Volkswagen is looking for potential partners in Taiwan to produce auto components for the German company, the Economic Daily News said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Another 800 Tzu Chi volunteers aid flood victims
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 12:52:14 (By Szu-yu Lin and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Hundreds of volunteers of the Tzu Chi Foundation again headed for northeastern Taiwan Monday to help flood victims rebuild their lives after extremely heavy rain brought death, destruction and injury to the area last week.
Eight hundred members of the Buddhist charity, including doctors, teachers and retired policemen, followed another 1,200 volunteers who had gone to Nanfang-ao in Yilan County a day earlier.
Traveling at their own expense, the volunteers brought cleaning equipment and medical supplies to help residents repair their homes damaged by floods and provide medical services.

Doctors who went there earlier told the foundation that many people had hurt their limbs while cleaning, so this time more ointments and first aid kits were taken, said Dr. Hsu Jung-Yuen, vice superintendent of the Taipei Tzu Chi General Hospital.
Other volunteer doctors and nurses visited residents in remote areas to see whether they needed medical care, added Hsu, who took a day off work for the humanitarian task.
"The houses in Nanfang-ao were submerged by mud. Volunteers worked in groups to help clean up. It's great to give a hand to those in need," said another volunteer surnamed Chan.

As of Sunday night, 13 people had died, 96 were injured and 25 were still missing following the heavy rains in Yilan County brought by Typhoon Megi, according to the Central Emergency Operation Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- China urged to end squeezing Taiwan's space

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office issued a strongly worded statement late Sunday urging China to take remedial measures after a row over Taiwan's name at the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival.

The Chinese delegation's insistence on forcing the Taiwanese delegation to attend the festival under the name "Taiwan, China" or "Chinese Taipei" has hurt Taiwanese people's feelings and will hobble peaceful development of cross-strait relations, the statement said.

"Chinese authorities should not disregard or treat lightly this episode and should immediately take remedial measures and stop suppressing Taiwan or squeezing its international space, " the statement added.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said Sunday that the Tokyo film festival is an international cultural activity sponsored by a non-governmental organization that does not carry any political significance.

Stressing that Taiwan's film community has attended the annual event under the name of "Taiwan" for many years, Lo said the Chinese delegation should not have asked for a change to this time-honored practice.
He cautioned that hard-won improvements in cross-strait relations in the past two years through cultivation of goodwill and mutual trust could be sabotaged by a single unfriendly move or gesture.

For the sake of maintaining regional peace and prosperity, Lo said, the two sides should shelve their political disputes, continue peaceful engagement and create win-win scenarios under the principles of mutual respect and goodwill. (Oct. 25, 2010).
China Times:

Premier Wu Den-yih slammed the Chinese delegation Sunday as "arrogant," saying the Chinese delegation's leader, Jiang Ping, made a serious mistake by sticking to the antiquated rhetoric that there is only one China.

"Cross-strait relations have come a long way. Jiang's rhetoric was in contrast to the peaceful cross-strait relations of recent years, " Wu said. "We hope China's Taiwan Affairs Office will appropriately deal with the issue."
The Beijing-based Taiwan Affairs Office said Sunday it is collecting information about the row. The office is expected to make a response at its weekly news conference scheduled for Wednesday.

Chinese sources versed in Taiwan affairs said the latest dispute over Taiwan's name mainly resulted from Jiang's poor knowledge of the latest developments in China's policy and strategy toward cross-strait relations. (Oct. 25, 2010).
Liberty Times:

The Chinese delegation's demand that the Taiwanese delegation change its designation while attending the star-studded "green carpet" walk indicated that China would never ease its suppression of Taiwan's sovereign status despite improvements in cross-strait ties in the past two years under President Ma Ying- jeou's "China leaning-policy, " opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Sunday.

DPP Legislator Chen Ting-hui echoed Tsai's view, saying that the Ma administration should suspend talks with China to protest its relentless suppression of Taiwan's international space. (Oct. 25, 2021).

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese official visits site of deadly landslides

TEXT.P: An official from China's quasi-official Cross-Strait Tourism Association (CSTA) visited the Suhua Highway on Taiwan's northeastern coast Monday to learn about progress in efforts to find the Chinese tourists missing since deadly rock slides last week.

CSTA Deputy Secretary-General Li Yaying viewed the site at the 112.8-kilometer mark of the winding highway at which a tour bus carrying 19 Chinese tourists reportedly fell down a cliff during torrential rain last Thursday.
Li said that family members of the missing tourists would arrive in Taiwan later the same day at the earliest.
Meanwhile, Fang Guishan, director of the CSTA's Taipei office, said the office has set up a task force to handle the aftermath of the incident. The unit would be under his direct command, he added.
Emergency search and road repair operations continued on the remote highway Monday. Military personnel looked for survivors or bodies from the air, on land and in the ocean.
At around 11: 30 a.m., a section of human thigh was discovered on the slope below the 112.8 mark, Yilan County Fire Bureau officials said.

The coastal highway suffered another rock slide, this time at the 106km mark, earlier the same day. Technicians from the Directorate General of Highway (DGH) fixed the problem within 15 minutes, according to the DGH.

Meanwhile, the schedule for reopening the highway, a key link to eastern Taiwan's Hualien County and a popular tourist route, has been brought forward by five days to Nov. 15, Transportation and Communications Minister Mao Chi-kuo announced. Reconstruction personnel were asked to speed up their efforts, he said.
Heavy rains brought by Typhoon Megi left 13 people died and 25 others missing, according to official statistics. (By Justin Su, Lee Ming-chung, Chou Yung- chieh, Kelven Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, India to cooperate in bike trade: county chief
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 15:53:18 (By Ho Horn-ru and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Central Taiwan's Changhua County has reached a preliminary agreement with Madhya Pradesh to export bicycle components to the Indian state, the county chief said Monday.

The deal was made after talks between Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan and Shivraj Singh Chouhan, chief minister of Madhya Pradesh in central India. The state will buy Taiwanese components and then assemble, market and sell the finished bikes in India, Cho said.

As Changhua is a bike-production hub in Taiwan, the Indian business sector has expressed great interest in working with the county, said Cho, who is leading a delegation to strengthen business ties between Taiwan and the South Asian country.

Another member of the group, Kuo Yung-pin of bike-control-system provider Chia Cherne Ind. Co., promised to coordinate with other bike-component manufacturers back in Taiwan about production cooperation with India.

The export of components for assembly will be the first step for Taiwan's bike industry to penetrate the Indian market, Kuo said. If such a production pattern works well, he added, Taiwan component makers will consider building and operating production facilities in India.

Taiwan's bicycle sector had little information about the Indian market before this visit, Kuo explained, and his company has been surprised by India's willingness to cooperate with Taiwanese bike and component makers.

With a population of 1.18 billion people -- the world's second largest -- India is such a huge market that garnering just a single- digit-percent market share will generate significant sales, Kuo observed.
"We are very confident in taking a share here," he said.
Cho's delegation arrived in India on Oct. 21 to promote Changhua County products in India.
The county chief participated in the Global Investors Summit held in Khajuraho, Madhya Pradesh, over the weekend.
The visit is aimed at boosting Changhua's international visibility, and also at giving the county a better understanding of the world, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Megi causes NT$67 million of agricultural damage: COA

TEXT.P: Agricultural damage relating to Typhoon Megi totaled around NT$67.74 million by Monday morning, according to the latest tally by the Council of Agriculture, with most damage occurring in the country's northeast.

A total of 583 hectares of farmland in Taipei, Yilan, Hualien and Taitung counties were destroyed by the powerful rain storm, the COA said. Crops such as green onions, leeks and rice were heavily battered, causing a sharp surge in prices.
The fishery sector reported NT$12.21 million in losses, while damage to livestock was calculated at NT$10.09 million.
Furthermore, due to damage to and closure of the Suhua Highway, many distributors and farmers are forced to take a longer route to deliver goods to Taipei.

The COA is currently mulling over a short-term subsidy plan to help farmers in Hualien and Taitung counties offset the cost of fuel until the roads are completely cleared for travel, its Chief Secretary Tai Yu-yen said. A meeting with agricultural officials and representatives of the business sector from the three eastern counties will be held Tuesday to discuss the measure.
The Ministry of Transportation and Communications will also provide Taipei-bound train services to transport vegetables and fruits for local vendors, Tai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Search dog joins Suhua Highway rescue operation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 16:03:21 (By Justin Su and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: A search dog on Monday joined efforts to detect dozens of missing travelers on a collapsed highway in eastern Taiwan, three days after heavy rain paralyzed the coastal artery.

Biscuit, a six-year-old Labrador, went down a deep valley at the 112.8-kilometer marker on Suhua Highway with a rescue team from Taipei to look for the 25 missing people, who include 19 Chinese tourists and a tour leader.
Having over five years' experience in rescue operation, Biscuit was not afraid of being lowered down the cliff, said her trainer Chung Chin-lung.
"She was even excited about going on a mission again, " added Chung.

Other rescue team members said Biscuit enjoyed this kind of task. She had been lowered from helicopters to rescue sites before, so going down the crag today was not too difficult for her, they commented.

DOC.HEADLINE: Possessions and body parts of missing persons found

TEXT.P: Taiwanese search teams and military personnel on Monday found personal items and passports belonging to the missing Chinese tourists whose last known whereabouts were on the landslide-hit Suhua Highway during torrential rainstorms brought by Typhoon Megi last week.
No new bodies have been found so far today, but an arm and a piece of what is believed a human thigh have been located near the 112.8-kilometer mark of the highway.

The latest figures from the Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC) indicate 13 confirmed deaths and 25 people still unaccounted for. A 20-person Chinese tourist group brought by Taipei-based Harula Travel Agency from Zhuhai City, Guangdong Province, along with their Taiwanese bus driver, has still not been found. Another Taiwanese driver and Chinese tour leader Tian Yuan working for Hong Tai Travel Co, as well as a Taiwanese couple are also missing.
Both the Taiwanese and Chinese authorities are closely monitoring the latest developments of the rescue effort, now in its fourth day.

Many family members of the missing Chinese tourists have arrived in Taiwan in the hope of finding their loved ones. Representatives of Guangdong tourism department have also come to keep an eye on developments. Local cable channels aired a press conference held in China on Sunday at which grieving family members blamed human error as 70-percent responsible for the disaster.

A spokesperson for the family members listed three demands: They must see the bodies of their loved ones, dead or alive; all personal belongings must be brought back to Zhuhai; and if necessary, a big ritual must be held in Taiwan to pay respect to the victims.
Fan Guishan, director of the Taipei-based Cross-Strait Tourism Association, said a special task force has been set up to offer assistance and consolation to the victims' families.

The passports of Tian and all 20 Chinese from the Harula bus have been found, as have some personal belongings such as luggages, jackets, notebooks and souvenirs. Tires, horns and other parts of the Hong Tai tour bus have also been found.
In addition to meticulously combing the area on foot and with vehicles, the military has dispatched helicopters and rescue boats to search the area in all directions.
The Suhua Highway is 118 kilometers in length, and the section between the 112- and 116-kilometer markers was hardest hit by the typhoon. (By Jenny W. Hsu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's retrocession procedurally clear: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 16:48:56 (By Shu-hua Lee and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday on Taiwan's 65th Retrocession Day that Taiwan's return to the Kuomintang-led Republic of China from its Japanese colonial rulers in 1945 was "procedurally clear" and had a documented legal basis.

The handover -- recognized as Taiwan's Retrocession Day on Oct. 25 each year -- was clearly documented in the 1943 Cairo Declaration, the 1945 Potsdam Declaration, and the 1945 Japanese Instrument of Surrender, Ma said at the opening of an exhibition of historical photos and documents to mark the occasion.
"Taiwan's return to the Republic of China was procedurally extremely clear. Every document and every move had legal and political significance," Ma said.
The three documents constituted the most important foundation of Taiwan's retrocession, he said, describing them as "binding."
Ma's argument attempted to counter those who believe Taiwan's status has never been finalized.

They contend that the San Francisco Peace Treaty, which officially ended World War II when it took effect in April 1952, did not explicitly cede Taiwan to any party, leaving its sovereignty status uncertain.
Meanwhile, the president spoke of his overwhelming emotion recalling Taiwan's fate and spells of misfortune since the beginning of the 20th century.
"Taiwan can forgive Japan's mistake of invasion, but we in Taiwan should never forget the history," Ma said.
He urged Taiwanese citizens to forget the hatred wrought by war and turn the sentiment into "a strength of peace."

Ma called for further improvement in Taiwan-Japan relations, such as through the imminent opening of air links between the city airports of Taipei and Tokyo, and said he hoped people on both sides could live together in peace and prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close above 8,300 points

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 1.7 percent higher and breached the 8,300-point level for the first time since Jan. 18 on Monday, benefiting from a rebound in the high-tech sector amid optimism over demand from China, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 138.92 points to 8,306.98, after moving between 8,199.49 and 8,307.59, on turnover of NT$127.10 billion (US$4.12 billion).

The market opened up 0.44 percent, and the momentum accelerated as investors expected that growing demand for electronics products in China would offset slowing sales in the United States and Europe, dealers said.
The buying also spilled over to the old economy sector and financial stocks as the market found itself awash in liquidity, they said.
A total of 2,696 stocks closed up and 1,361 finished down, with 306 stocks remaining unchanged. All eight major sectors ended higher.

The plastics and chemical sector scored the biggest gains, rising 2.07 percent. Paper and pulp shares added 1.78 percent, machinery and electronics stocks rose 1.75 percent, financial shares added 1.49 percent and construction stocks closed up 0.85 percent.
Foodstuff issues rose 0.41 percent, cement stocks gained 0.34 percent, and the textile sector closed up 0.23 percent.
"The buying was strong after recent consolidation had digested much of technical pressure ahead of the 8,300 point mark, " Taiwan International Securities analyst Michael Chiang said.
"It was basically a liquidity driven market," he said.

Chiang said market sentiment improved after the local media reported Monday morning that China's prolonged Oct. 1 National Day holiday had ignited a buying spree, significantly lowering the inventories of high-tech products there.
"The inventory adjustments are expected to increase product shipments in the fourth quarter, " Chiang said. "That's why investors turned upbeat."
Chiang said the buying focused on large cap high-tech stocks.
PC vendor Acer gained 4.94 percent to NT$87.10 and rival AsusTek rose 6.72 percent to NT$246.00.
Among old economy stocks, Formosa Plastics added 2.84 percent to NT$86.90 and Shinkong Synthetic Fiber gained 3.46 percent to NT$16.45.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's health insurance system a valuable experience: minister

TEXT.P: The success of and future challenges to Taiwan's national health insurance (NHI) system is an experience that will be valuable to many countries, said Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang at the 2010 Taiwan Health Forum on Monday.

Speaking to more than 200 academics in the health-care field, including some 30 health specialists from 20 different countries, Yaung added that Taiwan's NHI experience can contribute some ideas to the United States health-reform discussions.

The annual forum, formerly known as "Global Forum for Health Leaders, " was launched in 2005 to provide a transnational platform for professional exchange in the Asian-Pacific region, DOH officials stated in a press release.

International experts will offer their insights on three topics -- leadership, climate change and health, and health systems -- during the two-day forum being held from Oct. 25 to Oct. 26 at the International Convention Center, Chang Yung- Fa Foundation, Taipei.
The forum is expected to promote international exchange and generate concrete ideas about health policies, said DOH officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Monday, dropping NT$0.18 to close at NT$30.730.
Turnover totaled US$740 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$30.910 and moved to a low of NT$30.595 before rebounding.
Dealers said the appreciation of other Asian currencies in regional markets helped spur gains in the Taiwan dollar against the U.S. dollar.
Anticipation that the U.S. would continue to loosen its monetary policy to stimulate its economy has led to expectations that the value of the greenback will be pulled down further, they said.
The strong showing of Taiwan's stock exchange also lent support to the local currency, with inflows of foreign funds buying local stocks, in particular electronics heavyweights, dealers said.
The benchmark weighted index closed up 1.70 precent to 8,306.98.
Dealers said that selling of the greenback largely came from foreign banks.

DOC.HEADLINE: World's No. 34 tennis player Lu Yen-hsun regains top spot in Asia

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tennis player Lu Yen-hsun has returned to Asia's No. 1 spot Monday after his latest victory in an ATP Challenger Tour a day earlier, a result that is likely to get him on the men's seed list for the upcoming Australia Open.

Lu defeated South African Kevin Anderson in Seoul on Sunday to claim the Samsung Securities Cup title, his second such championship this year. The 27-year-old picked up 125 ranking points, gaining his career-best -- the world's No. 34 spot.
He surpassed the world's No. 36 Kazakhstani Andrey Golubev to assume the top rank in Asia with a 21-point advantage over Golubev.
Lu's current goal is to enter the world's top 32 and to be seeded in a Grand Slam. The Wimbledon quarterfinalist is now 99 points behind French Michael Llodra, the world's 32.

Lu is scheduled to play in the St. Petersburg Open that runs from Oct. 23-31. He is currently the fourth seed of the tournament, which is offering prize money totalling US$750,000. (By Oscar Wu and C.Y. Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: Tour groups urged to use GPS-equipped buses in the future

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Travel Agent Association on Monday urged all tour groups to only use buses installed with the global positioning system (GPS) , as search and rescue teams continued to search for a group of missing Chinese tourists who were on a bus not equipped with such a system.

The bus is feared to have fallen off the Suhua Highway when parts of the major scenic coastal route collapsed from rockslides and heavy rain brought by Typhoon Megi last week. The bus was carrying 19 tourists as well as their tour guide and bus driver when they were last heard from on Thursday.

Taiwan's authorities do not know exactly where the bus is. They believe it could be buried under rock and mud or washed out to sea. A vehicle part, at least two body parts and a female body have been found in the area where the accident is believed to have occurred.

At the moment, 13 people have been confirmed dead from the typhoon. The busload of Chinese tourists, their Taiwanese tour guide and driver are among 25 people still missing. The tourists are from Guangdong Provinces Zhuhai City, with the bus operated by Harula Travel Agent. A bus driver and Chinese tour leader who worked for Hong Tai Tour Co. are also missing along with their bus. The passengers of that bus got out in time. Also missing is a Taiwanese couple.

In order to ensure the safety of tourists in the future, the travel agents association's chairman Yao Ta-kuang told a news conference that all tour groups should use only GPS-installed buses as priority in the future.
The two missing buses were not equipped with GPS, Yao pointed out. He added that in his four decades of experience in the tourism business, he had never encountered a case like this.
I have never seen anything like this in which two tour buses are missing, he said, stressing that the calamity was entirely a nature disaster and no one should be blamed.
A group of 36 family members of the victims are expected to arrive in Taiwan from China Monday night in hopes of finding their loved ones.

DOC.HEADLINE: Merrill Lynch raises target price on Formosa Plastics
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 19:44:04 (By Jeff Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Merrill Lynch said Monday it has raised its target price to NT$100 (US$3.24) from NT$84 for Formosa Plastics on expectations that rising petrochemical product prices will boost the company's bottom line.

In a research note, Merrill Lynch said the market consensus on Formosa Plastics' earnings was too conservative to reflect the company's fundamentals, especially since the global petrochemical sector is in a cyclical upturn.
The brokerage has also revised upward its forecast of Formosa Plastics' earnings per share to NT$6.95 from NT$6.36 for 2010, to NT$7.61 from NT$6.99 for 2011 and to NT$8.85 from NT$8.20 for 2012.

"The EPS revision stems from a new margin forecast for its various premium-grade products" such as ethylene vinyl acetate (EVA) and methyl methacrylate (MMA) due to the price hikes, the brokerage said.
Merrill Lynch said its recent visit to Formosa Plastics has reaffirmed its bullish sentiment toward the petrochemical giant because of the potential of the premium grade products.
Formosa Plastics shares have risen 13.3 percent since Sept. 30 on optimism toward its earnings outlook, with foreign institutional investors standing on the buy side, analysts said.

Apart from rising product prices, the market has widely anticipated that Formosa Plastics would also benefit from increasing business ties with China after the implementation of an economic cooperation framework agreement Taiwan signed with China in late June, they said.
On Monday, the stock closed up 2.84 percent to NT$86.90 with 21.72 million shares changing hands.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bank of China holds low-key opening of Taipei office

TEXT.P: The Bank of China, one of the first Chinese banks that have been permitted to set up a representative office in Taiwan, held a low-profile inaugural ceremony for its office in Taipei on Monday, amid concerns about its impact on Taiwan's upcoming local elections.
Local media reports cited speculation that the bank's low-profile opening was the result of a request from Taiwan's financial regulator, the Financial Supervisory Commission.

The opening is coming just weeks before the Nov. 27 election of mayors, councilors and ward chiefs in Taipei City and four soon-to-be established special municipalities in Taiwan. Some segments of Taiwan's population are concerned about the government and ruling party opening too much or too fast to Chinese investments.
FSC Chairman Chen Yu-chang, however, has denied such speculations at the legislature.
A source familiar with the bank's opening told reporters that bank officials had originally planned a high-profile opening, but that the plans were later scrapped.
Bank of China Chairman Xiao Gang, who visited Taiwan for the first time this week, declined to speak to the media following a noon banquet in celebration of the bank's office opening.

Under existing regulations, Chinese banks are required to operate a representative office in Taiwan for no less than a year before they can seek approval to upgrade the office into a bank branch, which can get into profit- making operations.

Representative offices of foreign banks in Taiwan are not allowed to conduct profit-making activities and can only liaise with local banks and customers and collect information on the local financial market.

Xiao reportedly will visit several financial institutions in Taiwan during his 10-day stay here. The private banquet was attended by the chairmen or general managers of local banking organizations, including First Financial Holding Co., Mega Financial Holding Co. and the Taiwan Cooperative Bank.

Susan Chang, who is the head of the Taipei-based Bankers Association of the Republic of China and chairwoman of Taiwan Financial Holding Co., told reporters before attending the event that the association will "provide all the necessary help" to the Chinese lender's office.
Last month, the FSC approved the applications of the Bank of China and China's Bank of Communications to establish an office in Taiwan.
The FSC is now reviewing a similar application from the China Merchants Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Green tourism in, PET bottles out in Taitung

TEXT.P: Providing free water stations along its highways to encourage bicycle riders to bring their own water bottles is one of the strategies Taitung County has adopted to promote itself as a green tourism destination and a cycling paradise.
Since the beginning of October, stations providing potable water have been set up every 10 kilometers on Taitung County's two main north-south roadways -- provincial highways No. 9 and No. 11.
The idea is just one of many recommended by hotelier Stanley C. Yen to boost tourism in the relatively remote county.

Yen, the group president of Landis Hotels & Resorts, set up the Alliance Cultural Foundation to promote the cultural revitalization of aboriginal areas along Taiwan's east coast by serving as a bridge between the public and private sectors and integrating their resources.
No longer involved in the day-to-day operations of his company, Yen spends at least half his time in Taitung County searching for potential tourist spots and looking for problems to be solved.

He has previously organized direct charter flights between eastern Taiwan and Hong Kong and invited media, bloggers, writers and tour operators to visit Taitung to bring in more tourists from the former British territory.

Many of those being lured to the southeastern county are into cycling, said Wang Chi-shun, head of a local service station for travelers set up by Giant Manufacturing Co., one of the world's biggest bicycle makers.
He said business has increased by 10-20 percent this year, mostly from foreigners, but he acknowledged that even Giant's outlet was not enough.

"The lack of a spot to get food, beverages, or supplies is a big problem, " said Wang, who added that a rider could have trouble finding a convenience store or restaurant for stretches of 30-40 kilometers in the sparsely populated county.
Yen's foundation thus partnered with global brand 3M's Taiwan subsidiary to find a solution.

"Plastic bottles are major sources of pollution, but how do we keep them out of the place? We discussed ideas with the foundation and decided to set up water stations, " said George Chao, general manager of 3M Taiwan.
The stations hope to create an incentive for travelers to bring their empty water containers and fill them up with water provided by the stations rather than buying new bottles of drinking water.

An increasing number of tourists are also visiting Taitung during the winter for another outdoor activity that takes advantage of the cool seasonal winds from the northeast that used to keep tourists away.
Surfers travel to Taitung every year for the big waves caused by the winds, with some enthusiasts considering it to be the best surfing spot in East Asia, Yen said.

"Mao Chi-kuo was surprised at how many tourists from Japan and western countries there were despite the heavy winds, " Yen said, recalling the reaction of the minister of Transportation and Communications during their trip to the area last year.

"Yen has helped Taitung a lot in the past two years, " said Taitung County Magistrate Justin Huang, who praised Yen for bringing in the right ideas and influential people such as first lady Chow Mei-ching.

With cycling and surfing, tourism in Taitung is becoming more diversified. Meanwhile, the county is experimenting with a new model of low-carbon tourism that aspires to protect one of the few regions in the country not yet polluted by industrialization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't mum on state compensation for Chinese victims
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 20:30:38 (By Chiachen Hsieh, Eva Feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah declined to comment Monday on whether, based on the State Compensation Law, compensation would be made to the families of Chinese tourists who lost their lives in Taiwan because of landslides triggered by Typhoon Megi.

Whether Chinese families of the victims could file for state compensation for the loss of their loved ones is a matter for the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) , Jiang told a Legislative Yuan committee convened to discuss the recent disaster on the Suhua Highway.

His ministry will give a consolation payment of NT$1 million (US$32,573) to the family of each victim of Megi Typhoon, in line with the precedent set after Typhoon Morakot wreaked havoc on Taiwan in August 2009. Chinese citizens are not entitled to this sum, however, as they are not ROC citizens, he said.
Families of the Chinese tourists who lost their lives in the aftermath of Typhoon Megi might receive an insurance payment up to around NT$5 million, he suggested.
MOTC Deputy Minister Yeh Kuang-shih said there had been many accidents on the Suhua Highway in the past, but there were no cases involving state compensation.

Chao Chien-min, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, said that government agencies have been focusing on rescue and road clear-up and they would meet later to discuss the issue of compensation.
Typhoon Megi thrashed Taiwan Oct. 21-22, dumping more than 1,200 millimeters of continuous rainfall in 48 hours, mostly on northeastern parts of the island.
As of Monday noon, official statistics showed the storm left 13 people dead in Taiwan and 25 others missing, including 20 Chinese citizens.
The 20 missing Chinese citizens included Tian Yuan, a tour group leader from Beijing and, on a separate bus, 19 tourists from Guangdong Province.

The wreckage of Tian's tour bus was found in a ravine into which on Friday it had plunged over a cliff-edge on the Suhua Highway, the road connecting Suao in Yilan with Hualien to its south. Most of the passengers survived, but Tian and the Taiwanese driver remained unaccounted for.
Military personnel continued looking for survivors or bodies of the missing Chinese tourists from the air, on land and in the ocean Monday.
The tour bus carrying the 19 tourists was believed to have been traveling north on the Suhua Highway Friday when heavy rain and rock slides caused several sections of the highway to collapse.

DOC.HEADLINE: China low key amid Taiwan protest over film festival row
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 20:34:48 (By Cheng-ching Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A Chinese official in charge of Taiwan affairs was low key Monday when asked about a row over Taiwan's name at the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival.
Sun Yafu, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, said he only learned about the matter that morning, and he did not have a complete picture of it.

The row involved China's delegation at the festival insisting on Saturday that the Taiwanese delegation attend the festival under the name "Taiwan, China" or "Chinese Taipei" instead of the name it has always used at the festival and wanted to use this time -- "Taiwan." As a result, neither the Chinese film stars or Taiwanese film stars walked down the "green carpet" at the festival.
On Premier Wu Den-yih's criticism that China's act was "overbearing," Sun said he had no comment.
"I have no comprehensive understanding of the dispute, so I can't comment on the matter substantively, not to mention comment on Wu's views," Sun added.
But Sun expressed the hope that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should avoid "unnecessary internal friction, " and that a reasonable arrangement can be made through coordination.

He said that after long exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, bilateral relations have undergone dramatic changes, especially after the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou in May 2008.
"The mainland of course would want Taiwan to take part in international organizations and activities as well as international meetings," Sun said.
"Both sides could make reasonable arrangements through bilateral coordination so long as they are made under the premise of not creating two Chinas or one China one Taiwan," Sun added.
Sun made the remarks on the sidelines of a seminar to mark the end of Japanese colonial rule in Taiwan at the end of World War II.
Taiwan's Presidential Office issued a strongly-worded statement late Sunday over the Chinese delegation's insistence about the name.
The office said the incident has hurt Taiwanese people's feelings and will hobble peaceful development of cross-strait relations.
The office asked for immediate remedial measures from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: County council in recess to protest highway improvement delay
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 20:47:29 (By Liu Chia-tai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Hualien County Council decided Monday to go into recess indefinitely in protest of the central government's long delay in improving the road leading to the eastern county, which is known for its beautiful natural vistas and tourist attractions.

The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) -dominated council launched its protest after deadly mudslides on the 78-year-old Suhua Highway -- the county's major road link to Yilan County and Taipei to the north -- left one dead and 25 others missing last week.
Council members observed a moment of silence for the victims of the roadway tragedy, including 19 tourists and a tour leader from China, before passing the resolution by a vote.

Council Speaker Yang Wen-chih said Hualien residents and tourists to eastern Taiwan have long had to risk their lives by traveling on the dangerous windy highway perched on a cliff overlooking the Pacific Ocean.

"Although the central government has proposed a plan to improve the Suhua Highway, it has so far remained on the drawing board. We need to take strong action to express our outrage over this procrastination," Yang said.
If the central government continued to drag its feet, Yang said, the council would extend its recess in protest.

Independent councilor Wang Yen-mei said, however, that she did not think the recess would generate a positive result because the KMT-controlled central government did not care about Hualien's development.
Huang Hui-pao, a councilor residing in Hsiulin Township in the northern tip of the county, said he traveled frequently between Hualien City and his hometown via the Suhua Highway.
"Since the landslides last Thursday, the Suhua Highway has nearly been deserted, " Huang lamented. "With the road cut off, tourists won't come and residents won't be willing to use the highway."

To ease Hualien residents' apprehension over the road's conditions, Transportation and Communications Minister Mao Chi-kuo said Monday that the damaged section of the Suhua Highway between the 104-kilometer and 116-kilometer markers will be able to accommodate one-way traffic by Nov. 15.
Mao, who traveled to the highway's 112.8 km marker to check on progress in fixing the road, said the Suao-Dongao section suffered the most severe damage during last week's storm.
"Engineering personnel are working day and night to clear up mud and rocks in order to have traffic resume on the coastal highway as early as possible," Mao said.
Meanwhile, the minister reaffirmed the government's commitment to offer eastern Taiwan residents a "safe road home" by launching a massive improvement project for the Suhua Highway.

"Although we have a north-link railway linking Hualien to Taipei, we still need to have a safe highway in place to meet the region's traffic demand. And the safety of the Suhua Highway will be greatly upgraded once the improvement project is completed," Mao said.

Some environmentalists have opposed the highway upgrade project, but Mao said the issue was not about "whether or not" the highway should be improved but about how to improve it and how the improvement project should be carried out.

According to the ministry's plan, the highway's Suao-Dongao section will be the first to be improved, with plans to build a 3.5 kilometer-long tunnel and a 3.5 kilometer-long bridge to bypass the existing roadway.
The project will also consist of improving the 20 km Nanao-Hoping section and the 8.5 km Hochung-Tachingshui section, which will require the construction of many other tunnels and new bridges.
The construction cannot be completed before 2018, however, even if it starts next year and is not plagued by glitches, a wait of eight years.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Zealand singer prays for highway landslide victims
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 20:52:00 (By Sabine Cheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: New Zealand singer Hayley Westenra, who is in Taiwan as part of her Asian Tour 2010, sang "Amazing Grace" at a press conference in Taipei Monday as a prayer for victims of Typhoon Megi, which thrashed Taiwan last week, leaving 13 people dead and 25 others unaccounted for.

Westenra said that she heard about the disaster that Typhoon Megi had wrought in Taiwan before she departed for Taipei Sunday from her hometown of Christchurch City, New Zealand, where a 7.0-magnitude earthquake hit in early September.
She said her heart goes out to the storm victims in Taiwan, and as a singer, she would like to bring warmth and consolation to those who have suffered, through her voice and songs.

A soprano, songwriter and UNICEF Ambassador, Hayley won Taiwan audiences' hearts last year when she sang "The Moon Represents My Heart" in mandarin with Taiwanese pop singer Shin at the opening of the Kaohsiung World Games.

This time, she will stage a concert in the southern port city of Kaohsiung on Wednesday, singing mostly classical songs with a full orchestra to be played by the Kaohsiung City Symphony Orchestra, and another concert in Taipei City, Nov. 1, at which she will sing the "Moon Represents My Heart" again with Taiwan's new pop sensation Yang Tsung-wei.
She will also stage a concert in Shanghai on Oct. 30 as part of her Asia tour.

Her first internationally-released album, "Pure, " reached No. 1 on the U.K. classical charts in 2003 and has sold more than two million copies worldwide. "Pure" is the fastest-selling international debut classical album to date, having made her an international star at age 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan making efforts to develop green industries
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 20:59:43 (By Chen Yi-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government is working to foster an environment that will encourage private companies and local residents to develop green industries and combat global warming and resource degradation, Environmental Protection Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen said Monday.

The centerpiece of the government's plan, Shen said, was to promote the birth of 50 low-carbon communities around Taiwan in two years, six low-carbon cities within five years and four low-carbon living regions with 10 years.

To achieve the goals, the government will push companies and banks devoted to ecological conservation to open their offices in "low carbon special zones, " in which electric vehicles will serve as the main transport tool, Shen said at the opening of the 2010 Taiwan Industrial Green Industry Show (TiGiS).

In addition, the government also planned to promote green building, make the agricultural sector more environmentally friendly, and turn incinerators into district biomass energy production centers, he said.
The trade show, in its second year, was jointly organized by the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and the Expo Union Corp.

The 2010 event, focused around energy, environmental protection and water technology, has attracted the participation of 180 domestic and foreign enterprises, with those from abroad originating primarily from the United States, Canada, Germany, France and Japan.
This year, a total of 321 booths were set up at the Taipei World Trade Center for the show, 19 percent more than in 2009, according to the organizers.

Also at the opening ceremony, TAITRA President and CEO Chao Yung-chuan said Taiwan's green technology has gained global recognition, citing the 2010 World Competitiveness Yearbook issued by the Switzerland-based International Institute for Management Development (IMD).
The report ranked Taiwan sixth among 58 economies around the world in green technology-generated competitiveness, higher than Singapore at 14th, South Korea at 15th and Hong Kong at 31st.
Within Asia, Taiwan was ranked second, trailing only Japan, Chao said.
The trade show will run through Oct. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: Judiciary urged to probe release of murderer who kills again
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 21:40:26 (By Yu-chia Lai, Kelven Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Judicial Yuan was urged Monday to investigate a problematic ruling lodged by a high court judge in 2009 that allowed a man convicted of murdering two girls to kill again after he was released from jail where he had served only six years.

Legislator Chiu Yi of the ruling Kuomintang made the request at the legislature's Judiciary and Organic Laws and Statutes Committee. Judicial Yuan Secretary-General Lin Ching-fang was present for lawmakers' questions.

Chiu questioned the process that the judge, Tsai Kuang-chih, who is now in custody after being arrested for allegedly being involved in a bribe-taking scandal, reduced the sentence on the convicted, Chen Kun-ming, in the sixth retrial at the High Court last May from life imprisonment to 12 years in jail.
Chen's penalty was later further commuted to half of the term for him to stay behind the bar thanks to the Reduction of Penalties Act.

Furthermore, Chiu criticized that while Chen was also ordered to be placed at the custody of the Beitou Armed Forces Hospital in suburban Taipei for two more years after serving his term, Chen -- who was diagnosed as suffering from insanity -- had been kept at the hospital for only four months after being released from jail last year.
Chen was arrested on Oct. 23 on charge of murder again after he was found to have allegedly beaten a 27-year-old woman to death with a baseball bat at his rented home in Banciao, Taipei County.

On Monday, the victim's husband, only identified by his surname Tsai, and other family members held a news conference at the Legislative Yuan accompanied by legislator Chiu, in which they accused "the system of killing people."
Tsai said he "could not understand why the law allows a murderer to be set free in such a short time."
Tsai is seeking state compensation for the family's loss of a wife and mother. The couple's son is less than one year old.

In 2003, Chen turned himself in, claiming he took the life of a pair of sisters, aged 7 and 8. He was then convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment in both district and high courts. The courts adopted the results of a medical examination by the Taipei Veterans General Hospital that said Chen was only affected by mental disorder instead of the claimed insanity.

The sentence was kept unchanged in the first three retrials at the High Court but reduced to 16 years in jail in the fourth retrial , and further to 12 years in fifth retrial by Judge Tsai Kuang-chih as he adopted the Beitou Hospital's diagnosis that said Chen was insane.

DOC.HEADLINE: Company taps into higher end Chinese medical tourism market

TEXT.P: While rescue workers were busy searching for a group of Chinese tourists missing in eastern Taiwan, another group of Chinese nationals were enjoying a leisurely checkup in the serenity of a hospital in the country's capital.

The group of 25 tourists, mostly middle-aged women in the beauty and cosmetics business, completed a detailed health exam Monday morning at Shin Kong Wu Ho-Su Memorial Hospital, said Alex Hung, president of Shin Kong Medical Club.
The experience was so enjoyable, Hung said, that some members of the group canceled the sightseeing part of their trip to squeeze in more health tests Tuesday.

"In China, a hospital is a place for sick people, " said a woman who would only identify herself by her surname Qian. She described the Taiwanese hospital as being more like home, with the strong aroma of coffee replacing the usual smell of disinfectant.

This group of medical tourists from Nanjing arrived in Taiwan Friday, a day after nearly 300 Chinese nationals were stranded on the scenic Suhua Highway on the east coast because of landslides triggered by Typhoon Megi.
Most of them have since been evacuated to safety, but 20 of them remained unaccounted for as of Monday night.

When asked whether the incident had any impact on her plan to come to Taiwan, Qian replied that initially her family had had qualms about her journey, but once a scheduled trip to the eastern part of Taiwan was scrapped, she jumped at the opportunity.

The Chinese visitors would not reveal how much they paid for the tour, but each had to first pay a membership fee of NT$177,890 (US$5,834) to join the Taiwanese-invested, Guangzhou-based Zion Health Control and Youth Rejuvenation Center (ZION).

ZION's stated purpose is to promote Taiwan's medical tourism to upscale consumers in China, offering them medical services at the centers on the mainland and bringing them to Taiwan for more thorough checkups once a year.
According to ZION CEO Tomson Lin, at least two groups of Chinese travelers will come to Taiwan every month for medical checkups beginning in December, boosting the country's medical tourism industry.
Lin explained that for medical tourism to flourish in Taiwan, promoting low-risk health checkups is a first step.
"Not only does it build up consumers' confidence, it is also easily accepted by most people," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Search continues unabated for missing travelers on Suhua Highway
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 22:08:40 (By Shen-hsu Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Search and rescue efforts for 25 people still missing from the collapse of Suhua Highway in eastern Taiwan due to landslides caused by Typhoon Megi last week, continued unabated on land, at sea and from the air on Monday, the Central Emergency Operation Center said.

The 25 missing people include: a group of 19 Chinese tourists, their Taiwanese tour guide and driver; a Taiwanese couple; and a Chinese tour leader and a Taiwanese driver from another tour group. The missing are feared to have fallen into the sea when their vehicles plunged down a steep mountainside when the highway they were traveling on collapsed.

On the ground, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) sent 35 personnel, including special force soldiers and engineers, to the site at the 114.5 km mark on the 118-km highway that connects Yilan and Hualien counties. Search teams used biometric and metal detectors.

Seventy-eight firefighters from Taipei and Taichung Cities, and Taoyuan County also searched at the site of 112.8 km mark, while 77 firefighters from Taipei and Taichung counties and the National Fire Agency searched at the 114.5 km mark. Joining them were 212 firefighters from the fire department of Yilan County.

In the aerial rescue, the MND sent an Air Force S-70C helicopter to the 114.5 km mark to assess the feasibility of transporting excavators there from the air, while another helicopter was sent to the 110-116 km marks to conduct sea and coastal searches.
The MND also sent a 22-member team to the sea to assess the feasibility of transporting the excavator by boat.
The center said vehicle wreckage retrieved have been sent to the Yilan Sports Park for cause analysis and body parts were sent to the Yilan County Funeral Home for identification.

The center also said that to help Yilan County, which was battered by torrential rains brought by Typhoon Megi, the MND has sent 6,651 military personnel to help with dredging, cleaning and disinfection works in the county.

DOC.HEADLINE: AsusTek denies Microsoft has made royalty request

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based AsusTek Computer Inc., the world's fifth-largest personal computer vendor, denied Monday that Microsoft Corp. had asked it to pay royalties on its Android smartphones, which the U.S. software giant said violated patents.
"We cautiously clarify that there is no such a thing, " AsusTek said in a filing Monday to Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp. in response to a local media report.
AsusTek said that it owned many patents itself and that it had always respected the protection and use of patent rights.
