The Chinese-language Commercial Times reported that Microsoft sent a high-level legal officer to Taiwan to ask AsusTek and Acer Inc., the world's second largest PC vendor, to pay royalties.
In a filing to the stock exchange later in the day, Acer said it could not comment on the market speculation.
Microsoft has already received similar royalties from HTC Corp., the world's largest maker of smartphones using Google's Android operating system, the report said.
Weeks ago, Microsoft filed a lawsuit against Motorola Inc. "for infringement of nine Microsoft patents by Motorola's Android-based smartphones."

The patents include synchronizing e-mail, calendars and contacts, scheduling meetings, and notifying applications of changes in signal strength and battery power, the company said in a recent statement.

"Motorola needs to stop its infringement of our patented inventions in its Android smartphones, " said Horacio Gutierrez, the company's corporate vice president and deputy general counsel of Intellectual Property and Licensing, in a statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: After one year, Taiwanese brothers still detained in Tanzania: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Monday night confirmed that two Taiwanese brothers surnamed Hsu have been detained in Tanzania for over a year, but the ministry said it has closely monitored the situation.
MOFA spokesman James Chang said the older brother was the captain of an Oman- registered fishing boat Tawariq 1.
The older brother, along with a 30-plus member crew, was detained by Tanzania's government on March 8, 2009 for fishing illegally and holding an expired fishing license, Chang said.
The captain's younger brother, who operated a boat based in Kenya, was also detained when he went to Tanzania to try and rescue his older brother.

Chang said the matter was brought to the MOFA's attention on Oct. 25, 2009, and since then, the country's representative offices in South Africa and Oman have been closely watching the situation and providing necessary help.

Chang explained that the ship owner has hired lawyers to oversee the legal process and that the Oman government was also involved in the matter since the boat was registered in the Middle Eastern country.

"We immediately contacted a group of Taiwanese citizens in Tanzania to visit the two brothers as soon as we were notified of their plight. According to our knowledge, the two brothers are in good health," Chang said.
The MOFA official was unable, however, to offer any approximate timetable for the release of the two men.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan pop star Selina undergoes surgery for burns

TEXT.P: Taiwanese pop star Selina underwent surgery for burns to over half of her body in a hospital outside Taipei Monday afternoon.

The star's father Jen Ming-ting said his daughter has been incredibly strong throughout the five-hour debridement procedure despite the pain and confirmed more than 50 percent of her body had been burned and 60 percent of the burns were third degree.
Her cheeks were also scalded, he said.
It is the first surgical procedure the singer has undergone since suffering burns in an accident during the filming of a new television series in Shanghai, China.
It would take up to three weeks before knowing if a skin graft would be necessary, said Jen.

In an emotional micro blog post, Selina's mother described her daughter as both brave and strong, adding that she had passed on all the warmth and concern shown for Selina by her friends since the accident.
Full recovery could take up to a year, according to some estimates.
Selina is the stage name of Chia-hsuan Jen, a member of the three-girl pop group S.H.E. She returned to Taiwan by chartered medical plane late Sunday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese delegation unwise to spark name row in Tokyo: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 23:33:24 (By Eva Feng, Shu-hua Lee and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Chinese delegation was unwise to incite a row over Taiwan's name at the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival, a senior official in charge of China-related affairs said Monday.

"Through concerted efforts of both sides of the Taiwan Strait over the past couple of years, cross-strait relations have finally been moving toward positive interaction and a harmonious, peaceful atmosphere is gradually taking shape, " said Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chao Chien-min.

"This hard-won achievement, accomplished with the two sides respecting each other and working concertedly, deserves to be treasured," Chao said in a keynote speech delivered ahead of an award presentation ceremony for outstanding cross- strait exchange promotion groups.

He expressed regret that the Chinese delegation told the festival's organizers last weekend that the Taiwanese delegation should not attend under the name "Taiwan" but should use the designation of "Taiwan, China" or "Chinese Taipei" -- the title Taiwan uses when participating in the Olympic Games.
Chao said China's demand was unacceptable because Taiwan has participated in the Tokyo event in the name of Taiwan for many years.

Moreover, he said, the event is a private cultural activity organized by a nongovernmental organization. "It does not carry political significance and has nothing to do with national sovereignty," he added.

Stressing that the Chinese delegation's interference with Taiwan's participation at the event had hurt the feelings of Taiwan's people, Chao said Chinese authorities should not brush aside the episode lightly and should seriously review its attitude toward Taiwan.

Premier Wu Den-yih also said Monday that Jiang Ping, the leader of the Chinese delegation, was arrogant and overbearing in demanding the Taiwanese delegation change its designation at the Tokyo festival.
He urged Chinese authorities to maintain their goodwill toward Taiwan and take remedial measures to prevent the incident from affecting cross-strait rapprochement.

DOC.HEADLINE: More body parts from Suhua Highway accident victims found
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 23:38:13 (By Jenny W. Hsu, Claudia Liu, and Mai-lan Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Yilan District Prosecutors Office said on Monday night that four sets of body parts were found during the day around the landslide-ridden Suhua Highway area but the identities of the victims had yet to be confirmed.
The heavy rains brought by Typhoon Megi last Thursday triggered landslides along the narrow highway overlooking the Pacific Ocean, burying cars and tourist buses and disrupting traffic.
One person has been identified as being killed in the disaster, while 25 others remain missing.

On the fourth day of the rescue operation Monday, search and rescue teams found several broken limbs and body parts, which were immediately sent to the Yilan County Morgue for DNA testing, the prosecutors office said.
Chief Prosecutor Wu Hui-lan said one of the limbs found Monday morning was a right leg, and a preliminary analysis on the toe suggested it belonged to a female.
The family members of a missing female Chinese tour leader named Tian Yuan have provided DNA samples for the medical examiners, hoping for a possible match.
Wu said the leg was found only 30 meters away from where a female body was located in the afternoon.
Another partial body with only the upper torso from the neck down was found around the same location. Preliminary testing suggested it to be the body of a male.
Wu said a finger print identification test would be conducted as soon as possible to confirm the identity of the body.

In the afternoon, another set of body parts -- a right leg connected to a left arm believed to belong to a woman -- was found roughly 8.5 nautical miles from a harbor in Yilan County's Jhuangwei Township, Wu said.

Earlier in the day, the search team found a purse that was later confirmed to be Tian's. The purse contained her passport as well as the passports of the 20 Chinese tourists in her group, who were all able to flee their bus before it was buried.
Two of the 20 sustained minor injuries and were to be kept under medical observation in Taiwan. The remaining 18 were scheduled to return to China Tuesday, the Tourism Bureau said.
The Taiwanese driver of the tour group also remained unaccounted for as of Monday night.

Tian's husband Kou Minghu, who flew to Taiwan immediately after he received the news that his wife was missing, said he last heard from her Wednesday night when she told him she was recovering well from a cold.

Kou described his wife as hardworking, thoughtful, and dedicated to her job. The director of the China-based Cross-Strait Tourism Association, Fan Guishan, also complimented Tian, saying all of her tour members praised her service.
Overall, Typhoon Megi has claimed 13 lives and left another 25 missing.

Most of the missing come from a tour bus traveling on the Suhua Highway on Thursday that has yet to be found. There were 19 Chinese nationals from Guangdong Province's Zhuhai and their Taiwanese tour guide and bus driver on board.

A group of 36 family members of the missing tourists along with seven Zhuhai City officials arrived in Taiwan Monday night and were to stay in a hotel in Yilan County, where they were to be received by the Travel Agent Association of the Republic of China.
The family members requested to see the bodies, dead or alive, and asked that all personal belongings found by the search team had to be brought back home to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: China low key amid Taiwan protest over film festival row
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 20:34:48 (By Cheng-ching Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A Chinese official in charge of Taiwan affairs was low key Monday when asked about a row over Taiwan's name at the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival.
Sun Yafu, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, said he only learned about the matter that morning, and he did not have a complete picture of it.

The row involved China's delegation at the festival insisting on Saturday that the Taiwanese delegation attend the festival under the name "Taiwan, China" or "Chinese Taipei" instead of the name it has always used at the festival and wanted to use this time -- "Taiwan." As a result, neither the Chinese film stars or Taiwanese film stars walked down the "green carpet" at the festival.
On Premier Wu Den-yih's criticism that China's act was "overbearing," Sun said he had no comment.
"I have no comprehensive understanding of the dispute, so I can't comment on the matter substantively, not to mention comment on Wu's views," Sun added.
But Sun expressed the hope that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should avoid "unnecessary internal friction, " and that a reasonable arrangement can be made through coordination.

He said that after long exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, bilateral relations have undergone dramatic changes, especially after the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou in May 2008.
"The mainland of course would want Taiwan to take part in international organizations and activities as well as international meetings," Sun said.
"Both sides could make reasonable arrangements through bilateral coordination so long as they are made under the premise of not creating two Chinas or one China one Taiwan," Sun added.
Sun made the remarks on the sidelines of a seminar to mark the end of Japanese colonial rule in Taiwan at the end of World War II.
Taiwan's Presidential Office issued a strongly-worded statement late Sunday over the Chinese delegation's insistence about the name.
The office said the incident has hurt Taiwanese people's feelings and will hobble peaceful development of cross-strait relations.
The office asked for immediate remedial measures from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: County council in recess to protest highway improvement delay
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 20:47:29 (By Liu Chia-tai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Hualien County Council decided Monday to go into recess indefinitely in protest of the central government's long delay in improving the road leading to the eastern county, which is known for its beautiful natural vistas and tourist attractions.

The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) -dominated council launched its protest after deadly mudslides on the 78-year-old Suhua Highway -- the county's major road link to Yilan County and Taipei to the north -- left one dead and 25 others missing last week.
Council members observed a moment of silence for the victims of the roadway tragedy, including 19 tourists and a tour leader from China, before passing the resolution by a vote.

Council Speaker Yang Wen-chih said Hualien residents and tourists to eastern Taiwan have long had to risk their lives by traveling on the dangerous windy highway perched on a cliff overlooking the Pacific Ocean.

"Although the central government has proposed a plan to improve the Suhua Highway, it has so far remained on the drawing board. We need to take strong action to express our outrage over this procrastination," Yang said.
If the central government continued to drag its feet, Yang said, the council would extend its recess in protest.

Independent councilor Wang Yen-mei said, however, that she did not think the recess would generate a positive result because the KMT-controlled central government did not care about Hualien's development.
Huang Hui-pao, a councilor residing in Hsiulin Township in the northern tip of the county, said he traveled frequently between Hualien City and his hometown via the Suhua Highway.
"Since the landslides last Thursday, the Suhua Highway has nearly been deserted, " Huang lamented. "With the road cut off, tourists won't come and residents won't be willing to use the highway."

To ease Hualien residents' apprehension over the road's conditions, Transportation and Communications Minister Mao Chi-kuo said Monday that the damaged section of the Suhua Highway between the 104-kilometer and 116-kilometer markers will be able to accommodate one-way traffic by Nov. 15.
Mao, who traveled to the highway's 112.8 km marker to check on progress in fixing the road, said the Suao-Dongao section suffered the most severe damage during last week's storm.
"Engineering personnel are working day and night to clear up mud and rocks in order to have traffic resume on the coastal highway as early as possible," Mao said.
Meanwhile, the minister reaffirmed the government's commitment to offer eastern Taiwan residents a "safe road home" by launching a massive improvement project for the Suhua Highway.

"Although we have a north-link railway linking Hualien to Taipei, we still need to have a safe highway in place to meet the region's traffic demand. And the safety of the Suhua Highway will be greatly upgraded once the improvement project is completed," Mao said.

Some environmentalists have opposed the highway upgrade project, but Mao said the issue was not about "whether or not" the highway should be improved but about how to improve it and how the improvement project should be carried out.

According to the ministry's plan, the highway's Suao-Dongao section will be the first to be improved, with plans to build a 3.5 kilometer-long tunnel and a 3.5 kilometer-long bridge to bypass the existing roadway.
The project will also consist of improving the 20 km Nanao-Hoping section and the 8.5 km Hochung-Tachingshui section, which will require the construction of many other tunnels and new bridges.
The construction cannot be completed before 2018, however, even if it starts next year and is not plagued by glitches, a wait of eight years.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Zealand singer prays for highway landslide victims
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 20:52:00 (By Sabine Cheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: New Zealand singer Hayley Westenra, who is in Taiwan as part of her Asian Tour 2010, sang "Amazing Grace" at a press conference in Taipei Monday as a prayer for victims of Typhoon Megi, which thrashed Taiwan last week, leaving 13 people dead and 25 others unaccounted for.

Westenra said that she heard about the disaster that Typhoon Megi had wrought in Taiwan before she departed for Taipei Sunday from her hometown of Christchurch City, New Zealand, where a 7.0-magnitude earthquake hit in early September.
She said her heart goes out to the storm victims in Taiwan, and as a singer, she would like to bring warmth and consolation to those who have suffered, through her voice and songs.

A soprano, songwriter and UNICEF Ambassador, Hayley won Taiwan audiences' hearts last year when she sang "The Moon Represents My Heart" in mandarin with Taiwanese pop singer Shin at the opening of the Kaohsiung World Games.

This time, she will stage a concert in the southern port city of Kaohsiung on Wednesday, singing mostly classical songs with a full orchestra to be played by the Kaohsiung City Symphony Orchestra, and another concert in Taipei City, Nov. 1, at which she will sing the "Moon Represents My Heart" again with Taiwan's new pop sensation Yang Tsung-wei.
She will also stage a concert in Shanghai on Oct. 30 as part of her Asia tour.

Her first internationally-released album, "Pure, " reached No. 1 on the U.K. classical charts in 2003 and has sold more than two million copies worldwide. "Pure" is the fastest-selling international debut classical album to date, having made her an international star at age 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan making efforts to develop green industries
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 20:59:43 (By Chen Yi-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government is working to foster an environment that will encourage private companies and local residents to develop green industries and combat global warming and resource degradation, Environmental Protection Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen said Monday.

The centerpiece of the government's plan, Shen said, was to promote the birth of 50 low-carbon communities around Taiwan in two years, six low-carbon cities within five years and four low-carbon living regions with 10 years.

To achieve the goals, the government will push companies and banks devoted to ecological conservation to open their offices in "low carbon special zones, " in which electric vehicles will serve as the main transport tool, Shen said at the opening of the 2010 Taiwan Industrial Green Industry Show (TiGiS).

In addition, the government also planned to promote green building, make the agricultural sector more environmentally friendly, and turn incinerators into district biomass energy production centers, he said.
The trade show, in its second year, was jointly organized by the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and the Expo Union Corp.

The 2010 event, focused around energy, environmental protection and water technology, has attracted the participation of 180 domestic and foreign enterprises, with those from abroad originating primarily from the United States, Canada, Germany, France and Japan.
This year, a total of 321 booths were set up at the Taipei World Trade Center for the show, 19 percent more than in 2009, according to the organizers.

Also at the opening ceremony, TAITRA President and CEO Chao Yung-chuan said Taiwan's green technology has gained global recognition, citing the 2010 World Competitiveness Yearbook issued by the Switzerland-based International Institute for Management Development (IMD).
The report ranked Taiwan sixth among 58 economies around the world in green technology-generated competitiveness, higher than Singapore at 14th, South Korea at 15th and Hong Kong at 31st.
Within Asia, Taiwan was ranked second, trailing only Japan, Chao said.
The trade show will run through Oct. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: Judiciary urged to probe release of murderer who kills again
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 21:40:26 (By Yu-chia Lai, Kelven Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Judicial Yuan was urged Monday to investigate a problematic ruling lodged by a high court judge in 2009 that allowed a man convicted of murdering two girls to kill again after he was released from jail where he had served only six years.

Legislator Chiu Yi of the ruling Kuomintang made the request at the legislature's Judiciary and Organic Laws and Statutes Committee. Judicial Yuan Secretary-General Lin Ching-fang was present for lawmakers' questions.

Chiu questioned the process that the judge, Tsai Kuang-chih, who is now in custody after being arrested for allegedly being involved in a bribe-taking scandal, reduced the sentence on the convicted, Chen Kun-ming, in the sixth retrial at the High Court last May from life imprisonment to 12 years in jail.
Chen's penalty was later further commuted to half of the term for him to stay behind the bar thanks to the Reduction of Penalties Act.

Furthermore, Chiu criticized that while Chen was also ordered to be placed at the custody of the Beitou Armed Forces Hospital in suburban Taipei for two more years after serving his term, Chen -- who was diagnosed as suffering from insanity -- had been kept at the hospital for only four months after being released from jail last year.
Chen was arrested on Oct. 23 on charge of murder again after he was found to have allegedly beaten a 27-year-old woman to death with a baseball bat at his rented home in Banciao, Taipei County.

On Monday, the victim's husband, only identified by his surname Tsai, and other family members held a news conference at the Legislative Yuan accompanied by legislator Chiu, in which they accused "the system of killing people."
Tsai said he "could not understand why the law allows a murderer to be set free in such a short time."
Tsai is seeking state compensation for the family's loss of a wife and mother. The couple's son is less than one year old.

In 2003, Chen turned himself in, claiming he took the life of a pair of sisters, aged 7 and 8. He was then convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment in both district and high courts. The courts adopted the results of a medical examination by the Taipei Veterans General Hospital that said Chen was only affected by mental disorder instead of the claimed insanity.

The sentence was kept unchanged in the first three retrials at the High Court but reduced to 16 years in jail in the fourth retrial , and further to 12 years in fifth retrial by Judge Tsai Kuang-chih as he adopted the Beitou Hospital's diagnosis that said Chen was insane.

DOC.HEADLINE: Company taps into higher end Chinese medical tourism market

TEXT.P: While rescue workers were busy searching for a group of Chinese tourists missing in eastern Taiwan, another group of Chinese nationals were enjoying a leisurely checkup in the serenity of a hospital in the country's capital.

The group of 25 tourists, mostly middle-aged women in the beauty and cosmetics business, completed a detailed health exam Monday morning at Shin Kong Wu Ho-Su Memorial Hospital, said Alex Hung, president of Shin Kong Medical Club.
The experience was so enjoyable, Hung said, that some members of the group canceled the sightseeing part of their trip to squeeze in more health tests Tuesday.

"In China, a hospital is a place for sick people, " said a woman who would only identify herself by her surname Qian. She described the Taiwanese hospital as being more like home, with the strong aroma of coffee replacing the usual smell of disinfectant.

This group of medical tourists from Nanjing arrived in Taiwan Friday, a day after nearly 300 Chinese nationals were stranded on the scenic Suhua Highway on the east coast because of landslides triggered by Typhoon Megi.
Most of them have since been evacuated to safety, but 20 of them remained unaccounted for as of Monday night.

When asked whether the incident had any impact on her plan to come to Taiwan, Qian replied that initially her family had had qualms about her journey, but once a scheduled trip to the eastern part of Taiwan was scrapped, she jumped at the opportunity.

The Chinese visitors would not reveal how much they paid for the tour, but each had to first pay a membership fee of NT$177,890 (US$5,834) to join the Taiwanese-invested, Guangzhou-based Zion Health Control and Youth Rejuvenation Center (ZION).

ZION's stated purpose is to promote Taiwan's medical tourism to upscale consumers in China, offering them medical services at the centers on the mainland and bringing them to Taiwan for more thorough checkups once a year.
According to ZION CEO Tomson Lin, at least two groups of Chinese travelers will come to Taiwan every month for medical checkups beginning in December, boosting the country's medical tourism industry.
Lin explained that for medical tourism to flourish in Taiwan, promoting low-risk health checkups is a first step.
"Not only does it build up consumers' confidence, it is also easily accepted by most people," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Search continues unabated for missing travelers on Suhua Highway
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 22:08:40 (By Shen-hsu Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Search and rescue efforts for 25 people still missing from the collapse of Suhua Highway in eastern Taiwan due to landslides caused by Typhoon Megi last week, continued unabated on land, at sea and from the air on Monday, the Central Emergency Operation Center said.

The 25 missing people include: a group of 19 Chinese tourists, their Taiwanese tour guide and driver; a Taiwanese couple; and a Chinese tour leader and a Taiwanese driver from another tour group. The missing are feared to have fallen into the sea when their vehicles plunged down a steep mountainside when the highway they were traveling on collapsed.

On the ground, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) sent 35 personnel, including special force soldiers and engineers, to the site at the 114.5 km mark on the 118-km highway that connects Yilan and Hualien counties. Search teams used biometric and metal detectors.

Seventy-eight firefighters from Taipei and Taichung Cities, and Taoyuan County also searched at the site of 112.8 km mark, while 77 firefighters from Taipei and Taichung counties and the National Fire Agency searched at the 114.5 km mark. Joining them were 212 firefighters from the fire department of Yilan County.

In the aerial rescue, the MND sent an Air Force S-70C helicopter to the 114.5 km mark to assess the feasibility of transporting excavators there from the air, while another helicopter was sent to the 110-116 km marks to conduct sea and coastal searches.
The MND also sent a 22-member team to the sea to assess the feasibility of transporting the excavator by boat.
The center said vehicle wreckage retrieved have been sent to the Yilan Sports Park for cause analysis and body parts were sent to the Yilan County Funeral Home for identification.

The center also said that to help Yilan County, which was battered by torrential rains brought by Typhoon Megi, the MND has sent 6,651 military personnel to help with dredging, cleaning and disinfection works in the county.

DOC.HEADLINE: AsusTek denies Microsoft has made royalty request

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based AsusTek Computer Inc., the world's fifth-largest personal computer vendor, denied Monday that Microsoft Corp. had asked it to pay royalties on its Android smartphones, which the U.S. software giant said violated patents.
"We cautiously clarify that there is no such a thing, " AsusTek said in a filing Monday to Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp. in response to a local media report.
AsusTek said that it owned many patents itself and that it had always respected the protection and use of patent rights.
The Chinese-language Commercial Times reported that Microsoft sent a high-level legal officer to Taiwan to ask AsusTek and Acer Inc., the world's second largest PC vendor, to pay royalties.
In a filing to the stock exchange later in the day, Acer said it could not comment on the market speculation.
Microsoft has already received similar royalties from HTC Corp., the world's largest maker of smartphones using Google's Android operating system, the report said.
Weeks ago, Microsoft filed a lawsuit against Motorola Inc. "for infringement of nine Microsoft patents by Motorola's Android-based smartphones."

The patents include synchronizing e-mail, calendars and contacts, scheduling meetings, and notifying applications of changes in signal strength and battery power, the company said in a recent statement.

"Motorola needs to stop its infringement of our patented inventions in its Android smartphones, " said Horacio Gutierrez, the company's corporate vice president and deputy general counsel of Intellectual Property and Licensing, in a statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: After one year, Taiwanese brothers still detained in Tanzania: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Monday night confirmed that two Taiwanese brothers surnamed Hsu have been detained in Tanzania for over a year, but the ministry said it has closely monitored the situation.
MOFA spokesman James Chang said the older brother was the captain of an Oman- registered fishing boat Tawariq 1.
The older brother, along with a 30-plus member crew, was detained by Tanzania's government on March 8, 2009 for fishing illegally and holding an expired fishing license, Chang said.
The captain's younger brother, who operated a boat based in Kenya, was also detained when he went to Tanzania to try and rescue his older brother.

Chang said the matter was brought to the MOFA's attention on Oct. 25, 2009, and since then, the country's representative offices in South Africa and Oman have been closely watching the situation and providing necessary help.

Chang explained that the ship owner has hired lawyers to oversee the legal process and that the Oman government was also involved in the matter since the boat was registered in the Middle Eastern country.

"We immediately contacted a group of Taiwanese citizens in Tanzania to visit the two brothers as soon as we were notified of their plight. According to our knowledge, the two brothers are in good health," Chang said.
The MOFA official was unable, however, to offer any approximate timetable for the release of the two men.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan pop star Selina undergoes surgery for burns

TEXT.P: Taiwanese pop star Selina underwent surgery for burns to over half of her body in a hospital outside Taipei Monday afternoon.

The star's father Jen Ming-ting said his daughter has been incredibly strong throughout the five-hour debridement procedure despite the pain and confirmed more than 50 percent of her body had been burned and 60 percent of the burns were third degree.
Her cheeks were also scalded, he said.
It is the first surgical procedure the singer has undergone since suffering burns in an accident during the filming of a new television series in Shanghai, China.
It would take up to three weeks before knowing if a skin graft would be necessary, said Jen.

In an emotional micro blog post, Selina's mother described her daughter as both brave and strong, adding that she had passed on all the warmth and concern shown for Selina by her friends since the accident.
Full recovery could take up to a year, according to some estimates.
Selina is the stage name of Chia-hsuan Jen, a member of the three-girl pop group S.H.E. She returned to Taiwan by chartered medical plane late Sunday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese delegation unwise to spark name row in Tokyo: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 23:33:24 (By Eva Feng, Shu-hua Lee and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Chinese delegation was unwise to incite a row over Taiwan's name at the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival, a senior official in charge of China-related affairs said Monday.

"Through concerted efforts of both sides of the Taiwan Strait over the past couple of years, cross-strait relations have finally been moving toward positive interaction and a harmonious, peaceful atmosphere is gradually taking shape, " said Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chao Chien-min.

"This hard-won achievement, accomplished with the two sides respecting each other and working concertedly, deserves to be treasured," Chao said in a keynote speech delivered ahead of an award presentation ceremony for outstanding cross- strait exchange promotion groups.

He expressed regret that the Chinese delegation told the festival's organizers last weekend that the Taiwanese delegation should not attend under the name "Taiwan" but should use the designation of "Taiwan, China" or "Chinese Taipei" -- the title Taiwan uses when participating in the Olympic Games.
Chao said China's demand was unacceptable because Taiwan has participated in the Tokyo event in the name of Taiwan for many years.

Moreover, he said, the event is a private cultural activity organized by a nongovernmental organization. "It does not carry political significance and has nothing to do with national sovereignty," he added.

Stressing that the Chinese delegation's interference with Taiwan's participation at the event had hurt the feelings of Taiwan's people, Chao said Chinese authorities should not brush aside the episode lightly and should seriously review its attitude toward Taiwan.

Premier Wu Den-yih also said Monday that Jiang Ping, the leader of the Chinese delegation, was arrogant and overbearing in demanding the Taiwanese delegation change its designation at the Tokyo festival.
He urged Chinese authorities to maintain their goodwill toward Taiwan and take remedial measures to prevent the incident from affecting cross-strait rapprochement.

DOC.HEADLINE: More body parts from Suhua Highway accident victims found
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct 25 (CNA) 10/25/10 23:38:13 (By Jenny W. Hsu, Claudia Liu, and Mai-lan Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Yilan District Prosecutors Office said on Monday night that four sets of body parts were found during the day around the landslide-ridden Suhua Highway area but the identities of the victims had yet to be confirmed.
The heavy rains brought by Typhoon Megi last Thursday triggered landslides along the narrow highway overlooking the Pacific Ocean, burying cars and tourist buses and disrupting traffic.
One person has been identified as being killed in the disaster, while 25 others remain missing.

On the fourth day of the rescue operation Monday, search and rescue teams found several broken limbs and body parts, which were immediately sent to the Yilan County Morgue for DNA testing, the prosecutors office said.
Chief Prosecutor Wu Hui-lan said one of the limbs found Monday morning was a right leg, and a preliminary analysis on the toe suggested it belonged to a female.
The family members of a missing female Chinese tour leader named Tian Yuan have provided DNA samples for the medical examiners, hoping for a possible match.
Wu said the leg was found only 30 meters away from where a female body was located in the afternoon.
Another partial body with only the upper torso from the neck down was found around the same location. Preliminary testing suggested it to be the body of a male.
Wu said a finger print identification test would be conducted as soon as possible to confirm the identity of the body.

In the afternoon, another set of body parts -- a right leg connected to a left arm believed to belong to a woman -- was found roughly 8.5 nautical miles from a harbor in Yilan County's Jhuangwei Township, Wu said.

Earlier in the day, the search team found a purse that was later confirmed to be Tian's. The purse contained her passport as well as the passports of the 20 Chinese tourists in her group, who were all able to flee their bus before it was buried.
Two of the 20 sustained minor injuries and were to be kept under medical observation in Taiwan. The remaining 18 were scheduled to return to China Tuesday, the Tourism Bureau said.
The Taiwanese driver of the tour group also remained unaccounted for as of Monday night.

Tian's husband Kou Minghu, who flew to Taiwan immediately after he received the news that his wife was missing, said he last heard from her Wednesday night when she told him she was recovering well from a cold.

Kou described his wife as hardworking, thoughtful, and dedicated to her job. The director of the China-based Cross-Strait Tourism Association, Fan Guishan, also complimented Tian, saying all of her tour members praised her service.
Overall, Typhoon Megi has claimed 13 lives and left another 25 missing.

Most of the missing come from a tour bus traveling on the Suhua Highway on Thursday that has yet to be found. There were 19 Chinese nationals from Guangdong Province's Zhuhai and their Taiwanese tour guide and bus driver on board.

A group of 36 family members of the missing tourists along with seven Zhuhai City officials arrived in Taiwan Monday night and were to stay in a hotel in Yilan County, where they were to be received by the Travel Agent Association of the Republic of China.
The family members requested to see the bodies, dead or alive, and asked that all personal belongings found by the search team had to be brought back home to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Organizers apologize over China's hostility at Tokyo film fest
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/26/10 00:04:25 (By Ming-chu Yang and Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: The organizing committee of the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival on Monday offered an apology to the Taiwanese delegation, which was unable to walk the "green carpet" on the opening day due to a protest raised by the Chinese delegation over Taiwan's name.

Festival office chief Nobushige Toshima told the Central News Agency in a telephone interview that the Taiwanese delegation was among the distinguished guests invited by the festival organization while the Chinese were not.

On the opening night of the festival on Saturday, as throngs of international stars and film makers were gracing the green carpet, the Taiwanese and Chinese groups were feuding over the name that would be used to introduce Taiwan's delegation.

The Chinese side headed by director Jiang Ping demanded that Taiwan's group use the word "China" as part of its name, a request deemed unreasonable and rejected by the Taiwanese delegation led by Chen Chih-kuan, director of the Department of Motion Pictures Affairs under the Government Information Office.
The argument lasted over 90 minutes, causing both delegations to miss their grand entrances.

Speaking to the CNA, Toshima said the committee was shocked and dumbfounded when it received the news regarding the feud. But when asked why the organizers did not step in to mediate the dispute, he admitted the committee did not take good care of the Taiwanese delegation.

Taiwan has been a regular participant at the festival and has always attended under the name "Taiwan, " he said, and he promised that the committee would not deviate from that as long as Taiwan continues to be part of the event in the future.

During the argument, Jiang threatened the committee with an ultimatum that if the name issue was not resolved in China's favor within 10 minutes, the Chinese delegation would withdraw from the festival and contemplate never attending again.

According to an individual familiar with the film festival, Jiang's behavior left the committee feeling "used" as his own self-promoting tool. Although the Chinese delegation was at fault, the committee had its hands tied, the source said.

He also pointed out that Jiang participated in the film festival last year but did not make the same request. If Jiang had made the demand one week ahead of the event, the organizer would have had time to come up with a solution, but what Jiang did caught everyone by surprise.

In Taiwan, the news of the row has sparked a heated response from the government as well as the public. Premier Wu Den-yih described the behavior by the Chinese delegation as "ruthless, " while legislators have proposed to list Jiang as persona non grata.

DOC.HEADLINE: National dignity must be maintained: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/26/10 00:18:04 (By Ming-chung Lee, Kelven Huang, Chen-feng Bien and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The head of Taiwan's delegation to the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival said Monday that he was sorry Taiwanese stars missed walking down the green carpet at the opening of the event but stressed that the country's dignity had to be upheld.

Chen Chih-kuan, director of the Government Information Office's Department of Motion Pictures Affairs, was referring to the demand by Jiang Ping, head of China's delegation, who insisted that Taiwan attend under the name of "Taiwan, China" or "Chinese Taipei, " a demand Taiwan flatly rejected.

The spat resulted in both China and Taiwan missing the opportunity to walk down the "green carpet" Saturday. Vivian Hsu, one of the actresses in Taiwan's delegation, reportedly cried out of deep frustration.
Speaking upon his return to Taiwan, Chen said other issues should not have been brought into a cultural event, and he expressed his sorrow for the frustration felt by Taiwanese stars.
"But national dignity is paramount, and should be considered," he said.
Meanwhile, a party whip of the ruling Kuomintang in the Legislative Yean said Monday that he has proposed Jiang be listed as persona non grata in Taiwan.
Legislator George Hsieh also said he will appeal for signatures in Facebook to tell China that this is not an act that Taiwan will tolerate.
In related news, an official of the Executive Yuan said Monday that this is a "Jiang Ping incident" and that he should be listed as persona no grata.

The official, who asked for anonymity, said that if Beijing was pulling the strings behind Jiang, then his move was aimed at getting Taiwan to withdraw from the festival. But in the end, it was Jiang who left the festival early.
In addition, the organizers of the festival called on Chen Sunday to say that all remaining activities would be held as usual and not be affected by politics, the official said.
This did not conform to the past pattern of China pressuring Taiwan, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's baseball team dominates Hong Kong in local tourney

TEXT.P: Taiwan extended its winning streak to three in round-robin play of the Intercontinental Cup in Taichung Monday when it coasted past Hong Kong 10-0.

It was the first time Taiwan and Hong Kong had competed against each other in an international baseball tournament, and the two teams will face each other again next month at the Asian Games held in Guangzhou, China.
Taiwan's starting pitcher Lin Chen-hua pitched all seven innings of the game, called early because of the 10-run rule, striking out nine while yielding only two hits.
"I appreciated the chance to start the game. I always give everything I have, whether the opponent is powerful or not," Lin said in a post-game interview.

The Hong Kong team, making its debut in the tournament with nine under-18 players on its 20-man roster, has had few chances to compete with other countries since its first baseball association was founded in 1993.

The young team managed to surprise the host fans by getting the first hit of the game, while Taiwan was kept scoreless in the bottom of the first as its batters were caught off balance by Hong Kong starter Leung Yu-hung's slow breaking ball.
Kao Kuo-ching's grounder in the second inning brought home the first run for Taiwan, and the host added two runs in the fifth inning on Chen Chun-hsiu's RBI triple and Lo Kuo-hui's RBI-double.
Taiwan put the game completely out of reach in the sixth when it jumped out to an 8-0 lead.
In another game of the same group, favorite Cuba defeated South Korea 3-0. The 10-time champion of the tournament will face Taiwan on Tuesday in a game that will likely determine the group's winner.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 26, 2010, or the 19th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1879: Leon Trotsky, Russian communist leader who, along with Lenin, organized the October Revolution, is born. He was forced into exile by Stalin, sentenced to death in a Soviet court, and murdered in Mexico, where he had found asylum.
1919: Francois Mitterand, French president from 1981, and founder of the French Socialist Party, is born.
1931: Japan turns down a proposal of the Council of the League of Nations which adopted a resolution on Oct. 24 urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: Chinese troops begin a withdrawal from Shanghai to the northern Soochow River after Japanese troops capture Tachang. Shanghai would be captured by the Japanese Nov. 11.
1942: The aircraft carrier USS Hornet is sunk after being attacked by Japanese aircraft in the Solomon Islands Battle.
1944: After three days, the Battle of Leyte Gulf in the Philippines ends with victory for the United States. Over 30 ships are sunk in the great sea battle, most of them Japanese, including the Japanese navy's last four aircraft carriers.
1954: Britain and the United States end their occupation of Trieste and return control of the area to Italy.
1951: Winston Churchill is appointed British prime minister for a second time.
1955: The Republic of South Vietnam is proclaimed under Ngo Dinh Diem.
1961: Outer Mongolia is admitted into the United Nations.
1964: The Republic of China opens a consulate in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
1964: The Republic of China and Panama sign a trade agreement in Panama City.
1971: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Belgium as the latter establishes ties with mainland China.
1971: The Republic of China withdraws from the United Nations.
1973: President Richard Nixon prepares for the possible launching of World War III after hearing that the Russians are sending arms to the Middle East as war rages there.
1973: David M. Kennedy, the U.S. ambassador-at-large, arrives in Taipei for a three-day private visit.
1975: The First Taiwan Area Games opens in Kaohsiung with 4,980 athletes participating.
1979: Park Chung Hee, president of South Korea, is slain by Kim Jae Kyu, the head of the Korean intelligence agency.
1989: A China Airlines passenger plane crashes near Taiwan's Siulin Village in Hualien County on its way from Hualien to Taipei, killing 54 people on board.
1993: The ROC and Mexico sign a pact to promote bilateral investment and technology transfers.
1994: Israel and Jordan sign a peace treaty in a ceremony at their mutual border attended by U.S. President Bill Clinton, ending 46 years of hostilities.
1995: Russian President Boris Yeltsin is hospitalized in Moscow after an apparent heart attack, his second in four months.
1999: Nankang Software Park, the largest software manufacturing park in Asia, is opened by President Lee Teng-hui in suburban Taipei.
2000: Former Commander in Chief of the ROC Navy Adm. Yeh Chang-tung claims that he has been falsely accused in an impeachment brought against him by the Control Yuan.
2000: Morris Chang, chairman and chief executive officer of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., urges the government to open up to the mainland Chinese market or face the stifling of Taiwan's industry.
2001: A passenger ship sails from a harbor other than Liaolo directly to mainland China, marking a breakthrough in the "mini three links" implemented by the Republic of China government at the start of 2001 on a trial basis.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sages are of the same species as ourselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan's per capita private wealth third highest in Asia: Allianz
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 26 (CNA) 10/26/10 12:01:19 (By Jiun-wei Hsieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's financial assets per capita exceeded 50,000 euros in 2009, the third highest among Asian countries and the 18th highest among 50 countries from around the world, according to the 2010 Allianz Global Wealth Report.
With financial assets per capita of 51,332 euros, Taiwan was classified by the report as one of 21 high wealth countries out of the 50 surveyed, said the report released Monday.

Japan, ranked fifth in the world at 88,659 euros, and Singapore, ranked 10th in the world at 66,831 euros, were the only Asian countries among nine surveyed to have higher financial assets per capita than Taiwan.

The report on private household wealth, compiled by the Frankfurt, Germany- based Allianz Group, also found that Taiwan's per capita financial assets grew by an average of 5.6 percent between 2001 and 2007, lower than the growth enjoyed by Asia's emerging economies, such as China and India.
In 2008, however, when the financial assets of private households around Asia as a whole contracted by more than 4 percent, or around 800 million euros, Taiwan also suffered negative growth.

Though experiencing a 5.1 percent rebound year-on-year in 2009, Taiwan's financial assets per capita still had not fully recovered from the global financial crisis, remaining slightly below the 2007 level, the report said.

Of the other Asian companies surveyed, only Japan had also not rebounded to pre- financial crisis per capita wealth levels, but much of the rest of the world, and especially industrialized countries, faced similar predicaments.
According to the report, the global wealth of private households in 2009 (82.24 trillion euros) was still 4 percent lower than the 85.59 trillion reached before the crisis.

Globally, there were about 565 million people classified as part of the middle wealth class (with assets between 5,300 euros and 31,600 euros), considerably higher than the 300 million classified as such in 2000.
Of these 210 million, or 38 percent of the world's total, lived in Asia, with 9 million in Taiwan.
Of the 493 million people with high wealth, 110 million (23 percent) were in Asia, but a high percentage of this group (79 percent) was concentrated in Japan.
Other Asian countries studied in the survey were South Korea (24,821 euros), Malaysia (9,631 euros), China (2,521 euros), Thailand (1,754 euros), India (544 euros) and Indonesia (532 euros).

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Beijing's manipulation or personal incident?

TEXT.P: At the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival, the Chinese delegation's leader, Jiang Ping, demanded that Taiwan attend the event under the name "Taiwan, China" or "Chinese Taipei." We hope that this incident stemmed from Jiang's personal rudeness and ignorance and did not represent Beijing's official stance. Otherwise, it would irrevocably damage cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

First, Jiang's demand ran counter to Beijing's current policy toward Taiwan, which emphasizes "peaceful development" and "diplomatic truce." Second, his claim that "Taiwan is part of China" was inconsistent with Beijing's latest statement that "both the mainland and Taiwan are part of China."

We do not believe this incident was the result of Beijing's manipulation of the Taiwan issue. Nevertheless, the incident highlights the necessity for Beijing to adopt a more open-minded and innovative policy to ensure an equal footing for Taiwan and the mainland.

If Beijing does not do so, cross-strait ties could get hurt very often without cause or reason, and a struggle could erupt sporadically between doves and hawks in China. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 26, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Volkswagen: No agreement reached on investment in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/26/10 12:50:29 (By Yu-li Lin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: German automobile maker Volkswagen said it had not yet reached any concrete agreement on investing in Taiwan, but indicated that the island remained in consideration as a possible location for an overseas production site.

Taiwanese media reported on Monday that Volkswagen and Yulon Motor Co., Taiwan's largest auto maker, were expected to strike a deal under which Yulon would assemble cars for the German company, but a company spokesman in Germany said the reports were premature.

The spokesman acknowledged that because the Asian market has played an important role in the company's long term expansion strategy, "Volkswagen is looking for opportunities for expansion in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and Taiwan."
"But Volkswagen has not reached any concrete agreement on investing in Taiwan, " the spokesman said, declining to disclose further details about Volkswagen's expansion plan.

Media reports said Yulon was expected to produce two Volkswagen models, including the Golf, in an initial production phase, with the two companies currently engaged in negotiations on details, including assembly costs and production volume.
The two sides were expected to reach a deal by the end of November, according to the reports.
Taiwan's Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang previously told reporters he was aware that Yulon and Volkswagen had met but declined to disclose any further information.
Shih indicated, however, that the government welcomed foreign investment in Taiwan and would try its best to provide assistance to foreign investors, such as finding land for factory construction.
The local media also said Volkswagen is looking for potential partners in Taiwan to produce auto components.
Volkswagen, headquartered in Wolfsburg, Germany, is Europe's largest car maker in Europe. Its brands include Audi, Porsche, Seat, Lamborghini and Scania.
The German firm was one of the first foreign investors in China, and its annual sales volume there has reached 2 million units.
Through its aggressive efforts to expand in Asia, Volkswagen hopes to replace Toyota as the world's largest car producer by 2018.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suhua Highway upgrade awaits environmental assessment: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 26 (CNA) 10/26/10 13:29:07 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih promised on Tuesday that the government would begin holding tenders for work on a project to improve the safety of the Suhua Highway immediately after the plan passed an environmental impact assessment.

The project, he said, could be completed by the end of 2016 or earlier if the environmental impact assessment were conducted and passed in a strict and just manner, and the construction proceeded without any obstacles.
The premier also vowed to spend a significant sum to maintain the vital roadway linking Yilan and Hualien counties in eastern Taiwan before the completion of the upgrade project.

Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Wang Ting-sheng, who questioned Wu on the issue at a legislative hearing Tuesday, also asked the Taiwan Railways Administration to increase service on eastern Taiwan rail lines while work on the road improvement was underway.

According to the premier, the Cabinet asked the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) in late September to conduct an environmental impact assessment of the improvement project, and the first meeting of the EPA's panel of experts was held on Oct. 18.
The issue gained urgency after the accident-prone highway was hit by a series of landslides during heavy rains brought by Typhoon Megi last week, leaving one person dead and 25 others missing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Taiwan third in Asia in per capita wealth

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked third in Asia behind only Japan and Singapore with per capita financial assets of 51,330 euros (NT$2.126 million or US$70,406) at the end of 2009, according to a report released Monday by the Germany-based Allianz Group.
The group's Global Wealth Report reviewed household financial assets in 50 countries around the world at the end of last year.
Taiwan ranked 18th in the Allianz global rating, while Japan finished fifth and Singapore 10th. All three were listed as high wealth countries in the report.

According to the report, more than 9 million people, or 40 percent of Taiwan's population, were classified as middle wealth class people, defined as those with financial assets ranging between 5,300 euros and 31,600 euros.

Also Monday, the British newspaper Daily Mail unveiled the Legatum Institute's latest Global Prosperity Index that ranked Taiwan 22nd globally in terms of its ability to foster nine drivers of prosperity. The rating was two notches up from its 2009 ranking.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the reports: United Daily News:

The Allianz Group released on Monday the latest edition of its "Global Wealth Report, " which was based on the financial assets held by private households in 50 countries around the world at the end of 2009.
The report said that although global financial markets calmed down last year, losses in wealth caused by the 2008 credit crunch had yet to be overcome.

According to the report, global financial assets have grown at an average clip of 3.7 percent a year since 2001, but any gains were largely offset by an average global inflation rate of 3.4 percent over the same period.
Even more discouraging was that global financial assets at the end of 2009 were still some 4 percent lower than the level reached before the crisis, the report said.

Michael Heise, the group's chief economist, said most countries and individual investors have not yet fully overcome their wealth losses during the global financial crisis. Some emerging markets, particularly those in Asia, were able to buck the trend, however.
Led by China, India and Indonesia, emerging Asian countries have maintained average annual growth of more than 10 percent in per capita financial assets, the report said.

In contrast, Taiwan managed to register 5.6 percent growth in per capita financial assets for much of the previous decade, higher than the global average but eclipsed by China's and India's double digit growth.

According to the Allianz report, Taiwan's per capita household financial assets, including bank deposits, securities, hedge funds and insurance policies, exceeded 50,000 euros at the end of 2009, ranking 18th in the Allianz global rating.
The world's 10 richest countries in the Allianz survey were Switzerland, the United States, Denmark, the Netherlands, Japan, Belgium, Britain, Australia, Ireland and Singapore. (Oct. 26, 2010).
China Times:

According to the Daily Mail report, Taiwan ranked 22nd in the 2010 Global Prosperity Index compiled by the Legatum Institute, a global investment organization, moving up from 24th in the institute's 2009 survey.
Among Asian countries, Taiwan trailed Singapore (17th) , Japan (18th) and Hong Kong (20th).

The Prosperity Index gauges nine major indicators that drive economic growth and contribute to quality of life -- economic fundamentals, entrepreneurish and innovation, democratic institutions, education, health, safety and security, governance, personal freedom and social capital.
The countries and areas studied encompassed over 90 percent of the world's population.
The top five countries were Norway, Denmark, Finland, Australia and New Zealand. (Oct. 26, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: HTC sued for patent infringement by Gemalto

TEXT.P: Gemalto NV, a Netherlands-based provider of digital security services, said Monday it had filed a lawsuit in a district court in the United States against Taiwan's smartphone maker HTC Corp. for patent infringement.

Gemalto is also suing U.S.-based Google Inc. and Motorola Inc., as well as Samsung Electronics of South Korea, claiming all four had infringed its patents by using its technologies in Google's Android operating system, a statement issued by the company stated.
The patented technologies were developed at Gemalto's research and development base in Texas in the 1990s, claimed the lawsuit, filed in the Eastern District of Texas.
Gemalto said the patents were fundamental to running software developed in a programming language such as Java on a resource- constrained device.
"Gemalto is recognized as a pioneer and ground-breaking contributor to the JavaCard -- one of the devices for which the patented technologies were conceived, " the company said in the statement.
"This lawsuit is necessary to protect our investment in innovation, " Gemalto said. "The technologies we develop and associated intellectual property rights are essential to Gemalto's future."
HTC was not immediately available for comment on the litigation.

According to Gartner, an information technology research firm, Android ranked as the U.S. number one and world number three most popular smartphone operating system after overtaking Apple's iPhone OS.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Normalize cross-strait trade statistics

TEXT.P: In Taiwan, great discrepancies exist between statistics on cross-Taiwan Strait trade compiled by different government agencies.

For example, Taiwan's exports to China in 2009 totaled US$54.25 billion according to the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and US$62.09 billion according to the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

While the MOF bases its statistics on customs declaration forms filed by exporters, the MOEA and MAC try to include indirect exports via Hong Kong. Both numbers are inaccurate. The MOF tends to underestimate the volume of China-bound exports, and the MOEA uses a strange formula to estimate export volume.

With cross-strait trade and economic ties beginning to normalize following the signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement, the government should try to guide exporters to truthfully report the ultimate destinations of their shipments so that clear distinctions can be made between China-bound and Hong Kong-bound exports.
This will ensure that the country's statistics reflect the true state of cross- strait trade and allow the government to make better policy judgments. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 26, 2010)
