DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese documentary film wins U.S. award

TEXT.P: "Let's Be Friends! " directed by Taiwanese film-maker Wang Chun-chiang, won a Certificate of Honorable Mention at the 58th annual Columbus International Film and Video Festival in Ohio, United States, Taiwan's liaison office in Chicago said Tuesday.
The documentary film displays Taiwanese people's passion and friendliness and the depth of Chinese culture preserved in Taiwan, the office stated.
It is hoped the film will encourage foreigners to study Chinese in Taiwan, the office added.
Established in 1952 to encourage the use of film and video in all forms of education and communication, the Columbus, Ohio, event is one of the oldest film festivals in North America.
The Honorable Mention awards are presented on the basis of films' overall quality or notable production values, the organizer's website explains.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.43 percent

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.43 percent Tuesday on follow-through buying after the index stood above the 8,300-point mark for the first time in more than nine months a day earlier, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 36.25 points to 8,343.23, after moving between 8,319.01 and 8,353.86, on turnover of NT$119.49 billion (US$3.93 billion).

The market opened up 0.36 percent as investors took their cues from a six-month high recorded on Wall Street overnight, and the buying continued, largely focusing on old economy stocks amid optimism toward their earning outlooks, the dealers said.
A total of 2,176 stocks closed up and 1,728 were down with 399 remaining unchanged.

The paper and pulp sector posted the highest gains, up 1.94 percent. Plastics and chemical stocks added 1.77 percent, textile shares rose 1.3 percent, cement shares gained 0.72 percent and foodstuffs closed up 0.48 percent.
The financial sector rose 0.3 percent, the construction sector gained 0.22 percent and the machinery and electronics sector closed up 0.15 percent.
"With foreign funds continuing to flow into the local market, ample liquidity has served as a driving force to the gains, " Concord Securities analyst Allen Lin said.
Lin said investors, leaving the bellwether electronics sector behind for now, resumed intensive buying in traditional industrial firms during the trading session.
"The domestic demand-oriented old economy sector is unlikely to be affected by a rising New Taiwan dollar, while the currency appreciation is expected to hurt high-tech exports," Lin said.
However, after strong showings in the recent few sessions, the market is moving closer to the nearest technical resistance at around 8,400 points, Lin said.
"Unless turnover expands to NT$140 billion or more, the market is expected to consolidate for some time before overcoming the technical difficulties," he said.
Formosa Plastics rose 3.57 percent to NT$90.00 after Merrill Lynch raised its target price on the stock to NT$100 from NT$84.00 on rising product prices.
Among the other old economy stocks, Taiwan Pulp and Paper gained 5.53 percent to close at NT$20.05, while textile firm Far Eastern New Century added 2.85 percent to end the day at NT$46.90.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Tuesday, gaining NT$0.03 to close at NT$30.760.
Turnover totaled US$789 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.800 and moved between NT$30.530 and NT$30.820 before the close.
Dealers said the rise in the U.S. dollar largely reflected the appreciation of the greenback against other Asian currencies in the regional markets.
As the market opened, the New Taiwan dollar staged a gain on further inflows of foreign funds into the local stock market and the momentum continued through morning trade, the dealers said.
The benchmark weighted index rose 0.43 percent after a 1.7 percent rise a day earlier to breach the 8,300-point mark for the first time in more than nine months.
However, the strengthening of the local currency was largely compromised in the afternoon trading session by a strong U.S. dollar in the region, according to the dealers.
The central bank stepped in during the latter part of the session to buy U.S. dollars, placing further pressure on the local currency, the dealers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA rejects idea of hastening highway environmental assessment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 26 (CNA) 10/26/10 17:46:04 (By Lee Shien-feng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will not hasten an environmental impact assessment for the Suhua Highway improvement project, despite the urgency of the project, EPA Minister Stephen Shen said Tuesday.
According to Shen, Premier Wu Den-yih was merely expressing his personal opinion when he said earlier that the project could be completed by the end of 2016.
Shen said the EPA will respect the professional opinions of experts on whether the project can pass the assessment.

If the project proceeds as planned, the road will provide safer passage between Yilan and Hualien than the existing one, which follows the contours of a series of ravines, he said, explaining that the upgrading project will involve replacing entire sections of the highway with tunnels and bridges.

The safety of the Suhua Highway came to the forefront once again after the accident-prone road was hit by serious landslides during Typhoon Megi last week, leaving one person confirmed dead and 25 others missing.
Wu said earlier in the day that the government would begin holding tenders for the project as soon as it passes the environmental impact assessment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan uses soft power to raise international profile

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been trying to raise its international profile with the goal of becoming a full member of the world community even though its relations with mainland China have improved over the past year, the British Broadcasting Corporation has reported.

The efforts to stake out a more distinct international image are "part of a strategy promoted by President Ma Ying-jeou, who says Taipei must increase its so-called 'soft power' if it is to stand on the international stage," said the BBC on Sunday.

The strategy "includes developing globally famous brands, boosting Taiwan's presence not only in the high-tech sector but also in arts, food and fashion, and marketing great things about Taiwan," it said in a dispatch from Taipei.
As part of the efforts to help the outside world to know Taiwan better, the country's major news agency has increased its coverage in English.

"The state-funded wire service, the Central News Agency, has been revamped, " said the BBC. "It now offers its stories written in English about Taiwan on Google and - for the first time - English video news about the island."

The efforts to raise Taiwan's profile have been spearheaded by President Ma and his wife Chow Mei-ching, who has been sent "on more official visits overseas than most (other) Taiwanese first ladies", said the report.
Chow has visited the United States, Canada, Germany, Italy and Haiti, where she promoted Taiwan's performance troupes, read stories to children, and hugged disaster victims.

Later this year, Taiwan will open Taiwan Academies to promote Taiwanese culture and the learning of the Chinese language abroad, partly in response to the hundreds of Confucius Institutes China established overseas in recent years.

"Like European countries, which are not militarily strong, this sort of thing raises their image, " the report quoted Kou Chien-wen, a political science professor specializing in Taiwan-China relations at National Chengchi University in Taipei, as saying.

Analysts believe these efforts are partly aimed at distinguishing Taiwan from China and at ensuring the world does not forget the cause of the democratic and self-ruled island - to be recognized as acountry and included in international decision-making bodies.
It is not only the government which wants to improve Taiwan's international standing, the people of Taiwan "also have a strong desire for Taiwan to be recognized", said the BBC article.

The effects of Taiwan's efforts to boost its profile may be too early to tell, the report added, saying that for many Taiwanese people, success will depend on whether Taiwan is included in international organizations.
"Ultimately, many Taiwanese people want Taiwan to be given what they see as its rightful status and long overdue inclusion in global affairs, " it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier takes heat for not closing Suhua Highway during typhoon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 26 (CNA) 10/26/10 18:30:07 (By Kelven Huang and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Decisions to close roads should be made based on objective standards, said Premier Wu Den-yih Tuesday in explaining why the government did not close the Suhua Highway on Oct. 21, when heavy rains triggered lethal landslides on the roadway.

At a legislative hearing Tuesday morning, the premier was immediately asked about the government's approach last Thursday when rains from Typhoon Megi triggered landslides on the road that left one person dead and 25 others missing and feared dead.

"The Suhua Highway often suffers landslides. Why did the government only start managing the road after Typhoon Megi and a weather system from the northeast resulted in deaths? " asked Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Liu Chien- kuo.
The premier replied that when the tour buses that suffered accidents during the storm departed from Sincheng Township in Hualien County between 9:30-10:30 a.m. on Oct. 21, there was only light rain.

Data from the Central Weather Bureau (CWB), he said, showed that less than five millimeters of rain had fallen per hour at the Sincheng weather station from 8-10 a.m. that day, meaning there was no need to keep vehicles off the road.
Rainfall of 50 mm per hour is the current standard for closing roads, according to the Directorate General of Highways.
The premier said the Cabinet has discussed in the past setting up landslide monitors along the highway to provide information that could help authorities decide on road closures.
Other objective indicators that could be used, he said, include hourly rainfall and maximum wind speed data provided by the Central Weather Bureau.

Wu said, however, that some Hualien residents, who rely on the Suhua Highway to head north to Yilan County and Taipei, had objected to the idea, complaining that the major transportation artery should not be closed arbitrarily.

Meanwhile, environmental groups held a press conference at the Legislative Yuan to urge the government to push urgently to expand railway services in the area and develop sea transportation along the country's eastern coast, which had more predictable time frames than the Suhua Highway project.

They said they did not object to the highway renovation project, which will reinforce some existing road sections and bypass others with tunnels and bridges, but they insisted that the new roads be safe and sustainable and not approved in haste.

DOC.HEADLINE: North joins south on guard against dengue fever: CDC

TEXT.P: As two epidemic-command centers were established Oct. 21 to combat dengue fever in southern Taiwan, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) also drew attention to a new case in Taipei County and put the north on alert against the disease.

A 72-year-old male from Wugu Township this week became the third confirmed case of indigenous dengue fever in Taipei this year. Acknowledging that this number was yet small, CDC Deputy Director- General Ting Lin said that many more as-yet- unidentified cases might come to light.
The elderly patient had not visited the south nor been abroad, but he had lived close to two patients found to be infected with dengue fever after returning from a trip to Cambodia in late August.

"We have reasons to believe that this is the result of a cluster infection, and suspect that the elderly patient is not the only indigenous dengue patient living in Wugu, " said Lin, explaining that other people might experience only minor symptoms and not seek treatment.

Department of Health (DOH) officials immediately disinfected the patient's surroundings, mobilized volunteers to clean up possible mosquito-breeding sites, and set up a dengue-screening station locally to provide free blood tests.

Lin said that dengue cases hit a record high this week, with 156 cases nationwide, 139 of them in the southern cities of Kaohsiung and Tainan. Nevertheless, he warned residents in the north not to lower their guard toward possible infection.

DOC.HEADLINE: China-based textile firm seeks listing in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 26 (CNA) 10/26/10 20:09:38 (By Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Tainan Enterprise (Cayman) Co., Ltd., a China-based garment designer and producer, has filed an application with the Taiwan Stock Exchange for a primary listing, the exchange said Tuesday.
The exchange said the firm's parent company is Taiwan-based Tainan Enterprises Co. Ltd., which has been listed on the local main board since 2000.

The Cayman-Islands registered entity, capitalized at NT$573 million (US$18.83 million) , operates a fashion wear design and production base in Shanghai, targeting mid- and up-scale customers in China.
The company has a distribution network with more than 800 outlets in China, which accounts for almost 100 percent of the company's annual sales.
According to a company prospectus, it is planning to issue 7.82 million new shares for the listing, with a price tentatively set at NT$52, to raise about NT$406 million.
The prospectus said the money raised will be used as working capital to repay bank loans and expand its China operations.

The document said China is a fast-growing market for fashion wear, with garment retail sales in 2009 totaling 326.4 billion Chinese yuan (NT$1.49 trillion). The figure is expected to exceed 630 billion Chinese yuan in 2010.

In 2009, Tainan Enterprise (Cayman) posted NT$168 million in net profit, with earnings per share (EPS) at NT$2.95, according to the Taiwan Stock Exchange. In the first three quarters of this year, its net profit reached NT$46.01 million, with EPS at NT$0.8, the exchange said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Social housing policy on way: Premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 26 (CNA) 10/26/10 20:23:35 (By Hsieh Chia-chen, Johnson Sun, Lin Shen-hsu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday that his Cabinet has outlined three programs for a social housing policy and that under one of the plans, the process of selling the surface rights for state-owned property has begun.
Wu made the revelation at a legislative hearing, but did not provide further details on which state-owned property he was referring to.

President Ma Ying-jeou recently answered a call from a civic organization promoting social housing with a promise that the government will increase the percentage of rented public housing in Taiwan to resolve the problem that more and more people are unable to afford a home amid rising housing prices.

According to the non-profit Social Housing Promotion Union, the percentage of so-called "rented public housing" in the country is as low as 0.08 percent, compared with 6.06 percent in Japan and 29 percent in Hong Kong.

As part of the government's social housing policy, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced earlier in the day that the capital city will build 4,808 more units of public housing within the next four years.
With the already existing 5,986 units, the volume of such housing operated by the city government will have increased to 10,794 units by 2014, Hau said.
In the longer term, the city government will continue expanding the scale of public housing to a total of 20,329 units, he added.

On a different occasion that same day, Hau further explained his policies on building social housing and housing for young people who cannot afford to buy a home in the expansive city of Taipei, saying that they are based on models used in Singapore and the Netherlands.
Currently, the percentage of social housing -- housing that is let at low rents and on a secure basis to people in housing need -- stands at 0.64 percent in Taipei City, Hau said.
If he wins a second term as mayor in the year-end elections, Hau pledged, he will raise this to 1.29 percent within four years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Name row at film festival individual case: Premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 26 (CNA) 10/26/10 20:34:17 (By Kelven Huang, Li-ting Chen, Cheng-ching Liu & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday that a cross-Taiwan Strait row over the name Taiwan is using at the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival was an individual incident.

The row was incited Oct. 23 by Jiang Ping, leader of China's delegation to the festival, who insisted that the Taiwanese delegation should attend the event under the name of either "Taipei, China" or "Chinese Taipei," instead of the name it has always used at the festival and wanted to use this time -- "Taiwan."
Jiang's request was flatly rejected by Chen Chih-kuan, leader of the Taiwanese delegation and director of the Motion Picture Affairs Department Under the Government Information Office.
As a result, neither the Chinese nor the Taiwanese film stars walked down the festival's green carpet at the opening ceremony.

The name row triggered waves of outcry from Taiwan's public, media and lawmakers, decrying it as just part of China's efforts to squeeze Taiwan's international space despite the warming cross-strait relations since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May 2008.

"It should be of course counted as a separate and individual case, since the ruthless remarks were made only by Jiang and have not been repeated by any of China's official spokesmen so far, " Wu said while answering questions raised by Legislator Kao Chih-peng of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party during a legislative session.
"It would not be defined as an individual case if those kinds of overbearing remarks were made by any of China's spokesmen, " Wu added.

On Kao's challenge as to why the Cabinet had not demanded an apology from Beijing, Wu said the Presidential Office had already expressed that China should revise any of its remarks or acts that would hurt the feelings of Taiwan's people and be detrimental to the development of cross-strait relations.

Wu said earlier that same day at the legislature that a response expected the following day by the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council would be a major indicator to determine whether the name row incident was indeed an individual case.

Legislator Lai Shyh-bao of the ruling Kuomintang said at the session that he suspected the name row was a show purposely put on by the Chinese authorities and Jiang, who is a famous movie director and a high-ranking official in China's propaganda department.
He said the row can only be deemed an individual case if Jiang is dismissed upon his return to Beijing. "This would not be the case if Jiang were to be promoted," he said.
Foreign Ministry spokesman James Chang also described the row as an individual incident that will not negatively affect cross-strait relations.
He refused to say whether Jiang will be listed as persona non grata in Taiwan, as was suggested by some lawmakers.
Beijing had so far said little about the incident.
Spokesman Ma Zhaoxu of China's Foreign Ministry told CNA that day that his ministry "is aware of the name row incident."

He repeated remarks made by Sun Yafu, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office a day earlier that as far as Taiwan's participation in the international community is concerned, "both sides should make reasonable arrangements through bilateral coordination so long as they are made under the premise of not creating two Chinas or one China, one Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese managers not preferred as companies expand in China: poll

TEXT.P: Almost two-thirds of Taiwanese companies plan to expand their presence in China to cash in on growing local demand, but many said they do not necessarily prefer Taiwanese white-collar workers for management positions, a local poll showed Tuesday.

About 62 percent of local companies surveyed by 104 Job Bank, an online employment agency, saw China as a market rather than just a factory for their products or services, and 64.2 percent planned to increase their investments in China.

With only 14.5 percent of respondents regarding China solely as a production base, this showed a marked transition from a period in which Taiwanese electronics manufacturing companies invested heavily in setting up factories in China.
The transition also follows a recent promise by the Chinese government to boost local demand through its new five-year plan on national development from 2011.

While planning to expand their presence in China, 64.4 percent of the local companies polled also planned to boost their manpower there, in the fields of management (36.7 percent) , sales (27.3 percent) and marketing (25.5 percent).

While he believes that Taiwanese white-collar workers have an advantage over Chinese competitors for management jobs, Max Fang, the agency's public relations manager, acknowledged that 86 percent of companies said they do not necessarily prefer Taiwanese job seekers.
Half of the 86 percent do not consider nationality to be a concern as long as the company's goals can be achieved, Fang said at a press briefing in Taipei.

Many China-based Taiwanese companies had previously reserved senior jobs for Taiwanese nationals due to a lack of trust in Chinese people and in their professionalism, he added, citing high turnover rate as another problem.

Kathy Chung, the director of Taiwan's largest coffee-shop chain, 85J Bakery Cafe, told the press briefing that her company's operations in China had promoted many Chinese employees to executive positions or hired Chinese executives from China-based international companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Microsoft launches Internet-based TV service in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Microsoft Corp. announced Tuesday its first TV service in Taiwan, as the world's largest software company sought to break into the local TV market in cooperation with a cable operator.

The on-demand service, which at present is only available to subscribers of cable operator "Vee Time" in central Taiwan's Taichung City and Taichung County, allows users to watch or access TV programs on various Internet-connected devices, including televisions with set-top boxes, computers and smartphones running the Windows operating system.

"Cable subscribers have felt it inconvenient that they cannot organize favorite programs or pay by the number of channels they use. We have solved these problems by using Microsoft's media platform Mediaroom, " Vee Time Chairman Richard Lai said at a press briefing.
"Mediaroom provides an easy and friendly interface to subscribers, and it helps cut down operators' costs of running such a service," Lai told reporters.

The Internet-based service was expected to help increase the company's number of subscribers from 780,000 this year to 1.5 million by 2011, he said. Furthermore, he predicted the average revenue per user would rise from NT$550 (US$18) to NT$800.
Asked if Vee Time will collaborate with other Taiwanese operators to introduce this kind of TV service to China, Lai said that Taiwan has a favorable chance in the media market.
"Taiwanese operators have advantages in service and content provision. We should make use of these advantages and introduce our services to the digital convergence market in China," Lai added.

Speaking on the sidelines of the press conference, Microsoft Taiwan Corp. General Manager Davis Tsai confirmed that the first tablet computer launched by a Taiwanese manufacturer on Microsoft's new Windows 7 operating system will be unveiled in November, but he declined to reveal the name of the maker.
A market source said the manufacturer will unveil the tablet computer before the launch of similar devices by Acer and AsusTek.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei airport to reflect city's image: official

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said Tuesday that he hopes Taipei International Airport can become a "small but beautiful" airport once its reconstruction is completed in September 2011.
Mao said the airport, which reflects the personality of the city, will provide tremendous advantages for business travelers as it is located in downtown Taipei.

As part of the reconstruction process, the airport's arrival services for international flights will be relocated from Terminal 2 to Terminal 1, ahead of the launch of direct flights between Taipei and Tokyo's Haneda Airport on Oct. 31.

The relocation, the first-stage of a three-phase reconstruction plan that started in March, will facilitate the entry of international travelers, according to the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA).
Terminal 1 currently serves domestic flights and provides departure services for international flights, while Terminal 2 provides arrival services for international flights.

In the main lobby of Terminal 1, where international and domestic arriving passengers are expected to mix from Oct. 31, facilities such as self-check-in kiosks, huge screens for flight information display systems (FIDS) , and four- language (Chinese, Japanese, English and Korean) indexes will assist the travelers, the CAA said.
A new 60-meter-long baggage conveyor will be ready to deliver the first bags just seven minutes after an airplane lands, and all luggage within 30 minutes.
The airport will also provide 500 new trolleys that are easier to control and will improve the efficiency of baggage handling, the CAA said.
The entire reconstruction of Taipei International Airport will be completed by Sept. 2011, when international and domestic flight services will be separately handled in Terminal 1 and Terminal 2.

"Inevitably for now there might be some inconvenience and confusion, " Mao said when he introduced the remodeled terminal 1 to the media. "We are confident, though, that we will hand in a satisfactory report card once the entire reconstruction is completed next September, " he said.
Before the reconstruction moves into the second phase, Terminal 1 is expected to handle 1.8 million travelers per year, with international flights increasing from 70 to 126 each week.

DOC.HEADLINE: 30,000 doses of flu vaccine to be sent to Suao

TEXT.P: In response to a request from the authorities in Yilan County, 30,000 doses of seasonal flu vaccine will be dispatched to Suao Township, one of the regions hardest-hit by Typhoon Megi, to aid flood victims there, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Tuesday.
Residents in the disaster-stricken area, regardless of age and occupation, are eligible for government-funded free inoculations, said CDC Deputy Director- General Ting Lin.
With accumulated precipitation of nearly 1,000 mm in a single day during the typhoon, Suao experienced what the media described as its heaviest rainfall in a century.

Nearly 3 million doses of flu vaccine were purchased this year, but as of Tuesday, only 1.4 million have been administered free to high-risk members of the public, especially the young and elderly, since the beginning of a vaccination program that began Oct. 1, said Lin.

He added that the DOH does not rule out the possibility of giving the remaining vaccine to the general public for free ahead of December, the scheduled time for the free program to be extended to all members of the public.
According to statistics, from July to Oct. 21, 556 cases of severe influenza had been reported, with the death toll standing at 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: Potential exists for Taipei-Hongqiao flights to double: official

TEXT.P: Taipei International Airport could double its number of cross-Taiwan Strait direct flights to Shanghai' s Hongqiao Airport, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said Tuesday.
With Taipei Airport currently undergoing a reconstruction project, Mao said, there is still room for the Taipei-Hongqiao flights to be increased from four to eight per day.
However, he noted that related issues will still need to be ironed out through negotiations between Taiwan and China.

If the increase is realized, he went on, the number of daily Taipei-Hongqiao flights will equal the number between Taipei Airport and Tokyo's Haneda Airport, a new direct flight service route scheduled to kick off Oct. 31.
Taiwan and China started offering 28 Taipei-Hongqiao direct passenger flights in June this year.
Meanwhile, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) is hoping that direct flights between Taipei and South Korea's Gimbo Airport can start next October, with between two and four flights per day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Childhood tooth decay linked to adult oral problems: dentist
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 26 (CNA) 10/26/10 22:18:31 (By Ching-fang Chen and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Childhood tooth decay is an important indicator for adult oral disease, a dentist said Tuesday at a National Oral Health Week activity to promote dental health care to all age groups.

Bad dental habits from childhood will affect dental health later in life, said Chiu Yao-chang, a committee member of the Taiwan Dental Association, at the National Taiwan Science Education Center in Taipei.
Cavities mostly begin to appear before kids start going to school and after 10th grade, Chiu noted.

He explained that from elementary school to 9th grade, school children learn to brush their teeth after meals and are given fluoridated water, which helps prevent tooth decay. However, most children then slacken off on oral hygiene, leading to adult oral disease.
He also warned that oral problems can be transferred across generations when adults kiss or feed their infants, passing on the bacteria in their mouths to their children.
A study published by the Bureau of Health Promotion in 2004 found some 70 percent of Taiwan's pre-schoolers had an average of 5.5 cavities.

Over 99 percent of adults aged 18 and older in another study conducted in 2008 were diagnosed with different degrees of periodontitis, a set of inflammatory diseases affecting the gum tissue around the teeth.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suhua Highway improvement project approval expected within two months

TEXT.P: The hotly debated Suhua Highway improvement project could finally be given a green light sometime between November and December, Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday, four days after a fatal landslide on the 80-plus year old highway that connects Hualien and Yilan counties.

Speaking during a legislative interpellation session, the premier said that although a final consensus has not been reached, environmental experts and environmental activists have agreed that improvements must be made to ensure the road's safety. The environmental impact assessment of the project is expected to win approval from a review committee sometime in the next two months, he said.

Wu said that if the project goes according to a schedule submitted by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) , the bidding process for contractors can begin by year-end, with the project due for completion by 2016.
Torrential rain brought by Typhoon Megi Oct. 21-22 caused five sections of the highway to collapse and the road is not expected to be cleared for normal two- way traffic until Nov 15.

Wu promised that more safety measures will be implemented on the highway, such as installation of a surveillance system, fortification work on adjacent land and construction of a tunnel to bypass the most unstable section. The capacity of the road will also be monitored to make sure traffic volume does not exceed set limits.
The surveillance equipment, he went on, will provide the authorities with better information on when to cut down or limit the number of vehicles entering the highway.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), however, said the government's plan to give the go-ahead on the improvement project will not cure the root of the problem and that the government should instead come up with a comprehensive plan to foster the overall development of eastern Taiwan

DPP spokesman Lin Yu-chang said the recent incident accentuated the importance of a well-rounded environmental impact assessment. If construction work on the highway begins without careful analysis, more natural-disaster induced disasters are bound to happen, he warned.
The latest typhoon-related agricultural damage reported by the Council of Agriculture (COA) is estimated at NT$95.54 million (US$3.12 million).

Due to the Suhua landslides, many farmers and vegetable retailers on the east cost have been forced to take a longer route to deliver their goods to Taipei. The COA announced that day a NT$50 million temporary subsidy program to help offset these additional transport costs until the road has been cleared.

The total death count from the typhoon as of late Tuesday stood at 14 fatalities, including nine people who died when a Buddhist temple in which they were sheltering in Suao Township was buried by a mudslide. A total of 24 people were still unaccounted for, among them 20 Chinese nationals.
The family members of the Taiwanese victims are expected to receive NT$1 million from the government as a token of consolation.
Wu said the MOTC is still considering whether families of the Chinese victims are entitled to Taiwan's national compensation program.
Previous actions taken by the Chinese government for Taiwanese tourists hurt or killed while traveling in China will also be used as reference, Wu added.
Wu said all Taiwan-bound Chinese tourists are required to purchase travel insurance which will pay up to NT$5.1 million in the event of their death.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan loses to Cuba in Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament

TEXT.P: Taiwan was held scoreless Tuesday in a 2-0 loss to Cuba, yielding first place in the preliminary round to its opponent in the Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament in Douliou City, Yunlin County.
The two teams, each of which were undefeated in round-robin play prior to the game, were each unable to break the other side's defenses throughout the first five scoreless innings.

Cuba broke the game open with a 1-0 lead in the top of the sixth inning on a single by Gouriel Yulieski, who hit another later in the eighth to give the team a 2-0 lead that it maintained until the end of the game.
Taiwan was held scoreless off Cuba's starter Gonzalez Yulieski, who sent out seven strikes and gave up three hits in six innings.
Taiwan's starter, Hung Chih-lung, pitched seven and two-thirds innings, striking out eight batters and yielding five hits before relief pitcher Lo Ching-lung took over.
With the loss, Taiwan had finished its games in the preliminary group with a 3-1 tally to rank in second place behind 3-0 Cuba, which was scheduled to face Hong Kong the following day.
The second round of the tournament will begin Oct. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: Missing Taiwan bus driver confirmed dead
DOC.DATELINE: Yilan, Oct. 26 (CNA) 10/26/10 23:37:57 (By Claudia Liu, Shen-hsu Lin, Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: The body parts found along an eastern coastal highway hit by landslides last week were belived to be those of a missing tour bus driver, Yilan District Prosecutors Office said Tuesday.

Tsai Chih-ming had been missing since Thursday, when heavy rain and strong gusts brought on by Typhoon Megi caused several rockslides on the Suhua Highway. His incomplete remains were found near the 112.8-kilometer mark of the winding road and identification was done using his daughter's DNA sample.

Tsai was the driver of a tour bus that carried a 20-person group of mainly Chinese nationals before it was presumably hit by falling rocks and mud. A female Chinese tour leader is still missing and presumed dead.

With the identification of Tsai's body, the death toll from Thursday's deluge increased to 14 while 24 are still unaccounted for. The missing persons include a group of 19 Chinese tourists from Zhuhai, Guangdong Province.

A total of 36 family members representing the missing tour group arrived in Taiwan on Monday and have asked the Taiwanese authority to expand the scope of the search, holding on to a hope of finding their loved ones, dead or alive.

The Taiwanese military has dispatched helicopters, patrol boats and Marine Corps divers to comb the areas near landslides from all directions. To further the search, the Central Emergency Operation Center said it had asked the navy to evaluate the feasibility of mobilizing a mine sweeper to scope out the waters below the 114.5-kilometer mark of the devastated highway.

DOC.HEADLINE: National police chief embarks on China visit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 26 (CNA) 10/26/10 23:59:19 (By S.H. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Wang Cho-chiun, director-general of the National Police Agency (NPA) under the Interior Ministry, left for China Tuesday for an eight-day visit, making him the agency's first incumbent chief to set foot on Chinese soil, the NPA reported in a news release that day.

Traveling at the head of a 16-member delegation that includes Criminal Investigation Bureau Commissioner Lin Teh-hua, Wang will visit Beijing, Shanghai and cities in Jiangsu and Zhejiang provinces before returning to Taiwan Nov. 2.

According to the release, the main purpose of Wang's visit revolves around the establishment of a cross-Taiwan Strait judicial assistance mechanism in a bid to further step up two-way cooperation on fighting crime based on the framework laid out in a pact inked in April 2009 during the third round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks.

Other issues such as exchanges of personnel and document verification will also be touched upon in Wang's meetings with high-ranking Chinese public security officials, including Public Security Minister Mong Jianzhu, it said.
His visit follows a Sept. 13-18 trip to Taiwan by China's Public Security Vice Minister Chen Zhimin during which he reached consensus with his local counterparts on several key issues.
From April last year until the end of September, law enforcement authorities of the two sides had jointly cracked 17 cross-border fraud cases, arresting 1,245 suspects, according to the NPA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan less corrupt: Transparency International survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 26 (CNA) 10/27/10 00:44:03 (By Garfei Li, Sherry Tang and Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan moved up four places in this years Corruption Perception Index (CPI) , ranking 33rd among 178 countries in the annual survey, Transparency International Taiwan (TIT) announced on Tuesday.
Taiwan ranked sixth in the Asia-Pacific region, trailing New Zealand, Singapore, Australia, Hong Kong and Japan, according to the survey.
Presidential Office Spokesman Lo Chih-chiang welcomed the result but said there is still much room for improvement.
"Clean governance is a core value of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration. The improved ranking shows the government's anti-corruption initiative has proven effective," he said.

Lo said in the past two and half years President Ma and government officials at all levels have pushed vigorously for a clean government, citing the passage of various anti-corruption laws in order to stop the "red envelope" practice that has long existed in Chinese culture.

The spokesman pointed out that in 2000 Taiwan's ranking shot up to 28th but quickly moved down after the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) headed by former President Chen Shui-bian became the ruling party. Chen is currently detained on charges of money laundering and corruption.
Echoing Lo's comments, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) pledged to to take further steps to improve conditions in the future.

The Germany-based Transparency International is a global coalition to monitor anti-corruption efforts by governments around the world. The organization defines corruption as the abuse of entrusted power for private gain. The 2010 CPI draws on information gathered from business opinion surveys carried out by independent and reputable institutions.
Taiwan's ranking fluctuated between 25th and 35th place from 1995-2007. In 2008, Taiwan dropped to 39th and moved back to 37th the following year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 27, or the 20th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1728: Captain James Cook, English navigator, is born. His voyages on the ship Endeavour led to the European discovery of Australia, New Zealand and the Hawaiian Islands.
1858: Theodore Roosevelt, U.S. statesman and president, is born. He won the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts in ending the Russo-Japanese War in 1905.
1921: Yen Fu, a noted Chinese translator who introduced Western culture to China, dies in his hometown of Minhou in Fukien Province at the age of 67.
1922: The Italian government resigns under increasing pressure from the fascist movement under Benito Mussolini.
1927: Mao Zedong leads his followers and reaches Chingkang Mountain in Kianghsi Province to establish a stronghold for the Chinese Communist Party.
1930: The Wuhsheh Incident occurs when Taiwan's aboriginal inhabitants in the Wuhsheh area of Taichung County launch their resistance campaign against Japanese rule and kill 134 Japanese.
1931: Representatives from Nanking and Canton meet in Shanghai for peace negotiations.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States to address a joint session of the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives.
1947: The Ministry of the Interior announces that the "Democracy Alliance" is an illegal organization subject to being cracked down on in accordance with current laws.
1947: The Sino-American Relief Treaty is signed in Nanking under which US$30 million worth of relief goods are to be shipped to Taiwan.
1955: Taiwan's first sex-change operation is successfully carried out at the Army First Hospital.
1961: The 16th United Nations General Assembly votes in favor of the admission of Outer Mongolia. The Republic of China abstains from the vote.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a treaty of amity in Seoul.
1974: Teizo Horikoshi, president of the Interchange Association of Japan, and Sadan Iguchi, the association's director, arrive in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1978: President Anwar Sadat of Egypt shares the Nobel Peace Prize with Premier Menachem Begin of Israel.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo calls on Korean Ambassador Ock Man Ho to express his condolences over the death of President Park Chung Hee.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan defends his decision to send a 2,000-strong force of Marines and Army Rangers to the Caribbean island of Grenada.
1986: An international conference on "Chiang Kai-shek and Modern China" opens in Taipei, with more than two hundred Chinese and foreign scholars attending the four-day meeting.
1987: A referendum in the Republic of Korea approves constitutional reforms, including the establishment of direct presidential elections.
1990: Moscow City Mayor Gavriil H. Popov arrives for a formal visit to the ROC to discuss the strengthening of ROC-Soviet trade relations.
1994: The Legislative Yuan passes revisions to the "Wildlife Conservation Law," greatly toughening penalties against violators and stipulating that the breeding of endangered animals in captivity must cease within three years.
1997: The Dow Jones index drops 554.26 points, its largest one-day decline in terms of points.
1999: The International Relations Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives amends and passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, aiming at extending U.S.-Taiwan security ties.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian and Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan hold their first meeting since Chen's election in March, in which Lien urges Chen to convene a National Unification Council meeting.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announces a decision to halt construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant, saying the move is the only choice for building a nuclear-free homeland.
2001: The 47th congress of the Asia Pacific League for Freedom and Democracy (APLFD) opens at a Auckland, New Zealand hotel with the participation of some 60 delegates from 15 countries.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sense of mercy is in all men; the sense of shame is in all men; the sense of courtesy and respect is in all men; the sense of right and wrong is in all men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Wednesday from its previous close, moving up 26.52 points at 8,369.75 on a turnover of NT$3.26 billion (US$105.16 million).
The weighted price index gained 36.25 points, or 0.43 percent, to close at 8,343.23 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China Times: Suhua Highway upgrade project

TEXT.P: In the wake of serious landslides caused by Typhoon Megi last week, calls have been mounting for an early start of an upgrade project for Suhua Highway.

The project must be launched as soon as possible to provide residents in eastern Taiwan "a safe road to travel home." In doing so, the government needs also to reduce the road's impact on the environment and the area's ecological system.

According to a Directorate General of Highways plan, tunnels will be built as alternative routes for landslide and erosion-prone sections of the coastal highway. It is hoped that the project will pass an environmental impact assessment by the end of this year, after which tenders for construction work on the highway upgrades can be opened.
The upgrade project will not provide a total solution to the existing problem, however, because the affected sections of the highway will remain in service even after new roads are built.

An early-warning system must be set up on the highway to prevent accidents and casualties. We must also examine Taiwan's ability to resist disaster amid drastic climate change. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 27, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$30.730 at 10 a.m. Wednesday at the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.03 from Tuesday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wet, cool weather hits northern Taiwan as typhoon moves northward
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 10:52:49 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Temperatures dropped to a low of 15.5 degrees Celsius in the northern Taiwan coastal town of Danshui early Wednesday as Typhoon Chaba moved northward to strengthen the effect of seasonal winds from the north, the Central Weather Bureau reported.
Typhoon Chaba was located 850 kilometers east of Hengchun in southern Taiwan at 2 a.m. Wednesday and was moving northward toward Japan at 10 kilometers per hour, the bureau said.
Although the typhoon is not expected to directly threaten Taiwan, the convergence of its periphery and seasonal winds will indirectly affect Taiwan's weather in the coming two days, the bureau said.
Coastal regions throughout Taiwan may see strong winds comparable to those brought by a tropical storm, meteorologists said.
Strong seasonal winds may also bring heavy rains to northern coasts and mountain regions in northern Taiwan and the northeastern county of Yilan, they added.
The weather bureau forecast that cooler rainy weather will continue through Thursday.
The mercury in Danshui fell to 15.5 degrees Celsius early Wednesday morning and was expected to range between 16 C and 22 C during the day.
Temperatures in other parts of Taiwan, particularly northern and northeastern Taiwan, also dropped Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Conditioned Reflex

TEXT.P: An altercation recently erupted at the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival over the name used by Taiwan to attend the event, in which the Chinese delegation's leader, Jiang Ping, rudely insisted that Taiwan use the name "Taiwan, China" or "Chinese Taipei."

To protect hard-won detente across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan's government described the blowup as an isolated incident stemming from Jiang's personal behavior. This was the right thing to do. It was not worth wasting our time arguing over Jiang's action.

Chinese officials who experienced persecution and class struggle during the Cultural Revolution learned they could protect themselves by leaning toward the left rather than the right. It was a kind of conditioned reflex for Jiang to call Taiwan part of China upon seeing Taiwan's delegation.

Such left-wing communism, which the late Marxist revolutionary Vladimir Lenin described as an "infantile disorder, " is harmful to China. It also proved to Taiwan's people that unification with China is absolutely not a good thing. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 27, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Giant earnings lifted by global warming concerns: analyst
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 12:15:52 (By Maranda Hsu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Giant Manufacturing Co. Ltd., one of the world's largest bicycle makers, posted double digit earnings growth for the first three quarters of 2010 in part because of lingering concerns over global warming, an analyst said Wednesday.
Giant on Tuesday announced net earnings of NT$2.34 billion (US$76.46 million) for the first nine months of the year, up 29.6 percent from a year earlier. Earnings per share were NT$6.6.
During the same period, Giant had sales of NT$33.38 billion, up 12.3 percent from the same period in 2009.
"Buying environment friendly products, like bicycles, has become a trend in the global market, " MasterLink Securities analyst Tom Tang said. "Giant is one of the beneficiaries of such a trend."
Tang said the EPS of NT$6.6 was relatively high for the old economy sector.
"It is very possible for the company to generate an EPS of NT$8 for 2010," he said.

According to Giant, while sales in the domestic market appeared to have slowed after a strong showing in 2009, its sales in overseas markets, including the United States, Europe, China, Japan, Australia and Canada, continued to grow.
A new subsidiary in South Korea that began operations last year also generated better than expected gains in earnings.
"Giant has become one of the favorites of foreign institutional investors. Foreign investors are very willing to hold the stock, " the analyst said.
Foreign institutional investors now own about 50 percent of Giant's shares in circulation, a ratio few old economy stocks could match, Tang said.
As the stock's valuation now appeared high, however, after recent intensive buying from foreign investors, it was approaching its nearest technical resistance at around NT$126.00, Tang said.
He suggested that investors buy the stock cautiously and remain aware of a possible technical pullback in the near future.
At 11: 46 a.m., Giant was up 0.4 percent at NT$120.00, off an early high of NT$123.00, with 647,000 shares changing hands. The benchmark weighted index was down 0.41 percent at 8,309.15.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing blames communications breakdown for row over name in Japan

TEXT.P: China's Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) on Wednesday blamed a "lack of communication" for the row over the name of Taiwan's delegation on the opening night of the Tokyo International Film Festival last Saturday.
It also urged the two sides to avoid "internal fighting" in public in the future to jointly safeguard the overall interests of all Chinese people.

"The situation probably took place due to a lack of communication between both sides. This is something we do not wish to see, " said TAO spokesman Yang Yi when asked about the altercation at a regular press briefing.
He added that he believed the matter would not affect the future collaboration or exchanges between filmmakers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
"Both sides should avoid internal fighting in public situations in the future in order to jointly safeguard the overall interests of all Chinese people," Yang said.

During the news conference, Yang did not directly reprimand Jiang Ping, the director of China's delegation who instigated the incident when he demanded that Taiwan's group must include "China" in its official name at the film festival.

Jiang's demand was immediately refused by the Taiwanese delegation, which asserted that Taiwan had always participated in the festival as "Taiwan" and that there was no reason to deviate from the usual practice.
Chen Chih-kuan, director of the Department of Motion Picture Affairs under the Government Information Office who headed the Taiwanese delegation, told Jiang not to mix arts with politics.
The incident lasted over 90 minutes and cost both delegations the chance to walk the "green carpet."

It also ignited anger among Taiwan's people and public officials. Premier Wu Den-yih described Jiang's behavior as "ruthless" and said it undermined the recently warming ties between Taiwan and China, even if an isolated case.
Taiwanese lawmakers proposed to list Jiang as "persona non grata."

On Tuesday, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Ma Zhaoxu told the Central News Agency that his ministry was aware of the incident and urged better coordination over Taiwan's participation in the international community.

"Both sides should make reasonable arrangements through bilateral coordination so long as they are made under the premise of not creating two Chinas or one China, one Taiwan," Ma said, repeating a comment made by TAO Deputy-Director Sun Yafu earlier in the day.

The festival's organizing committee offered an apology to Taiwan over their lack of action in handling the matter. The festival office's head, Nobushige Toshima, promised that Taiwan will always be welcomed to attend the festival using the name "Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu Yen-hsun scores upset in St. Petersburg Open doubles
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 13:30:50 (By Oscar Wu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Lu Yen-hsun teamed with Germany's Rainer Schuettler to upset the top seeds in the first round of the St. Petersburg Open men's doubles on Tuesday.

Lu and Schuettler knocked off Frantisek Cermak of the Czech Republic and Michal Mertinak of Slovakia 7-6 (5) , 6-3 to set up a quarterfinal encounter against the Russian duo of Michail Elgin and Teymuraz Gabashvili.

Playing against a team that grabbed five ATP-level men's titles in 2009 and another in Malaysia this year, Lu and Schuettler were not particularly sharp in the first set, losing their service games twice.
But they managed to break their opponents twice as well, setting up a tense tiebreaker that went to 5-5 before the Taiwan-Germany team snatched the final two points to close out the set.
The second set turned in the pivotal eighth game, when Lu and Schuettler broke the top seeds' serve for the only time in the set on the second break point of the game.
That gave them a 5-3 lead, and they served out the final game to clinch the victory.

The winning duo had not played doubles together since the 2009 Australia Open early last year. Their best result was winning the Chennai Open doubles in 2005, Lu's first ATP-level doubles title in his career.
Lu, seeded fourth in the men's singles at St. Petersburg, was scheduled to play his first round match there against Italian Potito Starace Wednesday afternoon.
The 27-year-old, now ranked 34th in the world, is coming off a title win in a second-tier ATP Challenger event in South Korea this past weekend.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese solar cell maker cuts deal with Chinese firm
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 14:03:30 (By Maranda Hsu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Neo Solar Power Corp. (NSP), a Taiwan-based solar cell maker, announced Tuesday that it has signed an agreement to purchase solar wafers from China's GCL-Poly Energy Holdings Ltd. in a bid to secure a steady production material supply.

In a statement, NSP said that GCL, the largest polysilicon supplier in China, will start to provide a total of 350 megawatts-worth of solar wafers to the Taiwanese company from the fourth quarter of 2010 to the end of 2013.
The Taiwanese company said the purchasing agreement is aimed at lowering manufacturing costs and maintaining wafer quality and timely delivery.
NSP said that the two companies have already established a long-term partnership and that the agreement is expected to strengthen the strategic relations between the two sides.

"This long-term cooperation sustains both companies on production capacity and business operations, leading to significant expansion of global presence and a win-win situation, " the company said in the statement.

NSP Chairman Quincy Lin said that given the sourcing availability of wafers and orders, his company is expected to continue to post solid gains in sales and earnings after a strong showing in the first three quarters of this year.

In the nine months to September, NSP posted NT$13.37 billion (US$436 million )in sales, up 92 percent from a year earlier, while its net profit totaled NT$1.96 billion with earnings per share of NT$8.95.
According to the statement, GCL owns a 20 megawatt solar farm in Xuzhou, Jiangsu Province, the largest solar farm in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Mayoral election campaign heating up

TEXT.P: With the mayoral elections for five special municipalities only one month away, campaign activities have heated up.
Violent clashes between campaign workers and supporters of Taiwan's two major political camps were reported in Taichung City and Tainan City on Tuesday.

Meanwhile, the results of an opinion poll published in Wednesday's United Daily News showed that if Taipei City voters were to go to the polls tomorrow, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) challenger Su Tseng-chang would beat incumbent Mayor Hau Lung-bin by a narrow 51 percent to 49 percent margin.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the electoral campaign.
China Times:
Clashes erupted Tuesday when Taichung City police tried to prevent a convoy of campaign vehicles of DPP mayoral candidate Su Jia-chyuan from entering the city hall complex in central Taiwan.

A group of DPP city councilors first shouted from atop the vehicles that they wanted to enter City Hall to protest what they called the city government's failure to maintain "administrative neutrality."
The group accused the city of repeatedly rejecting applications from Su's campaign office to hold rallies in city parks or at elementary schools.

After getting down from their vehicles, they attempted to force their way into City Hall but were blocked by rows of police. In chaotic clashes, three DPP councilors said they sustained leg injuries after being pushed by police officers to the ground.
The violent protest ended only after the city government agreed to allow the councilors to enter City Hall on the condition that they took off their campaign vests.
The city councilors rushed to the mayor's office on the second floor but failed to meet Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, who according to his aides, was out on public business.

Huang Ching-hsiao, director of the city government's Department of Construction, denied that the city government blocked the Su campaign's Oct. 5 application to hold a rally at the city's Gancheng Park.
"The application was approved Oct. 19, " Huang said, asserting that the screening procedures took 14 days to complete.

The Nov. 27 mayoral election in the central Taichung municipality to be formed by merging Taichung City and Taichung County later this year has Su challenging Hu's bid for re-election. The ruling Kuomintang has traditionally been stronger than the DPP in both Taichung City and Taichung County.

Responding to Su's complaint that the city government illegally rejected his application to hold a rally at Kuangfu Elementary School, the Central Election Commission said Tuesday it does not have the authority to get involved in such disputes because existing election law does not contain relevant provisions. (Oct. 27, 2010).
Liberty Times:

Clashes also erupted between the rival camps in the southern city of Tainan Tuesday when KMT candidate Kuo Tien-tsai's campaign aides visited the campaign office of DPP rival Lai Ching-te to push for a Kuo-Lai debate on their policies.
Chang Pi-chin, a spokeswoman for the Kuo campaign, stumbled after being pushed by Lai's supporters but was not injured. The conflict ended after police arrived at the scene.

Lai described Chang's visit as grandstanding to raise Kuo's profile, because, according to Lai, the KMT was the party that prevented debates from being held between KMT and DPP hopefuls in the five special municipality elections on Nov. 27. Tainan is seen a DPP stronghold. (Oct. 27, 2010).
United Daily News:
Respondents to an election-related public opinion poll can be grouped into "vocal" and "silent" voters in terms of their willingness to express their voting preferences in public.

According to the results of a telephone poll conducted by this paper between Oct. 23 and Oct. 24, incumbent Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin led his DPP challenger Su Tseng-chang by a large margin, 48 percent to 37 percent.

Compared with the results of a similar survey conducted a month ago, Hau's and Su's support ratings rose 7 percent and 4 percent, respectively, and the ratio of those unwilling to reveal their voting preferences narrowed from 26 percent to 14 percent.

An in-depth analysis of the latest survey findings showed, however, that if the population characteristics and political attitudes of those who declined to answer the poll were taken into consideration, Su's support rate should reach 51 percent, higher than Hau's 49 percent.

Nevertheless, it is still premature to come to any conclusion about the race's outcome because the gap fell within the poll's 3 percent margin of error, and voting is still a month away, during which many variables could affect the final results. (Oct. 27, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing calls for continued search for missing Chinese tourists
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 14:26:28 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Beijing urged Taiwan Wednesday to continue searching for a group of Chinese tourists who were reported missing in eastern Taiwan when Typhoon Megi struck last week.

Yang Yi, spokesman for the Taiwan Affairs Office, said in a news conference held in Beijing that of the 269 Chinese nationals who were traveling on the Suhua Highway when landslides caused a section of the highway to collapse, 247 had already returned to China and two were receiving medical treatment in Taiwan.
The remaining 20 other Chinese travelers remained unaccounted for as of press time.
The confirmed death toll in the landslide accident stood at two as of Wednesday, with four other Taiwanese also unaccounted for.

In Taiwan, Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said that over the past week, the military has deployed more than 200 soldiers every day for the search and rescue operation, with work currently underway at the 112.8-km, 114.5-km and 116-km marks of the highway.
He said excavators airlifted to the site two days earlier were being used at the 112.8-km mark.

Meanwhile, manual excavation began Wednesday at the 114.5-km mark, where metal detectors discovered responses under the rubble at nine different sites, Jiang said. Rescuers were considering using a boat to deliver excavators to that location because the area is unsafe for helicopter landing.
At the 116-km mark, metal detectors were also to be used to check for possible traces of buried vehicles, according to the minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: Silicon Valley businesses said to expand investments in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 26 (CNA) 10/27/10 15:47:13 (By Leaf Jiang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Many enterprises in California's Silicon Valley have signed letters of intent to increase their investments in Taiwan, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Sheng-chung said during a visit to the U.S. high-tech hub Tuesday.

Lin Sheng-chung, traveling at the head of a business promotion delegation, said he had visited several companies in the valley, including the A10 Network, which specializes in cloud computing, Henlius Biopharmaceuticals, Cisco and Lam Research since arriving in California two days earlier on a trip aimed at drawing investors to Taiwan.

Many enterprises have expressed interest in opening research and development centers in Taiwan, Lin said. He attributed the expected new investment to Taiwan's signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement with China in June, which he said has turned Taiwan into a bridge that enables international businesses to easily enter the vast Chinese market.

He also touted the Taiwan government's efforts to improve the investment environment, including cutting the business income tax to 17 percent and expanding government subsidies for the manufacturing industry to the services sector.

Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) Vice President Liu Jong-min, a member of the delegation, said that most American enterprises have strong capability in software design and know how to integrate different systems and create new products.

Taiwanese enterprises lack those characteristics and therefore, the ITRI will increase its developments in the field of system integration to help Taiwanese businesses improve their innovation abilities, Liu said.

According the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the delegation was tasked prior to departure on its week-long visit with promoting Taiwan's "six major emerging industries" -- tourism, biotech, green energy, health care, agriculture and cultural innovation -- as well as the "four intelligent sectors" that focus on the development of cloud computing, electric vehicles, green architecture and the commercialization of patented inventions.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Post: Tiaoyutai voyage is folly

TEXT.P: Politicians have to be thymotic or fearful of not being recognized. So a group of Taiwanese legislators are set to leave Nov. 4 for the Tiaoyutai Islands to join in a diplomatic spat between China and Japan over the eight uninhabited islets, which the Japanese call the Senkakus and the Chinese call the Diaoyutais.
The row started with the arrest of a Chinese trawler skipper and the seizure of his ship in the waters off the Tiaoyutais Sept. 7.

The best thing our prideful lawmakers can do for the good of the country is to call off their planned voyage. We only want to shelve the sovereignty dispute to resolve issues relating to fishing rights and the development of oil resources under the sea in our best national interests. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 27, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 0.62 percent

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 0.62 percent Wednesday as investors pocketed the significant gains posted in the previous two trading sessions, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 52.19 points to 8,291.04, after moving between 8,285.73 and 8,372.52, on turnover of NT$110.17 billion (US$3.59 billion).

The weighted index opened up 0.32 percent but began to lose steam as investors witnessed declining regional markets, including Shanghai, Hong Kong, Tokyo and Seoul, and cut their holdings, with selling focusing on old economy stocks, the dealers said.
A total of 2,678 stocks closed down and 1,194 were up with 330 remaining unchanged.

The paper and pulp sector suffered the heaviest losses, down 2.23 precent. Cement stocks dropped 1.51 percent, foodstuffs lost 1.24 percent, textile firms fell 1.15 percent and financial shares shed 0.92 percent.
The machinery and electronics sector closed down 0.66 percent and the construction sector fell 0.04 percent, while plastics and chemicals closed unchanged.
"The downslide was simply a technical correction after a recent strong showing," Hua Nan Securities analyst Henry Miao said.
In the first two days of the week, the local bourse rose 2.14 percent.
Miao said technical resistance ahead of 8,400 points remained heavy so that the market needed some time to consolidate before having another takeoff.
He said investors seized the opportunity to adjust their portfolios, in particular the old economy sector, using the regional market declines as an excuse.
"I am not particularly worried about the mild pullback, " Miao said. "Ample liquidity is expected to continue to lend support to the market and prevent heavy losses."
Miao said he expects inflows of foreign funds will continue as the U.S. might further loosen the monetary policy to stimulate its economy.
He said non high-tech firms are likely to regain their momentum soon amid optimism toward the earnings outlook in the sector.

In the old economy sector, Chung Hwa Pulp lost 2.83 percent to close at NT$17.15 and Taiwan Pulp and Paper fell 2.74 percent to NT$19.50, while Taiwan Cement shed 1.34 percent to end the day at NT$33.05.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Wednesday, gaining NT$0.14 to close at the day's high of NT$30.900.
Turnover totaled US$1.05 billion during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.840 and moved to a low of NT$30.556 before rebounding.
Dealers said a stronger U.S. dollar in the regional markets against other Asian currencies, including the Chinese yuan, imposed pressure on the local currency.
A downslide on the local bourse added selling pressure to the New Taiwan dollar, they said, adding that the selling was conducted largely by foreign banks.
However, the gains by the U.S. dollar against Asian currencies were simply a technical rebound, dealers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: UMC Q3 net profit up 65.4 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 17:21:29 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) , the world's second-largest contract chip maker, reported Wednesday a 65.4 percent increase in net profit for the third quarter of this year from the previous quarter, on strong global demand.

During the July-September period, UMC's net profit totaled NT$8.72 billion (US$284 million) , a new high in almost three years, compared with NT$5.27 billion recorded in the previous quarter, while operating profit rose 32.2 percent to NT$7.19 billion, UMC said.
The company posted an earnings per share of NT$0.70 for the same quarter, up from NT$0.42 in the second quarter, it added.
UMC said its intensive efforts to boost production capacity and improve its product mix continued to help the company deliver positive results for the quarter.
The company's gross profit margin for the past three months stood at 32.6 percent, a record high in nearly six years.

In an investor conference, UMC Chief Executive Officer Sun Shih-wei said that products on the 65-nanometer production process or below accounted for 30 percent of total third quarter sales, which boosted the gross margin.
Sun said he expects the portion of the 65-nanometer production process or below to rise to 35 percent in the fourth quarter.

The European market accounted for 13 percent of UMC's total sales in the third quarter, up from 11 percent in the second quarter, while Asia Pacific made up 40 percent of the total sales, down from the previous quarter's 42 percent, according to the company.
The North American markets represented 46 percent of UMC's total sales in the July-September period, unchanged from a quarter earlier, the company said.
Sun said that in the past quarter, UMC's overall capacity utilization rate exceeded 99 percent and that the utilization in the fourth quarter is expected to range between 90 percent and 95 percent.

Sun went on to say, however, that high-end production capacity is expected to be fully utilized in the coming quarter and that product mix optimization will push the blended average selling price up by about 5 percent.
He added that shipments in the fourth quarter are likely to fall about 5 percent on weakening demand for computer and related products.

Sun said the fluctuation of the New Taiwan dollar against the U. S. dollar is also expected to affect UMC's sales, but he added that he remains "cautiously optimistic about the foundry market in the fourth quarter."

Furthermore, Sun said, global production value of the semiconductor sector in 2011 is expected to grow 5 percent-10 percent, while output of the global foundry business is expected to rise 10 percent-15 percent year-on-year.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Chinese officials arrive to observe highway search
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 17:23:43 (By Mai-land Kuo, Chin-feng Bien, Worthy Shen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: More Chinese officials arrived in Taiwan on Wednesday to keep abreast of progress in efforts to find their compatriots missing since deadly rock slides were triggered by Typhoon Megi last week.

Man Hongwei, director of the China National Tourism Administration's (CNTA) Department of Affairs on Tourism of Hong Kong, Macao and Taiwan, who doubles as secretary-general of China's quasi-official Cross-Strait Tourism Association (CSTA) , reached Taipei around noon with four other officials.

After meeting with CSTA officials posted in Taiwan, Man told the Central News Agency he planned to visit the accident site on the Suhua Highway where a bus carrying 19 tourists from Guangdong Province is suspected of falling from the road into the Pacific Ocean during stormy weather. All people on the bus, including its Taiwanese guide and driver, are still missing as of Wednesday.
Meanwhile, Zhang Shenglin, deputy secretary-general of Beijing's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), also flew into Taiwan on Wednesday.
Zhang said she will learn more about the progress in the search for the missing tourists. She called for Taiwan to accelerate the search and strengthen rescue teams' manpower.
As for when the search might be called off, Zhang said she would discuss this with relevant Taiwanese agencies at a later time.
Zhang was scheduled to meet with Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, ARATS' Taiwan counterpart, Wednesday afternoon.

In related news, 36 relatives of the 19 missing tourists visited the cliff edge at the east coast highway's 112.8-kilometer marker Wednesday, in a bid to get as close as possible to the spot where the ill-fated bus went missing.
The family members requested to see the victims, dead or alive, and asked that all personal belongings found by the search team would be taken back to China.
If needed, the family members will be accorded "one-on-one" assistance, said Yao Ta-kuang, chairman of the Travel Agent Association of the Republic of China, Taiwan (TAAT).

Traveling with the relatives were 13 officials and workers from Zhuhai City in Guangdong Province. Eight of the 19 missing tourists are officials of the Gongbei Land Taxation Bureau in Zhuhai, according to TAAT.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travelers praise Taipei airport's renovated terminal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CANA) 10/27/10 18:15:43 (By Wang Shu-fen and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Taipei International Airport's newly renovated Terminal 1, which opened Wednesday to international arrivals, received good marks from some of the first travelers who arrived there from an overseas destination.

Though the terminal still has work left to be done, some of the passengers on a flight arriving from Shanghai gave it an 85 on a scale of 100, praising the speed with which they got their bags and the improved displays around the facility.

"My wife and I feel lucky to be able to use the terminal's new arrival facilities. The lighting was really good, and there were people who helped me get my luggage, " said Chung Shu-jen, who returned home after visiting the Shanghai Expo.

The old airport, known locally as Songhsan Airport, is currently undergoing a three-phase renovation. The first phase was concluded with the partial renovation of Terminal 1, which originally handled domestic flights and international departures but will now handle all flights.
Some of its jetways were also upgraded, enabling the airport to handle bigger double-aisle aircraft such as the Airbus 330.
Phase 2 will consist of renovating part of Terminal 2, building connecting skybridges between the two terminals, and modernizing some jetways and expanding waiting areas in Terminal 1.
Phase 3 will involve the completion of Terminal 2 and the addition of duty-free stores and check-in counters in Terminal 1.
When the project is completed in September 2011, international and domestic flight services will be separately handled in Terminal 1 and Terminal 2.
Fang Hai-chin, who travels frequently between Taiwan and China, compared the newly renovated terminal favorably with Terminal 2.
He said the signs directing travelers around the airport were clear, the new baggage trolleys were much easier to control, and luggage could be claimed after only a two-minute wait.

Fang believed, however, that the airport still lagged behind other comparable international airports, and he suggested that officials travel to other airports in the region to get ideas on how to improve service.

Once the renovation project is complete, Terminal 1 will be expected to handle 1.8 million travelers per year, as the number of international flights increases from 70 to 126 per week, according to the airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumer confidence index grows five months in row
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 19:08:01 (By Chen Yi-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer confidence index (CCI) grew for five consecutive months to reach 80.19 points in October, the highest level since February 2004, according to the results of a CCI survey released Wednesday by National Central University (NCU).

The October index rose 0.05 points from the previous month, which researchers attributed to growing consumer confidence in the job market, said Hsu Chi- chiang, director of the NCU's Research Center for Taiwan.

The researchers found that since Taiwan's economy began to rebound in the second quarter of last year, it has continued to grow since then, with corresponding growth in the employment market, Hsu said.

The survey results show that four out of the six major indicators that reflect consumer confidence for the next half-year moved up in October compared with the previous month, with the index for consumer expectations for employment opportunities in the coming six months recording the largest growth of 1.9 points to reach 87.2 points.

The index for future household economic conditions rose O.35 points to 73.9 points and the index for future economic growth increased 0.15 points to 82.15 points, while that for stock investment prospects moved up 0.1 points to 96.3 points.
The index for commodity prices in the coming half-year dropped 1.8 points from the previous month to 52.2 points, marking the second consecutive decline on a month-to-month basis, the results show.
Hsu attributed the fall to expectations of rising commodity prices due to Typhoon Megi and raw material price increases on the international market.

The other drop was recorded in the index for purchases of durable goods, which moved down 0.4 points to 89.4 points. Hsu said he found that central bank measures to rein in rising housing prices led consumers to believe that the next six months will not be a good time to purchase real estate.
The survey was conducted Oct. 19-22 among 2,368 randomly selected adults aged over 20 around Taiwan. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 2 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO Q3 profit affected by falling prices, high inventories
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 19:24:04 (By Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)
