TEXT.P: Flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp. said Wednesday that it witnessed a sharp decline in net profit for the third quarter from the previous quarter due to lower-than-expected product prices and high inventories.
In the July-September period, AUO posted NT$227 million (US$7.4 million) in net profit, down 98 percent from NT$11.25 billion recorded a quarter earlier.

AUO's operating profit in the third quarter reached NT$232 million, a drop of 98.2 percent from NT$13.22 billion posted in the second quarter, while sales during the same period were down 3.3 percent at NT$124.40 billion.
The company's earnings per share in the third quarter fell to NT$0.01 from NT$1.24 generated in the second quarter.
The third quarter's gross margin stood at 5 percent, also down from 15.8 percent recorded in the second quarter, while its operating margin fell to 0.2 percent from 10.3 percent.

The company said shipments of large panels, which refers to those of 10 inches or above, totaled 28.7 million units in the third quarter, down 3.2 percent from the second quarter, while shipments of small and medium-sized panels rose 0.3 percent to 55.6 million units.

Panels used in TVs accounted for 56 percent of the total sales, making the largest portion of its products sold during the period, up from the 51 percent recorded in the second quarter, the company said.

AUO said it had adjusted capacity utilization rates to improve the number of inventory turnover days from 43 days at the end of the second quarter to 40 days at the end of the third quarter and would continue to do so, along with boosting the volume of value-added products and enhancing research and development.

TLG Asset Management analyst Arch Shih said the third quarter's earnings data confirmed the market's concerns over the gloomy outlook for the global flat panel business in the third quarter, but said the numbers for AUO were better than expected.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fewer runners expected in this year's Taroko Gorge Marathon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 19:33:26 (By Chen Hsun-hsieh and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: The recent damage to the Suhua Highway could discourage some marathon runners from participating in this year's Taroko Gorge Marathon, the organizers said Wednesday.

The highway on the eastern coast, the only major road to the location, remained closed that day after heavy rain brought by Typhoon Megi Oct. 21-22 triggered landslides that affected several sections of the road.

In previous years, as many as 2,000 of the participants would arrive by coach to compete in the annual race at the scenic spot. Because the road is expected to remain closed until Nov. 15 at the earliest, however, some of the runners will probably not come to the Nov. 6 race, according to the Taroko National Park Headquarters.
The park has arranged for extra trains to run to Hualien from Taipei and for shuttle buses to get the runners from the Hualien Railway Station to make the 7 a.m. start of the marathon.
The event is limited to 10,000 people, more than 7,000 of whom sign up for either a full marathon of some 41.1 km or a half one. The rest of the runners take part in a 5-km fun run.
Taroko Gorge in eastern Taiwan's Hualien Country is one of the country's best- known tourist attractions.

DOC.HEADLINE: One dead, 12 missing after freighter capsizes off Oluanpi
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 19:42:39 (By Cheng Che-fon and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: One member of a Panama-registered cargo ship was killed and 12 others remained unaccounted for Wednesday afternoon after the freighter capsized off Taiwan's southernmost tip the same morning, reported the Coast Guard Administration (CGA).

Another 12 of the 25-member Chinese crew were rescued from the freighter, Jian Fu Star, by CGA patrol boats, a passing foreign cargo ship and helicopters dispatched by the National Airborne Service Corps, said an official with the CGA's Maritime Patrol Directorate-General.

Despite stormy weather, rescuers continued to search the area where the freighter sank -- about 78 nautical miles south of Oluanpi -- in the hope that the missing crew members could be snatched from the sea water within the "golden" 72-hour period, the official surnamed Chen said.
The 35,000-ton freighter was on its way from Indonesia to Qingdao, China, carrying mainly nickel ore, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: Night markets get poor ratings for basic services
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 19:54:39 (By Lin Ye-fong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Most of the night markets that have recently been crowned with a "most special" title are nevertheless unsatisfactory in terms of their basic services, especially toilet facilities, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday by the Consumers' Foundation.

The survey was conducted earlier in the month among the 10 winners of a specialty competition held recently by the Tourism Bureau -- Shilin Night Market, Huaxi Street Night Market and Ningxia Night Market in Taipei City, Keelung's Miaokou Night Market, Kaohsiung City's Liuhe Night Market, the Chunghua Street Night Market in Kaohsiung County's Fengshan, Taichung's Fengchia Night Market, Yilan's Luodong Night Market, Chiayi's Wenhua Street Night Market, and Tainan's Huayuan Night Market.
The foundation used three criteria to evaluate their basic services: space layout, garbage can availability and public toilets.
The results show that Luodong Night Market, which was selected the "most friendly" in the competition, has poor space layout and unclear toilet directions for visitors.
Wenhua Road Night Market and the Chunghua Street Night Market, which were presented with "special mention" awards, do not provide garbage cans for visitors.
Among the 10 night markets, Chunghua Street Night Market is the only one that has no public toilets. Eight out of the remaining nine received below average ratings for their toilet directions.
Six of the night markets, meanwhile, have no emergency help buttons in their toilets.

Overall, three night markets were given failing scores, with Chunghua Street Night Market given just 19 points on a 100-point scale, Wenhua Street Night Market receiving 54 points and Huayuan Night Market earning 57 points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top Taipei City aide questioned, barred from leaving country
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 19:55:48 (By Johnson Sun, Shu-hua Lee & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taipei City government Secretary-General Yang Hsi-an was interrogated Wednesday for the first time since being accused by Taipei prosecutors of involvement in granting inflated material prices to contractors on the city's Xinsheng Overpass improvement project.
Yang was later released on NT$600,000 (US$19,483) bail and barred from leaving the country.

Huang Hsi-hsun, former director of the city government's New Construction Office (NCO) and Chen Chih-sheng, a former NCO division chief, were detained by prosecutors after suspected evidence of their roles in the alleged scandal were found by investigators who searched their offices and residences in September.
Among the evidence was a note asking Huang and Chen to argue to investigators that the overpriced project "was simply caused by their negligence" and had nothing to do with corruption.
Prosecutors suspected the note to be from the detainees' superiors, including Yang.
After examining the testimonies of witnesses and related documents, prosecutors found that Yang had several times contacted contractors of the project in secret to finalize the price tags.

Prosecutors searched Yang's residence and office Oct. 5, and seized 12 computers and a flash memory disc, leading to Yang being questioned Oct. 20 as a witness, during which he protested his innocence, saying he did nothing wrong when he served as convener of the bidding task force for the Xinsheng project.
City officials invited bidders Nov. 6, 2007 for the elevated highway work, but were unable to find a contractor capable of carrying out the project at the price fixed by the city government.

The city government finally farmed out the project April 23, 2008, after raising the price it would be willing to pay to NT$1.86 billion in the wake of six unsuccessful bids. Prosecutors suspected that contractors on the project overcharged the city government in 120 procurement cases.

Yang said after being released that he was surprised by the prosecutor's move to list him as a defendant. He added that he received no instructions from Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin regarding the Xinsheng project's bidding process.
Questioned by the media, Hau said he would respect any decision by the judicial system and that Yang will be removed from his post to facilitate the investigation process.
"I will step down immediately if I am found to have been involved in any irregularities related to city engineering projects, " Hau vowed.

Hau, who is running for a second mayoral term as the candidate of the ruling Kuomintang, has been beset by allegations that he is also involved in the Xinsheng Overpass scandal, with the latest poll results showing him to be 2 percentage points behind his opponent, former Premier Su Tseng- chang of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

The poll results, released by the United Daily News that same day, one month before the elections take place, show that Hau would have the support of 48 percent of the respondents, compared to Su's 37 percent, if the elections were to take place the following day.

However, based on its cross-analysis of the results, the newspaper estimated that most of those who declined to reveal their voting choice will eventually cast their ballots for Su, giving him a razor-thin lead over the incumbent mayor.

DOC.HEADLINE: Expo Taiwan pavilion to re-open in Hsinchu next October

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Pavilion in Expo Shanghai will open its doors to the public on next year's Double Ten National Day after it is brought back and reassembled in Hsinchu when the exhibition ends at the end of this month.
Hsinchu City Mayor Hsu Ming-tsai and city council speaker Hsieh Wen-chin finalized plans about opening the pavilion on Oct. 10 next year during a meeting Tuesday.
Rebuilding work will finish on Sept. 30 and after a nine-day trial, it will be officially unveiled to the public, said Hsieh.
The news came after Hsu briefed Hsieh on details of the city government's successful bid to purchase and bring the pavilion back to Taiwan from Shanghai at a City Council meeting.

Director of Hsinchu's department of transportation Cheng Chih-chiang said the future tourist attraction will be on the route of a free shuttle-bus service in the east district of the city. The service will begin on a trial basis on Dec. 1.

According to Cheng, Taiwan Railways Administration and the Railway Reconstruction Bureau have formed a special commitee to look at the possibility of constructing a Mass Rapid Transit(MRT) station for the pavilion on the Neiwan train line. The group will hold a meeting on Nov. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asia's biggest tourism fair to kick off next month in Taipei

TEXT.P: The Taipei International Travel Fair, set to kick off next month, will feature over 1,200 booths from 60 countries, making it Taiwan's most anticipated tourism event of the year, the organizers announced Tuesday.

Organizers said the fair is the biggest of its kind in Asia and that visitors can expect discount bargains ranging from hotel stays to air tickets, all the way to theme park admission tickets, at the event to be held at Exhibition Hall 1 of the Taiwan World Trade Center Nov. 5-8.

Taiwan Visitors Association Chairman C.S. Chou said the scale of this year's event makes it the biggest in history, with exhibitors going all-out to give visitors the travel bug by offering unique tourism packages at rock-bottom prices.
In addition to the usual participants such as the U.S., Japan, South Korea, Europe and Latin America, Saipan and Jordan will make their debuts at this year's event, he said.

"Taiwan has much to offer to our foreign friends, from beautiful natural landscape to delicious food. Our hospitality is also well-known. Many foreign tourists who have come here say they were warmly received everywhere they went in the country. We are one of the favorite destinations for Japanese and Chinese tourists because of the similarities in culture and the close geographic proximity, " he said.

Chou said that so far this year, Taiwan has welcomed over 4 million foreign tourists. The figure could easily surpass 5 million because of the upcoming Taipei International Flora Expo and the start of direct flights between Taipei and Tokyo, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO renews call for executives' travel freedom in U.S.

TEXT.P: AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) , Taiwan's second-largest LCD panel maker, urged a U.S. court Wednesday to give greater travel freedom to some of its top executives who are currently barred from leaving the United States, where they face price- fixing charges.
"We hope the U.S. court will grant more travel freedom to the executives based on humane considerations, " AUO acting Chief Executive Max Cheng said at a company investors' conference in Taipei.
"The executives' parents are old and they are in Taiwan. It is one of the company's biggest hopes that the executives will be given greater freedom," he said.
Cheng made the remarks after he was named an acting chief executive in an Oct. 8 management reshuffle. CEO Chen Lai-juh continues to lead the company's solar energy business, AUO added.

About three months ago, a U.S. court ordered Chen Lai-juh, Vice Chairman Chen Hsuan-bin and former Executive Vice President Hsiung Hui to remain in California after they appeared at a hearing on the case.

The executives, along with AUO, its U.S. subsidiary and other senior managers were indicted in June by the U.S. Department of Justice for allegedly conspiring with other companies to fix the prices of TFT- LCD panels from Sept. 14, 2001 to Dec. 1, 2006.

Other Taiwanese companies, including Chunghwa Picture Tubes and Chimei Innolux Corp., have chosen to plead guilty and accept punishments, including prison terms for top executives in some cases, after facing similar charges by the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foundation to work with DOH to promote whole-grain awareness

TEXT.P: To mobilize public interest in a Department of Health (DOH) campaign to regulate terms used in food advertising, a health-promotion organization displayed a wide range of products claiming "whole-grain" status at a Taipei press conference Wednesday.

Of 113 products labeled "whole grain"or "whole wheat" tested in a study undertaken by the John Tung Foundation, only 15 contained at least 51 percent of whole grain by weight, a new standard set by the Taiwan Food and Drug Administration (TFDA) Tuesday.

Manufacturers of whole-grain products must abide by the guideline by as early as the end of next year or be in violation of the Food Hygiene Act and face fines of between NT$40,000 (US$1,300) to NT$200,000, said Tsai Shu-jen, director of TFDA's food safety division.

During the one-year grace period in which manufacturers are encouraged but not forced to follow the guideline, Tsai said the TFDA's priority will be to talk to relevant companies. It will also work closely with the John Tung Foundation to enhance public awareness of whole-grain products.
Consumers will be better protected once the TFDA's threshold is applied to advertising of whole-grain foods, said Chang Kuo-rong, chairman of the Taipei Bakery Association.

Reminding the public not use texture and appearance as the sole indicators of whole-grain products, Chang pointed out that whole- grain bread does not necessarily taste rough, since flour used in bread-making undergoes varying milling processes. Some consumers also mistake dark breads decorated with bran and nuts for whole-grain products, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Luzhou Line to start operations on Nov. 3

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced Wednesday that the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system's Luzhou Line will begin operations on Nov. 3 to coordinate with the grand opening of the Taipei International Flora Expo on Nov. 11.

Furthermore, from Nov. 3 to Dec. 2 the line will provide a 30-day free trial service for people using Easycards, he said. "We hope the public will take great advantage of the new line to visit the Flora Expo, " said Hau, adding that he hopes the now 105.4- kilometer-long MRT network will help ease the traffic flow expected when international travelers visit the flower festival.
The Luzhou Line, which began construction in 2002, connects the capital with Luzhou and Sanchong cities in Taipei County, on the west side of Danshui River.

The 12.5-kilometer Luzhou Line is expected to lift the system's current average daily total of 1.41 million passenger-trips to around 1.58 million, according to the Department of Rapid Transit Systems (DORTS).
DORTS also projected that the annual total would surpass 500 million passenger- trips by the end of this year, as the MRT system better connects Taipei City and Taipei County.
As an example, DORTS said passengers will be able to travel from Luzhou Station to Taipei Main Station via a combination of the Luzhou and Danshui lines in just 22 minutes. (By Hsin-Yin Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Environmentalists adopt new tactics

TEXT.P: In addition to raising public awareness of environmental crises facing Taiwan, a number of environmental controversies that surfaced this year have also illustrated the variety of new tactics being adopted by the nation's social activists.

Events receiving extensive media coverage and sparking strong public reaction included an author's plea for preservation of wetlands in Taipei's Nangang District, a protest by farmers in Dapu Township against the forced expropriation of their land by the Miaoli County Government, more than 1,000 researchers signing a petition against a proposed construction of a petrochemical complex, and the court ruling against expansion of the Central Science Park.

Reaction was strong enough to catch government officials and commercial enterprises off guard, and perhaps suggests a shift in values: that many people no longer accept the idea of putting the economy ahead of the environment.

It also reveals how environmentalists' tactics have evolved. In the past -- such as in campaigns against construction of nuclear power plants prior to 2000 -- protest groups relied on mobilizing large crowds.

After election of the Democratic Progressive Party administration in 2000, these groups worked closely with the government, but soon discovered that politicians' promises are unreliable and government decision-making processes are conservative.

They have since sought to operate "outside the system" and have adopted new approaches. One has been the use of legal mechanisms. This had been rare previously, partly because there were not many legal professionals participating in such social movements, and partly because Taiwan lacks the tradition of group litigation.

The court's assessment of environmental impact and its judgment in the case concerning expansion of the Central Science Park shows that the judicial system has become more independent and that judges are now more willing to confront mistakes made in government decisions.

Another new approach can be seen in the tactic of using a charitable trust to buy and protect the wetland threatened by the Kuokuang Petrochemical Technology Co. project in central Taiwan's Changhua County.

While local politicians and businesses standing to benefit from the project gathered buses of supporters to protest against environmental groups, by the end of August more than 50,000 people had signed up to donate money to set up just such a trust.
Environmental activists have also made use of "citizen journalism" and non- mainstream media, particularly the Internet, to set news agendas and gain the attention of the traditional media.

Photographs and videos of helpless Dapu farmers watching as excavators destroyed their expropriated rice paddies in June were disseminated online, successfully attracting widespread interest in the Miaoli case.

Without assembling crowds or relying on traditional political power, environmental groups are using these new strategies to maintain a dialogue with wider society. This can be an inspiration for social activists seeking political changes.

DOC.HEADLINE: China urged to respect Taiwan's right to attend world activities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 21:23:18 (By Ming-chung Lee and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China should respect Taiwan's right to attend international activities in order to safeguard the hard-won detente achieved in the past two years, Government Information Office Minister Johnny Chiang said Wednesday.
"Our participation in international activities is a reality and our legitimate right. China should face up to this fact of life and deal with it with goodwill," Chiang said.

Noting that it is not easy for the two sides to achieve peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, Chiang said China should substantiate the principle of "facing up to reality and shelving disputes" with concrete actions to foster mutual trust.

His remarks came after China's Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) blamed earlier in the day a "lack of communication" for a row over the name of the Taiwanese delegation on the opening night of the Tokyo International Film Festival last weekend.

"The incident probably arose from a lack of communication between the two sides. This is something we do not wish to see, and we believe the matter will not affect future cross-strait collaboration or exchanges in filmmaking, " said TAO spokesman Yang Yi when asked about the altercation at a regular press briefing.

Chiang said he is pleased to learn that China will uphold its promise to open its market wider from Thursday to Taiwan-produced films according to the bilateral Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement signed in June.

"This indicates that the Tokyo name row will not affect bilateral film exchanges or engagements between filmmakers on the two sides, " Chiang said. "In the future, we hope both sides can take part in international film festivals together in line with the principles of mutual trust, parity and cooperation."
Premier Wu Den-yih also hailed Yang's remarks as reflecting China's recognition of the importance of upholding cross-strait detente.

"Cross-strait relations are now moving on the track of peace and stability through concerted efforts of the two sides, and no one should be allowed to derail such a development, " Wu said while meeting with a group of overseas ethnic Chinese business professionals who are attending a study program in Taiwan.

After decades of hostility and separation across the strait, Wu said that there might be a few people like Jiang Ping who instigate rifts from time to time, but that such accidental incidents will not prevent cross-strait relations from moving toward peace.
Jiang was the head of China's delegation at the Tokyo festival who ignited the spat when he demanded that Taiwan's group must include "China" in its official name at the film festival.

His demand was immediately refused by the Taiwanese delegation, which asserted that Taiwan had always participated in the festival as "Taiwan, " and that there was no reason to deviate from the usual practice.
Chen Chih-kuan, director of the Department of Motion Picture Affairs under the Government Information Office, who headed the Taiwanese delegation, told Jiang not to mix arts with politics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's economic expansion slows in September

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy looked less rosy in September than the previous month as the stock price index fell, but the economy has been growing steadily as a whole, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.
The monitoring indicator for the overall economy fell one point in September to 37 points and turned a red light to yellow-red, indicating a moderate economy, according to the CEPD.
Of all the monitoring indicator's nine components, the stock price index decreased by one point, resulting in the loss of overall score.
The composite leading index, which gauges economic performance over three to six months, measured 117.6, a fall of 0.4 percent since August.
The year-on-year six-month rate of change stood at 1.8 percent, a fall of 2.3 percentage point from August and the 10th consecutive monthly fall.
"The leading indicator has continued to fall, yet the decline has been narrowing," said the CEPD said in a press release.
The planning agency uses a five-color system to gauge the country's economic performance for any given month.
Blue implies a sluggish economy, yellow-blue represents a slowdown, green indicates a stable economy, yellow-red means the economy is mildly overheated, and red signifies overheating.
The index of coincident indicators, which reflect economic activity in the period measured, rose 0.6 percent to 124.4 in September.

Despite the small drop, the CEPD said it remained cautiously optimistic about the economy's prospects because strong growth in emerging economies will help maintain export momentum and government investment promotion drives are expected to spur private investment.

Taiwan's economy grew 13.7 percent year-on-year in the first quarter and 12.5 percent in the second quarter, the Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics reported on Aug. 19. It revised its forecast for full-year growth upwards to 8.24 percent. (By Yi-chun Chen and C.Y. Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: Nicaragua baseball player accused of sexual assault
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 22:05:00 (By Hsia Pao-hsian, Hao Hsueh-chin, Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Nicaraguan baseball team coach apologized Wednesday after one of his players, Gustavo Horacio Lopez, was accused of sexually assaulting a Taiwanese woman on Tuesday. Lopez was taken to the Taichung District Prosecutors Office for further interrogation after being questioned by police.

Speaking at a press conference, team coach Edgard Matamoros apologized to the Taiwanese people and government, and expressed the desire to continue to compete in the tournament. The Nicaragua team is in Taiwan to participate in the 17th Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament.
The team was still looking into the accusation leveled against the player, he said, but theyfully believe in the Taiwanese justice system and will accept any verdict handed down by the court.
Lopez met the woman when he went out to buy beer Tuesday, before the pair headed back to his hotel together, Matamoros and the Taichung City Police Bureau confirmed.

Taichung police said the victim called a friend for help from the hotel room. By the time the friend arrived at the hotel, the woman had disappeared. She was subsequently found by police and taken to hospital for examination.

As of press time, Lopez was still being detained by Taichung District Prosecutors Office. Bail has been set at NT$200,000 (US$6,500), which the team says it does not have, so the player will remain in custody overnight.
Nicaraguan Ambassador William Tapia might travel to Taichung on Thursday, his office announced. For the time being, the Nicaragua team will continue to play in the tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: More than 300 endangered spoonbills sighted in Tainan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 22:18:02 ( By Huang Po-kai and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Availing of stronger northeasterly winds, a total of 347 black-faced spoonbills had arrived in the wetlands of Tainan County in southern Taiwan by Wednesday, reported a wildlife conservation group.

The first of the endangered species to arrive this year was observed in the southern county on Sept. 26, around one week later than usual because of Typhoon Fanapi, said Chiu Jen-wu, chairman of the Wildlife Conversation Institute of Tainan County.

The rare birds migrate each autumn from northern China and the border area between North Korea and South Korea, with some choosing to spend the winter on wetlands near Tainan's Tzengwen River estuary.

By Oct. 16 the number of spoonbills had increased to just 68, because the northeasterly monsoon winds were too weak, explained Chiu. With the winds now stronger, the population could number up to 500 by the end of October and reach its peak during November, he predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Intel to forge more local partnerships

TEXT.P: Intel Corp., the world's largest chip maker, is expected to forge more partnerships in Taiwan when its chief executive arrives in Taipei for a short visit Thursday.

Intel President and CEO Paul Otellini is expected to announce collaborative projects with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the National Science Council (NSC) at a press conference in Taipei, but the company was hesitant to go into details in advance.

Local media have reported that the U.S. company will sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the MOEA regarding research and development (R&D) into cloud computing, which allows data storage online and other Internet-based services.
It will mark the first new collaboration between the two since they signed a deal in 2008 to promote the development of the WiMAX broadband wireless technology in Taiwan.
Intel is also expected to use the Thursday press conference to announce R&D cooperation with the NSC, but the area of research is as yet unknown.

Further industry speculation suggested the U.S. corporation is likely to sign a separate MOU with Chunghwa Telecom Co., Taiwan's largest telecommunications firm, for the development of smart TVs that are equipped with Internet-surfing and other online functions.
J.T. Wang, chairman of the world's second largest PC vendor, Acer Inc., told reporters Oct. 19 that he would discuss business with Otellini during his stay in the country.

Similarly, Richard Lee, chief executive of Inventec Corp., a leading Taiwanese contract notebook computer maker, confirmed to CNA Oct. 24 that his company would have contact with Intel during Otellini's visit, but declined to provide further details.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to defer arms acquisition from U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 22:55:56 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will defer the acquisition of some weapons systems from the United States due to the government's financial constraints, Legislator Lin Yu-fang of the ruling Kuomintang quoted the Ministry of National Defense (MND) as saying Wednesday.

The MND has preliminarily determined to talk to the U.S. about postponing the production schedule of the six Patriot Advanced Capability (PAC-3) anti-missile batteries from 2014 to 2017 and of 60 UH-60M Black Hawk helicopters from 2016 to 2019, according to a statement issued by Lin.

The deferral is necessary due to production schedules at the U.S. end, as well as out of consideration of the Taiwan government's financial constraints combined with the fact that it is unlikely the annual defense budget will be raised significantly in the near future, Lin added.

Earlier in the day, Defense Minister Kao Hua-chu said at a legislative committee meeting that Taiwan is now entering the peak period for making payments for military investment. He added that, if it was acceptable to the legislature, the MND wanted to redistribute to other uses those sums budgeted for the U.S. weapons systems that Taiwan cannot acquire according to the original schedule.
Lin said that according to the MND's plans, the defense accumulated budget stands at NT$330.7 billion (US$10.7 billion) for the period 2011 to 2014, or NT$82.7 billion per year.

Procurement of the U.S. arms systems would take about 61 percent of the budget, or NT$50.3 billion a year, he noted. This would affect the budget for purchasing domestically developed weapons and related facilities over the same period, he continued.
"Cut the budget for those items we are not getting in the following several years, such as the F-16C/D fighters and submarines," he suggested.

The US$6.4 billion package of arms that Washington announced in late January that it wants to sell to Taiwan includes 60 UH-60M Black Hawk helicopters, two Osprey Class mine-hunting ships, 12 ATM-84L and RTM-84L Harpoon Block II Telemetry missiles, 114 PAC-3 missiles and communications equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shipments of Taiwan's large TFT-LCD panels post rare decline

TEXT.P: Shipments of Taiwan's large TFT-LCD panels posted a quarter-on-quarter decline of 7.9 percent in Q3 of this year, a market research firm said Wednesday.

A decline for TFT-LCD panels of 10 inches and over has rarely been seen in the third quarter of any year, when demand for the products is traditionally high, Tony Huang, a senior analyst with Digitimes Research, said in a statement.
"Weaker demand forced display clients to slash orders, and Taiwanese display manufacturers also reduced production capacity to minimize losses on IT (information technology) panels," he said.
Huang noted that the decrease was not limited to Taiwan.
The world has also seen an unusual decline in shipments, with monitor panels falling 13.5 percent quarter-on-quarter and notebook computer panels dropping 12.3 percent in the same period, he added.
In terms of the annual growth rate, shipments of large TFT-LCD panels in the quarter grew only 3.2 percent from the same period last year, Huang noted.
"This represents a huge difference, as the annual growth rate for each quarter has surpassed 22 percent since the third quarter of 2009," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu breezes to first-round win at St. Petersburg Open
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 23:31:02 (By Lee Hsin-Yin and Lee Yu-cheng)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top ranking tennis player Lu Yen-hsun won his first-round match in the St. Petersburg Open men's singles against Potito Starace from Italy on Wednesday.
The world number 34 and the tournament's 4th seed, Lu needed just 58 minutes to get by Starace 6-2, 6-2.
"I didn't find my pace for serving on the hard indoor court at the beginning," Lu said on his Facebook page, "but I later picked it up and served better."
Lu added that he kept pressure on the world number 55, forcing him to make mistakes on his own serve.
Lu will meet wild-card entrant, world number 264 Dimitry Tursunov from Russia in the second round of men's singles. The former world number 20, Tursunov leads the pair's head-to-head clashes 3-0.
With his partner, Rainer Schuettler from Germany, Lu also won his earlier match in the first round of the St. Petersburg Open men's doubles against their top- seeded opponents.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO calls for approval on China plant plan

TEXT.P: AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) , Taiwan's second-largest LCD panel maker, urged the Taiwan government on Wednesday to quickly approve its application to set up a plant in China or it will fall further behind its South Korean rivals.
"Taiwan was ahead of South Korea in the past in terms of the global LCD panel market share, " AUO vice president Paul Peng said at the company's quarterly investors' conference.
"At present, however, Taiwan's global market share is 37 percent, while South Korea's is 52 percent," he noted.
If Taiwanese flat-panel companies want to boost their competitiveness, they need to establish factories in China, he added.
AUO plans to open a flat-panel plant in Kunshan, Jiangsu Province in eastern China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vienna Boys' Choir begins sixth tour of Taiwan

TEXT.P: Members of the Vienna Boys' Choir said they were looking forward to seeing Taipei 101, one of the world's tallest buildings, after the world-famous youngsters touched down in Taiwan Wednesday afternoon for a tour that will take them around the island.
They will perform songs from their motion pictureSilk road - Songs Along the Road and Timeat concerts scheduled in Taichung, Kaohsiung, Taipei and Hsinchu beginning Thursday.
The 25 boys aged between 10 and 14 gave a taste of their youthful sound when they launched into an Austrian clapping song accompanied by accordion at a press conference for their arrival.

Taipei 101, the tallest skycraper in the world until early this year, is a must- see for the boys, said Zhou Dun-ren, general manager of Ars Taiwan, the company that invited the choir to tour the island for the sixth time.
The choir is divided into four touring groups named after famous composers with the Mozart group arriving in Taiwan this time, said Zhou.
Their program also includes Alpine folk music and a selection of Viennese music. The Vienna Boys' Choir was founded in Austria in 1498.

DOC.HEADLINE: Petrochemical plant contributes little to local communities: report
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 23:55:14 (By Li Hsien-feng, Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: After over 10 years in operation, the sixth naphtha cracker plant run by the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) in Yunlin County has not had a major negative impact on local residents' lives, but nor has it made a significant contribution to the local community, a seminar heard Wednesday.

These findings from an investigation conducted by National Sun Yat-sen University Professor Lee Cheng-di were reported on day one of a three-day seminar being held by the Institute of Environment and Resource in Taipei under the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
While the plant has helped boost some small retail businesses in nearby communities, it has not helped to increase output of local fishery and agricultural industries, he reported.
Yunlin is an agricultural-based county in central Taiwan.

More than 20 experts and scholars gathered to debate the overall contribution and condition of the naphtha cracker in Yunlin's Mailiao Township, which has encountered a series of problems in recent months, including two major fires in July and two reports of foul odor leaking from the plant in September.
"This is the first time such a large meeting to evaluate public safety has been held," EPA Minister Stephan Shu-hung Shen said at the event.
"The FPG's naphtha cracker plant is a huge project, and we are very concerned whether its fifth-stage expansion would pose an adverse impact on the environment, " Shen said.
The FPG will also present a self-assessment report, Shen said, but the EPA has yet to reach an agreement with the group regarding the assessment method to be adopted by FPG.
Conclusions drawn at the seminar will serve as a reference for the government to decide the fate of the plant's expansion.

A recent survey showed that nearly 80 percent of Yunlin residents are dissatisfied with feedback measures proposed by FPG, while 32.4 percent of respondents believe the plant has done little help to the local economy.

As of the end of 2009, FPG had invested NT$628.3 billion (US$20.33 billion) in the naphtha plant and its peripheral businesses, with the production value totaling around NT$952.2 billion, according to Gu Young, a professor at the National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, who also attended Wednesday's seminar.

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top ranking tennis player Lu Yen-hsun won his first-round match in the St. Petersburg Open men's singles against Potito Starace from Italy on Wednesday.
The world number 34 and the tournament's 4th seed, Lu needed just 58 minutes to get by Starace 6-2, 6-2.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO calls for approval on China plant plan

TEXT.P: AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) , Taiwan's second-largest LCD panel maker, urged the Taiwan government on Wednesday to quickly approve its application to set up a plant in China or it will fall further behind its South Korean rivals.
"Taiwan was ahead of South Korea in the past in terms of the global LCD panel market share, " AUO vice president Paul Peng said at the company's quarterly investors' conference.
"At present, however, Taiwan's global market share is 37 percent, while South Korea's is 52 percent," he noted.
If Taiwanese flat-panel companies want to boost their competitiveness, they need to establish factories in China, he added.
AUO plans to open a flat-panel plant in Kunshan, Jiangsu Province in eastern China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vienna Boys' Choir begins sixth tour of Taiwan

TEXT.P: Members of the Vienna Boys' Choir said they were looking forward to seeing Taipei 101, one of the world's tallest buildings, after the world-famous youngsters touched down in Taiwan Wednesday afternoon for a tour that will take them around the island.
They will perform songs from their motion pictureSilk road - Songs Along the Road and Timeat concerts scheduled in Taichung, Kaohsiung, Taipei and Hsinchu beginning Thursday.
The 25 boys aged between 10 and 14 gave a taste of their youthful sound when they launched into an Austrian clapping song accompanied by accordion at a press conference for their arrival.

Taipei 101, the tallest skycraper in the world until early this year, is a must- see for the boys, said Zhou Dun-ren, general manager of Ars Taiwan, the company that invited the choir to tour the island for the sixth time.
The choir is divided into four touring groups named after famous composers with the Mozart group arriving in Taiwan this time, said Zhou.
Their program also includes Alpine folk music and a selection of Viennese music. The Vienna Boys' Choir was founded in Austria in 1498.

DOC.HEADLINE: Petrochemical plant contributes little to local communities: report
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/10 23:55:14 (By Li Hsien-feng, Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: After over 10 years in operation, the sixth naphtha cracker plant run by the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) in Yunlin County has not had a major negative impact on local residents' lives, but nor has it made a significant contribution to the local community, a seminar heard Wednesday.

These findings from an investigation conducted by National Sun Yat-sen University Professor Lee Cheng-di were reported on day one of a three-day seminar being held by the Institute of Environment and Resource in Taipei under the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
While the plant has helped boost some small retail businesses in nearby communities, it has not helped to increase output of local fishery and agricultural industries, he reported.
Yunlin is an agricultural-based county in central Taiwan.

More than 20 experts and scholars gathered to debate the overall contribution and condition of the naphtha cracker in Yunlin's Mailiao Township, which has encountered a series of problems in recent months, including two major fires in July and two reports of foul odor leaking from the plant in September.
"This is the first time such a large meeting to evaluate public safety has been held," EPA Minister Stephan Shu-hung Shen said at the event.
"The FPG's naphtha cracker plant is a huge project, and we are very concerned whether its fifth-stage expansion would pose an adverse impact on the environment, " Shen said.
The FPG will also present a self-assessment report, Shen said, but the EPA has yet to reach an agreement with the group regarding the assessment method to be adopted by FPG.
Conclusions drawn at the seminar will serve as a reference for the government to decide the fate of the plant's expansion.

A recent survey showed that nearly 80 percent of Yunlin residents are dissatisfied with feedback measures proposed by FPG, while 32.4 percent of respondents believe the plant has done little help to the local economy.

As of the end of 2009, FPG had invested NT$628.3 billion (US$20.33 billion) in the naphtha plant and its peripheral businesses, with the production value totaling around NT$952.2 billion, according to Gu Young, a professor at the National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, who also attended Wednesday's seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 28, or the 21st day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: Christopher Columbus discovers Cuba on his first voyage to the New World and claims it in the name of Spain.
1636: Harvard College is founded at Cambridge by the General Court of Massachusetts on the comparatively modest sum of US$740, part of US$1,440 bequeathed to the university by Mr. John Harvard, assistant pastor of the First Church of Charleston.
1746: An earthquake completely destroys Lima and Callao in Peru, killing more than 18,000 people.
1794: Robert Liston, the Scottish doctor who performed the first operation in Britain on an anesthetized patient, is born.
1886: A statue called Liberty Enlightening the World, the largest present ever sent to the American people from the French, is inaugurated on Liberty Island in the Upper Bay of New York Harbor by President Grover Cleveland.
1891: A strong earthquake rocks the Niphon Islands in Japan, killing 10,000 people and leaving more than 300,000 others homeless.
1901: Taiwan's first Shinto shrine is inaugurated on Yuanshan in Taipei during Japanese colonial rule of Taiwan.
1912: Sir Richard Doll, the British cancer researcher who proved the link between cigarette smoking and lung cancer, is born.
1914: Jonas Salk, the American microbiologist who developed a polio vaccine, is born.
1950: Finland establishes diplomatic relations with Communist China.
1953: A launch ceremony for the first batch of U.S.-provided fishing boats to Taiwan is held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
1962: Soviet leader Nikita Krushchev informs U.S. President John F. Kennedy that work on missile sites under construction in Cuba will be halted and that missiles already delivered will be shipped back to the USSR.
1966: Wu Chen-nan, former leader of the "Taiwan Independence Revolutionary Council" in Japan, returns to Taiwan.
1972: Two pandas, a gift from Communist China to Japan, arrive at the Ueno Zoo in Tokyo.
1973: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi and two other Japanese leaders arrives in Taipei to extend birthday congratulations to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1977: Taiwan's first experimental geothermal power plant goes into operation in Ilan.
1979: Movie star James Mason arrives in Taipei to attend the Golden Horse Awards presentation ceremony at the invitation of the Movie and Drama Association of the ROC.
1980: Asaad Abdul Aziz Al-Zuhair, the first resident Saudi Arabian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1982: Felipe Gonzales, 40, becomes Spain's first Socialist prime minister in a landslide victory.
1992: Australian Tourism and Resources Minister Alan Griffiths visits Taipei to promote closer bilateral trade relations. He is the first Australian minister to visit Taipei since 1972.
1993: An explosion occurs at Taiwan Power Company's Hsintienlun power plant in central Taiwan, killing six people and injuring 26 others.
1993: Communist China resumes trade relations with South Africa, cut off since July 1960.
1999: Renowned Japanese writer Ayako Sono arrives in Taipei, bringing with her a cash donation of 300 million yen (US$2.88 million) and immeasurable compassion for Taiwan's earthquake victims.
2000: Former Finance Minister Paul Chiu is ordered to post NT$600,000 bail after he was formally questioned by a Taipei district prosecutor about his alleged wrongdoings during his tenure as finance minister.
2001: Amid increased exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Philippine Airlines begins operating flights on the Taipei-Manila-Shanghai route.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "He who attends to his smaller self becomes a small man, and he who attends to his greater self becomes a great man."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Thursday from its previous close, moving up 23.96 points at 8,315.00 on a turnover of NT$2.796 billion (US$90.19 million).
The weighted price index fell 52.19 points, or 0.62 percent, to close at 8,291.04 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$30.743 at 9:45 a.m. Thursday at the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.157 from Wednesday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Economic Daily News: Independent visitors will build mutual trust

TEXT.P: Workers at China's top 500 companies are expected to become the first to take advantage of a recent proposal by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to allow independent Chinese tourists, rather than just those in organized groups, to visit Taiwan.

With mutual trust a fragile commodity across the Taiwan Strait -- as highlighted by this week's spat over Taiwan's name at the Tokyo International Film Festival -- the opening up to Chinese tourists may help deepen trust and understanding between the two sides at the grass-roots level, in addition to bringing financial benefits.

Those Chinese nationals opting to travel to Taiwan on their own will probably be younger people who have greater autonomy, vitality, access to information and financial wherewithal. Allowing these social elites to have direct contact with Taiwanese people will enable them to experience Taiwan's liberal politics and pluralistic culture, and will be helpful in promoting mutual understanding and trust.

Taiwan's political, social, cultural and judicial developments provide valuable reference points for China's future reforms. We should have confidence in our own systems and in our ability to influence China. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 28, 2010)
