DOC.HEADLINE: Military working all out in Suhua Highway search: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 11:48:29 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng, Eva Feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The military has been making every effort in the search for people missing since last week when deadly rockslides hit the coastal Suhua Highway amid heavy downpours brought by Typhoon Megi, Defense Minister Kao Hua-chu said Thursday.
"We hope the public will have confidence in our soldiers' determination and abilities, " Kao told reporters upon his arrival at the Legislative Yuan to attend a meeting.

His remarks came after relatives of 19 missing Chinese tourists called a news conference in Taipei on Wednesday and questioned the intensity and efficiency of search operations. The tour group was last known to be traveling by bus on the Suhua Highway in eastern Taiwan last Thursday.
Kao said the military has been cooperating closely with the Central Emergency Operation Center to find the missing people.
"We have been doing everything we can in the operations, " Kao said. "And more backhoes have been mobilized to join the search since Tuesday."
Twenty-four persons, including 20 Chinese nationals, remained missing as of the press time.

Three Chinese officials, headed by Zhang Shenglin, deputy secretary-general of the Beijing-based quasi-official Association for Relations across the Taiwan Straits, traveled to the east coast highway's collapsed section Thursday morning to observe the search efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO predicts capacity utilization of 85 percent for Q4
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 12:31:30 (By Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp. said Thursday the company expects its production capacity utilization rate for the fourth quarter to reach about 85 percent, little changed from the third quarter.
"While inventories in the U.S. and European markets remain high, inventories in the China market have been lowered to some extent to boost demand," said Hsiao Ya-wen, an AUO spokeswoman.
"We therefore expect the capacity utilization rate for the fourth quarter will be maintained at 85 percent, as seen in the third quarter," Hsiao said.

AUO announced Wednesday it has posted a third-quarter net profit of NT$227 million (US$7.36 million) , down 98 percent from NT$11.25 billion recorded a quarter earlier due to high inventories in the global market and lower-than- expected product prices.
The unfavorable market conditions had lowered the company's gross margin to 5 percent in the third quarter, down from 15.8 percent in the second quarter, the Q3 report continued.

In related news, Hsiao said the company's second 8.5th-generation plant, located in the Central Taiwan Science Park, is scheduled to begin operations next year after installation of equipment is completed by the end of this year.
Production capacity of the new plant is yet to be finalized, she said, adding it is up to market conditions.
AUO's first 8.5th G plant, which manufactures large panels for TV use, is equipped for a monthly capacity of 40,000 units.
Such large TV panels accounted for 56 percent of AUO's total Q3 sales and represented its top-selling sector, up from the 51 percent recorded in the second quarter.
Regarding the company's business-diversification strategies, Hsiao said AUO expects its investments in solar energy will return a profit in 2011 or 2012.
AUO will invest NT$100 billion in capacity expenditure for 2010, she said, adding that 10-15 percent of this total will be in its solar-energy business.
AUO currently owns more than a 90-percent stake in Japan-based silicon wafer maker M. Setek, giving it access to the upstream solar- energy business.
In addition, the company jointly runs a solar cell plant in Malaysia with U.S.-based SunPower Corp.

AUO is one of many Taiwanese high-tech companies which have engaged in diversifying businesses, in particular into renewable energy, in the hope that these moves will alleviate any impact from a cyclical downturn in their core businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Building a disaster prevention network

TEXT.P: Possibly as a result of global climate change, any typhoon might now cause record levels of rainfall and lead to widespread disaster. The latest victim of this is Yilan County, which was drenched during last week's Typhoon Megi.

During his campaign for election as the county's magistrate, successful candidate Lin Tsong-hsien criticized his predecessor Lu Kuo-hua for responding too slowly to typhoons. Now Lin himself has performed no better, as shown by his failure to announce school and office closures early. This resulted in many children being stranded in flood water.

The serious flooding caused by several recent typhoons should provide a lesson for local government chiefs. It would be better to close schools and offices early as a precaution, and it is not important if a typhoon's impact turns out to be less serious than expected.

Moreover, in the wake of the severe landslides triggered by Typhoon Megi on the Suhua Highway, the government should set a rainfall-based standard for closing landslide-prone highways to traffic during rainy weather.
Government officials at both central and local levels must put more effort into establishing a comprehensive disaster-prevention network. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 28, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- China opens market wider for 5 service sectors

TEXT.P: China announced Wednesday that Taiwan-based companies will be allowed to operate businesses in five service sectors starting Thursday under an "early harvest" program set out in the bilateral Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) signed in June.
Most noteworthy among the new measures is that Taiwan-produced films screened in China will now be exempt from the previous quota restrictions.
Nevertheless, Taiwanese films must still pass Chinese censorship before being shown.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the announcement:
United Daily News:

According to China's Ministry of Commerce, Taiwanese companies can operate accounting, computer, and conference services as well as scientific and technological research and development services in China as part of the "early harvest" program stipulated in the ECFA that took effect Sept. 12.
In addition, in a liberalization measure related to audio/video services, the Chinese ministry said Taiwan-produced movies will no longer be subjected to a quota system.
Hitherto, China capped the annual number of movie imports at 50, of which the United States accounted for 20. Taiwan used to vie with other countries for slots in the remaining 30-film quota.
From Thursday, Taiwanese films no longer face such a restriction.
Local political analysts said China's announcement of the new market-opening measures was a goodwill gesture following a row over Taiwan's name at the Tokyo International Film Festival last weekend.

Chen Chih-kuan, director of the Government Information Office's (GIO) Department of Motion Picture Affairs, said it remains to be seen whether China will sincerely uphold its promise and refrain from using the content-censorship process to find faults.
A number of Taiwan-produced films, including "Au Revoir Taipei" and "Hear Me, " are waiting for approval to enter the Chinese market, according to Chen. (Oct. 28, 2010).
China Times:

Based on the principle of reciprocity, Taiwan will similarly open its market to Chinese service providers in five categories from Nov. 1. These are R&D, conference, computerized-booking and brokering services, and the distribution of China-produced films.

While China agrees to lift its quota system for Taiwanese films in accordance with the ECFA provisions, Taiwan only agrees to allow a maximum of 10 China- produced movies to be screened in Taiwan each year.

According to ECFA, China will offer easier market access for Taiwanese service providers in 11 business categories under the "early harvest" program, compared to nine service sectors that Taiwan has promised to open. (Oct. 28, 2010).
Liberty Times:

The Mainland Affairs Council issued a statement Wednesday expressing disappointment and regret over China's failure to apologize for the Chinese delegation head's rude demand on the opening night of the Tokyo film festival.
Jiang Ping, the head of China's delegation at the Tokyo festival ignited the spat when he demanded that Taiwan's group must include "China" in its official name at the film festival.

His demand was immediately refused by the Taiwanese delegation, which asserted that Taiwan had always participated in the festival as "Taiwan, " and that there was no reason to deviate from the usual practice.
On Wednesday, China's Taiwan Affairs Office spokesman Yang Yi said at a regular press briefing that the incident probably arose from a lack of communication between the two sides.
"This is something we do not wish to see, and we believe the matter will not affect future cross-strait collaboration or exchanges in filmmaking, " Yang said.
The MAC said Yang's remarks were disappointing and did not meet Taiwanese people's expectations.
"We can hardly see China's determination to treasure the hard-won cross-strait detente achieved in the past two years, " the MAC statement said. (Oct. 28, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: HannStar predicts no impact from former executive's guilty plea
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 14:24:13 (By Chang Chi-yun and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based flat panel maker HannStar Display Corp. said Thursday that an agreement reached between its former executive and the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) will have no impact on the company's operations.

The DOJ announced Wednesday that Wu Jui-hung, a former executive director for HannStar's global marketing and sales division, agreed to plead guilty and serve seven months in a U.S. jail for his role in a global conspiracy to fix the price of thin film transistor liquid crystal display (TFT-LCD) panels.
HannStar said that as Wu has left the company and is no longer its employee, the guilty plea will not affect the company's operations.

A DOJ statement cited a one-count felony charge filed in the U.S. District Court in San Francisco as saying Wu conspired with others to undermine competition by fixing the TFT-LCD panel prices from as early as Sept. 21, 2001, until on or about Jan. 31, 2006.

Wu was charged with meeting other participants in the conspiracy to set prices of TFT-LCD panels at predetermined levels. They also exchanged information relating to sales to monitor adherence to the agreed prices, the department said.
In addition to the jail term, Wu agreed to pay a US$20,000 criminal fine and to assist the DOJ in its ongoing investigation.
The agreement is subject to court approval, the DOJ said.

As a result of this investigation, more than US$890 million in criminal fines have been obtained to date, with 21 executives and eight companies in Japan, South Korea and Taiwan having been charged with price fixing.
endiem /MH

DOC.HEADLINE: Travelers should be aware of Bali, New Delhi health risks: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwanese nationals visiting parts of India and Indonesia are advised to be alert for contagious diseases that have been spread locally, the Bureau of Consular Affairs (BOCA) under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a press release Thursday.

Cases of chikungunya fever, a disease affecting joints, have increased in the New Delhi area during the past two weeks. These come on top of dengue fever epidemics in India's capital. Meanwhile on the Indonesian resort island of Bali, a rabies epidemic has not been effectively controlled, according to the BOCA.
Taiwanese nationals visiting these areas are advised to be careful and check information on the Center for Diseases Control website (www.cdc.gov.tw), the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nicaraguan baseball player behind bars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 16:10:46 (By Lee Hsi-chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Nicaraguan baseball catcher, Gustavo Horacio Lopez, who was detained Wednesday on suspicion of sexually assaulting a Taiwanese woman, was put behind bars in Taichung Thursday after his team failed to come up with bail of NT$200,000 (US$6,500).

Lopez, who is in the central Taiwan city with his national team to participate in the 17th Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament, was taken to the Taichung District Prosecutors Office for interrogation Wednesday afer he was accused of the assault.
After interrogation, Taichung prosecutors set bail for his release. As the team has not produced the sum, Lopez remained in custody Wednesday night.
The Taichung District Court approved Lopez's detention Thursday, said chief prosecutor Wu Tzu-yen.

Lopez met the woman when he went out to buy beer Tuesday, before the pair headed back to his hotel together, according to the Taichung City Police Bureau. The police said the alleged victim telephoned a friend for help from the hotel room. By the time the friend arrived at the hotel, the woman had disappeared. She was subsequently found by police and taken to hospital for examination.
As of press time, the Nicaragua team has continued to play in the tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.75 percent

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.75 percent Thursday led by large-cap electronics firms after United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC), the world's second largest contract chip maker, announced better-than-expected earnings for the third quarter, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 63.01 points to 8,354.05, after moving between 8,281.52 and 8,386.29, on turnover of NT$127.53 billion (US$4.14 billion).

The market opened up 0.29 percent on a technical rebound from the previous day. Buying then accelerated, particularly in select high-tech heavyweights, as investors hoped they would follow UMC and release satisfactory Q3 results.
A total of 2,085 stocks closed up, 1,777 down, and 378 remained unchanged.
The machinery and electronics sector scored the highest gain, up 1.3 percent. Financial stocks gained 0.6 percent and foodstuffs added 0.5 percent.
Among losers, textile companies fell 2.1 percent, the paper-and- pulp sector lost 1.3 percent, plastics and chemicals dropped 0.4 percent, and cement stocks fell 0.1 percent.
Construction stocks closed unchanged.

"UMC's third-quarter results were very encouraging, so investors are increasingly expecting other bellwether electronics firms will come up with good news," Taiwan International Securities analyst Michael Chiang said.
In the third quarter, UMC posted NT$8.72 billion, a new high in almost three years, up 65.4 percent from the previous quarter, while its operating profit rose 32.2 percent to NT$7.19 billion.
"Strong interest in the electronics sector helped the broader market offset the impact from selling in the old-economy sector, in particular textile stocks," Chiang said.
Chiang stated that turnover failed to expand to NT$160 billion or higher, however, the level needed for the market to overcome technical hurdles ahead of the key 8,400 point mark.
"The market may consolidate over the next few sessions before jumping the barrier," he said.
Among large-cap stocks, UMC rose 4.71 percent to NT$14.45, and TSMC gained 1.13 percent to NT$62.70, while HTC added 4.73 percent to NT$708.00.
In the old-economy sector, textile firm Far Eastern New Century fell 3.22 percent to NT$45.10, and Chung Hwa Pulp lost 2.62 percent to NT$16.70.

DOC.HEADLINE: President reiterates `1992 consensus' as basis of cross-strait ties
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 16:53:00 (By Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Thursday his administration's adherence to the "1992 consensus" as a foundation for the development of relations between Taiwan and China.

According to Ma, the consensus refers to an understanding reached in 1992 between the two sides to respectively interpret the meaning of "one China." This consensus was mentioned by a Chinese representative during a recent visit to Taiwan.
"This shows that both sides have a consistent understanding (of the content of the consensus)," Ma said.
The president was speaking to a U.S. delegation that was in Taiwan to attend an international conference on China's military power.
He said the cross-Taiwan Strait military balance has been tilting in favor of China since 2005, a situation that has drawn widespread regional and global concern.

In light of this, Ma said, he has taken various steps to try to improve relations with China and ease cross-strait tension since his inauguration two years ago, because Taiwan is unlikely to engage in an arms race with China.

It was against this background that he pledged to maintain the status quo across the strait by following a policy of "no unification, no independence, no use of force" and to develop relations with China on the basis of the "1992 consensus," Ma said.

On a proposal to establish confidence-building measures between the two sides, the president said the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement signed by the two sides in June is one of these steps. According to Ma, the trade agreement would not have been possible without mutual cross-strait confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Thursday, dropping NT$0.076 to close at NT$30.824.
Turnover totaled US$914 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$30.910 and moved to a low of NT$30.631 before rebounding.
Dealers said the New Taiwan dollar turned stronger right after the market opened as the local bourse steamed ahead, led by foreign institutional buying.
Due to the gains in Taiwan share prices, foreign funds kept flowing into the local market, lending further support to the local currency, they said.
The benchmark weighted index rose 0.75 percent to 8,354.05.
The continued appreciation of most Asian currencies against the U.S. dollar in the regional market also added downward pressure to the greenback on the local market, the dealers said.
The selling of U.S. currency on the local market largely came from foreign banks and exporters, they said.
The central bank made its presence felt in late trading, buying U.S. dollars in a bid to prevent a rapid rise of the New Taiwan dollar, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares of HTC jump on China hopes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CAN) 10/28/10 18:04:57 (By Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of smartphone maker HTC Corp. soared Thursday on institutional buying as investors were anticipating that the huge China market will further boost the company's bottom line, dealers said.

After United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) , the world's second- largest contract chip maker, reported better-than-expected third quarter results the previous day, more and more investors were expecting that HTC will release strong third quarter earnings Friday, they said.
HTC rose 4.73 percent to the day's high of NT$708.00 (US$22.98) Thursday, with 6.80 million shares changing hands, while the benchmark weighted index closed up 0.75 percent at 8,354.05.
"The China smartphone market is still in its infancy, " Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said.
"Investors, therefore, have high hopes that HTC will reap massive benefits from the China market since the company launched its own brands there for the first time in July, " said Hsu.

On Wednesday, HTC joined forces with China Telecom, one of the largest telecom operators in China, to market an HTC-branded 3G model in China, a move that enhanced market confidence in HTC's presence there, the dealers said.
The market is watching closely to see what agreements HTC and China Telecom might strike next week when China Telecom Chairman Wang Xiaochu meets in Taipei with HTC Chairman Cher Wang, they said.
"The buying in HTC today largely came from institutional investors who are betting that the company will release satisfactory third quarter results," Hsu said.

Market consensus predicts that HTC will post an earnings per share (EPS) of NT$45 for 2010, up from NT$28.71 recorded in 2009, and that the 2011 EPS will rise even further up to NT$65, according to Hsu.
"Based on HTC's profit prospects, the stock's current valuation remains low and there is room for further gains, " Hsu said, giving a target price of NT$900.00.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier to visit Hualien to meet road protesters
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 18:26:35 (By Chen Shun-hsieh, Andrew Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih told residents of eastern Taiwan's Hualien County Thursday not to make the arduous journey to Taipei in the current stormy weather, and said he will instead travel to Hualien to meet them and address their grievances.

Wu said he would like to lead a delegation of officials to Hualien to meet residents there who are planning to lodge a protest in Taipei Nov. 1 demanding that the government accelerate the start of an upgrading project for the Suhua Highway -- the cliff-edge highway connecting Suao in Yilan with Hualien to the south that serves as the major route in and out of the area for the people and their produce.
He said the administration knows very well the aspirations of the Hualien residents for an improved highway, and the purpose of their planned protest.
The road improvement project, although environmentally and geologically challenging, is viable, Wu said.
The administration has been planning the project for two years and has communicated with environmental groups and local opinion leaders over the past year, he said.
"Construction can start as soon as the project has passed an environmental impact assessment," the premier promised.

Wu made the remarks after the Hualien county government began mobilizing residents to travel to Taipei Nov. 1 to stage a sit-in demanding the start of the road improvement project, which has been stalled for nearly a decade.
Calls have been mounting for an early start of the improvement project in the wake of serious landslides there caused by Typhoon Megi a week previously.
Wu's remarks came after a tour bus carrying 19 Chinese tourists went missing on the road Oct. 21 during torrential rain.

Several other tour buses and automobiles, which were also traveling on the highway at the time, were also affected by the typhoon, which thrashed northeastern Taiwan Oct. 21-22 with record-high rainfall.
Twenty-three people, including 19 Chinese nationals, remained unaccounted for as of press time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Intel to collaborate on cloud computing

TEXT.P: The government signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with U.S. chipmaker heavyweight Intel Thursday to collaborate on cloud computing technology and set up the company's first research and development center in the country.

Intel said it will provide technical and training resources for two leading Taiwanese companies in the information and communication sector -- Inventec and Wistron -- which have been recommended by the Taiwan Cloud Computing Association (TCCA) and the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to develop cloud data center offerings.

Intel President and CEO Paul Otellini said at a press conference that he sees no better partners for the company than Taiwan's IT industry because no-one else has the same track record in commercializing innovation.

Otellini also announced that Intel and the National Science Council (NSC) will work with a leading local university to establish a research center to strengthen Taiwan's academic position in the emerging connected embedded devices segment. The three parties will invest a total of up to NT$750 million (US$23.5 million) over the coming three to five years in the project.

Meanwhile that same day, the U.S. company also signed a cooperation agreement with the country's top telecom operator, Chunghwa Telecom, as part of its efforts to build up the cloud computing industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-Japanese prime minister to visit Taiwan: legislator

TEXT.P: Former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is scheduled to visit Taiwan and meet President Ma Ying-jeou, Legislative Yuan sources said Thursday.

Abe is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan for a two-day visit Oct. 31-Nov. 1 with more than a dozen Japanese parliamentarians aboard the maiden flight that will kick off direct flights between Taipei's Songshan Airport and Tokyo's Haneda Airport, said a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislator who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Abe, who served as the 57th prime minister of Japan from September 2006 until September 2007, is scheduled to meet Ma Oct. 31 and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng the following day, the legislator said.
However, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs denied all knowledge of any such visit.

"Visits of any former foreign dignitaries are welcomed and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) believes such visits are beneficial to bilateral relations. However, we have no information about any forthcoming visit by the former Japanese Prime Minister, " MOFA spokesman James Chang said.
The Japan Interchange Association (JIA) which acts as Japan's representative office in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties, declined to comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese big spenders on health food: survey

TEXT.P: Taiwanese people are big spenders on health food, with each adult spending an average NT$1,031 (US$33.47) per month on such foodstuff, according to the results of a survey published Thursday.

Around 85 percent of the people in Taiwan would spend that amount of money to buy organic, functional food or Chinese herbs to gain greater health or medical benefits, in addition to purchasing basic nutritional food, the survey conducted by the Taiwan Pharmaceutical Marketing and Management Association has found.

The amount spent on health food is well above the average of NT$275 spent per month by each individual on buying medicine, an indication that Taiwanese people prefer to rely on consuming health food and supplements instead of on medicine to boost their health, association officials said.

However, two thirds of the respondents said they would go to see a doctor and get prescribed medicine at clinics or hospitals covered in the National Health Insurance program whenever they suffer from just a little discomfort.

The reasons cited for such behavior included belief in doctors' and hospitals' professionalism, safety, and effectiveness. People also prefer seeing a doctor because the fees are covered by the insurance program.

The number of visits made by the public to the appointed hospitals under the health insurance program has steadily risen in recent years, with the average insured person going to the hospital 15 times last year.
Around NT$508 billion has been allocated for the program's expenses in 2011.

The association carried out the random telephone survey from Sept. 13-24, questioning 1,074 men and women aged between 20-65 across Taiwan about their medical practices. It had a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese woman missing for nine days in Malaysia found
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 19:32:29 (By Sun Tien-mei and Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: A 27-year-old Taiwanese woman named Lin Wei-wen who was reported missing in Malaysia after a serious argument with her French boyfriend called her family on Thursday after being out of reach for nine days.
Lin and her boyfriend arrived in Malaysia for a short vacation on Oct. 11. Friends of Lin said she had a quarrel with her boyfriend which led to a break-up on Oct. 19.
Lin decided to continue the trip on her own, but she had not been seen or heard from for nine days after the break-up, according to her friends.

James Chang, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said on Thursday afternoon Lin's mother got a phone call from her daughter, who is in Tioman Island, a small island located 32 km off the east coast of Malaysia. Lin told her mother that her mobile connection was bad on the island.

The Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Malaysia had said on Wednesday that Lin was listed as missing in Malaysia and that the Malaysian police had passed Lin's information to the International Criminal Police Organization. The police had said departure records showed Lin was still in Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA may reconsider site of petrochemical park
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 19:40:27 (By Lin Hui-chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will await the final result of an environmental impact assessment before deciding whether to change the site of the controversial Kuokuang Petrochemical Park, minister Shih Yen-shiang said Thursday.

Shih noted that the site of the proposed park has been changed a number of times, with the location last shifted from Yunlin County to Changhua County, based on a proposal by the Changhua County government.
Before that, the MOEA had also considered Pingtung and Kaohsiung counties as a possible site, the minister said during a hearing held by the Legislative Yuan's Economics Committee on the project.
The project involves building the country's eighth naphtha cracker on a plot of tidal land in Changhua's Dacheng area.

Environmentalists have expressed strong opposition to the plan, arguing that the facility would cause irreversible damage to local flora and fauna, endanger marine life, and ultimately threaten the livelihoods of local farmers and fishermen.

Also at the legislative hearing, Tsai Chia-yang, president of the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union's Changhua Division, called it a "mistake" to try to build a petrochemical park at one of the country's most important agricultural and fishing capitals.
The designated site is also home to a major wetland of great conservation value, Tsai pointed out.

Addressing these concerns, Council of Agriculture Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung said his council will demand that comprehensive assessments are made before construction work begins to minimize its impact on the agricultural and fishing sectors.

On concerns that underground water might be extracted for use at the future petrochemical park, which could lead to land subsidence, Shih said the park will not do so because underground water is insufficient to meet the high demand for water by the park.
According to Shih, if the project is scrapped, Taiwan's self-sufficient ratio for ethylene -- a substance used for manufacturing plastics and other chemicals -- will decrease.
This could lead to an exodus of Taiwan's petrochemical midstream and downstream operations because it is difficult to import ethylene from other countries, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Body part recovered from sea confirmed to be Chinese tourist's
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 19:48:13 (By Sunrise Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A body part recovered from the waters off the coast of northeastern Taiwan on Monday has been confirmed through DNA tests to belong to that of a female Chinese tourist, the Yilan District Prosecutors Office said Thursday.

"DNA tests conducted by the Ministry of Justice's Institute of Forensic Medicine confirmed that the body part belonged to that of Gong Yen, a member of a Chinese tour group, " said Lin Jhe-hui, a chief prosecutor at the Yilan County prosecution office.

Gong was a member of a 19-person tour group from China's Guangdong Province, which was last known to be traveling on the Suhua Highway Oct. 2l when the major scenic route perching on a cliff overlooking the Pacific Ocean was hit by rockslides amid heavy downpours brought by Typhoon Megi.

Judging from the fact that Gong's body part was salvaged from waters 8 nautical miles off Yilan County's Chuangwei Township, Lin said, the bodies of some of the other members of the Guangdong tour group might have also fallen into the sea.
Lin said Gong's relatives have been informed of the latest DNA test results.

Last week's deadly rockslides on the accident-prone Suhua Highway linking eastern Taiwan's Hualien county to Yilan County and Taipei had left three dead and 23 others missing, of whom 19 were Chinese nationals.
Besides Gong's, some body parts of the Taiwanese bus driver of the Guangdong tour group, identified as Tsai Chih-ming, have also been recovered.

Also found were the remains of Liu Yu-chun, a local special education teacher. Liu's body was found on a slope off the highway and it is believed that her car slid off the highway when rockslides struck. The 53-year-old teacher at a Christian school for the mentally and physically disabled in Hualien was on her way to her sister's home in northwestern Taiwan's Miaoli County.
The search for the missing people continued for an eighth day on Thursday, with the military mobilizing more backhoes and other equipment for the operations.

Three Chinese officials, headed by Zhang Shenglin, deputy secretary-general of the Beijing-based quasi-official Association for Relations across the Taiwan Straits, traveled to the east coast highway's collapsed section Thursday morning to observe the search efforts.
A group of 36 relatives of the missing Chinese tourists also arrived in Taipei earlier this week to get first-hand information about their loved ones.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers want increased national debt repayment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 19:58:31 (By Chao-fen Kao & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Lawmakers across the political spectrum demanded Thursday that the government speed up the pace of its debt repayment.

"It will take the government 75 years to pay off its huge accumulated debts, even if austerity measures are taken and no more new debts are raised, " Legislator Lay Shyh- bao of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) said, while panning the government for making too little effort addressing the debt problem.

Lai's view was echoed by his colleagues at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Finance Committee, including the KMT's Luo Shu-lei, Sun Da-chien, Lin Teh-fu and Lu Hsiu-yen, and Kao Chih-peng of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, as well as Kang Shih-ju, an independent lawmaker.

They passed a resolution to ask the government to raise the sum budgeted for debt repayment to 7.5 percent of the annual tax revenue, representing an increase of NT$30 billion (US$9.6 billion) to NT$100 billion, beginning 2012.
According to Lai, the government's ratio of debt-repayment fund to its tax revenue currently stands at only 5.38 percent, far lower than the 10.33 percent for the period between 1992 and 2001.

In response, Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der said the debts have been raised for national construction projects and that it is common for industrialized countries to have high per capita income, a high tax burden and a high national debt.
According to official statistics, Taiwan's accumulated outstanding debts totaled NT$4.06 trillion (about US$134 billion) as of the end of 2009, and are expected climb to NT$4.96 trillion this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC's Q3 net profit hits record high
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 20:27:02 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) , the world's largest contract chip maker, said Thursday its third-quarter net profit hit a record high on the back of strong global demand for consumer electronics and internet-related products.
In the July-September period, TSMC posted NT$46.94 billion (US$1.52 billion) in net profit, up 16.5 percent from the second quarter and 53.6 percent from a year earlier.
During the same time, the company's sales also hit a record high at NT$112.25 billion which represented a quarter-on-quarter increase of 6.9 percent and a year-on-year rise of 24.8 percent, it said.
TSMC recorded an earnings per share of NT$1.81 in the third quarter, compared with NT$1.55 in the second quarter and NT$1.18 a year earlier.

Its gross margin in the third quarter rose to 50.0 percent from 49.5 percent in the second quarter and 47.7 percent a year earlier, while its operating margin fell to 38.4 percent in the third quarter from 38.6 percent in the second quarter, but rose from 35.6 percent a year earlier.
In the third quarter, products on the advanced 40 nanometer production process accounted for about 17 percent of the company's total sales.

In a quarterly investors conference, TSMC Chairman Morris Chang said he expects the ratio of the 40 nm production process will rise to 20 percent in the fourth quarter on rising demand for higher end products.
Chang said he expects the more advanced 28 nm production process will generate 1-2 percent of the company's sales in the second half of next year.

The chairman said the market demand for micro chips surpassed supply in the past quarter and such favorable market conditions are expected to continue in the fourth quarter, adding that TSMC is faced with piling orders, in particular the orders for certain specialty products.

Looking ahead, TSMC said its sales for the fourth quarter are expected to range between NT$107 billion and NT$109 billion, while its gross margin is expected to stand at 48 percent-50 percent in the October-December period and the operating margin is likely to reach 35.5 percent to NT$37.5 percent, the company said.

Chang said he remains optimistic about the outlook of the global foundry business, and expects production value of the industry to grow 14 percent in 2011, compared to 2010, higher than a 5 percent increase expected for the overall semiconductor sector.
The anticipated 14 percent growth in the global foundry business will be partly the result of continued production outsourcing from fabless integrated circuit designers, Chang said.
Chang added that to meet demand from logic IC buyers, TSMC will continue to expand its research and development capacity in 2011 with spending in R&D expected to exceed US$1.1 billion.
He said TSMC's total capital expenditure for 2011 will top 2010's US$5.9 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to launch national plan to promote swimming

TEXT.P: An inter-agency national action plan will be launched to teach more Taiwanese students and servicemen how to swim, a government official said in a press conference Thursday.

The ambitious 12-year plan, supervised by the Executive Yuan, hopes to teach at least eight out of 10 Taiwanese students, soldiers, policemen and firemen how to swim, which will dramatically reduce cases of drowning, said Tai Hsia-ling, minister of the Sports Affairs Council (SAC).

"In an island country like Taiwan, it is difficult to fathom why there are so many drownings and why so few people know how to swim, " Tai said, adding that President Ma Ying-jeou, an avid swimmer, is the driving force behind the scheme.
Almost all major developed countries, such as Japan, France and the United Kingdom, have public policies to promote swimming, she said.

According to Tai, the ratio of swimming pools per 100,000 students between Japan and Taiwan is an eye-popping 188 to 9.6. Citing a World Health Organization study conducted in 2001, she added that the ratio of drownings per 100,000 children under the age of 14 in Japan and Taiwan is 0.6 to 1.8.
Under the project, swimming pools will be built, personnel will be trained and pool management will be improved from 2010-2022 so that local people will have better access to swimming facilities.

Joining the SAC will be the Ministry of National Defense, the National Police Agency, the Coast Guard Administration, the National Fire Agency, the Ministry of Education and 25 municipalities around the country.

A supervisory committee under the Executive Yuan will set targets for different groups. Among them, 80 percent of school children, 85 percent of military servicemen and 80 percent of police officers will have to be able to swim for at least 50 meters, while 90 percent of firemen and all Coast Guard Administration staff will be required to pass a 200-meter test.

With more people participating in swimming, Taiwan will be able to select athletes to represent the country in international competitions, said Thomas Tsai, President of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee.

Educators also hope the project will be able to help bridge the huge gap in the balance of resources between the north and the south, where only around half of the townships have swimming pools, said Cheng Mei-nu, an elementary school principal in the southern county of Yunlin.

DOC.HEADLINE: Absentee voting favored by most people: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 20:50:17 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: Seventy- eight percent of the people polled are in favor of adopting an absentee voting system, which Taiwan is considering introducing in the 2012 presidential election, a survey released by the Ministry of the Interior showed Thursday.
The telephone poll found 78 percent of the respondents supported allowing voters to vote by absentee ballot, compared with 21.1 percent who were against the idea.
In addition, 73.5 percent of the respondents particularly backed one form of absentee voting, which allows voters to cast their ballots at polling stations outside their hometowns on election day.
Another 24.8 percent of the people surveyed did not prefer this alternative, according to the survey.

Many people in Taiwan, especially young people, work away from their registered places of residence -- usually their hometowns -- but under Taiwan's current voting laws, they must return to their hometowns to vote.

The results found younger and more educated respondents showed more support for the system, with 85 percent of the respondents aged 20-29 being in favor of it. Eighty-two percent of the respondents with a college or master's degree also favored being able to vote by absentee ballot.
Citizens living overseas, however, will not be able to vote by absentee ballot; they are required to return to Taiwan to vote, the ministry announced earlier.
Nearly 83 percent of the respondents agreed with this approach compared with 64.9 percent who said absentee voting should be applied to as many people as possible.

In terms of who should be included as priority voters under such a system, 77 percent of the respondents said people who work outside their hometowns, followed by voters who study outside their hometowns, policemen on duty, servicemen in the military, and election staff.
In addition, more than 71 percent of the respondents were in favor of putting the system into effect in the presidential election in 2012, while 27.2 percent were against the idea.
The poll conducted between Oct. 14-16 collected 1,094 valid samples, with a sampling error of plus or minus 2.96 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan fine product fair opens in China's Shandong Province

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-Shandong culture week and fine Taiwanese product exhibition opened Thursday in Jinan, capital of China's Shandong Province.

Some 8,300 local and foreign buyers, including China's top 50 distributors, are expected to visit the major fair that is co-sponsored by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and the Shandong provincial government.

About 500 high-tech and traditional companies, as well as service and cultural innovation businesses from Taiwan, are displaying more than 20,000 items of high-quality goods at the fair, hoping to polish the image of "made-in-Taiwan" products among Chinese consumers.

Speaking to a capacity crowd at the opening ceremony, TAITRA Chairman Wang Chih- kang predicted a rosy picture for two-way Taiwan-Shandong trade and commerce, citing the complementary economies of the two sides.
"Bilateral cooperation will be as deep and broad as the sea, " he said.
Shandong Provincial Governor Jiang Daming also addressed the event, noting that two-way exchanges in personnel and activities are growing rapidly.
Shandong with a population of 95 million, has the second- highest retail sales level among China's provinces, autonomous regions and municipalities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ability to swim crucial for Taiwanese military: official

TEXT.P: Learning how to swim is a crucial aspect of Taiwanese soldiers' training, to help them meet the requirements of serving the country, a Taiwanese military official said Thursday.

"There is no doubt that we would require our soldiers to know how to swim so they are able to function better for the two most important aspects of the Republic of China's (Taiwan) armed forces: combat and disaster relief, " said Wang Shih-tu, Deputy Chief of Staff for Operation and Planning of the Ministry of National Defense (MND).

Speaking on the sidelines of a news conference about a national action plan to promote swimming, Wang said that a military force with around 40 percent of its soldiers who don't know how to swim "will not be able to do combat in Taiwan, where there are plenty of rivers, ponds and fish farms."
"Nor will they be able to execute disaster relief operations when most of the time they have to wade into the water to rescue people in need and protect themselves at the same time, " he said.

The last thing the MND wants to see is the loss of soldiers during disaster relief operations when the troopers are sent out to rescue people's lives, he said. "Fortunately, we haven't lost any up to now," Wang said.

The lieutenant general's remarks came hours after a legislator questioned the MND's five-year budget of NT$5.4 billion to build and renovate swimming pools in a legislative session on Thursday morning.

Taiwan's military had started to implement extensive swimming training since last May and the results have been fruitful, Wang said, adding that 62.4 percent of its troops have now met the requirement of 50-meter tests, up from 47.7 percent last May.

"We see it as a combat skill rather than only a recreational activity. And I'm glad the commander-in-chief of the armed forces -- President Ma Ying-jeou -- has recognized the importance of this crucial skill, "Wang said, referring to the president's assertiveness in promoting swimming.

DOC.HEADLINE: Naphtha cracker air pollution affects three counties: academic
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 21:40:15 (By Lee Hsien-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Toxic air pollution caused by Taiwan's sixth naphtha cracker complex in Mailiao Township, Yunlin County, has not just affected that county but has spread to the two counties further south at even higher density, an academic said Thursday.
The naphtha cracker complex was run by the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG).

Ozone from volatile organic compounds discharged from factories in the FPG petrochemical complex have been carried to the southern counties of Chiayi and Tainan, said Yen You-li, an associate professor with the Department of Safety, Health and Environmental Engineering of National United University in Miaoli County.

Quoting the results of a quantitative study conducted between 1994 and 2009, Yen said the ozone density monitored in Chiayi's Singang Township has been as high as 221 ppb, much higher than the allowable level of 120 ppb.

The ozone density monitored in Tainan city and county is also higher than that found in Yunlin County and its neighboring Changhua County, said Yen at a workshop sponsored by the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration on an assessment of the overall industrial examination of the FPG petrochemical complex.
Ozone can cause coughing and allergies, Yen said.

Meanwhile, the density of sulfur dioxide in the air at Yunlin County's Taisi Township has been found to be exceptionally high and complaints lodged by local residents have also increased noticeably since the petrochemical complex was built, Yen noted.
FPG said Thursday that it would not comment on the discussions at the workshop until the two-day session ended.

The Chiayi County government said it was paying close attention to the workshop and the discussions. If finances permit, the county government will launch a health risk assessment drive in the county, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of dengue fever cases rises sharply in Taipei County
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 21:46:56 (By Yang Su-jui and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Three more cases of indigenous dengue fever have been reported in Taipei County, bringing to nine the total number of cases recorded in the northern county within a week, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Thursday.
Among the cases reported this week, eight live in Wugu Township and one in Sanchong City, according to CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi.

Despite the sharp rise in the number of dengue fever cases in such a short time, Shih said he was not overly concerned about the outbreak, since the latest cases recorded were all related to latent infections that just happen to have been discovered at the same time.
The time between infection and the manifestation of symptoms can range from three to 14 days, but five to seven days is more usual, he said.
In addition, the county has only detected the Aedes albopictus mosquito, which is a less efficient vector of dengue fever than the Aedes aegypti that is prevalent in southern Taiwan, Shih said.

In southern Taiwan, an outbreak there has shown no signs of easing. A total of 230 cases had been reported in Tainan City as of Wednesday, during the height of the epidemic season, said Hu Shu-chen, head of the city's Health Bureau.
Around 200 soldiers were deployed around Tainan City Thursday to spray insecticide in a bid to eradicate adult mosquitoes and prevent further cases, Hu said.
Taiwan has recorded 834 indigenous dengue fever cases this year since August.

DOC.HEADLINE: Film official to be given merit for defending national dignity
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 22:02:38 (By Lee Ming-chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The head of the Taiwanese delegation to the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival deserves recognition for the way he defended the country's national dignity in a name row with China at the event, Premier Wu Den-yih said Thursday.

The premier was referring to Chen Chih-kuan, director of the Department of Motion Pictures Affairs under the Government Information Office (GIO), who rejected his Chinese counterpart's rude demand that the Taiwanese delegation include "China" in its official name on the opening night of the film festival Oct. 23.

In the altercation, Chen told Jiang Ping, head of the Chinese delegation, that since Taiwan has always participated in the festival as "Taiwan, " there was no reason to deviate from the usual practice. He also advised Jiang not to mix arts with politics. The spat lasted over 90 minutes and cost both delegations the chance to join the star-studded Oscar-style "green carpet walk."
"Chen has set a good model for us with his `neither humble nor arrogant' manner in dealing with the incident, " Wu said at a weekly Cabinet meeting.
According to Wu, GIO Minister Johnny Chiang, Chen's direct boss, came up with a proposal to give Chen an official merit for his efforts to safeguard Taiwan's national dignity and interests.

As the 2010 Asian Games will open in China's Guangzhou City Nov. 12, Wu said he hopes China will be a good host and will show goodwill and sincerity by refraining from touching on any sensitive name issues at the event.
He also reminded the Sports Affairs Council to exercise caution and prudence in dealing with relevant issues.
"We should abide by Olympic Games regulations and safeguard our national dignity in a graceful, appropriate manner, " the premier said.

When asked whether Taiwan will seek a formal response from Beijing on the Tokyo incident, Chiang said only that the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) had already issued a statement the previous day on the issue.
The MAC statement expressed disappointment and regret over China's failure to apologize for Jiang's instigation of the name issue at the film festival.

"We hope the Chinese authorities will understand Taiwan's feelings about being isolated and denigrated in the international community.... Only if both sides show goodwill can hard-won cross-strait detente be maintained and bilateral relations move forward," the statement said.
Earlier that day, China's Taiwan Affairs Office spokesman Yang Yi said at a regular press briefing that the incident probably arose from a lack of communication between the two sides.

"This is something we do not wish to see, and we believe the matter will not affect future cross-strait collaboration or exchanges in filmmaking, " Yang said. He did not reprimand Jiang for igniting the row. DITEM/J

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholars warn against haste in Suhua Highway improvement project

TEXT.P: Work on a Suhua Highway improvement project should not be rushed under pressure from public opinion, scholars said after serious landslides on the road had claimed 15 lives and left 23 people missing as of Thursday.

The warning came after angry residents in the eastern county threatened to stage a rally in Taipei City Nov. 1 and the Hualien County Council went into indefinite recess in protest over the central government's long delay in improving the road linking Yilan and Hualien counties.
Lee Hong-yuan, a professor of the Department of Civil Engineering at National Taiwan University (NTU) , said policy makers should not react emotionally simply because of pressure from the public.
"We should pay closer attention to the issue of the Suhua Highway improvement project instead of hastening the government to start the improvement construction," Lee said.
His words were echoed by Hongey Chen, professor of the Department of Geosciences at NTU.
Chen said the government should spend more time investigating the unique geological structure of the region and the environmental impact of the project before construction takes place.
"If we do not take variables such as faultlines and groundwater into consideration, building tunnels on the Suhua Highway in haste could do more harm to the area," he said.
The Suhua improvement project calls for tunnels to be built to avoid some of the worst existing sections of the road.
An environmental impact assessment for the project remains under evaluation by a review committee, the last hurdle before the bidding process for contractors can begin.
During the intervening period, Chen went on, the government should clearly identify the most unstable sections of the highway.
Lee said that the government should also examine its ability to manage the highway after the reconstruction.
According to the National Police Agency, there were more casualties due to traffic accidents than to natural disasters between 2002 and 2007 on the highway.
Lee said that without careful planning, the situation will be even worse if car accidents happen inside the proposed tunnels.
Other scholars emphasized the importance of seeking long-term solutions for the people of Taiwan, who have to learn how to live with extreme weather and natural disasters.

Liu Shawchen, director of the Research Center for Environment Changes at Academia Sinica, said the public could take advantage of alternative transport rather than being caught in a radical yes-or-no situation regarding the road.
"If we can upgrade the current railway system and even ferry services, I believe there will be more possibilities for figuring out how to take care of the Suhua Highway problem," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Road protest plan unchanged: Hualien magistrate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 22:30:03 (By Andrew Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih is welcome to visit Hualien County, but the county's plan to stage a protest in Taipei to push for the upgrading of the Suhua Highway remains unchanged, Hualien Magistrate Fu Kun-chi said Thursday.
The premier is welcome to visit the eastern county to gain a better understanding of development there, which lags 40 years behind the rest of the country, Fu said.

He was responding to remarks by Wu, who called for Hualien residents earlier in the day not to make the arduous journey to Taipei in the current stormy weather, and said he will instead travel to Hualien to meet them and address their grievances.

Wu said he wanted to lead a delegation of officials to Hualien to meet residents there who are planning to lodge the protest in Taipei Nov. 1 demanding that the government accelerate the start of an upgrading project for the Suhua Highway -- the cliff-edge highway connecting Suao in Yilan with Hualien to the south that serves as the major route in and out of the area for the people and their produce.
He said the administration knows very well the aspirations of the Hualien residents for an improved highway, and the purpose of their planned protest.

The road improvement project, although environmentally and geologically challenging, is viable, Wu said, adding that construction can start as soon as the project has passed an environmental impact assessment.
According to the Hualien County government, more than 10,000 local residents will travel to Taipei Nov. 1 to stage a sit-in demanding an early start to the road improvement project.

Fu disclosed that the Hualien County government came under pressure when it applied for permission to hold the protest in Taipei, and said related central government units have tried to dissuade the Hualien officials from organizing the protest.
Meanwhile, Lai Kun-cheng, a legislator representing the eastern county of Taitung, said residents there have also started planning to join the protest.
Calls have been mounting for an early start to the improvement project in the wake of serious landslides caused by Typhoon Megi a week previously on the Suhua Highway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Southern Taiwan school receives donation from Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 22:35:33 (By Kuo Chu-chen and Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: An elementary School in Pingtung County has received a donation of NT$110,000 (US$3,585) from a Japanese school for a restoration fund, school officials said Thursday.

Representatives of Kobe Takatsuka Senior High School in Japan, including two teachers and three students visited the Linbian Elementary School in the southern county to make the donation during a graduation trip to Taiwan.

One of the teachers said the school's second grade teachers and students raised the money at the school and in the neighborhood after learning that some areas of Taiwan were damaged badly by Typhoon Morakot in August last year.
The school contacted the Pingtung County government, which suggested that the donation should go to Linbian Elementary School, which was flooded to a depth of two meters during the typhoon.
"A massive earthquake struck Kobe 15 years ago and the city's residents understand the pain suffered by the Taiwanese people during the disaster," one of the students said.
"The fund-raising campaign won great support in the city, " the student said at the donation ceremony.

Many of the Linbian students' parents became unemployed after the typhoon and approximately 200 students cannot afford their lunch and tuition fees. Therefore, the donation will be used to help those students, said the school's principal, Liu Wan-te.
At the end of ceremony, the teachers and students of the two schools also jointly planted a jasmine orange on the campus to commemorate the visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Intel to continue support for WiMAX in Taiwan: President

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou confirmed Thursday that chipmaker Intel will continue its support for Taiwan's development of wireless broadband technology WiMAX, after a meeting with Intel President and CEO Paul Otellini in Taipei.
Ma said the government has released six licenses for WiMAX operators and has invested US$220 million in developing related technologies and applications.
He said previous cooperative programs with chip company Qualcomm and mobile network equipment maker Ericsson can be role models for Intel to strengthen its long-term cooperation with Taiwan.

Otellini's visit has been highly anticipated in Taiwan after the company's closure of its WiMAX Program Office (WPO) in June sparked speculation that it was withdrawing support for WiMAX, in which Taiwan has made significant investments over the past two years.
Earlier in the day, Stanley Huang, Intel's director of advanced technical sales and services in the Asia-Pacific region, told reporters that WiMAX still has prospects in the industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan routs Japan in Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament

TEXT.P: Taiwan routed a young Japanese national team 12-5 Thursday to win its first game in the semifinal round of the 2010 Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament in the central city of Taichung.
