Lin came up to the mound after starter Chen Hong-wen and the first relief pitcher Liao Wen-yang had failed to contain the opposing hitters. The amateur right-hander pitched 5 1/3 strong innings and gave up only one hit.
Taiwan, scheduled to meet Italy (2-1) in Taichung the following evening, was 2-1 and ranked second behind Cuba (3-0) in the six-team semifinal round. Japan was 1-2.
Unfazed by a 4-0 early deficit, Taiwan punished Japanese starter Takahiro Iwao with four hits in the bottom of the second inning, including two doubles and a triple by Lo Kuo-hui, to tie the score.

After Japan regained a 5-4 lead, the home boys again took advantage of Japanese reliever Hideki Sunaga's inconsistency and his teammates' shaky defense. Chen Chun-hsiu's double was followed by a deadball and an error as Taiwan tied the game and added two more runs by consecutive sacrifice flies to bring the score to 7-5.

The situation almost got out of hand in the top of the fourth inning, when Lin Yu-ching's consecutive hit batsmen came close to turning the game into a bench- clearing brawl as players from both teams exchanged heated words on the field before the umpire managed to regain control.

Japan, which had an average age of less than 23 as a team, was hurt by five defensive errors, four of which came in the first four innings, a rare showing for any Japanese national team. The first baseman Taishi Ota and shortstop Shota Ohmine committed two errors apiece.
Taiwan had six consecutive hits with two outs in the bottom of the eighth to add four runs and turn the game into a rout.
In other semifinal round games Thursday, Cuba beat the Netherlands 6-3 and Italy defeated South Korea 5-2.
Semifinal standings: Cuba 3-0, Italy 2-1, Taiwan 2-1, Japan 1-2, Netherlands 1-2, South Korea 0-3

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC disappointed at Chinese official's remarks over name row
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 23:13:01 (By Charles Kang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday that it issued two statements a day earlier to drive home the message of regret and disappointment over China's response to a row over the name of the Taiwanese delegation at the opening ceremony of the Tokyo International Film Festival Oct. 23.

MAC Deputy Chairman Liu Teh-hsun said the MAC first issued a statement after China's Taiwan Affairs Office spokesman Yang Yi said earlier that day that "the incident probably took place due to a lack of communication between both sides. This is something we do not wish to see."
Yang's remarks "failed to live up to our expectations" and no efforts to maintain bilateral relations were seen, the MAC said in the statement.
The MAC also expressed "regret and disappointment" at Yang's remarks.

In the second statement issued a few hours later, the MAC said Yang's remarks might have meant well, but he obviously lacked knowledge of the Taiwanese people and could not empathize with Premier Wu Den-yih's "overbearing" description of Jiang Ping, the leader of the Chinese delegation to the festival, who had insisted that Taiwan attend the festival under the name of "Taiwan, China" or "Chinese Taipei," which Taiwanese delegation flatly rejected.
The incident lasted over 90 minutes and cost both delegations the chance to walk down the "green carpet" at the star-studded Oscar-style event.

The incident seriously hurt the feelings of the Taiwanese people and was detrimental to the peaceful development of cross-strait relations, the MAC said in the statement, urging Beijing to take "immediate remedial measures."
Liu said the first statement was terse, while the second more fully expressed the government's stance on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: No extra aid needed for Suhua search: Mainland Affairs Council
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 23:21:40 (By Mai-lan Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The government has been doing its utmost in the search for Chinese tourists who were probably buried by mudslides on the Suhua Highway when Typhoon Megi hit northeastern Taiwan Oct. 21-22, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Deputy Chairman Liu Te-shun said Thursday.

"The biggest problem that the rescuers have encountered is the extremely rugged slopes and the amount of rubble that continues to come down on several sections of the highway where they are still making all-out efforts to search for the missing, " Liu said in a routine news briefing.
"The Taiwan government fully understands the grave concerns of their families, but full-scale search missions are underway and no extra assistance is needed," he said.
Liu's remarks came after Zhang Shenglin, deputy secretary-general of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, offered to help with the search.
"China is willing to provide necessary assistance should Taiwan issue such a request, " Zhang said, who visited Taiwan last weekend upon learning of the fatal accidents.
As of late Thursday, 15 people had been confirmed dead and 23 remained missing, including 20 Chinese nationals.

Earlier that same day, upon returning from the highway where she and Chinese family members of the missing tourists observed the search work, Zhang visited two Chinese nationals who were rescued from the highway and who were being treated at National Taiwan University Hospital in Taipei.
On behalf of the Beijing authorities, Zhang expressed appreciation for the Taiwan government's swift rescue work and assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two arrested for smuggling sheep placenta
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 23:36:28 (By Claudia Liu and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) said Thursday that it had arrested two people suspected of smuggling 1,700 doses of sheep placenta into Taiwan.
The total market value of the doses is around NT$8 million (US$242,000), according to CGA official Chao Chi-tien.
One of the suspects, surnamed Chiu, was arrested while attempting to deliver 700 doses to Yeh. Both of them were arrested at the scene, Chao said.
Another 1,000 doses were seized at the cargo terminal at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport following the first arrest, Chao added.

"The profits are handsome," Chao said, adding that sheep placenta is believed to have anti-aging effects and can be sold in beauty clinics for up to NT$6,000 per dose, while the cost of buying it in South Korea and smuggling into Taiwan is less than NT$200 per dose.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan fine product fair opens in China's Shandong Province

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-Shandong culture week and fine Taiwanese product exhibition opened Thursday in Jinan, capital of China's Shandong Province.

Some 8,300 local and foreign buyers, including China's top 50 distributors, are expected to visit the major fair that is co-sponsored by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and the Shandong provincial government.

About 500 high-tech and traditional companies, as well as service and cultural innovation businesses from Taiwan, are displaying more than 20,000 items of high-quality goods at the fair, hoping to polish the image of "made-in-Taiwan" products among Chinese consumers.

Speaking to a capacity crowd at the opening ceremony, TAITRA Chairman Wang Chih- kang predicted a rosy picture for two-way Taiwan-Shandong trade and commerce, citing the complementary economies of the two sides.
"Bilateral cooperation will be as deep and broad as the sea, " he said.
Shandong Provincial Governor Jiang Daming also addressed the event, noting that two-way exchanges in personnel and activities are growing rapidly.
Shandong with a population of 95 million, has the second- highest retail sales level among China's provinces, autonomous regions and municipalities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ability to swim crucial for Taiwanese military: official

TEXT.P: Learning how to swim is a crucial aspect of Taiwanese soldiers' training, to help them meet the requirements of serving the country, a Taiwanese military official said Thursday.

"There is no doubt that we would require our soldiers to know how to swim so they are able to function better for the two most important aspects of the Republic of China's (Taiwan) armed forces: combat and disaster relief, " said Wang Shih-tu, Deputy Chief of Staff for Operation and Planning of the Ministry of National Defense (MND).

Speaking on the sidelines of a news conference about a national action plan to promote swimming, Wang said that a military force with around 40 percent of its soldiers who don't know how to swim "will not be able to do combat in Taiwan, where there are plenty of rivers, ponds and fish farms."
"Nor will they be able to execute disaster relief operations when most of the time they have to wade into the water to rescue people in need and protect themselves at the same time, " he said.

The last thing the MND wants to see is the loss of soldiers during disaster relief operations when the troopers are sent out to rescue people's lives, he said. "Fortunately, we haven't lost any up to now," Wang said.

The lieutenant general's remarks came hours after a legislator questioned the MND's five-year budget of NT$5.4 billion to build and renovate swimming pools in a legislative session on Thursday morning.

Taiwan's military had started to implement extensive swimming training since last May and the results have been fruitful, Wang said, adding that 62.4 percent of its troops have now met the requirement of 50-meter tests, up from 47.7 percent last May.

"We see it as a combat skill rather than only a recreational activity. And I'm glad the commander-in-chief of the armed forces -- President Ma Ying-jeou -- has recognized the importance of this crucial skill, "Wang said, referring to the president's assertiveness in promoting swimming.

DOC.HEADLINE: Naphtha cracker air pollution affects three counties: academic
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 21:40:15 (By Lee Hsien-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Toxic air pollution caused by Taiwan's sixth naphtha cracker complex in Mailiao Township, Yunlin County, has not just affected that county but has spread to the two counties further south at even higher density, an academic said Thursday.
The naphtha cracker complex was run by the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG).

Ozone from volatile organic compounds discharged from factories in the FPG petrochemical complex have been carried to the southern counties of Chiayi and Tainan, said Yen You-li, an associate professor with the Department of Safety, Health and Environmental Engineering of National United University in Miaoli County.

Quoting the results of a quantitative study conducted between 1994 and 2009, Yen said the ozone density monitored in Chiayi's Singang Township has been as high as 221 ppb, much higher than the allowable level of 120 ppb.

The ozone density monitored in Tainan city and county is also higher than that found in Yunlin County and its neighboring Changhua County, said Yen at a workshop sponsored by the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration on an assessment of the overall industrial examination of the FPG petrochemical complex.
Ozone can cause coughing and allergies, Yen said.

Meanwhile, the density of sulfur dioxide in the air at Yunlin County's Taisi Township has been found to be exceptionally high and complaints lodged by local residents have also increased noticeably since the petrochemical complex was built, Yen noted.
FPG said Thursday that it would not comment on the discussions at the workshop until the two-day session ended.

The Chiayi County government said it was paying close attention to the workshop and the discussions. If finances permit, the county government will launch a health risk assessment drive in the county, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of dengue fever cases rises sharply in Taipei County
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 21:46:56 (By Yang Su-jui and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Three more cases of indigenous dengue fever have been reported in Taipei County, bringing to nine the total number of cases recorded in the northern county within a week, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Thursday.
Among the cases reported this week, eight live in Wugu Township and one in Sanchong City, according to CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi.

Despite the sharp rise in the number of dengue fever cases in such a short time, Shih said he was not overly concerned about the outbreak, since the latest cases recorded were all related to latent infections that just happen to have been discovered at the same time.
The time between infection and the manifestation of symptoms can range from three to 14 days, but five to seven days is more usual, he said.
In addition, the county has only detected the Aedes albopictus mosquito, which is a less efficient vector of dengue fever than the Aedes aegypti that is prevalent in southern Taiwan, Shih said.

In southern Taiwan, an outbreak there has shown no signs of easing. A total of 230 cases had been reported in Tainan City as of Wednesday, during the height of the epidemic season, said Hu Shu-chen, head of the city's Health Bureau.
Around 200 soldiers were deployed around Tainan City Thursday to spray insecticide in a bid to eradicate adult mosquitoes and prevent further cases, Hu said.
Taiwan has recorded 834 indigenous dengue fever cases this year since August.

DOC.HEADLINE: Film official to be given merit for defending national dignity
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 22:02:38 (By Lee Ming-chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The head of the Taiwanese delegation to the 23rd Tokyo International Film Festival deserves recognition for the way he defended the country's national dignity in a name row with China at the event, Premier Wu Den-yih said Thursday.

The premier was referring to Chen Chih-kuan, director of the Department of Motion Pictures Affairs under the Government Information Office (GIO), who rejected his Chinese counterpart's rude demand that the Taiwanese delegation include "China" in its official name on the opening night of the film festival Oct. 23.

In the altercation, Chen told Jiang Ping, head of the Chinese delegation, that since Taiwan has always participated in the festival as "Taiwan, " there was no reason to deviate from the usual practice. He also advised Jiang not to mix arts with politics. The spat lasted over 90 minutes and cost both delegations the chance to join the star-studded Oscar-style "green carpet walk."
"Chen has set a good model for us with his `neither humble nor arrogant' manner in dealing with the incident, " Wu said at a weekly Cabinet meeting.
According to Wu, GIO Minister Johnny Chiang, Chen's direct boss, came up with a proposal to give Chen an official merit for his efforts to safeguard Taiwan's national dignity and interests.

As the 2010 Asian Games will open in China's Guangzhou City Nov. 12, Wu said he hopes China will be a good host and will show goodwill and sincerity by refraining from touching on any sensitive name issues at the event.
He also reminded the Sports Affairs Council to exercise caution and prudence in dealing with relevant issues.
"We should abide by Olympic Games regulations and safeguard our national dignity in a graceful, appropriate manner, " the premier said.

When asked whether Taiwan will seek a formal response from Beijing on the Tokyo incident, Chiang said only that the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) had already issued a statement the previous day on the issue.
The MAC statement expressed disappointment and regret over China's failure to apologize for Jiang's instigation of the name issue at the film festival.

"We hope the Chinese authorities will understand Taiwan's feelings about being isolated and denigrated in the international community.... Only if both sides show goodwill can hard-won cross-strait detente be maintained and bilateral relations move forward," the statement said.
Earlier that day, China's Taiwan Affairs Office spokesman Yang Yi said at a regular press briefing that the incident probably arose from a lack of communication between the two sides.

"This is something we do not wish to see, and we believe the matter will not affect future cross-strait collaboration or exchanges in filmmaking, " Yang said. He did not reprimand Jiang for igniting the row. DITEM/J

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholars warn against haste in Suhua Highway improvement project

TEXT.P: Work on a Suhua Highway improvement project should not be rushed under pressure from public opinion, scholars said after serious landslides on the road had claimed 15 lives and left 23 people missing as of Thursday.

The warning came after angry residents in the eastern county threatened to stage a rally in Taipei City Nov. 1 and the Hualien County Council went into indefinite recess in protest over the central government's long delay in improving the road linking Yilan and Hualien counties.
Lee Hong-yuan, a professor of the Department of Civil Engineering at National Taiwan University (NTU) , said policy makers should not react emotionally simply because of pressure from the public.
"We should pay closer attention to the issue of the Suhua Highway improvement project instead of hastening the government to start the improvement construction," Lee said.
His words were echoed by Hongey Chen, professor of the Department of Geosciences at NTU.
Chen said the government should spend more time investigating the unique geological structure of the region and the environmental impact of the project before construction takes place.
"If we do not take variables such as faultlines and groundwater into consideration, building tunnels on the Suhua Highway in haste could do more harm to the area," he said.
The Suhua improvement project calls for tunnels to be built to avoid some of the worst existing sections of the road.
An environmental impact assessment for the project remains under evaluation by a review committee, the last hurdle before the bidding process for contractors can begin.
During the intervening period, Chen went on, the government should clearly identify the most unstable sections of the highway.
Lee said that the government should also examine its ability to manage the highway after the reconstruction.
According to the National Police Agency, there were more casualties due to traffic accidents than to natural disasters between 2002 and 2007 on the highway.
Lee said that without careful planning, the situation will be even worse if car accidents happen inside the proposed tunnels.
Other scholars emphasized the importance of seeking long-term solutions for the people of Taiwan, who have to learn how to live with extreme weather and natural disasters.

Liu Shawchen, director of the Research Center for Environment Changes at Academia Sinica, said the public could take advantage of alternative transport rather than being caught in a radical yes-or-no situation regarding the road.
"If we can upgrade the current railway system and even ferry services, I believe there will be more possibilities for figuring out how to take care of the Suhua Highway problem," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Road protest plan unchanged: Hualien magistrate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 22:30:03 (By Andrew Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih is welcome to visit Hualien County, but the county's plan to stage a protest in Taipei to push for the upgrading of the Suhua Highway remains unchanged, Hualien Magistrate Fu Kun-chi said Thursday.
The premier is welcome to visit the eastern county to gain a better understanding of development there, which lags 40 years behind the rest of the country, Fu said.

He was responding to remarks by Wu, who called for Hualien residents earlier in the day not to make the arduous journey to Taipei in the current stormy weather, and said he will instead travel to Hualien to meet them and address their grievances.

Wu said he wanted to lead a delegation of officials to Hualien to meet residents there who are planning to lodge the protest in Taipei Nov. 1 demanding that the government accelerate the start of an upgrading project for the Suhua Highway -- the cliff-edge highway connecting Suao in Yilan with Hualien to the south that serves as the major route in and out of the area for the people and their produce.
He said the administration knows very well the aspirations of the Hualien residents for an improved highway, and the purpose of their planned protest.

The road improvement project, although environmentally and geologically challenging, is viable, Wu said, adding that construction can start as soon as the project has passed an environmental impact assessment.
According to the Hualien County government, more than 10,000 local residents will travel to Taipei Nov. 1 to stage a sit-in demanding an early start to the road improvement project.

Fu disclosed that the Hualien County government came under pressure when it applied for permission to hold the protest in Taipei, and said related central government units have tried to dissuade the Hualien officials from organizing the protest.
Meanwhile, Lai Kun-cheng, a legislator representing the eastern county of Taitung, said residents there have also started planning to join the protest.
Calls have been mounting for an early start to the improvement project in the wake of serious landslides caused by Typhoon Megi a week previously on the Suhua Highway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Southern Taiwan school receives donation from Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/28/10 22:35:33 (By Kuo Chu-chen and Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: An elementary School in Pingtung County has received a donation of NT$110,000 (US$3,585) from a Japanese school for a restoration fund, school officials said Thursday.

Representatives of Kobe Takatsuka Senior High School in Japan, including two teachers and three students visited the Linbian Elementary School in the southern county to make the donation during a graduation trip to Taiwan.

One of the teachers said the school's second grade teachers and students raised the money at the school and in the neighborhood after learning that some areas of Taiwan were damaged badly by Typhoon Morakot in August last year.
The school contacted the Pingtung County government, which suggested that the donation should go to Linbian Elementary School, which was flooded to a depth of two meters during the typhoon.
"A massive earthquake struck Kobe 15 years ago and the city's residents understand the pain suffered by the Taiwanese people during the disaster," one of the students said.
"The fund-raising campaign won great support in the city, " the student said at the donation ceremony.

Many of the Linbian students' parents became unemployed after the typhoon and approximately 200 students cannot afford their lunch and tuition fees. Therefore, the donation will be used to help those students, said the school's principal, Liu Wan-te.
At the end of ceremony, the teachers and students of the two schools also jointly planted a jasmine orange on the campus to commemorate the visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Intel to continue support for WiMAX in Taiwan: President

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou confirmed Thursday that chipmaker Intel will continue its support for Taiwan's development of wireless broadband technology WiMAX, after a meeting with Intel President and CEO Paul Otellini in Taipei.
Ma said the government has released six licenses for WiMAX operators and has invested US$220 million in developing related technologies and applications.
He said previous cooperative programs with chip company Qualcomm and mobile network equipment maker Ericsson can be role models for Intel to strengthen its long-term cooperation with Taiwan.

Otellini's visit has been highly anticipated in Taiwan after the company's closure of its WiMAX Program Office (WPO) in June sparked speculation that it was withdrawing support for WiMAX, in which Taiwan has made significant investments over the past two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 29, or the 22nd day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1618: Sir Walter Raleigh, English courtier, navigator, colonizer and writer, is beheaded in the Tower of London for treason against King James I at the age of 54. His literary works include poetry, memoirs, and a world history.
1863: Henri Dunant, Swiss philanthropist, founds the International Red Cross. He was a joint recipient of the 1901 Nobel Peace Prize.
1881: The first national political party is founded in Japan.
1911: Joseph Pulitzer, Hungarian-born American journalist and newspaper publisher, dies at the age of 64. He owned papers in St. Louis and New York City as well as established the Pulitzer Prize.
1923: The Republic of Turkey is proclaimed, with nationalist leader Kemal Ataturk as its first president.
1927: Russian archaeologist Peter Kozlov discovers the tomb of Genghis Khan in the Gobi Desert.
1929: "Black Tuesday" follows "Black Thursday" on Wall Street as the crisis of confidence hits the New York stock market, leading to the Great Depression of the 1930s.
1932: The Normandie, one of the three most luxurious ships ever built, is launched in France. The 300 meter-long vessel crossed the Atlantic Ocean in just over four days. A fire destroyed the ship while it was berthed in New York Harbor in 1942.
1942: Nazis massacre 16,000 Jews in Pinsk, Russia.
1944: In his capacity as supreme commander of the China Theater of War, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek appoints U.S. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China Theater of War. Meanwhile, U.S. Gen. Daniel L. Sultan is appointed commander in chief of the U.S. Expeditionary Forces in India.
1945: Anna Rosenberg is given the first U.S. Medal of Freedom ever awarded to a woman.
1953: The North American F-100 Super Sabre jet fighter sets a record by reaching a speed of 1,215 kilometers per hour, becoming the first jet capable of being operated at supersonic speeds.
1962: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry issues a statement refusing to recognize India's position of using the "McMahon Line" as the border line between India and China.
1964: Tanganyika unites with Zanzibar, forming Tanzania.
1974: A five-member Korean parliamentary mission headed by the chairman of the Korean Democratic Republican Party, Rhee Hyo Sang, and 130 members of the Japanese Diet, arrive in Taipei to take part in celebrations marking President Chiang Kai-shek's 87th birthday.
1977: Taiwan's first IC (integrated circuit) plant, under the Industrial Technology Research Institute, is inaugurated in Chutung in Hsinchu County.
1980: A declaration by Deng Xiaoping, vice chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, that Mao Zedong made serious political mistakes during his rule, is made public.
1981: The Chinese National Federation of Industries and the Chamber of Industry of Guatemala sign a cooperation agreement to promote economic, trade and cultural relations.
1984: The Chinese team from Taiwan wins second place in the World Amateur Baseball Championship in Cuba.
1985: The first prototype of "Ching Kuo," the first ROC-developed and manufactured indigenous defense fighter, bursts its nose-wheel during a test flight at Chingchuenkang Air Force Base in Taichung.
1986: The Ministry of Economic Affairs announces that ROC-U.S. trade talks on wine and tobacco imports are in a stalemate. Washington charged that Taipei failed to keep promises of providing greater market access for U.S. beer, wine and tobacco, and said the United States would draft retaliatory measures against the ROC under Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974.
1998: John Glenn, U.S. astronaut, blasts off aboard the space shuttle Discovery at the age of 77, 36 years after his first space mission.
1999: Carleton S. Fiorina, chief executive of Hewlett-Packard Co., the world's No. 2 computer maker, arrives in Taipei for a two-day whirlwind visit.
2000: Taiwan's China Airlines inaugurates a new flight route between Taipei, Penang in Malaysia, and Medan in Indonesia.
2000: A poll unveiled by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party shows that only 33.2 percent of the Taiwan public supports the Cabinet's decision to halt construction on the island's fourth nuclear power plant, while 47.5 percent oppose the decision.
2001: The Republic of China Ministry of Finance approves an application from Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp. -- the second-largest banking group in Japan and the world -- to upgrade its local representative office to a branch office.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "When a ruler regards his ministers as his hands and feet, they regard him as their belly and heart; when he regards them as dogs and horses, they regard him as a common citizen; when he regards them as dirt and grass, they regard him as a robber and enemy."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open marginally lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Friday from its previous close, moving down 5.66 points at 8,348.39 on a turnover of NT$4.203 billion (US$135.58 million).
The weighted price index rose 63.01 points, or 0.75 percent, to close at 8,354.05 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Liberty Times: Tiaoyutais and Taiwan's sovereignty

TEXT.P: According to National Security Council Secretary-General Hu Wei-jen, the cross- Taiwan Strait consensus of "one China, respective interpretations" applies in the territorial dispute over the Tiaoyutai Islands because Beijing states that the island group belongs to "China, " instead of saying that it belongs to "the People's Republic of China."

Over the past two years, the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou has been boasting of how the so-called "1992 consensus" has helped improve the situation across the Taiwan Strait. In fact, the Ma administration is using the illusionary "respective interpretations" to cheat the Taiwanese people into believing that it is working hard to "safeguard the Republic of China." Such trickery cannot withstand scrutiny in international settings.

Taiwan was granted observer status in the World Health Assembly under the name "Chinese Taipei, " but the Ma administration was nevertheless overjoyed. At the Tokyo International Film Festival, the Taiwanese delegation was suppressed by the Chinese delegation because it used the name "Taiwan" instead of "Taiwan, China, " or "Chinese Taipei." The Ma administration, however, put on a smiling face to try to placate Beijing over the spat.

The Tokyo incident was described by the Ma administration as an "isolated case, " although there have been numerous such "isolated cases" over the past two years. We can foresee that such "isolated incidents" will continue to occur. How much longer do the Taiwanese people have to put up with such deception? (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 29, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: AsusTek shares rally on better-than-expected earnings
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 11:28:41 (By Jeff Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of personal computer vendor AsusTek Computer Inc. made a strong showing in Friday morning trade after the company reported better-than-expected earnings for the first three quarters of this year, dealers said.
At 11: 10 a.m., AsusTek rose 2.46 percent to 249.50 with 3.11 million shares changing hands, while the benchmark weighted index fell 0.86 percent to 8,282.37.
AsusTek announced a day earlier that it posted NT$12.47 billion (US$406 million) in net profit for the first nine months of this year, with an earnings per share (EPS) of NT$19.88.
"The EPS is higher than the market consensus of about NT$15.00, " MasterLink Securities analyst Tom Tang said.
"Investors appear happy with the results. That's why the stock bucked the fall seen on the broader market," Tang said.
Tang said AsusTek is moving in the right direction by promoting its own brands in the global market after spinning off its manufacturing arm, Pegatron Technology Corp., earlier this year.
He said that as the PC production sector's gross margin has been squeezed badly amid fierce competition, the spinoff has been a way for the company to boost its bottom line.
According to AsusTek, its gross margin stood at 13.9 percent in the third quarter, up from 11.9 percent recorded in the second quarter.
"I expect AsusTek's EPS will hit NT$24.00 for 2010," Tang said.

The company said it ranked as the world's sixth-largest notebook computer vendor in the third quarter and that it expects to rise one notch to fifth in the fourth quarter and even grab the fourth-largest vendor position in 2011.
Tang said that while there is some room for AsusTek's share price to go up, investors had better stay alert to the prospect of strong technical resistance as the stock moves closer to NT$280.00.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Maintain perspective on salaries

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan was censured by the Control Yuan in September after the top executives of some government-affiliated corporate bodies were found to receive higher compensation than the country's president, who is paid NT$6.24 million per annum.

Examples cited by the Control Yuan included the presidents of the National Health Research Institutes (NHRI) and the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) , who get NT$8.41 million and NT$7.8 million, respectively. The Control Yuan members said these top executives should not receive higher salaries than the president or Cabinet ministers, because they have less to do.

According to economic theory, however, a person's salary should be determined by his or her contribution, or productivity. Those busy government officials do not necessarily have any productivity. They are probably busy dealing with such trivialities as cutting ribbons, giving addresses, attending weddings or funerals, and apple-polishing.

In Singapore, a minister receives approximately NT$40 million in annual compensation, which is 18 times the amount paid to a Taiwanese minister. Because of such excellent treatment for government employees, the Singaporean government is able to attract the best talent to its ranks.

Instead of seeking ways to raise the salaries for our ministers and thereby attract talent, the Control Yuan is now trying to slash the salaries for the top position-holders in the NHRI and ITRI, despite their potential contributions to the country. This is what is called completely misplacing priorities. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 29, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier to visit eastern Taiwan Oct. 31 over Suhua Highway issue
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 12:37:42 (By Justin Su and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yi said Friday that he will travel to eastern Taiwan Oct. 31 to brief residents there on the government's commitment to upgrading the accident- prone Suhua Highway, one of the region's major traffic arteries.

"I will visit Hualien and Taitung counties Sunday as part of my efforts to dissuade residents there from traveling to Taipei the following day to protest what they perceive as government procrastination in launching the highway upgrade project, " Wu said upon his arrival at the Legislative Yuan to attend an interpellation session.
According to Wu, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Lin Chung-shen had contacted Hualien Magistrate Fu Kun-chi and Taitung Magistrate Justin Huang to arrange his itinerary.
Wu said he will sincerely brief eastern Taiwan residents on the proposed Suhua Highway upgrade project in detail and answer their questions about relevant matters.
"If Fu still insists on leading Hualien residents to Taipei to lodge a protest, I will meet them at the Executive Yuan, too, " Wu added.
Wu said earlier that the highway upgrade project will be launched as soon as it has passed an environmental impact assessment.
The project has been in the works for many years, but due to opposition from activists over environmental and geological concerns, the project has remained on the drawing board.

The Hualien residents' protest plan came after deadly rockslides triggered by torrential rain Oct. 21-22 on the scenic route that snakes along a cliff overlooking the Pacific Ocean. The disaster left three dead and 23 others, including Chinese nationals, missing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Numerical designations of mayoral candidates decided

TEXT.P: Draws were held Friday to decide the numerical designations of the candidates running in the Nov. 27 mayoral elections for Taipei City and four other new special municipalities set to be created at the end of this year.
In the capital city, incumbent mayor Hau Lung-bin of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) got No. 2 and his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rival, Su Tseng-chang, received No. 5.
The three independent candidates running -- Wu Wu-ming, Hsiao Shu-hua and Wu Yen-cheng -- got No. 4, No. 3 and No. 1, respectively.
In Taipei County -- which will be renamed Xinbei City after it is upgraded to a special municipality -- the KMT's Eric Li-luan Chu received No. 1 and the DPP's Tsai Ing-wen got No. 2.
In Taichung, incumbent Mayor Jason Hu of the KMT got No. 2 and his DPP opponent Su Jia-chyuan was given No. 1.
In Tainan, the KMT's Kuo Tien-Tsai was No. 1 and the DPP's Lai Ching-te received No. 2.

In Kaohsiung, incumbent Mayor Chen Chu of the DPP was No. 3, the KMT's Huan Chao-shun got No. 2, and independent Yang Chiu-hsiung got No. 1. (By Johnson Sun, Wang Hung-kuo, Lee Hsi-chang, Chang Jung-hsiang, Wang Shwu-fen and Y.F. Low)

DOC.HEADLINE: Local company to acquire stake in German solar cell firm
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. (CNA) 10/29/10 13:55:06 (By Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Walsin Lihwa Corp., a Taiwan-based copper cable and specialty steel maker, said Thursday that it has signed an agreement to acquire a 49 percent stake in German solar cell firm Solarion AG.

Apart from the stake acquisition, Walsin Lihwa will also gain access to Solarion's patents in copper-indium-gallium-diselenide (CIGS) thin-film solar cell production technology through licensing, according to the agreement.
Based on the patent licensing, Walsin Lihwa will be able to independently produce and market CIGS-based solar energy products.
The investment will be carried out through Walsin Lihwa's wholly owned subsidiary, Ally Energy Ltd., the company said.

The total consideration of the transactions will be 60 million euros (NT$2.55 billion), while Walsin Lihwa is expected to receive 20 million euros as subsidies from the city government of Leipzig, where Solarion is located, under an incentive program to solicit foreign investment, the Taiwanese company said.
Solarion, founded in 2000, established the first pilot production line of flexible and highly efficient CIGS thin-film solar cells in Europe in 2002.
Walsin Lihwa said it will work with its German partner to engage in CIGS solar cell production and enter into development of the next- generation solar energy technologies.
In the first step, the two sides are planning to set up a solar cell plant in Leipzig with an annual capacity of 20 megawatts in the initial stage, increasing to 200 MW in the future.
Construction of the new plant is expected to be completed in 2011 and commercial production is scheduled to start in 2012, Walsin Lihwa said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Weapons are not key to cross-strait issue: AIT

TEXT.P: Continued engagement is the best guarantee for maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, the de facto U.S. ambassador in Taipei said Thursday in an exclusive interview with a local newspaper.
"Weapons are not the key" to cross-strait issues, said William Stanton, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), in the interview with the United Daily News (UDN).
On Taiwan-U.S. relations, Stanton confirmed that the two parties are discussing an extradition agreement, which he said might be signed next year.
As for Taiwan's inclusion in the U.S. visa waiver program (VWP) , Stanton said: "The truth is that we want you in."
Nevertheless, he admitted that the United States is now in a dilemma over the issue.
The following is an excerpt of the UDN report about the interview published Friday.
United Daily News:

Stanton reaffirmed that the U.S. welcomes cross-strait engagement. However, he added, as Taiwan is a democratic country, it is up to the people of Taiwan to decide the speed and direction of such engagement.

Noting that quite a few Taiwanese people remain wary about the cross-strait detente, evidenced by the results of a series of local opinion surveys, Stanton said it is an issue that Taiwan's current and future administrations have to address.
Asked whether the U.S. government will sell F-16 C/D jet fighters to Taiwan, Stanton said Washington and Taipei are divided over this aspect of U.S. arms sales to Taiwan.
In the safeguarding of national security, he said, military power is by no means the only defense.
Stanton said he doesn't think that any specific weapon system can be the golden key to solve an issue. No single weapon system can solely change the whole situation, he added.
On the timing for the signing of a bilateral extradition agreement, Stanton said his personal opinion is that it will take place next year.
He expressed hope that once the accord is struck, major Taiwanese fugitives with U.S citizenship or green cards will be included on a list of people subject to extradition.

Stanton revealed that the U.S. government has been working very hard in preparation for the signing of the extradition agreement and said that the Federal Investigation Bureau and the Drug Enforcement Administration, for instance, have been cooperating in drafting provisions of the accord.

He said that both Taiwan and the U.S. have done a great deal to make the treaty a reality, but noted that it is a very complicated issue. Besides differences in the legal systems on the two sides, extradition also involves some sensitive political issues, he added.

Stanton pointed out that the extradition agreement must be approved by each side's legislative branch. An existing bilateral judicial aid agreement was approved by Taiwan's Legislative Yuan, but has not been sent to the U.S. Congress for approval.
Touching on Taiwan's aspiration to be included in the U.S. visa waiver program, Stanton said it is not a political problem but a legal issue.

He said the U.S. is facing a dilemma in that while the U.S. truly intends to grant Taiwanese passport holders visa-waiver privileges, it also hopes Taiwan can live up to the conditions set forth by the program.
Noting that the VWP program has many requirements, Stanton said the major hindrance to Taiwan's inclusion is its failure to demand that its citizens apply in person for their passports.

Last year, only 2.2 percent of the U.S. visa applications filed by Taiwanese passport holders were rejected, far lower than the standard 3 percent required to become eligible for visa-waiver privileges, Stanton said.
The figure indicates that the visa rejection rate is not a hurdle to Taiwan's VWP inclusion, he added.

Citing media reports that human trafficking rings have smuggled Chinese citizens into the United States by falsifying or tampering with Taiwanese passports, Stanton said the problem is the absence of the requirement that Taiwanese citizens must apply for their passports in person.

With cross-strait exchanges continuing to expand and the number of Chinese tourist arrivals increasing significantly, the problem could become ever-more serious, to the point that U.S. immigration officers will routinely suspect incoming tourists with Taiwanese passports of hailing from China, Stanton said.
The large number of human trafficking cases has led U.S. officials to exercise more caution than usual in immigration interviews with Taiwanese passport holders, Stanton said.
Pointing out that it is normal around the world that people must apply in person for their passports, Stanton said he hopes Taiwan will adopt the practice soon. (Oct. 29, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT vows to secure party territories in year-end elections

TEXT.P: If the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) fails to retain its existing territory in the coming mayoral elections in five special municipalities in Taiwan, "it means the party has lost the battle, "the party's secretary-general said in a newspaper interview published Friday.
And if the party loses, he is the person who "should shoulder the whole responsibility, " King Pu-tsung said in the interview carried by the Chinese- language United Daily News (UDN).

The KMT now controls Taipei City and Taipei County which will be upgraded into a municipality after the Nov. 27 elections and renamed Xinbei City, as well as Taichung City and Taichung County, both of which will be integrated into a municipality following the elections.
King explained that in the upcoming elections, "both political and practical responsibilities fall on the shoulders of the party secretary-general."
"From start to finish, from nominating (candidates) to handling campaign affairs, it has been me who should be held accountable for defeat or victory, " King said.
This is because the position of the secretary-general of a political party is like that of a company CEO, who is responsible for the company's success or failure, he said.
He added the party's chairman, President Ma Ying-jeou, has not involved himself in campaign affairs for these elections.
King also said in the interview that the percentage of votes garnered for KMT candidates in the elections is less important than the number of mayorships the party wins.

King also criticized his opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) counterpart, Wu Nai-jen, accusing him of making inconsistent remarks about the political responsibility of DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, who is also the candidate for the mayorship of Xinbei City.
Wu said that if Tsai fails to win, she should step down, but said later that the chairmanship should be changed only if the DPP as a whole does not secure victory.
According to Wu, the DPP will need to take at least three cities before it can claim success.

Asked to comment on the issue, Tsai replied that "of course the more we win, the better." However, she did not clearly answer the question of whether or not she will step down if the DPP only gets two seats, saying only that "it is an option worthy of consideration, "the UDN reported.

The DPP currently controls Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County, Tainan City and Tainan County. Kaohsiung County will merge with Kaohsiung City while Tainan city and county will be integrated into a special municipality after the elections.
The municipal elections, considered a precursor for the 2012 presidential election, will take place in Taipei, Xinbei, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Mr. Candle' travels around Taiwan -- upside down
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 15:15:49 (By Sabine Cheng and Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: For the past few months, people might have spotted a man standing on his head taking photographs in places normally regarded as dangerous.

The man is Huang Ming-cheng, a renowned stuntman and a dancer with the Lafa Dance Company, who has been nicknamed "Mr.Candle" and who since March has been traveling around Taiwan taking more than 1,000 pictures from his unusual vantage point.
"I have dreamed about standing on my head and taking pictures since the age of 13," said Huang.
"I'd like to continue my project of standing upside down and taking photos all over the world," he told reporters Thursday.

The 27-year-old said he spent eight months working as a street entertainer to fund the project that began March 13 in Pingtung County, southern Taiwan and took him 20,000 km to spots all over the country.
He would take his photos at locations such as near cliffs, on rocks in the sea, on top of roofs, even on the back seat of a scooter. "You see things differently when standing on your head, " he said.

Sometimes the weather would be so bad that the wind would threaten to blow him into the sea, but the moment he would stand on his head to take the photos, the wind would drop and the mission would be accomplished, he said.
Huang has taken about 1,200 photographs in this way over the past 150 days.

He first came under the spotlight at the age of 13 when he won the first international prize from the Chinese Wuqiao Stunt Games, one of the world's four stunt events. He then studied stunts for stage and circus at National Taiwan College of Performing Arts.

He joined the Lafa Dance Company in 2008, an experience he described as a turning point in his life. He saw how choreographer/dancer Sheu Fang-yi and Bulareyaung Pagarlava live their art, and he also discovered the possibility of fulfilling his dreams.

Huang, who was scheduled to meet with his fans at the Xinyi Eslite bookstore in Taipei the following day, will present a circus drama in Pingtung Nov. 11-13 and in Taipei Dec. 9-12. The drama is inspired by what he experienced during his five-month journey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 0.80 percent

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 0.80 percent Friday on profit taking ahead of strong technical resistance at around the 8,400-point mark, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 66.96 points to 8,287.09, after moving between 8,278.72 and 8,348.39, on turnover of NT$106.59 billion (US$3.47 billion).

The market opened down 5.66 points and moved upward to reach the day's high before investors pocketed their recent strong gains, in particular posted by old economy stocks, until the end of the trading session, dealers said.
A total of 2,731 stocks closed down and 1,125 were up, with 280 remaining unchanged.

The plastics and chemicals sector suffered the heaviest losses, down 2.07 percent. Textiles fell 1.49 percent, cement stocks lost 0.93 percent, paper and pulp shares dropped 0.81 percent and financial issues closed down 0.68 percent.
The machinery and electronics sector lost 0.6 percent and the construction sector fell 0.38 percent, while foodstuffs closed up 0.13 percent.
"Investors seized falls in other regional markets as an excuse to cut holdings amid fears of a major pullback ahead of 8,400 points, " Concord Securities analyst Allen Lin said.
The markets in Tokyo, Hong Kong and Seoul witnessed losses in Friday morning trade.
"Investors have been watching closely to see how the U.S. Federal Reserve Board will adjust its monetary policy in an upcoming policy making meeting scheduled for Nov. 3," Lin said.
Lin said that after the local bourse staged a recent significant rebound, sentiment took a turn toward caution, so the latest downturn came as no surprise.
However, as the market remains awash in liquidity, the market is expected to see some short-term support at around 8,200 points even if the correction continues, Lin said.

In the non high-tech sector, Formosa Plastics fell 2.77 percent to NT$87.80 and Nan Ya Plastics shed 1.87 percent to end the day NT$68.20, while Shinkong Synthetic Fiber lost 2.82 percent to close at NT$15.50.

Personal computer vendor AsusTek bucked the downward trend on the broader market, closing up 2.05 percent at NT$248.50 after reporting better-than- expected earnings in the first three quarters of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: More excavators sent to Suhua landslide for search mission
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 17:40:33 (By Sunrise Huang, Lee Ming-chung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Three more excavators joined an operation at the 114.5-km mark of the Suhua Highway on Taiwan's eastern coast Friday to search for a group of Chinese tourists missing for over a week and feared dead beneath a landslide, a provisional rescue operation command center said that day.

The latest deployment brought to six the number of excavators working on a cliff slope that searchers believed could be where a tour bus carrying 23 people, including 19 Chinese tourists from Guangdong, might have been buried under rocks in a landslide that occurred during torrential rain brought by Typhoon Megi the previous week, the command center said.
Earlier in the day, Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah reiterated that the government has deployed a considerably high amount of manpower and equipment for the search mission.
"We will send out all we have, " Jiang said while answering reporters' questions regarding an offer from China to help with the search.
He noted that over 90 rescue personnel were working at the site that day. If weather permitting, a further two excavators will be deployed, he added.

"In an area no bigger than an elementary school playground, it is a big search group, with a massive scale of personnel and equipment, as well as four sniffer dogs," Jiang said. He added that there would be little point in making the group much larger.
The 19 tourists and their Chinese tour guide have been unaccounted for since the rockslide occurred Oct. 21-22.
A day earlier, body parts found in the water off Yilan County in northeastern Taiwan were confirmed as being the remains of a Chinese tourist in the Guangdong group, identified as Gong Yen.
A mourning hall was set up at Taipei Medical University Friday to allow members of Gong's family to mourn her death.

Aside from the Guangdong tourists, one Chinese tour guide and one Taiwanese driver on another tour bus that also went missing during the series of rockslides on the highway last week remained unaccounted for.

DOC.HEADLINE: Touch panel firm more than doubles listing price
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 18:18:15 (By Jeff Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of TPK Holding Co. Ltd., a China-based touch panel maker more than doubled its listing price Friday on the first day of trading on the Taiwan Stock Exchange amid optimism toward the company's earnings outlook, dealers said.

TPK, which was the second foreign company to make a primary listing on the local main board, closed at NT$505.00, up from the listing price of NT$220.00, with 9.66 million shares changing hands, while the benchmark weighted index fell 0.80 percent to 8,287.09.
TPK's production base is located in Xiamen, in China's Fujian Province, while its management team is largely from Taiwan, the company said.
It said touch panel technology applications are mainly used by handheld devices and in particular mobile phones and smartphones.
Both Nomura Securities and Barclays Capital called TPK, the world's largest capacitive touch panel maker, "the king of touch panel", praising its lead over its rival in production technology.
Nomura Securities said TPK will ride the waves of strong demand for smartphones and tablet computers to further boost its bottom line.
Barclay Capital expected the TPK will see its earnings per share grow 52 percent in 2010, 60 percent in 2011 and 17 percent in 2012, from NT$11.82 recorded in 2009.
The two brokerages have given a "buy" recommendation on TPK.
Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu agreed, saying TPK has secured large orders from Apple, HTC and Samsung Electronics and its earnings outlook appeared convincing to investors.
Hsu said TPK has been working with Apple, the company's largest customer, to develop capacitive touch panels and enjoyed patent protection which few of its rivals can match.
"TPK's production yield rate exceeds 90 percent, leaving its competitors far behind. It is not easy to challenge TPK's lead in technology," Hsu said.
Hsu said he expects TPK's EPS for 2010 will rise to NT$20 and the figure will rise further to NT$30.00-NT$31.00 in 2011.
"The NT$220 listing price is too low to reflect the company's fundamentals," Hsu said. "That's why the stock staged such a strong showing on its debut."
"There is some room for the stock to gain further," he added.
Hsu and Barclay Capital set a target price at NT$600 for the stock, while the target price of Nomura Securities was NT$520.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tycoon family's acquisition of Kbro conditionally approved
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 18:20:19 (By Hsieh Jiun-wei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission approved with conditions Friday the acquisition of Kbro Co., Taiwan's largest cable TV operator, by Daniel Tsai and his brother Richard, scions of one of Taiwan's richest families.

Granting the conditional approval, the commission said it does not oppose the Tsai family's acquisition of Kbro via the recently established Da-fu Media, but it noted that the buyout will be restricted by 13 conditions to assuage monopoly concerns.

Topping the list of strings attached is that Da-fu Media cannot hold or acquire, directly or indirectly, shares of any other cable TV companies or of Taiwan Mobile Co., which is also controlled by the Tsai family, without prior approval from the Fair Trade Commission.

Daniel Tsai, chairman of Fubon Financial Holding Co., and his brother, who is chairman of Taiwan Mobile, are buying Kbro from the Carlyle Group for a reported NT$65.3 billion (US$2.13 billion), which will make them the most influential cable TV group in Taiwan.

Da-fu Media was created to allow the Tsai family to get around a law banning public ownership of media groups. Since Da-fu Media does not have any government shareholders, it does not contravene the law, the National Communications Commission (NCC) , the official media regulator, said in September.

The Tsai brothers previously attempted to acquire Kbro through Taiwan Mobile, but the NCC blocked the deal because the Taipei city government holds a 15 percent stake in Taiwan Mobile's majority shareholder, Fubon Financial Holding Co., also controlled by the Tsai family.

According to Fair Trade Commission spokeswoman Shih Hui-fen, once the acquisition deal goes through, the number of households to which the Tsai family can provide cable TV will not exceed 33 percent of Taiwan's total cable subscribers, while the number of channels they own will not exceed 25 percent of the total number of available cable TV channels.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Fun in the UK' offers authentic British experience
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 19:23:31 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Planning to visit Britain but don't know where to find travel information? Try the "Fun in the UK" Chinese-language blog maintained by the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) in Taipei.

The blog, launched in March this year, features articles by BTCO Deputy Director Margaret Tongue and five other staff members, providing information on travel, shopping, food, culture and events in the United Kingdom to guarantee travelers an authentic British experience.

In a "British pub food guide, " for example, Tongue introduces readers to popular British food besides fish and chips and shepherd's pie. According to Tongue, sausage and mash as well as toad in the hole, a traditional dish consisting of sausages in Yorkshire pudding batter, are also common items on UK menus.
Tongue also recommends her favorite streets in London. On the historic market street of Lower Marsh, she writes, there is a knitting shop where people can sit and drink some beverages.

On Lamb's Conduit Street, a nurse's uniform used during World War I may be seen inside the shop window of a publishing house. Also, Tongue says her decision to come to Taiwan was made in a pub on that same street.
Meanwhile, Bonbon, a Taiwanese BTCO staff who is one of the bloggers, shares her experience during her five-year studies in London.
Bonbon says in those five years, she often joined her homestay family in watching EastEnders, a long-running TV soap opera that has been broadcast for 25 years.

The series is set in the fictional borough of Walford in the East End of London where many poor people and immigrants live. Because of the realistic depiction of local life, Bonbon says she once thought Walford actually existed.

She says watching the TV show helped deepen her understanding of British culture, lifestyle and the country's racial issue and allowed her to learn a lot of slangs that were taught in school. The blog has received very good responses from readers, who left messages saying that the information provided was both interesting and useful.
According to Christy Wang, head of BTCO's Communications Section, "Fun in UK" has seen more than 37,000 visitors since its launch, with the number of visitors now standing at around 9,000 per month.
Besides Chinese-language readers from Taiwan, the United Kingdom, Hong Kong and the United States, the blog has also attracted readers from 60 other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Friday, dropping NT$0.042 to close at NT$30.782.
Turnover totaled US$727 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of 30.824 and moved to a low of NT$30.551 before rebounding.
Dealers said the local currency sustained its upward momentum from recent days because foreign funds continued to flow into the local market.
They said the market also was anticipating that the U.S. Federal Reserve would loosen its monetary policy to boost the country's economy and further drag down the value of the greenback.
The selling in the U.S. dollar in the local market mainly came from foreign banks and exporters, dealers said.
The central bank again intervened later in the session to prevent too rapid of a rise in the value of the local currency, they added.

Thanks to central bank intervention, the Taiwan dollar has closed within a narrow range of NT$31.07 and NT$30.73 to the greenback since Oct. 11, when it first broke through the NT$31 barrier, despite rising to much higher levels during trading sessions.

DOC.HEADLINE: HTC expects Q4 sales to hit NT$100 billion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 20:19:52 (By Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Smartphone maker HTC Corp. predicted Friday that its sales in the final three months of the year would hit a record high of NT$100 billion (US$3.26 billion) on strong global demand and eclipse the record it set in the third quarter.
The company also anticipated that sales volume for the fourth quarter would rise to 9 million units, also a record high, from 6.8 million units recorded in the third quarter.

At a quarterly investors conference, HTC said third-quarter sales totaled NT$75.85 billion (US$2.47 billion), up 24.4 percent from the second quarter, and net profit rose 28.5 percent to NT$11.1 billion, yielding earnings per share of NT$13.61.

Monthly production capacity at its northern Taoyuan factory reached 3 million units at the end of the third quarter and was expected to rise to 4 million at the end of this year to meet demand, the company said.

Smartphones based on the Android operating system have become a hit in North America and experienced growing demand in Europe, the company added, and it expected that demand in Europe would act as a driving force in expanding the company's sales from 2011.

Investors also have high hopes that China will help HTC reap major benefits after the company, one of the world's five biggest smartphone makers, launched HTC branded handsets for the first time in July.

In the near-term, however, the company expected China's contribution to sales would be minimal, but in the long-term, it expected to gain from the fast- growing market, especially after establishing distribution partnerships earlier this year with three major Chinese telecom operators -- China Mobile, China Telecom and China Unicom.
In the July-September period, HTC's gross margin stood at 30.2 percent, and the company expects it will continue to maintain its gross margin at above 30 percent in the fourth quarter.

TLG Asset Management analyst Arch Shih expressed doubts, however, that the 30 percent gross margin could be sustained because accelerating price competition in the global smartphone market has eroded cell phone makers' bottom line.

DOC.HEADLINE: Online appeal for Suhua Freeway draws 16,000 endorsements
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 20:40:25 (By Andrew Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: More than 16,000 people have joined a Facebook campaign to support the building of a freeway in northeastern Taiwan to replace the existing Suhua Highway, Hualien County's main road link to Taipei and northern Taiwan.

The Facebook petition for a freeway, led by Huang Ting-ting, Huang Hsiao-jou and Nico Chen, had 16,000 endorsements as of noon Friday after being launched last week in response to accidents triggered by Typhoon Megi on Oct. 21.
The storm's torrential rains caused one tour bus to go missing and led to landslides that crushed at least two others, leaving three people confirmed dead and 23 yet to be accounted for.

Called "Give Hualien Residents a Safe Road Home, " the campaign urged the government to build a freeway in place of the 78-year-old highway, a narrow winding road perched above the Pacific Ocean, which the group said had left thousands of travelers dead and many others injured.

Taiwan's government has proposed upgrading the most dangerous stretch of the highway -- by reinforcing the existing road or bypassing it with tunnels and bridges -- rather than building a separate freeway.
But the online petitioners described the plan as unrealistic because it would still use the existing road.
They also expressed skepticism over a proposal by environmentalists to develop a "blue highway" in waters along the east coast.
With even naval vessels being battered there during inclement weather, who would dare board a private ferry navigating in those waters, one petitioner wrote.

In related news, Hualien County Magistrate Fu Kun-chi said Friday that if the Suhua Freeway project had been carried out immediately after being planned in 2003, it would have been ready for service by now.
The project was repeatedly delayed because of environmental concerns and ultimately failed to pass an environmental impact assessment.

Fu said that while the central government planned to upgrade the existing road, it had yet to set a timetable, prompting the county government to organize a protest Nov. 1 in Taipei to push for an early start to the renovation project.

Premier Wu Den-yih urged Hualien residents Thursday not to make the journey to Taipei in the current stormy weather, and said he will instead travel to Hualien to meet them and address their grievances.

DOC.HEADLINE: To leverage ECFA, Taiwan advised to 'de-politicize' relations

TEXT.P: The true benefit of a cross-Taiwan Strait trade pact was the momentum it provided for Taiwan and East Asian economies to move toward regional integration, scholars said at a symposium Friday, but they advised Taiwan to "de-politicize" its relations to take the next step forward.

"Taiwan can play a more effective role in the process of Asia-Pacific integration by taking the path of de-politicization, " said Daniel Rosen, adjunct associate professor of international and public affairs at Columbia University, at a forum titled "Beyond ECFA: Taiwan and Regional Integration in the Asia-Pacific."

The symposium, organized by Taiwan's Institute for National Policy Research, aimed to define Taiwan's future role following the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China in June to liberalize and institutionalize cross-strait trade ties.
Beijing's readiness to cease impeding Taiwan's links to other economies depends in part on Taiwan's willingness to de-politicize the significance of those external links, Rosen observed.
If the function of those links is to maximize Taiwan's prosperity, then Taiwan would be advised to sidestep Beijing's anxiety, the scholar said.

Rosen also urged Taiwan to empower private enterprises and serve as a bridge in Asia between East and West, grasping opportunities to deepen economic relations across the Pacific and with Europe at the same time.
The scholar did express some concerns over Taiwan's future course mainly because of its internal situation, which he said seemed to "get more politicized every year, and this is not good news."

John Ravenhill, a political scientist at Australian National University, argued that the ECFA would have at best a marginal impact on Taiwan's aggregate welfare but said it would be significant in other ways.
He believed the pact would affect the dynamics of negotiations on preferential trade agreements among the four large economies of Northeast Asia -- China, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan.
"The significance of ECFA may lie less in its contents -- or in its welfare effects -- than in the momentum it will provide for the negotiation of further agreements in the region, " Ravenhill said.
"But whether Beijing will permit Taiwan to participate independently in bilateral or region-wide negotiations remains to be seen," he added.
Cho Hui-wan, a professor at National Chung Hsing University, said Taiwan's government will face many challenges once the agreement takes hold.

Liberalization means promoting competition and the elimination of weaker sectors, which is why Taiwan should transform its economy from high-polluting industries to innovative and value-added industries, Cho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-Japanese PM to visit Taiwan to celebrate Songshan-Haneda flights
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 20:43:40 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng, Mike Chang, Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will come to Taiwan Sunday to attend celebrations marking the launch of direct flights between Taipei's Songshan Airport and Tokyo's Haneda Airport, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.

Abe, who served as the 57th prime minister of Japan between September 2006 and September 2007, is scheduled to arrive aboard the maiden flight between the two downtown airports, the ministry said in a press statement.

The flights are considered one of the biggest achievements in bilateral relations since Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou took office in 2008. In the past, the two airports mostly handled domestic flights. The two sides are also hoping to boost tourism. Currently, around 1 million Japanese people visit Taiwan each year. Taiwan is hoping to increase that figure.
Legislative Yuan sources said the previous day that Abe will meet with President Ma and Taiwan's other political heavyweights during his two-day visit.

According to the MOFA statement, scores of other Japanese politicians, including Naoki Inose, lieutenant governor of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government and parliamentarians of the ruling Democratic Party of Japan and the opposition Liberal Democratic Party, are also scheduled to fly to Taipei via maiden flights of various carriers serving the route.
The inauguration of the Songshan-Haneda flights is one of President Ma's major policy goals, the statement said.

The MOFA will co-host a cocktail reception with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) at noon next Monday to celebrate the event, with the participation of about 300 dignitaries and well-wishers from both countries.

In addition, the MOTC's Civil Aeronautics Administration will host a celebration ceremony at Songshan Airport on Oct. 31 while the Tourism Bureau will also stage a welcoming event at the airport the same day, according to the statement.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's representative office and the Japanese Interchange Association, a quasi-official organization authorized to handle Taiwan-Japan exchanges in the absence of diplomatic ties, will also co-organize a celebration party in Tokyo Monday evening, the statement added.

On Sunday, 12 Japanese citizens bearing the surnames "Matsuyama" (meaning Songshan in Chinese) and "Haneda" (meaning Yutien in Chinese) will travel to Taipei via the Taiwan-based China Airlines' (CAL) maiden Haneda-Songshan flight departing 7 a.m. for a one-day tour at the co-sponsorship of the Tourism Bureau and the carrier.

Besides attending the celebration party, they will also tour the National Palace Museum in suburban Taipei and sample Taiwanese delicacies before returning to Tokyo via a CAL flight scheduled to arrive at Haneda Airport at 9:55 p.m. that same day.
"The trip will allow the Japanese tourists to experience the convenience of one- day travel between the two cities," said a Tourism Bureau official.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-grown 'honey angel' orchids gaining favor in Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 21:09:13 (By Chu-chen Kuo and Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's dancing-lady orchids have long been favored by Japanese flower enthusiasts, but a new orchid variety called the "honey angel" is beginning to win the hearts of Japanese consumers and could be the next export star of local farmers.
Orchids account for 78 percent of Taiwan's total flower exports, and the dancing-lady orchid species, more formally known as "oncidium gower ramsey, " is the main variety grown for export.

About 21 million flowers of the species, or 90 percent of the exported shipments, are sent to Japan every year, according to Council of Agriculture (COA) figures, but the dancing lady may one day face a challenge for supremacy from a young, more romantic upstart.
Dancing-lady orchids, also known as dancing-doll orchids, are generally yellow with chestnut colored stripes and look like a girl in ruffled skirts.
The honey angel variety is also part of the oncidium genus but does not have the chestnut stripes and has a pure yellow color to the naked eye.

When seen under artificial light, however, it has a romantic fluorescent green aura, earning its nickname "honey angel," said Chen Wen-chin, director-general of the Taiwan-based Chinese Development Association of Oncidium Production and Marketing.
About 200,000 honey angels were exported to Japan last year, and Chen predicted the total will soar to 2 million next year.

He said Friday that he bought 1,000 potted "honey angels" from Japan five years ago when the variety was relatively unknown in Taiwan, and then started selling them to Japan during the winter at triple the price of the dancing-ladies.

Drawn by the high unit price, more Taiwanese farmers began raising "honey angels" and found the flower to be heat- and transportation- resistant and a perfect fit for Taiwan's warm and tropical weather, Chen said.
Once cut, the flower also can last for up to three weeks, a week longer than the "gower ramsey" variety, making it a favorite in Japan.

Chen said Pingtung County has become the center for honey angel growing because of its excellent climatic conditions during the winter and spring, when the flower is in especially short supply in Japan.

The COA also plans to promote the honey angel orchid in China by leading a promotional delegation of orchid farmers to several major Chinese cities, including Tianjin, Beijing and Shanghai, in December.
