DOC.HEADLINE: Acer to launch Windows tablets, online software store in November

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Acer Inc., the world's second-largest personal computer vendor, announced on Friday that it would launch a series of tablet computers running the Windows operating system next month to expand its mobile device offerings.

"We are going to launch the Windows tablet computers in November and Android tablet computers in the first quarter of 2011, " Acer Chairman J.T. Wang said at the company's quarterly investor conference held in Taipei.

Acer President and CEO Gianfranco Lanci predicted the company could achieve a 15 to 20 percent global market share in the tablet computer segment in 2011 based on Acer's current 18 percent share of the global notebook market.

The computer maker is hoping to cash in on the success of Apple's iPad in recreating a market for tablet computers. Dell, Samsung, RIM (Research in Motion) , and Hewlett-Packard have already introduced their own tablet models, but Acer is likely to become the first Taiwanese manufacturer to launch a device in the segment.
The company is scheduled to introduce its first line of tablet computers on Nov. 23. The new mobile devices will retail for between US$299 and US$699.

On the same day, Acer will also start open its online software "Next Generation Store, " which is aimed at attracting developers to the platform and cooperating with 10 to 20 telecom operators worldwide by the end of 2011.
Acer hoped the new initiatives would sustain the momentum created by its strong third quarter, when operating income set a record quarterly high of NT$5.28 billion, up 11 percent from a year earlier.

The company expected fourth-quarter sales to rise 5-10 percent quarter-on- quarter, and it projected that sales would grow another 10-15 percent and shipments would grow by 25-30 percent to 55 million desktop and notebook computers next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: More than 170 taxi stands to be set up in Taipei: MOTC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 21:40:40 ( By Wang Shu-fen and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: A total of 176 taxi stands will be set up in the greater Taipei area by the end of March next year in an effort to reduce carbon emissions and improve passenger safety, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Friday.
With the additional taxi stands, fewer taxis will have to cruise around the streets looking for passengers, and wasting gasoline while doing so.

The taxi stands will also be in well-lit areas with security cameras -- mainly in front of convenience stores -- which will improve safety for passengers, the MOTC said. Passengers can also ask for taxi service at the stores, it added.
The MOTC will ask the Taipei City and Taipei County governments to design signs for the taxi stands and help find suitable stores with 24-hour video surveillance and bright lights, it said.

Taipei city and county are the first to take part in the program, since they have the most taxi drivers, the MOTC said, adding that other cities and counties can also take part in the program if it proves effective.
In addition, the MOTC will also encourage taxi operators to add more taxi pickup points to reduce the taxi vacancy rate.
According to the MOTC, Taipei City currently has seven pickup points that can accommodate 189 taxis, with some having monitoring equipment and security staff.
As for Taipei County, it currently has seven service points with 24 parking spaces.
Taipei city and county have a total of 54,000 registered taxis, accounting for around 62 percent of the total number of taxis -- 88,000 -- in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier to look into alleged misconduct at airport
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 22:05:27 (By Kelven Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih vowed Friday to look into the alleged misconduct at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport after a lawmaker criticized the lax management at the nation's main gateway.

Legislator Lo Shu-lei of the ruling party Kuomintang said at a legislative question and answer session that when tropical storm Namtheun hit Taiwan Aug. 30-31, the airport was on alert, but the Central Control Center was having a party to celebrate the arrival of a new section chief.

In response, the premier said he has turned over related information from Lo to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) , which has jurisdiction over the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) . The CAA oversees operations at the airport.
The premier said that he has asked Transportation and Communications Minister Mao Chi-kuo to look into the alleged misconduct.
Mao has promised to get to the bottom of the matter within a week, and if the allegations are substantiated, personnel involved will be severely disciplined, according to the premier.
The premier said that after the poor maintenance of the airport came to light earlier in the year, the CAA head and the director of the airport were replaced.
If the Central Control Center were to show dereliction of duty, Wu said, he will not tolerate it and will ask for efficient supervision and improvement.
"Otherwise, we will not be able to face our people," he said.
Lo first revealed in July that airport personnel were partying with alcohol and food while on duty.
In the previous month, a jet bridge at the airports' newer second terminal collapsed.
The airport was also widely criticized for dilapidated facilities and lax management.
The government has formed a task force to address all the grievances, which also included poor and expensive food service.

DOC.HEADLINE: Win Air eyes cross-strait market for business aviation

TEXT.P: A luxury airline company invested by Hon Hai Precision's Chairman Terry Gou held launching ceremonies Friday for its new charter and aircraft management service, which it called the first of its kind in Taiwan.

Win Air, which relies on Gulfstream aircrafts, said it hopes to provide increased mobility for business executives worldwide, especially at a time when business between Taiwan and China is on the rise.
"Business aviation has long been mature industries in Europe and the U.S. Yet in Asia, these services are just taking off, " said Win Air President David Fei.
The company currently operates two U.S.-registered aircrafts and recently took delivery of a G550, which is the first business jet to receive Taiwanese registration.
Fei said the company hopes to increase its number of airplanes to 20 in five years.
The average fare of the charter flights, according to Fei, could range from US$7,000 to US$10,000 per hour.

Fei said that as Taiwan and China signed the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) earlier this year, Taiwan should also prepare to offer cross- strait business aviation services in the future, noting that this type of service will be in high demand.
But while Win Air has made money on its missions to the U.S. and European destinations, it is unclear whether it will make money from flights between Taiwan and China.

Taiwan's government has hopes that many Taiwanese business people currently living in China with their families can move their families back to Taiwan and fly to work in China in the morning and fly back home in the evening. But there is a large number of direct flights on regular commercial airlines launched between the two sides, and it is not clear if company executives would choose to fly the much more expensive chartered flights offered by Win Air.

According to the Cross-strait Air Transport Agreement signed in 2008, business aviation is limited to non-commercial business missions. In other words, rich people who have their own planes can fly between the two sides, but companies cannot try to make money from flying business executives back and forth.

So Win Air would not be able to make money from cross-strait flights for business executives unless further negotiations take place between the Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) to allow commercial business aviation.
The need to develop the business aviation industry in Taiwan, however, has been recognized by the authorities.
In September, there were 55 business flights taking off and landing at the Taipei International Airport, said the airport's deputy director Chen Jau-yuh.

As a proposed business aviation center is expected to start operations at the Taipei International Airport next year, Chen said that Win Air, TransAsia Airways and Sunrise Airlines have all shown interests.
"We hope that the bidding process can start by the end of the year," Chen said.
Gou's company Win Air says it believes eventually its cross-strait business will make up 40 percent of its total business.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan one win away from Intercontinental Cup title game

TEXT.P: Taiwan beat Italy 6-2 in the semifinal round of the 2010 Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament in Taichung City Friday night to move within one win of the competition's championship game.

The home team, which is now 3-1 in the semifinal round, will earn its chance at revenge against perennial powerhouse Cuba in the title game if it beats the Netherlands (2-2) Saturday at Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium.

Cuba clinched a berth in the championship game with a 4-1 win over Japan on Friday to stay undefeated at 4-0 in the six-team semifinal round. It handed Taiwan its only loss in the tournament with a 2-0 victory in the preliminary round.
The top two teams in the semifinal round will meet in the championship game while the third-place and fourth-place teams meet in the bronze medal game.

Powered by another solid performance at the plate and a dominant outing by starter Pan Wei-lun, who struck out eight Italian batters and yielded only five hits in seven innings, Taiwan jumped to a 5-2 lead after two innings and never looked back.
Though the home team committed three errors, it made up for the defensive lapses by outhitting Italy 11-7. It has had double-digit hits in all but one game in the tournament so far.
The Netherlands beat South Korea 3-1 to tie Italy (2-2) , which will meet Cuba Saturday. South Korea remained winless in the semifinal round while Japan was 1-3 after four games.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ang Lee's new 3D film 'Life of PI' to be shot in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 23:02:51 (By Amy Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: New York-based Oscar-winning film director Ang Lee announced in Taipei Friday that 70 percent of his new 3D movie "Life of PI" will be filmed in Taiwan.
"The filming of the fantasy adventure movie is scheduled to start at the Shuinan Airport in central Taiwan's Taichung City in January 2011," the Taiwan-born director said at a news conference.

Speaking at the same occasion, Government Information Office Minister Johnny Chiang said he was very pleased to see Lee return to Taiwan with a production crew to shoot a film after having worked abroad and achieved international fame for more than a decade.
"We hope Lee's new movie will help our film industry forge new links with the international community," Chiang said.
Lee said the idea of shooting the "Life of PI" in Taiwan came to him last year when he returned to attend the annual Golden Horse Film Festival.

"At first, I felt a bit uneasy because it will be an epic film with a grand scale and will involve three tricky elements -- water, children and animals. I was not sure then whether Taiwan would be an ideal place for location shooting," Lee said.
Much to his surprise, Lee said, 20th Century-Fox Film Corp. decided to have the film shot in Taiwan and India after an overall evaluation.
In the past few days, Lee and a 150-member production team searched Taiwan for suitable filming sites.
"All crew members have a good impression of Taiwan, which left me feeling flattered," Lee said.

The film will be a 3D version of the novel of the same name by Indian writer Yann Martel. It tells the story of 16-year-old Indian boy PI Patel's life story of adventure, survival and faith after a harrowing shipwreck on his way from India to Canada.
The boy drifted in the Pacific Ocean for 227 days before reaching Mexico.

As beaches in the Kenting National Park on the southern tip of Taiwan closely resemble Mexico coasts portrayed in the prize-winning novel, Lee said he will arrange for PI Patel to land at Kenting in the film.
The filming in Taiwan will take place from Jan. 3 to the end of May next year, Lee said, with the movie scheduled to be screened worldwide in December 2010.
A 17-year-old Indian youth has been selected to play the role of PI Patel.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mixed picture on cancer incidence near Formosa Plastics complex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 23:42:40 (By Lee Shien-feng, Chao Hsiao-huei and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Male residents aged 15-45 living in a Yunlin County township near Formosa Plastics' huge petrochemical complex were 1.7 times more likely than men in the same age group around Taiwan to come down with cancer, a scholar said Friday at a seminar.

But Hsu Hui-tsung, an assistant professor in China Medical University's Department of Health Risk Management, also found that women in Mailiao Township in the same age bracket did not show any higher prevalence of cancer than their peers in other parts of the country.

Speaking at a seminar organized by the Institute of Environment and Resources in Taipei, Hsu explained that he based his study on data in research reports and government statistics from 1996 to 2006 related to the health of people residing in townships surrounding the complex.
The naphtha cracker complex, covering the two townships of Mailiao and Taisi in the central Taiwan county, was inaugurated in 2001.

Hsu also found that compared with Mailiao, the cancer rate of all residents of Wujie Township in Yilan County in eastern Taiwan, which was originally designated as the site for the naphtha cracker complex in the 1990s, had not recorded with any significant changes in the years covered in the study.
The prevalence of cancer among men in the 15-45 age group in Wujie has even trended lower, Hsu noted.

He did not speculate, however, on why men but not women showed a higher cancer rate in the Mailiao area compared to the rest of Taiwan and acknowledged that it was still too early to say the growing cancer rate among men was caused by the Formosa Plastics complex.

At the same seminar, Formosa Plastics said it conducted a study that suggested that the air pollution from the complex did not have as big an impact on the health of local residents as critics claimed.

The company said it looked at the growth of lung cancer cases in the area since the complex opened because lung cancer was more related to air pollution than other forms of cancer, and found that there was a much lower increase than in other parts of the country.
According to the study, in the 10 years since the complex opened, the incidence of lung cancer rose 5.6 percent in the Mailiao area compared to 59.8 percent around the country.

The growth rate in Mailiao was even lower than the 22.7 percent rise in new lung cancer cases in Hualien County in eastern Taiwan, known for its eco-friendly tourism and lack of industrial development.
The seminar was attended by more than 20 experts and scholars who presented their studies and observations on the environmental impact of the petrochemical complex.

The Formosa Plastics facility has encountered a series of problems in recent months, including two major fires in July and two reports of foul odor leaking from the plant in September, which spawned public health concerns.
Conclusions drawn at the seminar will serve as a reference for the government to decide whether or not to give the plastics giant a green light to further expand the complex's production capacity.

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows to improve facility access for disabled persons
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/10 23:43:10 ( By Garfie Li and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou vowed Friday to help a 12-year-old wheelchair-bound girl make her dream come true by improving the country's barrier-free facilities.
Ma said he instructed Transportation Minister Mao Chi-kuo to improve railway facilities first so that disabled persons could lead more convenient lives.

Chen Wan-ping, who suffers from Nemaline Myopathy, a group of disorders that cause problems with the tone and contraction of skeletal muscles, expressed her aspiration in a letter to Ma written on July 30 before she received the 2010 Presidential Education Award.

"My biggest dream is that barrier-free facilities can be available everywhere in Taiwan, " Chen wrote in the letter, which she was not allowed to present to the president at the award ceremony but which later reached Ma.
Speaking at an anniversary celebration of a Taipei elementary school, Ma said he was deeply moved by her passion for life and "I made my promise and she has my word now."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese celebrity 'Da S' confirms engagement

TEXT.P: Barbie Hsu, better known as Da S, has confirmed her engagement to the son of a wealthy Chinese businessman, ending days of rumors about the couple's whirlwind romance.
The older of Taiwan's celebrity Hsu sisters described her happiness as she and partner Wang Xiaofei made the announcement Friday via micro-blog.
The two, who met less than three weeks ago in Beijing, are to be married in February next year, according to Da S's father.
Wang is reportedly worth NT$11.5 billion (US$376 million) through his involvement in a chain of restaurants owned by his father.
Younger sister, TV personality Dee Hsu, commonly known as Xiao S, could not confirm her sister's engagement when she took questions before a media engagement in Taipei Friday.
It was as the press conference was ending that the younger Hsu received news her sister had announced the engagement via the micro-blog.
"I can't believe it, I want to see (the blog)," said the younger sister.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's exports to China hit record high in first three quarters
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/30/10 00:13:01 (By Lin Hui-chun and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports to China hit a record high of US$85.38 billion in the first three quarters of 2010, according to government figures released on Friday.

Bill Cho, director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade, said total exports to China in the first nine months grew 45.6 percent year-on-year, and he expected exports for the full year to surpass the previous record of US$100.4 billion set in 2007.

China received 42.2 percent of Taiwan's outbound shipments in the January- September period, higher than the 41.1 percent recorded for the whole of 2009, keeping its place as Taiwan's biggest export market, Cho said.
China also remained Taiwan's second biggest source of imports and the country with which Taiwan had the biggest trade surplus in the first nine months of the year.
Meanwhile, export orders from China (including Hong Kong) for the July-September quarter of the year rose 10.4 percent compared to the same period in 2009, Cho noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 30, 2010, or the 23th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1735: John Adams, the second president of the United States, is born. He was one of the signatories to the Declaration of Independence, and he negotiated the end to the War of American Independence.
1910: Swiss philanthropist Henri Dunant dies at the age of 82. He founded the International Red Cross and shared the first Nobel Peace Prize with Frederic Passy of France in 1901.
1911: On the advice of the regent Prince Chun, Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, grants a constitution to combat growing support for the revolutionary forces of Dr. Sun Yat-sen.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party launches armed rebellions in Haifeng and Lufeng in Kwangtung Province.
1937: The National government decides to move the capital from Nanking to Chungking.
1952: The Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations is set up in Taipei following the first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference, which opened in Taipei on Oct. 22.
1953: Wu Ching-heng, former chairman of the Presidium of the Constituent Assembly, dies in Taipei at the age of 88.
1973: Tsengwen Dam and Reservoir, the largest in Taiwan, is completed and dedicated as a birthday present to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1973: Economic Minister Y. S. Sun leaves for Saigon to take part in the eighth Sino-Vietnamese Ministerial Conference on economic cooperation.
1974: Nobusuke Kishi, former Japanese prime minister, and Mitsujiro Ishii, former speaker of the House of Representatives, arrive in Taipei to join in birthday celebrations for President Chiang Kai-shek.
1974: The first F-5E Freedom jetfighter made in the Republic of China rolls off the assembly line.
1975: Ground for the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, named after the late president, is broken by Adm. Ni Yue-si, president of the ROC Amateur Athletic Federation, and Wang Yung-ching, the donor.
1975: Li Teng-hui, the ROC minister of state, leaves for Nakualofa at the head of an envoy to attend the 100th anniversary of the Constitution of the Kingdom of Tonga.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the establishment of National Chiang Kai-shek University in central Taiwan.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the code on gold trading and importation, to go into effect Nov. 1.
1986: The ROC-made "Sky Bow" and "Sky Sword" missiles are officially renamed the "Chung Cheng (Chiang Kai-shek) 100" series in a renaming ceremony presided over by Premier Yu Kuo-hwa.
1988: Rev. Sun Myung Moon, head of the Unification Church, presides over one of the biggest mass wedding ceremonies in history, held in Yongin, South Korea, where 6,516 couples tie the knot.
1990: Communist China announces the results of a nationwide census which shows its population totals 1.13 billion people.
1990: The Republic of China establishes trade and consular ties with Bolivia.
1995: Voters in the province of Quebec vote in favor of remaining part of Canada in a referendum.
1995 Fire breaks out on a subway train below the streets of Baku, capital of the Republic of Azerbaijan, killing 337 people and injuring at least 270 others.
1997: Mary McAleese, a Belfast lawyer, is elected President of Ireland.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the Republic of China has never forsaken its goal of promoting eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: The ROC's opposition parties declare Premier Chang Chun-hsiung "persona non grata" for his announcement of a major policy turnabout that they say was not only "illegal," but also "sacrificed the public interest."
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen signs a memorandum on military cooperation with his Macedonian counterpart Ljuben Paunoski in Taipei.
2001: Microsoft Taiwan formally launches the new Microsoft Windows XP operating system at the Taipei International Convention Center, with thousands registered to try out the system.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "There never was a man trained to benevolence who neglected his parents. There never was a man trained to righteousness who made his ruler an after-consideration."

DOC.HEADLINE: More than Matsu enshrined at new temple in Changhua industrial park

TEXT.P: At first glance, there is little to distinguish the Changhua Coastal Industrial Park from Taiwan's other manufacturing complexes. Towering power-generating windmill turbines hover nearby, but the spaciousness of the 3,650-hectare industrial park -- Taiwan's biggest -- seems to dwarf everything else, including the factories that dot the wind-swept landscape.

The park, however, has one relatively small oddity that could soon turn into its most important landmark. A new temple devoted to Matsu, the widely worshipped Goddess of the Sea, is currently under construction there, and the building's structural frame has already been erected.
The western coast of central Taiwan is peppered with Matsu temples, so the addition of one more in the Changhua industrial park should in itself barely cause a stir.
This one, though, is unique, the only Matsu temple among hundreds in Taiwan built almost completely of glass.

Beyond that, however, it is intended to become a symbol of the resilience and creativity of the country's glass industry, which had been eroded and nearly driven out of Taiwan by cheap Chinese competition.
"It will not just simply be a temple," declared Jackson Lin, the CEO of Taiwan Mirror Glass Enterprise Co. (TMG) , the company that designed the glass temple and has been working on it since 2007.
If the temple aspires to become a shrine to the local glass industry, Lin could be seen as its unofficial deity.

Nicknamed "big brother" in Taiwan's glass sector out of respect for his accomplishments in preserving the industry's presence on the island, Lin was the driving force behind the creation of a glass cluster in the Changhua Coastal Industrial Park, which now has annual sales of more than NT$20 billion (US$652.5 million).

Lin's vision originated in 1998, when he received an order from IKEA that was too big for him to handle. Instead of expanding his own factory's capacity, he mobilized dozens of glass makers and other related wooden furniture and metal component manufacturers to band together and supply IKEA and other clients.
"If individual factories expand production to absorb rising orders, they face the risk of having to maintain idle production lines once overall output surpasses demand," Lin said.

Though motivated as much by minimizing risk as by rescuing Taiwan's glass industry, Lin's "cluster strategy" successfully kept many local producers at home at a time when cost pressures had them thinking of moving offshore.
To further promote the glass grouping, Lin also established a glass gallery in 2006 to serve as a marketing platform for between 140 and 150 local artists and glass businesses around Taiwan.
"My boss wanted to have a place where domestic and foreign buyers could see all of Taiwan's glass brands and glass art creations in one trip," said Lin's secretary Paggy Shih.
And how does the glass temple fit in to the gallery?
"You could call the gallery a data bank of information on the glass industry, and the temple its concrete manifestation, " Shih said.

The new temple, called "Hu Sheng, " will provide a place where people can worship Matsu as well as two other important local deities -- Wangye and the Land God -- but it also will showcase Taiwan's glass industry.

The 1,000 square-meter glass temple, a copy of the historic Tianhou Temple in Changhua County's Lugang Township being built at a cost of NT$70 million, will consist of 70,000 pieces of glass from 132 glass makers and other related manufacturers around the country, according to Lin.

All of the temple's furnishings and ornaments, including the shrine and statues of the deities, are made of glass, Lin said, a testament to the variety of glass-processing techniques and glass art at which Taiwan excels. Only its steel frame is being made of something other than the silica-based material.
Among its special features is an inner wall shaped like Jade Mountain -- Taiwan's highest mountain also known as Yushan - that is composed of 1,400 hand- crafted pieces of green glass.
The temple's transparent walls also mean that when the sunlight slants through the shrine, it will be bathed in colorful rays, Lin said.
But perhaps the most enduring trait of the reproduction of one of Taiwan's oldest temples may be how it embraces 21st century environmental principles.
Its roof will be made of "miracle glass," an innovation conceived by Young Chin- huai, an associate professor at National Taiwan University of Science and Technology and an expert in green materials.

Named heat-insulation solar glass, this state-of-the-art material can deflect harmful ultraviolet rays, transform heat into electricity, and can clean itself. It will generate enough electricity to power the temple's lighting devices, Shih said.

Other glass materials simulating common worshipping practices have also been designed for the temple project to minimize pollution. LED lights, for example, have been installed in glass incense and paper money to recreate the common practice of making offerings to the gods.

"The advantages are that these processes don't require cutting down trees or pollute the air, " Shih said. "Visitors to the glass temple will also be able to take the incense home with them as a souvenir."

Lin's temple complex is expected to be completed in 2013, and he is proud of the many values it represents - sharing, working together, keeping the glass industry's roots in Taiwan, and preserving the environment.
"Being able to share candles with others will naturally bring honor to oneself," the glass industry's "big brother" said. By CNA staff writer Elizabeth Hsu CNA photo 8,9

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Apple Daily: All reforms stop at time of election

TEXT.P: Political parties in Taiwan often need to gain the favor of specific groups such as the elderly, ward chiefs, civil servants, farmers and fishermen in order to win in elections. This is especially true with the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , which owns huge assets that allow it to spend big in elections.

The problem is once the party gives something good to a group, it has to keep doing so or it will face the threat of the group switching its support to the green camp. As a result, many reforms are grounded to a halt around the time of elections.

An example is a plan by the Examination Yuan to eliminate poor performing civil servants, which would require that 3 percent of government employees be given a "C" rating in a single year, with those receiving a "C" for three years to be dismissed. After the plan drew a strong backlash from civil servants, the KMT government dropped the ratio from 3 percent to 1 percent. This minimum ratio was removed altogether when the plan was finalized and unveiled recently.
In addition, some KMT legislators have suggested that civil servants be given one or two days of "blind date leave" every year to encourage them to get married.

The government may win the favor of a small minority of voters with such practices, but it will lose the respect of the majority. This also highlights the government's non-credibility, cowardice and incompetence. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 30, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese official urges continued search of tourists
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/30/10 13:26:36 (By Chiu Chun-chin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A Chinese official urged Taiwan Saturday to continue its search for a group of mainland tourists who went missing in eastern Taiwan during Typhoon Megi last week.

"Even if there is only a shred of hope, we hope 100 percent of efforts can be given (to the rescue operation) , " said Zhang Shenglin, deputy secretary- general of Beijing's semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, upon her departure from Taiwan to return to China.
Zhang had arrived in Taiwan three days earlier to assess the progress in the search for the missing tourists.

Nineteen Chinese tourists and their Chinese tour guide who were traveling on the Suhua Highway were reported missing immediately after landslides caused a section of the highway to collapse on Oct. 21 due to heavy rain triggered by the typhoon.
One of them was confirmed dead Thursday, after her body part was recovered from the waters off the coast of northeastern Taiwan and her identity determined through DNA tests.
Zhang said she was very thankful that Taiwanese authorities had sent additional forces to join the search operation at the request of the families of the missing tourists.
She said after her departure, officials of China's Cross-Strait Tourism Association will continue to stay in Taiwan to provide necessary assistance to the families.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Close combat as elections approach

TEXT.P: Draws were held Friday to decide the numerical designations of the candidates running in the Nov. 27 mayoral elections for Taipei City and four other new and expanded special municipalities set to be created at the end of this year, sparking hand-to-hand competition.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of campaigns amid the approach of the municipal elections -- the precursor of the 2012 presidential elections:
United Daily News:

The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) is going all out to defend its rule over the capital city, with a plan to mobilize 100,000 supporters to gather on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office on the last Sunday before the mayoral election in Taipei City. "It's a Saving Private Hau battle, " KMT members said, as Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin is struggling in defeat Su Tseng- chang of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in a bid for reelection.

The DPP camp described the KMT's plan of holding a public parade from the Taipei City Hall to Ketagalan on Nov. 21 as a display of the party's lack of self- confidence in winning the election and its inner anxiety.
Su said he will organize several campaign activities and visit local markets to solicit supporters.
Hau picked the No. 2 in the Friday draw, while Su got No. 5. (Oct. 30, 2010).
China Times:
The draw in the central Taiwan city of Taichung was completed in chaos and arguments, with incumbent Mayor Jason Hu of the KMT getting the No. 2 and his DPP opponent Su Jia-chyuan picking No. 1.

For the event, Hu disguised himself as the Chilean miner Luis Urzua, who led his fellow miners to survive when the group of 36 miners were trapped underground for more than two months. Hu chanted a slogan that he will "lead Taichung to walk into the light, letting the world see Taiwan."
But the show drew Su Jia-chyuan's criticism, who described Hu as a "better actor than mayor."

During the draw procedure, Su Jia-chyuan's wife Hung Heng-chu had cast doubt on the size of lots, fearing they might have been changed for Hu to get the best number "1." The dispute was then resolved after Hu asked a city election commission staff to draw the lot for him. (Oct. 30, 2010).
Liberty Times:

Candidates running in the upcoming elections in the five special municipalities began battles at close quarters following the draws on Friday. Facing increasing competition from the DPP, the KMT is using all-out efforts to secure its grassroots supporters.

As the countdown began, both the KMT and DPP camps were observed ready to throw campaign activities to not just promote their candidates but also demonstrate their determination to win more than half of the seats in the city council of each of the five municipalities, which are Taipei City, Xinbei City (the upgraded Taipei County) , Taichung City (the integration of Taichung city and county), Tainan City (the integration of Tainan city and county) and Kaohsiung City (a merger with Kaohsiung County.)

According to the KMT's self-assessment and that by the DPP in the mayoral elections in the five municipalities, the opposition is leading in the two southern Taiwan cities of Tainan and Kaohsiung, while the DPP candidates in Taichung in central Taiwan are catching up to the KMT frontrunner.
In the capital and Xinbei in northern Taiwan, the KMT and DPP candidates are meanwhile in a tug-of-war. (Oct. 30, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei-Tokyo direct flights said to boost property market

TEXT.P: The launch of direct flights between airports in the downtowns of Taipei and Tokyo slated for Sunday is expected to boost the property market in two areas near the Taipei airport, according to real estate agents.

Taipei's Songshan Airport will see its first direct flight carrying 90 passengers -- including former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe -- from Tokyo's Haneda Airport on Sunday for the launch celebrations in Taipei.

Property prices in the Songshan and Neihu districts near the Songshan Airport have already seen price rises since direct flights were launched between Taipei and Shanghai in June. With the new Taipei-Tokyo flights, property values in the areas are expected to increase further, market analysts said.

A local real estate agency said that the residential and commercial properties in the two districts saw bigger value increases in September than other districts in Taipei after the airport opened to direct flights from Shanghai in June.

"Since June, the transactions in the housing market and the business office market in the Songshan district rose 6.05 percent and 4.49 percent, respectively, last month, compared to those in May, " Bright Lee, a spokesman for Evertrust Rehouse Co., said Thursday.
The residential property market and the commercial market in the Neihu district meanwhile grew 0.68 percent and 6.91 percent, respectively, in September, from May, he noted.
"The growths (in both districts) were higher than those in the rest of Taipei," Lee said.

He expressed confidence that the upcoming launch of the Taipei-Tokyo direct flights will serve as another boost to demand in the two districts. This prediction came despite the central bank launching a series of tightening measures since June on bank lending, to control soaring housing prices in Taipei. The skyrocketing prices have raised complaints and fears that many local residents are unable to buy homes.
The average housing prices in Taipei fell 6.87 percent in September from May due to the central bank's measures, according to Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese-American Jeremy Lin makes NBA debut

TEXT.P: Jeremy Lin, the first person of Taiwanese descent to make the roster of a National Basketball Association (NBA) team, made his regular season debut with the Golden State Warriors Saturday Taiwan time.

The 22-year-old point guard -- the first Harvard graduate to play in the NBA in 57 years -- received a standing ovation when he entered the game with 2: 32 left and the Warriors well out in front of the Los Angeles Clippers on their way to a 109-91 home victory.

Lin did not attempt a field goal or dish out an assist in his limited appearance, but he did register a steal, taking the ball away from Clippers backup center Brian Cook with 47.1 seconds left to play.
The Warriors turned the close game into a rout with a 32-13 third quarter and led by as many as 20 points in the final period, giving Lin a chance to get game experience.

The 1.90-meter player, who did not play in the Warriors' 132-128 season-opening win over the Houston Rockets, was kept on the team's roster to provide depth at point guard behind starter Stephen Curry.

Lin is behind both Curry and Charlie Bell on the team's depth chart at the position, but when Curry suffered an ankle injury during the game, neither Bell nor Lin replaced him. A group of small forwards filled in instead.
Lin, who grew up in nearby Palo Alto, California, was not selected in the NBA Draft in June but was signed by the Warriors to a two-year contract after his strong performance in the summer league.
His parents emigrated to the United States from Taiwan in the 1970s.

Lin has already become a celebrity in Taiwan, a status cemented during a trip to Taipei in late July for a charity game featuring NBA players. The July charity game was organized by Chinese All-Star center Yao Ming, who plays for the Houston Rockets.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Taiwan-U.S. extradition agreement

TEXT.P: In a recent interview with the United Daily News, William Stanton, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , said a U.S.-Taiwan extradition agreement might be signed next year.
He also said the United States hoped to include Taiwan in its visa-waiver program and that bilateral talks under the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement would be resumed in December.

This seemed to be the first time that a "timetable" has emerged with regard to the signing of an extradition agreement, an issue that was delayed by the United States because of possible opposition from China. With relations improving and judicial cooperation increasing across the Taiwan Strait, it is reasonable that the United States takes advantage of the opportunity to promote the agreement with Taiwan.
Also in the interview, Stanton proposed that Taiwan seek to strengthen its capacity to conduct non-military engagement with neighboring countries.
This is a goal that Taiwan must work hard to achieve and also an area where the United States can provide Taiwan with the greatest help. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 30, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan makes Asian Games baseball roster changes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/30/10 16:00:10 (Uni-President Lions), Lin Kun-sheng (National Preparatory Team) (Seattle Mariners), Chang Chien-ming (Sinon Bulls) (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan made two minor adjustments to its 24-man roster for the Asian Games baseball tournament in November, replacing two players who perform professionally in Japan.

Right-handed pitcher Lo Chin-lung and infielder Kuo Yen-wen were added to the roster to replace Seibu Lions pitcher Hsu Ming-chieh and Nippon-Ham outfielder Yang Tai-kang, according to national team manager Yeh Chih-hsien in Taichung City, where Taiwan is currently competing in the 2010 Intercontinental Cup.

Lo, who plays for the Triple-A team of the Colorado Rockies, was added because of his stellar play in the Intercontinental Cup, Yeh said. Yang withdrew from the team because of an elbow injury sustained during the Japanese professional baseball season.
Taiwan, which won the baseball gold medal at the 2006 Asian Games in Doha, Qatar, was left with only three outfielders following the roster changes.
But Yeh said he was more concerned with the infield defense and believed that several players on the team could double as outfielders.

Taiwan will not field any players currently active at the Major League level in the United States, but eight members of the team play in the minor leagues, and one (Kuo Yen-wen) played in the Cincinnati Reds' organization before being released recently.
The Asian Games will take place in Guangzhou, China, Nov. 12-27. The baseball competition is scheduled for Nov. 13-19.
The complete 24-man roster (with team affiliation in parentheses) after the changes is as follows:

Pitchers (10) : Cheng Hung-wen (Chicago Cubs) , Yang Yao-shun (Softbank Hawks) , Huang Chih-lung (Yomiuri Giants) , Lin Yi-hao (Yomiuri Giants) , Lo Chin-lung (Colorado Rockies) , Hsiao Yi-chieh (Hanshin Tigers), Yang Chien-fu (Sinon Bulls), Lin Ying-chieh (Sinon Bulls), Pan Wei-lun (Uni-President Lions), Chen Kuan-yu (Taiwan Beer)
Catchers (3): Chen Chun-shiou (Cleveland Indians), Kao Chih-kang

Infielders (8) : Hu Chin-lung (LA Dodgers) , Chen Yung-chi (Pittsburgh Pirates), Lee Pin-yen (Softbank Hawks) , Peng Cheng-min (Brother Elephants) , Lin Yi-chuan (Sinon Bulls) , Chang Tai-shan (Sinon Bulls), Lin Chih-sheng (La New Bears), Kuo Yen-wen (formerly Cincinnati Reds)
Outfielders (3): Lin Che-hsuan (Boston Red Sox), Lo Kuo-hui

DOC.HEADLINE: Opening to Chinese students helpful to cross-strait ties: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/30/10 16:22:35 (By Wang Hung-kuo and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that the government's policy to open Taiwanese universities to Chinese students would be helpful to the long-term relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Under this liberalization policy, the first group of students enrolling in postgraduate programs are expected to arrive next spring, and those enrolling in undergraduate programs are expected in the fall, Ma said while addressing National Taipei University's anniversary celebration.

"Allowing young people from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to become friends during the early stages of life will help them develop a cooperative and competitive relationship, and allow them to think and learn how to resolve problems through peaceful means," Ma said.

Also, the government will encourage local universities to recruit more international students, in the hope that the ratio of international students will increase from 1.5 percent to 2.5 percent of all enrolled students within the next two years, he said.
The president, meanwhile, reaffirmed his goal of gradually raising the country's education spending from 4.4 percent of gross domestic product to 6 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pink carnival for breast cancer survivors draws strong response

TEXT.P: A "pink carnival" held Saturday to raise breast cancer awareness drew a strong turnout and raised money to support breast cancer education among younger women, who are increasingly at risk of suffering from the disease.

A total of 1,552 breast cancer survivors from 35 different charities attended the carnival, and a special mammography car on-site was kept busy during the day, according to Lin Wei-chieh, the secretary-general of the Taiwan Breast Cancer Alliance (TBCA) , the event's organizer.

"The response was sensational, " said Lin, carrying a pink backpack and holding a pink umbrella in the rain. She said 40 people had signed up to have a mammography done on-site just two hours into the event at Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall.

Sixty-nine booths selling merchandise such as pink brooches, cupcakes with pink ribbon icing, and even pink bras were busy trying to raise money to support the TCBA's efforts to raise awareness of the disease, especially among younger women.
Lin said women in Taiwan were being stricken with the disease at a younger age than women in other parts of the world and needed to pay attention to it earlier than in the past.

According to Lin, the peak ages at which Taiwanese women get breast cancer are 45 and 55, 10 years younger than women in the West, and one in 10 local breast cancer patients are under 40 years of age.
Lin said her group reminds women 45 years and older to receive government-funded mammograms each year and urges women above 35 to sign up for breast ultrasounds to keep the disease at bay.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan group wins big at Singapore music awards
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/30/10 18:55:31 (By Tang Pei-chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan pop trio S.H.E. emerged as the biggest winner at the Singapore Hit Awards 2010 presented Friday.

The group took home a total of five awards: Most Popular Group/Band, Best Group, Asia Media Award (Group), Y.E.S. 93.3 FM Pick of the Pops: Song of the Year, and Y.E.S. 93.3 FM Pick of the Pops: Artiste with Most Chart Hits.
The outstanding performance aside, the condition of S.H.E. member Selina, who sustained severe burns in a filming accident last week in Shanghai, remained the focus of media attention.

According to Hebe, the only S.H.E. member who attended the presentation ceremony, Selina is still receiving treatment in an isolated ward after she was sent back to Taiwan and needs to rely on painkillers to relieve her pain.
Another major winner at this year's event was Sodagreen, another band from Taiwan, which captured three awards: Best Composing Artiste, Best Band, and Asia Media Award (Band).

Other Taiwanese singers who were honored included Jay Chou, who won the Album of the Year award for "The ERA" and the Asia Media Award (Male Artiste) , and A-Mei, who garnered the Outstanding Regional Artiste (Taiwan) award.
Tiger Huang was crowned Best Female Vocalist, Show Luo the Most Popular Artiste, and Rainie Yang the Most Popular Female Artiste. Jeff Chang was given the Honorary Award.
The Most Acclaimed Male Artiste award went to Alien Huang, and the Most Acclaimed Female Artiste award was seized by Jing Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Family day to be held to promote safe medication

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Food and Drug Administration (TFDA) will hold a family day Sunday that will give people a chance to expand their knowledge on safe medication and enjoy a series of fun activities at Taipei Water Park.

Liu Shu-fen, the head of the TFDA's Consumer Protection Center, invited the public to join Premier Wu Den-yih and other officials Sunday morning at 9: 30 to celebrate the success of a six-month old Executive Yuan task force in seizing fake, counterfeit and inferior drugs.

Because of the task force, 4.1 times as many fake or substandard drugs have been removed from the market in the first nine months of 2010 compared to all of 2009, Liu said, but she indicated that local residents cannot rely on the group alone to battle fake drugs, which are rampant on the market.
"We urge the public to care more about the medication habits of the elderly at home to ensure their well-being, because they have a higher chance of drug misuse and misinformation," she said.
Victims of drug misuse will speak to the audience about their personal experiences, and they will urged people not to fall victim to drugs of unknown origin, Liu said.
Participants who complete all the activities at the event are eligible for a lucky draw that will feature prizes like bicycles and Wii Fit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan school boy shows creativity at invention show in Germany
DOC.DATELINE: Nuremberg, Germany, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/30/10 19:21:34 (By Lin Yu-li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Eight-year-old Yeh Chi-chang, the youngest inventor ever to represent Taiwan at an annual invention show in Nuremberg, has made a splash with his innovative pants designed to prevent the user from drowning.

"I got the idea after seeing people on television drown while swimming at sea, " said the Kaohsiung American School student at the venue of the four-day 2010 International Trade Fair for Ideas-Inventions-New Products (2010 iENA) that opened on Oct. 27.

Yeh's 11-year-old sister, Yeh Yi-you, was also present at the world's oldest annual invention show and displayed a foldable and energy-saving lamp that can also be used as a battery charger for cell phones.
She designed the device to help people get through power blockouts, a common occurrence in Taiwan when typhoons strike the country, she said.

The pair's teacher, Hsieh Wen-chan, praised the young inventors for their fertile imaginations. He said he helped the students by offering opinions on how to concretize their ideas but gave them the freedom to build things by themselves.
"I can't catch fish for them, but I've showed them how to fish, " he said.

Hsieh told the Central News Agency that invention clubs have mushroomed in elementary, junior high, and high schools around Taiwan in recent years, and that he often traveled to schools with invention classes to guide students in using their creativity.

If Taiwan wants to produce another economic miracle, it should stop serving as a contract manufacturer and begin moving to inspire the creativity of its people, contended Hsieh, a lecturer with the Department of Industrial Design at National United University in Miaoli City in northern Taiwan.
A total of 800 inventions from 37 countries, including 98 from Taiwan, are competing for prizes at the 2010 iENA.
The award presentation is scheduled for Saturday evening, German time.
Taiwan was the biggest winner of the 2009 invention contest, taking 26 gold medals, 26 silver medals and 15 bronze medals, plus the coveted team championship.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 minor earthquakes hit northeastern, eastern Taiwan in 8 hours
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/30/10 19:47:34 (By Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A series of 15 earthquakes, including two with magnitudes above 4.0, hit northeastern and eastern Taiwan over an eight-hour period starting late Friday but did not cause any casualties, the Central Weather Bureau reported Saturday.
The bureau advised local residents not to panic over the tremors because the series of small-scale earthquakes did not imply that a stronger earthquake was imminent.

But Kuo Kai-wen, director of the bureau's Seismology Center, said residents in hilly areas of Yilan County needed to exercise extra caution because the earthquakes may have left the region even more vulnerable to mudslides after the onslaught of heavy rainfall last week.

The series of earthquakes that hit between 10: 34 p.m. Friday and 6: 21 a.m. Saturday was centered in areas adjacent to Yilan's Nan-ao Township and Hualien County's Hsiulin Township in eastern Taiwan, Kuo said.
The epicenters of all of the quakes were close to each other, he added.
According to the Seismology Center's records, nine of the earthquakes in the series struck between 11 p.m. and midnight.
The strongest one, a magnitude 4.4 earthquake, hit at 11:27 p.m. at a depth of 21.6 kilometers and was entered 19.4 kilometers south of the Nan-ao seismic observation center.
The tremor reached an intensity of 5 at scenic Taroko Gorge in Hualien County, but lasted for only about 0.3 seconds, the Seismology Center said.
A magnitude 4.2 earthquake also jolted northeastern Taiwan at 11:30 p.m. in roughly the same location, according to the center.
With the Nan-ao-Hsiulin area located where the Eurasian and Philippine Sea tetonic plates converge, series of earthquakes often occur in the region, the center added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Extra-inning loss keeps Taiwan out of Intercontinental Cup final

TEXT.P: Taiwan lost to the Netherlands 5-3 in 10 innings Saturday, missing an opportunity to vie for gold in the 2010 Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament in central Taiwan's Taichung City.
Mariekson Gregorius' two-run walk-off home run off Taiwanese closer Lo Chin-lung in the bottom of the 10th inning clinched victory for the Dutch and sent them to the title game Sunday against Cuba.
Both Taiwan and the Netherlands tied for second in the six-team semifinal group with 3-2 records, but the Dutch won the tiebreaker because of their victory over Taiwan head-to-head.
Taiwan will play for third place against Italy on Sunday.

Lin Chih-sheng's RBI single helped Taiwan pull ahead 3-2 in the top of the first extra inning, when runners were placed on first and second at the start of the inning based on international rules to help decide games more quickly.

But Taiwan's pitcher and catcher were suddenly out of synch in the bottom of the inning as the Dutch scored the tying run on a wild pitch and a passed ball, before Gregorius finished the host team off.

Taiwan's manager Yeh Chih-hsien said after the game that the players did their best, but he admitted there were problems at the plate and with player chemistry, referring to the wild pitch and passed ball in the bottom of the 10th and a base-running error that prevented Taiwan from scoring more runs in the top of the inning.
Taiwan was limited to six hits for the game while the Netherlands had nine.
Taiwan rallied to tie the score 2-2 in the seventh inning on a Kao Kuo-ching two-run double that chased Dutch starter Diegomar Markwell, who held Taiwan to one hit in the first five innings.
Taiwan's amateur left-handed starter Chen Kuan-yu, 20, yielded only five hits in 5 2/3 innings, but one of those was a home run by Curt Smith in the sixth that increased the Dutch lead to 2-0.
The Netherlands will meet undefeated Cuba in the championship game for the second straight time. Cuba beat the Netherlands for gold in the 2006 Intercontinental Cup, which was also held in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical electronics forum to focus on Chinese demand

TEXT.P: China's demand for medical electronic equipment and devices will be one of the major topics of emphasis at a medical electronics forum that opens on Monday, according to the Industrial Development Bureau, which is organizing the event.

As part of the focus on the issue, one of the speakers at the two-day Medical Electronics and Devices in Taiwan Forum will be Wang Dongsheng, the deputy head of the China Association of Medical Equipment (CAME), who will discuss the impact of China's health care reforms and the opportunities they present for Taiwan.

Those reforms have already increased demand not only for basic medical equipment but also for advanced devices, said Chang Tsz-yin, an analyst with the Taiwan- based Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) 's Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center.

In the past, Europe and the U.S. were the major markets for image-diagnosing products, but demand for such products in the Asia-Pacific region have grown significantly thanks to China's health care initiatives, Chang said.

The analyst contended that Asia will soon become a manufacturing base for the medical electronics industry because a growing number of international companies have set up research and development centers in China and India and will likely procure components in the region.

Aside from discussions on China's market, experts from companies and associations in China, the United States, Japan, Britain, Germany and Taiwan will also talk about the latest market information, management strategies and innovative applications at the forum, which is being organized by the Industrial Development Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: Disadvantaged people need health insurance coverage too: group
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/30/10 21:33:25 (By Chen Ching-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A civic watchdog group called on the government Friday to eliminate a regulation that stops health insurance coverage for those who fail to pay their premiums when it considers its "second-generation" health reform program.

Huang Ching-hsiang, an official with the Taiwan Healthcare Reform Foundation, said the nonprofit organization often received complaints from poorer families over their plight after their national health insurance cards were invalidated because their premiums were overdue.
The insurance cards must be presented at all health care facilities when seeking treatment if patients want to have the cost of their treatment covered by the national health insurance program.

While many low-income households qualified for subsidies under national health insurance guidelines and could maintain use of their cards, others unable to afford the premiums were not so lucky, Huang said.
He described the policy to void cards as violating the right to health care of disadvantaged groups, particularly people living near the poverty line.

Citing Bureau of National Health Insurance estimates, Huang said there could be 600,000 people this year who do not pay their premiums on time, with 230,000 of them having their cards invalidated automatically and the other 370,000 qualifying for subsidies.
Huang urged the government to reconsider the policy when it puts together its second-generation national health insurance program, which is expected to take effect in 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan issues advisory for travelers heading to France, Korea
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/30/10 21:41:18 (By Lee Ming-chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: People intending to visit France should be mindful of their personal safety as the French police have been tipped off to possible terrorist attacks, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Saturday.
The ministry's Bureau of Consular Affairs also advised local citizens to avoid visiting areas near the G-20 Summit venue in Seoul, South Korea when the city hosts the summit on Nov. 11 and Nov. 12.

The bureau said in a statement that France's four-tier national security alert system remains at the highest "red" level, which means the country faces threats of major terrorist attacks and should have disaster-relief and counterattack measures in place.
Thus, those traveling in France or intending to go there soon should be on alert, particularly when taking subways and trains or flying to one's destination, the statement said.
Meanwhile, some South Korean activist groups are preparing to stage protests when the G-20 summit takes place in their capital city, the ministry said.
It urged local citizens to avoid traveling to the meeting venue when visiting the country during the summit period because protest activities could turn ugly or erupt into violence.
The U.S. Department of State issued a travel advisory on Oct. 27 suggesting that American citizens refrain from visiting Seoul during the G-20 summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai donates 'electronic schoolbags' to school-of-hope students
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/30/10 22:06:02 (By Wang Shu-fen, Jeff Chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Twenty-five hundred disadvantaged students living in remote areas in Taiwan have recently received a special gift from the Hon Hai Group -- an "electronic schoolbag" designed to help them acquire digital skills.

They were the first batch of students to be given the "schoolbag" by the "Yonglin School of Hope," founded by the Yonglin Foundation to assist disadvantaged children in strengthening their computer skills and supplement their education outside of the classroom.

Another 1,500 students of the school are expected to get the "schoolbag" -- essentially a portable computer with special functions -- by the end of this year, the foundation said Saturday at a news conference.
The donation is part of the foundation's efforts to reduce the rural-urban digital gap, said foundation chief executive Yuan Ning.

The Yonglin Foundation is a charity organization established by the Hon Hai Group -- the world's largest contract manufacturer of electronic products -- to improve the education of disadvantaged children and promote art and culture in Taiwan.

The electronic device, developed by the Technology Merging Services Business Group under Hon Hai Precision Industry, will make learning more interesting through animations and an interactive learning system and also help students in remote areas gain access to the latest textbooks, the foundation said.
The business group's senior vice president Hsieh Kuang-hou stressed that the electronic schoolbag was created to meet the educational needs of disadvantaged children, not to generate sales.
The Yonglin devices were made to be given away, he said, citing Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Gou's directive that the e-book system was a nonprofit initiative launched to help the disadvantaged.
The Yonglin School of Hope was inaugurated in 2007 to promote remedial education with the help of 10 universities around Taiwan.

In the past four years, 24,000 children around the country have joined Yonglin's after-school programs, and the number of universities cooperating with the program has risen to 18, according to the foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Independent Chinese tourist' plan remains unchanged: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/30/10 22:19:39 (By Charles Kang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's plan to admit Chinese tourists traveling independently rather than with tour groups will not be affected by the recent Suhua Highway tragedy in which a Chinese tourist was confirmed dead and 19 others remain missing, a senior negotiator with China said Saturday.

"The tragedy was an isolated incident that will not affect the plan to open our doors to independent Chinese tourists, " said Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), a quasi-official intermediary body formed to deal with China in the absence of official ties across the Taiwan Strait.

"The two sides will continue negotiating technical details and the program will be put into practice when the time is ripe, " said Kao after observing search operations near a collapsed section of the scenic Suhua Highway.

At present, Chinese nationals can only visit Taiwan for pleasure as part of an organized tour, but the government hopes that relaxing the restriction will provide an additional spark to the country's tourism industry.
Kao said he was visiting the site on behalf of SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung to express his respect and gratitude for the efforts of emergency search personnel.
"We hope they will continue doing their utmost to search for the missing people out of humanitarian considerations," Kao said.

Responding to complaints by some relatives of missing Chinese nationals that Taiwan did not mobilize sufficient manpower and equipment for the search, Kao said rugged terrain and inclement weather hobbled the operation.
"As a matter of fact, a large number of search and rescue professionals, military SWAT team members, warships and Coast Guard vessels have taken part in the operation," Kao said.

Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council Deputy Chairman Kao Chang, who accompanied Kao Koong-lian on the visit to the Suhua Highway, said the Ministry of Justice is studying whether Taiwan's State Compensation Law is applicable to Chinese victims.

Search personnel continued working in the mountains and at sea Saturday, but failed to locate any of those who have remained missing since Oct. 21 when deadly landslides hit the Suhua Highway amid torrential rains brought by Typhoon Megi.
Body parts of three people -- one Chinese and two Taiwanese -- have been recovered, but 23 other people remain unaccounted for.
