DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 31, or the 24th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Martin Luther nails his 95 theses against papal corruption in Rome to the church door in Wittenberg.
1887: Chiang Kai-shek, the late president of the Republic of China, is born at Hsikou in Fenghua County, Chekiang Province.
1916: Gen. Huang Hsin, leader of the revolution that overthrew the Ching dynasty, dies in Shanghai at the age of 43.
1947: The United Nations sets aside Oct. 24 as "United Nations Day."
1952: The China Youth Corps is organized with Chiang Ching-kuo serving as director.
1957: Tsung Dao Lee and Chen Ning Yang share the Nobel Prize for physics for work disproving the law of conservation of parity.
1958: Nobel Prize winning author Boris Pasternak is expelled from the Soviet Writers' Union and faces possible exile for his "Dr. Zhivago."
1966: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Lesotho.
1971: China Television Service, the third commercial TV network in the Republic of China, begins regular programming.
1972: The Southern Cross-Island Highway, which took four-and-a-half years to build at a cost of nearly NT$500 million, is opened to traffic.
1974: People throughout the Republic of China celebrate the 87th birthday of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan addresses leaders gathered to pay tribute to President Chiang Kai-shek on the late leader's 90th birthday, then breaks ground for the Chung Cheng Memorial Hall to honor President Chiang.
1976: Taichung port in west central Taiwan is formally opened.
1978: The Taiwan Area Freeway, with a total length of 377 km, is fully opened to traffic on the 92nd anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang Kai- shek.
1978: The Sino-Saudi Arabian Bridge over the Choshui River in central Taiwan, which was built with low-interest loans from Saudi Arabia, opens to traffic as a part of the newly completed North-South Freeway.
1979: Representatives of retired servicemen meet at the Taipei City Auditorium to mark the first Veterans Day, also marking the 25th anniversary of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen.
1981: Premier Sun Yun-suan receives J.A. Guevara Moran, the minister of agriculture and pasture of the Republic of El Salvador.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old MiG-19 pilot in the Communist Chinese air force who flew to a U.S. military base outside Seoul on Oct. 16, arrives in Taipei.
1983: Taipei's Kuantu Bridge, the first multi-arch steel bridge in East Asia, opens to traffic. The construction of the bridge, 809 meters long, took three years and cost NT$700 million to complete.
1984: Mrs. Indira Gandhi, Indian prime minister, is shot dead while walking in the garden of her home in New Delhi. She was 67.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek presides over and addresses a mass rally at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang.
1996: Former Polish President Lech Walesa visits the Republic of China.
1999: A delegation from the Taiwan Roots Medical Organization leaves for a visit to four African countries to evaluate the possibility of providing medical care to one of them.
2000: Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the opposition Kuomintang says that he is continuing to solicit more support for his proposal to recall President Chen Shui-bian.
2000: A Los Angeles-bound Singapore Airlines Boeing 747-400 jumbo jet crashes while taking off from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing 81 of the 179 aboard, leaving 44 injured and 54 others unhurt.
2001: Participants in a civil nuclear cooperation meeting between the Republic of China and the United States agree to increase exchanges on nuclear power plant safety and to establish formal communication channels regarding the matter.
2001: Former U.S. Secretary of Defense William Cohen, accompanied by a two- member entourage for a three-day visit in the Republic of China, calls on Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao and other high ranking officials.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "If you will practice a benevolent government, then the people will love all above them and will die for their officers."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Songshan-Haneda flights resume after 31 years

TEXT.P: Direct flights between the city airports of Taipei and Tokyo resumed Sunday after a hiatus of 31 years, a major milestone in Taipei's ambition to become part of a golden flight circuit connecting Northeast Asia's major metropolitan areas.

A total of 245 passengers, including incumbent Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin, set off on the inaugural flight from Taipei International Airport (Songshan) to Tokyo International Airport (Haneda) at 7:30 a.m.

"After our inauguration flight to Shanghai's Hongqiao Airport on June 14, I believe Taipei City is ready to 'take off,'" Hau said at a ceremony at the Taipei airport before the EVA Airways Airbus 330 departed.

Hau said he believed the resumption of Songshan-Haneda flights, one of President Ma Ying-jeou's major policy goals when he served as Taipei City mayor, would transform the Taipei airport into a "capital-city business airport."

The government has positioned the airport as a key link in a "Northeast Asian Golden Flight-route Circuit" of city airports in Taipei, Seoul, Shanghai and Tokyo that reduces travel time on the ground and helps businessmen get more done in less time.
By leaving from the city airport rather than from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, travelers who live in Taipei can save up to 40 minutes in transit time to the airport.

Likewise, landing at Haneda Airport rather than at the more common destination for international flights outside Tokyo, Narita International Airport, can save travelers at least 30 minutes on the commute into Japan's capital.

Taipei International Airport, which was once the country's only international gateway, offered direct flights to Haneda until 1979, when Chiang Kai-shek Airport opened in Taoyuan to handle international flights.
Tseng Mao-pin, a 77-year-old retired umbrella manufacturer who lives in the Taipei suburb of Yonghe, said he used to fly the Songshan-Haneda route on business when he was young.
"I'm excited to go to see my old friends in Japan again this time on the first Songshan-Haneda flight, " Tseng said, explaining why he booked a seat on the groundbreaking flight.
Other travelers, however, said they were confused because they were more familiar with Taoyuan Airport.

Jennifer Chan, who traveled with 43 members of a mountaineering club in Taichung City in central Taiwan, said they left home at 2 a.m. without knowing that their travel agent had arranged for them to take the historic flight.
"I still prefer Taoyuan Airport, not only because we have to spend more time to come to Taipei than to go to Taoyuan" Chan said. "It's really too small here, plus the ceiling is incredibly low."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan excels at Nuremberg invention fair
DOC.DATELINE: Nuremberg, Germany, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/31/10 15:13:48 (By Lin Yu-li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan once again emerged as the top winner at the world's oldest invention show, capturing 27 gold, 32 silver and 23 bronze medals at the 2010 iENA Nuremberg after winning the team championship in 2009.
A total of 800 inventions from 37 countries were on display at the four-day exhibition, known as the International Trade Fair for Ideas-Inventions-New Products, or iENA for short.
Taiwan had the biggest overseas delegation, exhibiting 98 inventions.
Taiwanese students performed particularly well at the show, whose theme this year was "Young, creative, oriented on the future -- Inventing at School."
Yeh Chi-chang, an eight-year-old student at Kaohsiung American School, won a silver medal for his innovative swimming trunks capable of preventing swimmers from being drowned.

Yeh's instructor, Hsieh Wen-chan, a lecturer at Taiwan's National United University, said creativity was primarily developed within one's family and at school, and the earlier interest in inventing was nurtured, the better.
Hsieh also contended that Taiwan, which possesses limited natural resources and faces stiff global competition, would have only a limited economic future if it relied only on OEM production.
"Only through innovation can Taiwan create another economic miracle," he stressed.

Meanwhile, Liu Chih-hsin, a teacher at Catholic Kung Tung Technical Senior High School in Taitung County, eastern Taiwan, who led his students to the venerable Nuremberg show for the first time, said he guides his students to create inventions that have practical applications in everyday life.
The high school won three medals at the exhibition, including a gold medal for a hair dryer capable of vacuuming dust and other particles.

Meanwhile, a technology to remove heavy metals from the fumes and dust discharged by garbage incinerators -- developed by National United University professor Chang Kun-sen -- won a gold medal and an environmental protection award from the International Federation of Inventors' Associations.
A thrilled Chang said his new technology, which has been awarded patents by five countries, could forge a new future for Taiwan in eco-friendly waste management.

DOC.HEADLINE: Surnames earn 12 lucky Japanese free Tokyo-Taipei flights

TEXT.P: Twelve Japanese nationals with the same names as the names of city airports in Taipei and Tokyo were flown for free between the two cities on Sunday to celebrate the resumption of direct flights between the two gateways after a 31-year hiatus.

The promotion, co-sponsored by Taiwan's Tourism Bureau and China Airlines, offered the passengers surnamed "Matsuyama" (or Songshan in Chinese) and "Haneda" free same-day round-trip travel between Haneda Airport in Tokyo and Songshan Airport in Taipei and a day tour in Taiwan's capital city.

The China Airlines flight that left Haneda Airport at 7 a.m. was the first to fly from the Tokyo city airport to the Taipei city airport since 1979, when international flights serving Taiwan were moved to newly opened Chiang Kai-shek Airport (now called Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport).
Keiko Matsuyama, a 37-year-old businesswoman, said she felt "amazed" to learn that her last name had the same characters as the Taipei airport, and she was eager to enjoy her day in the city.
"I am looking forward to having a massage and some hsiaolungpao (steamed dumplings)," she said.

Matsuyama also praised the Taipei airport -- now formally known as Taipei International Airport -- for its advantageous downtown location and quick service compared to Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, saying it took only five minutes for her luggage to be delivered.
Matsuyama and her fellow lucky travelers were scheduled to return to Tokyo on a flight departing from Songshan Airport at 6: 15 p.m. Sunday evening.
Another 24 Tokyo metropolitan councilors were also on the China Airlines flight from Haneda and will visit the Taipei City Council and the Presidential Office during a three-day trip.
The new flight route is expected to stimulate business travel between the two cities by saving travel time on the ground and baggage pick-up time at the airport.

Commutes from downtown areas to the two cities' more common international gateways -- Taoyuan International Airport and Narita International Airport -- take about 30 minutes more than to the city airports.

A total of 56 round-trip flights per week between Songshan and Haneda airports will be offered by four carriers -- China Airlines (CAL) , EVA Airways, Japan Airlines (JAL) and All Nippon Airways (ANA).
They said round-trip fares will be roughly NT$14,000 (US$454) , with stays of up to 30 days allowed.
According to the Tourism Bureau, 780,000 Japanese travelers visited Taiwan between January and September, 19.45 percent more than the same period last year.
During the same period, 1 million Taiwanese travelers visited Taiwan, a 26 percent year-on-year rise.

To promote 2010-2011 Taiwan-Japan tourism exchange year, the authorities concerned said they hope to increase the number of people traveling between the two countries annually from the current 2 million people to 3 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Broadband infrastructure lag could be fatal

TEXT.P: Taiwan's lack of urgency in the development of wireless broadband infrastructure compared to other major Asian economies could lead to a national crisis involving a cultural collapse.

Some have blamed the partially state-owned Chunghwa Telecom for causing Taiwan to lag behind Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea in WiMAX wireless broadband communication development because it charges unreasonably high fees to system operators.
In fact, however, wireless broadband infrastructure development is not simply a function of Chunghwa Telecom's profits. It is a matter of Taiwan's overall digital policy.

Once we lag behind our Asian competitors in the sectors of filmmaking, television, information technology (IT) , e-book, e-commerce, IT security and cloud computing and storage, Taiwan will face a crisis involving the collapse of culture.

The Encyclopedia Britannica, even with its unarguable authority and veracity, has been replaced by Microsoft's online counterpart based on Encarta, a former nobody in the dictionary industry. Microsoft won because its encyclopedia is globally accessible online, free of charge.
Wikipedia's story is even more telling. It proved that "the one who controls digital platform hardware controls the digital content industry."

Taiwan is an IT giant, with a solid academic and industrial foundation. If the country were to fail to grasp the opportunity to accelerate the development of the IT industry -- Taiwan's only advantage -- it would not only fall behind in industrial growth but also risk losing its culture. (Editorial abstract -- Oct. 31, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: New era dawns for Taoyuan international airport

TEXT.P: Taiwan's busiest international airport will open a new era Monday when it becomes a state-run company, a move aimed at enhancing the airport's efficiency and improving an image tarnished by repeated glitches and heavy criticism of its services.

Instilling a "business management spirit" through the airport's corporatization is one of the ways the government hopes to enhance the airport's management and develop the facility's adjacent areas, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said in a statement Saturday.

The airport, which has been a government agency since it opened in 1979, has suffered repeated malfunctions in recent months, including leaky bathrooms, defective jetways, and a breakdown of the automatic baggage handling system.

Chang You-hern, the convener of a government task force aimed at improving the airport's services, has said the government would make the airport one of the world's top 10 airports within three years. It currently ranks 27th in the world.
The ministry will hold a ceremony on Monday to mark the formation of the new company, which it said was the result of a government plan in 2009 to reform the airport.
The government will also invest NT$67 billion (US$2.2 billion) in the construction of a third terminal for the airport, slated to be completed by 2018.
By that time, the airport will serve 75 million passengers per year, with the third terminal able to handle 43 million of them, the ministry projected.

Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Tsao Erh-chang recently expressed skepticism, however, over the ministry's projections, noting that the international airport has handled only 24 million travelers so far this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- KMT, DPP keep to strongholds in elections: polls

TEXT.P: With mayoral elections in five special municipalities fast approaching, polls have shown that candidates from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) remain strong in places where they are favored, despite efforts by their opponents to reverse the momentum.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of their latest polls on the Nov. 27 races -- widely seen as a bellwether of the 2012 presidential election:
United Daily News:
The UDN's survey found little change in Taichung municipality (which merges Taichung City and Taichung County) from a similar poll conducted two months ago.

Some 52 percent of respondents still expected incumbent Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, the KMT candidate, to win the election compared with 13 percent who said Hu's DPP rival, Su Jia-chyuan, would win. The remaining 35 percent said they could not predict the outcome.

If the election were held tomorrow, Hu would get 49 percent of the vote, compared with Su's 31 percent, with 20 percent still undecided. The survey showed that support for both had risen, as the ratio of undecided voters had fallen to 20 percent from 32 percent in the previous survey.
Further analysis showed that in Taichung City, respondents backed Hu over Su by a 55 percent to 29 percent margin, while in Taichung County, Hu had a 45-32 edge.
In terms of age, Su's popularity among voters over 60 was on par with Hu's, but in all other age groups, Su lagged behind Hu by at least 14 percentage points.
In addition, although both were found to be equally effective in galvanizing voters of their own parties, Hu was favored by independent voters.

The survey also used statistical models to predict who the poll's undecided respondents would back. After including those estimates, the conclusion was that if the election were held tomorrow, Hu would get 56 percent of the vote to Su's 44 percent. (Oct. 31, 2010) China Times:

Hu on Thursday dressed himself as Chilean mining foreman Luis Urzua -- who led his fellow miners to safety after the group was trapped underground for more than two months -- when he drew lots to get his numerical designation as a mayoral candidate.
Four out of the 32 "miners" who accompanied Hu at the event later showed up at Su's campaign activity Friday.
The four said they did not know that they were to campaign for Hu, and that they stumped for Su because they wanted to be "true" to their political stance.

One of the four, identified by his surname Liao, said he is a carpenter and when a labor union official asked if he would like to get NT$600 to campaign for a candidate, he agreed without bothering to check the name of the candidate he was to back.

Hu's camp said three of the four who allegedly supported Su were not the same people who joined Hu on Thursday, and it was still checking the identity of the fourth person. The camp said it wanted to get to the bottom of the "defection" issue to see who was lying.
Su's camp responded by saying that it welcomed the probe by Hu's camp.

Hu said it was normal in a democratic society to support different candidates, and he asked that the four not be given a hard time. He also joked, "if they had really stayed with me for 69 days underground to get to know who I am, I'm confident they would give me their full support."

Su said that if Hu's posing as a foreman was to symbolize leading the city out of all of its difficulties, he wanted to ask if all the problems were not in fact the results of Hu's performance in his nine years as mayor. (Oct. 31, 2010) Liberty Times:

A survey showed that if voters were to go to polls tomorrow, incumbent Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu of the DPP would get 43.27 percent support, compared with 18.52 percent for incumbent Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing and 7.8 percent for KMT candidate Huang Chao-hsun.
But it is noteworthy that 30.41 percent have yet to express their opinion.

In view of the past two Kaohsiung mayoral and magistrate elections in which pro- KMT pan-blue candidates received over 40 percent of the votes, the poll presumed that the undecided voters would favor the KMT, meaning the support rate for the candidates trailing in the poll should be higher than the figures shown.
Chen's camp said that although the mayor leads her rivals by big margins, she will not let down her guard.
Huang's camp said that Huang truly wants to serve the people, a point that the voters will show they recognize on Election Day.

Yang's camp believed the Kaohsiung election would end up as a two-horse race between Chen and him. It said that with up to 30 percent of voters undecided, more than half of the electorate could oppose Chen. (Oct. 31, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Workers protest JAL layoffs as Taipei-Tokyo route launched

TEXT.P: On a day when flights between the city airports of Taipei and Tokyo resumed after a 31-year hiatus, around 50 aviation union workers gathered outside the Taipei airport to protest what they called the illegal dismissal of 70 workers by Japan Airlines (JAL) in July.

The protesters, holding cardboard signs with slogans such as "Butcher of East Asia" and "Taiwan is no longer a colony of Japan, " accused JAL of being contemptuous of Taiwanese people and the employees' working rights.
"We can't understand why JAL only bullied Taiwanese workers but was afraid to lay off staff in China, " said protester Lin Chia-wei. "It's a clear sign that this Japanese company despises Taiwan."

Four protesters even broke through police lines and ran toward visiting Tokyo metropolitan councilors during a welcoming ceremony after the arrival of their historic flight at Taipei International Airport (Songshan Airport) from Tokyo International Airport (Haneda Airport).
The protesters hoped to appeal their case to the councilors, but they were forced away by the police.
The layoffs were part of a plan by JAL to reduce its global work force by a third this year as part of a restructuring plan after filing for bankruptcy in January.

The protesters also expressed anger at the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) for not standing up for them even though Taipei City's Department of Labor ruled the JAL layoffs illegal on Oct. 19, but they did not specify how the layoffs broke Taiwan's labor laws.
"We urge the Japanese government to take this issue seriously for the sake of harmonious bilateral relationships between Taiwan and Japan," said Yang Shao- yung, the chairman of the aviation union.

The protesters, who rallied outside the CLA and Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) earlier this month, said they would continue their campaign until Sunday afternoon, when former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was scheduled to arrive.
Abe, in Taiwan on a two-day trip, is expected to meet with President Ma Ying- jeou.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan finishes fourth in Intercontinental Cup baseball tourney

TEXT.P: Taiwan suffered its second heartbreaking loss in two days Sunday, a 4-3 defeat to Italy, to finish fourth in the 2010 Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament in Taichung

The game was not decided until Taiwan's final at-bat, when, trailing by a run, it loaded the bases with two outs. But Kao Kuo-ching could not bring the tying run home, being thrown out at first after hitting a weak grounder to the pitcher.
On Saturday, Taiwan missed out on playing in the tournament's title game when it lost to the Netherlands 5-3 on a two-run walk-off home run.
Italy, whose third place finish was its best showing ever at the Intercontinental Cup, set the tone early when it took advantage of two errors by the home team and stole a base to jump to a 2-0 lead.
Taiwan added a run in both the first and second inning to tie the game, but Italy answered with timely hits and took a 4-2 lead into the bottom of the seventh inning.
Taiwan cut the deficit to 4-3 in the bottom of the inning, setting up the tense finish.
Taiwan manager Yeh Chih-hsien apologized to Taiwan's baseball fans in a televised post-game interview, saying the team "had let the fans down and didn't get the job done."
He also said Taiwan's 12-6 advantage in the hit column was misleading.
"Our lineup failed to put together consecutive hits. Seven of our 12 hits came from only two batters, the second and fourth batters in our lineup," Yeh lamented.
Taiwan failed to duplicate its third place finish in the previous Intercontinental Cup, when the tournament was also held in Taiwan in 2006.
In other games, Japan beat South Korea 2-1 at Douliou Baseball Stadium in the central city of Douliou, Yunlin County, on Sunday to finish fifth in the 10-team tournament.
Nicaragua, the Czech Republic, Thailand and Hong Kong finished the tournament in the seventh to 10th spots.
Cuba and the Netherlands were playing for the Intercontinental Cup title Sunday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suhua Highway upgrade to begin upon passage of EIA: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 31 (CNA) 10/31/10 19:24:06 (By Andrew Liu, Lu Tai-cheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih promised Hualien County residents on Sunday that the project to upgrade the Suhua Highway -- the county's main road link to Taipei and northern Taiwan -- will start as soon as an environmental impact assessment (EIA) is passed.

Wu said the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) had made NT$500 million (US$16.23 million) available to fund the first year of construction, and he vowed to push the project through even if the funding were insufficient.

He stressed, however, that the plan could only begin after the environmental impact assessment was approved by a panel of specialists, because if he ordered an earlier start, he would be violating the law.

Wu was in Hualien County with a delegation of officials from the MOTC, the Council of Agriculture and the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission to try and stave off a rally by county residents in Taipei planned for Monday to push for an early start to the highway project.

But following the premier's visit, Hualien County Magistrate Fu Kun-chi said the rally would be held as planned, arguing that an able government would not shift responsibility for an infrastructure project to an environmental impact assessment.
"All the governments of other nations make their own decisions on the development of major highways, and EIA panels serve only to tell the governments how should the roads be built," Fu argued.
After visiting Hualien, Wu and his entourage proceeded to Taitung County to address residents' concerns over the lack of road access to their remote county on Taiwan's southeastern coast.

The premier promised Taitung County residents that a project to upgrade the mountainous Southern Link Highway -- Taitung County's main link to western Taiwan connecting Taimali Township in the east and Fonggang Township in the west -- would begin in 2011, one year ahead of schedule.
The highway improvement project is expected to be completed by 2017 at a cost of NT$16.8 billion, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Japanese prime minister visits Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 31 (CNA) 10/31/10 20:00:53 (By Chen Li-ting, Hsieh Chia-chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe flew into Taiwan on Sunday for a two- day visit, taking advantage of the first direct flights between Taipei's Songshan Airport and Tokyo's Haneda Airport since 1979.

Abe, Japan's prime minister between September 2006 and September 2007, said upon his arrival at the Taipei city airport that he was extremely happy that the resumption of Songshan-Haneda flights -- one of the policies he pushed while in power -- had finally been achieved.

When asked about relations among Taiwan, China and Japan, Abe responded briefly that Japan-Taiwan ties have always been very friendly and he hoped that triangular relations would remain amicable and constructive.

After making stops around Taipei during the afternoon, Abe met on Sunday evening with President Ma Ying-jeou, who also pushed for the direct flights between the Taipei and Tokyo city airports while serving as Taipei mayor until late 2006.

Flights between the two airports ended 31 years ago when Taiwan's international flights were moved to the newly opened Chiang Kai-shek International Airport (now known as Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport) in Taoyuan County, about 45 minutes from the city.

Songshan Airport -- now known formally as Taipei International Airport -- then served as a domestic airport, but has been repositioned in recent years as part of a golden flight circuit connecting city airports in Taipei, Tokyo, Seoul, and Shanghai.

Soon after arriving in Taipei, Abe had lunch at the famous dumpling restaurant Din Tai Fung, accompanied by Tadashi Imai, the director of the Interchange Association, Taipei Office, Japan's unofficial embassy in Taiwan.
He then headed to the Martyrs Shrine located in the city's northern suburb of Dazhi for a short visit.

He is scheduled to meet with opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen at 9 a.m. Monday, before attending a cocktail reception at noon jointly hosted by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to celebrate the new direct flights between Taipei and Tokyo.
Some 300 dignitaries and well-wishers from both countries are expected to attend.
After the reception, Abe will be the guest of Foreign Minister Timothy Yang at a luncheon.
He is scheduled to return to Tokyo via a CAL flight scheduled to arrive at Haneda Airport at 9:55 p.m. Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Pavilion ends run in China as Shanghai Expo ends

TEXT.P: A pavilion featuring Taiwan's natural landscape and culture has finished its run in China with the World Expo in Shanghai coming to an end Sunday, but it will reappear in northern Taiwan in 2011.
The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and other members of the management team were to hold a closing ceremony later that same day for the Taiwan Pavilion after 184 days in use.

The Hsinchu City government won a tender in September to buy the pavilion with a bid of nearly NT$500 million, and after it is disassembled and shipped to Taiwan, it will be reassembled in the northern Taiwan city.
It is expected to open to the public on Oct. 10, 2011.

TAITRA Chairman Wang Chih-kang said at an event in Shanghai Friday that the pavilion's management team earned NT$160 million (US$5.2 million) from the sky lantern-shaped pavilion after selling it to the Hsinchu City government,
The money will be used to construct a more advanced exhibition hall in Taiwan, which he said Taiwan needed to remain on a "par" with venues in Shanghai and Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Taiwan, Japan send messages at Shanghai expo

TEXT.P: All of the participants of the Shanghai World Expo, which concludes on Sunday, have used the event to engage in dialogue with the world. Among them, the Taiwanese and Japanese pavilions targeted China as their audience.
Japan has used the crested ibis, a bird once on the verge of extinction that China helped to conserve, as one of the themes of its pavilion.

Japan went out of its way to use the rare species to symbolize its friendly relations with China, but when one considers their recent spat over the Tiaoyutais, a group of islets in the East China Sea, one cannot but feel that the effort was futile.
The Taiwan pavilion, in the shape of a sky lantern, has inadvertently revealed the hearts of Taiwan's people, who are hoping for a wish to come true.

The lyrics of the pavilion's theme song "The Heartbeat of Taiwan" -- "less harm, more applause/less hatred, more us/fewer wars, more simplicity/less coldness, more tenderness" -- best illustrate Taiwan's aspirations for cross-Taiwan Strait relations. (By Lilian Wu)/ls

DOC.HEADLINE: World's longest 'fluorescent' fish displayed at aquarium expo

TEXT.P: The world's longest fluorescent fish, bred by Taiwanese researchers, is being featured in an aquarium exhibition that is introducing Taiwan's research and development efforts in the aquaculture field.

The 2010 Taiwan International Aquarium Expo, being held in Taipei between Oct. 29 and Nov. 1, is showcasing many kinds of fish bred in Taiwan and creative landscapes for aquariums, according to the show's organizer, the Fisheries Agency, which is hoping for a turnout of 100,000 visitors.
The fluorescent fish on display, known as convict cichlids, were bred jointly by Academia Sinica, Taiwan's leading research body, and Jy Lin Trading, a private Taiwanese company.
At 12 centimeters in length, the convict cichlids on display are the longest fluorescent fish in the world, according to the company.
Another of the show's main attractions are the international prize-winning discus fish, a colorful fish genus composed of three different species of freshwater fish native to the Amazon River basin.

Chen Tian-shou, deputy director-general of the Fisheries Agency, said Taiwan's team won 14 medals at the International Discus Championship in Duisburg, Germany early this month, a sign of its prowess in the field.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitung County offers cash incentives to lure tourists

TEXT.P: Hoping to offset the impact of the closure of a major roadway to the area, the Taitung County government said Sunday that it will offer a cash incentive to travel agencies that bring over 1,000 tourists to the county in November.

"The travel agencies will be given an award of NT$30,000 for bringing at least 1,000 visitors who stay one night, have two meals and see three scenic spots in Taitung between Nov. 1-30, " said Taitung County Magistrate Justin Chien-ting Huang, during a meeting in the county with Premier Wu Den-yih.
"The more people they bring, the higher the award they will receive."

Huang and representatives of tourism operators in the county called on the central government to work out concrete plans to minimize the impact of the closure of Suhua Highway on Taitung's tourism sector.

The coastal highway connecting Yilan and Hualien counties on Taiwan's eastern coast north of Taitung represented the fastest way for people from northern Taiwan to get to the southeastern county by car.
The 118-kilometer Suhua Highway collapsed during Typhoon Megi on Oct. 21, and the road is not expected to be opened again to traffic until the middle of November.
Huang said his goal is to draw 300,000 tourists per month to the county, famous for its natural mountain-ocean landscapes, hot springs and aboriginal cultures.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCCU promotes exchanges with U.S. universities

TEXT.P: The College of International Affairs at Taiwan's National Chengchi University (NCCU) has established cooperative relations with three American universities on a recent visit to the U.S.

Teng Chung-chien, the dean of the College, signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to promote academic cooperation and student exchanges with the president of Dalton State College in Georgia, following meetings with universities that took place from Oct. 26 to Oct. 29.

According to Teng, he also agreed with the presidents of Endicott College in Massachusetts and Bucknell University in Pennsylvania to promote exchanges and will complete the signing of MOUs with those schools in the near future.
Speaking to the Central News Agency, Teng said NCCU plans to send students to all three universities on study programs arranged through the exchanges.

The agreements were part of the college's efforts to broaden students' educational horizons by providing links to foreign universities and giving them a chance to study in other environments, Teng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President meets former Japanese prime minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 31 (CNA) 10/31/10 21:28:04 (By Lee Shu-hua and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday he was optimistic about tourism growth after commercial flights flew between Taipei's Songshan Airport and Tokyo's Haneda Airport for the first time in 31 years.

At a meeting with former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who arrived in Taipei on one of the first direct flights between the two city airports, Ma said the resumption of flights was a crucial part of his administration's efforts to seek better relations with Japan over the past two years.
Direct flights will save valuable time for travelers in both cities, "making travel between Taipei and Tokyo and doing some business in one day possible."
He hoped that Taiwan could reach out to 48 Japanese cities or airports through Haneda Airport, adding that Songshan Airport also connects Taiwan proper and its outlying islands.
The number of Taiwanese visitors to Japan grew by 30 percent in the first half of the year, while Japanese tourists to Taiwan grew by 7 percent over the same period, the president said.
"We are optimistic about tourism growth," he added.
Abe served as Japan's prime minister between September 2006 and September 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung-Tokyo flights kick off
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 31 (CNA) 10/31/10 22:06:59 (By Chang Che-fon, Jeffrey Wu and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Flights between Kaohsiung and Tokyo were launched Sunday, giving residents of southern Taiwan the opportunity to fly directly to Japan's capital from an airport much closer to home.
The first flight from Kaohsiung International Airport to Narita International Airport outside of Tokyo Sunday morning, operated by Taiwan's China Airlines, was fully booked.
The carrier will offer a round-trip flight between Kaohsiung and Narita every Sunday, Monday and Thursday.
In the past, residents of southern Taiwan either had to first fly or drive north to the Taipei area or to a third destination before flying on to the Japanese city.
Tokyo became the southern port city's 16th new international destination added since 2009, said Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu.

Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Huang Chao-shun said she hoped that China Airlines could start service from Kaohsiung to Tokyo's city airport, Tokyo International Airport, as it did Sunday from Taipei to Tokyo.

She said launching the route to the Tokyo city airport, known commonly as Haneda airport, would allow Kaohsiung residents to cut down on their travel time to downtown Tokyo even further compared to arriving at Narita.
Chen, Huang, and independent candidate Yang Chiu-hsing, Kaohsiung County' incumbent magistrate, are the main candidates in the Nov. 27 election for mayor of the new Kaohsiung municipality.

Earlier Sunday, another China Airlines flight that left Haneda Airport at 7 a.m. was the first to fly from the Tokyo city airport to Taipei's city airport (known commonly as Songshan Airport) since 1979, when international flights serving Taiwan were moved out of the city to the newly opened Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cuba wins 2010 Intercontinental Cup baseball tourney in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Cuba defeated the Netherlands 4-1 in Taichung on Sunday to win its third straight Intercontinental Cup baseball title and its 11th since the tournament began in 1973.
The Caribbean country showed why it is considered to be one of the best baseball countries in the world, going undefeated in eight games in the tourney.
The win, however, did not come without some drama for the defending champion, which seemed to have little to worry about with a 4-0 lead entering the top of the ninth inning.

The Dutch hitters, who had only produced two hits in eight innings against Cuban starter Miguel Martinez, punished closer Yadier Pedroso with three hits to score their first run and threatened to narrow the gap further by loading the bases.
But right-hander Jonder Martinez finished off the next three batters, striking out two of them, to end the suspense.
Cuba had 10 hits in the game, including a solo home run by Alexeis Bell, to the Netherlands' five.
It was Cuba's second consecutive victory over the Netherlands in the Intercontinental Cup title game. It beat the Netherlands 6-3 in the 2006 championship game, which was also held in Taiwan.
Italy beat host Taiwan 4-3 in the bronze medal game earlier Sunday for its first ever medal finish in the tournament. Japan beat South Korea 2-1 in the fifth place game.
Nicaragua, the Czech Republic, Thailand and Hong Kong took the seventh- to 10th- place spots in the 10-team tournament.
According to the official Web site of the International Baseball Federation (IBAF), the 2010 Intercontinental Cup played in Taiwan may be the final edition of the tournament.
